What is the name of the organism that synthesizes the superantigen known as Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin-1 (TSST-1)?	The organism that synthesizes the superantigen Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin-1 (TSST-1) is Staphylococcus aureus.
What is another name for squamous carcinoma in situ, and what is the term used to refer to this condition?	Squamous carcinoma in situ is also known as Bowen's disease.

How does right-sided colorectal carcinoma usually grow?	Right-sided colorectal carcinoma usually grows as a raised (exophytic) mass.
What are the common symptoms of right-sided colorectal carcinoma?	Right-sided colorectal carcinoma presents with vague pain, weight loss, and iron deficiency anemia.

What is the characteristic appearance of the liver associated with right heart failure?	Right heart failure is associated with a characteristic "nutmeg" appearance of the liver.

What is the mechanism by which Rhinovirus enters host cells?	Rhinovirus is a virus that enters host cells by attaching to ICAM-1.

What is Reye syndrome and what is the relationship between this condition, viral illness, and aspirin use in children?	Reye syndrome is fulminant liver failure and encephalopathy in children with viral illness who take aspirin.
What type of fatty change is characteristic of Reye syndrome?	Reye syndrome is characterized by micro-vesicular fatty change.
What type of cellular injury is characterized by the clumping of nuclear chromatin at an ultrastructural level?	Reversible cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally with clumping of nuclear chromatin.
What type of cellular injury is characterized by membrane blebbing and loss of microvilli at an ultrastructural level?	Reversible cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally by membrane blebbing and loss of microvilli.
What is the only type of insulin that can be administered intravenously (IV)?	Regular insulin is the only insulin that can be administered IV.
What are the characteristic features of Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma?	Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma are bi-nucleate with prominent nucleoi (also known as "owl eyes").
What are the characteristics of Reed-Sternberg cells in relation to their cell type, size, nucleus, and nucleoli appearance?	Reed-Sternberg cells are large B cells with multilobed nuclei and prominent nucleoli, giving them an "owl eye" appearance.
What is the definition of reciprocal translocation in terms of chromosomal rearrangement and the chromosomes involved?	Reciprocal translocation is a type of chromosomal rearrangement that occurs between non-homologous chromosomes.

What is keratoconjunctivitis, and what is the underlying cause of this condition?	Keratoconjunctivitis of the cornea is a complication of HSV-1.
What is Kallmann syndrome, and what are the characteristic features of this condition?	Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a defective migration of GnRH cells and defective formation of the olfactory bulb.
What is Kallmann syndrome, and what are the characteristic defects associated with this condition?	Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a defective migration of GnRH cells and defective formation of the olfactory bulb.
What are K+ sparing diuretics, and in what conditions are they beneficial for treatment?	K+ sparing diuretics are useful in the treatment of primary and secondary hyper-aldosteronism.
What are Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells, and what is their origin in the renal system?	Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole.
What is Juvenile polyposis syndrome, and what is the distinguishing feature of the polyps associated with this condition?	Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by numerous hamartomatous polyps WITHOUT hyperpigmentation.
What is Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome, and what is the genetic basis for this condition?	Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome is due to a mutation in the STAT3 gene.
What type of metabolic acidosis can isotonic saline cause?	Isotonic saline can cause a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
What is the mechanism of action of isoniazid (INH), and what specific component of the bacteria does it target?	Isoniazid (INH) works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid production on Mycobacteria tuberculosis.
What substance can be used to calculate glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and why is it a useful marker for GFR?	Inulin clearance can be used to calculate GFR because it is freely filtered and is not reabsorbed or secreted.
What is the characteristic of gram staining for intracellular bacteria, and which specific intracellular bacteria do not gram stain well?	Intra-cellular bacteria do not gram stain well, including Rickettsia, Chlamydia, and Legionella.
What is the most common cause of intrarenal azotemia, and what are the specific conditions that can lead to it?	Intrarenal azotemia is generally due to acute tubular necrosis or ischemia/toxins.
What is the most common cause of intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and what specific condition is it associated with?	Intraparenchymal hemorrhage most commonly occurs due to rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms, secondary to chronic hypertension.
What is the characteristic of inappropriate absolute polycythemia in terms of O2 saturation?	Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by normal O2 saturation.
What is the location of herniation for indirect inguinal hernias in relation to the inferior epigastric vessels?	Indirect inguinal hernias herniate lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
What is the effect of increased cAMP on bronchoconstriction or bronchodilation?	Increased cAMP causes bronchodilation.
What is the characteristic of O2 saturation in inappropriate absolute polycythemia?	O2 saturation is normal in inappropriate absolute polycythemia.
Who are the individuals at risk of Toxoplasma gondii infection?	Immunocompromised individuals (e.g. HIV) and pregnant individuals are at risk of Toxoplasma gondii infection.
What is the function of IgA protease and what is the result of its action?	IgA protease cleaves IgA and allows for colonization of mucosal surfaces.
What is the end result of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and how is it seen on CT scans?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis eventually results in diffuse fibrosis with end-stage 'honeycomb' lung on CT.
What is another name for idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is also known as pseudotumor cerebri.
What effect can hypo-osmolarity have on potassium levels and what condition can it cause?	Hypo-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia.
What type of arrhythmias can be induced by hypokalemia and how do they appear on an ECG?	Hypo-kalemia induced arrhythmias may present on ECG with U waves at the end of the T wave.
What is the role of hypoxia-inducible factor 1α on renal fibroblasts and what mRNA does it cause synthesis of?	Hypoxia-inducible factor 1α acts on renal fibroblasts to cause synthesis of the mRNA for erythropoietin.
What effect can hyper-osmolarity have on potassium levels and what condition can it cause?	Hyper-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia.
What is the common complication of hyper-coagulable states in women and what is this complication characterized by?	Hyper-coagulable states are often complicated by recurrent pregnancy loss in women.
What are the common genetic mutations that can cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?	Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is commonly due to mutations in β-myosin heavy chain or myosin-binding protein C.
What is the trinucleotide repeat expansion disease that is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?	Friedreich ataxia is the trinucleotide repeat expansion disease that is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
What is the refractive error that is commonly referred to as "far-sightedness"?	Hyperopia is the refractive error that is commonly referred to as "far-sightedness".
What is another name for Hurler syndrome and why is it called by this name?	Hurler syndrome is also known as gargoylism due to the physical appearance of those afflicted by this disease.
What is the characteristic presentation of HSV conjunctivitis and how does it typically manifest?	HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often presents with a vesicular rash.
What is Horner syndrome and what are the three characteristic symptoms that make up its triad?	Horner syndrome is a triad of ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis.
What is Homocystinuria and what are the common physical presentations of this metabolic disorder, including the characteristic lens dislocation?	Homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder that may present with marfanoid habitus, however with lens dislocation that subluxes down and in.
What is Hodgkin lymphoma and what type of cells are involved in the neoplastic proliferation?	Hodgkin lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of Reed-Sternberg cells.
What is the characteristic histological appearance of Hodgkin's lymphoma and what types of cells are found within the affected tissue?	Hodgkin's lymphoma consists of malignant "Reed-Sternberg" cells surrounded by inflammatory cells.
What is the similarity between HIV and HTLV-1 in terms of their classification?	HIV and HTLV-1 are both retroviruses.
What is the target of Histoplasmosis within the body and what is the ultimate outcome of this targeting?	Histoplasmosis targets the reticuloendothelial system, which can lead to dissemination of the infection to the liver and spleen.
In which specific regions of the United States is Histoplasma endemic?	Histoplasma is endemic to the central and midwestern regions of the United States.
What type of cells in the gastric mucosa are responsible for the release of histamine?	Histamine is released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa.
What diagnostic method is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease and what specific finding on this test confirms the diagnosis?	Hirschsprung disease is diagnosed by rectal suction biopsy, and the absence of ganglionic cells on the biopsy confirms the diagnosis.
What is the association between Hirschsprung disease and Down syndrome?	Hirschsprung disease is a congenital megacolon that is associated with Down syndrome.
What frequencies are best heard at the base of the cochlea (basilar membrane)?	High frequencies are best heard at the base of the cochlea (basilar membrane).
What is the cause of Kaposi Sarcoma?	HHV-8 is the cause of Kaposi Sarcoma.
What is the cause of Hers disease?	Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hepatic glycogen phosphorylase.
What is Hers disease also known as in terms of glycogen storage disease?	Hers disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type VI.
What is the cause of multiple small vesicles in the anterior pharynx/lips?	Herpetic gingivostomatitis is the cause of multiple small vesicles in the anterior pharynx/lips.
How is hereditary spherocytosis diagnosed?	Hereditary spherocytosis is diagnosed by the acidified glycerol lysis fragility test in combination with eosin-5-maleimide binding test (flow cytometry).
What is Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia and what symptoms does it cause?	Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is an autosomal dominant disorder resulting in thin-walled blood vessels, especially in the mouth and GI tract.
What is the cause of Henoch-Schonlein purpura?	Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a vasculitis that occurs secondary to IgA immune complex deposition.
What is Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and what are its symptoms?	Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is a systemic overactivation of macrophages and cytotoxic T cells that leads to fever, pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.
What is the association between Hemochromatosis and HLA, and which HLA subtype is commonly associated with Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis is a condition that is associated with HLA A3.
What is HELLP syndrome, and what are the characteristic symptoms of this condition?	HELLP syndrome is a manifestation of severe preeclampsia that presents with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets.
What is hairy leukoplakia, and where does it typically appear in the mouth?	Hairy leukoplakia is a white, rough patch that typically arises on the lateral tongue.
What is Guillain-Barré syndrome, and what type of muscle weakness or paralysis is typically associated with this condition?	Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder that results in symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis.
What are Greenstick fractures and torus fractures, and in what population are these types of fractures commonly seen?	Greenstick fractures and torus fractures are both types of bone fractures, and they are commonly seen in pediatric populations.
What is gout, and what is the cause of this condition that particularly affects the joints?	Gout is a condition that is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in tissues, especially the joints.
What is Goodpasture syndrome, and what immunofluorescence pattern is typically seen in this form of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)?	Goodpasture syndrome is a form of RPGN that presents with a linear pattern on immunofluorescence.
What is gonococcal conjunctivitis, and how can it be prevented in newborns?	Gonococcal conjunctivitis is a type of conjunctivitis that can be prevented with prophylactic topical erythromycin ointment soon after birth.
What substances can cross the blood-brain barrier, and how do they typically cross this barrier?	Glucose and amino acids can cross the blood-brain barrier, and they typically do so slowly via carrier-mediated transport mechanisms.
What structures surround glomerular capillaries, and what is the relationship between these structures and the first portion of the nephron?	Glomerular capillaries are surrounded by Bowman's capsule (space), which is continuous with the first portion of the nephron.
What is glaucoma, and what is its characteristic appearance in terms of optic disc atrophy?	Glaucoma is a condition characterized by optic disc atrophy with characteristic cupping.
What is Glanzmann thrombasthenia, and what is the genetic cause of this qualitative platelet disorder?	Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a qualitative platelet disorder caused by a genetic GPIIb/IIIa deficiency.
What is the first sign of HSV-1 infection, and where does it typically occur?	The first sign of HSV-1 infection is gingivostomatitis of the mouth.
What is giant cell (temporal) arteritis, and which artery branches are classically involved in this granulomatous vasculitis?	Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves branches of the carotid artery.
What is the relationship between Gardnerella vaginalis and the pH level in the vagina?	Gardnerella vaginalis is a bacterial infection that typically occurs when the pH level in the vagina is higher than 4.5.
How does Gardnerella vaginalis affect the pH level in the vagina?	Gardnerella vaginalis is known to change the pH level in the vagina.
How does gabapentin work as an anti-epileptic medication?	Gabapentin exerts its effects as an anti-epileptic medication by blocking voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
What is Francisella tularensis, and how does it affect the lymph nodes of the reticuloendothelial system?	Francisella tularensis is a zoonotic bacteria that forms caseating granulomas within the lymph nodes of the reticuloendothelial system.
What is Francisella tularensis, and what is the characteristic feature of the granulomas it forms?	Francisella tularensis is a zoonotic bacteria that forms caseating granulomas with regional lymphadenopathy.
What is Francisella tularensis, and what is the characteristic feature of the ulcer it forms at the site of infection?	Francisella tularensis is a zoonotic bacteria that forms a painful ulcer with a black base at the site of infection.
What is the genetic basis of Fragile X syndrome?	Fragile X syndrome is due to a trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene.
What is Fondaparinux, and what is its mechanism of action as an anticoagulant?	Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant that acts only on factor Xa.
What is Fomepizole, and for what types of poisoning is it used as an antidote?	Fomepizole is used as an antidote for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning.
What is the genetic basis of Follicular lymphoma?	Follicular lymphoma is driven by a t(14;18) translocation.
What are the clinical features of Follicular lymphoma?	Follicular lymphoma is characterized by painless "waxing and waning" lymphadenopathy.
What are the characteristics of focal seizures with no impairment of awareness?	Focal seizures with no impairment of awareness are characterized by intact consciousness.
What is a common precursor to focal seizures with impairment of awareness?	Focal seizures with impairment of awareness are often preceded by a seizure aura.
What are the characteristics of focal seizures with impairment of awareness?	Focal seizures with impairment of awareness are characterized by impaired consciousness.
What type of nephrotic syndrome is associated with heroin abuse?	Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a type of nephrotic syndrome associated with heroin abuse.
What is the recommended duration of discontinuation of fluoxetine before initiating an MAOI?	Fluoxetine is an SSRI with a relatively long half-life and thus must be discontinued 5 weeks before initiating an MAOI.
What is the process of metabolism of flucytosine (5-FC) in cells?	Flucytosine (5-FC) is metabolized to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) in fungal cells.
What is the target of fidaxomicin, an antimicrobial agent?	Fidaxomicin is an antimicrobial that inhibits the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase.
Which gender is more prone to femoral hernias?	Femoral hernias are more common in females.
What are the three main clinical features of Felty syndrome?	Felty syndrome classically presents with a triad of rheumatoid arthritis plus splenomegaly and neutropenia.
What is the association between fatty casts ("oval fat bodies") and the "Maltese cross" sign?	Fatty casts ("oval fat bodies") are often associated with the Maltese cross" sign.
What is the role of farnesyl PPi, an intermediate of cholesterol synthesis?	Farnesyl PPi is an intermediate of cholesterol synthesis that is important for synthesis of coenzyme Q (ETC).
What are the clinical features associated with Fanconi anemia?	Fanconi anemia is associated with short stature, café au lait spots, and malformed forearms and/or thumbs.
What is the cause of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH)?	Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is caused by inactivating mutations of the Ca2+-sensing receptors that regulate PTH secretion.
What is the pathology behind familial amyloid cardiomyopathy / polyneuropathies?	Familial amyloid cardiomyopathy / polyneuropathies are characterized by deposition of mutated transthyretin (TTR) protein in the heart and nerves.
What is the pathology behind familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?	Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by 100s to 1000s of adenomatous colonic polyps.
What induces the expression of E-selectin?	E-selectin expression is induced by IL-1 and TNF.
What is the characteristic feature of protein content in exudative pleural effusion?	Exudative pleural effusion is characterized by high protein content.
What causes exudative pleural effusion?	Exudative pleural effusion is caused by states of increased vascular permeability (e.g. malignancy, pneumonia, trauma, collagen vascular disease).
What methods can be used to measure extracellular fluid volume?	Extracellular fluid volume can be measured using inulin or mannitol.
What is the exotoxin of Pseudomonas aeruginosa?	Exotoxin A is the exotoxin of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
What effect does exercise have on the expression of the GLUT 4 receptor, and in which tissue does this occur?	Exercise may increase the expression of the GLUT 4 receptor in muscle tissue, only.
What bone tumor is associated with t(11;22) translocation?	Ewing sarcoma is a bone tumor that is associated with t(11;22) translocation.
What bone tumor is associated with a characteristic "onion-skin" appearance on X-ray?	Ewing sarcoma is a bone tumor associated with a characteristic "onion-skin" appearance on X-ray.
What is the first line treatment for absence seizures?	Ethosuximide is the first line treatment for absence seizures.
What organic solvents can disrupt the envelope of a virus, resulting in loss of infectivity?	Ether and other organic solvents can disrupt the envelope of a virus, resulting in loss of infectivity.
What is the mechanism of action of Ethambutol in inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis?	Ethambutol blocks the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, inhibiting carbohydrate polymerization at the bacterial cell wall.
What is the function of Etanercept as a decoy soluble receptor?	Etanercept is a decoy soluble receptor that binds TNF-a.
What is the cause of esophageal varices?	Esophageal varices result from portosystemic shunting between the left gastric (portal) and esophageal branch of the azygos (systemic) veins.
What is the treatment for neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis?	Erythromycin drops can be used to treat neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis.
How does Erythromycin affect gastrointestinal motility and what is the consequence?	Erythromycin can bind GI motilin receptors, increasing GI motility and causing diarrhea.
What is the most common infection associated with erythema multiforme, a blistering skin disorder?	Erythema multiforme is a blistering skin disorder most commonly associated with HSV infection.
What type of inhibitor is Erlotinib, and what is its target?	Erlotinib works as an EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
What is epidural hematoma, and what is a common presentation of this condition?	Epidural hematoma often presents with a loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval for up to 48 hours.
What is the cause of epidural hematoma, and which artery is typically involved in its rupture?	Epidural hematoma is due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of maxillary artery).
What are ependymomas, and what is their characteristic histological feature?	Ependymomas are CNS tumors characterized histologically by perivascular pseudorosettes.
What are the clinical features of eosinophilic esophagitis, particularly in terms of esophageal appearance on endoscopy?	Eosinophilic esophagitis presents with esophageal rings and linear furrows, often seen on endoscopy.
What are the envelope proteins of coronavirus?	Envelope proteins of coronavirus include M, E, and S.
What is enterotoxin, where is it found, and what type of food poisoning does it cause?	Enterotoxin is a pre-formed heat stable exotoxin found in Staphylococcus aureus that causes food poisoning from eating meat, cream-based foods.
Which type of E. coli is transmitted by water sources?	Enterotoxigenic E. coli is transmitted by water sources.
What are the toxins associated with enterotoxigenic E. coli?	Enterotoxigenic E. coli is associated with the toxins heat labile toxin (LT) and heat stable toxin (ST).
What are the typical symptoms of enteropathogenic E. coli infection and who is most commonly affected?	Enteropathogenic E. coli usually presents as diarrhea in children.
What is the effect of enteropathogenic E. coli on the intestinal microvilli and what condition can it lead to?	Enteropathogenic E. coli destroys intestinal microvilli resulting in malabsorption.
How is enterohemorrhagic E. coli typically transmitted and through what type of food?	Enterohemorrhagic E. coli is transmitted by eating undercooked beef.
What serotype is associated with enterohemorrhagic E. coli?	Enterohemorrhagic E. coli is associated with the O157:H7 serotype.
What mechanism do Enterococcus spp. (VRE) use to confer resistance to Vancomycin, and what changes occur in the peptidoglycan structure?	Enterococcus spp. (VRE) can alter its peptidoglycan to D-ala-D-lac, conferring resistance to Vancomycin.
What is the mechanism of action of entacapone, and for what purpose is it used in conjunction with levodopa?	Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa.
What is the type of ischemic stroke that results in a hemorrhagic (red) infarct at the periphery of the cortex?	Embolic ischemic strokes result in a hemorrhagic (red) infarct at the periphery of the cortex.
What are the conditions associated with elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)?	Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is associated with neural tube defects, abdominal wall defects, and multiple gestation.
What is the alternative name for EDTA?	EDTA is also known as calcium disodium edetate.
What is the name of the helminth that can form 'hydatid cysts' in the liver, lungs or brain?	Echinococcus granulosus is a helminth that can form 'hydatid cysts' in the liver, lungs or brain.
What type of ulcers present with epigastric pain that improves with meals?	Duodenal ulcers present with epigastric pain that improves with meals.
How are duodenal ulcers diagnosed and what is the characteristic feature seen in endoscopic biopsy?	Duodenal ulcers are diagnosed via endoscopic biopsy, which shows an ulcer with hypertrophy of Brunner glands.
What type of atresia is associated with Down syndrome?	Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome.
What is the characteristic feature seen on X-ray in a patient with duodenal atresia and how is it characterized?	Duodenal atresia is characterized by dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum with a "double bubble" sign on X-ray.
What is duloxetine and for what condition is it indicated for treatment?	Duloxetine is an SNRI that is indicated for the treatment of fibromyalgia.
What is the classic presentation of Duchenne muscular dystrophy and what is the characteristic feature seen in the calf muscles?	Duchenne muscular dystrophy classically presents with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles.
What type of macular degeneration is associated with a gradual decrease in vision?	Dry (nonexudative) macular degeneration is associated with gradual decrease in vision.
What is the karyotype that characterizes Double Y males?	Double Y males are characterized by a 47 XYY karyotype.
What does DNA polymerase require to bind and what is the nature of this molecule in relation to the polymerase?	DNA polymerase must see a RNA primer to bind, which is complementary and antiparallel to the polymerase.
What type of degeneration occurs distal to a site of CNS or PNS axon injury?	Anterograde (Wallerian) degeneration occurs distal to a site of CNS or PNS axon injury.
What type of renal tubular acidosis is caused by a defect in the ability of α-intercalated cells to secrete H+?	Distal renal tubular acidosis is caused by a defect in the ability of α-intercalated cells to secrete H+.
What is the characteristic urine pH in distal renal tubular acidosis?	Distal renal tubular acidosis is characterized by a urine pH > 5.5.
What is another name for type 1 RTA?	Distal renal tubular acidosis is another name for type 1 RTA.
In relation to the inferior epigastric vessels, where do direct inguinal hernias herniate?	Direct inguinal hernias herniate medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.
What is the helminth that can result in megaloblastic anemia due to B12 (cobalamin) deficiency?	Diphyllobothrium latum is the helminth that can result in megaloblastic anemia due to B12 (cobalamin) deficiency.
Which type of calcium channels do dihydropyridine CCBs primarily block, and in which type of muscle?	Dihydropyridine CCBs primarily block L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle.
Why are dihydropyridine CCBs useful for treating angina?	Dihydropyridine CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to cause coronary vasodilation.
What is the best diagnostic test for acute limb ischemia?	Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is the best test to diagnose acute limb ischemia.
What is DiGeorge Syndrome and what does it result in?	DiGeorge Syndrome is a defective development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, which leads to hypoplastic thymus and parathyroids.
What is diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis characterized by on light microscopy?	Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is characterized by "wire looping" of capillaries on light microscopy.
What is diffuse cortical necrosis and with what conditions is it associated?	Diffuse cortical necrosis is a renal pathology associated with obstetric catastrophes and septic shock.
What is dialysis-associated amyloidosis and what does it result in?	Dialysis-associated amyloidosis is characterized by deposition of β2-microglobulin in joints.
How does dextromethorphan work as an anti-tussive and which receptor does it antagonize?	Dextromethorphan works as an anti-tussive by antagonizing the NMDA glutamate receptor.
What is dexamethasone and how does it work in the body?	Dexamethasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid that mimics the actions of cortisol, including suppression of ACTH.
What are descending colon varices and how do they develop?	Descending colon varices develop from portosystemic shunting between the left colic vein (portal) and retroperitoneal (of Retzius) (systemic) veins.
What is dermatomyositis and what are its characteristic features on biopsy?	Dermatomyositis is a condition characterized by peri-mysial inflammation with perifascicular atrophy on biopsy.
What is the association between dermatomyositis and malignancy?	Dermatomyositis is associated with an increased risk for occult malignancy.
What is the characteristic skin manifestation that may be present in dermatomyositis?	Dermatomyositis may present with Gottron papules, which are red papules located on the elbows, knuckles, and knees.
What is the specific type of rash that may be present in dermatomyositis and where is it located?	Dermatomyositis may present with a "heliotrope" rash, which is an erythematous periorbital rash.
What is the characteristic change in norepinephrine levels seen in individuals with depression?	Depression is characterized by decreased levels of norepinephrine.
What is the characteristic change in dopamine levels seen in individuals with depression?	Depression is characterized by decreased levels of dopamine.
What is the specific name given to dendritic cells in the skin?	Dendritic cells in the skin are called Langerhans cells.
What is the typical pattern seen on EEG in individuals with dementia?	Dementia is typically associated with a normal pattern on EEG.
What is the typical pattern seen on EEG in individuals with delirium?	Delirium is typically associated with a diffuse, slowing pattern on EEG.
After how many hours of alcohol withdrawal does delirium tremens typically occur?	Delirium tremens, which can occur as a result of alcohol withdrawal, typically occurs after 48-96 hours.
Why can't daptomycin be used to treat pneumonia?	Daptomycin cannot be used to treat pneumonia because it is inactivated by alveolar surfactant.
What are the typical findings in Dandy-Walker malformation?	Dandy-Walker malformation typically presents as a massively dilated 4th ventricle and an absent cerebellum.
What is the underlying defect in Dandy-Walker malformation?	Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital failure of the cerebellar vermis to develop.
What is cystitis?	Cystitis is an infection or inflammation of the bladder.
What is the characteristic shape of urine crystals in cystine kidney stones?	Cystine kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals that are hexagonal in shape.
How does cyanide inhibit the electron transport chain (ETC)?	Cyanide may inhibit the ETC by binding Fe3+ and preventing transfer of electrons to O2 in complex IV.
What type of stain can be used to visualize Cryptosporidium oocysts?	Cryptosporidium oocysts can be visualized with an Acid-Fast (Ziehl-Neelsen) stain.
What is the macrolide antibiotic that can be used to treat Cryptosporidium?	Cryptosporidium can be treated with the macrolide antibiotic spiramycin.
What is the most common cause of fungal meningitis?	Cryptococcus is the most common cause of fungal meningitis.
Where is Cryptococcus mainly found?	Cryptococcus is found mainly in pigeon droppings and soil.
What antibodies may be present in the serum of patients with Crohn disease?	Crohn disease (IBD) may be associated with positive serum anti-Saccharomyces cervisiae antibodies (ASCA).
What type of T cells are involved in the pathogenesis of Crohn disease?	Crohn disease (IBD) is T 1 mediated.
What is the histological characteristic of Crohn disease?	Crohn disease (IBD) is characterized histologically by lymphoid aggregates with noncaseating granulomas.
What is the characteristic lesion of Crohn disease and where can it occur in the gastrointestinal tract?	Crohn disease (IBD) is characterized by skip lesions, which can occur anywhere from the mouth to the anus.
What is the "string" sign on imaging and with which condition is it associated?	The "string" sign on imaging is associated with Crohn disease (IBD), secondary to strictures.
What is the gross appearance of the mucosa in Crohn disease?	Crohn disease (IBD) appears grossly with cobblestone mucosa.
What is the characteristic finding on EEG in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?	Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG.
What is the protein that is increased in the CSF of patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?	Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with increased 14-3-3 protein in CSF.
What is the origin of the epithelial remnants that give rise to craniopharyngioma, a CNS tumor?	Craniopharyngioma is a CNS tumor that arises from epithelial remnants of Rathke's pouch (oral ectoderm).
What virus can cause myocarditis that progresses to dilated cardiomyopathy?	Coxsackie B is a virus that causes myocarditis which progresses to dilated cardiomyopathy.
What disease is caused by Coxsackie B virus?	Coxsackie B is a virus that causes Bornholm's disease.
What disease is caused by Coxsackie A virus?	Coxsackie A is a virus that causes hand-foot-and-mouth disease.
What bacterium is responsible for causing Q fever?	Coxiella burnetti is the bacterium that causes Q fever.
What is Coxiella burnetti and where is it commonly found?	Coxiella burnetti is an obligate intracellular bug that forms spores in animal feces.
What is the characteristic feature of Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection in the posterior pharynx and upper airways?	Corynebacterium diphtheriae will produce a gray pseudomembrane on the posterior pharynx and upper airways.
What is the significance of a positive Elek's test in the diagnosis of a bacterial infection?	Corynebacterium diphtheriae will have a positive Elek's test for toxin.
What is the characteristic presentation of a Corynebacterium diphtheria infection in the posterior pharynx and upper airways?	Corynebacterium diphtheria will produce a gray pseudomembrane on the posterior pharynx and upper airways.
What are the potential consequences of a coronavirus infection in the respiratory system?	Coronavirus is a virus that can cause acute bronchitis, eventually leading to ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome).
What are the structural features of a coronavirus?	Coronavirus is a positive RNA virus with a helical shaped capsid.
What is coronary steal syndrome and how does it occur?	Coronary steal syndrome occurs when administration of vasodilators shunts blood towards well-perfused areas, increasing ischemia in post stenotic regions.
What is the cause of Cori disease, and what enzyme is deficient in individuals with this condition?	Cori disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase & 4-α-d-glucanotransferase).
What is another name for Cori disease, and how is it classified in the category of glycogen storage diseases?	Cori disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type III.
What is the medical term for isolated right heart failure that is caused by a pulmonary condition?	Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure due to pulmonary cause.
In which region of the United States is Coccidioidomycosis commonly found?	Coccidioidomycosis is commonly found in the Southwestern United States.
What is the characteristic mold form of Coccidioidomycosis, and what shape are the arthroconidia contained within it?	The characteristic mold form of Coccidioidomycosis contains barrel-shaped arthroconidia.
What is another name for Coal workers' pneumoconiosis, a disease caused by long-term exposure to coal dust?	Coal workers' pneumoconiosis is also known as black lung disease.
What type of virus is CMV, and what does it bind to on the surface of cells?	CMV is a virus that binds to cellular integrins, specifically heparan sulfate.
Which gender is more commonly affected by cluster headaches?	Cluster headaches are more common in males.

What is DiGeorge syndrome and what is the pathophysiology behind the condition?	DiGeorge syndrome involves the failed development of the thymus resulting in very low T cell maturation.
What is diffuse scleroderma and what are its characteristic features?	Diffuse scleroderma is a type of scleroderma characterized by widespread skin involvement with early visceral involvement.

What is Winter's formula for simple metabolic acidosis and what does it state?	Winter's formula for simple metabolic acidosis states that PCO2 = 1.5[HCO3-] + 8 +/- 2.

At what age does Wilson disease typically present?	Wilson disease typically presents before age 40.
What is a common presentation of Wilson disease, and what is the cause of this presentation?	Wilson disease often presents with cirrhosis, which is caused by copper accumulation in the liver.
What type of renal disease may present in individuals with Wilson disease?	Individuals with Wilson disease may present with renal disease, such as Fanconi syndrome.
What is a potential consequence of excess circulating copper in individuals with Wilson disease?	Excess circulating copper in individuals with Wilson disease may cause hemolytic anemia.
What is a characteristic feature of urinary copper in individuals with Wilson disease?	Urinary copper is increased in individuals with Wilson disease, which is a characteristic feature of the condition.
What are the characteristic features of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper in individuals with Wilson disease?	Individuals with Wilson disease typically have decreased serum ceruloplasmin and increased urinary copper, which are characteristic features of the condition.
What is a characteristic feature of serum ceruloplasmin in individuals with Wilson disease?	Individuals with Wilson disease typically have decreased serum ceruloplasmin, which is a characteristic feature of the condition.
Where is copper accumulation most commonly observed in individuals with Wilson disease?	Copper accumulation is most commonly observed in the liver, brain, cornea, and kidneys in individuals with Wilson disease.
By what other name is Wilson disease known?	Wilson disease is also known as hepatolenticular degeneration.
What are the typical clinical presentations of Wilms tumor?	Wilms tumor typically presents as a large, unilateral flank mass and/or hematuria.

What is the reason for thrombocytopenia in splenic sequestration crisis during acute severe anemia in sickle cell disease?	Thrombocytopenia occurs because platelets are trapped in the spleen during a splenic sequestration crisis.
What is the reason for the absence of secondary sex characteristics in congenital GnRH deficiency?	The absence of secondary sex characteristics in congenital GnRH deficiency is due to a total lack of estrogen.

What is the reason for much more T4 being produced compared to T3?	Much more T4 is produced compared to T3 because the coupling reaction for T4 is much faster.
What is the reason for giving lidocaine with epi?	Lidocaine is given with epi because vasoconstriction leads to prevent systemic absorption.
What is the reason for HPV cotesting not being recommended for ages 21-29?	HPV cotesting is not recommended for ages 21-29 because most HPV infections spontaneously clear in these patients.
What is the reason for giving heparin after an extremity injury?	Heparin is given after an extremity injury to prevent low thrombosis.
What is the reason for Rickettsia spp. not gram staining well?	Rickettsia spp. do not gram stain well because they are obligate intracellular bacteria.
What is the reason for PCOS increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer?	PCOS increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer due to exposure to estrogen only, without progesterone.
What is the reason for normocytic anemia occurring in a patient with CKD?	Normocytic anemia occurs in a patient with CKD due to decreased production of erythropoietin (EPO) by renal peritubular cells.
What is the reason for lactation not occurring during pregnancy, despite increasing prolactin levels?	Lactation does not occur during pregnancy due to downregulation of prolactin receptors on the breast by progesterone and estrogen.
What is the reason for hemochromatosis having a slower progression in women?	Hemochromatosis has a slower progression in women due to iron loss through menstruation.
What is the reason for HCV displaying antigenic variation due to a lack of proofreading ability?	HCV lacks 3'-5' exonuclease, which leads to a lack of proofreading ability and thus displays antigenic variation.
What is the reason for splenomegaly resulting from extravascular hemolysis?	Splenomegaly results from extravascular hemolysis due to hyperplasia of splenic macrophages, also known as red pulp hyperplasia.
What is the reason for the increased risk of infection in patients with multiple myeloma?	Patients with multiple myeloma have an increased risk of infection due to hypogammaglobulinemia.
What is the reason for breast development in patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS)?	Patients with AIS have breast development because the increased testosterone in their bodies is aromatized to estrogen.
What is the reason for the increased risk of physiologic jaundice in Asians?	Asians have an increased risk of physiologic jaundice due to decreased UGT (uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase) activity.
What was the reason for the can crusher quitting his job?	The can crusher quit his job because it was "soda pressing".
What is the reason for NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors causing edema?	NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors can cause edema due to their potential to impair renal function.
What is the reason for the initial menstrual cycles in adolescents being irregular and anovulatory?	The initial menstrual cycles in adolescents can be irregular and anovulatory due to the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.
What is the reason for NSAIDs being contraindicated in heart failure?	NSAIDs are contraindicated in heart failure due to their potential to decrease renal perfusion.
What is the reason for hypotonic saline solutions rarely being used by themselves?	Hypotonic saline solutions are rarely used by themselves because they can cause red blood cell (RBC) lysis.

What is the overall effect of thyroid hormone on protein metabolism, even though it increases both protein synthesis and degradation?	While thyroid hormone increases both protein synthesis and degradation, the overall effect of thyroid hormone is catabolic.
What is the difference between the clonality of neoplasia and hyperplasia?	While neoplasia is monoclonal, hyperplasia is polyclonal.
What is the difference between the kinetics of most enzymatic reactions and allosteric kinetics?	While most enzymatic reactions follow a hyperbolic curve (Michaelis-Menten kinetics), allosteric kinetics follow a sigmoidal curve.
What is the most common cause of death in lightning injuries, despite their rarity?	While lightning injuries are rare, the most common cause of death is an arrhythmia.
What is the difference between the binding sites of DNA polymerase and RNA polymerase?	While DNA polymerase binds to a primer, RNA polymerase binds to a promoter.
What are some of the rare symptoms that may present in Chronic lymphocytic leukemia, despite it being typically asymptomatic?	While Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is typically asymptomatic, it infrequently presents with B-symptoms and mucocutaneous bleeding.
What is the difference between the spread of carcinomas and sarcomas?	While carcinomas typically spread lymphatically, sarcomas spread hematogenously.
What happens to proinsulin during the process of being packed into secretory granules?	While being packed into secretory granules, proteases cleave the connecting peptide of proinsulin, yielding insulin.

Among the three zones of the liver, which one is affected by Yellow Fever?	Zone II or the intermediate zone of the liver is affected by Yellow Fever.

What type of vulvar cancer presents with symptoms of redness and itching?	Paget's disease of the vulva.
Which vitamins belong to the fat-soluble group?	Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fat-soluble vitamins.
Which vitamin supplement should be avoided during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects?	Vitamin A, particularly isotretinoin, should be avoided during pregnancy due to its potential to cause birth defects.
Which vitamin deficiencies can increase the risk of thrombosis?	Deficiencies in vitamin B12 and B9 (folate) have been associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
Which group of viruses have a characteristic "grainy" or "sand-like" appearance on electron microscopy?	Arenaviruses are known for their distinctive "grainy" appearance on electron microscopy.
Which virus replicates in the ileal Peyer's patches and oropharyngeal tonsils?	The poliovirus is known to replicate in the ileal Peyer's patches and oropharyngeal tonsils.
Which virus remains dormant or latent in the dorsal root ganglia (DRG)?	Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is known to remain latent in the dorsal root ganglia.
Which virus is known to produce Warthin-Finkeldey cells as a result of its surface fusion (F) proteins?	Measles virus (rubeola virus) is known to produce Warthin-Finkeldey cells due to its surface fusion (F) proteins.
Unlike most viruses, which virus is capable of making its own envelope?	The poxvirus is unique in that it is capable of producing its own envelope, unlike most other viruses.
What is the name of the largest DNA virus known to date?	The poxvirus is currently recognized as the largest DNA virus.
Which virus is specifically associated with the mixed cellularity and lymphocyte-depleted subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma?	The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is strongly linked to the development of mixed cellularity and lymphocyte-depleted subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Which virus is commonly described as having a wheel-like or circular shape?	The rotavirus is often referred to as being wheel-shaped due to its characteristic appearance.
Which virus is commonly described as being 'bullet-shaped'?	The rabies virus, which belongs to the rhabdovirus family, is often referred to as having a bullet-like shape.
What virus is commonly associated with causing outbreaks on cruise ships?	The norovirus, also known as the norwalk virus, is frequently linked to outbreaks of illness on cruise ships.
What virus is commonly referred to as German measles or 3-day measles?	The rubella virus is also known as German measles or 3-day measles.
What virus is considered to be a risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma?	The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is known to be a risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma.
What virus is responsible for causing slapped-cheek fever?	The parvovirus B19 is the virus that causes slapped-cheek fever, also known as fifth disease.
What virus is responsible for causing SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)?	The coronavirus is the virus that causes SARS.
What virus is responsible for causing Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS)?	The coronavirus is the virus that causes MERS.
What virus is responsible for causing Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome (HFRS)?	The hantavirus (sin nombre) is the virus that causes HFRS.
What virus is responsible for causing erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease?	The parvovirus B19 is the virus that causes erythema infectiosum.
What virus is responsible for causing croup, a respiratory illness characterized by a barking cough?	The parainfluenza virus is the virus that causes croup.
What virus is responsible for causing cardiopulmonary syndrome (HCPS), a severe respiratory illness?	The hantavirus (sin nombre) is the virus that causes HCPS.
What virus, commonly transmitted by bats and raccoons, causes symptoms such as dysphagia, muscle spasms, and coma?	The rabies virus (rhabdovirus) is the virus that commonly causes these symptoms.
What virus can cause symptoms such as swollen gums and inflamed lesions on the hard palate and lips?	The herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is the virus that can cause these symptoms.
What virus can cause symptoms such as respiratory insufficiency and decreased deep tendon reflexes (DTRs)?	The poliovirus is the virus that can cause these symptoms.
What virus can be treated with Vitamin A supplementation as a beneficial therapy?	The measles virus is the virus that can benefit from Vitamin A supplementation.
What virus affects the lower motor neurons (LMNs) of the anterior horn?	The poliovirus is the virus that affects LMNs in this way.

What are the viral virulence factors associated with Measles?	The viral virulence factors associated with Measles are Hemagglutinin and F (fusion) protein.
Which viral virulence factor is responsible for promoting the release of progeny virions?	Neuraminidase is the viral virulence factor responsible for promoting the release of progeny virions.
What is the viral virulence factor associated with RSV?	The viral virulence factor associated with RSV is the F (fusion) protein.
What is the viral virulence factor that causes respiratory cell fusion and multinucleated giant cell production?	The viral virulence factor responsible for causing respiratory cell fusion and multinucleated giant cell production is the F (fusion) protein.
Which viral virulence factor is responsible for binding sialic acid and promoting viral entry?	The viral virulence factor responsible for binding sialic acid and promoting viral entry is Hemagglutinin.
Which viral manifestation is characterized by a "dew drops on a rose" appearance in a dermatomal distribution?	The viral manifestation characterized by a "dew drops on a rose" appearance in a dermatomal distribution is Herpes Zoster (shingles).
What is the viral genetic phenomenon that occurs in segmented viruses?	The viral genetic phenomenon that occurs in segmented viruses is reassortment.
What is the viral genetic phenomenon exhibited by HBV, which provides HBsAg for HDV?	The viral genetic phenomenon exhibited by HBV, which provides HBsAg for HDV, is complementation.
What is the viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A receiving nucleocapsid proteins from virus B intracellularly?	The viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A receiving nucleocapsid proteins from virus B intracellularly is phenotypic mixing.
What is the viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A and virus B exchanging genomic segments intracellularly?	The viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A and virus B exchanging genomic segments intracellularly is reassortment.
What is the viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A and virus B exchanging genes between two chromosomes?	The viral genetic phenomenon characterized by virus A and virus B exchanging genes between two chromosomes is recombination.
What viral genetic phenomenon can cause antigenic shift?	The viral genetic phenomenon that can cause antigenic shift is reassortment.

What is the name of the viral gene in HIV that codes for its Aspartate Protease?	The name of the viral gene in HIV that codes for its Aspartate Protease is pol.

What type of cancer is more likely to spread through the bloodstream (hematogenously) to distant sites?	Sarcomas and some carcinomas are the types of cancer that tend to metastasize hematogenously.
Between calcium-oxalate and calcium-phosphate kidney stones, which one is more frequently encountered?	Calcium oxalate is the type of calcium kidney stone that is more common compared to calcium-phosphate kidney stone.
What type of calcification is more likely to occur extensively throughout the body?	Metastatic calcification, specifically metastatic or dystrophic calcification, tends to be widespread.
What type of calcification is more likely to occur in a specific area or tissue of the body?	Dystrophic calcification, specifically dystrophic or metastatic calcification, tends to be localized.
What type of calcification is a result of tissue damage or cell death?	Dystrophic calcification, specifically dystrophic or metastatic calcification, occurs secondary to injury or necrosis.
What type of calcification is a result of abnormal levels of calcium or phosphate in the blood?	Metastatic calcification, specifically metastatic or dystrophic calcification, occurs secondary to hypercalcemia or hyperphosphatemia.
What type of calcification occurs in healthy tissues that are not undergoing cell death?	Metastatic calcification, specifically metastatic or dystrophic calcification, can occur in normal, non-necrotic tissues.
What type of calcification occurs in tissues that have undergone abnormal cell death or necrosis?	Dystrophic calcification, specifically dystrophic or metastatic calcification, occurs in abnormal, necrotic tissues.
What type of brain tumor is characterized by the presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions at the gray-white junction?	The brain tumor that typically appears as multiple ring-enhancing lesions at the gray-white junction is brain metastasis.
What type of blood vessel is responsible for the exchange of nutrients, gases, and water between the blood and tissues?	Capillaries are the blood vessels that facilitate the exchange of nutrients, water, and gases between the blood and tissues.
Among all types of blood vessels, which one has the largest total cross-sectional and surface area?	Capillaries have the largest total cross-sectional and surface area among all types of blood vessels.
Among arteries, veins, and capillaries, which type of blood vessel has the highest capacitance?	Veins have the greatest capacitance among all types of blood vessels.
Among all types of blood vessels, which one has a significant amount of elastic tissue and smooth muscle?	Arteries have extensive elastic tissue and smooth muscle among all types of blood vessels.
In a series of blood vessels, which type of vessel causes the most significant reduction in pressure?	Arterioles cause the greatest decrease in pressure in a vascular system arranged in series among all types of blood vessels.
What type of bladder cancer is associated with the use of cyclophosphamide?	Cyclophosphamide is known to cause transitional cell carcinoma, a type of bladder cancer.
Among the different types of Bacillus cereus food poisoning, which one has the shortest incubation period?	The emetic type of Bacillus cereus food poisoning has the shortest incubation period.
What type of aphasia is characterized by fluent speech, impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition?	The type of aphasia characterized by fluent speech, impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition is known as Wernicke (receptive) aphasia.
What type of aphasia is characterized by nonfluent speech, impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition?	The type of aphasia that is characterized by nonfluent speech, impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition is known as Global aphasia.
What type of aphasia is characterized by fluent speech, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition?	The type of aphasia that is characterized by fluent speech, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition is known as Conduction aphasia.

What type of thyroid malignancy forms nests of polygonal-shaped or spindle-shaped cells?	Medullary thyroid carcinoma forms nests of polygonal-shaped or spindle-shaped cells.

In which phase of the cell cycle are primary oocytes arrested until ovulation?	Primary oocytes are arrested in Prophase I (of meiosis I) until ovulation.

Which pancreatic buds during embryonic development contribute to the uncinate process?	The ventral pancreatic buds contribute to the uncinate process.

What are the electrolyte disturbances that can cause arrhythmias, muscle cramps, spasms, and weakness?	Both low and high levels of potassium (K+) can cause arrhythmias, muscle cramps, spasms, and weakness.
What electrolyte disturbance can cause wide QRS and peaked T waves on an ECG?	Hyperkalemia, or high levels of potassium (K+), can cause wide QRS and peaked T waves on an ECG.
What electrolyte disturbance can cause U waves and flattened T waves on an ECG?	Hypokalemia, or low levels of potassium (K+), can cause U waves and flattened T waves on an ECG.
What electrolyte disturbance can cause tetany, torsades de pointes, and hypokalemia?	Hypomagnesemia, or low levels of magnesium (Mg2+), can cause tetany, torsades de pointes, and hypokalemia.
What electrolyte disturbance can cause tetany, seizures, QT prolongation, twitching, and spasm?	Hypocalcemia, or low levels of calcium (Ca2+), can cause tetany, seizures, QT prolongation, twitching, and spasm.
What electrolyte disturbance is associated with the symptoms of stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones?	Hypercalcemia, or high levels of calcium (Ca2+), can cause the symptoms of stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones.
What electrolyte disturbance is associated with the development of renal stones, metastatic calcifications, and hypocalcemia?	High levels of phosphate (PO43-) in the blood, or hyperphosphatemia, can cause renal stones, metastatic calcifications, and hypocalcemia.
What electrolyte disturbance is associated with symptoms such as irritability, stupor, and coma?	Hypernatremia, or high levels of sodium (Na+) in the blood, can cause symptoms such as irritability, stupor, and coma.

What is the cell cycle phase that is not part of interphase?	The cell cycle phase that is not part of interphase is M phase (mitosis).
What is the name of the cell cycle phase that is characterized by non-dividing, resting cells?	The cell cycle phase that is characterized by non-dividing, resting cells is called G0.
What is the name of the cell cycle phase that is characterized by DNA synthesis and replication?	The cell cycle phase that is characterized by DNA synthesis and replication is called S phase.

In which cellular organelle is most of the ribosomal RNA (rRNA) synthesized?	Most of the ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is synthesized in the nucleolus.
In which cellular structure is most messenger RNA (mRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA) synthesized?	Most mRNA and tRNA are synthesized in the euchromatin of the nucleus within the chromatin.
In which type of cells does the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) remain latent or dormant?	The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) remains latent or dormant in B cells.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to ventricular septal defect (VSD) the loudest?	A murmur due to ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically loudest in the tricuspid area of the heart.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation (TR) the loudest?	A murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is typically loudest in the tricuspid area of the heart.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to pulmonic stenosis (PS) the loudest?	A murmur due to pulmonic stenosis (PS) is typically loudest in the pulmonic area of the heart.
In which area of the chest is a murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) best heard?	A murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is best heard in the left infraclavicular area of the chest.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse (MVP) the loudest?	A murmur due to mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically loudest at the apex (mitral area) of the heart.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to mitral regurgitation (MR) the loudest?	A murmur due to mitral regurgitation (MR) is typically loudest at the apex (mitral area) of the heart.
In which area of the chest is a murmur due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) best heard?	A murmur due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is best heard at the left sternal border of the chest.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to atrial septal defect (ASD) the loudest?	A murmur due to atrial septal defect (ASD) is typically loudest in the pulmonic area of the heart.
In which area of the heart is a murmur due to aortic stenosis (AS) the loudest?	A murmur due to aortic stenosis (AS) is typically loudest at the heart base (aortic area) of the heart.
In which area of the chest is a murmur due to aortic regurgitation (AR) the loudest?	A murmur due to aortic regurgitation (AR) is typically loudest at the left sternal border of the chest.
In which part of the testis does the process of spermatogenesis occur?	Spermatogenesis occurs in the seminiferous tubules of the testis.

In which region of the spleen are B-cells primarily found?	B-cells are primarily found in the follicles (white pulp) of the spleen.
In which part of the respiratory tract do the cilia come to an end?	The cilia terminate in the respiratory bronchioles of the respiratory tract.
In which part of the nephron does isotonic reabsorption occur?	Isotonic reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron.
In which part of the nephron does the majority of uric acid reabsorption occur?	The majority of uric acid reabsorption occurs in the early proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron.

In which region of the lymph node do T-cells concentrate and multiply?	T-cells localize and proliferate in the paracortex region of the lymph node.
In which part of the lymph node do B-cells concentrate and multiply?	B-cells localize and proliferate in the follicles (outer cortex) of the lymph node.
In which part of the kidney does amyloid deposition occur, leading to nephrotic syndrome?	Amyloid deposits in the mesangium of the kidney, causing nephrotic syndrome.
In which part of the heart is the conduction velocity the slowest?	The conduction velocity is the slowest in the atrioventricular (AV) node of the heart.
In which part of the heart is the conduction velocity the fastest?	The conduction velocity is the fastest in the Purkinje fibers of the heart.
In which part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract does intussusception occur most frequently?	Intussusception most commonly occurs at the ileocecal junction of the GI tract.

In which part of the cell is the carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I enzyme located?	The carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I enzyme is found in the mitochondria of the cell, specifically for the urea cycle.
In which part of the cell does β-oxidation take place?	β-oxidation occurs in the mitochondria of the cell.
In which part of the cell does the process of translation start?	Translation begins in the cytoplasm of the cell.
In which part of the cell does the process of the urea cycle start?	The urea cycle begins in the mitochondria of the cell.

In which part of the cell does the Krebs cycle occur?	The Krebs cycle takes place in the mitochondria of the cell.

In which part of the cell does oxidative phosphorylation occur?	Oxidative phosphorylation takes place in the mitochondria of the cell.

What are the two common sites of metastasis for renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma typically metastasizes to the lung and bone.

What is the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in males when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?	The frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in males is equal to q when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics.
What is the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in females when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?	The frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in females is equal to q2 when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics.
What is the frequency of a carrier of a recessive disease when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?	The frequency of a carrier of a recessive disease is equal to 2pq when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics.
What do p2, 2pq, and q2 represent when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?	When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p2, 2pq, and q2 represent genotypic frequencies.
What do p and q represent when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?	When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p and q represent allelic frequencies.
In ELISA, what is involved in the detection process?	In ELISA, the detection process involves the use of an antibody linked to an enzyme.

What determines what sequences are detected when using blotting procedures?	When using blotting procedures, the probe determines what sequences are detected.
What changes and what remains the same when using an irreversible competitive inhibitor?	When using an irreversible competitive inhibitor, the Vmax changes, while the Km remains the same.
What changes and what remains the same when using a reversible competitive inhibitor?	When using a reversible competitive inhibitor, the Km changes, while the Vmax remains the same.
What changes and what remains the same when using a noncompetitive inhibitor?	When using a noncompetitive inhibitor, the Vmax changes, while the Km remains the same.

What is the goal range for maintaining PaO2 when using a ventilator?	When using a ventilator, the goal is to keep PaO2 between 55 - 80 mmHg.
What FiO2 levels during prolonged use of a ventilator are associated with oxygen toxicity?	When using a ventilator, prolonged FiO2 levels > 60% are associated with oxygen toxicity.
Where is the glucocorticoid receptor located when it is unbound?	When unbound, the glucocorticoid receptor is located in the cytoplasm.

What happens when tidal volume is limited and the respiratory control centers need to restore minute ventilation?	When tidal volume is limited, the respiratory control centers increase the respiratory rate to restore minute ventilation.
What happens to the exocytosis of insulin and C peptide when the β cell is stimulated?	When the β cell is stimulated, exocytosis of insulin and C peptide are released in equimolar quantities.
What happens to iodinated thyroglobulin when the thyroid gland is stimulated?	When the thyroid gland is stimulated, iodinated thyroglobulin is endocytosed into the follicular epithelial cells.
What happens when the plasma concentration of bicarbonate ([HCO3-]) exceeds a certain level, and what is that level?	When the plasma [HCO3-] is greater than 40 mEq/L, the reabsorption mechanisms are fully saturated and excess HCO3- is secreted.

What happens to the abdominal contents when the diaphragm contracts, and in which direction are they pushed?	When the diaphragm contracts, the abdominal contents are pushed downwards.
What happens to the Pco2 and pH levels in the brain when it is ischemic?	When the brain is ischemic, the Pco2 levels increase and pH levels decrease.

What laboratory tests are used to detect a myocardial infarction?	When suspecting a myocardial infarction, laboratory tests are used to detect elevated cardiac enzymes.
What happens when subendothelial collagen and glycosaminoglycans are exposed?	When subendothelial collagen and glycosaminoglycans are exposed, they contribute to rapid thrombus formation.
What is the term used for Stevens-Johnson syndrome that involves more than 30% of the body surface?	When Stevens-Johnson syndrome involves more than 30% of the body surface it is termed toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

How far in advance should smoking cessation begin prior to surgery?	Smoking cessation should commence 8 weeks before surgery because congestion initially worsens.

At what point during pregnancy should pregnant women be screened for hepatitis B?	Pregnant women should be screened for hepatitis B at their first prenatal visit.

At what point should patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome undergo bilateral gonadectomy?	Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome should undergo bilateral gonadectomy after puberty.
Within what time frame should patients with acute cholecystitis undergo cholecystectomy?	Patients with acute cholecystitis should undergo cholecystectomy within 72 hours.
What is the recommended timeline for older patients with hip fractures to undergo definitive surgical correction?	Older patients with hip fractures should undergo definitive surgical correction as soon as reasonably possible.
What is the recommended timeline for surgical correction with orchiopexy for cryptorchidism?	Cryptorchidism should be surgically corrected with orchiopexy by 1 year of age.

What is the relationship between Reynolds' number and blood flow in terms of turbulence?	When Reynolds' number is increased, there is a greater tendency for blood flow to become turbulent.
What happens to the total flow through each level of a system when resistances are arranged in series?	When resistances are arranged in series, the total flow through each level of the system remains the same.
What happens to the pressure through each level of a system when resistances are arranged in parallel?	When resistances are arranged in parallel, the pressure through each level of the system remains the same.
What happens to the specificity and positive predictive value (PPV) when the cutoff point for a disease is raised?	When raising the cutoff point for a disease, the specificity and PPV will increase.
What happens to the sensitivity and negative predictive value (NPV) when the cutoff point for a disease is raised?	When raising the cutoff point for a disease, the sensitivity and NPV will decrease.
What is added to misfolded proteins to aid in trafficking to the proteasome?	When proteins are misfolded, multiple ubiquitins are added, which aids in trafficking to the proteasome.
What happens to parathyroid hormone secretion when plasma Ca2+ concentrations decrease (and vice versa)?	When plasma Ca2+ concentrations decrease, parathyroid hormone secretion is increased (and vice versa).
What can be identified using TRAP when performing Immunohistochemistry?	When performing Immunohistochemistry, TRAP can be used to identify Hairy Cell Leukemia.
What type of malignancies can be identified using Thyroglobulin when performing Immunohistochemistry?	When performing Immunohistochemistry, Thyroglobulin can be used to identify malignancies of the thyroid.

What type of stain can be used when performing Immunohistochemistry to identify Epithelial tumors, such as Squamous Cell Carcinoma?	When performing Immunohistochemistry, a Cytokeratin stain can be used to identify Epithelial tumors, such as Squamous Cell Carcinoma.
What type of cancer can be identified using a PSA stain when performing Immunohistochemistry?	When performing Immunohistochemistry, a stain for PSA can be used to identify Prostate Cancer.
What type of malignancies of epithelium can be identified using a stain for ER when performing Immunohistochemistry?	When performing Immunohistochemistry, a stain for ER can be used to identify malignancies of breast epithelium.
What does the surgical tools pierce through when performing a suprapubic cystostomy?	When performing a suprapubic cystostomy, the surgical tools pierce through the anterior abdominal aponeurosis.
What medications can be used to treat hypertension or proteinuria in patients with Autosomal Dominant PKD?	When patients with Autosomal Dominant PKD develop hypertension or proteinuria, you may treat with ACE inhibitors or ARBs.

What happens to O2 transfer in patients with diseased lung tissue such as fibrosis or emphysema?	When patients have diseased lung tissue (e.g. fibrosis/emphysema) O2 transfer becomes diffusion-limited.
What is it called when there is net fluid movement out of the capillary and into the interstitial fluid?	When net fluid movement is out of the capillary into the interstitial fluid, it is called filtration.
What is it called when there is net fluid movement into the capillary from the interstitial fluid?	When net fluid movement is into the capillary from the interstitial fluid, it is called absorption.
In what configuration do membrane phospholipids cause decreased membrane fluidity?	When membrane phospholipids are in the trans configuration, they cause decreased membrane fluidity.
What is the net force on the lung-chest wall system when lung volume is less than FRC?	When lung volume is less than FRC, there is a net expanding force on the lung-chest wall system.
What is the net force on the lung-chest wall system when lung volume is greater than FRC?	When lung volume is greater than FRC, there is a net collapsing force on the lung-chest wall system.
What happens to the specificity and PPV when the cutoff point for a disease is lowered?	When lowering the cutoff point for a disease, the specificity and PPV will decrease.
What happens to the sensitivity and NPV when the cutoff point for a disease is lowered?	When lowering the cutoff point for a disease, the sensitivity and NPV will increase.
What symbol on a pedigree indicates that an individual is diseased?	When looking at a pedigree, a shaded circle/square is indicative of a diseased individual.
What does a square on a pedigree indicate?	When looking at a pedigree, a square is indicative of a male.
What does a circle on a pedigree indicate?	When looking at a pedigree, a circle is indicative of a female.
What happens to 11-cis retinal when light strikes the retina?	When light strikes the retina, 11-cis retinal is converted to all-trans retinal.
What is the relationship between Jv (fluid flow) and net fluid movement out of the capillary?	When Jv (fluid flow) is positive, there is net fluid movement out of the capillary (filtration).
What is the relationship between Jv (fluid flow) and net fluid movement into the capillary?	When Jv (fluid flow) is negative, there is net fluid movement into the capillary (absorption).

Between what ages is the Haemophilus influenzae vaccine typically given?	The Haemophilus influenzae vaccine is typically administered between 2 and 18 months of age.
