During what time frame is it considered normal to see a lactate doublet in a normal human?	It is considered normal to see a lactate doublet in a normal human within the first hours of life.
In what situation is an increased AFP in pregnancy considered normal?	An increased AFP in pregnancy is considered normal in the case of multiple gestation.
When is it considered an extremely important time to revisit advanced care planning for end-of-life issues?	It is considered an extremely important time to revisit advanced care planning for end-of-life issues upon hospital admission.
Under what circumstances is an EGD typically performed for GERD?	An EGD is typically performed for GERD only when PPIs fail or when there are alarm symptoms present.
In what situation is amnioinfusion contraindicated?	Amnioinfusion is contraindicated in patients with a history of uterine surgery, presumably due to the risk of rupture.
What happens when insulin binds to its receptor?	When insulin binds to its receptor, tyrosine kinase is activated and autophosphorylates the β-subunits.
What happens to the insulin receptor when insulin binds to it?	When insulin binds to its receptor, the receptor dimerizes and is activated via tyrosine kinase activity.
What are the effects of insulin on muscle tissue?	When insulin acts on muscle tissue, it causes increased glycogen storage and increased protein synthesis.
What are the effects of insulin on liver tissue?	When insulin acts on liver tissue, it causes increased glycogenesis and decreased glycogenolysis.
What are the effects of insulin on adipose tissue?	When insulin acts on adipose tissue, it causes increased triglyceride storage and decreased lipolysis.
What types of cancer can be treated with intravenous injection of 5FU?	When injected intravenously, 5FU can be used to treat colon cancer and pancreatic cancer.
What is the cause of infection when individuals consume contaminated water?	When individuals consume water filled with cysts of Giardia, infection occurs.
What is the reason for chain termination when NRTI's are incorporated into the nascent DNA chain?	When incorporated into the nascent DNA chain, NRTI's cause chain termination as they lack an 3' OH group.
What is the role of Rb in the cell cycle when it is in the hypophosphorylated state?	When in the hypophosphorylated state, Rb sequesters E2F transcription factor, which is necessary for transition to the S phase.
What is the purpose of the Microcytotoxicity test in HLA typing?	When HLA typing, the purpose of the Microcytotoxicity test is to test for MHC class I (ex HLA-A, HLA-B).
In HLA typing and testing for a Mixed lymphocyte reaction, what does higher radioactivity signify?	In HLA typing and testing for a Mixed lymphocyte reaction, higher radioactivity signifies lower compatibility.
What happens when high frequency strains of bacteria undergo conjugation?	When high frequency strains of bacteria undergo conjugation, they transfer their bacterial genome with the plasmid to the recipient.
In GTPAL, the obstetrical grading system for females, what does the L represent?	In GTPAL, the obstetrical grading system for females, the L represents the number of living children.
In GTPAL, the obstetrical grading system for females, what does the G represent?	In GTPAL, the obstetrical grading system for females, the G represents gravidity, which is the total number of pregnancies.
What is the name given to facial nerve palsy when it is idiopathic?	When facial nerve palsy is idiopathic, it is called Bell's palsy.
What does differentiation refer to when examining a tumor?	When examining a tumor, differentiation refers to the degree to which the tumor resembles its tissue of origin.
What do gun-powder lesions refer to in endometriosis?	Gun-powder lesions refer to the appearance of endometriosis when it spreads to soft tissue.
What is recommended to precede lumbar puncture when elevated intracranial pressure is suspected and why?	When elevated intracranial pressure is suspected, neuroimaging is recommended to precede lumbar puncture because of the risk of cerebral herniation.
During which period of pregnancy does acute fatty liver of pregnancy typically occur?	Acute fatty liver of pregnancy typically occurs during the third trimester or early postpartum period.
At what age does β-thalassemia major (β0/β0) typically present?	β-thalassemia major (β0/β0) typically presents months after birth.
At what age does X-linked agammaglobulinemia typically present?	X-linked agammaglobulinemia typically presents at 6 months after birth.
How long after exposure does the rash for Rocky Mountain spotted fever typically appear?	The rash for Rocky Mountain spotted fever typically appears after a 2-14 day incubation period.
At what age does pyloric stenosis typically present?	Pyloric stenosis typically presents at 3-6 weeks of age.
What are the conditions in which hypermetabolic syndrome typically occurs?	Hypermetabolic syndrome typically occurs in severe burns, sepsis, and hyperthyroidism.
At what point does gestational diabetes typically resolve?	Gestational diabetes typically resolves after delivery of the placenta.
At what age does common variable immunodeficiency typically present?	Common variable immunodeficiency typically presents after the age of 2.
At what age does colonoscopy screening typically begin?	Colonoscopy screening typically begins at age 50 or 10 years before a relative who had colon cancer.
In what situations do you use a CIR?	A CIR is used when there is a fixed or closed situation.

At what age do children typically receive their first dose of the varicella vaccine?	Children typically receive their first dose of the varicella vaccine between 12-15 months of age.
How does the likelihood of chronic infection differ between HBV and HCV?	When compared to HCV, HBV is less likely to become a chronic infection.
What are the effects of chronically elevated PTH on bone, and what is this condition known as?	When chronically elevated, PTH has catabolic effects on bone, known as osteitis fibrosa cystica.
What is the relationship between CH2O and the osmolarity of urine relative to plasma?	When CH2O is zero, urine is iso-osmotic relative to plasma.
How does CH2O affect the osmolarity of urine relative to plasma?	When CH2O is positive, urine is hypo-osmotic relative to plasma.
How does CH2O affect the osmolarity of urine relative to plasma?	When CH2O is negative, urine is hyper-osmotic relative to plasma.
What is the effect of bisphosphonate on osteoclasts when they are bound to it?	When bound to bisphosphonate, osteoclasts are unable to adhere to the bony surface, thus decreasing their activity.
At what point during pregnancy are women typically screened for gestational diabetes mellitus?	Women are typically screened for gestational diabetes mellitus at 24-28 weeks, which is the end of the second trimester.
In the context of ulcerative colitis (UC), when are systemic corticosteroids typically indicated?	Systemic corticosteroids are typically indicated for the treatment of an active flare in UC.
At what point in time are patients typically screened for phenylketonuria?	Patients are typically screened for phenylketonuria 2-3 days after birth.
At what point in time are patients typically screened for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection?	Patients are typically screened for GBS infection at 35-37 weeks of pregnancy.
In the context of preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), when are antibiotics typically indicated?	Antibiotics are always indicated for PPROM.
During which periods of life are anovulatory cycles more likely to occur?	Anovulatory cycles are more likely to occur during menarche and menopause.
When and in what location does a galactocele typically present?	A galactocele typically presents after cessation of breastfeeding and in the subareolar area.
In what manner is Amphotericin B administered when it is used for the treatment of meningitis?	Amphotericin B is administered intrathecally when it is used for the treatment of meningitis.
What is the effect of β2-adrenergic receptor activation on vascular smooth muscle?	When activated, β2-adrenergic receptors cause relaxation of vascular smooth muscle.
What is the effect of α1-adrenergic receptor activation on vascular smooth muscle?	When activated, α1-adrenergic receptors cause contraction of vascular smooth muscle.
What is the term used to describe a xanthoma that affects the eyelids?	When a xanthoma affects the eyelids, it is known as xanthelasma.
What happens to the blood in the lower extremities when a person moves from a supine to a standing position?	When a person moves from a supine to a standing position, blood pools in the veins of the lower extremities.
Where is pulmonary blood flow lowest when a person is standing?	When a person is standing, pulmonary blood flow is lowest at the apex (top) of the lungs.
Where is pulmonary blood flow highest when a person is standing?	When a person is standing, pulmonary blood flow is highest at the base (bottom) of the lungs.
What type of cells secrete K+ in the terminal nephron segments when a person has high K+ levels?	When a person has high K+ levels, K+ can be secreted in the terminal nephron segments by the principal cells.
What should be a concern when a pregnant patient has low levels of β-hCG?	When a patient is pregnant, low levels of β-hCG should be concerning for failing or ectopic pregnancies.

What happens to the total resistance when a blood vessel is added to a system in series?	When a blood vessel is added to a system in series, the total resistance increases.
What happens to the total resistance when a blood vessel is added to a system in parallel?	When a blood vessel is added to a system in parallel, the total resistance decreases.

What is the expected result of a dexamethasone suppression test in a patient with Cushing's disease?	The cortisol response in a patient with Cushing's disease would be suppressed by a high dose of dexamethasone.
What would be the platelet count and bleeding time in a patient with uremia-induced platelet dysfunction?	The platelet count would be normal in a patient with uremia-induced platelet dysfunction.
What is the consequence of absent or dysfunctional signal recognition particles (SRPs)?	The consequence of absent or dysfunctional signal recognition particles (SRPs) is the accumulation of proteins in the cytosol.
What would a physical examination reveal in a patient with Hirschsprung's disease?	The physical examination may reveal either increased or decreased bowel sounds.

What is the genetic classification of togaviruses?	Togaviruses are positive-sense RNA viruses, meaning their genetic material is RNA that can be directly translated into proteins.

What is the genetic classification of Flaviviruses?	Flaviviruses are positive-sense RNA viruses, meaning their genetic material is RNA that can be directly translated into proteins.

What is the genetic classification of Poliovirus?	Poliovirus is a positive-sense RNA virus, meaning its genetic material is RNA that can be directly translated into proteins.
What is the genetic classification of Parvovirus B19?	Parvovirus B19 is a single-stranded DNA virus, meaning its genetic material is DNA that is only composed of one strand.
What is the genetic classification of HTLV-1?	HTLV-1 is a positive-sense RNA virus, meaning its genetic material is RNA that can be directly translated into proteins.
What is the genetic classification of HHV-8?	HHV-8 is a double-stranded DNA virus, meaning its genetic material is DNA that consists of two complementary strands.

What type of ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch is caused by a pulmonary embolus?	A pulmonary embolus causes a dead space V/Q mismatch.
What type of ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch is caused by airway obstruction?	Airway obstruction causes a shunt V/Q mismatch, which is characterized by perfusion but no ventilation.
What type of ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch can occur in patients with pneumonia?	Patients with pneumonia may experience a right-to-left intrapulmonary shunt V/Q mismatch.
In COPD patients with O2-induced CO2 retention, which type of ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch is exacerbated?	The dead space V/Q mismatch is worsened in COPD patients with O2-induced CO2 retention.
What type of urethral injury is commonly seen in men following straddle injuries?	Straddle injuries in men typically result in anterior urethral injury.
What type of urethral injury is commonly associated with pelvic fractures in men?	Pelvic fractures in men are typically associated with posterior urethral injury.
In men, what type of urethral injury is commonly caused by pelvic fractures?	Pelvic fractures in men typically result in posterior urethral injury.
What type of upper airway obstruction is commonly observed in patients with vocal cord paralysis/dysfunction and laryngeal tumors?	Patients with vocal cord paralysis/dysfunction and laryngeal tumors typically present with variable extrathoracic obstruction of the upper airway.
What type of upper airway obstruction is commonly observed in patients with tracheomalacia and bronchogenic cysts?	Patients with tracheomalacia and bronchogenic cysts typically present with variable intrathoracic obstruction of the upper airway.
What type of upper airway obstruction is commonly observed in patients with tracheal stenosis, extraluminal goiter, and mediastinal mass?	Patients with tracheal stenosis, extraluminal goiter, and mediastinal mass typically present with fixed upper airway obstruction.
What is the type of transport mechanism utilized by the H+-K+ ATPase?	The H+-K+ ATPase utilizes primary active transport as its mechanism of action.
What is the type of transport mechanism utilized by Na+/glucose cotransport?	Na+/glucose cotransport utilizes secondary active transport as its mechanism of action.
What is the type of transport mechanism utilized by the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter?	The Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter utilizes secondary active transport as its mechanism of action.
What is the type of transport mechanism utilized by glucose transport through GLUT1 and GLUT2?	Glucose transport through GLUT1 and GLUT2 utilizes facilitated diffusion as its mechanism of action.
Which type of tissue does not have significant regenerative potential?	Permanent tissue lacks significant regenerative potential.
Which type of tissue is composed of stem cells that can continuously cycle to regenerate tissue?	Labile tissue is comprised of stem cells that can continuously cycle to regenerate tissue.
Which type of tissue is comprised of cells that can re-enter the cell cycle to regenerate tissue when necessary?	Stable (quiescent) tissue is comprised of cells that can re-enter the cell cycle to regenerate tissue when necessary.
Which type of tick is responsible for spreading babesia?	Ixodes scapularis tick is responsible for spreading babesia.
Which type of thyroid nodule, hyperfunctioning ("hot") or hypofunctioning ("cold"), is more likely to be cancerous?	Hypofunctioning ("cold") thyroid nodules are more likely to be cancerous.
Which type of therapy is commonly used to treat nightmare disorder?	Desensitization/Imagery rehearsal therapy is often used to treat nightmare disorder.
Which type of therapy is most effective for a patient that presents with borderline personality disorder?	Dialectical behavioral therapy is the most useful therapy for a patient that presents with borderline personality disorder.
What type of syncope is likely to occur in a person who has had a myocardial infarction (MI)?	Cardiac syncope is likely to occur in a person who has had an MI.
Which surgical procedure is commonly performed in patients with Ulcerative Colitis?	Proctocolectomy is the surgical procedure that is performed in patients with Ulcerative Colitis.
Which type of study design uses the subjects as their own controls?	Crossover studies use the subjects as their own controls.
Which type of study is considered to be at the top of the hierarchy of medical evidence?	Meta-analysis is considered to be at the pinnacle of the hierarchy of medical evidence.
Which type of stroke can be treated with thrombolytics, and within what time frame should the treatment be administered?	Ischemic stroke can be treated with thrombolytics, and the treatment should be administered within a specific time frame.

Which types of infections caused by Streptococcus pyogenes can lead to the development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?	Pharyngitis and impetigo caused by Streptococcus pyogenes can precipitate the development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
What type of signaling mechanism does histamine use to reach parietal cells in the stomach?	Histamine uses the paracrine signaling mechanism to locally diffuse and reach parietal cells in the stomach.
What type of signaling mechanism does gastrin use to reach parietal cells in the stomach?	Gastrin uses the endocrine signaling mechanism to enter the systemic circulation and reach parietal cells in the stomach.
What is the term used to describe a type of scar that has parallel collagen organization?	A keloid scar is characterized by parallel collagen organization.
What is the term used to describe a type of scar that has disorganized collagen organization?	A hypertrophic scar is characterized by disorganized collagen organization.
What is the term used to describe a type of scar that goes beyond the boundaries of the original wound?	A keloid scar is a type of scar that extends beyond the borders of the original wound.

What is the term used to describe the resistance demonstrated by the organization of blood vessels in systemic circulation?	Vascular resistance in parallel is illustrated by the arrangement of blood vessels in systemic circulation.

Which type of probe is employed to bind DNA/RNA during a Southern/Northern blot?	A labeled single-stranded DNA/RNA oligonucleotide is used as the probe to bind DNA/RNA in a Southern/Northern blot.

Which type of anemia is unlikely to be caused by NSAID therapy?	Aplastic anemia.

What is the type of anemia associated with a deficiency of vitamin B9 (folate)?	Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is associated with macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia.
What is the type of anemia associated with a deficiency of vitamin B12 (cobalamin)?	Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is associated with macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia.
Which type of amyloidosis is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis?	The type of amyloidosis commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis is secondary (AA) amyloidosis.
Which type of adrenergic receptor is present on both the renal afferent and efferent arterioles?	The adrenergic receptor found on both the renal afferent and efferent arterioles is the α1-adrenergic receptor.
Which type of adrenergic receptor is present in veins?	Veins have α1-adrenergic receptors.
Which type of acute renal failure is characterized by a normal BUN/Cr ratio?	The type of acute renal failure with a normal BUN/Cr ratio is intrinsic renal failure.
Which type of acute renal failure is characterized by a significant increase in BUN/Cr ratio?	The type of acute renal failure with a large increase in BUN/Cr ratio is prerenal failure.

What is the type of acid-base disturbance that is commonly associated with vomiting?	The type of acid-base disturbance that occurs with vomiting is hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

Which two types of photoreceptors are utilized for vision?	The two types of photoreceptors that are used for vision are rods and cones.

Which two HLA subtypes are linked to Graves disease?	Graves disease is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-B8.

Which two factors affect the mean systemic pressure?	The value for mean systemic pressure is influenced by blood volume and venous tone.
Which two factors play a role in determining the filtration coefficient (Kf) of a glomerular capillary?	The Kf of a glomerular capillary is influenced by the water permeability and total surface area of the capillary.

Which two categories of medications are linked to methemoglobinemia?	Methemoglobinemia is associated with the use of nitrates (including nitrites) and sulfa drugs.

Which serologic marker for HBV (Hepatitis B virus) infection is indicative of infectivity?	HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is the serologic marker for HBV infection that is indicative of infectivity.
What is the potential serious adverse effect of using vigabatrin?	The potential serious adverse effect of using vigabatrin is permanent vision loss, which is indicated by a black box warning.
Which sequence of nucleotides is repeated in myotonic dystrophy?	The sequence of nucleotides repeated in myotonic dystrophy is CTG.
Which sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Huntington's disease?	The sequence of nucleotides repeated in Huntington's disease is CAG.
Which sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Friedreich ataxia?	The sequence of nucleotides repeated in Friedreich ataxia is GAA.
Which sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Fragile X syndrome?	The sequence of nucleotides repeated in Fragile X syndrome is CGG.
What is the sequence of bases that represents a polyadenylation signal?	The sequence of bases that represents a polyadenylation signal is AAUAAA.
What is the anatomical feature that separates LN 5A/5B?	The anatomical feature that separates LN 5A/5B is the level of the cricoid cartilage.

What is the anatomical feature that separates LN 1A from 1B?	The anatomical feature that separates LN 1A from 1B is the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
What is the anatomical feature that separates LN 1B from 2A?	The anatomical feature that separates LN 1B from 2A is the stylohyoid muscle.

What are the typical sensory deficits associated with ALS?	None, ALS typically does not present with sensory deficits.
What specific sensory deficits can occur as a result of anterior spinal artery occlusion?	Loss of pain and temperature sensation can occur as a result of anterior spinal artery occlusion.

What is the name of the selection bias that occurs when specifically selecting healthy individuals?	The name of this selection bias is the healthy worker effect.

During which phase of the cell cycle do base excision repairs occur?	Base excision repairs can occur throughout the cell cycle.

Which phase of the cardiac cycle starts during the QRS complex on an ECG?	The isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase of the cardiac cycle begins during the QRS complex on an ECG.
Which phase of drug metabolism involves reduction, oxidation, and hydrolysis?	Phase I of drug metabolism involves reduction, oxidation, and hydrolysis.

In an adolescent with cystic fibrosis, which organism is commonly responsible for causing recurrent pulmonary infections?	Pseudomonas aeruginosa is frequently responsible for causing recurrent pulmonary infections in adolescents with cystic fibrosis.

What organism(s) is commonly found in dental plaques?	S. viridans, specifically S. mutans and S. sanguinis, are commonly found in dental plaques.
Which organism is responsible for causing Relapsing Fever?	Borrelia recurrentis is the organism responsible for causing Relapsing Fever.
Which organ in the body is responsible for synthesizing complement proteins?	The liver is the organ responsible for synthesizing complement proteins.
Which organ in the body is responsible for the metabolism of ethanol?	The liver is the organ responsible for the metabolism of ethanol.
In systemic amyloidosis, which organ is commonly affected the most?	The kidney is the organ that is most commonly affected by systemic amyloidosis.
Which organ in the body is primarily affected by the M2 receptor?	The heart is the organ that is primarily affected by the M2 receptor.
Which opioid analgesic is known to cause mydriasis?	Meperidine is the opioid analgesic that is known to cause mydriasis.
What is the opening pressure (lumbar puncture) associated with viral meningitis?	The opening pressure associated with viral meningitis is normal.
What is the opening pressure (lumbar puncture) associated with fungal or TB meningitis?	The opening pressure associated with fungal or TB meningitis is increased pressure.
What is the opening pressure (lumbar puncture) associated with bacterial meningitis?	The opening pressure associated with bacterial meningitis is increased pressure.

What is the classic ocular finding in Tay-Sachs disease?	The classic ocular finding in Tay-Sachs disease is a "cherry-red" spot on the macula.
What is the classic ocular finding in Niemann-Pick disease?	The classic ocular finding in Niemann-Pick disease is a "cherry-red" spot on the macula.

What is a notable indication for the use of cerclage?	Cerclage is commonly used for the management of cervical insufficiency.

Which non-volatile acid may be elevated in cases of aspirin overdose?	Salicylic acid is the non-volatile acid that may be elevated in cases of aspirin overdose.

With what non-pathologic state is an increased risk for pyelonephritis associated?	Pregnancy is the non-pathologic state that is associated with an increased risk for pyelonephritis.
Which non-nucleated cell type expresses MHC class I?	Platelets are the non-nucleated cell type that expresses MHC class I.
Which non-third generation group of cephalosporins is effective in treating bacterial meningitis?	Cefepime, which belongs to the fourth generation of cephalosporins, can be used to treat bacterial meningitis.

Which neurotransmitters are released by the striatum in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia?	In the direct pathway of the basal ganglia, the striatum releases the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and substance P.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in Parkinson's disease?	Parkinson's disease is characterized by a decrease in the neurotransmitter dopamine.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in Huntington's disease?	Huntington's disease is characterized by a decrease in the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in depression?	Depression is characterized by a decrease in the neurotransmitter serotonin.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in anxiety?	Anxiety is characterized by a decrease in the neurotransmitter serotonin.
Which neurotransmitter mediates relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter during swallowing?	VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) is the neurotransmitter that mediates relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter during swallowing.
Which neurotransmitter is released when the globus pallidus externus (a component of the basal ganglia pathway) is stimulated?	The globus pallidus externus releases the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) when it is stimulated.
Which neurotransmitter is released by the subthalamic nucleus in the indirect basal ganglia pathway?	The subthalamic nucleus releases the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate in the indirect basal ganglia pathway.
Which neurotransmitter is released by the motor cortex in both the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways?	The motor cortex releases the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate in both the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways.
Which neurotransmitter is released by the globus pallidus internus in both the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways?	The globus pallidus internus releases the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) in both the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways.
Which neurotransmitter is commonly secreted by carcinoid tumors?	Carcinoid tumors often secrete the neurotransmitter serotonin.
Which neurotransmitter is typically elevated in individuals with schizophrenia?	The neurotransmitter dopamine is commonly increased in individuals with schizophrenia.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in Parkinson's disease?	The neurotransmitter dopamine is typically decreased in Parkinson's disease, while the neurotransmitter acetylcholine may be increased.
Which neurotransmitter is decreased in Huntington's disease?	The neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is typically decreased in Huntington's disease, while the neurotransmitter dopamine may be increased.
Which neurotransmitter is often elevated in individuals with anxiety?	The neurotransmitter norepinephrine is commonly increased in individuals with anxiety.
Which neurotransmitter is typically elevated during REM sleep?	The neurotransmitter acetylcholine is commonly increased during REM sleep, which can lead to increased vagal tone.
Which neurotransmitter is typically decreased in individuals with Alzheimer's disease?	The neurotransmitter acetylcholine is commonly decreased in individuals with Alzheimer's disease.

Which nerve supplies sensation to the sole of the foot?	The tibial nerve provides sensation to the sole of the foot.

Which nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the sole of the foot?	The tibial nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the sole of the foot.
Which nerve is responsible for foot inversion and plantar flexion?	The tibial nerve is responsible for foot inversion and plantar flexion.
Which nerve is responsible for foot eversion and dorsiflexion?	The peroneal (fibular) nerve is responsible for foot eversion and dorsiflexion.
Which nerve is responsible for flexion at the hip and extension at the knee?	The femoral nerve is responsible for flexion at the hip and extension at the knee.

Which type of nephrotoxicity is caused by sulfonamides?	Sulfonamides can cause acute interstitial nephritis.

Which musculoskeletal disorder is found at a significantly higher rate in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?	Patients with rheumatoid arthritis have a significantly higher prevalence of osteopenia/osteoporosis.

Which muscular symptom is commonly associated with neuroleptic malignant syndrome?	Lead-pipe rigidity is a muscular symptom that is often linked with neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
Which muscles are typically utilized for expiration during periods of rest?	Normally, no muscles are used for expiration during rest as it is a passive process.

What is the diagnostic level of random blood glucose for T2DM?	A level of ≥ 200 mg/dL is diagnostic for T2DM.
What is the required level of proteinuria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia?	A level of ≥ 300 mg/day is required to make a diagnosis of preeclampsia.
What is the required level of proteinuria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia?	A level of ≥ 300 mg/day or a protein/creatinine ratio > 0.3 is required to make a diagnosis of preeclampsia.
Where does a 2nd degree, Mobitz type I heart block typically occur?	A 2nd degree, Mobitz type I heart block typically occurs at the level of the AV node.
What is the predictive lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio for NRDS?	A lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio of < 1.5 is predictive of NRDS.
What is the indicative lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio for adequate surfactant production?	A lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio of > 2 is indicative of adequate surfactant production.
What is the indicative lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio for a mature fetal lung?	A lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio of > 2 is indicative of a mature fetal lung.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an inferior myocardial infarction?	Leads II, III, and aVF show ST elevations or Q waves in an inferior myocardial infarction.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroseptal myocardial infarction?	Leads V1 - V2 show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroseptal myocardial infarction.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anterolateral myocardial infarction?	Leads V5 - V6 show ST elevations or Q waves in an anterolateral myocardial infarction.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroapical myocardial infarction?	Leads V3 - V4 show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroapical myocardial infarction.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a posterior myocardial infarction?	Leads V7 - V9 show ST elevations or Q waves in a posterior myocardial infarction.
Which leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a lateral myocardial infarction?	Leads I and aVL show ST elevations or Q waves in a lateral myocardial infarction.
Which lead shows ST elevations or Q waves in a Left Main (LCA) myocardial infarction?	Lead aVR shows ST elevations or Q waves in a Left Main (LCA) myocardial infarction.
What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in an 18 month old child?	A child at 18 months is expected to have acquired 10-25 language developmental milestones.
What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 9 month old infant?	A 9 month old infant is expected to say "dada" and "mama" as language developmental milestones.
What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 6 month old baby?	A 6 month old baby is expected to respond to their name and babble as language developmental milestones.
What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 4 month old infant?	A 4 month old infant is expected to turn to voice as a language developmental milestone.
What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 2 month old baby?	A 2 month old baby is expected to coo as a language developmental milestone.
What laboratory findings are associated with prehepatic jaundice?	The laboratory finding associated with prehepatic jaundice is an increased level of unconjugated bilirubin.
Which laboratory technique is commonly used to determine the CD4 cell count in patients with HIV?	Flow cytometry is a laboratory technique that is useful in determining CD4 cell count in HIV patients.
Which laboratory technique is commonly used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances?	Karyotyping is the laboratory technique used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances.
Which laboratory measurement is used to categorize chronic kidney disease (CKD) into stages?	Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the laboratory measurement used to stratify CKD into stages.
Which laboratory function tests should be monitored when using amiodarone?	Pulmonary function tests (PFTs), liver function tests (LFTs), and thyroid function tests (TFTs) should be checked when using amiodarone.
Which laboratory assay is used to monitor the effects of warfarin?	The prothrombin time/international normalized ratio (PT/INR) is the laboratory assay used to follow the effects of warfarin.
Which laboratory assay is used to monitor the activity of heparin?	The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is the laboratory assay used to follow the activity of heparin.
Which laboratory assay is increased by anti-platelet therapy?	The bleeding time is a laboratory assay that is increased with anti-platelet therapy.
Which lab value is assessed when a flare-up of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is suspected?	Fecal calprotectin is the lab value that is checked during a suspected flare-up of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
Which lab value can be used to screen for Primary Biliary Cirrhosis?	Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) is the lab value that can be screened for Primary Biliary Cirrhosis.
Which lab finding can be used to differentiate between E. coli and Enterobacter?	Indole positivity, which is present in E. coli, can be used as a lab finding to distinguish it from Enterobacter.
Which knee injury is characterized by acute onset of "catching/locking" sensation and reduced range of motion?	A meniscal tear is the knee injury that presents with acute onset of "catching/locking" sensation and reduced range of motion.
Which toxin is responsible for causing scalded-skin syndrome?	Exfoliative toxin A and B are the toxins that produce scalded-skin syndrome.
Which type of hip rotation is enabled by the following muscles?	The muscles allow for internal rotation of the hip.
Which type of hip rotation is enabled by the following muscles?	The muscles allow for external rotation of the hip.
What type of renal disease is associated with infective endocarditis?	Glomerulonephritis, specifically immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, occurs in infective endocarditis.
Which laboratory test is used to measure LDL levels and determine the need for statin therapy?	A fasting lipid profile is the laboratory measurement used to measure LDL levels and determine the need for statin therapy.
What type of inheritance pattern is seen in patients with androgenetic alopecia?	Androgenetic alopecia exhibits a polygenic inheritance pattern.
What hair texture is commonly associated with hypothyroidism?	Hypothyroidism is commonly associated with dry, brittle hair.
What size of gifts is generally considered acceptable?	Small gifts are generally considered acceptable.
What type of flow volume pattern can be caused by compression atelectasis?	Compression atelectasis can cause a restrictive flow volume pattern.
What type of medication is ketotifen?	Ketotifen is a second-generation antihistamine.
What type of discharge is commonly associated with gonorrhea?	Gonorrhea is commonly associated with a creamy, white, purulent discharge.

Which kidney abnormality is commonly associated with Turner syndrome?	Horseshoe kidney is the kidney abnormality that is associated with Turner syndrome.

Which joint is most commonly affected by pseudogout?	The knee joint is the joint that is most commonly affected by pseudogout.
Which joint complication is commonly associated with tabes dorsalis?	Charcot joint, especially in the knee, is the joint complication that is associated with tabes dorsalis.
What problem can be partially eliminated by using matching during the design of a case-control study?	Confounding can be partially eliminated by using matching during the design of a case-control study.
What is the recommended course of action in cases of intra-amniotic infection with reassuring fetal heart tones?	Induction of labor is warranted in cases of intra-amniotic infection with reassuring fetal heart tones.
What is the definition of vaginismus?	Vaginismus is a condition characterized by dyspareunia due to muscle spasm that prevents vaginal penetration.
What imaging modality is useful for the detection of CNS tumors?	MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is useful for imaging of CNS tumors.
What treatment is used to temporarily increase the platelet count in cases of symptomatic bleeding in immune thrombocytopenic purpura?	IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin) is used to transiently raise the platelet count in cases of symptomatic bleeding in immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

Is there an antidote available to reverse phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade?	No, there is no antidote available to reverse phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade.
What type of medication is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade?	Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade.
What is the recommended treatment for respiratory failure secondary to flail chest?	Mechanical positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is used to manage respiratory failure secondary to flail chest.
What is the diagnostic and treatment modality used for intussusception?	Air enema is used to both diagnose and treat intussusception.
What is the diagnostic test used to differentiate between primary CNS lymphoma and toxoplasmosis?	Brain biopsy is used to differentiate between primary CNS lymphoma and toxoplasmosis.
What imaging modality is used to diagnose vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)?	MRI of the internal auditory canals is used to diagnose vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma).
What scoring system is used to assess an individual's risk for DVT?	The Wells score is used to determine whether an individual is at a high or low risk for DVT.

Which medication is used for prophylaxis of Haemophilus influenzae?	Rifampin is used for prophylaxis of Haemophilus influenzae.
Which medication is used for prevention of RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) in premature infants?	Palivizumab is used for prevention of RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) in premature infants.
What is the typical mode of inheritance of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?	Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
What is the first sign of puberty in girls?	The first sign of puberty in girls is typically breast development (thelarche).
What is the treatment for zero output after a surgery?	The treatment for zero output after a surgery is to unkink the catheter, which will allow the urine to flow.
What is the treatment for a tracheoesophageal fistula?	The treatment for a tracheoesophageal fistula is surgery. Additionally, physicians should look for VACTERL anomalies.
What is the recommended treatment for symptomatic gallstones?	The recommended treatment for symptomatic gallstones is an elective cholecystectomy.
What is the recommended treatment for pyloric stenosis?	The recommended treatment for pyloric stenosis is pyloromyotomy.
What is the recommended treatment for a pilonidal cyst?	The recommended treatment for a pilonidal cyst is drainage followed by resection.
What is the recommended treatment for a perforation?	The recommended treatment for a perforation is an exploratory laparotomy (ex-lap).
What is the recommended treatment for pancreatic head cancer?	The recommended treatment for pancreatic head cancer is the Whipple procedure.
What is the recommended treatment for a pancreatic abscess?	The recommended treatment for a pancreatic abscess is drainage.
What is the recommended treatment for meconium ileus?	The recommended treatment for meconium ileus is a water-soluble Gastrografin enema to help breakdown the obstruction.
What is the recommended treatment for Hirschsprung's disease?	The recommended treatment for Hirschsprung's disease is surgery to remove the aganglionic segment.
What is the recommended treatment for gastroschisis or omphalocele if primary closure cannot be achieved?	The recommended treatment for gastroschisis or omphalocele if primary closure cannot be achieved is to use a silo.

What is the recommended treatment for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus?	The recommended treatment for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus is resection.
What is the recommended treatment for congenital diaphragmatic hernia?	The recommended treatment for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is surgical repair.
What is the recommended treatment for complete small bowel obstruction (SBO)?	The recommended treatment for complete small bowel obstruction (SBO) is an exploratory laparotomy (ex-lap).
What is the recommended treatment for colon cancer?	The recommended treatment for colon cancer is resection of the affected portion of the colon and chemotherapy.
What is the recommended treatment for Boerhaave syndrome?	The recommended treatment for Boerhaave syndrome is definitive surgical repair.
What is the recommended treatment for biliary atresia?	The recommended treatment for biliary atresia is the Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy).
What is the recommended treatment for asymptomatic gallstones?	The recommended treatment for asymptomatic gallstones is typically observation and no intervention.
What is the recommended treatment for anal cancer?	The recommended treatment for anal cancer is either Nigro radiochemotherapy or resection.
What is the recommended treatment protocol for anal cancer?	The recommended treatment protocol for anal cancer is the Nigro chemotherapy regimen using 5-fluorouracil and mitomycin, followed by resection.
What is the recommended treatment for an esophageal perforation?	The recommended treatment for an esophageal perforation is surgical repair, similar to the treatment for Boerhaave syndrome.
What is the recommended treatment if metaplastic changes are observed during an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)?	The recommended treatment for metaplastic changes seen on EGD is high-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy.
What is the recommended treatment if dysplastic changes are observed during an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)?	The recommended treatment for dysplastic changes seen on EGD is local ablation methods.
What is the recommended treatment if carcinoma in situ (CIS) is found on the pathology of a polyp?	The recommended treatment for CIS found on the pathology of a polyp is more frequent screening.
What is the recommended treatment for pulmonary embolism?	The recommended treatment for pulmonary embolism is heparin for prophylaxis (PPX) or as a bridge to Coumadin.
What is the recommended treatment for a clear case of appendicitis?	The recommended treatment for an obvious case of appendicitis is to proceed directly to surgery.
What is the definition of Turcot syndrome?	Turcot syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of gastrointestinal polyps along with glioblastoma multiforme or medulloblastoma.
What is the recommended treatment for bloody diarrhea caused by EHEC?	The recommended treatment for bloody diarrhea caused by EHEC is supportive care.
What is the recommended treatment for Legionnaires' disease?	The recommended treatment for Legionnaires' disease is to use a macrolide or fluoroquinolone antibiotic.
What is the first-line treatment for conversion disorder?	The first-line treatment for conversion disorder is education and self-help techniques.
What are the components of the work-up for pneumonia?	The components of the work-up for pneumonia typically include obtaining a chest X-ray (CXR) and prescribing antibiotics (ABx).
What is the term used to describe the vulvar counterpart of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)?	The term used to describe the vulvar counterpart of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN 1-3).
What is the pathway of venous drainage for the right ovary/testis?	The right ovary/testis drains into the right gonadal vein, which then empties into the inferior vena cava (IVC).

What is the typical range of urine osmolality (in mOsm/kg) in prerenal azotemia?	In prerenal azotemia, the urine osmolality is typically greater than 500 mOsm/kg, which is within the normal range.

What is the typical range of urine osmolality (in mOsm/kg) in early postrenal azotemia?	In early postrenal azotemia, the urine osmolality is typically greater than 500 mOsm/kg, which is considered within the normal range.
What is the usual range of urine osmolality (in mOsm/kg) in acute tubular necrosis (ATN)?	In ATN, the urine osmolality is typically less than 350 mOsm/kg, which is considered low.

What is the typical range of urine Na+ (in mEq/L) in postrenal azotemia?	The typical range of urine Na+ in postrenal azotemia is greater than 40 mEq/L.

What causes hypotension after administration of epidural anesthesia?	The underlying pathophysiology of hypotension after administration of epidural anesthesia is vasodilation and venous pooling.
What causes poor vision for close-up objects (presbyopia) in a patient?	The underlying pathophysiology in a patient that presents with poor vision for close-up objects (presbyopia) is decreased lens elasticity.
What causes Wernicke encephalopathy?	The underlying pathophysiologic cause of Wernicke encephalopathy is thiamine (B1) deficiency.
What causes gallstones in patients on total parenteral nutrition?	The underlying etiology of gallstones in patients on total parenteral nutrition is gallbladder stasis.
What causes aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease?	The underlying etiology of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease is an aspirin-induced prostaglandin/leukotriene imbalance.
What causes altered mental status in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state?	The underlying etiology of altered mental status in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state is hyperosmolality.

What causes variable decelerations on fetal heart tracing?	The underlying cause of variable decelerations on fetal heart tracing is fetal cord compression.

What causes splenomegaly in patients with cirrhosis?	The underlying cause of splenomegaly in patients with cirrhosis is portal hypertension.
What causes nonpitting edema in a newborn patient with Turner syndrome?	The underlying cause of nonpitting edema in a newborn patient with Turner syndrome is congenital lymphedema.
What causes megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia in an alcoholic with normal methylmalonic acid levels?	The underlying cause of megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia in an alcoholic with normal methylmalonic acid levels is folate (B9) deficiency.
What causes megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia in an alcoholic with elevated methylmalonic acid levels?	The underlying cause of megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia in an alcoholic with elevated methylmalonic acid levels is cobalamin (B12) deficiency.

What causes late decelerations on fetal heart tracing?	The underlying cause of late decelerations on fetal heart tracing is placental insufficiency.
What causes hypocalcemia in a patient with hyperphosphatemia and normal renal function?	The underlying cause of hypocalcemia in a patient with hyperphosphatemia and normal renal function is hypoparathyroidism.
What causes hypercoagulability in patients with nephrotic syndrome?	The underlying cause of hypercoagulability in patients with nephrotic syndrome is the loss of antithrombin III in urine.

What causes edema in patients with cirrhosis?	The underlying cause of edema in patients with cirrhosis is hypoalbuminemia, which is a result of synthetic dysfunction.
What causes early decelerations on fetal heart tracing?	The underlying cause of early decelerations on fetal heart tracing is fetal head compression.
What is the usual volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic) of patients with hypercalcemia?	Patients with hypercalcemia typically have a hypovolemic volume status.
What is the most common cause of acromegaly?	The typical underlying etiology of acromegaly is a pituitary somatotroph adenoma, which results in excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH).
What is the usual outcome or prognosis of colitis induced by milk or soy protein in infants?	The typical prognosis of milk- or soy-protein-induced colitis is spontaneous resolution by the time the infant is 1 year old.

What is the expected or typical resolution of postpartum thyroiditis?	The typical outcome of postpartum thyroiditis is a gradual return to a euthyroid state over several months.

What is the typical or usual value for anatomic dead space in milliliters (mL)?	The typical normal value for anatomic dead space is 150 mL.

In what age group and demographic does adenomyosis typically present?	Adenomyosis typically presents in multiparous women who are over the age of 40.
What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has suffered a myocardial infarction (MI) following surgery?	The recommended treatment for a post-operative MI is to perform percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and administer heparin.
What are the three main features of Felty syndrome?	The three main features of Felty syndrome are rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.
What is the recommended treatment and administration route for Chlamydial conjunctivitis?	The recommended treatment for Chlamydial conjunctivitis is oral erythromycin.
What is the prophylactic treatment regimen for diabetic ketoacidosis?	The prophylactic treatment regimen for diabetic ketoacidosis includes potassium.
What medication is included in the treatment plan for acute decompensated heart failure?	The medication included in the treatment plan for acute decompensated heart failure is furosemide (also known as Lasix).

What is the recommended treatment for Trichomonas vaginalis infection in both partners?	The recommended treatment for Trichomonas vaginalis infection in both partners is metronidazole.
What are the recommended treatments for transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN)?	The recommended treatments for transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) include oxygen if needed and occasionally positive pressure ventilation (CPAP).

What is the recommended treatment for osteomyelitis caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)?	The recommended treatment for MRSA osteomyelitis is vancomycin.

What is the recommended treatment for herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis?	The recommended treatment for HSV encephalitis is intravenous (IV) acyclovir.
What is the recommended treatment for Haemophilus influenzae mucosal infections such as epiglottitis and otitis media?	The recommended treatment for Haemophilus influenzae mucosal infections is amoxicillin with or without clavulanate.
What is the recommended treatment for Haemophilus influenzae meningitis?	The recommended treatment for Haemophilus influenzae meningitis is ceftriaxone.
What is the recommended treatment for gastric varices that are secondary to splenic vein thrombosis?	The recommended treatment for gastric varices secondary to splenic vein thrombosis is splenectomy.
What is the recommended treatment for fetal anemia in a pregnant mother with parvovirus infection?	The recommended treatment for fetal anemia in a pregnant mother with parvovirus infection is intrauterine red blood cell (RBC) transfusion.
What is the recommended treatment for enteropathic arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)?	The recommended treatment for enteropathic arthritis is to treat the underlying inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
What is the recommended treatment for endometritis?	The recommended treatment for endometritis is a combination of clindamycin and gentamicin.
What is the recommended treatment for early (blood-borne) Trypanosoma brucei infection?	The recommended treatment for early (blood-borne) Trypanosoma brucei infection is suramin.
What is the recommended treatment for disseminated fungal infections?	The recommended treatment for disseminated fungal infections is amphotericin B.
What is the current recommended approach for the treatment of Dengue fever?	Currently, there is no specific antiviral treatment available for Dengue fever, and the recommended approach is supportive care.
What is the recommended treatment for delirium tremens?	The recommended treatment for delirium tremens is intravenous benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam.
What is the recommended treatment for culture-negative endocarditis caused by Coxiella?	The recommended treatment for culture-negative endocarditis caused by Coxiella is a combination of doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine.
What is the recommended treatment for croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis?	The recommended treatment for mild croup is a combination of cool mist therapy and steroids.
What is the recommended treatment for umbilical granuloma?	The recommended treatment for umbilical granuloma is the application of silver nitrate.
In the case of treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, what is the recommended treatment of choice?	The recommended treatment of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder is the use of clozapine.
What is the recommended treatment for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction?	The recommended treatment for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction is sphincterotomy.
In the case of severe hypovolemic hypernatremia, what is the recommended treatment of choice?	The recommended treatment of choice for severe hypovolemic hypernatremia is the administration of isotonic 0.9% saline solution.

In patients with suspected nocardiasis, what is the recommended treatment of choice?	The recommended treatment of choice for patients with suspected nocardiasis is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

What is the recommended treatment of choice for Naegleria fowleri infection?	The recommended treatment of choice for Naegleria fowleri infection is amphotericin B.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for patients experiencing multiple yearly episodes of recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection?	The recommended treatment of choice for patients experiencing multiple yearly episodes of recurrent HSV infection is once-daily oral valacyclovir.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for mild cases of hypovolemic hypernatremia?	The recommended treatment of choice for mild hypovolemic hypernatremia is D5W, which is a solution of 5% dextrose in water.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for moderate to severe cases of hypovolemic hypernatremia?	The recommended treatment of choice for moderate to severe cases of hypovolemic hypernatremia is 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline solution.

What is the recommended treatment of choice for Dressler's syndrome?	The recommended treatment of choice for Dressler's syndrome is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
What is the recommended treatment of choice for compartment syndrome?	The recommended treatment of choice for compartment syndrome is a surgical procedure called fasciotomy.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for chronic insomnia?	The recommended treatment of choice for chronic insomnia is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).
What is the recommended treatment of choice for an adult with suspected ADHD and a history of substance use disorder?	The recommended treatment of choice for an adult with suspected ADHD and a history of substance use disorder is atomoxetine.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for adjustment disorder?	The recommended treatment of choice for adjustment disorder is psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT).
What is the recommended treatment of choice for acute opioid withdrawal?	The recommended treatment of choice for acute opioid withdrawal is low-dose methadone and adjunctive medications for symptoms.
What is the recommended treatment of choice for acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis with disabling neurologic symptoms?	The recommended treatment of choice for acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis with disabling neurologic symptoms is corticosteroids.

What is the recommended treatment of choice for a pregnant woman with hyperthyroidism in the second or third trimester?	The recommended treatment of choice for a pregnant woman with hyperthyroidism in the second or third trimester is methimazole.
What is the recommended acute treatment of choice for uremic coagulopathy?	The recommended acute treatment of choice for uremic coagulopathy is desmopressin (DDAVP).
What is the recommended treatment for androgen insensitivity syndrome (phenotypic female with 46-XY)?	The recommended treatment for androgen insensitivity syndrome (phenotypic female with 46-XY) is bilateral gonadectomy after puberty.
What is the recommended treatment for Addison's disease (primary adrenocortical insufficiency)?	The recommended treatment for Addison's disease (primary adrenocortical insufficiency) is replacement of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.
What is the recommended treatment for a pigmented skin lesion that has palpable nodularity?	The recommended treatment for a pigmented skin lesion that has palpable nodularity is excisional biopsy.
What is the recommended treatment for Yersinia pestis infection?	The recommended treatment for Yersinia pestis infection is a combination of doxycycline and streptomycin.

What is the recommended treatment for uterine tachysystole?	The recommended treatment for uterine tachysystole is to discontinue uterotonic agents.
What is the recommended treatment for uncomplicated Proteus mirabilis infection?	The recommended treatment for uncomplicated Proteus mirabilis infection is TMP-SMX (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).
What is the recommended management for umbilical hernias in children?	The recommended management for umbilical hernias in children is to monitor for spontaneous resolution by the age of 5.

What is the recommended treatment for tertiary hyperparathyroidism?	The recommended treatment for tertiary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroidectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

What is the recommended treatment for congenital strabismus ("crossed eyes")?	The recommended treatment for congenital strabismus is surgery, which can help to realign the eyes and improve vision.

For a small hydrophilic molecule, what is typically the relative volume of distribution (Vd)?	The relative volume of distribution (Vd) for such a molecule is typically medium.

Is there an increased relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with apocrine metaplasia (fibrocystic changes)?	No, there is no increased relative risk.
In a positively skewed distribution, how are the mean, median, and mode related?	The mean is greater than the median, which is greater than the mode.
In a negatively skewed distribution, how are the mean, median, and mode related?	The mean is less than the median, which is less than the mode.

In Acyclovir activation, which step is rate-limiting?	The rate-limiting step of Acyclovir activation is the phosphorylation of Acyclovir monophosphate by thymidine kinase.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle?	The rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle is Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP shunt?	Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is the rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP shunt.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis?	HMG-CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis?	δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS) is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis?	Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis?	Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase is the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of the process of fatty acid β-oxidation?	The enzyme Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1 (CPT-1) is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid β-oxidation.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of the process of fatty acid synthesis?	Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo synthesis of pyrimidine?	Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo pyrimidine synthesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo synthesis of purine?	Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase is the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo purine synthesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of adrenocortical hormones?	Cholesterol desmolase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of adrenocortical hormones.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme for the Krebs cycle (TCA cycle)?	Isocitrate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme for the Krebs cycle (TCA cycle).
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenolysis?	Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenolysis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenesis?	Glycogen synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis?	HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis.
Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting enzyme for bile acid synthesis?	The rate-limiting enzyme for bile acid synthesis is 7α-hydroxylase.
Which test is used for the rapid diagnosis of Legionnaires' disease?	The urine antigen test is used for the rapid diagnosis of Legionnaires' disease.

What is the normal range for blood glucose levels in mg/dL?	The normal range for blood glucose levels in mg/dL is 70-120 mg/dL.
Why is a sugar (e.g. glucose) phosphorylated to form glucose-6-phosphate?	A sugar, such as glucose, is phosphorylated to form glucose-6-phosphate to prevent it from leaving the cell.
Why is maternal PCO2 decreased during pregnancy?	Maternal PCO2 is decreased during pregnancy to facilitate the elimination of CO2 from the fetus.
Why is cholesterol converted into cholesterol ester?	Cholesterol is converted into cholesterol ester to make it more space-efficient and anhydrous.
Why are bile acids conjugated in the liver?	Bile acids are conjugated in the liver to increase their water solubility.

Among adverse effects associated with inhaled corticosteroids, which one is the most common?	Oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush) is the most common adverse effect associated with inhaled corticosteroids.
Among patients with SLE, what is the most common and severe form of renal disease?	Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) is the most common and severe form of renal disease in patients with SLE.
Among forms of chronic gastritis, which one is the most common (90%)?	Chronic H. pylori gastritis is the most common form of chronic gastritis, accounting for 90% of cases.
Among mutant alleles for α1-antitrypsin, which one is the most clinically significant?	PiZ is the most clinically significant mutant allele for α1-antitrypsin.
What is the most notable symptom of allergic conjunctivitis?	Itching is the most characteristic feature of allergic conjunctivitis.
Among therapies for reducing the progression of diabetic nephropathy, which one is considered the most beneficial?	Strict blood pressure control is considered the most beneficial therapy for reducing the progression of diabetic nephropathy.
For a patient with advanced prostate cancer with bony metastasis, status-post orchiectomy, what is the most appropriate pain management?	Radiation therapy is the most appropriate pain management for a patient with advanced prostate cancer with bony metastasis, status-post orchiectomy.
What is the most accurate method for determining estimated gestational age?	The most accurate method for determining estimated gestational age is by using ultrasound crown-rump measurement in the first trimester.
Which test is considered the most accurate for measuring ejection fraction?	Nuclear ventriculography, specifically the multiple-gated acquisition scan (MUGA), is considered the most accurate test for measuring ejection fraction.
Which test is considered the most accurate for diagnosing PCP pneumonia?	The most accurate test for diagnosing PCP pneumonia is bronchoalveolar lavage with silver stain.
Which test is considered the most accurate for diagnosing thalassemia?	The most accurate test for diagnosing thalassemia is hemoglobin electrophoresis.
Which measurement is considered the most accurate for determining gestational age?	The most accurate measurement for determining gestational age is the crown-rump length measurement obtained through first trimester ultrasound.
Which test is considered the most accurate and the first diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis?	The sweat chloride test, induced via pilocarpine, is considered the most accurate and the first diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis.
Which protein is the most abundant in the human body?	Collagen is the most abundant protein in the human body.
Which immunoglobulin isotype is the most abundant in serum?	The most abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum is IgG.
What is the composition of reduced glutathione at the molecular level?	Reduced glutathione is composed of two molecules of glutathione-sulfhydryl (G-SH).
What is the composition of oxidized glutathione at the molecular level?	Oxidized glutathione is composed of two molecules of glutathione joined together by a sulfur-sulfur bond, forming glutathione-sulfur-sulfur-glutathione (GS-SG).
What could be the possible diagnosis for an elderly patient with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and painless jaundice?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is malignant biliary obstruction (pancreatic, biliary).
What could be the possible diagnosis for an elderly patient with chronic constipation, LLQ abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is acute diverticulitis.
What could be the possible diagnosis for an elderly diabetic with non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and mild renal insufficiency?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is type 4 (hyperkalemic) renal tubular acidosis.
What could be the possible diagnosis for an asymptomatic patient with a slightly elevated TSH despite normal free T3/T4 levels?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is subclinical hypothyroidism.
What could be the possible diagnosis for an adolescent that presents with features of nephrotic syndrome and hepatitis B infection?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is Membranous nephropathy.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a young woman with significant hypertension, amaurosis fugax, and a carotid bruit?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is fibromuscular dysplasia.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a young woman with recurrent headaches, significant hypertension, and a subauricular/carotid systolic bruit?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is fibromuscular dysplasia.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a young patient who has both liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is Wilson disease.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a woman who has a history of recurrent miscarriages and transient ischemic attacks?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is antiphospholipid syndrome.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a tall patient with kyphoscoliosis, neuromas on the lip/tongue, and medullary thyroid cancer?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).
What could be the possible diagnosis for a stillborn fetus with multiple limb fractures and a hypoplastic thoracic cavity?	The likely diagnosis for the fetus' condition is Type II osteogenesis imperfecta.
What could be the possible diagnosis for a stillborn fetus with multiple limb fractures and a hypoplastic thoracic cavity?	The likely diagnosis for the fetus' condition is Type II Osteogenesis Imperfecta.
In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, who suddenly develops dyspnea, hypoxia, and crackles, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the woman's condition is pulmonary edema.
In a post-operative patient presenting with hypotension, JVD, and new-onset right bundle branch block, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is a massive pulmonary embolism.
In a patient with sudden-onset dyspnea and dysphagia and scattered urticaria, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is upper airway obstruction (e.g. laryngeal edema).
In a patient with sinusitis/otalgia, lung nodules/cavitations, and elevated creatinine/hematuria, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener's).
In a patient with scoliosis, long fingers and toes, and upward lens dislocation, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is Marfan syndrome.
In a patient with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and dextrocardia, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is Kartagener syndrome (primary ciliary dyskinesia).
In a patient with QRS widening and peaked T waves on ECG, what could be the possible diagnosis?	The likely diagnosis for the patient's condition is hyperkalemia.
Does an increase in temperature affect testosterone production?	According to research, an increase in temperature does not have a significant effect on testosterone production.
Does an increase in temperature have an effect on sperm production?	Yes, research suggests that an increase in temperature can lead to a decrease in sperm production.
Does an increase in temperature affect inhibin B secretion?	Yes, research indicates that an increase in temperature can lead to a decrease in inhibin B secretion.
Does an increase in serum PO43- have an effect on PTH secretion?	Yes, research suggests that an increase in serum PO43- can lead to an increase in PTH secretion.
Does an increase in heart rate have an effect on cardiac O2 consumption?	Yes, research indicates that an increase in heart rate can lead to an increase in cardiac O2 consumption.
Does an increase in fetal insulin have an effect on surfactant production?	Yes, research indicates that an increase in fetal insulin can lead to a decrease in surfactant production.
Does an increase in contractility have an effect on cardiac O2 consumption?	Yes, research suggests that an increase in contractility can lead to an increase in cardiac O2 consumption.
Does an increase in alveolar ventilation have an effect on arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2?	Yes, research suggests that an increase in alveolar ventilation can lead to a decrease in arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2.
Does an increase in afterload (increased aortic pressure) have an effect on cardiac O2 consumption?	Yes, research suggests that an increase in afterload can lead to an increase in cardiac O2 consumption.
Do hypoxia (low O2) and hypercapnia (high CO2) have an effect on contractility (and SV)?	Yes, research suggests that hypoxia and hypercapnia can lead to a decrease in contractility (and SV).
Do hypoglycemia and starvation have an effect on growth hormone secretion?	Yes, research suggests that hypoglycemia and starvation can lead to an increase in growth hormone secretion.
Does hypocortisolism have an effect on blood pressure?	Yes, research suggests that hypocortisolism can lead to a decrease in blood pressure, which is also known as hypotension.
Does hyperthyroidism have an effect on systemic vascular resistance?	Yes, research suggests that hyperthyroidism can lead to a decrease in systemic vascular resistance.
Does hyperthyroidism have an effect on pulse pressure?	Yes, research suggests that hyperthyroidism can lead to an increase in pulse pressure.
Does hyperglycemia have an effect on serum sodium levels?	Yes, research suggests that hyperglycemia can lead to a decrease in serum sodium levels, which is also known as hyponatremia.
Does Hyper-IgM syndrome have an effect on neutrophil count?	Yes, research suggests that Hyper-IgM syndrome can lead to a decrease in neutrophil count.
Does high lung volumes have an effect on airway resistance?	Yes, research suggests that high lung volumes can lead to a decrease in airway resistance.
Does glucocorticoids have an effect on insulin resistance?	Yes, research suggests that glucocorticoids can lead to an increase in insulin resistance.
Does glucocorticoids have an effect on fibroblast activity?	Yes, research suggests that glucocorticoids can lead to a decrease in fibroblast activity.
Does glucocorticoids have an effect on blood peripheral eosinophil levels?	Yes, research suggests that glucocorticoids can lead to a decrease or reduction in blood peripheral eosinophil levels.
Does glucocorticoids have an effect on blood neutrophil levels?	Yes, research suggests that glucocorticoids can lead to an increase or neutrophilia in blood neutrophil levels.
How do glucocorticoids affect blood neutrophil levels?	Glucocorticoids can lead to an increase or neutrophilia in blood neutrophil levels by decreasing white blood cell adhesion.
Does glucocorticoids have an effect on blood lymphocyte levels?	Yes, research suggests that glucocorticoids can lead to a decrease, especially in T-helper cells, in blood lymphocyte levels.
How does glucagon affect urea production?	Glucagon can lead to an increase in urea production, which is secondary to an increase in gluconeogenesis.
How does ghrelin affect appetite?	Ghrelin can lead to an increase in appetite.
How does exercise affect pulse pressure?	Exercise can lead to a transient increase in pulse pressure.
How does exercise and stress affect growth hormone secretion?	Exercise and stress can lead to an increase in growth hormone secretion.
How does estrogen affect sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels?	Estrogen can lead to an increase in SHBG levels.
How does estrogen affect prolactin secretion?	Estrogen can lead to an increase in prolactin secretion.
How does estrogen affect the production of coagulation factors?	Estrogen can lead to an increase in the production of coagulation factors.
How does estrogen affect levels of LDL?	Estrogen can lead to a decrease in levels of LDL.
How does estrogen affect levels of HDL?	Estrogen can lead to an increase in levels of HDL.
How does estrogen affect bone mineral density?	Estrogen can lead to an increase in bone mineral density.
How does estrogen regulate bone mineral density?	Estrogen can regulate the breakdown of osteoclasts, which can help maintain bone mineral density.
How do endocannabinoids affect appetite?	Endocannabinoids can lead to an increase in appetite, often referred to as "the munchies".
How does emphysema affect lung compliance?	Emphysema can lead to an increase in lung compliance.
How does emphysema affect functional residual capacity (FRC)?	Emphysema can lead to an increase in functional residual capacity (FRC).
How does distributive shock affect pulse pressure?	Distributive shock can lead to an increase in pulse pressure.
How does dilated cardiomyopathy affect contractility?	Dilated cardiomyopathy can lead to a decrease in contractility, often referred to as systolic dysfunction.
How does digoxin affect the PR interval?	Digoxin can lead to an increase in the PR interval.
How does decreased viscosity (e.g. helium inhalation) affect airway resistance?	Decreased viscosity can lead to a decrease in airway resistance.
How does decreased alveolar ventilation affect arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2?	Decreased alveolar ventilation can lead to an increase in arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2.
How does cryptorchidism affect inhibin B levels?	Cryptorchidism can lead to a decrease in inhibin B levels, which is due to decreased Sertoli cell activity.
How does cryptorchidism affect FSH levels?	Cryptorchidism can lead to an increase in FSH levels.
How does cryptorchidism affect fertility? Why?	Cryptorchidism can lead to a decrease in fertility. This is because the increased temperature of the testis impairs spermatogenesis.

How do PTH levels differ between hypoparathyroidism and pseudohypoparathyroidism?	In pseudohypoparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated due to stimulation by hypocalcemia, while in hypoparathyroidism, PTH levels are typically low.
What is the main distinguishing feature between Gram Positive and Gram Negative bacteria?	The main distinguishing feature between Gram Positive and Gram Negative bacteria is the composition of their cell walls.
How do thymine and uracil differ structurally from each other?	Thymine and uracil differ structurally in that thymine has a methyl group, while uracil does not.

When diagnosing biliary strictures, which diagnostic test is considered the test of choice?	The diagnostic test of choice for biliary strictures is magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP).

What is the criteria for diagnosing neonatal hypoglycemia?	The criteria for diagnosing neonatal hypoglycemia is a glucose level of <40 mg/dL.
