What is the diagnostic test of choice for Legionnaires' disease (Legionella pneumophila)?	The definitive test for diagnosing Legionnaires' disease is a sputum culture.
During a lumbar puncture, which is the deepest layer that is crossed?	The arachnoid mater is the deepest layer that is crossed during a lumbar puncture.
What are the possible causes of malignant biliary obstruction?	The differential diagnosis for malignant biliary obstruction includes cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), and metastasis.
Is there a current recommended screening regimen for bladder cancer?	No, there is no current recommended screening regimen for bladder cancer, even in patients with significant smoking and family histories.
What is the treatment for Crigler-Najjar syndrome that is considered curative?	The treatment for Crigler-Najjar syndrome that is considered curative is a liver transplant.
Which patients meet the criteria for long-term maintenance antidepressant therapy?	Patients who have had two or more major depressive episodes meet the criteria for long-term maintenance antidepressant therapy.

Which type of bacteria are covered by Aminoglycosides?	Aminoglycosides provide coverage for aerobic gram-negative bacteria.
What is the recommended head position for a neonate who is receiving positive pressure ventilation?	The recommended head position for a neonate on positive pressure ventilation is the "sniffing" position.

What is the recommended colonoscopy screening protocol for patients with inflammatory bowel disease?	Patients with inflammatory bowel disease should begin colonoscopy screening 8 years after diagnosis and repeat the procedure every 1-2 years.
What is the recommended colonoscopy screening protocol for patients with familial adenomatous polyposis?	Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis should begin colonoscopy screening at age 10-12 and repeat the procedure every year.

What is the active coenzyme form of vitamin B1?	The active coenzyme form of vitamin B1 is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP).
What is the clinical indication for ulipristal?	Ulipristal is used as an emergency contraceptive and is classified as a progesterone receptor modulator.

What is the clinical indication for tramadol?	Tramadol is commonly used for the relief of chronic pain.
What is the clinical indication for pentazocine?	Pentazocine is used for the relief of moderate to severe pain.
What is the clinical indication for orlistat?	Orlistat is used for weight loss.
What is the clinical indication for galantamine, rivastigmine, donepezil, and tacrine?	Galantamine, rivastigmine, donepezil, and tacrine are used for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
What is the clinical indication for butorphanol?	Butorphanol is used for the relief of severe pain such as migraines and labor pain.
What are the clinical features of transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN)?	Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is characterized by grunting and respiratory distress in term neonates delivered by caesarian section.
What are the clinical features of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)?	Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is characterized by grunting and respiratory distress in premature neonates delivered due to perinatal distress.
What are the clinical features of neonatal hypoglycemia?	Neonatal hypoglycemia may be asymptomatic, but it can present with poor feeding, jitteriness, tremors, seizures, and lethargy.
What are the clinical features of Coccidioides infection in an immunocompetent individual?	In an immunocompetent individual, Coccidioides infection can present as pneumonia with arthralgias.
What are the classic signs of placental separation during delivery?	The classic signs of placental separation during delivery include cord lengthening, gushing of vaginal blood, and uterine fundal rebound.
What is the most common symptom observed in caffeine withdrawal?	The most common symptom observed in caffeine withdrawal is a headache.
What is the most common cause of pseudoappendicitis?	The most common cause of pseudoappendicitis is Yersinia enterocolitica.
What is the standard chemotherapy regimen used for treating small cell lung carcinoma?	The standard chemotherapy regimen used for treating small cell lung carcinoma is cisplatin-etoposide therapy.
At body pH, what is the electrical charge of histidine amino acid?	Histidine amino acid has no electrical charge at body pH.
What is the CD4+ count threshold at which candidal esophagitis is likely to develop?	A CD4+ count of less than 100 is the threshold at which candidal esophagitis is likely to develop.
Which virus is responsible for causing verruca (warts)?	The human papillomavirus (HPV) types 1-4 are responsible for causing verruca (warts).
Which organism is responsible for causing primary amoebic meningoencephalitis?	Naegleria fowleri is the organism responsible for causing primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.
In a patient with a high pCO2, what is the underlying cause of premature ventricular contractions?	The underlying cause of premature ventricular contractions in a patient with a high pCO2 is hypoxemia.
What is the underlying cause of pernicious anemia?	The underlying cause of pernicious anemia is the presence of autoantibodies against gastric intrinsic factor or parietal cells.
What is the underlying cause of painful crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia?	Vaso-occlusion is the underlying cause of painful crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia.
In a patient with diabetes mellitus, what is the underlying cause of metabolic acidosis?	The underlying cause of metabolic acidosis in a patient with diabetes mellitus is the increased production of ketoacids.
In severe acute pancreatitis, what is the underlying cause of hypotension?	The underlying cause of hypotension in severe acute pancreatitis is the increased vascular permeability.
Which organism is responsible for causing granulomatous amoebic encephalitis?	Acanthamoeba spp. is responsible for causing granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.
In Potter sequence, what is the underlying cause of death?	The underlying cause of death in Potter sequence is pulmonary hypoplasia.

Which virus is responsible for causing Chickenpox?	The virus responsible for causing Chickenpox is VZV (Varicella-Zoster).
Which bacterium is responsible for causing Bubonic Plague?	The bacterium responsible for causing Bubonic Plague is Yersinia pestis.
Which bacterium is responsible for causing bacterial vaginosis?	The bacterium responsible for causing bacterial vaginosis is Gardnerella vaginalis.
What is the underlying cause of anemia in renal failure?	The underlying cause of anemia in renal failure is low EPO (erythropoietin) levels.

What is a potential skin issue that can arise as a result of taking fludrocortisone?	Hyperpigmentation is a possible skin complication associated with fludrocortisone.

What is a potential complication that may arise in monochorionic twins due to anastomosis?	Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a possible complication of monochorionic twins as a result of anastomosis.

What is a potential risk associated with performing chorionic villus sampling before 9 weeks of gestation?	Limb defects are a possible adverse effect associated with performing chorionic villus sampling before 9 weeks of gestation.
What is the definition of a pilonidal cyst?	A pilonidal cyst is an abscessed hair follicle.
What is a possible explanation for low phenytoin concentration in pregnant patients from a physiological perspective?	During pregnancy, the increase in protein levels that bind to phenytoin can lead to low concentration of phenytoin.
What is a medication-related reason for the development of cataracts?	Long-term use of corticosteroids can cause cataracts.
What is the typical value for total serum calcium level considered normal?	A normal total serum calcium level is around 9 mg/dL.
What is considered a normal baseline heart rate and moderate baseline variability when using electronic fetal monitoring during labor?	A normal baseline heart rate is between 110-160 beats per minute, and moderate baseline variability is observed.
What is a risk factor for Metabolic Syndrome that cannot be modified?	Family history is a non-modifiable risk factor for Metabolic Syndrome.
What is a sign of neurological damage that can result from testicular torsion?	The absence of the cremaster reflex is a neurological consequence of testicular torsion.
Which risk factor for prostate adenocarcinoma can be modified?	Smoking is a modifiable risk factor for prostate adenocarcinoma.
Which risk factor for penile squamous cell carcinoma can be modified?	Smoking is a modifiable risk factor for penile squamous cell carcinoma.
What is a possible symptom or outcome of chronic Brucellosis?	Osteomyelitis is a manifestation of chronic Brucellosis.

What is a potential long-term complication of pancreatitis?	Pancreatic pseudocyst is a late sequelae of pancreatitis.
What is a treatment option that is considered when other treatments have failed for aplastic anemia?	Bone marrow transplant is a last resort treatment for aplastic anemia.

What is a potential symptom or complication of roseola?	One potential symptom or complication of roseola is extreme spiking in the prodrome, which may cause febrile seizures.
What is a potential consequence of malrotation of the intestines?	Malrotation of the intestines can lead to acute torsion and volvulus of the intestines.

What is the fate of most of the LDL receptors that are endocytosed by the cell?	Most of the endocytosed LDL receptors are recycled back to the cell membrane.

Which age and gender group is associated with ankylosing spondylitis?	Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with young adult males.

Which age and gender group is associated with scleroderma?	Scleroderma is associated with middle-aged females, typically between 30-50 years old.
On which day of fetal development is amnion formation characterized?	Amnion formation is characterized on day 8 of fetal development. Therefore, twins that split after day 8 are monoamniotic.

Which class of antibiotics is known to cause teeth discoloration in children?	Tetracyclines are known to cause teeth discoloration in children.
Which class of antibiotics is considered a teratogen and can deposit in fetal teeth and bone?	Tetracyclines are considered a teratogen and can deposit in fetal teeth and bone.
Which class of antibiotics is considered a teratogen and can cause deafness in newborns?	Aminoglycosides are considered a teratogen and can cause deafness in newborns.
Which class or classes of antiarrhythmic drugs are known to prolong QRS duration?	Class I antiarrhythmic drugs, which include subclasses Ia, Ib, and Ic, are known to prolong QRS duration.
Which class of anti-platelet drugs is associated with the potential adverse effect of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)?	ADP receptor inhibitors are associated with the potential adverse effect of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
Which class of anti-platelet drugs is associated with the potential adverse effect of thrombocytopenia?	GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors are associated with the potential adverse effect of thrombocytopenia.
Which class of anti-platelet drugs is associated with the potential adverse effects of facial flushing and abdominal pain?	PDE inhibitors, such as cilostazol and dipyridamole, are associated with the potential adverse effects of facial flushing and abdominal pain.
Which class of antimicrobial drugs is commonly associated with causing acute tubular necrosis?	Aminoglycosides are commonly associated with causing acute tubular necrosis.
Which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs do beta-blockers belong to?	Beta-blockers belong to class II anti-arrhythmic drugs.
Which class of analgesic drugs may potentially contribute to prolonged post-operative ileus?	Opiates are the class of analgesic drugs that may potentially contribute to prolonged post-operative ileus.
Which class of alkylating agents requires bioactivation via non-enzymatic hydroxylation in the liver?	Nitrosoureas are the class of alkylating agents that require bioactivation via non-enzymatic hydroxylation in the liver.
Which chromosomes are classified as acrocentric chromosomes?	Chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22 are classified as acrocentric chromosomes.
On which chromosome is the Ig heavy chain gene located?	The Ig heavy chain gene is located on chromosome 14.
On which chromosome is the cyclin D1 gene located?	The cyclin D1 gene is located on chromosome 11.
On which chromosome is the c-myc gene located?	The c-myc gene is located on chromosome 8.
On which chromosome is the BCL2 gene located?	The BCL2 gene is located on chromosome 18.
What specific chromosomal mutation is responsible for the pathophysiology of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?	The chromosomal mutation responsible for the pathophysiology of CML is t(9;22), which results in the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
Which chromosomal deletion is linked to DiGeorge syndrome?	DiGeorge syndrome is associated with the 22q11 microdeletion.
Which chromosomal abnormality is characterized by clenched hands with overlapping fingers?	The chromosomal abnormality that presents with clenched hands with overlapping fingers is trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome.
Which chromosomal abnormality is frequently linked to endocardial cushion defects?	Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, is commonly associated with endocardial cushion defects.
Which chromosomal abnormality is linked to Patau syndrome?	Patau syndrome is associated with trisomy 13.
Which chromosomal abnormality is characterized by intellectual disability, rocker-bottom feet, cleft lip/palate, and small eyes?	The chromosomal abnormality associated with these features is trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome.
Which chromosomal abnormality is characterized by intellectual disability, prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease?	Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, is associated with intellectual disability, prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease.
Which chromosomal abnormality is characterized by holoprosencephaly/microcephaly, intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, and small eyes?	The chromosomal abnormality associated with these features is trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome.
Which chromosomal abnormality is commonly associated with Edwards syndrome?	Trisomy 18 is the chromosomal abnormality associated with Edwards syndrome.
Which chromosomal abnormality is commonly associated with Down syndrome?	Trisomy 21 is the chromosomal abnormality associated with Down syndrome.
Which childhood malignancy is characterized by an asymptomatic, smooth, non-tender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline?	Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, typically presents with these features.
What finding on chest imaging is considered virtually pathognomonic for asbestosis?	The presence of pleural plaques is the finding on chest imaging that is considered virtually pathognomonic for asbestosis.
Which two chemotherapeutic drugs inhibit eukaryotic topoisomerase II?	Etoposide and teniposide are the two chemotherapeutic drugs that inhibit eukaryotic topoisomerase II.
Which chemotherapeutic drug is commonly used for the treatment of an ectopic pregnancy?	Methotrexate is the chemotherapeutic drug that is used for the treatment of an ectopic pregnancy.
Which chemotherapeutic agent or agents are known to be associated with heart failure characterized by myocyte necrosis and fibrosis?	Anthracyclines, such as doxorubicin and daunorubicin, are known to be associated with heart failure characterized by myocyte necrosis and fibrosis.
Which chemotherapeutic agent or agents are known to be associated with heart failure characterized by myocardial stunning without necrosis?	Trastuzumab is the chemotherapeutic agent that is known to be associated with heart failure characterized by myocardial stunning without necrosis.
Which chemotherapeutic agent is known to potentially cause acute tubular necrosis?	Cisplatin is the chemotherapeutic agent that may cause acute tubular necrosis.
Which characteristics of colonic adenomatous polyps suggest a higher risk of malignancy in terms of growth pattern and histology?	Sessile (non-pedunculated) growth and villous histology are the characteristics of colonic adenomatous polyps that suggest a greater malignant potential.
What specific characteristic of Malassezia furfur makes it a concern for neonates who are receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN)?	Malassezia furfur's lipophilic nature is the characteristic that makes it problematic for neonates receiving TPN.
What specific change occurs during spermiogenesis?	The loss of cytoplasmic contents is a change that occurs during the process of spermiogenesis.
What type of changes in stool are typically observed in individuals with Yellow fever?	Bloody diarrhea is the type of stool changes that are commonly seen with Yellow fever.
Do hyperkalemia or hypokalemia induce arrhythmias?	Both hyperkalemia and hypokalemia can induce arrhythmias.
If a patient's baroreceptor reflex is intact, what change in heart rate is expected during the valsalva maneuver?	An increase in heart rate is expected during the valsalva maneuver if the patient's baroreceptor reflex is intact.
Which change in bowel movement is commonly associated with pellagra, a deficiency of vitamin B3?	Diarrhea is the change in bowel movement that is commonly associated with pellagra, a deficiency of vitamin B3.
Which change in bowel movement is commonly associated with opioid withdrawal?	Diarrhea is the change in bowel movement that is commonly associated with opioid withdrawal.
Which change in bowel movement is commonly associated with the activation of μ-opioid receptors?	Constipation is the change in bowel movement that is commonly associated with the activation of μ-opioid receptors.
Which cervical segment is best evaluated by flexing the neck to 45° and rotating the head?	The C1 (atlas) cervical segment is best evaluated by flexing the neck to 45° and rotating the head.
Which cephalosporins are considered first-line for empiric treatment of meningitis?	Ceftriaxone and Cefotaxime, which are third-generation cephalosporins, are considered first-line for empiric treatment of meningitis.
What is the cephalosporin that should be used to treat endocarditis caused by Strep viridans and HACEK organisms?	Ceftriaxone is the cephalosporin that should be used to treat endocarditis caused by Strep viridans and HACEK organisms.
Which cephalosporin is typically used as prophylaxis prior to abdominal surgery?	Cefoxitin, which belongs to the cephamycin group of cephalosporins, is typically used as prophylaxis prior to abdominal surgery.
Which cephalosporin is useful for surgical prophylaxis due to its long half-life?	Cefazolin is the cephalosporin that has a long half-life, making it useful for surgical prophylaxis.
Which cephalosporin has the ability to bind the altered penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) of MRSA?	Ceftaroline is the cephalosporin that can bind the altered PBPs of MRSA.
Which cephalosporin is effective in treating disseminated Lyme disease?	Ceftriaxone is the cephalosporin that can be used to treat disseminated Lyme disease.
Which cellular organelle serves as the site of synthesis and storage of melanin?	Melanosomes are the cellular organelles that serve as the site of synthesis and storage of melanin.
Which cellular organelle is responsible for the synthesis of Plasmalogens?	The peroxisome is the cellular organelle responsible for synthesizing Plasmalogens.
Which cellular adhesion molecule plays a role in transmigration during leukocyte extravasation?	PECAM-1 (CD31) is the cellular adhesion molecule that aids in transmigration during leukocyte extravasation. It is also known as CD31.
Which cells are responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerves III through XII?	Schwann cells are the cells responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerves III through XII.
Which cells are responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerve II?	Oligodendrocytes are the cells responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerve II.
Which cells are responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerve I?	There are no cells responsible for synthesizing the myelin for cranial nerve I.
Which cells may be present on a pap smear, especially during menses?	Endometrial cells may be present on a pap smear, particularly during menses.
Which cells are predominant in pap smears from postmenopausal women and postpartum women?	Parabasal cells are predominant in pap smears from postmenopausal women and postpartum women.
Which cell type remains in G0 and can only regenerate from stem cells?	Permanent cells remain in G0 and can only regenerate from stem cells.
Which cell type never enters G0 and divides rapidly with a short G1?	Labile cells never enter G0 and divide rapidly with a short G1.
Which cell type is characteristic of a rhabdomyosarcoma?	Rhabdomyoblast is the cell type that is characteristic of a rhabdomyosarcoma.
Which cell type is characteristic of a liposarcoma?	Lipoblast is the cell type that is characteristic of a liposarcoma.
Which cell type enters G1 from G0 when stimulated?	Stable (quiescent) cells are the cell type that enters G1 from G0 when stimulated.
What is the cell morphology of ovarian surface epithelium?	Ovarian surface epithelium has a cuboidal cell morphology.
During which phase of the cell cycle does DNA and histone synthesis occur?	DNA and histone synthesis occur during the S phase of the cell cycle.
In HIV patients, what is the CD4+ cell count associated with CMV retinitis?	A CD4+ cell count of less than 50 cells/mm3 is associated with CMV retinitis in HIV patients.
In cirrhosis, what is the cause of thrombocytopenia?	Thrombocytopenia in cirrhosis is caused by hypersplenism.
What is the cause of the midsystolic click in a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse?	The midsystolic click in a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendinae.
What is the cause of right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain in HELLP syndrome?	The cause of RUQ pain in HELLP syndrome is the distension of the hepatic (Glisson's) capsule.
What are the two causes of prehepatic jaundice?	The two causes of prehepatic jaundice are hemolysis and hematomas.
What are the five causes of post-hepatic disease?	The five causes of post-hepatic disease are gallstones, pancreatic cancer, primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), and strictures.
What are the two causes of intrahepatic jaundice?	The two causes of intrahepatic jaundice are hepatitis and genetic disease.
What is the cause of anal cancer?	The cause of anal cancer is HPV (human papillomavirus).
What is the cause of acute cholecystitis?	The cause of acute cholecystitis is a gallstone that becomes lodged in the cystic duct.
Which viral cause of gastroenteritis is more commonly seen in vaccinated children?	Norovirus is the viral cause of gastroenteritis that is more commonly seen in vaccinated children.
Which viral cause of gastroenteritis is more commonly seen in unvaccinated children?	Rotavirus is the viral cause of gastroenteritis that is more commonly seen in unvaccinated children.
Which viral cause of gastroenteritis is more commonly seen in adults?	Norovirus is the viral cause of gastroenteritis that is more commonly seen in adults.
Which cause of vaginitis is characterized by a positive amine whiff test?	Bacterial vaginosis is the cause of vaginitis that is characterized by a positive amine whiff test.
Which cause of secondary headache involves fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits?	Intracranial abscess is the cause of secondary headache that involves fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits.
Which cause of osteomyelitis is more frequently seen in vertebrae?	Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Pott disease) is the cause of osteomyelitis that is more commonly observed in vertebrae.
Which cause of osteomyelitis is more frequently observed in prosthetic joint replacement?	Staphylococcus epidermidis is the cause of osteomyelitis that is more commonly associated with prosthetic joint replacement.
Which cause of osteomyelitis is more frequently observed in IV drug users and diabetics?	Pseudomonas is the cause of osteomyelitis that is more commonly associated with IV drug users and diabetics.
Which cause of osteomyelitis is more frequently observed in bites from dogs and cats?	Pasteurella multocida is the cause of osteomyelitis that is more commonly associated with bites from dogs and cats.
Which cause of hypoxemia is not significantly improved by administration of supplemental oxygen?	Right-to-left shunt is the cause of hypoxemia that is not greatly helped by supplemental oxygen.
Which cause of free radical injury is commonly observed following thrombolytic therapy?	Reperfusion injury is the cause of free radical injury that is commonly observed following thrombolytic therapy.
Which cause of abnormal uterine bleeding has a slight risk of underlying endometrial cancer?	Endometrial polyps are the cause of abnormal uterine bleeding that has a small risk of underlying endometrial cancer.
Which catecholamine is administered as a treatment for acute, severe asthma exacerbation?	The catecholamine that may be administered to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation is epinephrine.
Which catecholamine is commonly used to treat anaphylactic shock?	The catecholamine that is used to treat anaphylactic shock is epinephrine.
Which catecholamine should be avoided in patients with closed-angle glaucoma due to its mydriatic effect worsening the condition?	The catecholamine that is contraindicated in closed-angle glaucoma is epinephrine.
What specific cardiovascular effects of thyrotoxicosis can lead to the development of systolic hypertension?	The increased myocardial contractility and heart rate associated with thyrotoxicosis can cause systolic hypertension.
Which cardiac pathology is characterized by the enlargement of the heart and dilation of all chambers?	The cardiac pathology that results in global enlargement of the heart and dilation of all chambers is myocarditis.
Which cardiac pathology can develop as a result of uremia, which is associated with renal failure?	Pericarditis is a cardiac pathology that can be a consequence of uremia or renal failure.
Which cardiac pathology can be caused by adenovirus, coxsackie B, parvovirus B19, HIV, and HHV-6?	Myocarditis is the cardiac pathology that can be caused by adenovirus, coxsackie B, parvovirus B19, HIV, and HHV-6.
In patients with skeletal muscle trauma, what is the cardiac complication that is associated with the use of succinylcholine?	The use of succinylcholine in patients with skeletal muscle trauma is associated with the development of cardiac arrhythmia.
Which cardiac complication is shared by Kawasaki disease, sarcoidosis, SLE, and poly/dermatomyositis?	Myocarditis is the cardiac complication that is shared by Kawasaki disease, sarcoidosis, SLE, and poly/dermatomyositis.
What is the name of the cardiac catheterization complication that is characterized by sudden hemodynamic instability and ipsilateral flank/back pain?	Retroperitoneal hematoma is the name of the cardiac catheterization complication that presents with sudden hemodynamic instability and ipsilateral flank/back pain.
Which type(s) of cancer are commonly associated with the presence of atypical glandular cells on Pap testing?	Cervical and endometrial adenocarcinoma are the types of cancer that are associated with atypical glandular cells on Pap testing.
Which type of cancer is commonly treated with continuous leuprolide therapy?	Prostate carcinoma is the type of cancer that may be treated with continuous leuprolide.
Which type of cancer may be linked to IgM-mediated immune hemolytic anemia?	Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is the type of cancer that may be associated with IgM-mediated immune hemolytic anemia.
Which type of cancer is commonly associated with IgG-mediated immune hemolytic anemia?	Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is the type of cancer that may be linked to IgG-mediated immune hemolytic anemia.
Which type of cancer is commonly associated with the genetic condition known as hereditary hemochromatosis?	Hepatocellular carcinoma is the type of cancer that may be linked to hereditary hemochromatosis.
What medical condition can be a potential consequence of administering aspirin to children who have a viral illness?	Reye syndrome is the medical condition that can result from aspirin use in children with a viral illness.
What is a potential cause of uterine distension in cases of placental abruption?	One potential cause of uterine distension in placental abruption is concealed bleeding behind the placenta.
What imaging technique can be employed to identify the location of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue before surgery?	A technetium-99m-sestamibi radionuclide scan can be used to localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue prior to surgery.
In H. pylori triple therapy, what medication can be used as an alternative to penicillin in patients with penicillin allergy?	Metronidazole can be used as an alternative to penicillin in H. pylori triple therapy for patients with penicillin allergy.
What medications can be used for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)?	TMP-SMX (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) or Dapsone can be used for prophylaxis against PCP.
What screening test can be performed for the detection of anal cancer in high-risk patients?	An anal pap smear can be done for screening of anal cancer in high-risk patients.
Which calcium channel blocker can be used in combination with nitrates to produce similar effects as β-blockers?	Verapamil can be combined with nitrates to produce similar effects as β-blockers.
What is the BUN:creatinine ratio that is indicative of prerenal acute kidney injury?	A BUN:creatinine ratio greater than 20:1 is suggestive of prerenal acute kidney injury.
What is the BUN:creatinine ratio that is suggestive of prerenal acute kidney injury?	A BUN:creatinine ratio greater than 20:1 is indicative of prerenal acute kidney injury.
What is the name of the breathing apparatus that is helpful in preventing post-operative atelectasis?	An incentive spirometer is a breathing instrument that is useful for preventing post-operative atelectasis.
Which branchial pouch gives rise to the thymus?	The third branchial pouch, also known as the ventral wing, develops into the thymus.
What is the name of the branchial arch abnormality that is characterized by facial abnormalities and mandibular hypoplasia?	Treacher Collins syndrome is the branchial arch abnormality that is characterized by mandibular hypoplasia and facial abnormalities.
What is the name of the branchial arch abnormality that presents with airway obstruction, cleft palate, micrognathia, and glossoptosis?	Pierre Robin sequence is the branchial arch abnormality that is characterized by cleft palate, airway obstruction, micrognathia, and glossoptosis.
What type of brain injury is commonly caused by traumatic acceleration/deceleration shearing forces?	Diffuse axonal injury is the type of brain injury that is typically caused by traumatic acceleration/deceleration shearing forces.
What is the blood pressure range that defines preeclampsia with severe features?	Preeclampsia with severe features is defined by a blood pressure reading of greater than 160/110 mm Hg.
Which bone tumor is identified by a "sunburst" pattern and Codman triangle on X-ray?	Osteosarcoma is the bone tumor that is characterized by a "sunburst" pattern and Codman triangle on X-ray.
What is the bone condition that is linked to chronic renal failure?	Renal osteodystrophy is the bone pathology that is associated with chronic renal failure.
What is the BMI threshold that warrants hospitalization of a patient with anorexia nervosa?	A BMI of less than 15 kg/m2 is an indication for hospitalization of a patient with anorexia nervosa.
Which blood smear finding is indicative of autoimmune hemolytic anemia?	The presence of spherocytes is consistent with autoimmune hemolytic anemia on a blood smear.
Which blood disorder is linked to ischemic priapism?	Ischemic priapism is associated with sickle cell anemia due to the sickled red blood cells getting trapped in vascular channels.
What bladder and bowel deficits are typically observed in ALS?	ALS typically does not present with any bladder or bowel deficits.
Which bladder deficit is commonly linked to anterior spinal artery occlusion?	Anterior spinal artery occlusion is associated with a spastic bladder.
What are the bladder complications that can arise from prolonged use of cyclophosphamide?	Long-term use of cyclophosphamide can lead to the development of acute hemorrhagic cystitis and bladder carcinoma.
What is the birth weight range that is classified as macrosomia?	Macrosomia is defined as a birth weight greater than 4000 to 4500 grams (or 9 to 10 pounds).
Which bad habit has been linked to an increased risk of cervical cancer?	Smoking is a bad habit that has been associated with a higher risk of developing cervical cancer.
Which bacteria is commonly associated with septic arthritis in older children and adults?	Staphylococcus aureus is a type of bacteria that frequently causes septic arthritis in older children and adults.
Which bacteria produces a toxin that can cleave SNARE proteins in Renshaw cells?	Clostridium tetani is a type of bacteria that releases a toxin capable of cleaving SNARE proteins in Renshaw cells.
Which bacteria is commonly associated with acute prepatellar bursitis?	Staphylococcus aureus is a type of bacteria that is typically responsible for causing acute prepatellar bursitis.
Which type of bacteria is typically responsible for causing subacute endocarditis?	Viridans streptococci are the most common cause of subacute endocarditis.
In intravenous drug users, which bacteria is the most frequent cause of endocarditis?	Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of endocarditis in intravenous drug users.
Among community-acquired pneumonia cases, which bacteria is the most frequent cause?	Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia.
Among community-acquired cases of bacterial meningitis, which bacteria is the most frequent cause?	Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired bacterial meningitis.
Which bacteria is typically responsible for causing acute bacterial parotitis?	Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute bacterial parotitis.
In cases of calculous cholecystitis, which bacteria is often responsible for secondary infections?	E. coli is a common cause of secondary infection in calculous cholecystitis.
Which bacteria is responsible for causing lymphocytosis by producing lymphocytosis-promoting factor?	Bordetella pertussis causes lymphocytosis via production of lymphocytosis-promoting factor.
Which bacteria is responsible for causing acne by producing lipases that break down sebum and releasing proinflammatory fatty acids?	Propionibacterium (Cutibacterium) acnes is the bacteria that causes acne through this mechanism.
In patients with infective endocarditis, which autoimmune antibody may be found at elevated levels?	Rheumatoid factor may be elevated in patients with infective endocarditis.
In cases of granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which autoantibody is typically found at elevated levels?	ANCA, typically c-ANCA, is the autoantibody that is classically elevated in granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
Which CNS tumor, derived from astrocytes, is associated with tuberous sclerosis?	Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas are the astrocyte-derived CNS tumors that are commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.
Which asthma medication has possible side effects that include CNS (central nervous system) stimulation, cardiac arrhythmia, and gastrointestinal disturbances?	Theophylline is the asthma medication that may cause these side effects.
In non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), what is the typical AST:ALT ratio observed?	An AST:ALT ratio of less than 1 is typically seen in NAFLD.
What is the AST:ALT ratio that may indicate heavy alcohol use?	An AST:ALT ratio greater than 2:1 may be indicative of heavy alcohol use.
What is the AST to ALT ratio that may indicate alcohol abuse?	An AST to ALT ratio greater than 2:1 may be indicative of alcohol abuse.
Which arthritic disorder is commonly associated with hematologic malignancies such as polycythemia vera?	It is not gout, but rather rheumatoid arthritis that is commonly associated with hematologic malignancies such as polycythemia vera.
Which artery supplies the medial pons, and via which branches?	The basilar artery supplies the medial pons, and it does so via paramedian pontine branches.
Which artery supplies both the medial and lateral portions of the midbrain?	The posterior cerebral artery supplies both the medial and lateral portions of the midbrain.
Which artery supplies the lateral portion of the pons?	The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) supplies the lateral portion of the pons.
Which artery supplies the lateral portion of the medulla?	The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral portion of the medulla.
Which artery is at risk of injury with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus?	The brachial artery is at risk of injury with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
Which artery branches off the aorta in front of the inferior vena cava (IVC)?	The gonadal artery branches off the aorta anterior to the IVC.
Which arteries supply the medial portion of the medulla?	The anterior spinal artery or vertebral artery can supply the medial portion of the medulla.
In patients with mitral stenosis, what is the common arrhythmia that develops?	Atrial fibrillation is the common arrhythmia that develops in patients with mitral stenosis.
Which parts of the colon are most commonly affected by ischemic colitis?	The splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction are the parts of the colon that are most commonly affected by ischemic colitis.
In a myocardial infarction with ST elevations in leads V1-V4, which area of the myocardium is likely involved?	The anterior area of the myocardium is likely involved, typically due to obstruction of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.
In a myocardial infarction with ST elevations in leads I and aVL, which area of the myocardium is likely involved?	The lateral area of the myocardium is likely involved, typically due to obstruction of the left circumflex artery (LCX).
In which area of the body does the acral lentiginous subtype of melanoma typically develop?	The acral lentiginous subtype of melanoma typically arises on the palms or soles of the feet.
What are the USPSTF recommendations for screening for lipid disorders in men?	The USPSTF recommends screening men for lipid disorders starting at age 35.
What are the USPSTF recommendations for hypertension screening?	The USPSTF recommends screening adults aged 18 and older for hypertension by measuring their blood pressure (Grade A recommendation).
What are two common symptoms associated with Rickettsia spp. infection?	Rash and vasculitis are two specific symptoms commonly associated with Rickettsia spp. infection.
What are two risk factors for cerebral aneurysms that can be modified?	Alcohol consumption and smoking are two modifiable risk factors for cerebral aneurysms.
What are two metabolic conditions that may be contraindications to surgery?	Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and high blood glucose levels are two metabolic contraindications to surgery.
Besides delayed cord clamping, what are two maternal risk factors for neonatal polycythemia?	Maternal hypertension and maternal diabetes mellitus are two maternal risk factors for neonatal polycythemia, other than delayed cord clamping.
What are two infectious agents that can cause erythema multiforme?	Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and Mycoplasma are two infectious causes of erythema multiforme.
What are two significant risk factors for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)?	Prematurity and maternal diabetes mellitus are two important risk factors for respiratory distress syndrome.
What is an example of a fastidious bacteria?	Haemophilus influenzae is an example of a fastidious bacteria.
What are two complications of chickenpox that are more prevalent in adults compared to children?	Pneumonia and encephalitis are two complications of chickenpox that more commonly present in adults.
What are two frequently occurring types of fractures in pediatric patients?	Greenstick fracture and torus fracture are two common pediatric fractures.
What are the typical X-ray findings seen in cases of transient synovitis?	The X-ray findings in cases of transient synovitis are typically normal.
What are the two types of bacterial transduction and how are they classified?	Bacterial transduction is classified into two types: generalized and specialized transduction.
What are the names of the two topical azoles?	The two topical azoles are clotrimazole and miconazole.
In prokaryotes, what are the two initial substrates required for folate synthesis?	The two starting substrates required for folate synthesis in prokaryotes are PABA and pteridine.
Which two gene mutations are most commonly associated with hereditary breast cancer?	The two most commonly associated gene mutations with hereditary breast cancer are BRCA1 and BRCA2.
Can you name the two purine nucleotide monophosphates?	The two purine nucleotide monophosphates are AMP and GMP.
Can you name the two most frequent culprits responsible for secondary bacterial pneumonia?	The two most common causes of secondary bacterial pneumonia are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus.
Can you name the two most frequent causes of chronic kidney disease?	The two most common causes of chronic kidney disease are hypertensive nephrosclerosis and diabetic nephropathy.
Among the various causes of bacterial conjunctivitis, what are the two most common bacteria responsible for this condition?	Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are the two most common bacteria causing bacterial conjunctivitis.
What are the two mechanisms of action of locally-active progestins when used as a contraceptive?	The two mechanisms of action of locally-active progestins as a contraceptive are thickening of cervical mucus and inhibition of ovulation.
In a patient with type 1 diabetes, which two ketone bodies are predominantly produced?	The two major ketone bodies produced in a type 1 diabetic patient are β-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate.
What are the two primary cell types found in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidney?	The two main cell types in the late distal tubule and collecting duct are principal cells and α-intercalated cells.
In Addison's disease, which two main areas of the body experience hyperpigmentation?	The two primary areas that experience hyperpigmentation due to Addison's disease are the skin and mucous membranes.
Which two genetic conditions are linked to an increased risk of surface epithelial cell tumors?	The two genetic conditions associated with an increased risk of surface epithelial cell tumors are BRCA1/2 and Lynch syndrome.
Which two drugs are considered first-line treatments for chronic gout caused by underexcretion?	The two first-line drugs for the treatment of chronic gout due to underexcretion are probenecid and pegloticase.
Which two drugs are considered first-line treatments for chronic gout caused by overproduction?	The two first-line drugs for the treatment of chronic gout due to overproduction are allopurinol and febuxostat.
Which two exotoxins are released by Bacillus anthracis?	The two exotoxins released by Bacillus anthracis are edema factor (EF) and lethal factor (LF).
What are the two different regimens for inpatient treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)?	The two different inpatient PID regimens are cefoxitin/cefotetan and doxycycline.
What are the treatment options for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I?	The treatment options for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I include plasmapheresis and phototherapy.
What are the main treatments for body dysmorphic disorder?	The main treatments for body dysmorphic disorder are cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
What are the treatment options for arsenic and mercury poisoning?	The treatment options for arsenic and mercury poisoning include dimercaprol and succimer (also known as DMSA).
What is the main treatment option for severe cases of polyhydramnios?	The main treatment option for severe cases of polyhydramnios is a procedure called amnioreduction.
What are the main treatment options for closed-angle glaucoma?	The main treatment options for closed-angle glaucoma are α-agonists, β-blockers, and laser surgery.
Which are the two most common sites of metastasis for renal cell carcinoma?	The two most common sites of metastasis for renal cell carcinoma are the lungs and another site.
In sickle cell disease patients, which are the two leading causes of osteomyelitis?	The top two causes of osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease patients are Salmonella (number one) and Staphylococcus aureus.
Which are the three treatment options for retinal artery occlusion?	The three treatment options available for retinal artery occlusion are eyeball massage, carbogen therapy, and surgical therapy.
Which are the three stages of Bordetella pertussis infection?	The three stages of Bordetella pertussis infection are catarrhal stage which lasts for 1-2 weeks, paroxysmal stage, and convalescent stage.
Which are the three risk factors associated with leiomyosarcoma/uterine sarcoma?	The three risk factors associated with leiomyosarcoma/uterine sarcoma are pelvic radiation, tamoxifen use, and postmenopausal patients.
Which are the three prophylactic shots/drops given to neonates?	The three prophylactic shots/drops given to neonates are vitamin K, hepatitis B vaccine, and conjunctivitis prophylaxis (erythromycin).
Which are the three non-modifiable risk factors associated with atherosclerosis?	The three non-modifiable risk factors associated with atherosclerosis are age, genetics, and gender.
Which are the three most common viral etiologies of acute bronchitis?	The three most common viral etiologies of acute bronchitis are influenza A/B, parainfluenza, and adenovirus.
Which are the three most common causes of aseptic meningitis?	The three most common causes of aseptic meningitis are enteroviruses such as poliovirus, coxsackievirus, and echovirus.
Which are the three most common bacterial causes of acute otitis media (AOM)?	The three most common bacterial causes of acute otitis media (AOM) are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.
What are the three main conditions that can precipitate sickling in sickle cell anemia?	The three main conditions that can precipitate sickling in sickle cell anemia are hypoxia, dehydration, and acidosis.
On which three locations does insulin act?	Insulin acts on the liver, muscle, and adipose tissue.
Name the three ketone bodies.	The three ketone bodies are acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone.
What are the three drugs used as outpatient therapy for PID?	The three drugs used as outpatient therapy for PID are ceftriaxone (or other cephalosporins), doxycycline, and metronidazole.
Name three Enteroviruses (picornaviridae family) that are commonly encountered.	Three commonly encountered Enteroviruses (picornaviridae family) are Coxsackie A/B, Polioviruses, and Echovirus.
Name the three auditory ossicles that are present in the middle ear.	The three auditory ossicles that are present in the middle ear are the malleus, incus, and stapes.
What are the three areas of the female genital tract that are commonly affected by HPV?	The three areas of the female genital tract that are commonly affected by HPV are the vulva, vagina, and cervix.
What are the symptoms of Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompetent individuals?	In immunocompetent individuals, Pneumocystis jirovecii infection is usually asymptomatic and does not cause any symptoms.
What is the typical serum CRH level in tertiary adrenal insufficiency?	The typical serum CRH level in tertiary adrenal insufficiency is decreased.
What is the typical serum ACTH level in tertiary adrenal insufficiency?	The typical serum ACTH level in tertiary adrenal insufficiency is decreased.
What are the different routes of administration for heparin and in what situations are they typically used?	Heparin can be administered intravenously (IV) for acute situations.
From which spinal nerve roots does the phrenic nerve arise?	The phrenic nerve arises from the C3, C4, and C5 spinal nerve roots.
What are three common risk factors for mesenteric ischemia?	Three common risk factors for mesenteric ischemia are atherosclerosis, embolic sources, and hypercoagulable disorders.
Which animals serve as reservoirs for the various strains of Brucella spp.?	Farm animals such as cows, pigs, goats, and sheep serve as reservoirs for the various strains of Brucella spp.
What is the recommended frequency for pap smear screening in women with average risk of cervical cancer?	For women between the ages of 21 and 65, it is recommended to have a pap smear every 3 years.
What is the recommended frequency for mammogram screening in women with average risk of breast cancer?	For women between the ages of 50 and 74, it is recommended to have a mammogram every 2 years.
What is the recommended frequency and age range for mammogram screening in women with average risk of breast cancer?	Women between the ages of 50 and 74 should have a mammogram every 2 years.
What is the recommended frequency and age range for Pap smear screening in women with average risk of cervical cancer?	Women between the ages of 21 and 65 should have a Pap smear every 3 years.
What antibiotics are recommended empiric treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis in immunocompromised patients?	The recommended empiric antibiotics for immunocompromised patients with suspected bacterial meningitis are Vancomycin, Ampicillin, and Cefepime.
What are the current recommendations for colorectal cancer screening?	Current recommendations for colorectal cancer screening recommend that adults over the age of 50 undergo regular screening.
Which prophylactic antibiotics are typically administered to a woman with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)?	The standard prophylactic antibiotics given to a woman with PPROM are azithromycin and ampicillin.
What are the available pharmacological treatments for Tourette's syndrome?	The pharmacological options for Tourette's syndrome include antipsychotics, tetrabenazine, and alpha-2-agonists such as guanfacine and clonidine.
Which type of cells are mutated in Hodgkin lymphoma?	Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by mutations in B lymphocytes.
What are the two critical initial steps in managing flail chest?	The two most important initial steps in managing flail chest are pain control and administration of supplemental oxygen.
Which types of low-risk HPV are the most commonly encountered?	The most common types of low-risk HPV are HPV6 and HPV11.
Which renal pathologies are commonly associated with analgesic nephropathy?	The most common renal pathologies seen with analgesic nephropathy are papillary necrosis and chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis.
What are the two most frequently encountered renal pathologies in patients with analgesic nephropathy?	The two most common renal pathologies seen with analgesic nephropathy are papillary necrosis and chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis.
Which symptoms are most commonly observed in patients presenting with pulmonary sarcoidosis?	The most common presenting symptoms of pulmonary sarcoidosis are dyspnea and cough.
Which peripheral artery is most commonly affected by aneurysms?	The popliteal artery is the most common site of peripheral artery aneurysms.
Which conditions are the most frequent causes of referred otalgia?	Dental disease and temporomandibular joint disease are the two most common causes of referred otalgia.
Which two factors are the most common causes of pancreatitis?	Gallstones and alcohol consumption (EtOH) are the two most common causes of pancreatitis.
In children with sickle cell disease, which two organisms are the most common causes of osteomyelitis?	Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in children with sickle cell disease, followed by Salmonella.
In female adults aged 20-50 years old, what are the two most common causes of iron deficiency?	Menorrhagia (excessive menstrual bleeding) and pregnancy are the two most common causes of iron deficiency in this population.
In pregnancy, which two conditions are the most common causes of hyperandrogenism?	Luteomas and theca luteum cysts are the two most common causes of hyperandrogenism in pregnancy.
Which two infections are the most common causes of acute cervicitis?	Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections are the most common causes of acute cervicitis.
In children with sickle cell disease, which two organisms are the most common causes of osteomyelitis?	Salmonella and Staphylococcus aureus are the two most common causes of osteomyelitis in children with sickle cell disease.
Which two organisms are the most commonly associated with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis?	Streptococcus pneumoniae and Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae are the two most common causative organisms associated with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.
Which three organisms are the most commonly associated with acute otitis media?	Streptococcus pneumoniae, nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis are the three most common causative organisms associated with acute otitis media.
What is the most common adverse effect of Fluoroquinolones?	GI upset, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, is the most common adverse effect of Fluoroquinolones.
Which factors are major determinants of autoregulation of blood flow to the kidney?	Myogenic and tubuloglomerular feedback are the two major factors determining autoregulation of blood flow to the kidney.
What is the major cause of chronic pancreatitis in adults?	Alcohol is the major cause of chronic pancreatitis in adults.
Which strains of HPV are considered low-risk?	HPV strains 6 and 11 are considered low-risk.
In hypothyroidism due to thyroiditis or iodine deficiency, what happens to the levels of TSH and why?	The levels of TSH are increased due to negative feedback from the decreased level of free T3.
In hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease or thyroid neoplasm, what happens to the levels of TSH and why?	The levels of TSH are decreased due to negative feedback from the increased level of free T3.
What are the two leading causes of lymphangitis?	The two leading causes of lymphangitis are Streptococcus pyogenes and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).
What are the two key features used to diagnose postrenal failure?	The two key features used to diagnose postrenal failure are anuria and hydronephrosis.
What are the three indications for surgical intervention in necrotizing enterocolitis?	The three indications for surgical intervention in necrotizing enterocolitis are perforation, peritonitis, and clinical worsening despite medical therapy.
Which strains of HPV are considered high-risk?	The high-risk strains of HPV include 16, 18, 31, and 33.
In restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis, what are the typical sizes of the heart chambers?	In both restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis, the ventricles are typically normal in size, while the atria are enlarged.
What are the two main functions of the Vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)?	The Vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) is responsible for both hearing and balance.
What are some of the perfusion-related causes of prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI)?	Some of the perfusion-related causes of prerenal AKI include hypovolemia due to bleeding, cirrhosis, or nephrosis.
What are some of the potential complications of preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)?	Some of the potential complications of PPROM include preterm labor, intraamniotic infection, placental abruption, and umbilical cord prolapse.
On contraction stress testing, what is indicated by early decelerations?	Early decelerations on contraction stress testing are typically indicative of head compression.
What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for reducing cravings during smoking cessation?	Nicotine replacement therapy is considered the first-line pharmacotherapy option for reducing cravings during smoking cessation.
What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for social anxiety disorder?	Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or venlafaxine are considered the first-line pharmacologic treatments for social anxiety disorder.
What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)?	The first-line pharmacologic treatments for PTSD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or venlafaxine.
What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for panic disorder?	Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are considered the first-line pharmacologic treatments for panic disorder.
What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for generalized anxiety disorder?	The first-line pharmacologic treatments for generalized anxiety disorder are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs).
What is the first-line antihypertensive agent that can be given during pregnancy for long-term treatment?	α-methyldopa is considered the first-line antihypertensive agent that can be given during pregnancy for long-term treatment.
What are the first-line agents for maternal hypertensive crisis?	The first-line agents for maternal hypertensive crisis are nifedipine, hydralazine, and labetalol.
What are the typical ESR and CK levels in steroid-induced myopathy and polymyalgia rheumatica?	The typical ESR and CK levels in steroid-induced myopathy and polymyalgia rheumatica are normal.
How do vomiting, diarrhea, or hyperventilation affect serum potassium levels?	Vomiting, diarrhea, or hyperventilation can cause a decrease in serum potassium levels, also known as hypokalemia.
How does severe acute pancreatitis affect serum calcium levels?	Severe acute pancreatitis can cause a decrease in serum calcium levels, also known as hypocalcemia.
How does hypomagnesemia affect serum potassium levels?	Hypomagnesemia can cause a decrease in serum potassium levels, also known as hypokalemia.
How does hyperglycemia (e.g. DKA/HHS) affect serum sodium levels?	Hyperglycemia, such as in DKA/HHS, can cause a decrease in serum sodium levels, also known as hyponatremia (low Na+).
How does adrenal insufficiency affect serum glucose levels?	Adrenal insufficiency can cause a decrease in serum glucose levels, also known as hypoglycemia.
Which drugs/toxins are dialyzable?	NH3 and isopropyl alcohol are examples of dialyzable substances.
What diagnostic test is used for HIV/AIDS in children younger than 18 months old?	The diagnostic test of choice for HIV/AIDS in children younger than 18 months old is DNA PCR.
What is the current recommendation for influenza vaccination in pregnant women?	The current recommendation is that all pregnant women should receive the inactivated (injectable) influenza vaccine.
What structures are found within the femoral triangle?	The femoral triangle contains the femoral nerve, artery, and vein.
What structures are found within the femoral sheath?	The femoral sheath contains the femoral artery, vein, and canal (which houses the deep inguinal lymph nodes).
What are some of the common bacterial pathogens that can cause sinusitis? (List 3)	Some of the common bacterial causes of sinusitis include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.
What are some of the central nervous system (CNS) side effects that can be caused by β-blockers, such as propranolol?	Some of the CNS side effects of β-blockers, including propranolol, may include drowsiness, fatigue/lethargy, and depression.
What are the primary or cardinal movements that a fetus undergoes during the delivery process?	One of the primary movements of the fetus during delivery is engagement.
Which markers are considered the most reliable indicators of resolution of diabetic ketoacidosis?	The serum anion gap and β-hydroxybutyrate levels are considered the best markers for indicating resolution of diabetic ketoacidosis.
How do B/T cell counts typically appear in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)?	In patients with CGD, B/T cell counts are usually normal.
What is one poor outcome that is commonly associated with oligohydramnios?	Umbilical cord compression or prolapse is a poor outcome that is commonly associated with oligohydramnios.
What is the adult derivative of the wall of the metencephalon?	The pons is the adult derivative of the wall of the metencephalon.
What is the adult derivative of the wall of the diencephalon?	The thalamus is the adult derivative of the wall of the diencephalon.
In trauma assessment, what do the ABCs stand for?	The ABCs in trauma assessment stand for Airway, Breathing, and Circulation.
What is one of the 9 (10*) essential amino acids?	Phenylalanine is one of the 9 (10*) essential amino acids.
What are the four locations where mumps is known to replicate?	Mumps is known to replicate in the parotid gland, testes, central nervous system (CNS), and pancreas.
