What condition is suggested by upper posterior vaginal wall prolapse?	Upper posterior vaginal wall prolapse is suggestive of enterocele.
In which part of the spinal cord do upper motoneurons synapse with the cell bodies of lower motoneurons?	Upper motoneurons synapse with the cell bodies of lower motoneurons in the ventral (anterior) horn of the spinal cord.
In what direction do upper motoneurons initially descend in relation to the lower motoneurons they innervate?	Upper motoneurons initially descend contra-lateral to the LMNs they innervate.
What condition is associated with upper lobe cavitation?	Upper lobe cavitation is seen in 2° TB.
What upper airway infections may present with drooling and a "hot-potato" muffled voice?	Epiglottitis, retropharyngeal abscess, and peritonsillar abscess are upper airway infections that may present with drooling and a "hot-potato" muffled voice.
What upper airway condition may improve with racemic epinephrine?	Croup.
What adverse effects can patients experience upon intravenous infusion of Amphotericin B?	Patients can present with fever and chills, hypotension, and headache upon IV infusion of Amphotericin B.
What adverse effects can patients experience upon intrathecal infusion of Amphotericin B?	Patients can present with seizures and headache upon intrathecal infusion of Amphotericin B.
What happens to the partially double-stranded DNA of HBV upon entry into the cell nucleus?	Upon entry into the cell nucleus, the partially double-stranded DNA of HBV is completed by the action of HBV DNA-polymerase.
What happens to the partially double-stranded DNA of HBV upon cellular entry?	Upon cellular entry, the partially double-stranded DNA of HBV is repaired and used for transcription.
What type of anomaly is commonly found in patients with müllerian defects?	Up to 50% of patients with müllerian defects will have a coexisting urologic anomaly.
What is the most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)?	Up to 50% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) occur secondary to chronic hepatitis B infection.
What is the most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)?	Up to 50% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) occur secondary to chronic HBV infection.
What are some of the germline mutations associated with pheochromocytoma?	Up to 25% of cases of pheochromocytoma are associated with germline mutations, including NF-1, VHL, and RET (MEN2A/2B).
What type of myocardial hypertrophy can untreated acromegaly cause?	Untreated acromegaly can cause concentric myocardial hypertrophy.
What type of heart failure can untreated acromegaly with concentric myocardial hypertrophy lead to?	Untreated acromegaly can cause concentric myocardial hypertrophy, leading to diastolic heart failure.
What type of heart failure can occur as a result of untreated acromegaly with concentric myocardial hypertrophy?	Untreated acromegaly can cause concentric myocardial hypertrophy leading to diastolic heart failure.
What is the gestational age limit for the administration of tocolytics in the management of preterm labor?	Tocolytics are given until 34 weeks gestational age in the management of preterm labor.
What are the treatment options for stable and unstable Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?	Unstable WPW is treated with cardioversion. Stable WPW can be treated with Procainamide or ibutilide.
What are the management options for patients with unstable and stable spontaneous abortion?	Unstable spontaneous abortion is managed with suction curettage. Stable spontaneous abortion is managed with expectant or medical management.
What is the recommended management for unstable pneumothorax or hemothorax?	Unstable pneumothorax or hemothorax is managed with needle or thoracostomy (chest tube).
What are the management options for patients with unstable and stable pericardial effusion?	Unstable pericardial effusion is managed with pericardiocentesis. Stable pericardial effusion is managed with pericardial window.
What are the management options for patients with unstable and stable ectopic pregnancy?	Unstable ectopic pregnancy is managed with surgery. Stable ectopic pregnancy is managed with methotrexate.
How is unstable angina characterized in terms of chest pain?	Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs during rest.
What is the potential risk associated with unstable angina?	Unstable angina has a high risk of progression to myocardial infarction.
How does norepinephrine differ from phenylephrine in terms of its effects on the cardiovascular system?	Unlike phenylephrine, norepinephrine causes increased cardiac contractility due to β1 activation which results in increased pulse pressure.
How do focal nodular hyperplasia lesions differ from hepatic adenomas in terms of stability and risk of complications?	Unlike hepatic adenomas, focal nodular hyperplasia lesions are generally stable and are rarely complicated by spontaneous rupture and hemorrhage.
At what point during pregnancy is universal screening for group B Streptococcus colonization typically conducted, and how is it done?	Universal screening for group B Streptococcus colonization is typically done by vaginal and rectal culture at 35-37 weeks gestation.
What is the relationship between uninhibited bladder contractions, urge incontinence, and detrusor muscle hyperactivity?	Uninhibited bladder contractions are synonymous with urge incontinence and are caused by detrusor muscle hyperactivity.
What is a common cause of unilateral, purulent rhinorrhea in young children?	Unilateral, purulent rhinorrhea in a young child is often due to a retained intranasal foreign body.
What condition is suggested by the presence of both unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus?	The presence of both unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus is suggestive of a cerebellopontine tumor.
What is the result of unilateral renal agenesis on the existing kidney?	Unilateral renal agenesis leads to hypertrophy of the existing kidney.
What condition is suggested by the presence of a unilateral pounding headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia?	The presence of a unilateral pounding headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia is suggestive of migraine.
What condition is suggested by the presence of unilateral ear pain and no relief with pulling on the pinna?	The presence of unilateral ear pain and no relief with pulling on the pinna is suggestive of otitis externa.
What type of dysmenorrhea is suggested by the presence of unilateral (nonmidline) pelvic pain?	The presence of unilateral (nonmidline) pelvic pain is suggestive of secondary dysmenorrhea.
What condition is suggested by a uniform distribution of gas?	A uniform distribution of gas is suggestive of paralytic ileus.
What is the half-life of unfractionated heparin?	Unfractionated heparin has a relatively short half-life.
Is unexplained, abnormal vaginal bleeding a contraindication only to hormonal-releasing IUDs?	No, unexplained, abnormal vaginal bleeding is not a contraindication only to hormonal-releasing IUDs.
What is a possible cause of unexplained fever on or after postoperative day 7?	An abdominal abscess is a possible cause of unexplained fever on or after postoperative day 7.
What is the potential outcome of metaplasia progressing to dysplasia under persistent stress?	Under persistent stress, metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and eventually lead to cancer.
What effects do uncoupling agents have on the proton gradient and ATP synthesis?	Uncoupling agents cause a decreased proton gradient and a block of ATP synthesis.
What is the potential consequence of uncorrected patent ductus arteriosus?	Uncorrected patent ductus arteriosus may eventually result in late cyanosis in the lower extremities.
What is the potential consequence of uncorrected left-to-right shunting and what is the name of the syndrome associated with it?	Uncorrected left-to-right shunting can eventually result in reversal, which presents with late cyanosis known as Eisenmenger syndrome.
What is the relationship between uncontrolled maternal diabetes and amniotic fluid volume?	Uncontrolled maternal diabetes can lead to polyhydramnios, an excess of amniotic fluid.
What is the significance of finding unconjugated bilirubin with a high reticulocyte count?	Unconjugated bilirubin with a high reticulocyte count is indicative of hemolysis or hemorrhage.
In what clinical scenario might unconjugated bilirubin be elevated along with a high hemoglobin level?	Elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels with a high hemoglobin level may be indicative of a recent blood transfusion.
What is the significance of finding unconjugated bilirubin with a positive Coombs test?	The presence of unconjugated bilirubin with a positive Coombs test is indicative of isoimmunization.
What is the protein to which unconjugated bilirubin binds and travels in the blood?	Unconjugated bilirubin travels in the blood bound to albumin.
What is the organ responsible for removing unconjugated bilirubin from the blood?	The liver is responsible for removing unconjugated bilirubin from the blood.
What are the recommended treatments for uncomplicated pyelonephritis in outpatient and inpatient settings?	Uncomplicated outpatient pyelonephritis is managed with fluoroquinolones while uncomplicated inpatient pyelonephritis is managed with ceftriaxone.
What is the recommended treatment for uncomplicated diverticulitis in terms of antibiotics?	Uncomplicated diverticulitis is treated with oral (PO) antibiotics.
What are some of the rare side-effects of acyclovir?	Uncommon side-effects of acyclovir include delirium, confusion, vertigo, and hallucinations.
What could be the diagnosis for an uncircumcised penis with a painless ulcer and bilateral inguinal adenopathy?	An uncircumcised penis with a painless ulcer and bilateral inguinal adenopathy could be a sign of penile cancer.
What part of the brain is displaced in cases of uncal herniation and where does it go?	In cases of uncal herniation, the medial temporal lobe (uncus) is displaced under the tentorium cerebelli.
What is UMP converted to in pyrimidine synthesis?	UMP is converted to UDP in pyrimidine synthesis.
What medical condition is umbilical hernia commonly associated with?	Umbilical hernias can be seen in association with Down syndrome.
What is the specific anatomical structure that is defective in individuals with umbilical hernias?	Umbilical hernias are specifically due to a defect in the linea alba.
What are the characteristics of umbilical hernias?	Umbilical hernias are soft, benign, and reducible.
What is the embryonic structure from which umbilical arteries and veins are derived?	Umbilical arteries and veins are derived from the allantois.
What is the potential diagnosis when an ultrasound shows a thin-walled, dilated gallbladder?	An ultrasound showing a thin-walled, dilated gallbladder is suggestive of a distal tumor.
What are the ultrasound characteristics that are consistent with epithelial ovarian carcinoma?	Ultrasound findings consistent with epithelial ovarian carcinoma include a solid mass with thick septations and the presence of ascites.
What is the location of an ulnar nerve lesion that can lead to referred pain in the forearm?	An ulnar nerve lesion at the elbow can lead to referred pain in the forearm.
How is ulcerative colitis typically characterized in terms of abdominal pain location?	Ulcerative colitis is typically characterized by left lower quadrant pain.
Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is always involved in ulcerative colitis, and how far can the inflammation extend proximally?	Ulcerative colitis always involves the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum.
What is the potential consequence of tyramine toxicity in patients who are taking MAO inhibitors?	Tyramine toxicity in patients on MAO inhibitors can precipitate hypertensive crisis.
What enzyme is responsible for the metabolism of tyramine in the gastrointestinal tract?	Tyramine is metabolized by the enzyme MAO-A in the GI tract.
On which day post-fertilization do hCG levels typically rise to detectable levels in serum?	hCG levels typically rise to detectable levels in serum on the 8th day post-fertilization.
What are the typical symptoms of pheochromocytoma?	The typical symptoms of pheochromocytoma include episodic hypertension, recurrent episodes of headaches, diaphoresis, and palpitations.
What is the typical symptom of aldosteronoma?	The typical symptom of aldosteronoma is hypertension.
In which type of dementia should typical antipsychotics not be used, and why?	Typical antipsychotics should not be used in patients with Lewy body dementia because they may exhibit neuroleptic hypersensitivity.
What is the effect of typical antipsychotics on cAMP levels?	Typical antipsychotics result in increased cAMP levels.
What are some symptoms of prolactin excess that may be caused by typical antipsychotics?	Typical antipsychotics may cause symptoms of prolactin excess, such as galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and gynecomastia.
What is the potential effect of typical antipsychotics on seizure threshold?	Typical antipsychotics may cause a decreased seizure threshold.
How does the lipid solubility of typical antipsychotics relate to their half lives?	Typical antipsychotics have high lipid solubility and thus long half lives.
Which receptor do typical antipsychotics block to exert their effects?	Typical antipsychotics exert their effects by blocking the D2 dopamine receptor.
What is the potential consequence of α1-adrenergic blockade associated with typical antipsychotics?	Typical antipsychotics are associated with α1-adrenergic blockade, which may cause orthostatic hypotension.
What are the extrapyramidal symptoms that are associated with typical antipsychotics?	Typical antipsychotics are associated with extrapyramidal symptoms, such as acute dystonia, akathisia, and Parkinsonism.
What is an example of an anti-histamine effect associated with typical antipsychotics?	Typical antipsychotics are associated with anti-histamine effects, such as sedation.
What are examples of anti-cholinergic effects that are associated with typical antipsychotics?	Typical antipsychotics are associated with anti-cholinergic effects, such as dry mouth and constipation.
What condition may typical and atypical antipsychotics be used to treat when it involves intractable or distressing tics?	Typical and atypical antipsychotics may be used to treat intractable or distressing tics associated with Tourette's syndrome.
What type of lipoproteinemia is caused by a deficiency in LPL or apo-CII?	Type I lipoproteinemia is caused by a deficiency in LPL or apo-CII.
What type of MPGN is associated with C3 nephritic factor, and what does this autoantibody stabilize?	Type II MPGN is associated with C3 nephritic factor, an autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase.
What type of familial dyslipidemia presents with tuberoeruptive and palmar xanthomas?	Type III familial dyslipidemia presents with tuberoeruptive and palmar xanthomas.
What type of familial dyslipidemia is caused by a defective Apo E allele?	Type III familial dyslipidemia is caused by a defective Apo E allele.
What type of cells are Type I pneumocytes, and why are they thin?	Type I pneumocytes are squamous cells, which are thin for optimal gas diffusion.
What type of hyperlipoproteinemia is commonly associated with eruptive/pruritic red-orange xanthomas?	Type I hyperlipoproteinemia is commonly associated with eruptive/pruritic red-orange xanthomas.
What type of familial dyslipidemia is characterized by a "creamy" layer in supernatant?	Type I familial dyslipidemia is characterized by a "creamy" layer in supernatant.
What type of hypersensitivity reactions may occur via direct cell cytotoxicity, which involves CD8+ T cells?	Type IV hypersensitivity reactions may occur via direct cell cytotoxicity, which involves CD8+ T cells.
What type of hypersensitivity reactions may occur via delayed-type hypersensitivity, which involves CD4+ T-cells?	Type IV hypersensitivity reactions may occur via delayed-type hypersensitivity, which involves CD4+ T-cells.
What type of familial dyslipidemia is due to hepatic overproduction of VLDL?	Type IV familial dyslipidemia is due to hepatic overproduction of VLDL.
What type of pneumocytes are clustered and cuboidal cells?	Type II pneumocytes are clustered, cuboidal cells.
What type of familial dyslipidemia commonly presents with tendinous xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon?	Type II familial dyslipidemia commonly presents with tendinous xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon.
What type of diabetes mellitus is associated with deposition of amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide) in the islets of the pancreas?	Type II diabetes mellitus is associated with deposition of amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide) in the islets of the pancreas.
What type of familial dyslipidemia is due to either absent or defective LDL receptors or defective Apo B-100?	Type IIa familial dyslipidemia is due to either absent or defective LDL receptors or defective Apo B-100.
Which type of pneumocytes line the alveoli and make up 97% of alveolar surfaces?	Type I pneumocytes line the alveoli and make up 97% of alveolar surfaces.
Which type of muscle fibers are increased in proportion after endurance training?	Type I muscle fibers are increased in proportion after endurance training.
What type of muscle fibers are also known as slow twitch muscle fibers?	Type I muscle fibers are also known as slow twitch muscle fibers.
What is Type I hyperlipoproteinemia also known as?	Type I hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome.
What type of collagen makes up scar tissue and dermis, and what type of collagen makes up skin?	Type I collagen makes up scar tissue and dermis. Type IV collagen makes up skin.
What is Type IV familial dyslipidemia also known as?	Type IV familial dyslipidemia is also known as familial hypertriglyceridemia.
What type of collagen is targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome?	Type IV collagen is targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome.
During lung damage, which type of pneumocytes proliferate?	Type II pneumocytes proliferate during lung damage.
Which type of pneumocytes have regenerative capacity for both type I and type II pneumocytes?	Type II pneumocytes have regenerative capacity for both type I and type II pneumocytes.
Which type of pneumocytes are responsible for the synthesis of pulmonary surfactant?	Type II pneumocytes are responsible for the synthesis of pulmonary surfactant.
Which type of muscle fibers are increased in proportion after weight/resistance training and sprinting?	Type II muscle fibers are increased in proportion after weight/resistance training and sprinting.
What are Type II muscle fibers also known as?	Type II muscle fibers are also known as fast twitch muscle fibers.
What is Type III familial dyslipidemia also known as?	Type III familial dyslipidemia is also known as Dysbetalipoproteinemia.
Which type of familial dyslipidemia presents with increased levels of LDL, cholesterol and VLDL?	Type IIb familial dyslipidemia presents with increased levels of LDL, cholesterol and VLDL.
Which type of familial dyslipidemia presents with increased levels of LDL and cholesterol?	Type IIa familial dyslipidemia presents with increased levels of LDL and cholesterol.
What is Type IIa familial dyslipidemia also known as?	Type IIa familial dyslipidemia is also known as familial hypercholesterolemia.
Which type of diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance?	Type 2 diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance.
Which type of HIT presents earlier (1-2 days) and causes a self-limited thrombocytopenia?	Type 1 HIT presents earlier (1-2 days) and causes a self-limited thrombocytopenia.
Which type of diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin deficiency?	Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin deficiency.
What is confirmed by genetic analysis that shows absence of 3 and 4 Apo alleles?	Type III familial dyslipidemia is confirmed by genetic analysis that shows absence of 3 and 4 Apo alleles.
What are the circulating levels of C3 associated with Type II MPGN?	Type II MPGN is associated with low circulating levels of C3.
What is Type II MPGN also known as?	Type II MPGN is also known as dense deposit disease.
How can Type II HSRs cause pathology?	Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing inflammation by antibodies depositing on cell surfaces, which in turn activates complement.
How can Type II HSRs cause pathology?	Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular dysfunction, causing abnormal blockade or activation/inactivation of downstream cellular processes.
How can Type II HSRs cause pathology?	Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular destruction by opsonizing the target with antibodies.
What deficiency leads to deposition of fibrin on mucous membranes?	Type I plasminogen deficiency leads to deposition of fibrin on mucous membranes.
What causes Type I plasminogen deficiency (hypoplasminogenemia)?	Type I plasminogen deficiency (hypoplasminogenemia) is caused by an autosomal recessive mutation in the PLG gene.
What do Type I Interferons increase cell surface expression of to facilitate recognition of infected cells?	Type I Interferons increase cell surface expression of MHC proteins to facilitate recognition of infected cells.
What do Type I Interferons downregulate to resist potential viral replication?	Type I Interferons downregulate protein synthesis to resist potential viral replication.
How do Type I interferons (IFN-α/IFN-B) work against viral replication?	Type I interferons (IFN-α/IFN-B) work by presensitizing cells to the products of viral replication.
What causes Type I HSR?	Type I HSR occurs due to cross-linking of IgE on presensitized mast cells and basophils by antigen.
What may cause Type 4 RTA?	Type 4 RTA may be caused by low renin levels.
What electrolyte abnormality is associated with Type 4 renal tubular acidosis?	Type 4 renal tubular acidosis is associated with hyperkalemia.
What acid-base disorder is associated with Type 1 RTA?	Metabolic acidosis is associated with Type 1 RTA.
What is the mechanism underlying Type 1 diabetes mellitus?	Type 1 diabetes mellitus is due to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β cells by anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies.
What human leukocyte antigen (HLA) alleles are associated with Type 1 diabetes?	Type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA DR3 and HLA DR4.
What is the effect of TXA2 on blood vessels?	TXA2 causes vasoconstriction.
Which populations are especially important to vaccinate against pneumococcal infections?	Immunocompromised individuals and asplenics.
What are two common side effects of osmotic laxatives?	Two main side effects of osmotic laxatives include diarrhea and dehydration.
What are the two types of excitatory input that enter the cerebellum?	Two kinds of excitatory input enter the cerebellum in the form of climbing fibers and mossy fibers.
What are two simple methods for preventing medication errors?	Two easy ways of preventing medication errors are instructing physicians to avoid the use of unsafe abbreviations and trailing zeros.
What are the two main causes of oral cancer?	Two distinct etiologies of oral cancer are tobacco/alcohol use and HPV (human papilloma virus).
What is the term used to describe twins who share both the placenta and amniotic sac?	Twins who share both the placenta and amniotic sac are called mono-chorionic, mono-amniotic twins.
In what type of twins does twin-twin transfusion syndrome most commonly occur?	Twin-twin transfusion syndrome most commonly occurs in mono-chorionic, di-amniotic twins.
What is the term used to describe twin-twin transfusion syndrome? What is the term used to describe umbilical cord entanglement?	Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is described as mono-chorionic, while umbilical cord entanglement is described as mono-amniotic.
What is the increased risk associated with twin pregnancies due to uterine crowding and overdistension?	Twin pregnancies increase the risk for spontaneous preterm labor because of uterine crowding and overdistension.
What is the typical gestational age at which twin pregnancies are often delivered?	Twin pregnancies are often delivered at 37 weeks.
What are the two types of twin pregnancies?	Twin pregnancies are divided into monozygotic and dizygotic pregnancies.
What type of cells are interspersed with connective tissue in the testis and are responsible for synthesizing and secreting testosterone?	Leydig cells are interspersed with connective tissue in the testis and are responsible for synthesizing and secreting testosterone.
What specific gene is associated with abnormalities in Turner syndrome?	Turner syndrome is associated with abnormalities in the SHOX gene.
What are the two cardiovascular conditions that individuals with Turner syndrome are at an increased risk of developing?	Individuals with Turner syndrome are at an increased risk of developing bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta (infantile).
What is a potential dermatological manifestation that may be seen in individuals with Turner syndrome?	Individuals with Turner syndrome may have melanocytic nevi as a potential dermatological manifestation.
What hormonal markers may be used to diagnose Turner Syndrome?	Turner Syndrome may be diagnosed with high levels of LH (luteinizing hormone) and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone).
What is a potential skeletal manifestation that may be seen in individuals with Turner Syndrome?	Individuals with Turner Syndrome may experience scoliosis as a potential skeletal manifestation.
What medical condition or disorder may be suggested by the presence of turbinate erythema?	Turbinate erythema may be suggestive of cocaine use disorder.
What does it mean when a tumor is considered to be low grade?	When a tumor is considered to be low grade, it means that it is well differentiated.
What does it mean when a tumor is considered to be high grade?	When a tumor is considered to be high grade, it means that it is poorly differentiated, undifferentiated, or anaplastic.
What are tumors of striated muscle known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of striated muscle are known as rhabdomyoma when benign and rhabdomyosarcoma when malignant.
What are tumors of smooth muscle known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of smooth muscle are known as leiomyomas when benign and leiomyosarcomas when malignant.
What are tumors of melanocytes known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of melanocytes are known as a nevus (mole) when benign and a melanoma when malignant.
What are tumors of glandular epithelium known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of glandular epithelium are known as adenomas when benign and adenocarcinomas when malignant.
What are tumors of fat known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of fat are known as lipomas when benign and liposarcomas when malignant.
What are tumors of connective tissue known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of connective tissue are known as fibromas when benign and fibrosarcomas when malignant.
What are tumors of bone known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of bone are known as osteomas when benign and osteosarcomas when malignant.
What are tumors of blood vessels known as when they are benign and when they are malignant?	Tumors of blood vessels are known as hemangiomas when benign and angiosarcomas when malignant.
According to what classification can tumors located near the esophagogastric junction be classified?	Tumors located near the esophagogastric junction can be classified according to the Siewert classification.
How are tumors classified?	Tumors are classified as either benign or malignant.
What defines the degree of localization/spread of a tumor?	Tumor staging defines the degree of localization/spread.
What is tumor grading and what does it define?	Tumor grading is the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity.
What is tumor grade and what does it represent on histology?	Tumor grade is the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity on histology.
What is the role of tumor suppressor genes in cell growth?	Tumor suppressor genes regulate cell growth.
What are the two types of findings that tumor staging is based on?	Tumor staging is based on clinical or pathological findings.
In terms of prognostic factors, which is more important: tumor staging or tumor grading?	Tumor staging is a more important prognostic factor than tumor grading.
What types of cancer treatments are associated with Tumor Lysis Syndrome?	Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most commonly seen in patients undergoing treatment for lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Which types of cancer treatment are most commonly associated with Tumor Lysis Syndrome?	Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most commonly associated with the treatment of lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
What types of cancer treatment are most commonly associated with Tumor Lysis Syndrome?	Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most commonly associated with the treatment of lymphomas and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Which types of cancer treatment are most commonly associated with Tumor Lysis Syndrome?	Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most commonly associated with the treatment of lymphomas and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
What are the methods for preventing or treating Tumor Lysis Syndrome?	Tumor Lysis Syndrome can be prevented or treated with aggressive hydration, xanthine oxidase inhibitors, or rasburicase.
What do tumor cells upregulate to evade anti-tumor T-cells?	Tumor cells upregulate PD-L1 to evade anti-tumor T-cells.
What type of cells can detect and destroy tumor cells that downregulate MHC class I?	Tumor cells that downregulate MHC class I can be detected and destroyed by Natural Killer cells.
How do tumor cells evade C 8+ T-cell immune surveillance?	Tumor cells evade C 8+ T-cell immune surveillance by down-regulating MHC I expression.
What type of factors do tumor cells commonly produce that are necessary for tumor survival and growth?	Tumor cells commonly produce angiogenic factors (ex. FGF / VEGF), which are necessary for tumor survival and growth.
How do tumor cells attach to and destroy the basement membrane?	Tumor cells can attach to laminin and destroy the basement membrane (type IV collagen) via collagenase.
What happens to the concentration of tubular inulin along the PCT as a result of water reabsorption?	Tubular inulin increases in concentration along the PCT as a result of water reabsorption.
How can tubular carcinoma be differentiated from normal breast tissue?	Tubular carcinoma can be differentiated from normal breast tissue by lack of myoepithelial cells and presence of desmoplastic stroma.
What type of neuromuscular blocking agent is tubocurarine?	Tubocurarine is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent.
What are subependymal nodules and how are they related to Tuberous Sclerosis?	Subependymal nodules are CNS hamartomas that line the ventricular system and may present in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis.
What is the increased risk associated with tubal ligation, endometriosis, and PID?	Tubal ligation, endometriosis, and PID increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy.
What are the typical PT and PTT values seen in patients with TTP and HUS?	TTP and HUS typically present with normal PT and normal PTT values.
What is the characteristic bleeding time seen in patients with TTP and HUS?	TTP and HUS present with an increased bleeding time.
What is the typical platelet count seen in patients with TTP and HUS?	TTP and HUS present with a decreased platelet count.
What is the inheritance pattern of TTN gene mutations in familial Dilated Cardiomyopathy?	TTN gene mutations in familial Dilated Cardiomyopathy are autosomal dominant.
What is the second messenger that is increased by TSH?	The second messenger that is increased by TSH is cAMP.
How common are TSH cell, LH-producing, and FSH-producing adenomas?	TSH cell, LH-producing, and FSH-producing adenomas occur, but are rare.
What is the name of the brush-border enzyme on duodenal and jejunal mucosa that converts trypsinogen to trypsin?	The brush-border enzyme on duodenal and jejunal mucosa that converts trypsinogen to trypsin is called enteropeptidase (enterokinase).
What is the effect of trypsin on the cleavage of trypsinogen to trypsin?	Trypsin results in increased cleavage of trypsinogen to trypsin.
What does the presence of trypanosomes on a cardiac biopsy indicate?	The presence of trypanosomes on a cardiac biopsy is indicative of Chagas disease.
Which structure does Trypanosoma cruzi burrow into to cause dilated cardiomyopathy in Chagas disease?	Trypanosoma cruzi burrows into the endocardium to cause dilated cardiomyopathy in Chagas disease.
What are the two subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei?	The two subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei are T. gambiense and T. rhodesiense.
What type of shunt is exemplified by truncus arteriosus?	Truncus arteriosus is an example of a right-to-left shunt.
What is the risk associated with true ventricular aneurysm, a complication that may occur months after a myocardial infarction?	True ventricular aneurysm is a complication that may occur months after an MI and increases the risk for mural thrombus.
Which layers of the vessel wall are involved in true aortic aneurysms?	True aortic aneurysms involve all layers of the vessel wall, including the intima, media, and adventitia.
What is Trousseau Syndrome and what type of thrombosis is associated with it?	Trousseau Syndrome is a condition characterized by migratory thrombosis, specifically superficial thrombophlebitis.
What is the time course for the rise and peak of troponin I levels after a myocardial infarction?	Troponin I levels typically rise between 2-4 hours after an MI and peak at around 24 hours.
How long does it take for troponin I levels to return to normal after a myocardial infarction?	Troponin I levels typically return to normal within 7-10 days following an MI.
What is Tropicamide and what is its mechanism of action?	Tropicamide is a medication that acts as a muscarinic antagonist and is used as a cycloplegic/mydriatic.
What type of anemia is commonly associated with Tropical Sprue?	Tropical Sprue is commonly associated with megaloblastic anemia.
What is the typical preceding event that can lead to the development of Tropical Sprue?	Tropical Sprue classically arises after an episode of infectious diarrhea.
What is the life cycle of Plasmodium and what is the role of schizonts and merozoites in this cycle?	The trophozoites of Plasmodium eventually mature into schizonts, which then rupture the hepatocytes and release merozoites.
What is Tropheryma whipplei and what is its gram stain classification?	Tropheryma whipplei is an intracellular organism that is classified as gram positive.
Who is more commonly affected by Trochanteric bursitis?	Trochanteric bursitis is often seen more in women.
What is the enzyme responsible for joining tRNA with its specific amino acid?	tRNA is joined with its specific amino acid via the enzyme aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.
What are Brushfield spots and with which genetic condition are they associated?	Brushfield spots are elevated white spots on the iris and they are associated with Trisomy 21.
Is overlapping fingers a characteristic feature of Trisomy 13?	No, Trisomy 13 does not have overlapping fingers.
What is the mechanism of action of triptans?	Triptans prevent the release of vasoactive peptides.
What is a potential side effect of triptans?	Triptans may cause mild paresthesias.
What is a potential cardiac adverse effect of triptans?	Triptans may cause coronary vasospasm as an adverse effect.
Which nerve activation do triptans inhibit?	Triptans inhibit trigeminal nerve activation.
What effect do triptans have on cerebral and meningeal vessels?	Triptans induce vasoconstriction of cerebral and meningeal vessels.
In which patients are triptans contraindicated?	Triptans are contraindicated in patients with CAD or Prinzmetal angina.
What type of receptor agonists are triptans (e.g. sumatriptan)?	Triptans (e.g. sumatriptan) are 5-HT1B,D receptor agonists.
What combination of medications can lead to excessive vasoconstriction and increase the risk of HTN, MI, and stroke?	Triptan and ergot or another triptan can lead to excessive vasoconstriction and increase the risk of HTN, MI, and stroke.
How is an allergy to amoxicillin managed in triple therapy treatment?	An allergy to amoxicillin in triple therapy treatment is managed by prescribing a combination of metronidazole and clarithromycin.
What is included in triple therapy for H. pylori?	Triple therapy for H. pylori includes a PPI, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin.
What is included in triple therapy?	Triple therapy includes a PPI and either clarithromycin and amoxicillin or metronidazole.

What medication is Trimethoprim often combined with?	Trimethoprim is often combined with Sulfamethoxazole.
What enzyme does Trimethoprim inhibit?	Trimethoprim inhibits the enzyme Dihydrofolate Reductase.
What teratogenic defects can be produced by Trimethoprim?	Trimethoprim can produce Neural tube defects.
What symptoms of Parkinson's disease are treated by Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine?	Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are useful for treating the tremor and rigidity of Parkinson's disease.
What symptom of Parkinson's disease are Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine NOT useful for treating?	Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are NOT useful for treating the bradykinesia of Parkinson's disease.
What enzyme hydrolyzes triglycerides in chylomicrons and what is released as a result?	Triglycerides in chylomicrons are hydrolyzed by the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), releasing free fatty acids.
What are the components of triglycerides?	Triglycerides are composed of three fatty acids and one glycerol.
What are the "Tri-C" side effects associated with tricyclic antidepressants?	The "Tri-C" side effects associated with tricyclic antidepressants are convulsions, coma, and cardiotoxicity.
Which adrenergic receptor do tricyclic antidepressants antagonize?	Tricyclic antidepressants antagonize the α1 adrenergic receptor.
Which histamine receptor do tricyclic antidepressants antagonize?	Tricyclic antidepressants antagonize the H1 histamine receptor.
For which condition can tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) be used as a treatment option when other medications have failed?	Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) may be used for treatment-resistant depression.

What is the effect of tricuspid atresia on the right ventricle?	Tricuspid atresia leads to right ventricle hypoplasia.
What type of shunt is exemplified by tricuspid atresia?	Tricuspid atresia is an example of a right-to-left shunt.

What is Treponema pallidum and how can it be described?	Treponema pallidum is a spirochete and can be described as spiral-shaped.
What is the characteristic feature of Trendelenburg sign and how is it related to the lesion?	Trendelenburg sign is characterized by tilting of the pelvis contralateral to the lesion.
What is Trendelenburg Gait and how is it related to the location of the lesion?	Trendelenburg Gait is characterized by dropping of the left hip, which indicates a right-sided lesion of the superior gluteal nerve.

What is trehalose and how is it digested by trehalase?	Trehalose is a disaccharide that is broken down into glucose and glucose by the enzyme trehalase.

What are the recommended treatments for Von Gierke disease and how are they administered?	The recommended treatments for Von Gierke disease are frequent oral intake of glucose or cornstarch between meals.
What dietary restrictions are recommended for individuals with Von Gierke disease as part of their treatment?	The recommended dietary restrictions for individuals with Von Gierke disease include avoidance of fructose, galactose, sucrose, and lactose.
What is the recommended treatment for vaginismus?	The recommended treatment for vaginismus is pelvic floor physical therapy.
What is a potential treatment for uric acid kidney stones, particularly in patients with gout?	A potential treatment for uric acid kidney stones, particularly in patients with gout, is allopurinol.
What are the recommended treatments for Tularemia?	The recommended treatments for Tularemia are streptomycin and gentamicin.
What is a potential effect of treating tuberculosis with isoniazid on the acid-fastness of mycobacteria?	Treating tuberculosis with isoniazid can result in mycobacteria losing their acid-fastness, which can be observed on culture.
What is the recommended treatment for TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura)?	The recommended treatment for TTP is plasma exchange.
What is the recommended treatment for the Tuberculoid form of Leprosy?	The recommended treatment for the Tuberculoid form of Leprosy includes Rifampin and Dapsone for a duration of 6 months.
What is the recommended treatment for testicular torsion?	The recommended treatment for testicular torsion is bilateral orchiopexy.
What is the recommended treatment for tension pneumothorax?	The recommended treatment for tension pneumothorax is needle decompression, which leads to thoracostomy (chest tube).
What are the recommended treatments for Streptococcus pneumoniae infection?	The recommended treatments for Streptococcus pneumoniae infection include azithromycin (macrolides) and ceftriaxone (3rd gen. cephalosporin).
What are the treatment options for strabismus?	The treatment options for strabismus include patching or blurring of the normal eye.
What are the recommended topical medications for treating small genital warts?	The recommended topical medications for treating small genital warts include trichloroacetic acid or podophyllin resin.
What is the standard treatment for SIADH and what medication is used as a part of it?	The standard treatment for SIADH includes water restriction and the use of demeclocycline, which is a tetracycline.

What is the standard treatment for Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF)?	The standard treatment for Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) is the use of doxycycline.
What is the standard treatment for right-sided heart failure (HF)?	The standard treatment for right-sided heart failure (HF) is the use of intravenous fluids (IVF).
What are the treatment options for renal failure?	The treatment options for renal failure include dialysis or renal transplant.
What is the recommended treatment for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) associated with sexual intercourse?	The recommended treatment for recurrent UTIs associated with sexual intercourse is postcoital prophylaxis with either TMP-SMX or nitrofurantoin.

What is a part of the treatment for Rabies virus?	Wound cleaning is a part of the treatment for Rabies virus.
What is the treatment for psoas abscess?	The treatment for psoas abscess involves drainage and antibiotics.
What are the treatments for primary dysmenorrhea and PMS?	The treatment for primary dysmenorrhea is NSAIDs, while the treatment for PMS is SSRI.
What is the treatment for postpartum urinary retention that causes overflow incontinence?	The treatment for postpartum urinary retention causing overflow incontinence is urethral catheterization.
What is the potential complication of treating portosystemic shunts with TIPS in cirrhotic patients?	Treating portosystemic shunts with TIPS in cirrhotic patients can potentially precipitate hepatic encephalopathy.
What is the treatment approach for Polymyositis/Dermatomyositis?	The treatment approach for Polymyositis/Dermatomyositis involves corticosteroids followed by long-term methotrexate therapy.
What is the treatment for pneumothorax?	The treatment for pneumothorax is thoracostomy, which involves inserting a chest tube to drain air.
What does treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease prevent the progression of infection to?	Treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease prevents the progression of infection to the uterus and fallopian tubes.
What are the treatment options for pancreatic adenocarcinoma?	The treatment options for pancreatic adenocarcinoma include the Whipple procedure, chemotherapy, and radiation.
What is the treatment for painless thyroiditis?	The treatment for painless thyroiditis is β-blockers.
What is the treatment for non-massive pulmonary embolism?	The treatment for non-massive pulmonary embolism is Xa inhibitor, both in the acute phase and for long-term management.
What is the treatment for neurogenic shock?	The treatment for neurogenic shock is the administration of fluids and pressors.
What are the treatments for neonatal tetanus?	The treatments for neonatal tetanus include antibiotics and tetanus immune globulin.
What are the treatments for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome?	The treatments for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome include positive pressure ventilation, and in some cases, intubation may be necessary.
What is a common treatment for narcolepsy?	A common treatment for narcolepsy involves taking nighttime sodium oxybate (GHB).
What type of medication is typically used for daytime treatment of narcolepsy?	Daytime treatment of narcolepsy typically involves the use of stimulants such as amphetamines or modafinil.
What is a common treatment for maple syrup urine disease?	A common treatment for maple syrup urine disease includes high-dose thiamine supplementation.
What is the common treatment for Kallman syndrome and craniopharyngioma?	The common treatment for Kallman syndrome and craniopharyngioma is hormone replacement therapy.
What is the main treatment for iron deficiency anemia?	The main treatment for iron deficiency anemia involves supplemental iron, such as ferrous sulfate.
What are the common treatments for invasive aspergillosis?	The common treatments for invasive aspergillosis often involve IV voriconazole and an echinocandin (e.g. caspofungin).
What is the treatment for infertility caused by inhospitable mucous?	The treatment for infertility caused by inhospitable mucous is estrogen.
What is the treatment for incompetent cervix that leads to repeated second-trimester pregnancy losses?	The treatment for incompetent cervix that leads to repeated second-trimester pregnancy losses is cerclage at 14 weeks.
What are the common treatments for ileus?	The common treatments for ileus include bowel rest, electrolyte correction, and cholinergic drugs that stimulate intestinal motility.
What are some components of the treatment plan for homocystinuria?	The treatment plan for homocystinuria may include vitamin (B6, B9, B12) supplementation and antiplatelets/anticoagulation.
What is the typical treatment for Hirschsprung disease?	The typical treatment for Hirschsprung disease involves resection of the involved bowel.
What are the components of the treatment plan for hemophilia A?	The treatment plan for hemophilia A may include desmopressin plus recombinant factor VIII.
What medications are typically used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydia?	The typical medications used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydia are ceftriaxone and azithromycin/doxycycline.
What are the potential outcomes of treating GAS with penicillin?	Treating GAS with penicillin may prevent rheumatic fever but not PSGN.
What is the recommended treatment for gas gangrene?	The recommended treatment for gas gangrene is emergency debridement along with administration of penicillin and clindamycin.
What medications are typically used to treat Gardnerella vaginalis?	The typical medications used to treat Gardnerella vaginalis are metronidazole and clindamycin.
What is the second medication typically used in the treatment of Gardnerella vaginalis?	Clindamycin is the second medication typically used in the treatment of Gardnerella vaginalis, in addition to metronidazole.
In what situations should treatment of friends be limited to emergency cases?	Treatment of friends should be limited to emergency situations only when no other physician is available.
What are the treatment options for symptomatic patients with follicular lymphoma?	The treatment options for symptomatic patients with follicular lymphoma include low-dose chemotherapy or rituximab (an anti-CD20 antibody).
What is the focus of treatment for DIC?	The focus of treatment for DIC is to address the underlying cause.
What are the treatment options for DIC?	The treatment options for DIC include transfusion of blood products and cryoprecipitate as needed.
What are the treatment options for cystine kidney stones?	The treatment options for cystine kidney stones include alkalinization of urine and a low sodium diet.
What is a treatment option for cystic fibrosis?	A treatment option for cystic fibrosis is hyper-tonic saline, which facilitates mucus clearing.
What medication is used as an anti-inflammatory agent in the treatment of cystic fibrosis?	Azithromycin is used as an anti-inflammatory agent in the treatment of cystic fibrosis.
What is a β2 agonist that is used in the treatment of cystic fibrosis?	Albuterol is a β2 agonist that is used in the treatment of cystic fibrosis.
What type of enzymes are replaced in the treatment of cystic fibrosis?	Pancreatic enzymes are replaced in the treatment of cystic fibrosis.
What is the treatment for contact dermatitis and what steps are involved in the treatment process?	The treatment for contact dermatitis involves removing the offending agent and, if needed, using topical glucocorticoids to alleviate symptoms.
What is the treatment for Conn syndrome and what medications are used in the treatment process?	The treatment for Conn syndrome involves administering an aldosterone antagonist, such as spironolactone, followed by removal of the aldosterone-secreting tumor.
What is the treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia?	The treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia involves low dose exogenous corticosteroids, also known as replacement therapy.
What is the treatment for circumferential burns?	The treatment for circumferential burns is escharotomy.
What is the treatment of choice for patients with primary CNS lymphoma?	The treatment of choice for patients with primary CNS lymphoma is high-dose methotrexate.
What is the treatment for cavernous sinus thrombosis, and what procedures are involved in the treatment?	The treatment for cavernous sinus thrombosis involves antibiotics and drainage of paranasal sinuses.
What is the recommended treatment for cardiogenic shock?	The recommended treatment for cardiogenic shock is to administer inotropes.
What is the recommended treatment for Brucellosis?	The recommended treatment for Brucellosis includes doxycycline and rifampin.
What is the additional medication that is recommended for the treatment of Brucellosis, along with doxycycline?	The additional medication that is recommended for the treatment of Brucellosis, along with doxycycline, is rifampin.
What areas of the body require prophylaxis during treatment for B-ALL?	During treatment for B-ALL, prophylaxis is required for the scrotum and CSF.
What is an important factor to consider when treating ARDS?	An important factor to consider when treating ARDS is addressing the underlying cause.
What is a common treatment approach for aplastic anemia?	A common treatment approach for aplastic anemia is transfusions of red blood cells (RBCs) and platelets.
What type of treatment options are available for aplastic anemia?	Treatment of aplastic anemia includes marrow-stimulating factors, such as erythropoietin (EPO), granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF).
What is the typical treatment approach for type A aortic dissection?	The typical treatment approach for type A aortic dissection is open surgery.
What is the recommended treatment for a patient who tests negative for Neisseria gonorrhea but positive for Chlamydia trachomatis?	The recommended treatment for a patient who tests negative for Neisseria gonorrhea but positive for Chlamydia trachomatis is azithromycin only.
What are the recommended treatments for urgency incontinence?	The recommended treatments for urgency incontinence include Kegel exercises and bladder training.
What are the recommended treatments for urgency incontinence?	The recommended treatments for urgency incontinence include anti-muscarinics and bladder training (e.g. timed voiding, distraction, or relaxation techniques).
What is the recommended treatment for trichotillomania?	The recommended treatment for trichotillomania is to treat the compulsion and refer the patient to psychiatry.
What is the recommended treatment for torsades de pointes?	The recommended treatment for torsades de pointes includes magnesium sulfate.
What is the recommended treatment for tinea capitis?	The recommended treatment for tinea capitis is oral Griseofulvin (note: NOT topical).
What is the recommended treatment for tick paralysis?	The recommended treatment for tick paralysis is to locate and remove the tick.
What are some of the treatments for stress incontinence?	Some of the treatments for stress incontinence may include weight loss and pessaries.
What is one of the main treatments for stress incontinence?	One of the main treatments for stress incontinence is strengthening pelvic floor/external sphincter muscles (e.g. Kegels).
What is the recommended treatment for a single brain metastasis?	The recommended treatment for a single brain metastasis is resection.
What are some of the treatments for separation anxiety disorder?	Some of the treatments for separation anxiety disorder include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), play therapy, and family therapy.
What is a common treatment for seborrheic dermatitis?	A common treatment for seborrheic dermatitis is selenium shampoo.
What type of nutrients are recommended for increased intake in the treatment of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency?	In the treatment of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, increased intake of ketogenic nutrients is recommended.
What are the first-line treatments for mild psoriasis?	The first-line treatments for mild psoriasis are topical corticosteroids and/or topical Vitamin D analogs.
What are some of the treatments for psoriasis?	Some of the treatments for psoriasis include corticosteroids, PUVA (psoralen + UV-A light), or immune-modulating therapy.
What are the primary treatments for pseudogout?	The primary treatments for pseudogout are NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.
What is the typical treatment approach for phenylketonuria?	The typical treatment approach for phenylketonuria involves a diet low in phenylalanine, along with supplemental tyrosine and possibly tetrahydrobiopterin.
What are the primary treatment options for patients with prolonged QT intervals?	The primary treatment options for patients with prolonged QT intervals include β-blocker therapy and pacemaker placement.
What are the main treatment options for Paget's disease of bone?	The main treatment options for Paget's disease of bone include calcitonin and bisphosphonates.
What are the treatment options for overflow incontinence?	The treatment options for overflow incontinence include catheterization and/or relief of obstruction, such as α-blockers for BPH.
What are the treatment options for obstructive sleep apnea?	The treatment options for obstructive sleep apnea include weight loss, surgery, and CPAP.
What are the treatment options for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	The treatment options for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus include hydration and HCTZ, which is a thiazide diuretic.
What is a crucial aspect of the treatment for medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?	A crucial aspect of the treatment for medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is avoiding fasting.
What is the recommended treatment for localized renal cell carcinoma?	The recommended treatment for localized renal cell carcinoma is surgical resection.
What are the recommended treatments for Legionella pneumophila infection?	The recommended treatments for Legionella pneumophila infection are azithromycin (macrolides) or levofloxacin/moxifloxacin (fluoroquinolones).
What are the other recommended treatments for Legionella pneumophila infection besides azithromycin?	The other recommended treatments for Legionella pneumophila infection besides azithromycin are levofloxacin and moxifloxacin, which are both fluoroquinolones.
What are the recommended treatments for Kawasaki disease?	The recommended treatments for Kawasaki disease are aspirin and IVIG.
What is one of the treatments for hemochromatosis?	One of the treatments for hemochromatosis is repeated phlebotomy.
What is the recommended treatment for femoral neck fracture and why?	The recommended treatment for femoral neck fracture is replacement with a prosthesis to prevent avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
What are some of the treatments for facial nerve palsy?	Some of the treatments for facial nerve palsy include corticosteroids and acyclovir.
What are some of the treatments for eclampsia?	Some of the treatments for eclampsia include blood pressure control, magnesium sulfate for seizure prevention, and expedient delivery.
What is the treatment for E. histolytica infections?	The treatment for E. histolytica infections includes metronidazole for invasive colitis, followed by paromomycin or iodoquinol to eliminate intraluminal cysts.
What are some of the treatments for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder?	Some of the treatments for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder include psychostimulants, antipsychotics, and CBT.
What is the treatment for disorders of fibrinolysis?	The treatment for disorders of fibrinolysis is aminocaproic acid, which blocks activation of plasminogen.
What is the treatment for cystinuria?	The treatment for cystinuria includes urinary alkalinization (e.g. potassium citrate, acetazolamide).
What are some treatments for cutaneous warts?	Some treatments for cutaneous warts include salicylic acid and liquid nitrogen.
What is a treatment option for prevention of compression ulcers?	A treatment option for prevention of compression ulcers is to use a roll.
What are some treatment options for CMV?	Some treatment options for CMV include ganciclovir, valganciclovir, and foscarnet/cidofovir.
What are some treatment options for Chlamydia?	Some treatment options for Chlamydia include azithromycin (first-line), doxycycline (second), and ceftriaxone for possible concurrent N. gonorrhoeae infection.
What are some treatment options for central diabetes insipidus?	Some treatment options for central diabetes insipidus include hydration and desmopressin, which is an ADH analog.
What are some treatment options for Campylobacter jejuni infection?	Some treatment options for Campylobacter jejuni infection include erythromycin or ciprofloxacin.
What are some treatment options for bulimia nervosa?	Some treatment options for bulimia nervosa may include psychotherapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and SSRIs (specifically fluoxetine).
What medication may be included in the treatment for bulimia nervosa?	Fluoxetine (an SSRI) may be included in the treatment for bulimia nervosa, along with psychotherapy and nutritional rehabilitation.
What are some treatment options for binge eating disorder?	Some treatment options for binge eating disorder include cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) with or without SSRIs, as well as lisdexamfetamine.
What is the recommended treatment for aortic stenosis after the onset of complications?	Valve replacement is the recommended treatment for aortic stenosis after the onset of complications.
When is valve replacement recommended as a treatment for aortic regurgitation?	Valve replacement is recommended as a treatment for aortic regurgitation before left ventricular (LV) dysfunction develops.
What type of valve replacement is recommended as a treatment for aortic regurgitation before left ventricular (LV) dysfunction occurs?	Mechanical valve replacement is recommended as a treatment for aortic regurgitation before LV dysfunction occurs.
What does the treatment for anemia of chronic disease involve?	The treatment for anemia of chronic disease involves addressing the underlying cause.
What type of treatment options are available for alopecia areata?	Topical, intralesional, and systemic steroids are treatment options for alopecia areata, depending on the severity.
What are some treatment options for allergic conjunctivitis?	Some treatment options for allergic conjunctivitis include using cold compresses and alternating between warm and cold compresses.
What is the treatment for acute kidney rejection?	The treatment for acute kidney rejection is steroid and antithymocyte.
What are some treatments for acute intermittent porphyria?	Some treatments for acute intermittent porphyria include heme and glucose, which inhibit ALA synthesis.
What is a common treatment for acute exacerbation of Crohn's disease?	Corticosteroids are a common treatment for acute exacerbation of Crohn's disease.
What is a common treatment for acute attacks of multiple sclerosis?	High-dose steroids are a common treatment for acute attacks of multiple sclerosis.
What is the recommended treatment for acute (lactational) mastitis?	The recommended treatment for acute (lactational) mastitis is continued drainage (e.g. feeding) along with antibiotics (e.g. dicloxacillin).
What medications are typically used to treat abdominal abscesses?	Metronidazole, which is effective against B. fragilis, and a gram-negative antibiotic are typically used to treat abdominal abscesses.
What is the recommended treatment for a pheochromocytoma?	The recommended treatment for a pheochromocytoma is surgical excision.
What is the recommended treatment for foreign body aspiration in a child?	The recommended treatment for foreign body aspiration in a child is with rigid bronchoscopy.

Does treating Group A Strep pharyngitis prevent post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)?	Yes, treating Group A Strep pharyngitis does prevent post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
How does Traztusumab work and what is its target?	Traztusumab works by binding to Her2/Neu and prevents it from dimerizing with EGFR.
What neurotransmitter does Trazodone weakly inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of?	Trazodone weakly inhibits the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT).
What type of adrenergic antagonist is Trazodone?	Trazodone is an α1-adrenergic antagonist.
What type of histamine receptor antagonist is Trazodone?	Trazodone is a H1 histamine receptor antagonist.
What adverse effect can be caused by Trazodone?	Trazodone can cause orthostatic hypotension as an adverse effect.
What is the result of traveling through the thick ascending limb of Henle?	Traveling through the thick ascending limb of Henle results in dilution of the tubular fluid.
What is the result of traveling through the early DCT?	Traveling through the early DCT results in dilution of the tubular fluid.
In what type of vessels does traumatic vascular dissection commonly cause ischemic stroke in the young?	Traumatic vascular dissection is a relatively common cause of ischemic stroke in the young, affecting the extracranial vessels.
Where is the most common site of occurrence for traumatic aortic rupture due to trauma and/or deceleration injury?	Traumatic aortic rupture (due to trauma and/or deceleration injury) most commonly occurs at the aortic isthmus.
What are the most common causes of acute monoarthritis in adults?	The most common causes of acute monoarthritis in adults are trauma, infection, and crystals.
How is trauma to the spinal cord assessed and treated?	Trauma to the spinal cord is assessed via MRI and treated via high dose steroids.
What type of platelet dysfunction may trauma cause?	Trauma may cause qualitative platelet dysfunction.

What is the contraindication for Trastuzumab usage?	Trastuzumab is contraindicated with anthracycline usage.
Which receptor is targeted by Trastuzumab, and what is its classification?	Trastuzumab is an IgG monoclonal antibody against the Her2/Neu receptor.
What type of cancer is treated with Trastuzumab (Herceptin), and what is the characteristic feature of this type of cancer?	Trastuzumab (Herceptin) is used to treat HER2+ breast cancer, which is characterized by overexpression of the HER2 protein.

What are the measures that can be taken to prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity?	To prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity, measures that can be taken include administering Amifostine or IV Saline diuresis.

How much cow's milk should children drink per day to decrease the risk of constipation?	To decrease the risk of constipation, children should drink less than 24 oz of cow's milk per day.
What type of breathing do obese patients have to compensate for reduced lung compliance?	To compensate for reduced lung compliance, obese patients have rapid shallow breathing.
How many physical and/or behavioral clinical features are required for a patient to be diagnosed with premenstrual syndrome?	To be diagnosed with premenstrual syndrome, patients require 5 physical and/or behavioral clinical features.
What type of cells release TNF-α, and what are the effects of this cytokine?	TNF-α is a cytokine released from macrophages that mediates cachexia and shock.
What condition is TMP-SMX considered the first line of treatment for?	TMP-SMX is considered the first line of treatment for UTIs.
What type of bacteria do TMP-SMX have activity against, and in which parts of the body are they effective?	TMP-SMX have activity against gram-negative GI and urinary tract bacteria.
What condition in men can TMP-SMX be used to treat?	TMP-SMX can be used to treat acute prostatitis in men.
What is the reason for avoiding TMP-SMX, and what is the potential risk associated with their use?	TMP-SMX should be avoided due to inhibition of folate metabolism, which can make them teratogenic.
During which trimester of pregnancy are TMP-SMX contraindicated, and what is the reason for this?	TMP-SMX are contraindicated in the 1st trimester of pregnancy, due to their effects on folate metabolism.
What is a common cutaneous skin complication that can result from the use of TMP-SMX (sulfonamides)?	Photosensitivity is a common cutaneous skin complication that can result from the use of TMP-SMX (sulfonamides).

What is the clinical administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) known as?	The clinical administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is known as a thrombolytic.
What may tissue in a multinodular goiter autonomously produce?	Tissue in a multinodular goiter may autonomously produce thyroid hormone (T4).
What type of antagonist is Tiotropium and how long-acting is it?	Tiotropium is a long-acting M3 antagonist.
What is the treatment for Tinea capitis in children?	Tinea capitis in children is treated with oral griseofulvin or oral terbinafine.
What part of the body is affected by Tinea pedis?	Tinea pedis affects the foot.
What is Tinea commonly referred to as?	Tinea is commonly referred to as ringworm.
What part of the body is affected by Tinea cruris?	Tinea cruris affects the groin.
What part of the body is affected by Tinea corporis?	Tinea corporis affects the body.
