What parts of the body are affected by Tinea capitis?	Tinea capitis affects the head and scalp.
What type of complications is tight blood glucose control in patients with diabetes most likely to decrease the risk of?	Tight blood glucose control in patients with diabetes is most likely to decrease the risk of microvascular complications.
What type of complications can be reduced by tight blood glucose control in diabetes?	Tight blood glucose control in diabetes can reduce the risk of microvascular complications.
In what type of infections is Tigecycline useful, based on its tissue penetration ability?	Tigecycline is useful for infections that have deep tissue penetration.
What type of bacteria is Tigecycline primarily used for?	Tigecycline is primarily used for bacteria that are multiple-drug resistant.
What type of derivative is Tigecycline and what is it resistant to in bacteria?	Tigecycline is a tetracycline derivative that is resistant to bacterial efflux pumps.
What type of paralysis does Tick-borne paralysis cause?	Tick-borne paralysis causes an ascending paralysis.
Is TIBC elevated in the setting of sideroblastic anemia?	No, TIBC is not elevated in the setting of sideroblastic anemia.
How does Tiagabine exert its effects as an anti-epileptic?	Tiagabine exerts its effects as an anti-epileptic by inhibiting GABA reuptake.
How long does it typically take for a TIA to resolve?	A TIA typically resolves within 24 hours.
Which nuclei of the hypothalamus secrete Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)?	The paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus secrete Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH).
In which fraction of plasma protein are Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb) found?	Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb) are found in the IgG fraction of plasma protein.
What type of cardiomyopathy can be caused by thyrotoxicosis?	Thyrotoxicosis can cause dilated cardiomyopathy.
What type of thyroidism is associated with thyroiditis?	Thyroiditis is associated with hyperthyroidism.
What is the response that leads to a decrease in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion?	The secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is decreased in response to free T3/T4.
What effect does chronic elevation of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) have on the thyroid gland?	Chronic elevation of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) causes hypertrophy/hyperplasia of the thyroid gland due to its trophic effect on the gland.
What is the characteristic feature of psammoma bodies on biopsy of thyroid papillary carcinoma?	Psammoma bodies on biopsy of thyroid papillary carcinoma are characterized by concentric layers of calcification.
What is the characteristic feature of the nuclei of cells lining thyroid papillary carcinoma?	The nuclei of cells lining thyroid papillary carcinoma may have clear, 'Orphan Annie eye' appearance.
What type of cells are involved in the malignant proliferation seen in thyroid medullary carcinoma?	Thyroid medullary carcinoma is a malignant proliferation of parafollicular "C" cells.
What type of thyroid carcinoma is known to invade local structures and cause dysphagia or respiratory compromise?	Thyroid anaplastic carcinoma is known to invade local structures and cause dysphagia or respiratory compromise.
What is the definition of thyroid anaplastic carcinoma?	Thyroid anaplastic carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant tumor of the thyroid gland.
What is the definition of thyroid adenoma?	Thyroid adenoma is a benign solitary growth of the thyroid gland.
What are the symptoms and potential cause of death associated with thyroid storm?	Thyroid storm presents with agitation, delirium, fever, diarrhea, coma, and tachyarrhythmia, which can be a potential cause of death.
What is the role of Thyroid Peroxidase in the synthesis of T4?	Thyroid Peroxidase is involved in the second part of T4 synthesis, generating T3 and T4 bound to thyroglobulin.
What is the therapeutic use of propylthiouracil (PTU) and how does it affect thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase?	Propylthiouracil (PTU) is used therapeutically for the treatment of hyperthyroidism and it inhibits thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase.
Which lymph nodes are commonly affected by lymphatic invasion in thyroid papillary carcinoma?	Thyroid papillary carcinoma often spreads to the cervical nodes (lymphatic invasion).
What is the difference between how thyroid papillary carcinoma and thyroid follicular carcinoma spread?	Thyroid papillary carcinoma spreads via the lymphatic system, while thyroid follicular carcinoma spreads hematogenously.
What is the method used to study thyroid nodules through radioactive uptake studies?	Thyroid nodules may be studied using 131I radioactive uptake studies.
In which type of patients are thyroid nodules almost never cancerous?	Thyroid nodules in hyperthyroid patients are almost never cancerous.
What is more common in thyroid nodules: benignity or malignancy?	Thyroid nodules are more likely to be benign than malignant.
What is the recommended procedure for thyroid nodules larger than 1 cm with high risk sonographic features (ultrasound)?	Thyroid nodules >1 cm with high risk sonographic features (ultrasound) should undergo fine-needle aspiration (FNA).
How is a thyroid nodule with normal or elevated TSH managed?	A thyroid nodule with normal or elevated TSH is managed with FNA.
What hormone do thyroid medullary carcinomas secrete?	Thyroid medullary carcinomas secrete calcitonin.
In which population groups are thyroid masses more likely to be malignant?	Thyroid masses are much more likely to be malignant in males and children.
What is the effect of thyroid hormones on bone growth and development?	Thyroid hormones stimulate bone maturation as a result of ossification and fusion of the growth plates.
Which receptors in the heart are upregulated by thyroid hormones to increase cardiac output?	Thyroid hormones induce synthesis (upregulation) of β1-adrenergic receptors in the heart to increase cardiac output.
Which cells in the thyroid gland are responsible for the synthesis of thyroid hormones?	The follicular epithelial cells of the thyroid gland are responsible for the synthesis of thyroid hormones.
What is the role of thyroid hormones (T3/T4) in the development of the body?	Thyroid hormones (T3/T4) play a role in the development of the central nervous system (CNS).
What is the result of the synergistic action of thyroid hormone, growth hormone, and somatomedins?	The synergistic action of thyroid hormone, growth hormone, and somatomedins promotes bone formation.
Which receptors in the heart are upregulated by thyroid hormone?	Thyroid hormone stimulates upregulation of B1 receptors in the heart.
What is the effect of thyroid hormone on glucose absorption from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract?	Thyroid hormone increases glucose absorption from the GI tract to meet the metabolic demands of increased O2 consumption.
What are the processes that are increased by thyroid hormone, which may provide sources of ATP?	Thyroid hormone increases the processes of glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, proteolysis, and lipolysis, all of which may provide sources of ATP.
What is the mechanism by which thyroid hormone increases basal metabolic rate (BMR)?	Thyroid hormone increases basal metabolic rate (BMR) via increased activity of Na/K-ATPase.
What is the similarity between the actions of thyroid hormone and the sympathetic nervous system?	Thyroid hormone has many of the same actions as the sympathetic nervous system because it upregulates β1 adrenergic receptors.
What is a thyroid follicular adenoma?	A thyroid follicular adenoma is a benign tumor of follicles surrounded by a fibrous capsule.
What type of goiter may be caused by thyroid adenoma, cancer, and cysts?	Nodular.
Where does thyroglobulin synthesis occur in the thyroid follicular cells as part of thyroid hormone synthesis?	Thyroglobulin synthesis occurs in the RER and Golgi apparatus of the thyroid follicular cells.
What conditions are associated with thymoma, a benign neoplasm of the thymus?	Thymoma is associated with myasthenia gravis, SVC syndrome, pure red cell aplasia and Good syndrome.
What is the function of Thymidylate Synthase, and what substrates does it use to catalyze its reaction?	Thymidylate Synthase is an enzyme that catalyzes the methylation of dUMP to dTMP, utilizing the methyl group from a methylated-THF.
What are the potential side effects of using thymidine synthesis inhibitors such as MTX, 5-FU, and hydroxyurea?	Thymidine synthesis inhibitor use can result in myelo-suppression and pan-cytopenia.
What is the secondary messenger through which TSH exerts its actions on the thyroid gland?	The secondary messenger through which TSH exerts its actions on the thyroid gland is cAMP.
What is the secondary messenger involved in propagating the signal of the angiotensin II-bound AT1 receptor?	The secondary messenger involved in propagating the signal of the angiotensin II-bound AT1 receptor is IP3/Ca2+.
What is the secondary messenger through which the ADH-bound V2 receptor propagates its signal?	The secondary messenger through which the ADH-bound V2 receptor propagates its signal is cAMP.
What is the secondary messenger involved in propagating the signal of the ADH-bound V1 receptor?	The secondary messenger involved in propagating the signal of the ADH-bound V1 receptor is IP3/Ca2+.
What is the secondary messenger through which glucagon exerts its actions on liver and adipose tissue?	The secondary messenger through which glucagon exerts its actions on liver and adipose tissue is cAMP.
What are the secondary messengers involved in initiating the action of GHRH on somatotrophs?	The secondary messengers involved in initiating the action of GHRH on somatotrophs are both cAMP (primarily) and IP3/Ca2+.
What is the secondary messenger through which CRH exerts its actions on the anterior pituitary?	The secondary messenger through which CRH exerts its actions on the anterior pituitary is cAMP.
What is the secondary messenger through which ACTH exerts its actions on the adrenal cortex?	The secondary messenger through which ACTH exerts its actions on the adrenal cortex is cAMP.
What is the secondary messenger through which ANP exerts its actions?	The secondary messenger through which ANP exerts its actions is cGMP.
What is the secondary messenger through which PTH exerts its actions on bone and kidney tissue?	The secondary messenger through which PTH exerts its actions on bone and kidney tissue is cAMP.
Which receptor does the sympathetic nervous system activate to increase heart rate?	The sympathetic nervous system activates the β1 adrenergic receptor to increase heart rate.
Which receptor does the parasympathetic nervous system activate to decrease heart rate?	The parasympathetic nervous system activates the M2 muscarinic receptor to decrease heart rate.
What is the hormone through which growth hormone exerts its growth promoting effects?	The hormone through which growth hormone exerts its growth promoting effects is insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1).
What is the effect of thromboxane A2 on platelets?	Thromboxane A2 promotes platelet aggregation.
Which enzyme synthesizes thromboxane A2 within platelets?	Thromboxane A2 is synthesized within platelets by the enzyme COX 1.
What is the effect of thromboxane A2 when it is released upon platelet degranulation?	Thromboxane A2 causes platelet aggregation and activation.
What is the effect of thromboxane A2 on blood vessels?	Thromboxane A2 acts as a vasoconstrictor.
Which platelet enzyme is responsible for synthesizing Thromboxane A2 (TXA2)?	Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is synthesized by the platelet enzyme cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1).
What is the laboratory finding associated with Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?	Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is associated with elevated serum LDH.
Which artery is commonly affected in thrombotic ischemic strokes?	Thrombotic ischemic strokes commonly affect the middle cerebral artery.
Where does thrombosis most commonly occur in the leg below the knee?	Thrombosis most commonly occurs in the deep veins (DVT) of the leg below the knee.
What is the characteristic feature of thrombosis, and what are the components of this feature?	Thrombosis is characterized by lines of Zahn, which are alternating layers of platelets/fibrin and RBCs.
What is the defining characteristic of thrombosis in relation to a vessel wall?	Thrombosis is characterized by attachment to a vessel wall.
What condition is suggested by the presence of thrombosis and a history of miscarriages?	Thrombosis and a history of miscarriages is suggestive of antiphospholipid syndrome.
What is the function of thrombopoietin, and where is it produced?	Thrombopoietin stimulates megakaryocyte proliferation and is made in the liver.
What effect do thrombolytics have on PT and PTT levels?	Thrombolytics result in an elevated PT and elevated PTT.
How do thrombolytics exert their effects on the body, and what substance is involved in this process?	Thrombolytics exert their effects via direct or indirect conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.
In which group of patients are thrombolytics contraindicated, and why?	Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with severe hypertension.
What are the situations in which thrombolytics are contraindicated, and why?	Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with recent surgery or head trauma.
In which group of patients are thrombolytics contraindicated, and what condition should be absent in these patients?	Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with any signs of active bleeds.
How is thrombocytopenia defined, and what is the platelet count threshold used to diagnose it?	Thrombocytopenia is defined as a platelet count < 150,000 uL.
In the context of severe eclampsia, what is the significance of thrombocytopenia, and how does it impact expectant management?	Thrombocytopenia in severe eclampsia is a contraindication to expectant management.
What is the timeframe for performing thrombectomy in cases of large strokes?	Thrombectomy is done for large strokes within 24 hours.
What types of bacterial infections are individuals with Leukocyte adhesion deficiency susceptible to, and which body parts are particularly affected?	Those with Leukocyte adhesion deficiency are susceptible to bacterial invasion, particularly nonpurulent skin and mucosal infections.
What prophylactic treatment should individuals in close contact with those infected with Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) receive?	Those in close contact with individuals infected with Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) should receive prophylactic macrolides (erythromycin).
What is the most common location for compression of structures that leads to Thoracic outlet syndrome?	Thoracic outlet syndrome most commonly occurs due to compression of structures within the scalene triangle.
What syndrome can result from thoracic aortic surgery?	Thoracic aortic surgery can lead to anterior spinal cord syndrome.
What is the potential consequence of thoracic aortic aneurysms extending proximally and blocking the coronary artery ostia?	Thoracic aortic aneurysms may extend proximally and block the coronary artery ostia leading to ischemic heart disease.
What disease is thoracic aortic aneurysm classically seen in patients with, and what is the underlying cause?	Thoracic aortic aneurysm is classically seen in patients with tertiary syphilis due to endarteritis of the vasa vasorum.
What type of inherited disorders are associated with thoracic aneurysm?	Thoracic aneurysm is associated with inherited connective tissue disorders.
What properties of Thiopental, a barbiturate, contribute to its rapid onset and duration of action?	Thiopental is a barbiturate with a rapid onset and duration of action due to high potency and high lipid solubility.
What effect does Thiopental have on cerebral blood flow?	Thiopental causes decreased cerebral blood flow.
What is the mechanism by which Thiocyanate and perchlorate interfere with the synthesis of thyroid hormones?	Thiocyanate and perchlorate are competitive inhibitors of the Na+-I- cotransport pump, thus interfering with the synthesis of thyroid hormones.
What is the term used to describe the thinning of the cervix during labor?	Effacement is the term used to describe the thinning of the cervix during labor.
What is the characteristic appearance of glioblastomas on MRI?	Thick peripheral rim enhancement is the characteristic appearance of glioblastomas on MRI.
How do thiazolidinediones enhance glucose uptake in peripheral tissues?	Thiazolidinediones enhance glucose uptake in peripheral tissues by causing increased insulin sensitivity.
What is the risk associated with thiazolidinediones use that affects the extremities?	Thiazolidinediones use can increase the risk of atypical extremity fractures.
What is a possible side effect in the extremities associated with thiazolidinediones use?	Thiazolidinediones use can cause fluid retention and thus peripheral edema as a possible side effect in the extremities.
What are the potential side effects associated with thiazolidinediones (glitazones) use?	Thiazolidinediones (glitazones) use can cause weight gain and increased Liver Function Tests as potential side effects.
What is a potential side effect associated with thiazolidinediones (glitazones) use?	Thiazolidinediones (glitazones) use can cause weight gain as a potential side effect.
What medical condition can be worsened by thiazolidinedione-induced fluid retention?	Thiazolidinedione-induced fluid retention can exacerbate heart failure.
What is the effect of thiazide diuretics on the diluting capacity of the nephron?	Thiazide diuretics decrease the diluting capacity of the nephron.
What is a potential adverse effect of thiazide diuretics?	Thiazide diuretics may cause hyper-calcemia as an adverse effect.
In what medical condition may thiazide diuretics be useful in treatment?	Thiazide diuretics may be useful in the treatment of idiopathic hypercalciuria.
What is the effect of thiazide diuretics on Ca2+ reabsorption or excretion?	Thiazide diuretics increase Ca2+ reabsorption.
What is the potential use of thiazide diuretics in the treatment of heart failure?	Thiazide diuretics can be useful in the symptomatic treatment of heart failure, although loop diuretics are first line.
To which binding site of the Na+-Cl- cotransporter do thiazide diuretics attach?	Thiazide diuretics attach to the Cl--binding site of the Na+-Cl- cotransporter.
What type of drugs are thiazide diuretics and what is the potential risk of allergic reactions associated with them?	Thiazide diuretics are sulfa drugs, and as such, may rarely cause allergic reactions.
How do thiazide and loop diuretics affect the delivery of Na+ to principal cells?	Thiazide and loop diuretics increase the delivery of Na+ to principal cells.
What is the role of thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) in glycolysis, and which enzyme does it act as a cofactor for?	Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) acts as a cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase in glycolysis.
How many coccygeal pairs of spinal nerves are present in humans?	In humans, there is one coccygeal pair of spinal nerves.
How many umbilical veins and arteries are present in the human body?	In the human body, there is one umbilical vein and two umbilical arteries.

What does the QT interval on an ECG represent?	The QT interval on an ECG represents the entire period of ventricular depolarization, contraction, and repolarization.
What does the QRS complex on an ECG represent?	The QRS complex on an ECG represents ventricular depolarization.
Which mitochondrial enzyme complex links glycolysis and the TCA cycle?	The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a mitochondrial enzyme complex linking glycolysis and the TCA cycle.
What is the pulse pressure?	The pulse pressure is the difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures.
Which part of the nephron is responsible for about 30% of Mg2+ reabsorption?	The proximal tubule of the nephron is responsible for approximately 30% of Mg2+ reabsorption.
What is the proteasome and what is its function?	The proteasome is a barrel-shaped protein complex that degrades damaged or ubiquitin-tagged proteins.
What is the function of the prostate gland in male reproductive system?	The prostate gland adds a slightly alkaline secretion to sperm ejaculate, which is rich in citrate, calcium, and enzymes.
Which artery gives rise to the right gastric artery?	The proper hepatic artery gives rise to the right gastric artery.
What is a progenitor B cell and what are its characteristics?	A progenitor B cell is a type of B cell that lacks cytoplasmic μ and surface IgM/IgD.
What is the pre-central gyrus and which part of the brain does it belong to?	The pre-central gyrus is the area of the primary motor cortex located in the frontal lobe of the brain.
What is a precursor B cell and what is its defining characteristic?	A precursor B cell is a type of B cell that is characterized by the presence of cytoplasmic μ.
Which aspect of the prostate gland can be palpated during a digital rectal exam (DRE)?	The posterior aspect of the prostate gland can be palpated during a digital rectal exam (DRE).
In cases of knee dislocation, which artery is frequently injured?	The popliteal artery is commonly injured due to a knee dislocation.
What enzymes are encoded by the pol gene of HIV?	The pol gene of HIV encodes the enzymes reverse transcriptase, aspartate protease, and integrase.
What is the function of the pneumotaxic center and where is it located?	The pneumotaxic center is located in the upper pons of the brainstem and its function is to inhibit inspiration.
What structures in E. coli allow for attachment to the urinary tract?	The pili/fimbria in E. coli allow for attachment to the urinary tract.
What is the peripheral nervous system composed of and what structures does it give rise to?	The peripheral nervous system consists of the cranial and spinal nerves, which give rise to axons and neurons.
What is the perineurium and what does it surround in a peripheral nerve?	The perineurium is a layer of connective tissue and it surrounds a fascicle of nerve fibers in a peripheral nerve.
What is the pericardial cavity and where is it located?	The pericardial cavity is a space that lies between the parietal and visceral layers of the serous pericardium.
What is the pectinate line and how is it formed?	The pectinate (dentate) line is a junctional line that is formed where the anal endoderm (hindgut) meets the ectoderm.
What is the driving force for the diffusion of a gas?	The partial pressure gradient is the driving force for the diffusion of a gas.

What structure stabilizes the proximal radioulnar joint?	The proximal radioulnar joint is stabilized by the annular ligament.

What are the typical symptoms of the prodrome (onset) of HIV?	The typical symptoms of the prodrome (onset) of HIV consist of flu or mono-like symptoms with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever.

What is the primary disturbance in respiratory acidosis and what does it result in?	The primary disturbance in respiratory acidosis is hypoventilation, which results in increased CO2.
What are the primary disturbances in metabolic alkalosis?	The primary disturbances in metabolic alkalosis are an increase in HCO3- or a decrease in H+.
What is the primary disturbance in metabolic acidosis?	The primary disturbance in metabolic acidosis is a decrease in HCO3-.
What is the primary cause of pseudogout (CPPD)?	The primary cause of pseudogout (CPPD) is most commonly idiopathic.
What is the primary cause of neuroleptic malignant syndrome?	The primary cause of neuroleptic malignant syndrome is antagonism of dopamine (D2) receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway.

What indicates adequate sampling in a pap smear?	The presence of glandular endocervical cells in a pap smear indicates adequate sampling.
What does the presence of the heart sound S3 indicate in middle-aged or older adults?	The presence of the heart sound S3 in middle-aged or older adults indicates volume overload.

What are the three main components that make up the juxtaglomerular apparatus?	The juxtaglomerular apparatus is composed of JG cells, macula densa, and extraglomerular mesangial cells.
Through which opening does the jugular vein exit the skull?	The jugular vein exits the skull through the jugular foramen.
Where does the IVC drain into, and at what level does this occur?	The IVC, or inferior vena cava, drains into the right atrium just above the level of the diaphragm at T8.
What are the sensory organs used by the inverse muscle stretch reflex to monitor muscle tension?	The inverse muscle stretch reflex uses Golgi tendon organs to monitor muscle tension.
What type of proteins can stimulate the intrinsic GTPase activity of Ras?	The intrinsic GTPase activity of Ras can be stimulated by GTPase Activating Proteins (GAPs).
When does the intravascular hemolysis caused by paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria typically occur?	The intravascular hemolysis caused by paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria occurs episodically, often while sleeping.
What type of immune response does the intranasal influenza vaccine induce?	The intranasal influenza vaccine induces a humoral and cell-mediated response.
What is the term used to describe the calcification that often occurs in the intimal plaque responsible for causing atherosclerosis?	The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis often undergoes dystrophic calcification.
What are the two main components of the intimal plaque responsible for causing atherosclerosis?	The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis consists of a necrotic lipid core (mostly cholesterol) with a fibromuscular cap.
Where does the intestinal type of gastric carcinoma most commonly arise in the stomach?	The intestinal type of gastric carcinoma most commonly arises on the lesser curvature of the antrum.
What type of receptors are predominantly expressed in the internal urethral sphincter?	The internal urethral sphincter predominantly expresses alpha1 receptors.
How do the intermolecular forces between liquid molecules lining the lung compare to the forces between liquid and air?	The intermolecular forces between liquid molecules lining the lung are much stronger than the forces between liquid and air.
In what type of tissue is the intermediate filament Vimentin found?	The intermediate filament Vimentin is found in mesenchymal tissue.
In what type of cells is the intermediate filament Neurofilament found?	The intermediate filament Neurofilament is found in neurons.
In what type of cells is the intermediate filament Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) found?	The intermediate filament Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) is found in neuroglial cells (ex. astrocytes, Schwann cells, oligodendrocytes).
In what type of cells is the intermediate filament Desmin found?	The intermediate filament Desmin is found in muscle cells.
In what type of cells is the intermediate filament Cytokeratin found?	The intermediate filament Cytokeratin is found in epithelial cells.
What do the interlobular arteries of the kidney divide into?	The interlobular arteries of the kidney divide into the afferent arterioles.
Which reflex's integrity can be tested with the Valsalva maneuver?	The integrity of the baroreceptor reflex can be tested with the Valsalva maneuver.
What are the subunits that make up the tetramer of the insulin receptor?	The insulin receptor is a tetramer consisting of two α subunits and two β subunits.
What is the name of the innermost tip of the kidney medullary pyramid?	The innermost tip of the kidney medullary pyramid is called the papilla.
What is the name of the innermost layer of the gut wall?	The innermost layer of the gut wall is the mucosa.
What is the name of the innermost layer of the arterial wall, and what does it consist of?	The innermost layer of the arterial wall is the intima, which consists of endothelial cells on a basement membrane.
What is the name of the inner layer of the pericardium?	The inner layer of the pericardium is the visceral layer of serous pericardium.
What is the name of the inner layer of the ovary, and what structures pass through it?	The inner layer of the ovary is the hilum, through which blood vessels and lymphatics pass.
What is the name of the inner layer of the cerebellar cortex?	The inner layer of the cerebellar cortex is the granule cell layer.
What is the name of the inner layer of lymph nodes, and what structures does it consist of?	The inner layer of lymph nodes is the medulla, which consists of medullary cords and sinuses.
What type of space is the inner ear?	The inner ear is a fluid-filled space.
What is the name of the inner cell layer of breast tissue?	The inner cell layer of breast tissue is the luminal (epithelial) cell layer.
What type of response does the injected influenza vaccine induce?	The injected influenza vaccine induces a humoral response.
What is the initial treatment for immune thrombocytopenic purpura?	The initial treatment for immune thrombocytopenic purpura is corticosteroids.
What is the initial treatment for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)?	The initial treatment for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is plasmapheresis.
What is the initial step in the evaluation of biliary atresia?	The initial step in the evaluation of biliary atresia is an abdominal ultrasound.
What does the ECG show in the initial phase of subendocardial infarcts of myocardial infarction?	The ECG shows ST-segment depression in the initial phase of subendocardial infarcts of myocardial infarction.
In a massive pulmonary embolism, what is the initial pathophysiology and which ventricle is affected?	The initial pathophysiology of a massive pulmonary embolism involves dilation and hypokinesis of the right ventricle with subsequent dysfunction.
What are the components of the initial mRNA of eukaryotes and what process do they undergo?	The initial mRNA of eukaryotes contains introns and exons, which undergo splicing.
What are the components of the initial management for patients with fibromyalgia?	The initial management for patients with fibromyalgia includes a regular exercise program, patient education, and good sleep hygiene.
Where does the initial lymphatic spread of a carcinoma occur?	The initial lymphatic spread of a carcinoma occurs to regional draining lymph nodes.
How is the initial growth phase of melanoma characterized?	The initial growth phase of melanoma is characterized by radial growth horizontally along the epidermis and superficial dermis.
What is the name of the initial (primary) transcript that is transcribed from eukaryotic DNA?	The initial (primary) transcript transcribed from eukaryotic DNA is called heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA).
What is the name of the tissue that is deposited during the initial "proliferative" phase of wound repair?	The tissue that is deposited during the initial "proliferative" phase of wound repair is called granulation tissue.

What adverse effect is most commonly associated with the inhaled anesthetic halothane?	The inhaled anesthetic halothane is most commonly associated with hepatotoxicity as an adverse effect.
Which inhaled anesthetic is associated with expansion of trapped gas in a body cavity as an adverse effect?	The inhaled anesthetic N2O is associated with expansion of trapped gas in a body cavity as an adverse effect.
What adverse effect is associated with the inhaled anesthetic methoxyflurane?	The inhaled anesthetic methoxyflurane is associated with nephrotoxicity as an adverse effect.
What nerve is the infraorbital nerve a continuation of, and across what structure does it run?	The infraorbital nerve is a continuation of the maxillary nerve that runs across the orbital floor.
What artery is the inferior rectal artery a branch of?	The inferior rectal artery is a branch of the internal pudendal artery.
From which artery does the inferior phrenic artery branch off, and at what vertebral level does this occur?	The inferior phrenic artery branches off the aorta at T12.
What is a common cause of injury to the inferior gluteal nerve?	The inferior gluteal nerve is commonly injured due to posterior hip dislocation.

What is the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for the HCO3-/CO2 buffer and how is it expressed?	The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for the HCO3-/CO2 buffer is expressed as pH = 6.1 + log ([HCO3-] / (0.03 * PCO2)).

What causes the heart sound S1?	The heart sound S1 is due to mitral and tricuspid valve closure.

What enzyme is deficient in Tay-Sachs disease?	What enzyme is deficient in Tay-Sachs disease? The enzyme hexosaminidase A is deficient in Tay-Sachs disease.
What enzyme is deficient in Gaucher disease?	What enzyme is deficient in Gaucher disease? The enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase) is deficient in Gaucher disease.
What enzyme is deficient in Krabbe disease?	What enzyme is deficient in Krabbe disease? The enzyme galactocerebrosidase is deficient in Krabbe disease.
What enzyme is deficient in metachromatic leukodystrophy?	What enzyme is deficient in metachromatic leukodystrophy? The enzyme arylsulfatase A is deficient in metachromatic leukodystrophy.
What is the name of the enzyme that recognizes and excises pyrimidine dimer mutations?	What is the name of the enzyme that recognizes and excises pyrimidine dimer mutations? The enzyme is called excision endonuclease.
What type of epithelium lines the endocervix?	What type of epithelium lines the endocervix? The endocervix is lined by simple columnar epithelium.
What does the embryonic notochord become in adults?	What does the embryonic notochord become in adults? The notochord becomes the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral discs.
What does the embryonic left horn of sinus venosus give rise to?	What does the embryonic left horn of sinus venosus give rise to? It gives rise to the coronary sinus.
What happens to the embryonic lung bud during development?	What happens to the embryonic lung bud during development? It divides into two bronchial buds that branch off into bronchi.
What is the location of the basal plate in the embryonic brain stem and spinal cord?	What is the location of the basal plate in the embryonic brain stem and spinal cord? It is ventrally-located.
What is the location of the alar plate in the embryonic brain stem and spinal cord?	What is the location of the alar plate in the embryonic brain stem and spinal cord? It is dorsally-located.
What type of derivatives does the embryonic basal plate give rise to?	What type of derivatives does the embryonic basal plate give rise to? It gives rise to motor derivatives.
What type of derivatives does the embryonic alar plate give rise to?	What type of derivatives does the embryonic alar plate give rise to? It gives rise to sensory derivatives.
What are the effects of thromboxane A2 (TXA2)?	What are the effects of thromboxane A2 (TXA2)? The effects of TXA2 include increased platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
Who is mostly affected by the effects of hyperemesis gravidarum?	Who is mostly affected by the effects of hyperemesis gravidarum? The effects of hyperemesis gravidarum are mostly to the mother.
What can be used to potentiate the effects of 5FU?	What can be used to potentiate the effects of 5FU? Leucovorin can be used to potentiate the effects of 5FU.
What is the relationship between 5-fluorouracil and leucovorin?	What is the relationship between 5-fluorouracil and leucovorin? Leucovorin can be used to potentiate the effects of 5-fluorouracil.
What effect does aspirin have on coagulation studies?	What effect does aspirin have on coagulation studies? Aspirin causes increased bleeding time, but no change in PT and PTT.
What type of epithelium lines the ectocervix?	What type of epithelium lines the ectocervix? The ectocervix is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
Is the early distal tubule permeable or impermeable to H2O?	Is the early distal tubule permeable or impermeable to H2O? The early distal tubule is impermeable to H2O.
Is the early distal convoluted tubule permeable or impermeable to water?	Is the early distal convoluted tubule permeable or impermeable to water? The early distal convoluted tubule is impermeable to water.
What is the location of the E. coli K antigen?	What is the location of the E. coli K antigen? The E. coli K antigen is present on its capsule.
What is the location of the E. coli H antigen?	What is the location of the E. coli H antigen? The E. coli H antigen is present on its flagella.
What is the effect of E-series prostaglandins on blood vessels?	What is the effect of E-series prostaglandins on blood vessels? The E-series prostaglandins are vasodilators.
How long does viral conjunctivitis typically last?	How long does viral conjunctivitis typically last? The duration of viral conjunctivitis is 1-2 weeks.
How long can allergic conjunctivitis last for?	How long can allergic conjunctivitis last for? The duration of allergic conjunctivitis can vary from 30 minutes to seasonal.
What is the typical strand of dsDNA sequence reported in databases?	The dsDNA sequence reported in databases is the coding strand, unless specifically stated otherwise.
What are the names of the drugs used to treat babesiosis?	The drugs used to treat babesiosis are atovaquone and azithromycin.
What is the drug of choice for treating Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS)?	The drug of choice for treating Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) is penicillin.
Through what structure do the dorsal spinocerebellar and cuneocerebellar tracts enter the cerebellum?	The dorsal spinocerebellar and cuneocerebellar tracts enter the cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
What nerve does the dorsal respiratory group use to send its motor output to the diaphragm?	The dorsal respiratory group uses the phrenic nerve to send its motor output to the diaphragm.
Through which nerves does the dorsal respiratory group receive sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors?	The dorsal respiratory group receives sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors via the glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and vagus (CN X) nerves.
What nerve is responsible for transmitting sensory input from lung stretch receptors to the dorsal respiratory group?	The vagus (CN X) nerve is responsible for transmitting sensory input from lung stretch receptors to the dorsal respiratory group.
In which part of the brain stem are the dorsal and ventral respiratory groups located?	The dorsal and ventral respiratory groups are located in the medulla of the brain stem.
What is the main symptom that is typically seen in cases of urethritis?	The main symptom that is typically seen in cases of urethritis is dysuria.
What is the name of the dominant hormone that is produced during the first trimester of pregnancy?	The dominant hormone that is produced during the first trimester of pregnancy is hCG.
In internuclear ophthalmoplegia, what does the directional term (e.g. right or left) indicate?	The directional term (e.g. right or left) in internuclear ophthalmoplegia indicates which eye is paralyzed.
In what direction does protein synthesis occur, with respect to the N-terminus and C-terminus?	Protein synthesis occurs in the direction from N-terminus to C-terminus.
What determines the direction of blood flow and in what direction does it always flow?	The direction of blood flow is determined by the pressure gradient and it always flows from high to low pressure.
How do direct acting antiretroviral HCV drugs work and what do they target?	Direct acting antiretroviral HCV drugs work by targeting RNA synthesis.
What is responsible for encoding the diphtheria toxin of Corynebacterium diphtheriae?	The diphtheria toxin of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is encoded by a β-prophage.
How does the dilatory effect of ANP on afferent arterioles compare to its constrictor effect on efferent arterioles?	The dilatory effect of ANP on afferent arterioles is greater than the constrictor effect on efferent arterioles.
How does the diffusion coefficient (DK) for CO2 compare to that of O2?	The diffusion coefficient (DK) for CO2 is approximately 20x higher than that of O2.
What is the cause of diffuse basement membrane thickening in diabetic microangiopathy?	The diffuse basement membrane thickening in diabetic microangiopathy is caused by overproduction of type IV collagen by vascular fibroblasts.
What nerve innervates the diaphragm?	The diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve.
What VIP level confirms the diagnosis of VIPoma?	The diagnosis of VIPoma is confirmed by a VIP level > 75 pg/mL.
How is the diagnosis of tinea corporis confirmed?	The diagnosis of tinea corporis is confirmed with KOH preparation of skin scrapings demonstrating segmented hyphae.
How can the diagnosis of sickle cell disease be confirmed?	The diagnosis of sickle cell disease can be confirmed with hemoglobin electrophoresis.
How can the diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism be confirmed and what is required before the confirmation test?	The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism may be confirmed with adrenal suppression testing after an oral saline load.
How is the diagnosis of G6PD deficiency confirmed and when are the enzyme studies typically performed?	The diagnosis of G6PD deficiency is confirmed via enzyme studies, which are performed weeks after a hemolytic episode resolves.
How is the diagnosis of esophageal perforation confirmed and what imaging tests are used for confirmation?	The diagnosis of esophageal perforation is confirmed with Gastrografin (water-soluble) contrast esophagram or CT scan.
How is the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis confirmed and what tests are used for confirmation?	The diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis is confirmed with endoscopy and esophageal biopsy (> 15 eos/hpf).
How is the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy made and what tests are used for confirmation?	The diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy is made by a pregnancy test combined with transvaginal ultrasound.
How is the diagnosis of cerebral sinus thrombosis confirmed and what imaging test is used for confirmation?	The diagnosis of cerebral sinus thrombosis is confirmed with MRI with venography.
How is the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome confirmed and what test is used for confirmation?	The diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome can be confirmed by elevated 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA in most patients.
How is the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease confirmed and what procedure is used for confirmation (when possible)?	The diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease is confirmed by histology at autopsy (when possible).
How is the diagnosis of a palpable breast mass confirmed and what procedure is required for confirmation?	The diagnosis of a palpable breast mass can only be confirmed with a biopsy.
Which receptors are predominantly expressed in the detrusor muscle?	The detrusor muscle predominantly expresses M3 and B3 receptors.
How can the dermatophyte Microsporum be identified and what is the method used for identification?	The dermatophyte Microsporum can be identified via Wood's lamp.
What causes the dermatitis herpetiformis that arises with celiac disease and where does the deposition occur?	The dermatitis herpetiformis that arises with celiac disease is due to IgA deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae.
What is a potential side effect of the Depot medroxyprogesterone shot (DMPA) and how long does it typically last?	The Depot medroxyprogesterone shot (DMPA) can cause unpredictable bleeding that resolves after 2-3 months.
What is the direct correlation between the degree of advanced glycation end product (AGE) formation and serum levels of what?	The degree of advanced glycation end product (AGE) formation is directly correlated with serum levels of glucose.
In Menkes disease, what is the consequence of having a defective Menkes protein?	In Menkes disease, a defective Menkes protein leads to decreased activity of the enzyme lysyl oxidase.
Which muscle is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve?	The deep peroneal nerve supplies the tibialis anterior muscle.
What are the names of the deep cerebellar nuclei, listed from lateral to medial?	The deep cerebellar nuclei, listed from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globose, and fastigial nuclei.
What is the effect of decreased cardiac output in heart failure on sympathetic activity and vascular tone?	Decreased cardiac output in heart failure causes increased sympathetic activity with vascular constriction.
What is the primary reason for the decrease in fertility in women after the age of 35?	The decrease in fertility in women after 35 is primarily due to the diminishing quality/quantity of ovarian reserve.
What is the role of the DCC tumor suppressor gene in apoptotic regulation of the gastrointestinal tract?	The DCC tumor suppressor gene is involved in apoptotic regulation of the gastrointestinal tract epithelium.
What is the function of the DCC gene and how is it commonly affected in advanced colorectal cancer?	The DCC gene is a tumor suppressor that is frequently mutated in advanced colorectal cancer.
How does the cytoplasm of apoptotic cells typically appear when stained?	The cytoplasm of apoptotic cells typically appears deeply eosino-philic when stained.
What is the composition of the cysts of Cryptosporidium?	The cysts of Cryptosporidium consist of 4 motile sporozoites.
What is the cause of cyst formation in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?	The cysts in PCOS are formed from unruptured follicles due to increased androgens and LH:FSH ratio.
In what part of the kidney do the cysts in medullary sponge kidney develop?	The cysts in medullary sponge kidney develop in the terminal collecting duct.
What is the Cushing reaction and what are its characteristic symptoms?	The Cushing reaction is a triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure.
What type of cells are found in the crypts of Lieberkühn and what substances do they secrete?	The crypts of Lieberkühn contain Paneth cells, which secrete defensins, lysozyme, and TNF.
What is the composition of the Cryptococcus capsule?	The Cryptococcus capsule is made up of repeating polysaccharide capsular antigens.
What are the components of the crescents observed in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)?	The crescents seen in RPGN are composed of fibrin and macrophages.
What type of cranial nerves exit medially and what is their function?	The cranial nerve nuclei that exit medially are motor CNs.
What type of cranial nerves are typically mixed or sensory and exit laterally?	The cranial nerve nuclei that exit laterally are typically mixed or sensory CNs.
Where is the corticospinal tract located in the brainstem?	The corticospinal tract is located medially throughout the brainstem.
How is the corticopapillary osmotic gradient established?	The corticopapillary osmotic gradient is established, in part, by countercurrent multiplication.
What process contributes to the establishment of the corticopapillary osmotic gradient?	The corticopapillary osmotic gradient is established, in part, by the urea cycle.
Which muscles of the face receive bi-lateral corticobulbar innervation from facial motoneurons?	The corticobulbar innervation of facial motoneurons to muscles of the upper face is bi-lateral.
Which muscles of the face receive contra-lateral corticobulbar innervation from facial motoneurons?	The corticobulbar innervation of facial motoneurons to muscles of the lower face is contra-lateral.
How is the corticobulbar innervation of cranial nerve lower motoneurons primarily distributed?	The corticobulbar innervation of cranial nerve lower motoneurons is predominantly bi-lateral.
What hormones are synthesized by the corpus luteum?	The corpus luteum synthesizes estradiol and progesterone.
What are the three ways in which the conversion of prions from PrPc to PrPsc can occur?	The conversion of prions from PrPc to PrPsc can occur sporadically, through inheritance, or transmission.
What are the contraindications for both external cephalic version and C-section?	The contraindications for both external cephalic version and C-section include prior C-section, prior uterine myomectomy, and placenta previa.
What types of connections exist between the hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary?	The connections between the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary are both neural and endocrine.
What types of connections exist between the hypothalamus and the posterior pituitary?	The connections between the hypothalamus and the posterior pituitary are neural only.

What sinuses do the confluence of sinuses drain into?	The confluence of sinuses drain into the transverse sinuses.
What is the confirmatory test for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip?	The confirmatory test for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip is an ultrasound.
What happens to the confidence interval of a study as the sample size increases?	The confidence interval of a study narrows as the sample size increases.
How is the compliance of the lungs and chest wall related to their elastance?	The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is inversely proportional to their elastance.
How is the compliance of the lungs and chest wall related to the wall stiffness?	The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is inversely proportional to the wall stiffness.
How does the compliance of the lung-chest wall system compare to that of the lungs or chest wall alone?	The compliance of the lung-chest wall system is less than that of the lungs or chest wall alone.
In what direction is the compensatory response to an acid-base disturbance, in relation to the original acid-base disturbance?	The compensatory response to an acid-base disturbance is always in the same direction as the original acid-base disturbance.
What are the names of the two arteries that the common hepatic artery bifurcates into?	The common hepatic artery bifurcates into the proper hepatic and gastroduodenal arteries.
At what level does the common carotid artery bifurcate?	The common carotid artery bifurcates at the level of C4.
Which two ducts form the common bile duct?	The common bile duct is formed by the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct.
What is the result of the combination of right ventricle hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension in response to left-to-right shunting?	The result of the combination of right ventricle hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension in response to left-to-right shunting is shunt reversal.
What is the specific toxicity associated with the combination of atrial tachycardia and AV block?	The combination of atrial tachycardia with AV block is specific for digitalis toxicity.
What syndrome is indicated by the combination of a vascular tumor (such as hemangioma) and consumptive thrombocytopenia?	The combination of a vascular tumor (e.g. hemangioma) and consumptive thrombocytopenia is indicative of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.
What staining technique can be used to distinguish the coarse yellowish-brown pigment in hepatocytes/kupffer cells from hemochromatosis from lipofuscin?	The coarse yellowish-brown pigment in hepatocytes/kupffer cells from hemochromatosis may be distinguished from lipofuscin by staining with Prussian blue.
How does the recombination frequency affect the proximity of alleles in a haplotype?	The closer the recombination frequency is to 0%, the closer alleles in a haplotype are to each other.
What is the relationship between the proximity of a destructive axon lesion and the survival of a neuron?	The closer a destructive axon lesion is to the neuronal cell body, the more likely the neuron is to die.

What is Coccidioidomycosis and what are its clinical manifestations similar to?	Coccidioidomycosis is a fungal infection, and its clinical manifestation is similar to acute pneumonia, characterized by cough, fever, and arthralgias.
What is the target of climbing fibers that enter the cerebellum and what type of terminals do they form?	The climbing fibers that enter the cerebellum target excitatory terminals on Purkinje cells.
How is the classical and vascular forms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome inherited?	The classical and vascular forms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
What is the classic presentation of ectopic pregnancy and when does it typically occur?	The classic presentation of ectopic pregnancy is lower quadrant abdominal pain weeks after a missed period (amenorrhea).

What is the classic location for basal cell carcinoma?	The classic location for basal cell carcinoma is the upper lip.

What does the CFTR gene encode and what type of channel does it produce?	The CFTR gene encodes an ATP-gated Cl- channel.
In which organs or parts of the body does the CFTR Cl- channel secrete Cl-?	The CFTR Cl- channel secretes Cl- in the lungs and GI tract.
What is the function of the CFTR Cl- channel in the sweat glands?	The CFTR Cl- channel reabsorbs Cl- in the sweat glands.
What are the three main structural components of the cerebellum?	The cerebellum consists of a midline vermis and two lateral hemispheres on each side.

What is the structure into which the cavernous sinus drains?	The cavernous sinus drains into the internal jugular vein.

What is the most common cause of dilated cardiomyopathy?	The most common cause of dilated cardiomyopathy is idiopathic.
What are some potential causes of aplastic anemia, and what medical condition may sometimes precede its development?	The cause of aplastic anemia may be immune-mediated, and it sometimes follows acute hepatitis.
What does the cardiac silhouette of transposition of great vessels look like on a chest X-ray?	The cardiac silhouette of transposition of great vessels appears as an "egg on a string" on a chest X-ray.

What types of cancers are significantly associated with the serum tumor marker Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)?	The serum tumor marker Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) has major associations with colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

What type of calcium channels open during the plateau phase of the myocardial action potential?	The calcium channels that open during the plateau phase of the myocardial action potential are L-type channels.
What is the effect of the Ca2+-calmodulin complex on smooth muscle contraction and what is the mechanism behind it?	The Ca2+-calmodulin complex upregulates myosin-light-chain kinase, which phosphorylates myosin and leads to the contraction of smooth muscle.
What does the c wave on jugular venous pulse correspond to?	The c wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to the contraction of the right ventricle.
Where does the majority of Na+ reabsorption occur in the nephron and what percentage of it occurs there?	The majority of Na+ reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron, accounting for 67% of it.

Where does the majority of Ca2+ reabsorption occur in the nephron and what percentage of it occurs there?	The majority of Ca2+ reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron, accounting for 67% of it.

What is the embryonic origin of the branchial arches?	The branchial arches are derivatives of mesoderm + neural crest.

What is the term used to describe the blood volume contained in the arteries?	The blood volume contained in the arteries is called the stressed volume.

What is the source of the blood supply to the distal ureter?	The blood supply to the distal ureter is the superior vesical artery.

What are the characteristics of the blasts seen in acute leukemia?	The blasts seen in acute leukemia are large, immature cells, often with "punched out" nucleoli.

What is the main issue associated with using mini-pills as a form of contraception?	The biggest problem with mini-pills is that they require daily compliance down to the hour.

What is the recommended initial pharmacological therapy for peripheral neuropathy?	The best initial pharmacological therapy for peripheral neuropathy is pregabalin or gabapentin.
What is the recommended initial diagnostic test for chest pain?	The best initial diagnostic test for chest pain is an ECG.

What type of vaccine is the BCG vaccine?	The BCG vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.
What test can the BCG vaccine cause a false positive for?	The BCG vaccine can cause a false positive for a tuberculin test.
What condition are the Barlow and Ortolani Maneuvers used to diagnose?	The Barlow and Ortolani Maneuvers are used to diagnose Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip.

How many neurons does the autonomic nervous system usually use to reach its target?	The autonomic nervous system usually reaches its target via two neurons.
What are the two divisions that make up the autonomic nervous system?	The autonomic nervous system is composed of two divisions: sympathetic and parasympathetic.
In what organ are the plasma cells responsible for producing the autoantibodies in ITP located?	The autoantibodies in ITP are produced by plasma cells in the spleen.
Which area of the ear receives sensory innervation from the auriculotemporal nerve?	The auriculotemporal nerve supplies sensory innervation in front of the ear.
What is the function of the auditory ossicles in the middle ear?	The auditory ossicles of the middle ear conduct and amplify sound from the eardrum to the inner ear.
What is the pathway for auditory input from the superior olivary nucleus to the midbrain?	The auditory input from the superior olivary nucleus travels via the lateral lemniscus to the inferior colliculus (midbrain).
What is the destination of auditory information from the medial geniculate body?	The auditory information from the medial geniculate body projects to the primary auditory cortex of the superior temporal gyrus.
How is the attributable risk percent calculated from the relative risk?	The attributable risk percent can be derived from the relative risk using the formula ARP = (RR - 1)/RR.
What ligaments stabilize the atlantoaxial joint?	The atlantoaxial joint is stabilized by the transverse ligament, apical ligament, and alar ligaments.
What is the cause of arthropathy in hemochromatosis?	The arthropathy in hemochromatosis occurs due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition.
What is the arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory alkalosis and how does it differ from normal values?	The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory alkalosis is: pH increased, [HCO3-] decreased, and PCO2 decreased.
What is the arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory acidosis and how does it differ from normal values?	The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory acidosis is: pH decreased, [HCO3-] increased, and PCO2 increased.
What is the arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic alkalosis and how does it differ from normal values?	The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic alkalosis is: pH increased, [HCO3-] increased, and PCO2 increased.
What is the arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic acidosis and how does it differ from normal values?	The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic acidosis is: pH decreased, [HCO3-] decreased, and PCO2 decreased.
What are the viruses included in the arenaviruses family and which disease is associated with them?	The arenaviruses family includes lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) and lassa fever.
What other virus is included in the arenaviruses family besides lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV)?	Lassa fever virus is the other virus included in the arenaviruses family besides lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV).
What type of receptors are present in the area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) and what substance activates them?	The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) contains neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptors, which are activated by substance P.
What is the approximate partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) in inspired, humidified air (PIO2) at sea level?	The approximate partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) in inspired, humidified air (PIO2) at sea level is 150 mmHg.
What is the process by which the APP receptor on neurons is normally broken down?	The APP receptor on neurons is normally broken down by alpha cleavage.
What are the antiphagocytic virulence factors associated with streptococcus pyogenes (GAS)?	The antiphagocytic virulence factors associated with streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) are M-protein and hyaluronic acid capsule.
Which type of lymphocytes have antigen receptors with a hinge region, and what is the function of this region?	B lymphocytes have antigen receptors with a hinge region, which allows for flexibility.
How can echinocandins, a class of antifungal drugs, be identified based on their naming convention?	Echinocandins, a class of antifungal drugs, can be identified based on the suffix -fungin in their names, such as caspofungin.
How can allylamines, a class of antifungal drugs, be identified based on their naming convention?	Allylamines, a class of antifungal drugs, can be identified based on the suffix -fine in their names, such as terbinafine.
What is the mechanism by which the antibody-heparin-PF4 complex may lead to thrombosis and thrombocytopenia?	The antibody-heparin-PF4 complex may activate platelets, leading to thrombosis and thrombocytopenia.
In the context of ITP, what is the mechanism by which antibody-bound platelets are removed from circulation, resulting in thrombocytopenia?	In the context of ITP, antibody-bound platelets are consumed by splenic macrophages, resulting in thrombocytopenia.
What are the two types of antibodies that can be involved in immune hemolytic anemia?	The antibodies in immune hemolytic anemia are either IgG or IgM.
What type of substances should be avoided when taking antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones and tetracyclines?	When taking antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones and tetracyclines, cations (Ca2+, Fe2+, Mg2+) should be avoided.
What specific type of molecules do the anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies target in Sjögren's syndrome?	In Sjögren's syndrome, the anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies target ribonucleoproteins.
What types of sensory information are carried by the anterior spinothalamic tract?	The anterior spinothalamic tract carries information for crude (non-discriminative) touch and pressure.
Which branch of the nervous system controls the anterior hypothalamus?	The anterior hypothalamus is controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system.
Which muscles of the anterior neck are innervated by the ansa cervicalis?	The ansa cervicalis innervates the strap (infrahyoid) muscles of the anterior neck.
From which nerve roots does the ansa cervicalis arise?	The ansa cervicalis arises from C1-C3 nerve roots.
What is the treatment for anemia in Chronic Kidney Disease?	The anemia in Chronic Kidney Disease can be treated with epoetin alfa.
What is the factor that determines water secretion in the gastrointestinal tract?	The amount of Cl- secretion by GI mucosal cells determines H2O secretion.
What is the term used to describe the amount of substance filtered in Bowman's space per unit time?	The amount of substance filtered in Bowman's space per unit time is called the filtered load.
Which amino acids are positively charged at body pH?	The amino acids lysine and arginine are positively charged at body pH (basic).
Which amino acids are negatively charged at body pH?	The amino acids aspartate and glutamate are negatively charged at body pH (acidic).
Which amino acid is essential for rapidly dividing tumor cells?	The amino acid asparagine is essential for rapidly dividing tumor cells.
During which periods is the amino acid arginine essential for nitrogen balance?	The amino acid arginine is essential during periods of positive nitrogen balance.
What are the two types of epithelial cells that line the alveolar walls?	The alveolar walls are lined with two types of epithelial cells, namely type I and type II pneumocytes.
What is the name of the bacteria whose alpha toxin breaks down phospholipids, resulting in myonecrosis (gas gangrene)?	The bacteria that causes myonecrosis (gas gangrene) by breaking down phospholipids with its alpha toxin is Clostridium perfringens.
Which allylamine is associated with hepato-toxicity?	Terbinafine is the allylamine that is associated with hepato-toxicity.
What is the name of the structure that the allantois becomes, and what is its function in the fetal body?	The allantois becomes the urachus, which is a duct between the fetal bladder and the umbilicus.
When does alcoholic hallucinosis typically occur in relation to the last drink during alcohol withdrawal?	Alcoholic hallucinosis typically occurs 12 to 48 hours after the last drink during alcohol withdrawal.
What is the name of the structure that separates the alar plate and basal plate in embryonic development?	The sulcus limitans is the structure that separates the alar plate and basal plate in embryonic development.
What are the names of the catecholamines that are secreted by the adrenal medulla?	The catecholamines that are secreted by the adrenal medulla are norepinephrine and epinephrine.
What is the origin of the adrenal medulla?	The adrenal medulla is of neural crest origin.
What type of cells is the adrenal medulla composed of and from which embryonic structure are these cells derived?	The adrenal medulla is composed of chromaffin cells, which are derived from neural crest.
How does the adrenal medulla exert its post-ganglionic sympathetic effects?	The adrenal medulla exerts its post-ganglionic sympathetic effects via neurohumoral transmission.
What is the characteristic feature of the adrenal glands in tertiary adrenal insufficiency?	The adrenal glands in tertiary adrenal insufficiency are characterized by atrophy of both adrenal glands.
What is the initial step in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence, and what gene mutations are associated with it?	The initial step in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence involves APC gene mutations.
What is the typical outcome of the acute form of ventricular free wall rupture?	The typical outcome of the acute form of ventricular free wall rupture is sudden death.
What is the relationship between the activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase and the levels of PTH?	The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with increased levels of PTH.
How does the activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase change in response to changes in serum phosphate concentration?	The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with decreased serum phosphate concentration.
How does the activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase change in response to changes in serum Ca2+ concentration?	The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with decreased serum Ca2+ concentration.
How does PTH's action on osteoclasts occur, and what mediates this action?	The action of PTH on osteoclasts is indirect and is mediated by cytokines released from osteoblasts.
What type of forces can cause injury to the Achilles tendon during strenuous activities?	The Achilles tendon can be injured with sudden forces during strenuous activities.
What type of receptors do the acetylcholine from pre-ganglionic neurons of the autonomic nervous system (ANS) bind to?	The acetylcholine from pre-ganglionic neurons of the ANS binds to neural nicotinic (NN) receptors.
What type of receptors do the acetylcholine from post-ganglionic neurons of the autonomic nervous system (ANS) bind to?	The acetylcholine from post-ganglionic neurons of the ANS binds to muscarinic (M) receptors.
What is the process through which the acetyl-CoA from acetoacetyl-CoA (ketone body metabolism) is used to generate energy?	The acetyl-CoA from acetoacetyl-CoA (ketone body metabolism) is used to generate energy via the Kreb's cycle.
What are the two ways in which the acetyl CoA generated through β-oxidation is used?	The acetyl CoA generated through β-oxidation is used for ketogenesis (liver) or the TCA cycle.
What are the two things that accompany the accommodation reflex?	The accommodation reflex is accompanied by convergence and miosis.
Which duodenal papilla does the accessory pancreatic duct drain into?	The accessory pancreatic duct drains into the minor duodenal papilla.
Which part of the neck is involved in surgeries that may cause injury to the accessory nerve?	The accessory nerve may be injured during surgery involving the posterior triangle of the neck.
Who is usually the abuser in cases of physical abuse of a child?	The abuser in the case of physical abuse of a child is usually the biological mother.
What are the typical absolute values of AST and ALT in cases of alcoholic hepatitis?	The absolute values of AST and ALT in alcoholic hepatitis are almost always < 500 IU/L.
What does the absence of bleeding following a progestin withdrawal challenge may indicate?	The absence of bleeding following a progestin withdrawal challenge may be indicative of low estrogen levels.
What is the significance of the abnormal promyelocytes seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), and what risk do they increase?	The abnormal promyelocytes seen in APML contain numerous primary granules that increase the risk for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
What is the ABL proto-oncogene, and what is its function when stimulated?	The ABL proto-oncogene encodes for a cytosolic Tyrosine Kinase that when stimulated leads to cell division.
What does the abbreviation RTK stand for?	The abbreviation RTK stands for Receptor Tyrosine Kinase.
What does the a wave on jugular venous pulse correspond to?	The a wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to atrial contraction.
What happens to the [TF/P]urea ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]urea ratio increases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]PAH ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]PAH ratio greatly increases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]K ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]K ratio slightly increases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]inulin ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]inulin ratio increases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]HCO3 ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]HCO3 ratio decreases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]glucose and [TF/P]AA ratios over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]glucose and [TF/P]AA ratios decrease over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]creatinine ratio over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]creatinine ratio greatly increases over the course of the PCT.
What happens to the [TF/P]Cl ratio initially over the course of the PCT?	The [TF/P]Cl ratio initially increases over the course of the PCT.
What is the [HA] form of the bicarbonate buffer and what is it in equilibrium with?	The [HA] form of the bicarbonate buffer is CO2, which is in equilibrium with H2CO3.
What is the [A-] form of the bicarbonate buffer?	The [A-] form of the bicarbonate buffer is HCO3-.
What are the 5A's of Down syndrome?	The 5A's of Down syndrome are: Advanced maternal age, Trisomy (Duodenal Atresia), Triventricular septal defect, Alzheimer's (early onset), ML/LL.
What is the purpose of the 5 to 3' exonuclease activity of prokaryotic DNA polymerase I?	The purpose of the 5 to 3' exonuclease activity of prokaryotic DNA polymerase I is to remove the RNA primer.
Where does the 3rd-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract travel to?	The 3rd-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract travels to the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus).
