Where does the 3rd-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract travel to?	The 3rd-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract travels to the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus).
What does the 3rd ventricle drain into and via which structure?	The 3rd ventricle drains into the 4th ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius).
What are the names of the 3 dermatophytes?	The 3 dermatophytes are: 1. Trichophyton 2. Epidermophyton 3. Microsporum.
In which nucleus of the thalamus do the 2nd-order neurons of trigeminal nerve nuclei synapse?	The 2nd-order neurons of trigeminal nerve nuclei synapse in the ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus of the thalamus.
In which nucleus of the thalamus do the 2nd-order neurons of the spinothalamic tract synapse?	The 2nd-order neurons of the spinothalamic tract synapse in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus.
In which nucleus of the thalamus do the 2nd-order neurons of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract synapse?	The 2nd-order neurons of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract synapse in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus.
What is the first-line and second-line therapy for polycythemia vera?	The first-line therapy for polycythemia vera is phlebotomy, while the second-line therapy is hydroxyurea.
What is the cause of the 'tram-track' appearance associated with MPGN, and what type of cell ingrowth is involved?	The 'tram-track' appearance associated with MPGN is caused by basement membrane splitting, which is due to mesangial cell ingrowth.
What is the cause of the 'blueberry muffin' rash seen in multiple congenital infections?	The 'blueberry muffin' rash seen in multiple congenital infections is caused by dermal erythropoiesis.
What are the typical symptoms of the "unhappy triad" injury?	The "unhappy triad" injury typically presents with acute knee pain and signs of joint injury/instability.
What are the "three D's" associated with endometriosis?	The "three D's" associated with endometriosis are dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and dyschezia.
What is the cause of the "spike" appearance in membranous glomerulopathy?	The "spike" appearance in membranous glomerulopathy is caused by the basement membrane engulfing "domes" of subepithelial immune deposits.
What is the cause of the "lumpy-bumpy" appearance of PSGN on immunofluorescence?	The "lumpy-bumpy" appearance of PSGN on immunofluorescence is caused by deposits with immune complexes consisting of IgG, IgM, and C3.
How does assuming the "knee-chest" position relieve headaches?	Assuming the "knee-chest" position opens flow of CSF fluid to relieve headaches. It is not related to ependymoma.
What is a possible symptom that may present in the "chronic stage" of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia?	Thrombosis is a possible symptom that may present in the "chronic stage" of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia due to thrombocytosis.
What is a possible symptom that may present in the "accelerated stage" of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia?	Bleeding is a possible symptom that may present in the "accelerated stage" of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia due to thrombocytopenia.
What does the "-ogen" suffix typically indicate in the name of a compound (e.g. urobilinogen)?	The "-ogen" suffix typically indicates a colorless compound.
What does the "-in" suffix typically indicate in the name of a compound (e.g. stercobilin)?	The "-in" suffix typically indicates a colored compound.
What is the purpose of vancomycin in Thayer-Martin Media?	The purpose of vancomycin in Thayer-Martin Media is to kill gram positive organisms.
What are the components in Thayer-Martin Media that are used to kill gram negative organisms?	The components in Thayer-Martin Media that are used to kill gram negative organisms are Trimethoprim and Colistin (polymixin).
What is the purpose of Nystatin in Thayer-Martin Media?	The purpose of Nystatin in Thayer-Martin Media is to kill fungi.
What is the treatment for Thalassemia major, and what prophylactic measure is taken to prevent a related condition?	Thalassemia major is treated with blood transfusions, and prophylactic deferoxamine is taken to prevent hemosiderosis.
How is Thalassemia minor characterized in terms of total RBC count and RDW?	Thalassemia minor is characterized by normal total RBC count and normal RDW.
What is the protective effect of the inherited mutation that causes Thalassemia?	The inherited mutation that causes Thalassemia protects carriers against Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
What type of anemia is caused by Thalassemia?	Thalassemia is a cause of microcytic anemia.
How do the MCV and iron levels differ in Thalassemia compared to normal levels?	In Thalassemia, the MCV is very low and the iron levels are high.
What are the two substances that Th1 cells secrete?	Th1 cells secrete IFN-γ and IL-2.
What are the two processes that TGF-β mediates, and how does it affect inflammation?	TGF-β is a growth factor that mediates fibrosis and angiogenesis, and it inhibits inflammation.
What are the two types of cells that TGF-α is a growth factor for?	TGF-α is an epithelial and fibroblast growth factor.
Which type of voltage-gated channels in cardiac/nerve tissue does tetrodotoxin bind to, and what is the effect of this binding?	Tetrodotoxin binds to fast voltage-gated Na+ channels in cardiac/nerve tissue, preventing depolarization.
What type of shunt and what symptom of cyanosis is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot?	Tetralogy of Fallot results in a right-to-left shunt with early cyanosis.
What are the four characteristic features of Tetralogy of Fallot?	Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a pulmonary artery stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and VSD.
What is the characteristic shape of the heart on CXR in a patient with Tetralogy of Fallot?	Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a boot-shaped heart on CXR.
What is the cause of Tetralogy of Fallot?	Tetralogy of Fallot is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum.
Is Tetralogy of Fallot a cyanotic or non-cyanotic heart disease?	Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic heart disease.
What is the role of Tetrahydrofolate (THF) in the body?	Tetrahydrofolate (THF) serves as a carrier of one carbon in the body.
Which tick-borne organisms are susceptible to the activity of tetracyclines?	Tetracyclines have activity against tick-borne organisms such as rickettsia, francisella, and borrelia.
Which type of antibiotic-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is susceptible to the activity of tetracyclines?	Tetracyclines have activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
In which groups of individuals are tetracyclines contraindicated due to their potential to deposit in teeth and bone?	Tetracyclines are contraindicated in children, pregnant women, and breastfeeding women due to their potential to deposit in teeth and bone.
What is the mechanism of action of tetracyclines in bacteria?	Tetracyclines bind reversibly to the 30s ribosomal subunit of bacteria.
What is the reason for the effectiveness of tetracyclines against Rickettsia and Chlamydophila?	Tetracyclines are very effective against Rickettsia and Chlamydophila because these drugs accumulate intracellularly.
What is the cause of atypical pneumonia that can be treated with tetracyclines?	Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the cause of atypical pneumonia that can be treated with tetracyclines.
What is the condition in which tetracyclines are generally contraindicated in patients?	Tetracyclines are generally contraindicated in patients with renal failure.
What is the mode of action of tetracyclines on bacteria?	Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic, meaning they inhibit bacterial growth and reproduction.
What is the side effect associated with tetracyclines?	Tetracyclines are associated with photosensitivity, which is an increased sensitivity to sunlight or artificial UV light.
What type of side effects are commonly associated with tetracyclines?	Tetracyclines are associated with gastrointestinal (GI) side effects, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
What enzyme is responsible for converting testosterone to dihydrotestosterone?	Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone via the enzyme 5α-reductase.
How does testosterone reinforce the spermatogenic effects of FSH in Sertoli cells?	Testosterone acts via an intratesticular paracrine mechanism to reinforce the spermatogenic effects of FSH in Sertoli cells.
What is the purpose of testing for expression of PD-L1 in advanced non-small cell carcinomas of the lung?	Testing for PD-L1 expression guides immunotherapy in advanced non-small cell carcinomas of the lung.
What is the purpose of testing for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs)?	Testing for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs) is highly sensitive and specific for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).
What is the purpose of testing for driver mutations in adenocarcinoma of the lung?	Testing for driver mutations in adenocarcinoma of the lung guides systemic therapy in advanced disease.
What are the typical characteristics of a testicular tumor in terms of its presentation and the patient population affected?	Testicular tumors typically present as a painless testicular mass in a young man that cannot be transilluminated.
What is the typical characteristic of a testicular tumor in terms of its transillumination and texture?	Testicular tumors typically present as a firm, painless testicular mass that cannot be transilluminated.
What are the two types of cells from which testicular tumors may arise?	Testicular tumors may arise from either germ cells or sex-cord stroma.
What is the demographic group that is most commonly affected by testicular tumors?	Testicular tumors are most common among young males aged 15-35.
What is the recommended treatment for testicular torsion, and what is the potential consequence of not treating it urgently?	Testicular torsion is treated with urgent surgery, as it may lead to infertility if left untreated.
When treating testicular torsion with orchiopexy (surgery), on which testes is the procedure typically performed?	Testicular torsion is typically treated with orchiopexy (surgery) on both testes.
What type of symptoms are commonly associated with testicular torsion, a pathology of the testes?	Testicular torsion is a pathology of the testes that is commonly associated with gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms.
What is a potential complication of testicular torsion, a pathology of the testes?	A potential complication of testicular torsion is a small hydrocele.
What type of infarction can be caused by testicular torsion?	Testicular torsion can cause hemorrhagic infarction of the testicle.
What is the composition and typical nature of testicular sex cord-stromal tumors?	Testicular sex cord-stromal tumors are composed of Sertoli cells and/or Leydig cells and are usually benign.
How do testicular germ cell tumors typically present, and how is prognosis determined?	Testicular germ cell tumors often present as a mixed germ cell tumor, and prognosis is based on the worst component.
What is the main surgical intervention used to manage testicular cancer?	Testicular cancer is managed with radical inguinal orchiectomy.
At what point is surgical intervention necessary for testes that have not descended?	Testes that have not descended by 6 months are unlikely to descend and require surgical intervention.
What is the preferred test for evaluating oropharyngeal dysphagia?	The test of choice for oropharyngeal dysphagia is the videofluoroscopic modified barium swallow.
What is the preferred test for detecting HSV?	The test of choice for HSV is PCR.
What is Tesamorelin and what is it used to treat in patients with HIV?	Tesamorelin is a GHRH analog used to treat HIV-associated lipodystrophy.
What is the characteristic appearance of the aorta in tertiary syphilis?	Tertiary syphilis results in a 'tree-bark' appearance of the aorta.
How does serum vitamin D (calcitriol) level typically present in patients with tertiary hyperparathyroidism?	Serum vitamin D (calcitriol) level typically presents as decreased (low Vitamin D) in patients with tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
What medical condition is suggested by the symptoms of projectile vomiting, alkalosis, and visible peristalsis in a term male neonate?	These symptoms are suggestive of pyloric stenosis.
What is the effect of using Teriparatide on patients with osteoporosis?	Teriparatide decreases the incidence of fractures in patients with osteoporosis.
What is a potential adverse effect of using both Teriparatide and Vitamin D therapy?	The use of Teriparatide and Vitamin D therapy can potentially cause hypercalcemia.
What is the mechanism of action of Terbutaline and what condition does it treat in relation to bronchoconstriction?	Terbutaline is a selective β2 agonist that treats bronchoconstriction in asthma.
What type of infections are treated with Terbinafine, and what is the location of these infections?	Terbinafine is used to treat superficial dermatophyte infections. These infections are located on the skin, hair, and nails.
What is the primary medical condition that Terbinafine is used to treat?	Terbinafine is mainly used to treat dermatophytoses, which are fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails.
What is the typical nature of teratomas in women?	Teratomas are usually benign in women, although they can sometimes become malignant.
What are some of the teratogenic effects associated with vitamin A, and what specific types of abnormalities can it cause?	Vitamin A is known to have teratogenic effects, including the potential to cause cardiac abnormalities and cleft palate.
What are the cardiovascular effects of tension pneumothorax, and how does it impact venous return and preload?	Tension pneumothorax can lead to decreased venous return and preload, which can have serious cardiovascular consequences.
Which muscle is commonly associated with bicipital groove tenderness, and what is the medical term for this condition?	Biceps tendonitis is a medical condition that is typically associated with tenderness at the bicipital groove.
What medical condition is typically associated with tenderness at the tibial tubercle?	Tenderness at the tibial tubercle is commonly suggestive of a medical condition known as Osgood-Schlatter disease.
What medical condition is typically associated with tenderness at the inferior patella in athletes?	Tenderness at the inferior patella in athletes is commonly suggestive of a medical condition known as patellar tendonitis.
What is the cause of temporal lobe encephalitis or hemorrhagic LP?	Temporal lobe encephalitis or hemorrhagic LP is caused by HSV-1.
What is the accepted temperature range for a normal reaction to a vaccine?	The accepted temperature range for a normal reaction to a vaccine is below 104°F.
What is the rare example of endogenous reverse transcriptase activity that occurs in humans?	Telomerase is the rare example of endogenous reverse transcriptase activity that occurs in humans.
What is the relationship between telomerase activity and cancer?	Telomerase activity is upregulated in cancer.
What medical condition is suggested by telescoping of the bowel into itself leading to vascular compromise?	Telescoping of the bowel into itself leading to vascular compromise is suggestive of intussusception.
What is the relationship between telangiectasia and carcinoid tumors?	Telangiectasia is a feature of carcinoid tumors.
What is the appropriate course of action when a teenager is experiencing active suicidal ideation?	It is appropriate to inform the parents and hospitalize the teenager.
When a teenager is experiencing active suicidal ideation, what is the appropriate course of action regarding hospitalization and parental consent?	Regardless of parental consent, it is appropriate to inform the parents and hospitalize the teenager.
What medical condition is suggested by progressive knee pain and tibial tubercle tenderness/swelling in teenage athletes?	Progressive knee pain and tibial tubercle tenderness/swelling in teenage athletes is suggestive of Osgood-Schlatter.
What is the medical term for the tearing of the placenta off the uterus?	The tearing of the placenta off the uterus is known as placental abruption.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of TdT (+) and CD10 (+) blasts?	The presence of TdT (+) and CD10 (+) blasts is suggestive of B-ALL (B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia).
What medication class, and specific medication, may be used for migraine prophylaxis?	TCAs, such as amitriptyline, may be used for migraine prophylaxis.
What type of side effects can be caused by TCAs, and what are some examples of these side effects?	TCAs may cause anti-cholinergic side effects, such as tachycardia, urinary retention, dry mouth, and confusion.
What type of pain can TCAs be used to treat?	TCAs may be used to treat neuropathic pain.
What specific types of pain can TCAs be used to treat, and provide examples?	TCAs may be used to treat peripheral neuropathy and chronic pain (e.g. neuropathic pain).
What neurotransmitters are inhibited by TCAs through the pre-synaptic reuptake pathway?	TCAs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin.
How can TCAs cause arrhythmias, and what specific type of channel inhibition is involved in the myocardium?	TCAs can cause arrhythmias due to fast Na+ channel inhibition in the myocardium.
In which patient population are TCAs relatively contraindicated, and why?	TCAs are relatively contraindicated in elderly patients due to severe anticholinergic and antihistamine effects.
What are the reasons why TCAs are contraindicated in elderly patients?	TCAs are contraindicated in the elderly due to their anticholinergic and antihistamine effects.
What are some of the symptoms that may be present in individuals with Tay-Sachs disease?	Tay-Sachs disease may present with progressive neurodegeneration and developmental delay.
How can Tay-Sachs disease be distinguished from Niemann-Pick disease based on clinical features?	Tay-Sachs disease can be differentiated from Niemann-Pick disease by the presence of hyperreflexia and the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.
What is the characteristic appearance of lysosomes in individuals with Tay-Sachs disease?	Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by an "onion-skin" appearance to the lysosomes.
How do taxanes exert their pharmacological effect?	Taxanes work by preventing the disassembly of microtubules.
What are some of the adverse effects associated with the use of taxanes?	Taxanes can cause a peripheral sensory neuropathy as well as induce hypersensitivity reactions.
Which types of carcinomas are commonly treated with taxanes?	Taxanes are used to treat breast and ovarian carcinomas.
At which phase of the cell cycle do taxanes (-taxel) prevent cell cycle progression?	Taxanes (-taxel) are antineoplastics that prevent cell cycle progression at the M-Phase.
What is the potential consequence of taxane treatment on rapidly dividing cells such as follicular hair cells?	Taxane can affect rapidly dividing cells like follicular hair cells, resulting in alopecia.
What are the targets of the JAK (tyrosine kinase associated-receptor pathway) and what is their function?	Targets of JAK (tyrosine kinase associated-receptor pathway) include STATs, which cause transcription of new mRNAs and new protein synthesis.
In TAPVR, which chambers of the heart become dilated?	TAPVR causes a dilated right atrium and ventricle.
What is the official name for tapeworms?	Tapeworms are officially known as cestodes.
What type of breast cancer is Tamoxifen used to treat and prevent recurrence of?	Tamoxifen is used to treat and prevent recurrence of ER/PR positive breast cancer.
What is the mechanism of action of Tamoxifen as a SERM in breast and endometrial tissue?	Tamoxifen is a SERM that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast and agonist in endometrium.
What is the potential risk associated with Tamoxifen use as a selective estrogen receptor modulator?	Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator associated with increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia/cancer.
What are the potential risks associated with Tamoxifen use?	Tamoxifen increases the risk of thromboembolic events and endometrial cancer.
What is the potential risk of Tamoxifen use in premenopausal women?	Tamoxifen use in premenopausal women is associated with a high risk of endometrial polyps.
What are the characteristic features of Talcosis, a lung disease?	Talcosis is a disease that causes granulomas of the lung.
What are the possible symptoms associated with Takayasu arteritis?	Takayasu arteritis may present with visual and neurologic symptoms.
What are the possible characteristics of pain associated with Takayasu arteritis?	Takayasu arteritis may present with pain in the upper extremities that is worse with activity.
What type of vasculitis is Takayasu arteritis?	Takayasu arteritis is a form of large-vessel vasculitis.
What is the name of the tapeworm that has a circle of hooklets on its scolex?	The tapeworm that has a circle of hooklets on its scolex is Taenia solium.
Which tapeworm species does not have a circle of hooklets on its scolex?	Taenia saginata is the tapeworm species that does not have a circle of hooklets on its scolex.
What is the potential effect of tacrolimus on blood glucose levels?	Tacrolimus can cause hyperglycemia.
What condition is suggested by the presence of tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety 2-4 days after surgery?	The presence of tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety 2-4 days after surgery is suggestive of delirium tremens (DTs).
What level of hypothermia is associated with symptoms such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased shivering?	Symptoms such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased shivering are associated with mild hypothermia.
What are the typical clinical features of tabes dorsalis?	Tabes dorsalis typically presents with decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes and brief, shooting/burning pain.
What is the typical presentation of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) in tabes dorsalis?	In tabes dorsalis, the typical presentation of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) is their absence.
What is the typical presentation of the Romberg sign in tabes dorsalis?	In tabes dorsalis, the typical presentation of the Romberg sign is positive.
What are the "three P's" that are typically associated with tabes dorsalis?	The "three P's" that are typically associated with tabes dorsalis are paresthesias, pain, and polyuria (incontinence).
What type of urinary incontinence may be present in patients with tabes dorsalis?	Patients with tabes dorsalis may present with urinary overflow incontinence.
What is the potential cause of progressive sensory ataxia in patients with tabes dorsalis?	Progressive sensory ataxia in patients with tabes dorsalis may be caused by impaired proprioception.
What is the name of the type of pupils that may be associated with Tabes Dorsalis?	Tabes Dorsalis may be associated with Argyll Robertson pupils.
What is the name of the symptom that may be associated with Tabes Dorsalis, and how is it characterized?	Tabes Dorsalis may be associated with paroxysmal pains, which are characterized by sudden and severe attacks of pain.
What are the structures that are affected by progressive demyelination in Tabes Dorsalis?	In Tabes Dorsalis, the structures that are affected by progressive demyelination are the dorsal columns and dorsal roots.
What type of receptors do T3/T4 hormones bind to?	T3/T4 hormones bind to intracellular receptors.
What is the potential significance of T-wave inversion on an electrocardiogram (ECG)?	T-wave inversion on an ECG may indicate recent myocardial infarction (MI).
What is the role of T-tubules in muscle contraction?	T-tubules allow for coordinated contraction of muscles.
How are self-reactive T-cells inactivated in the periphery?	Self-reactive T-cells in the periphery are inactivated by clonal anergy.
What happens to T-cells and B-cells when they are exposed to their antigen without a costimulatory signal?	T-cells and B-cells become anergic when exposed to their antigen without a costimulatory signal.
What is the result of T-cell proliferation in Epstein-Barr Virus?	T-cell proliferation in Epstein-Barr Virus results in (hepato)splenomegaly.
What is a common presentation of T-cell ALL (leukemia or lymphoma)?	T-cell ALL (leukemia or lymphoma) often presents with lymphadenopathy, particularly in the cervical, supraclavicular, and axillary lymph nodes.
What markers are expressed by lymphoblasts in T-ALL?	Lymphoblasts in T-ALL (which are TdT+) express markers ranging from CD 2 to CD 8.
What is a systolic murmur that is soft, vibratory, and musical, and heard best at the lower mid-sternum?	The systolic murmur that is soft, vibratory, and musical, and heard best at the lower mid-sternum is called Still's murmur.
What is the significance of a systolic murmur, s3 gallop, and JVD during pregnancy?	It is normal to have a systolic murmur, s3 gallop, and JVD during pregnancy.
What is the potential consequence of systolic dysfunction caused by dilated cardiomyopathy?	Systolic dysfunction caused by dilated cardiomyopathy may lead to biventricular congestive heart failure.
What is cardiac Raynaud and how is it related to systemic sclerosis?	Cardiac Raynaud, characterized by recurrent vasospasm of small coronary vessels, is a manifestation of systemic sclerosis.
What is a potential manifestation of systemic sclerosis in the hands and what is the specific feature of this manifestation?	Systemic sclerosis may manifest in the hands with contractures in the interphalangeal joints.
What is the result of systemic release of Streptococcus pyogenes exotoxins A, B, and C in the body?	Systemic release of Streptococcus pyogenes exotoxins A, B, and C can lead to scarlet fever.
What is a common marker that is highly expressed in systemic mastocytosis?	Systemic mastocytosis is often characterized by prominent expression of mast cell tryptase.
What is one symptom of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?	One symptom of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is rash.
At what age range is Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis typically seen in patients?	Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis is a childhood arthritis seen in patients younger than 16 years old.
In how many joints does Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis commonly manifest with arthralgias?	Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis commonly manifests with arthralgias in 2 or more joints.
What are some manifestations of systemic inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis (RA)?	Systemic inflammation in RA may present with interstitial lung fibrosis, pericarditis, vasculitis, and anemia of chronic disease.
How does systemic hypoxia affect coronary oxygen supply?	Systemic hypoxia will decrease coronary oxygen supply (e.g. in cases of hypotension, shock, anemia, and carbon monoxide poisoning).
What systemic condition can result from systemic endothelial dysfunction due to preeclampsia?	Systemic endothelial dysfunction due to preeclampsia can lead to hypertension, as a result of systemic vasoconstriction.
What are some potential consequences of systemic amyloidosis?	Systemic amyloidosis can result in a peripheral neuropathy and carpal tunnel syndrome.
What are some hematologic manifestations that can occur with systemic amyloidosis?	Systemic amyloidosis can have hematologic manifestations, including splenomegaly and periorbital purpura.
What are some potential gastrointestinal manifestations of systemic amyloidosis?	Systemic amyloidosis can have gastrointestinal manifestations, including hepatomegaly, malabsorption, and macroglossia.
What are some treatments for systemic (disseminated) infections of Candida albicans?	Systemic (disseminated) infections of Candida albicans are treated with Amphotericin B and Caspofungin.
What is the treatment for systemic (disseminated) infections of paracoccidioidomycosis?	Systemic (disseminated) infections of paracoccidioidomycosis are treated with Amphotericin B.
What is the treatment for systemic (disseminated) infections of Histoplasmosis?	Systemic (disseminated) infections of Histoplasmosis are treated with Amphotericin B.
What is the treatment for systemic (disseminated) infections of coccidioidomycosis?	Systemic (disseminated) infections of coccidioidomycosis are treated with Amphotericin B.
What is the treatment for systemic (disseminated) infections of Blastomycosis?	Systemic (disseminated) infections of Blastomycosis are treated with Amphotericin B.
What type of motoneurons in the anterior horn can be damaged due to syrinx expansion in syringomyelia?	Syrinx expansion in syringomyelia may lead to damage to the lower motoneurons of the anterior horn.
What syndrome may be caused by syrinx expansion in the late stage of syringomyelia?	Syrinx expansion in syringomyelia (late stage) may cause Horner syndrome.
In which extremity do pain/temperature deficits typically occur as a result of syringomyelia?	Syringomyelia typically results in pain/temperature deficits in the upper extremity.
What part of the spinothalamic tract is damaged in syringomyelia, and where do the 2nd-order neurons crossing occur?	Syringomyelia results in damage to the spinothalamic tract 2nd-order neurons crossing in the anterior white commissure.
At which spinal cord levels does syringomyelia most commonly occur?	Syringomyelia most commonly occurs at spinal cord levels C8 - T1.
With which type of Chiari malformations is syringomyelia (cystic dilation of central cord) associated?	Syringomyelia (cystic dilation of central cord) is associated with Chiari I malformations.
What is another name for synthetic cathinones?	Synthetic cathinones are also known as bath salts.
What class of drugs are synthetic cathinones, also known as "bath salts", similar to?	Synthetic cathinones, also known as "bath salts", are recreational drugs that are similar to amphetamines.
What are the typical manifestations of synthetic cathinone intoxication and how does it affect mental status?	Synthetic cathinone intoxication typically causes manifestations of sympathetic stimulation and markedly altered mental status.
What are the vitamins required for the synthesis of vitamin B3 (niacin)?	The synthesis of vitamin B3 (niacin) requires vitamins B2 and B6.
What is the cofactor required for the synthesis of GABA from glutamate?	The synthesis of GABA from glutamate requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor.
What type of crystals are found in synovial fluid analysis of patients with gout, and what are their characteristics?	Synovial fluid analysis in patients with gout is characterized by needle-shaped crystals made of monosodium urate, that are negatively-birefringent.
What are the treatment options for Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH)?	Treatment options for Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) include water restriction, conivaptan/tolvaptan, or a tetracycline such as demeclocycline.
What are the treatment options for Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?	Treatment options for Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess include K+ sparing diuretics or corticosteroids.
What are the symptoms of Sheehan syndrome?	The symptoms of Sheehan syndrome include poor lactation, loss of pubic hair, and fatigue.
When do symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome typically worsen or occur?	Symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome typically worsen or only occur during the night-time.
What can partially or totally relieve symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome?	Movement can partially or totally relieve symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome.
What are the symptoms of orbital cellulitis?	The symptoms of orbital cellulitis include proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and visual changes.
What are the symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome?	The symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome include diarrhea, sweating, irritability, and tachypnea.
What are the symptoms of magnesium toxicity?	The symptoms of magnesium toxicity include hypo-calcemia and cardiac arrest.
What are the symptoms of magnesium toxicity?	The symptoms of magnesium toxicity include somnolence, respiratory depression, and hypo-reflexia.
What is a typical way that symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis are relieved?	Symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis are typically relieved while walking up-hill.
What activities can worsen the symptoms of intracranial hypertension?	Symptoms of intracranial hypertension can worsen with leaning forward, Valsalva, and coughing.
What are the common symptoms of intracranial hypertension?	The common symptoms of intracranial hypertension include headache that is worse in the morning, nausea/vomiting, and mental status changes.
What are the symptoms associated with increased intracranial pressure?	Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure include headache that is worse in the morning, nausea/vomiting, and mental status changes.
What percentage of pituitary parenchyma loss can cause symptoms of hypopituitarism?	Symptoms of hypopituitarism can arise when approximately 75% of the pituitary parenchyma is lost.
What are the symptoms associated with hyperammonemia?	Symptoms of hyperammonemia include asterixis (tremor), slurred speech, somnolence, vomiting, cerebral edema, and blurry vision.
At what age range do the symptoms of Huntington's disease typically appear?	Symptoms of Huntington's disease typically manifest between the ages of 20 and 50.
What are the risks associated with essential thrombocythemia that are related to its symptoms?	Symptoms of essential thrombocythemia are related to an increased risk of bleeding and/or thrombosis.
What are the symptoms associated with esophageal carcinoma?	Symptoms of esophageal carcinoma include progressive dysphagia (solids to liquids), weight loss, pain, and hematemesis.
What are the symptoms associated with Coltivirus (Colorado tick virus)?	Symptoms of Coltivirus (Colorado tick virus) include fevers, vomiting, and myalgia.
What are the symptoms associated with bronchial carcinoid tumor?	Symptoms of bronchial carcinoid tumor are related to mass effect or carcinoid syndrome.
What are the symptoms associated with botulism?	Symptoms of botulism include bilateral cranial neuropathies followed by symmetric, descending muscle weakness.
At what point do symptoms of atherosclerosis typically present?	Symptoms of atherosclerosis generally present when 70% of a vessel has been occluded (stenosis).
When do symptoms of atelectasis typically manifest, and what are some examples of these symptoms?	Symptoms of atelectasis (e.g. dyspnea, tachypnea) typically manifest on post-operative day 2 and 3.
What medical condition can symptoms of anxiety mimic?	Symptoms of anxiety can mimic a myocardial infarction.
What is a symptom of androgen excess in PCOS that may be treated with spironolactone?	Symptoms of androgen excess, such as hirsutism, in PCOS may be treated with spironolactone.
What are some symptoms of acute arsenic toxicity?	Symptoms of acute arsenic toxicity include vomiting, rice-water stools, garlic breath, and QT prolongation.
What is a possible symptomatic treatment for spasticity in MS patients?	Symptomatic treatment of spasticity in MS patients may include baclofen or other GABAB receptor agonists.
What is a possible symptomatic treatment for pain in MS patients?	Symptomatic treatment of pain in MS patients may include TCAs and anticonvulsants.
What is a possible symptomatic treatment for neurogenic bladder in MS patients?	Symptomatic treatment of neurogenic bladder in MS patients may include catheterization and/or muscarinic antagonists.
What is the urgent surgical procedure required for symptomatic spinal epidural hematomas?	Symptomatic spinal epidural hematomas require urgent surgical decompression of the spinal canal and evacuation of the hematoma by laminectomy.
What is the management strategy for symptomatic PVCs and stable ventricular tachycardia?	Symptomatic PVCs is managed with β-blocker / CCB while stable ventricular tachycardia is managed with amiodarone.
What are the typical blood glucose and C-peptide levels in symptomatic patients with insulinoma?	Symptomatic patients with insulinoma have low blood glucose and high C-peptide levels.
What is the potential risk for a female fetus in cases of symptomatic maternal luteoma?	Symptomatic maternal luteoma puts a female fetus at a high risk of virilization.
What is the management strategy for symptomatic bradycardia?	Symptomatic bradycardia is managed with IV atropine.
What type of aortic valve abnormality is commonly associated with symptomatic aortic stenosis in patients around age 50?	Symptomatic aortic stenosis may present in patients around age 50 with a bicuspid aortic valve.
What is the effect of sympathetic stimulation of β2 receptors in skeletal muscle?	Sympathetic stimulation of β2 receptors in skeletal muscle causes vasodilation.
What is the effect of sympathetic stimulation of α1 receptors in skeletal muscle?	Sympathetic stimulation of α1 receptors in skeletal muscle causes vasoconstriction.
What is the mechanism by which sympathetic stimulation increases the activity of Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA)?	Sympathetic stimulation increases the activity of Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) via phosphorylation/inhibition of phospholamban.
Through which receptors does sympathetic stimulation increase myocardial contractility?	Sympathetic stimulation increases myocardial contractility via β1 receptors.
What are the possible presentations of sympathetic ophthalmia?	Sympathetic ophthalmia may present as unilateral or bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis.
What is the difference in length between pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic neurons in the sympathetic nervous system?	Sympathetic neurons have short pre-ganglionic and long post-ganglionic neurons.
What nerves do sympathetic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion use to innervate the pupillary dilator muscle?	Sympathetic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion innervate the pupillary dilator muscle via long ciliary nerves.
What condition is characterized by symmetric distal sensory loss or burning sensation associated with motor weakness?	Symmetric distal sensory loss or burning sensation associated with motor weakness is characteristic of polyneuropathy.
What type of back pain is characterized by symmetric aching in a belt-like distribution?	Symmetric aching in a belt-like distribution is characteristic of musculoskeletal (MSK) back pain.
What medical condition may be indicated by the presence of swollen posterior cervical lymph nodes, swollen spleen, and pharyngitis?	Swollen posterior cervical lymph nodes, swollen spleen, and pharyngitis may indicate mononucleosis (EBV).
What type of volume contraction is caused by sweating in a desert?	Sweating in a desert causes hyper-osmotic volume contraction.
What is the management approach for swallowing a battery, magnet, or sharp item?	Swallowing a battery, magnet, or sharp item is managed with endoscopic removal.
What is the management approach for swallowing more than two magnets in the esophagus or stomach?	Swallowing more than two magnets in the esophagus or stomach is managed with endoscopic removal.
What are the common malignancies that can cause SVC syndrome?	SVC syndrome is commonly caused by malignancy, such as mediastinal mass and superior sulcus tumor.
What is the clinical manifestation of SVC syndrome related to the neck?	SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the neck, resulting in jugular venous distention.
What is the clinical manifestation of SVC syndrome related to the head?	SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the head, resulting in "facial plethora".
What are the potential neurological symptoms associated with severe cases of SVC syndrome?	SVC syndrome can raise intracranial pressure (if obstruction is severe), leading to headaches and dizziness.
What is a common cause of SVC syndrome related to central venous catheters?	SVC syndrome can be caused by thromboemboli from indwelling central venous catheters.
In which patient population is the use of Suvorexant not recommended?	Suvorexant is not recommended in patients with liver disease.
What is the medical condition in which the use of Suvorexant is contraindicated?	Suvorexant is contraindicated in patients with narcolepsy.
What type of medication should be avoided in patients taking strong CYP3A4 inhibitors?	Suvorexant is contraindicated in patients taking strong CYP3A4 inhibitors.
What is the recommended method of evaluation for suspicious thyroid nodules that are cold and growing?	Suspicious thyroid nodules (cold, growing) should be evaluated with FNA (fine needle aspiration).
What is the recommended diagnostic test for suspected pneumonia?	Suspected pneumonia is typically diagnosed with an X-ray.
What is the recommended management strategy for suspected pleural effusion?	Suspected pleural effusion is typically managed with diagnostic thoracocentesis.
What is the recommended management strategy for suspected duodenal ulcer?	Suspected duodenal ulcer is typically managed with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and antibiotics.
What is the recommended diagnostic test for suspected constitutional growth delay?	Suspected constitutional growth delay is typically diagnosed with a bone age assessment.
What is the recommended treatment for suspected acute megacolon with cecal dilation to 12 cm or signs of ischemia?	Suspected acute megacolon with cecal dilation to 12 cm or signs of ischemia is typically treated with laparotomy.
What laboratory test should be obtained if intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is suspected?	If intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is suspected, serum bile acid levels should be obtained.
What is the surgical management for primary hyperparathyroidism due to four gland hyperplasia?	The surgical management for primary hyperparathyroidism due to four gland hyperplasia is to remove 3.5 glands.
What is the contraindication for surgical ligation of a patent ductus arteriosus?	Surgical ligation of a patent ductus arteriosus is contraindicated when there is severe pulmonary hypertension.
What type of tissues is important to surgically excise in the treatment of Mucormycosis?	Surgical excision of necrotic tissues is an important step in the treatment of Mucormycosis.
What should be accompanied with surgical abortion to prevent infection?	Surgical abortion should be accompanied with antibiotics to prevent infection.
What medical condition may be precipitated by surgery, infection, trauma, childbirth, and acute iodine load in patients with hyperthyroidism?	Thyroid storm may be precipitated by surgery, infection, trauma, childbirth, and acute iodine load in patients with hyperthyroidism.
What are some common causes of ileus?	Surgery, diabetes, drugs, and sepsis are common causes of ileus.
What intermolecular forces are disrupted by surfactant to reduce surface tension?	Surfactant reduces surface tension by disrupting the intermolecular forces between liquid molecules.
How does surfactant prevent collapse of alveolar air sacs after expiration?	Surfactant decreases surface tension in the lung, preventing collapse of alveolar air sacs after expiration.
What is another name for surface alveolar growth?	Surface alveolar growth is also known as lepidic growth pattern.
What type of injury to the arm/elbow most often leads to supracondylar fractures?	Supracondylar fractures most often occur after hyperextension injuries of the arm/elbow.
What type of supplementation has been shown to improve premenstrual syndrome?	Supplementation with calcium (Ca2+) has been shown to improve premenstrual syndrome.
What are the layers of the skin involved in superficial partial thickness burns?	Superficial partial thickness burns involve the epidermis and the superficial dermis layers of the skin.
What is the typical skin reaction to a superficial partial thickness burn?	A superficial partial thickness burn typically causes the skin to blister.
What are the characteristics of superficial partial thickness burns?	Superficial partial thickness burns are typically blanchable, meaning the skin turns white when pressure is applied, and painful.
Which layer of the skin is involved in superficial burns?	Superficial burns involve only the epidermis layer of the skin.
What are the characteristics of superficial burns?	Superficial burns are typically blanchable, meaning the skin turns white when pressure is applied, and painful.
What degree of burns are classified as superficial burns?	Superficial burns are classified as 1st degree burns.
What syndrome can result from the presence of superantigens?	Superantigens can result in toxic shock syndrome.
What happens when superantigens result in a large release of cytokines?	When superantigens result in a large release of cytokines, it can lead to massive vasodilation/hypotension and shock.
What type of activation do superantigens cause in the body?	Superantigens are exotoxins that cause a massive amount of T-cell activation.
What type of cancer, characterized by VEGFR overexpression, can be treated with Sunitinib and Sorafenib?	Sunitinib and Sorafenib can treat cancer characterized by VEGFR overexpression, such as renal cell carcinoma.
What are the adverse effects associated with Sunitinib and Sorafenib?	Sunitinib and Sorafenib are associated with cutaneous hyperkeratosis and skin rashes.
What is the increased risk associated with Sunitinib and Sorafenib use?	Sunitinib and Sorafenib use is associated with an increased risk of hemorrhage.
How do sulfur granules of Actinomyces stain on H&E stain?	Sulfur granules of Actinomyces stain basophilic on H&E stain.
What is a significant possible side effect of sulfonylureas?	A significant possible side effect of sulfonylureas is hypoglycemia.
What type of drugs are sulfonylureas and how may they affect allergic patients?	Sulfonylureas are sulfa drugs and may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients.
What is a possible side effect of sulfonylureas and meglitinides?	A possible side effect of sulfonylureas and meglitinides is weight gain.
What is a significant possible side effect of sulfonylureas and meglitinides?	A significant possible side effect of sulfonylureas and meglitinides is hypoglycemia.
What are some agents that can cause renal failure by precipitating in renal tubules?	Sulfonamides, methotrexate, IV acyclovir, and triameterene are agents that can precipitate in renal tubules, causing renal failure.
What is the effect of sulfonamides on cytochrome P450?	Sulfonamides inhibit cytochrome P450.
What is the potential risk associated with taking sulfonamides and Warfarin together?	Sulfonamides increase the risk of bleeding when taken along with Warfarin.
What is the potential risk associated with sulfonamides in neonates?	Sulfonamides displace unconjugated bilirubin from albumin; can precipitate kernicterus in neonates.
What is the mechanism by which sulfonamides can cause kidney damage?	Sulfonamides can cause kidney damage by causing tubulointerstitial nephritis.
What is the potential skin sensitivity associated with sulfonamides?	Sulfonamides can cause skin sensitivity to light.
What is the potential thyroid-related side effect associated with sulfonamides?	Sulfonamides can cause hypothyroidism.
What type of Renal Tubular Acidosis can sulfonamides cause?	Sulfonamides can cause a Type IV Renal Tubular Acidosis.
What is the mechanism of action of sulfonamides as inhibitors of an enzyme?	Sulfonamides are competitive inhibitors of the enzyme Dihydropteroate Synthase.
What is the effect of sulfonamides on CYP-450?	Sulfonamides are inhibitors of CYP-450.
What is the effect of sulfonamides on cytochrome p450?	Sulfonamides are cytochrome p450 inhibitors.
In which patients are sulfonamides contraindicated due to enzyme deficiency?	Sulfonamides are contraindicated in patients with a deficiency of the enzyme Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.
Against which gram-positive branching, filamentous rod do sulfonamides (e.g. sulfamethoxazole) have activity?	Sulfonamides (e.g. sulfamethoxazole) have activity against the gram-positive branching, filamentous rod Nocardia.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting sulfatides to galactocerebroside?	The enzyme responsible for converting sulfatides to galactocerebroside is arylsulfatase A.
What is the primary medical condition for which sulfasalazine is indicated as an anti-inflammatory therapy?	Sulfasalazine is primarily indicated as an anti-inflammatory therapy for Rheumatoid Arthritis.
What activates sulfasalazine?	Sulfasalazine is activated by colonic bacteria.
What are the components of sulfasalazine and why is it contraindicated in patients with certain allergies?	Sulfasalazine is a combination of Mesalamine (anti-inflammatory) and Sulfapyridine (anti-bacterial), and thus is contraindicated in patients with sulfa allergies.
What potential side effect can sulfasalazine cause, and is it reversible?	Sulfasalazine can cause a reversible oligospermia.
In what type of patients can sulfasalazine cause hemolytic anemia?	Sulfasalazine can cause a hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency.
What type of bacteria is sulfamethoxazole effective against, including highly resistant strains such as MRSA?	Sulfamethoxazole has activity against gram positive bacteria, even the highly resistant MRSA.
What type of analog is sulfamethoxazole (SMX), and which enzyme does it inhibit?	Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) is a PABA analog, thus inhibiting the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase.
What type of drug-induced condition can sulfa drugs cause?	Sulfa drugs can cause a drug-induced lupus.
What rare cutaneous skin complication is associated with sulfa drugs?	Sulfa drugs are associated with the rare cutaneous skin complication Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
In what medical condition may sulcal effacement be seen on CT/MRI imaging?	Sulcal effacement may be seen on CT/MRI imaging of intracranial hypertension.
What medical condition is suggested by sudden-onset unilateral lower abdominal pain after strenuous activity with pelvic free fluid?	Sudden-onset unilateral lower abdominal pain after strenuous activity with pelvic free fluid is suggestive of ruptured ovarian cyst.
What medical conditions are associated with sudden-onset psoriasis?	Sudden-onset psoriasis is associated with HIV and streptococcal pharyngitis.
What condition is suggested by sudden onset pain with pain out of proportion (POOP) and possibly bloody stool?	Sudden onset pain with pain out of proportion (POOP) and possibly bloody stool is suggestive of ischemic condition.
What can sudden onset hydronephrosis cause in the kidney?	Sudden onset hydronephrosis may cause renal papillary necrosis.
What condition is suggested by sudden onset abdominal pain and patient being motionless?	Sudden onset abdominal pain and patient being motionless is suggestive of perforation.
How can sudden extremely loud noises cause hearing loss?	Sudden extremely loud noises can cause hearing loss due to tympanic membrane rupture (noise-induced hearing loss).
What type of symptoms can sudden discontinuation of SSRIs or SNRIs cause?	Sudden discontinuation of SSRIs or SNRIs can cause flu-like symptoms.
What medical device may prevent sudden cardiac death?	Sudden cardiac death may be prevented with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).
What is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death?	Sudden cardiac death is most commonly due to a lethal arrhythmia, such as ventricular fibrillation.
What are the products of the digestion of sucrose by sucrase?	Sucrose is digested by sucrase into glucose and fructose.
What type of receptors does succinylcholine bind to, and what effect does this have on ion flow?	Succinylcholine binds to post-synaptic ACh receptors, triggering an influx of Na+ and efflux of K+ (depolarization).
What is the mechanism of action of succinylcholine and what effect does it have on muscle function?	Succinylcholine is a strong ACh receptor agonist that produces sustained depolarization and prevents muscle contraction.
What is the product of the conversion of succinyl CoA, and which enzyme catalyzes this reaction?	Succinyl CoA is converted to succinate via the enzyme succinyl CoA synthetase.
What is the product of the conversion of succinate, and which enzyme catalyzes this reaction?	Succinate is converted to fumarate via the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase.
What are the potential symptoms associated with submucosal leiomyomas (fibroids)?	Submucosal leiomyomas (fibroids) may cause infertility and menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding).
What is the likely diagnosis of a submucosal gastrointestinal (GI) mass that is positive for c-KIT?	A submucosal gastrointestinal (GI) mass that is positive for c-KIT is likely to be a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).
In the case of subluxation of the radial head, where does the annular ligament slip over and into?	In the case of subluxation of the radial head, the annular ligament slips over and into the radiocapitellar joint.
What are the possible causes of a subhepatic abscess?	A subhepatic abscess may result from a perforated duodenal or gastric ulcer.
What is the cause of subgaleal hemorrhage?	Subgaleal hemorrhage is caused by injury to the emissary veins.
What is the function of subendothelial collagen and glycosaminoglycans in relation to atherosclerotic plaques?	Subendothelial collagen and glycosaminoglycans form the subendothelial fibrous cap over an atherosclerotic plaque and are potent platelet activators.
What condition can subendocardial vacuolization and patchy fibrosis due to severe coronary artery disease cause?	Subendocardial vacuolization and patchy fibrosis due to severe coronary artery disease may cause chronic ischemic heart disease.
What is the cause of subdural hematoma?	Subdural hematoma occurs due to tearing of bridging veins.
Which groups of people are most commonly affected by subdural hematoma?	Subdural hematoma is most commonly seen among elderly alcoholics and infants (shaken baby).
What type of subcutaneous swelling is diagnostic of Loa loa helminth infection?	Subcutaneous, 'Calabar' swellings are diagnostic of the helminth Loa loa.
What is the mechanism behind retrograde blood flow in subclavian steal syndrome?	Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when the subclavian artery is occluded, leading to retrograde flow from the vertebral artery.
What is the effect of subclavian steal syndrome on the brachial systolic blood pressure in the affected arm?	Subclavian steal syndrome is associated with a significantly lower brachial systolic blood pressure in the affected arm.
What are the radiological findings that suggest the presence of rheumatoid arthritis?	Subchondral cysts, periarticular osteopenia and joint margin erosions on X-ray is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis.
What is the significance of subareolar mass and nipple retraction in smokers?	Subareolar mass and nipple retraction in smokers is suggestive of periductal mastitis.
What are the common symptoms associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage?	Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden headache and nuchal rigidity.
What is one of the potential symptoms that may be caused by subarachnoid hemorrhage?	Subarachnoid hemorrhage may cause photophobia (fear of light).
What are the potential complications associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage?	Subarachnoid hemorrhage is associated with increased risk of developing communicating high pressure and/or obstructive hydrocephalus.
How is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis diagnosed?	Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is diagnosed with the presence of anti-measles antibodies in CSF.
What are the initial and subsequent states of presentation in subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain)?	Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) may initially present with hyperthyroidism, which typically is followed by a brief hypothyroid state.
What is the cause of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) and is it a self-limited disease?	Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) is often caused by viral infection and is a self-limited disease.
What is the common cause of subacute endocarditis and what procedures can lead to it?	Subacute endocarditis is often caused by bacterial infection and is a sequela of dental procedures.
What is subacute combined degeneration and which tracts are affected by demyelination in this condition?	Subacute combined degeneration is a neurological condition characterized by demyelination of spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns.
What type of bacterial infection is typically indicated by subacute bacterial endocarditis following a dental procedure?	Subacute bacterial endocarditis following a dental procedure likely indicates an infection from the viridans group streptococci bacteria.
What condition is suggested by subacute appendicitis lasting for more than five days?	Subacute appendicitis lasting for more than five days is suggestive of an appendiceal abscess.
What is the potential cause of sudden-onset seizures and acute hemiparesis in individuals with Sturge-Weber syndrome?	Individuals with Sturge-Weber syndrome may present with sudden-onset seizures and acute hemiparesis due to contralateral leptomeningeal angiomas.
What is Sturge-Weber syndrome and what is its potential cause?	Sturge-Weber syndrome is a developmental anomaly of neural crest derivatives that is potentially caused by somatic mosaicism.
What type of blood vessels are affected by Sturge-Weber syndrome?	Sturge-Weber syndrome affects small, capillary-sized blood vessels.
How is struvite stone managed?	Struvite stone is managed with stone removal.
Which structures are included in the limbic system?	The structures included in the limbic system are the hippocampus, amygdala, fornix, mammillary bodies, and cingulate gyrus.
What are the treatment options for Strongyloides stercoralis infection?	The treatment options for Strongyloides stercoralis infection are albendazole or ivermectin.
What is the strongest risk factor that predicts suicide?	The strongest risk factor that predicts suicide is a prior suicide attempt.
What is the strongest risk factor for developing gastric cancer?	The strongest risk factor for developing gastric cancer is H. Pylori infection.
Which artery forms strong anastomoses with the left gastroepiploic artery?	The right gastroepiploic artery forms strong anastomoses with the left gastroepiploic artery.
Which artery forms strong anastomoses with the left gastric artery?	The right gastric artery forms strong anastomoses with the left gastric artery.

Which cerebral artery is involved in strokes that may cause aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere?	Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery may cause aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere.
Which cerebral artery is involved in strokes that may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral lower limb?	Strokes involving the anterior cerebral artery may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral lower limb.
Which brain structures are typically involved in strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery?	Strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery typically involve the striatum and internal capsule.
What are the potential effects of strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery on the body?	Strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral entire body.
What medical conditions or events may cause SIADH?	Stroke, meningitis, surgery, ectopic-producing tumor, and head trauma may cause SIADH.
What diagnostic imaging technique is typically used to manage stroke and exclude hemorrhage before administering tPA?	Noncontrast CT is typically used to manage stroke and exclude hemorrhage before administering tPA.
What are the benign and malignant tumors that can arise from striated muscle?	Striated muscle can give rise to a rhabdomyoma (benign) and rhabdomyosarcoma (malignant).

What is the condition that stress urinary incontinence is often associated with, which refers to excessive movement of the urethra?	Stress urinary incontinence is often associated with urethral hyper-mobility.
What are the weight conditions associated with stress fractures and shin splints, respectively?	Stress fracture is associated with underweight individuals, while shin splints are associated with overweight individuals.
What are the two hormones that are secreted in response to stress, especially when insulin is not present?	The two hormones that are secreted in response to stress, particularly in the absence of insulin, are epinephrine and cortisol.
What is the bacterial cause of tularemia that is treated by the aminoglycoside antibiotic, streptomycin?	Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that treats tularemia caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis.
What type of drug is streptomycin in the treatment of tuberculosis, and where does it fall in the treatment hierarchy?	Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is classified as a second-line drug in the treatment of tuberculosis.
What are the two notable toxicities associated with the use of streptomycin?	The use of streptomycin is associated with notable CNS (central nervous system) toxicity and nephrotoxicity (kidney toxicity).
What zoonotic infection can be treated with streptomycin?	Streptomycin can also be used to treat tularemia, a zoonotic infection caused by Francisella tularensis.
Which gram-positive species is Streptokinase a virulence factor for?	Streptokinase is a virulence factor for Group A Streptococcus (GAS).
Which species of Streptococcus is optochin sensitive?	Streptococcus pneumoniae is optochin sensitive.
Which species of Streptococcus can cause bacteremia and subacute endocarditis, and is also associated with colon cancer?	Streptococcus gallolyticus can cause bacteremia and subacute endocarditis, and is also associated with colon cancer.
What type of hemolysis is associated with Streptococcus viridans?	Streptococcus viridans is alpha-hemolytic.
Is Streptococcus viridans optochin sensitive or resistant?	Streptococcus viridans is optochin resistant.
Is Streptococcus viridans bile soluble or insoluble?	Streptococcus viridans is bile insoluble.
What is the name of the superficial skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes?	The superficial skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes is called erysipelas.
What is the name of the deep skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes?	The deep skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes is called cellulitis.
What is the name of the skin condition characterized by "honeycomb-like" crusts on the skin caused by Streptococcus pyogenes?	The skin condition characterized by "honeycomb-like" crusts on the skin caused by Streptococcus pyogenes is called non bullous impetigo.
What is another name for Streptococcus pyogenes?	Streptococcus pyogenes is also known as group A strep (GAS).
What is the result of the pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) test for Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS)?	The result of the PYR test for Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) is positive.

What are the two virulence factors of Streptococcus pneumoniae?	The two virulence factors of Streptococcus pneumoniae are an anti-phagocytic polysaccharide capsule and IgA protease.
What type of hemolysis does Streptococcus pneumoniae exhibit?	Streptococcus pneumoniae exhibits alpha-hemolysis.
What is the characteristic feature of Streptococcus pneumoniae in terms of bile solubility?	Streptococcus pneumoniae is bile soluble.
What is the characteristic feature of Streptococcus gallolyticus in terms of pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) activity?	Streptococcus gallolyticus is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) negative.
What is another name for Streptococcus bovis biotype 1?	Streptococcus bovis biotype 1 is known as Streptococcus gallolyticus.
What medical condition is associated with both Streptococcus bovis and Clostridia septicum?	Streptococcus bovis and Clostridia septicum are associated with colon cancer.
What is the neonatal respiratory complication associated with Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) infection?	Neonatal pneumonia is the respiratory complication associated with Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) infection.
What type of hemolysis is associated with Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is β-hemolytic.
What is the result of the pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) test for Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) negative.
What is the result of the hippurate hydrolysis test for Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is hippurate positive.
What is the Gram stain result for Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is gram positive.
What is the result of the catalase test for Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is catalase negative.
What is the susceptibility of Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) to bacitracin?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is bacitracin resistant.
What are some diseases caused by Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)?	Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) causes neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia.
What are the typical symptoms of Strep. pyogenes (group A) pharyngitis?	Strep. pyogenes (group A) pharyngitis typically presents with a positive fever, negative cough, and negative rhinorrhea.

What type of immune response does the Strep pneumoniae polysaccharide vaccine produce in adults?	The Strep pneumoniae polysaccharide vaccine in adults produces an IgM response.
Why will Strep pneumoniae present a problem in sickle cell/asplenic patients?	Strep pneumoniae is encapsulated, which means it will present a problem in sickle cell/asplenic patients.
What does Strep pneumoniae contain that allows it to adhere and colonize the mucous membranes?	Strep pneumoniae contains IgA protease, which allows the bacteria to adhere and colonize the mucous membranes.

What type of immune response does the Strep pneumoniae conjugate vaccine produce in children?	The Strep pneumoniae conjugate vaccine produces an IgG response in children.
What condition is suggested by strabismus or congenital cataracts leading to cortical blindness?	Strabismus or congenital cataracts leading to cortical blindness is suggestive of amblyopia.
What type of eye drops, used for penalization, may be used to treat strabismus?	Cycloplegic eye drops, such as cyclopentolate, may be used for penalization to treat strabismus.
What type of agents are stool softeners, and how do they facilitate the penetration of stool?	Stool softeners are surfactant agents that facilitate the penetration of stool by water and lipids.
What inhibits the stimulation of the lateral area of the hypothalamus?	Leptin inhibits the stimulation of the lateral area of the hypothalamus.
What physiological responses result from the stimulation of hypothalamic osmoreceptors?	Stimulation of hypothalamic osmoreceptors results in the stimulation of thirst and secretion of ADH (antidiuretic hormone).
What effect can stimulants such as amphetamine and methylphenidate have on appetite?	Stimulants such as amphetamine and methylphenidate may suppress appetite.
What medical condition is often indicated by the presence of a stiff neck, fever, headache, and mental status changes?	The presence of a stiff neck, fever, headache, and mental status changes often indicate meningitis.
What medications are commonly included in STI prophylaxis regimens following a sexual assault?	STI prophylaxis regimens following a sexual assault commonly include ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and azithromycin.
What type of reaction typically leads to the development of Stevens-Johnson syndrome?	Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically arises as an adverse drug reaction.
What effect do steroids have on the production of RANK-L and osteoprotegerin?	Steroids cause high production of RANK-L and low production of osteoprotegerin.
What is suggested by the presence of psychotic symptoms in individuals taking steroids?	The presence of psychotic symptoms in individuals taking steroids is suggestive of substance-induced psychotic disorder.
What specific DNA sequences do steroid receptors bind to in order to initiate a steroid response?	Steroid receptors are specific transcription factors that bind to steroid response elements to cause a steroid response.
What are steroid hormone-receptor dimers and what is their role in DNA transcription?	Steroid hormone-receptor dimers are transcription factors that bind to steroid-response elements (SREs) of DNA and initiate transcription.
What medication or treatment may cause steroid diabetes in patients?	Steroid diabetes may be seen in patients on glucocorticoid therapy.
What is the typical next step or outcome after sternal wound drainage following cardiovascular surgery?	Sternal wound drainage after CV surgery leads to chest imaging.
What type of dementia is characterized by a step-wise decline and the presence of periventricular (lacunar) infarcts?	Step-wise decline with periventricular (lacunar) infarcts = vascular dementia.
What anatomic landmark is considered Station 0 during fetal delivery?	The ischial spine is considered Station 0 during fetal delivery.
In patients with a history of TIA, what is the effect of statins on the risk of future vascular events?	Statins reduce the risk of future vascular events in patients with a history of TIA or stroke.
What is the potential adverse effect of statins on liver function tests?	Statins may cause mild hepato-toxicity, and thus mild elevations in liver function tests.
What is the potential risk associated with the use of statins during the first trimester of pregnancy?	Statins may be teratogenic, therefore they should be avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy.
What is the effect of statins on LDL receptor expression on hepatocytes?	Statins indirectly cause increased LDL receptor expression on hepatocytes.
What is the potential biomarker of myopathy that may be elevated in serum due to the use of statins?	Statins can cause elevations in serum CK, which may be indicative of myopathy.

What is the recommended course of action if a patient on statin therapy develops myositis or hepatitis?	If a patient on statin therapy develops myositis or hepatitis, it is recommended to stop the statin.

What is the catalase result for Staphylococcus aureus?	Staphylococcus aureus is catalase positive.
What type of infection can Staphylococcus aureus cause that may present with a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray?	Staphylococcus aureus infection can cause pneumonia with patchy infiltrate on CXR.
What type of endocarditis does Staphylococcus aureus cause and what are the characteristics of the vegetations that it produces?	Staphylococcus aureus causes acute endocarditis, which is characterized by large vegetations that destroy the valve.

What type of agar will Staphylococcus aureus turn bright yellow?	Staphylococcus aureus will turn Mannitol agar bright yellow.

What are the typical symptoms of Lyme disease during Stage 1?	During Stage 1, Lyme disease commonly presents with flu-like symptoms.

What are the treatment options for Stage 3 Heart Failure?	The treatment options for Stage 3 Heart Failure include adding spironolactone or BiDil to the patient's medication regimen.
What is the recommended treatment for Stage 2 hypertension in terms of medication?	The recommended treatment for Stage 2 hypertension is to use two medications.
What is the recommended treatment for stable small bowel obstruction?	The recommended treatment for stable small bowel obstruction includes IV fluids and NG intubation for decompression.
What are the management strategies for stable and unstable atrial fibrillation?	Stable atrial fibrillation is managed with rate or rhythm control, while unstable atrial fibrillation is managed with cardioversion.
What are the typical characteristics of chest pain in stable angina?	Chest pain in stable angina typically lasts less than 20 minutes and can radiate to the left arm or jaw.
What are the typical ways that stable angina can be relieved?	Stable angina is often relieved by rest or with the use of nitroglycerin.
What is the typical cause of stable angina and what percentage of stenosis is commonly associated with it?	Stable angina is often due to atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries, with a commonly associated stenosis percentage of 70%.
What is the typical electrocardiogram (ECG) finding associated with stable angina?	Stable angina is typically associated with ST depression on an ECG.
What is the effect of St. John's wort on CYP-450?	St. John's wort is an inducer of CYP-450.
What condition is typically suggested by the presence of ST elevation?	The presence of ST elevation is typically suggestive of STEMI (ST-elevation myocardial infarction).
How long should a patient take SSRIs at full dose before considering a change in medication?	Patients should take SSRIs at full dose for 6 weeks before considering a change in medication.
What is the primary neurotransmitter whose pre-synaptic reuptake is inhibited by SSRIs?	The primary neurotransmitter whose pre-synaptic reuptake is inhibited by SSRIs is serotonin (5-HT).
What potential complication in newborns is associated with the use of SSRIs during pregnancy?	The use of SSRIs during pregnancy may cause persistent pulmonary hypertension in newborns.
What is a potential side effect of SSRIs in regards to weight?	A potential side effect of SSRIs is weight gain.
What types of sexual dysfunction can be caused by SSRIs?	SSRIs can cause sexual dysfunction, such as anorgasmia and decreased libido.
What condition is SSRIs effective in treating?	SSRIs are effective in treating bulimia.

What is a common presentation of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder?	Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder typically presents with painless hematuria.
What type of metaplasia is associated with the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder?	Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder arises in a background of squamous metaplasia.
Which part of the lip is most commonly affected by squamous cell carcinoma?	Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy of the lower lip.
What is the histological feature of squamous cell carcinoma characterized by invasive cords of squamous cells?	Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls.
What is the histological feature of squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the formation of a specific structure?	Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by the formation of keratin pearls.
What are the two different causes associated with squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma of the esophagus?	Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus is associated with irritants, while adenocarcinoma of the esophagus is associated with GERD.
What does Spurling's maneuver involve in terms of tilting the neck and applying pressure to the head?	Spurling's maneuver involves tilting the neck towards the affected side and applying downward pressure to the head.
What is the cause of sprains of the Anterior Talofibular Ligament?	Sprains of the Anterior Talofibular Ligament are caused by an over inversion of the foot.
What type of ankle sprain is a sprain of the Anterior Talofibular Ligament classified as?	A sprain of the Anterior Talofibular Ligament is classified as a low ankle sprain.
What is the destination of Plasmodium sporozoites from mosquitoes in the human body and what do they mature into?	Plasmodium sporozoites from mosquitoes travel to the human liver (hepatocytes), where they replicate and mature into trophozoites.
What are the methods used to confirm a diagnosis of sporotrichosis?	A diagnosis of sporotrichosis is confirmed via culture or biopsy.
What is the typical result of Sporothrix schenckii infection at the site of trauma and first entry?	Sporothrix schenckii infection at the site of trauma and first entry typically results in a local pustule or ulcer.
What type of cells make up the granulomas in Sporothrix schenckii lesions?	The granulomas in Sporothrix schenckii lesions are made up of histiocytes and giant cells.
How would you describe the behavior of Sporothrix schenckii in terms of its morphology?	Sporothrix schenckii is dimorphic, which means that it assumes different forms depending on the temperature of its environment.
Where are spores of Clostridium perfringens commonly found?	Spores of Clostridium perfringens are commonly found in soil.
What is the recommended follow-up procedure for someone experiencing spontaneous, unilateral serosanguinous nipple discharge?	Spontaneous, unilateral serosanguinous nipple discharge is typically followed up with mammography, ultrasound, and biopsy.
What is the empirical treatment for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?	Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is empirically treated with a 3rd generation cephalosporin.
What are the common aerobic, gram-negative organisms that cause spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?	Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is commonly caused by aerobic, gram-negative organisms, especially E. coli and Klebsiella.
What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortions?	Spontaneous abortions are most commonly the result of fetal chromosomal abnormalities.
What is the definition of spontaneous abortion and at what point in gestation does it occur?	Spontaneous abortion is the miscarriage of a fetus before 20 weeks gestation.
What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion and which chromosomal anomaly is frequently associated with it?	Spontaneous abortion is most often due to chromosomal anomalies, especially trisomy 16.
How common is spontaneous abortion and what percentage of recognizable pregnancies does it occur in?	Spontaneous abortion is common and occurs in up to 1/4 of recognizable pregnancies.
What are splenic sinusoids and what part of the spleen do they constitute?	Splenic sinusoids are long, vascular channels with fenestrated basement membranes that constitute the red pulp of the spleen.
What is the potential consequence of splenic lacerations and which nerve can be irritated as a result?	Splenic lacerations can lead to the irritation of the phrenic nerve.
What is the most common cause of splenic abscess?	Splenic abscess is typically caused by infective endocarditis.
What is the long-term risk associated with splenectomy and which type of bacteria is commonly involved?	Splenectomy is associated with a long-term risk for sepsis, which is commonly caused by encapsulated bacteria.
How does spironolactone potentially exert anti-androgenic effects and which receptor does it directly antagonize?	Spironolactone may exert anti-androgenic effects via direct antagonism of the androgen receptor.
What are the potential adverse effects associated with spironolactone and how might they affect sexual function?	Spironolactone may cause impotence and decreased libido as adverse effects, which can affect sexual function.
What are the potential adverse effects associated with spironolactone and how might they manifest?	Spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia and gynecomastia as adverse effects.
Where does spinal stenosis most commonly occur?	Spinal stenosis most commonly occurs in the lumbar region.
What type of physical activity can be beneficial for individuals with spinal stenosis?	For individuals with spinal stenosis, walking uphill can be beneficial.
How does spinal muscular atrophy typically present in terms of weakness?	Spinal muscular atrophy typically presents with bilateral symmetric weakness.
What are the typical characteristics of back pain associated with spinal metastases?	Back pain associated with spinal metastases is typically worse at night and is not relieved by position changes or analgesics.
