At what vertebral levels is spina bifida occulta typically observed?	Spina bifida occulta is typically observed at lower vertebral levels.
What is the typical level of AFP in utero in individuals with spina bifida occulta?	Individuals with spina bifida occulta typically have normal levels of AFP in utero.
In spina bifida, which part of the vertebral arch fails to close properly?	Spina bifida is due to failure of the posterior vertebral arch to close.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting sphingomyelin to ceramide?	Sphingomyelin is converted to ceramide via the enzyme sphingomyelinase.
What are the symptoms of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction?	Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction produces recurrent, episodic pain in the right upper quadrant or epigastric region with elevations in AST/ALT/ALP.
What happens to spherocytes due to their reduced ability to maneuver through splenic sinusoids?	Spherocytes are consumed by splenic macrophages because they are less able to maneuver through splenic sinusoids.
What is the characteristic feature of spherocytes?	Spherocytes are characterized by the absence of central pallor.
Which strains of Streptococcus pyogenes cause toxic shock-like syndrome?	Sp A and C of Streptococcus pyogenes cause toxic shock-like syndrome.
Which strains of Streptococcus pyogenes are considered superantigens?	Sp A and C of Streptococcus pyogenes are considered superantigens.
What is the spectrum of amoxicillin and ampicillin (aminopenicillins)?	The spectrum of amoxicillin and ampicillin (aminopenicillins) is broad.
For ruling out which type of disease is it desirable to have specificity values approaching 100%?	For ruling out disease, it is desirable to have specificity values approaching 100%.
What form of behavioral therapy is used to treat specific phobias?	Systematic desensitization therapy, a form of behavioral therapy, is used to treat specific phobias.
What are the specific indications for caspofungin?	The specific indications for caspofungin are RACE: refractory aspergillosis, azole-resistant Candida, candidemia, and empiric treatment in a febrile, neutropenic patient.
What are the special findings associated with a median nerve injury?	The special findings associated with a median nerve injury are "Median Claw" (distal lesion) and "Pope's blessing" (proximal lesion).
What is SpeB associated with?	SpeB of Streptococcus pyogenes is associated with necrotizing fasciitis.
What condition is suggested by spasms/hypertonicity in an infant of a poorly-immunized mother with poor umbilical stump management?	Spasms/hypertonicity in an infant of a poorly-immunized mother with poor umbilical stump management is suggestive of neonatal tetanus.
What ability does Sorafenib have and how does it affect tumor growth?	Sorafenib has the ability to induce autophagy, which helps suppress tumor growth but can also cause drug resistance.
Which RTK is inhibited by Sorafenib and Sunitinib?	Sorafenib and Sunitinib inhibit the VEGF RTK.
What is the purpose of using sonohysterography (saline-infusion ultrasound) and which type of fibroids is it commonly used to detect?	Sonohysterography (saline-infusion ultrasound) is used for detecting submucosal fibroids, the most common type to cause abnormal bleeding / pregnancy loss.
What do some malignant tumors secrete and how is it structurally related to the PTH secreted by the parathyroid glands?	Some malignant tumors secrete PTH-related peptide (PTH-rp), which is structurally homologous with the PTH secreted by the parathyroid glands.
Why are some VSDs asymptomatic at birth?	Some VSDs are asymptomatic at birth due to high pulmonary vascular resistance.
What may happen to some patients with a history of irregular periods after they discontinue OCPs?	Some patients with a history of irregular periods may have a period of amenorrhea following discontinuation of OCPs.
What happens to some of the iron that is absorbed in the duodenum and where is it stored?	Some of the iron that is absorbed in the duodenum is taken up by hepatocytes for storage as ferritin.
What molecules are responsible for returning some of the hemoglobin in the blood due to intravascular hemolysis to the spleen?	Haptoglobin molecules are responsible for returning some of the hemoglobin in the blood due to intravascular hemolysis to the spleen.
What is lip oligosaccharide and what does it lack in some Gram Negative Bacteria?	Lip oligosaccharide is a component found in some Gram Negative Bacteria, which lacks an O antigen.
What are the tooth abnormalities seen in some forms of osteogenesis imperfecta and what causes them?	Some forms of osteogenesis imperfecta have tooth abnormalities, including opalescent teeth that wear easily due to lack of dentin.
What is the effect of some Fluoroquinolones on the QT interval?	Some Fluoroquinolones can prolong the QT interval.
Which breast(s) are at increased risk for invasive carcinoma due to fibrocystic-related changes?	Some fibrocystic-related changes carry increased risk for invasive carcinoma, which applies to both breasts.
What is the function of choroid epithelial cells that are produced from the differentiation of some ependymal cells?	Some ependymal cells differentiate into choroid epithelial cells, which produce cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
What is the purpose of glycocalyx secretion by some bacteria?	Some bacteria secrete a glycocalyx, allowing the bacteria to stick to a surface.
What is the dormant state called that some bacteria can enter?	Some bacteria can enter a dormant state called a spore.
What are the symptoms that may be presented by somatostatinoma due to the inhibition of secretin and CCK?	Somatostatinoma may present with gallstones and steatorrhea due to inhibition of secretin and CCK.
What is the symptom that somatostatinoma may present with due to the inhibition of insulin?	Somatostatinoma may present with diabetes due to inhibition of insulin.
What is the symptom that somatostatinoma may present with due to the inhibition of gastrin?	Somatostatinoma may present with achlorhydria due to inhibition of gastrin.
How does somatostatin secretion respond to vagal stimulation?	Somatostatin secretion is decreased in response to vagal stimulation.
What is the factor that stimulates somatostatin secretion in the GI mucosa?	Somatostatin secretion is stimulated by low pH in the GI mucosa.
What medical condition is diagnosed using somatostatin receptor scintigraphy or CT scan?	Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy or CT scan is used to diagnose ZES.
What is the mechanism by which somatostatin decreases gastric acid secretion?	Somatostatin decreases gastric acid secretion by decreasing levels of cAMP.
Which fluid compartment are solutes like NaCl and mannitol confined to, since they cannot cross cell membranes?	Solutes such as NaCl and mannitol do not cross cell membranes and are thus confined to the extracellular fluid compartment.
What are the common symptoms of solitary plasmacytoma, and which part of the body does it most commonly affect?	Solitary plasmacytoma most commonly affects bone and causes pain or pathologic fractures.
What condition is suggested by the presence of a soft, mobile, non-tender subareolar mass?	The presence of a soft, mobile, non-tender subareolar mass is suggestive of galactocele.
What condition is sodium stibogluconate used to treat?	Sodium stibogluconate is used to treat all forms of Leishmaniasis.
What are some modifiable risk factors for primary hypertension?	Modifiable risk factors for primary hypertension include sodium intake, obesity (sedentary lifestyle), and alcohol intake.
What type of drug overdoses can be treated with sodium bicarbonate?	Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat drug overdoses that are caused by drugs that are weak acids.
How is sodium bicarbonate used in the management of hyperkalemia?	Sodium bicarbonate is used in the management of hyperkalemia to deal with the acidosis caused by rapid cell buffering.
How does sodium bicarbonate alleviate the cardiotoxicity associated with TCA overdose?	Sodium bicarbonate alleviates the cardiotoxicity associated with TCA overdose by decreasing TCA's ability to bind fast-acting Na+ channels.
Which type of arterioles in the kidney primarily experience vasoconstriction due to SNS activity and catecholamines?	SNS activity and catecholamines primarily cause vasoconstriction of the renal afferent arterioles.
For what type of chronic pain might SNRIs be used as a treatment?	SNRIs may be used to treat chronic pain, such as neuropathic pain.
Which neurotransmitters do SNRIs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of?	SNRIs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin.
What is the effect of smoking on the risk of developing Crohn disease and Ulcerative colitis?	Smoking increases the risk for Crohn disease and decreases the risk for Ulcerative colitis.
What disease is smoking protective against?	Smoking is protective against ulcerative colitis.
Which inflammatory bowel disease is smoking considered a protective factor for?	Smoking is considered a protective factor for ulcerative colitis.
What is the effect of smoking on the risk of developing Crohn disease?	Smoking increases the risk for Crohn disease.
Is there a specific virus that smokers can contract that will lead to an aversion to tobacco products?	Yes, smokers who contract hepatitis A virus may develop an aversion to tobacco products.
What is another name for smallpox, and to which family of viruses does it belong?	Smallpox is also known as variola, and it belongs to the poxviridae family of viruses.
What are the typical characteristics of smaller ventricular septal defects, and how do they present on physical examination?	Smaller ventricular septal defects are often asymptomatic and may close spontaneously, but on physical exam will present with a murmur.
What is the likely diagnosis for a small, mobile, firm mass with sharp edges?	A likely diagnosis for a small, mobile, firm mass with sharp edges is a fibroadenoma, which is a benign tumor.
Which small vessels in the brain are particularly susceptible to hypertensive vasculopathy and hemorrhagic stroke?	The small vessels supplying the deep cerebellar nuclei are particularly susceptible to hypertensive vasculopathy and hemorrhagic stroke.
What are the diagnostic methods for small intestinal bacterial overgrowth?	Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth can be diagnosed via carbohydrate (lactulose) breath testing or jejunal aspirate/culture.
What is the relationship between small intestinal bacterial overgrowth and D-xylose urine levels?	Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth can result in reversible low D-xylose urine levels.
What are small DNA structures that replicate independently within the cells of bacteria known as?	Small DNA structures that replicate independently within the cells of bacteria are known as plasmids.
What is the primary treatment for small cell carcinoma?	The primary treatment for small cell carcinoma is chemotherapy.
What are the common symptoms associated with small bowel obstruction?	Small bowel obstruction may present with colicky abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, and constipation.
What are the physical signs of small bowel obstruction?	Small bowel obstruction may present with a tympanitic abdomen and distension due to backup of gas in the intestines.
What is a less common cause of small bowel obstruction?	Tumor (e.g. cancer) is a less common cause of small bowel obstruction.
How are bowel sounds affected in cases of small bowel obstruction?	Small bowel obstruction is characterized by hyper-active bowel sounds initially.
What is a common presenting symptom of small bowel obstruction caused by fibrotic stricture?	Small bowel obstruction (SBO) due to fibrotic stricture typically presents with bilious vomiting.
Where is small (oat) cell carcinoma typically located?	Small (oat) cell carcinoma is centrally located.
What oncogene is commonly associated with amplification in cases of small (oat) cell carcinoma?	Small (oat) cell carcinoma is commonly associated with amplification of the myc oncogene.
What conditions are typically associated with diminished mesenteric fat and can lead to SMA syndrome?	SMA syndrome typically occurs in conditions associated with diminished mesenteric fat (e.g. low body weight, malnutrition).
What type of intermittent obstruction symptoms are primarily associated with SMA syndrome?	SMA syndrome is characterized by intermittent obstruction symptoms, primarily postprandial pain.
What are the possible causes of SMA syndrome?	SMA syndrome can occur due to pronounced lordosis or surgical correction of scoliosis.
What is the purpose of the delayed conduction through the AV node in the heart?	Slowed conduction through the AV node normally causes a 100-msec delay, allowing time for ventricular filling.
What is the factor that increases the risk of side effects from Isoniazid (INH)?	Slow acetylators have an increased risk of side effects from Isoniazid (INH).
What is the origin of slow waves in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and what is their function?	Slow waves originate in the interstitial cells of Cajal, which serve as the pacemaker for GI smooth muscle.
What is the reason for slow twitch muscle fibers to perform more oxidative phosphorylation?	Slow twitch muscle fibers perform more oxidative phosphorylation due to increased mitochondria.
What is the reason for slow twitch muscle fibers to appear red in color?	Slow twitch muscle fibers are red due to increased myoglobin concentration.
What is the characteristic feature of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) in terms of thigh rotation upon hip flexion?	Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by external rotation of the thigh upon hip flexion.
What is the consequence of slippage in a template strand?	Slippage in a template strand will cause a deletion.
What is the consequence of slippage in a replicated strand?	Slippage in a replicated strand will cause an insertion.
What are the two stages into which sleep is divided?	Sleep is divided into two stages, REM and non-REM.
What is the association between sleep and REM latency in the elderly?	Sleep in the elderly is associated with increased REM latency.
What is the association between sleep and REM sleep in the elderly?	Sleep in the elderly is associated with decreased REM sleep.
What is a common clinical presentation of sleep apnea?	Sleep apnea often presents clinically with daytime sleepiness.
How is sleep apnea characterized in terms of Pao2 and Paco2 during the day?	Sleep apnea is characterized by a normal Pao2 and Paco2 during the day.
What medical condition is sleep apnea associated with and what is the cause of this association?	Sleep apnea is associated with pulmonary hypertension due to nocturnal hypoxia.
What type of arrhythmias are commonly associated with sleep apnea?	Sleep apnea is associated with arrhythmias, especially atrial fibrillation/flutter.
What antibodies are commonly associated with SLE?	SLE may be associated with antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g. anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant).
What part of the body may be affected by SLE, and what are some potential neurological symptoms that may result?	SLE may affect the brain, causing seizures or psychosis.
What is the typical level of CH50 associated with SLE?	SLE is characterized by decreased levels of CH50.
What is the typical level of C3 and C4 associated with SLE?	SLE is characterized by decreased levels of C3 and C4.
What types of rashes are commonly associated with SLE, and when are they more likely to occur?	SLE is associated with malar ("butterfly") and discoid rashes, especially upon exposure to sunlight.
What part of the body is commonly affected by SLE, and what are some potential neurological symptoms that may result?	SLE can often affect the brain, causing seizures or psychosis.
What are the symptoms that may indicate ACTH dependent Cushing's Syndrome?	Skin hyperpigmentation and high androgen levels are symptoms that may indicate ACTH dependent Cushing's Syndrome.
What is the recommended counseling for patients with fair skin types to prevent skin cancer?	Skin cancer counseling to patients with fair skin types should consist of minimizing exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
What is a potential symptom of Sjögren's syndrome that may occur repeatedly?	Sjögren's syndrome may present with recurrent dental caries.
What is a common characteristic of Sjögren's syndrome in regards to gland enlargement?	Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by bilateral enlargement of the parotid glands.
What is the classic presentation of Sjögren's syndrome that is also known as xerostomia?	Sjögren's syndrome classically presents with dry mouth, known as xerostomia.
What is the classic presentation of Sjögren's syndrome that is also known as keratoconjunctivitis sicca?	Sjögren's syndrome classically presents with dry eyes, known as keratoconjunctivitis sicca.
What are the two types of Sjögren's syndrome and which autoimmune disorder is it commonly associated with?	Sjögren's syndrome can be primary (sicca syndrome) or associated with another autoimmune disorder, especially rheumatoid arthritis.
What typically happens to the size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast prior to menstruation?	The size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast typically increases prior to menstruation.
What is the hormone that can cause an increase in the size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast?	Estrogen is the hormone that can cause an increase in the size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast.
At which specific location are sister chromatids joined together at the end of S phase?	Sister chromatids are joined together at the end of S phase at the centromere.
How does Sirolimus work to inhibit cell growth?	Sirolimus works by binding to FKBP, which in turn inhibits the mTOR signalling complex involved in cell growth.
In which medical condition is Sirolimus primarily used, and in which group of patients is it commonly administered?	Sirolimus is primarily used for transplant rejection prophylaxis in patients who have received a kidney transplant.
How do Sirolimus and cyclosporine interact with each other when given together?	Sirolimus and cyclosporine are synergistic when given together.
What does a sinusoidal pattern on a fetal heart rate monitor indicate, and how severe is the condition it suggests?	A sinusoidal pattern on a fetal heart rate monitor indicates severe fetal anemia.
What is the significance of sinus bradycardia with delayed or dropped p waves, and what condition is it suggestive of?	Sinus bradycardia with delayed or dropped p waves is suggestive of sick sinus syndrome.
What is Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome, and where is the apophysis located that becomes inflamed and causes this overuse injury?	Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is an overuse injury caused by inflammation of the apophysis located on the inferior pole of the patella.
What is the nature of methotrexate, and how can a methotrexate overdose be treated in order to alkalinize urine?	Since methotrexate is a weak acid, a methotrexate overdose can be treated with bicarbonate in order to alkalinize urine.
What are the typical findings for breath sounds, percussion, and fremitus in a patient with a simple pneumothorax?	In a patient with a simple pneumothorax, the breath sounds are typically low, percussion is hyperresonant, and fremitus is low.
What is the typical approach to treatment for simple ovarian cysts?	Simple ovarian cysts are usually not treated.
What is the typical treatment for simple febrile seizures?	The typical treatment for simple febrile seizures is acetaminophen.
What is the typical pattern of seizure activity seen in cases of simple febrile seizures?	The typical pattern of seizure activity seen in cases of simple febrile seizures is generalized.
What viral infection can present with a "blueberry muffin" rash, similar to Rubella?	Similar to Rubella, CMV (Cytomegalovirus) can present with a "blueberry muffin" rash.
What is the effect of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol on the renal reabsorption of Ca2+ and phosphate?	Similar to its action on the intestines, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol increases the renal reabsorption of Ca2+ and phosphate.
What is the mechanism by which Simeprevir can cause drug-drug interactions?	Simeprevir can cause drug-drug interactions by inhibiting cytochrome P450, which is a group of enzymes that metabolize many drugs.
What medical condition is treated with silver sulfadiazine and mafenide?	Silver sulfadiazine and mafenide are used as treatments for burn wounds.
In which part of the lungs do fibrotic nodules typically appear in patients with silicosis?	Fibrotic nodules in patients with silicosis typically appear in the upper lobes of the lungs.
What is the potential presentation of calcification in the lymph nodes for a patient with silicosis?	Silicosis may present with "eggshell" calcification of the hilar lymph nodes.
What are the occupational groups that are at risk of developing silicosis?	Silicosis is seen in sandblasters, silica miners, and foundry workers.
What is the cause of silicosis, a type of pneumoconiosis?	Silicosis is caused by prolonged exposure to silica.
What is the association between silica exposure and a specific type of carcinoma?	Silica exposure is associated with an increased risk of developing lung carcinoma.
What is an example of head injury that can be caused by shaking a baby?	Shaken baby syndrome is an example of head injury that can be caused by shaking a baby.
In what type of patients are SGLT2 inhibitors contraindicated?	SGLT2 inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency.
What is the mnemonic used to remember the severe and permanent symptoms of congenital CMV infection?	The mnemonic used to remember the severe and permanent symptoms of congenital CMV infection is MR DICS.
What is the most common cause of death during the acute phase of rheumatic fever?	The most common cause of death during the acute phase of rheumatic fever is severe pancarditis.
What are the potential symptoms of a hyperdynamic state caused by severe iron deficiency anemia?	A hyperdynamic state caused by severe iron deficiency anemia may present with symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, and angina.
What type of liver disease is especially associated with an increased risk of severe Vibrio vulnificus infection?	Those with liver disease, especially hereditary hemochromatosis, are at an increased risk of severe Vibrio vulnificus infection.
What condition is suggested by the presence of severe unilateral headache, vision changes, and jaw claudication?	The presence of severe unilateral headache, vision changes, and jaw claudication is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.
What condition is suggested by the presence of severe unilateral headache and jaw claudication?	The presence of severe unilateral headache and jaw claudication is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.
Should a patient with severe tuberculosis who refuses treatment be treated?	The patient cannot be treated if they refuse.
What is the recommended treatment for severe purulent skin infections?	Severe purulent skin infections are typically managed with vancomycin.
What is the recommended management for severe post-operative pain?	Severe post-operative pain is typically managed with PCA (patient-controlled analgesia).
What are some potential consequences of severe amphetamine intoxication?	Severe amphetamine intoxication may cause seizures and cardiac arrest.
What are the potential consequences of severe infant deprivation?	Severe infant deprivation can result in infant death.
What condition is suggested by the presence of severe hypovolemia, tachyarrhythmias, high fever, and CNS dysfunction?	The presence of severe hypovolemia, tachyarrhythmias, high fever, and CNS dysfunction is suggestive of thyroid storm.
In what locations may the urethral opening be found in cases of severe hypospadias?	In cases of severe hypospadias, the urethral opening may be found on the perineum or scrotum.
What is the treatment for severe hemorrhage in vWF disease?	The treatment for severe hemorrhage in vWF disease involves IV normal saline and cryoprecipitate (thawed FFP).
What are the potential complications of severe hemorrhage during pregnancy or after delivery?	Severe hemorrhage during pregnancy or after delivery may lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and/or hypovolemic shock.
What is the recommended management for a patient presenting with severe headache, neck stiffness, and hemiparesis?	The recommended management for a patient presenting with severe headache, neck stiffness, and hemiparesis is a CT scan.
How is pre-eclampsia classified when a patient presents with severe headache or visual changes?	When a patient with pre-eclampsia presents with severe headache or visual changes, it is classified as severe.
What illness is suggested by the presence of severe fever, cough, and myalgias?	The presence of severe fever, cough, and myalgias is suggestive of influenza.
What type of failure can be caused by severe diabetic acidosis?	Severe diabetic acidosis can cause respiratory failure.
What deficiency can lead to pellagra?	Severe deficiencies of vitamin B3 can lead to pellagra.
What is the potential cardiovascular consequence of severe croup (laryngeotracheobronchitis)?	Severe croup (laryngeotracheobronchitis) can result in pulsus paradoxus of blood pressure secondary to upper airway obstruction.
What is a potential consequence of severe bleeding from leiomyoma (fibroid)?	Severe bleeding from leiomyoma (fibroid) may lead to iron deficiency anemia.
What type of heart failure can be associated with severe anemia?	Severe anemia can be associated with high-output heart failure.
What is the typical serum pH several hours after an aspirin overdose?	The typical serum pH several hours after an aspirin overdose is normal.
What condition is Sevelamer used to treat, and in what disease is it commonly associated with this condition?	Sevelamer is used to treat hyperphosphatemia, and it is commonly associated with chronic kidney disease.
What is the purpose of a Sestamibi scan, and what glands does it help to localize?	The purpose of a Sestamibi scan is to help localize glands, specifically the parathyroid glands.
What is the effect of SIADH on the level of serum uric acid?	SIADH causes a decrease in the level of serum uric acid.
For what specific purposes should serum tumor markers be used?	Serum tumor markers should only be used for monitoring tumor recurrence and monitoring response to therapy.
What is the minimum level of serum triglycerides required to cause pancreatitis?	Serum triglycerides generally must be higher than 1,000 mg/dL to cause pancreatitis.
What are the two types of agents that are associated with serum sickness-like reactions?	Serum sickness-like reactions are associated with some drugs acting as haptens (such as penicillin) and infections (such as HBV).
How long after antigen exposure does serum sickness typically present with symptoms such as fever, urticaria, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy?	Serum sickness typically presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy 1 - 2 weeks after antigen exposure.
What are the symptoms of serum sickness and how long after antigen exposure do they typically appear?	Serum sickness presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy 1 - 2 weeks after antigen exposure.
What is the treatment for serum sickness?	Serum Sickness can be treated with pulsed corticosteroid therapy.
In what type of infection may serum Ig levels be elevated?	Serum Ig levels may be elevated in a Helicobacter pylori infection.
What do Sertoli-Leydig tumors produce and what is the result of this production in women?	Sertoli-Leydig tumors produce androgens causing rapid-onset hirsutism/virilization in women.
What hormonal changes are caused by Sertoli-Leydig tumors?	Sertoli-Leydig tumors cause high testosterone and low FSH/LH.
Is bilateral ovarian enlargement commonly associated with Sertoli-Leydig tumors?	No, bilateral ovarian enlargement is not commonly associated with Sertoli-Leydig tumors.
What is Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, and what is the potential effect of its production of androgens in women?	Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal cell tumor that may produce androgens, thus causing hirsutism/virilization in women.
What color pigment does Serratia produce?	Serratia produces a red pigment.
How may serrated colonic polyps develop into CRC, and what mutations are associated with this development?	Serrated colonic polyps may develop into CRC via CpG hypermethylation with microsatellite instability and mutations in BRAF.
Are serrated colonic polyps benign or malignant, and do they have any potential to become malignant?	Serrated colonic polyps are benign with some malignant potential.
What symptom is associated with serotonin syndrome?	Serotonin syndrome is associated with hyper-reflexia.
What part of the brain is responsible for serotonin production?	Serotonin production is attributed to the raphe nuclei.
What effect does serotonin have on arterioles?	Serotonin causes arteriolar constriction.
Which receptors on the vagal afferents does serotonin activate, and where do these afferents relay their impulse?	Serotonin activates 5-HT3 receptors on the vagal afferents, which relay their impulse to the nucleus tractus solitarius.
What condition is suggested by the presence of serosanguineous drainage and incisional pain?	Serosanguineous drainage and incisional pain is suggestive of incisional hematoma.
What is the effect of exercise on the inflammatory back pain that may be present in seronegative spondyloarthropathies?	Exercise improves the inflammatory back pain that may be present in seronegative spondyloarthropathies.
What human leukocyte antigen (HLA) is associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies?	Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are associated with HLA B27.
What type of antibodies in serology signify recent infection with systemic fungi such as histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, and coccidioidomycosis?	Serology with IgM antibodies to histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, coccidioidomycosis (systemic fungi) signifies recent infection.
What is the serious complication that can result from a Bartholin abscess?	The serious complication that can result from a Bartholin abscess is necrotizing fasciitis.
What type of shock can result from serious burns?	Hypovolemic shock can result from serious burns.
What are the potential causes of hyper- and hypopituitarism as sequelae of pituitary adenoma?	Pituitary apoplexy is one potential cause of hyper- and hypopituitarism as sequelae of pituitary adenoma.
What is the management approach for septic arthritis that is unresponsive to vancomycin treatment?	Adding ceftriaxone is the management approach for septic arthritis that is unresponsive to vancomycin treatment.
What is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children?	Hematogenous spread is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children.
What joint is typically affected in septic arthritis, which presents as a single red, swollen, and painful joint?	The knee joint is typically affected in septic arthritis, which presents as a single red, swollen, and painful joint.
What is the cause of septic abortion?	Septic abortion is caused by retained products of conception.
What is the definition of septic abortion?	Septic abortion refers to any type of abortion resulting in infected retained products of conception in the uterine cavity.
What are the common bacterial causes of septic abortion?	The common bacterial causes of septic abortion are S. aureus, E. coli (gram negatives), and S. agalactiae.
What is the characteristic of skin in sepsis or anaphylaxis?	The characteristic of skin in sepsis or anaphylaxis is warm skin.
What is a potential cause of direct hyperbilirubinemia?	Sepsis, galactosemia, hypothyroidism, choledochal cyst, and CF are all potential causes of direct hyperbilirubinemia.
What is sepsis and what causes organ dysfunction in this condition?	Sepsis is an acute life-threatening condition characterized by organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated immune response to infection.
What is the recommended treatment for sepsis in a patient with sickle cell disease?	The recommended treatment for sepsis in a patient with sickle cell disease is ceftriaxone.
What is the definition of sepsis?	Sepsis is defined as the presence of two or more SIRS criteria and a source of infection.
Up to what age can separation anxiety disorder be considered a normal behavior in children?	Separation anxiety disorder can be considered a normal behavior up to age 3-4.
Which congenital infections can lead to sensorineural deafness?	Sensorineural deafness can be a complication of congenital infections such as CMV, Rubella, Toxoplasmosis, and Syphilis.
In medical testing, why is it desirable to have sensitivity values approaching 100%?	Sensitivity values approaching 100% are desirable for ruling out disease in medical testing.
What are the treatment options for sensitive Enterococcus spp.?	Sensitive Enterococcus spp. can be treated with vancomycin or IV ampicillin.
What type of agents are Senna and Bisacodyl, and how do they act on the body?	Senna and Bisacodyl are cathartic (stimulant) agents that act via stimulation of the enteric nervous system and increased colonic secretions.
What are the typical levels of AFP and β-HCG in patients with seminomatous germ cell tumors?	Patients with seminomatous germ cell tumors typically present with normal AFP and normal β-HCG levels.
What enzyme is typically elevated in patients with seminomas?	Patients with seminomas typically have increased levels of placental ALP.
What is the medical condition that Selegiline is used to treat, and what type of medication is it?	Selegiline is a medication that belongs to the class of MAO-B inhibitors and is used to treat Parkinson's disease.
What is the potential effect of Selegiline and rasagiline on the adverse effects of levodopa?	Selegiline and rasagiline may worsen the adverse effects of levodopa.
What medical condition can be treated using selective α1 adrenergic antagonists, with the exception of tamsulosin?	Hypertension can be treated using selective α1 adrenergic antagonists, except for tamsulosin.
What is the most common primary immunodeficiency, and what type of infections does it increase susceptibility to?	Selective IgA deficiency is the most common primary immunodeficiency and increases susceptibility to Giardia infections.
How do selective estrogen receptor modulators increase the risk for venous thromboembolism?	Selective estrogen receptor modulators increase the risk for venous thromboembolism by increasing protein C resistance.
What is selection bias, and how can it be reduced?	Selection bias is most commonly a type of sampling bias, and it can be reduced via concealment.
What is the next step in managing seizures that are refractory to benzodiazepines?	The next step is to administer phenytoin.
What is one possible cause of seizures?	Seizures can occur secondary to low blood sugar.
What are some medications that can be used to manage seizures during pregnancy?	Lamotrigine or levetiracetam are medications that can be used to manage seizures during pregnancy.
What type of seizure is suggested by a blank stare, suspected ADHD, and no post-ictal confusion?	A seizure with a blank stare, suspected ADHD, and no post-ictal confusion is suggestive of an absence seizure.
What type of seizure is suggested by alternating stiffness and shaking with loss of consciousness?	A seizure with alternating stiffness and shaking with loss of consciousness is suggestive of a tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizure.
What type of arteries do the segmental arteries of the kidney further branch into?	The segmental arteries of the kidney further branch into interlobar arteries.
What are the stimuli that trigger the secretion of secretin?	The secretion of secretin is triggered by H+ and fatty acids in the lumen of the duodenum.
Which part of the lung is typically affected by secondary TB and why?	Secondary TB typically affects the apex of the lung due to the high oxygen tension in that area.
What is the most common cause of sciatica?	The most common cause of sciatica is a herniated disc.
Which cranial nerve is most frequently involved in Schwannomas, and can they involve any other cranial or spinal nerve?	Schwannomas most frequently involve CN VIII, but can involve any cranial or spinal nerve.
At what location do Schwannomas classically arise?	Schwannomas classically arise at the cerebellopontine angle.
What are the treatment options for Schwannomas?	Schwannomas are treated with resection and/or stereotactic radiosurgery.
What is the cellular composition of Schwannomas, and how are they arranged within the tumor?	Schwannomas are biphasic tumors containing dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells alternating with hypocellular, myxoid areas.
Which cranial nerves are often affected by Schwannomas, specifically acoustic neuromas?	Schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) often affect cranial nerve 7 and cranial nerve 8.
What type of tumor is Schwannoma, and what is its origin?	Schwannoma is a benign tumor of Schwann cells.
What substance use is associated with schizophrenia/psychosis in teenagers?	Schizophrenia/psychosis in teens is associated with frequent cannabis use.
What is the characteristic finding on CT scans in individuals with schizophrenia?	Schizophrenia is characterized by ventriculomegaly on CT.
What changes in serotonergic activity and dendritic branching are associated with schizophrenia?	Schizophrenia is associated with increased serotonergic activity and decreased dendritic branching.
What changes in dopaminergic activity are associated with schizophrenia?	Schizophrenia is associated with increased dopaminergic activity.
What changes in dendritic branching are associated with schizophrenia?	Schizophrenia is associated with decreased dendritic branching.
What are the features that characterize schizoaffective disorder?	Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by features of both schizophrenia and major mood disorder, such as depression or bipolar disorder.
What are the types of Schistosoma that can result in jaundice due to cirrhosis?	Schistosoma mansoni and japonicum can result in jaundice due to cirrhosis.
What type of spine does Schistosoma mansoni have?	Schistosoma mansoni has a large lateral spine.
What type of spine does Schistosoma japonicum have?	Schistosoma japonicum has a small terminal spine.
What type of spine does Schistosoma haematobium have?	Schistosoma haematobium has a large terminal spine.
Which type of Schistosoma can result in hematuria?	Schistosoma haematobium can result in hematuria.
Where do Schistosoma spp. mature before disseminating?	Schistosoma spp. mature in the liver before disseminating.
What type of fluke is Schistosoma spp.?	Schistosoma spp. is a blood fluke.
In which veins do Schistosoma mansoni and japonicum tend to inhabit?	Schistosoma mansoni and japonicum tend to inhabit the mesenteric veins.
What type of hypertension can Schistosoma mansoni and japonicum cause?	Schistosoma mansoni and japonicum can cause portal hypertension.
Where does Schistosoma haematobium tend to inhabit?	Schistosoma haematobium tends to inhabit the bladder.
What type of cancer is Schistosoma haematobium infection associated with in Middle Eastern males, and in which organ?	Schistosoma haematobium infection is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder in Middle Eastern males.
What is the usual treatment for scarlet fever?	Scarlet fever is usually treated with penicillin.
What is the causative agent of scarlet fever?	Scarlet fever is caused by infection with group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes).
Which toxin is associated with scarlet fever?	Scarlet fever is associated with erythrogenic exotoxin (SPE).
What are some common clinical features of scarlet fever?	Scarlet fever can present with a red, swollen, "strawberry" tongue, pharyngitis, and a diffuse, "sandpaper-like" rash that spares the face.
What percentage of tensile strength is typically regained in a scar by 3 months after formation?	Scar formation typically results in 70-80% of tensile strength regained by 3 months.
What is the causative agent of scalded skin syndrome?	Scalded skin syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
What are the most common modes of transmission for scabies?	Scabies is transmitted through skin-to-skin contact most commonly, or via fomites.
Which populations are at a higher risk of developing scabies?	Scabies is common in children and crowded populations.
When does the pruritus caused by scabies typically worsen?	Scabies causes pruritus that is worse at night.
In which patient populations is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) commonly observed?	SBP is often seen in cirrhotics and patients receiving peritoneal dialysis.
What is the cause of Savage syndrome, also known as "resistant ovary syndrome"?	Savage syndrome is caused by FSH receptor insensitivity.
What is the composition of Sargramostim, a medication used to stimulate the production of white blood cells?	Sargramostim is a recombinant form of GM-CSF.
In which condition can Sargramostim be used for rebuilding the bone marrow?	Sargramostim can be used for rebuilding the bone marrow in patients who have aplastic anemia.
What is the medical condition caused by Sarcoptes scabiei?	Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies.
What type of arthropathy may be present in Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis may present with a rheumatoid arthritis-like arthropathy.
What medical condition can Sarcoidosis mimic when it involves the salivary and lacrimal glands?	Sarcoidosis may involve the salivary and lacrimal glands, which mimics Sjögren's syndrome.
What type of cardiomyopathy may be caused by Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis may cause restrictive cardiomyopathy.
What is the mechanism by which Sarcoidosis may cause polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia?	Sarcoidosis may cause polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia due to helper T cell dysregulation.
What are the typical findings on a chest X-ray that suggest the presence of Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis may be visualized on CXR as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and coarse reticular opacities.
What is the typical symptomatology of Sarcoidosis, and what is the exception to this?	Sarcoidosis is often asymptomatic except for enlarged lymph nodes.
What is a common characteristic of individuals who are more likely to develop Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis is more common in non-smokers.
What is the proposed mechanism behind the development of Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis is likely due to C4+ T-cell response to an unknown antigen.
What is lupus pernio, and how is it related to Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis is associated with lupus pernio, which are skin lesions on the face resembling lupus.
What is the relationship between Sarcoidosis and hypercalcemia, and what is the proposed mechanism behind this association?	Sarcoidosis is associated with hypercalcemia due to increased 1α-hydroxylase activity in epithelioid histiocytes.
How is the C4+/C8+ ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid associated with Sarcoidosis?	Sarcoidosis is associated with elevated C4+/C8+ ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.
What is the association between Sarcoidosis and Bell palsy?	Sarcoidosis is associated with Bell palsy, a type of facial paralysis.
What is the relationship between Sarcoidosis and serum levels of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)?	Sarcoidosis is associated with elevated serum levels of the enzyme angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE).
How is Sarcoidosis characterized in terms of the distribution of granulomas?	Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by widespread noncaseating granulomas.
How does saponification of fat appear on H&E stain?	Saponification of fat appears dark blue on H&E stain.
What is the medical term for San Joaquin Valley fever?	San Joaquin Valley fever is a buzzword for Coccidioidomycosis.
What type of bias is sampling bias an example of?	Sampling bias is an example of selection bias.
What is the relationship between salt retention and nephritic syndrome?	Salt retention is a feature of nephritic syndrome.
Which type of Salmonella has a live, attenuated vaccine?	Salmonella typhi has a live, attenuated vaccine.
Which type of Salmonella can present with abdominal pain and 'rose spots' cutaneously?	Salmonella typhi can present with abdominal pain and 'rose spots' cutaneously.
Which type of Salmonella can cause constipation or 'pea soup' diarrhea?	Salmonella typhi can cause constipation or 'pea soup' diarrhea.
Which type of Salmonella causes paratyphoid fever?	Salmonella paratyphi causes paratyphoid fever.
Which type of Salmonella causes inflammatory diarrhea?	Salmonella enteritidis causes inflammatory diarrhea.
What does Salmonella spp. produce on Hektoen enteric agar and how does it appear?	Salmonella spp. produces hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which appears as black colonies on Hektoen enteric agar.
What is the intracellular behavior of Salmonella spp. and within which cells does it occur?	Salmonella spp. is facultative intracellular within macrophages.
What is the acid stability of Salmonella spp.?	Salmonella spp. is acid labile.
What type of secretion system does Salmonella spp. contain and how does it act as a virulence factor?	Salmonella spp. contains a type III secretion system that acts as a virulence factor.
What is the characteristic of the diarrhea caused by Salmonella enteritidis and what is present in the stool?	Salmonella enteritidis produces an inflammatory diarrhea, with leukocytes present in stool.
What is the classification of Salmeterol and formoterol and what type of agonists are they?	Salmeterol and formoterol are long-acting β2 agonists.
What is the typical presentation of salivary gland tumors and where do they usually occur?	Salivary gland tumors typically present as a mobile, painless mass/swelling at the angle of the jaw.
Which salivary gland is most commonly affected by tumors?	Salivary gland tumors most commonly arise in the parotid gland.
What is the most common nature of salivary gland tumors?	Salivary gland tumors are most commonly benign.
How does the tonicity of saliva compare to that of plasma?	Saliva is hypo-tonic relative to plasma.
What are the three major glands that form saliva?	Saliva is formed by three major glands: parotid, submandibular, and sublingual.
How does the concentration of Na+ and Cl- in saliva compare to that of plasma?	Saliva is characterized by low Na+ and Cl- concentration relative to plasma.
How does the concentration of K+ and HCO3- in saliva compare to that of plasma?	Saliva is characterized by high K+ and HCO3- concentration relative to plasma.
What is the characteristic urine chloride level in saline-responsive metabolic alkalosis?	Saline-responsive metabolic alkalosis is characterized by urine chloride < 20 mEq/L.
What is the characteristic urine chloride level in saline-resistant metabolic alkalosis?	Saline-resistant metabolic alkalosis is characterized by urine chloride > 20 mEq/L.
What is the composition of saline solution?	Saline is a solution of sodium chloride.
How is the safety of drugs measured in terms of therapeutic index value?	Safer drugs have a higher therapeutic index value.
What type of inhibitor is Sacubitril?	Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor.
What is the location of saccular aneurysms that can cause compression of the CN III, and which artery is involved?	Saccular aneurysms that can cause compression of the CN III are located in the posterior communicating artery.
What is the location of saccular aneurysms that can cause compression of the optic chiasm?	Saccular aneurysms that can cause compression of the optic chiasm are located in the anterior communicating artery.
What bacterial group does S. sanguinis belong to?	S. sanguinis belongs to the group of bacteria known as viridans streptococci.
What is the susceptibility of S. pyogenes (GAS) to bacitracin?	S. pyogenes (GAS) is sensitive to bacitracin.
What type of infection can S. bovis produce?	S. bovis can produce subacute endocarditis.
What is the most common cause of S. aureus pneumonia?	S. aureus pneumonia is most commonly seen after an influenza infection, also known as post-viral pneumonia.
What type of donor is S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)?	S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) is a methyl donor.
What is formed when S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) donates a CH3 group to anabolic pathways?	When S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) donates a CH3 group to anabolic pathways, it forms S-adenosylhomocysteine.
What are the products of the breakdown of S-adenosylhomocysteine?	The breakdown of S-adenosylhomocysteine results in the formation of adenosine and homocysteine.
What chronic myeloproliferative disorders are treated with Ruxolitinib and what specific mutations are associated with these disorders?	Ruxolitinib is used to treat chronic myeloproliferative disorders that have JAK2 mutations, which include myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera.
What type of inhibitor is Ruxolitinib?	Ruxolitinib is a JAK1/2 inhibitor.
What is the potential consequence of a rupture of the thoracic duct?	Rupture of the thoracic duct can cause chylothorax.
What is the potential consequence of a rupture of the middle meningeal artery?	Rupture of the middle meningeal artery leads to epidural hematoma.
What are the potential consequences of the rupture of Echinococcus granulosus cysts?	The rupture of Echinococcus granulosus cysts results in anaphylaxis and spread of infection.
What developmental milestone is typically achieved when a child is able to run and kick a ball?	Running and kicking a ball is typically achieved at around 18 months of age.
What is the typical outcome of brain stem lesions that affect the motor nuclei or nerves?	Brain stem lesions that affect the motor nuclei or nerves typically result in ipsi-lateral loss of the affected nerve.
How do Ruffini corpuscles adapt?	Ruffini corpuscles adapt slowly.
What is the hematological side effect of Rubicins and actinomycin D, and how do they cause this effect?	The hematological side effect of Rubicins and actinomycin D is myelosuppression, which occurs because these drugs target rapidly dividing cells.
What is the family that Rubella belongs to?	Rubella belongs to the Matonaviridae family.
What type of hemorrhoids is rubber band ligation used for?	Rubber band ligation is only used for internal hemorrhoids.
What is the virulence factor found in RSV, and what is its function?	The virulence factor found in RSV is the F (fusion) protein, which allows the production of multinucleated giant cells.
What is the protein that RSV attaches to in order to infect respiratory epithelial cells?	RSV attaches to the G protein in order to infect respiratory epithelial cells.
In what age group is RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) typically seen in children?	RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) is typically seen in children under 6 months of age.
What is the most common cause of RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis) with a granular immunofluorescence pattern?	RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is more commonly due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
What is a less common cause of RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis) with a granular immunofluorescence pattern?	RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is less commonly due to diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis.
Under what circumstances is routine testing for toxoplasmosis recommended?	Routine testing for toxoplasmosis is recommended if the patient has been exposed to cats.
For patients being treated with long-term hydroxychloroquine, which organ requires routine monitoring?	The eyes require routine monitoring for patients being treated with long-term hydroxychloroquine.
What is the characteristic feature of Rotor syndrome and Dubin-Johnson syndrome in terms of bilirubin levels, LFTs, and CBC?	Rotor syndrome and Dubin-Johnson syndrome are characterized by elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin with normal LFTs and CBC.
What type of bilirubin is elevated in patients with Rotor syndrome and Dubin-Johnson syndrome?	Patients with Rotor syndrome and Dubin-Johnson syndrome have elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin.
During which months is rotavirus infection most commonly seen?	Rotavirus infection is most commonly seen during the winter months.
What type of vaccine is available for rotavirus and how is it administered?	The vaccine available for rotavirus is a live, attenuated vaccine that is administered orally.
What type of deficiency can result from rotavirus gastroenteritis?	Rotavirus gastroenteritis can result in a secondary lactase deficiency.
What are the effects of rotavirus on the body and what electrolyte imbalances can result from it?	Rotavirus causes villous destruction and atrophy, which can result in decreased serum levels of Na+ and K+.
What is the cause of rotator cuff tendinopathy?	Rotator cuff tendinopathy is caused by impingement of the supraspinatus tendon.
What causes ovarian torsion?	Ovarian torsion is caused by rotation of the ovary around the infundibulopelvic ligament.
What is another name for roseola?	Roseola is also known as exanthema subitum.
What age group is commonly affected by roseola?	Roseola commonly affects children between 6 and 24 months old.
What is Romiplostim and what is it used for?	Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin analog that is used to treat thrombocytopenia.
What is Romaña's sign and what disease is it associated with?	Romaña's sign is inflammation and swelling around the eyelids and it is associated with acute Chagas disease.
At what age do babies typically start rolling over and laughing and smiling?	Babies typically start rolling over and laughing and smiling at around 3 months of age.
What are rods characterized by in terms of visual acuity and sensitivity?	Rods are characterized by low visual acuity and high sensitivity.
What is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever?	The causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever is Rickettsia rickettsii.
Where do RNA viruses typically replicate?	RNA viruses typically replicate in the cytoplasm.
What is the function of RNA polymerase I?	RNA polymerase I is responsible for making ribosomal RNA (rRNA).
What is the function of RNA polymerase II?	RNA polymerase II is responsible for making messenger RNA (mRNA).
What is the function of RNA polymerase III?	RNA polymerase III is responsible for making transfer RNA (tRNA) and 5S ribosomal RNA (rRNA).
What is the target of Rituximab in B cells, and how does it bind to it?	Rituximab targets B cells by binding to the CD20 surface antigen.
What medical condition is Rituximab indicated for?	Rituximab is indicated for immune thrombocytopenic purpura.
What type of lymphocytes do disorders that are treated with Rituximab affect?	Disorders that are treated with Rituximab affect B lymphocytes.
What specific molecule on B-cells does Rituximab, an antitumor monoclonal antibody, target?	Rituximab targets CD20, a specific molecule on B-cells.
What type of immunoglobulin (Ig) is Rituximab, and what are its other characteristics as a monoclonal antibody?	Rituximab is a chimeric, monoclonal IgG antibody.
What type of antibody can be depleted as a result of Rituximab treatment?	Rituximab treatment can lead to a depletion of IgG antibodies.
What specific type of leukemia can be treated with Rituximab?	Rituximab can be used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
What type of lymphoma, characterized by the presence of CD20 molecules, can be treated with Rituximab?	Rituximab can be used to treat CD20+ non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, such as follicular lymphoma.
What type of monoclonal antibodies are Rituximab and Cetuximab?	Rituximab and Cetuximab are chimeric monoclonal antibodies.
What is the difference in potency between Risperidone and Quetiapine/Clozapine in terms of their classification as antipsychotics?	Risperidone is classified as a high potency antipsychotic, while Quetiapine and Clozapine are classified as low potency antipsychotics.
What type of analog is Ribavirin?	Ribavirin is a guanosine nucleoside analog.
What type of viral infection can Ribavirin be used to treat?	Ribavirin can be used to treat hepatitis C virus (HCV) infections.
What is the family of viruses that Rhinovirus belongs to?	Rhinovirus belongs to the Picornaviridae family of viruses.
What is the characteristic of Rhinovirus in relation to acidity?	Rhinovirus is acid labile, meaning that it is easily destroyed by acidic conditions.
How many different serotypes of Rhinovirus are there?	There are 113 different serotypes of Rhinovirus.
What is the optimal temperature for the growth of Rhinovirus?	Rhinovirus grows best at a temperature of 33°C.
What type of infection is caused by Rhinovirus?	Rhinovirus typically causes an upper respiratory tract infection.
Which sinus is most commonly affected by rhinosinusitis in adults?	Rhinosinusitis most commonly affects the maxillary sinus in adults.
Which sinus is most commonly affected by rhinosinusitis in children?	Rhinosinusitis most commonly affects the ethmoid sinus in children.
What is the most common cause of rhinosinusitis?	Rhinosinusitis is most commonly caused by a viral upper respiratory infection (URI).
What types of deviations may be present in a person with rheumatoid arthritis?	A person with rheumatoid arthritis may present with ulnar finger deviation and radial wrist deviation.
What type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with rheumatoid arthritis?	Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with a type III hypersensitivity reaction.
What is the classic presentation of joint stiffness in rheumatoid arthritis, and what improves this symptom?	The classic presentation of joint stiffness in rheumatoid arthritis is stiffness that improves with activity.
In the context of rheumatic fever, what valve is most commonly affected by damage and stenosis?	The mitral valve is most commonly affected by damage and stenosis in the context of rheumatic fever.
What type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with rheumatic fever?	Rheumatic fever is associated with a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
What is the late consequence of rheumatic fever that is associated with mitral valve involvement?	The late consequence of rheumatic fever that is associated with mitral valve involvement is mitral stenosis.
What is the shape of the capsid of rhabdovirus?	The capsid of rhabdovirus has a helical shape.
What electrolyte abnormality is commonly associated with rhabdomyolysis, in addition to muscle pains, weakness, and vomiting?	Hypocalcemia is commonly associated with rhabdomyolysis, in addition to muscle pains, weakness, and vomiting.
What are the two most common causes of rhabdomyolysis?	The two most common causes of rhabdomyolysis are crush injury and strenuous exercise.
What is rhabdomyolysis and what are the potential consequences of this syndrome?	Rhabdomyolysis is a syndrome caused by muscle necrosis that can lead to renal failure and death.
What are rhabdomyoblasts and what is a potential characteristic of these cells?	Rhabdomyoblasts are spindle-shaped cells and a potential characteristic of these cells is that they sometimes exhibit cytoplasmic cross-striations.
What are the two markers used in immunohistochemistry (IHC) to identify rhabdomyoblasts?	The two markers used in immunohistochemistry (IHC) to identify rhabdomyoblasts are desmin and myogenin.
What is the potential cause of Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn?	Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn has the potential to occur when a Rh-negative mother has a Rh-positive fetus.
What are the clinical features of Reye syndrome?	Reye syndrome presents with micro-vesicular fatty change in the liver, hypoglycemia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and eventually coma/death.
What is the possible mechanism behind the development of Reye syndrome?	Reye syndrome may occur due to decreased β-oxidation secondary to reversible inhibition of mitochondrial enzymes in hepatocytes by aspirin metabolites.
What are some of the possible clinical presentations of Reye syndrome?	Reye syndrome can present with liver failure and encephalitis.
What is the mechanism of action of bacteriostatic agents?	Bacteriostatic agents work by reversible inhibition of bacterial growth.
Which vitamin deficiencies can lead to reversible dementia?	Reversible dementia may occur with deficiencies in vitamins B1, B3, and B12.
What are the characteristic features of asthma?	Reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation of distal bronchioles is characteristic of asthma.
Which condition is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation of the airways?	Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation of the airways.
What are the options for reversing thrombolytic therapy?	Reversal of thrombolytic therapy may involve platelet transfusions or factor corrections (e.g. FFP, cryoprecipitate, PCC).
How is opioid overdose and withdrawal managed?	Reversal of opioid overdose is managed with naloxone, while treatment of opioid withdrawal is managed with methadone or buprenorphine/naloxone (Suboxone).
At what age do symptoms of Rett syndrome typically become apparent?	Rett syndrome symptoms usually become apparent between ages 1 to 4.
What are the typical symptoms of Rett syndrome?	Rett syndrome presents with regression, including loss of development and verbal abilities.
Who is primarily affected by Rett syndrome, and what are the typical symptoms?	Rett syndrome primarily affects girls, and presents as motor, verbal, and intellectual regression with stereotyped hand-wringing.
What is the gender distribution of Rett syndrome?	Rett syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females.
Who is most commonly affected by retropharyngeal abscesses?	Retropharyngeal abscesses most commonly affect children.
What is the management strategy for retinopathy of prematurity?	Retinopathy of prematurity is managed with laser.
What is the pathophysiology of retinopathy of prematurity?	Retinopathy of prematurity is due to high levels of oxygen causing neoangiogenesis in the eye.
What vitamin are retinoids, such as isotretinoin and all-trans retinoic acid, derived from?	Retinoids, such as isotretinoin and all-trans retinoic acid, are derivatives of Vitamin A.
What type of retinal degeneration is retinitis pigmentosa?	Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited retinal degeneration.
What are the initial symptoms of retinitis pigmentosa?	Retinitis pigmentosa is a painless, progressive vision loss beginning with night blindness.
What are the symptoms that often precede retinal detachment and are associated with posterior vitreous detachment?	Retinal detachment is often preceded by posterior vitreous detachment, which presents with "flashes" and "floaters".
What are some of the causes of retinal detachment?	Retinal detachment may be secondary to retinal breaks, diabetic traction, and inflammatory effusions.
What are the common characteristics of retinal vein occlusion?	Retinal vein occlusion is characterized by retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement with edema in the affected area.
How does retinal vein occlusion appear on funduscopy?	Retinal vein occlusion causes a "blood and thunder" appearance on funduscopy.
What are the risk factors for retinal detachment?	Retinal detachment is more common in patients with high myopia and/or history of head trauma.
What are the common causes of retinal detachment?	Retinal detachment is commonly caused by retinal breaks, inflammatory effusions, and proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
What is the visual outcome of retinal detachment?	Retinal detachment eventually results in monocular loss of vision like a "curtain drawn down".
In what type of diabetic retinopathy do retinal blood vessel ruptures lead to "flame" hemorrhages?	Retinal blood vessel rupture leads to "flame" hemorrhages in nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
What is the reason for the bluish cytoplasm of reticulocytes on Wright-Giemsa stain?	Reticulocytes have a bluish cytoplasm on Wright-Giemsa stain due to presence of residual ribosomal RNA.
In what condition can reticulocyte count be falsely elevated?	Reticulocyte count may be falsely elevated in anemia.
How can reticulocyte count in anemia be corrected?	Reticulocyte count in anemia can be corrected by multiplying reticulocyte count by Hct/45.
How is retained placenta defined?	Retained placenta is defined as failure of the placenta to deliver within 30 minutes of delivery.
What is the most common cause of restrictive lung diseases?	Restrictive lung diseases are most commonly due to interstitial diseases of the lung.
How is total lung capacity affected in restrictive lung diseases?	Total lung capacity is decreased in restrictive lung diseases.
How are residual volume and functional residual capacity affected in restrictive lung diseases?	Residual volume and functional residual capacity are decreased in restrictive lung diseases.
What is a potential presentation of restrictive lung disease?	Respiratory acidosis may be a presentation of restrictive lung disease.
How is the FEV1/FVC ratio affected in restrictive lung disease?	The FEV1/FVC ratio is greater than 70% of predicted in restrictive lung disease.
How are total lung capacity (TLC) and residual volume (RV) affected in restrictive lung disease?	Total lung capacity (TLC) and residual volume (RV) are decreased in restrictive lung disease.
How are forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) affected in restrictive lung disease?	Forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) are decreased in restrictive lung disease.
What type of dysfunction is caused by restrictive cardiomyopathy?	Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction.
What are some possible clinical presentations of restrictive cardiomyopathy?	Restrictive cardiomyopathy can present with jugular venous distension (JVD) and a prominent Y descent on jugular venous pressure tracings.
What type of dysfunction is associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy?	Restrictive cardiomyopathy is associated with diastolic dysfunction.
What are the typical features of Restless Leg Syndrome?	Restless Leg Syndrome is characterized by unpleasant sensations in the legs and an uncontrollable urge to move when at rest.
What medical conditions are commonly associated with Restless Leg Syndrome?	Restless Leg Syndrome is commonly associated with iron deficiency and chronic kidney disease.
What type of deficiency is often associated with Restless Leg Syndrome?	Restless Leg Syndrome is often associated with iron deficiency.
What are the typical circumstances in which discomfort is experienced by individuals with Restless Leg Syndrome?	Individuals with Restless Leg Syndrome typically experience discomfort during rest, which is worse at night.
How do resting tremors and essential tremors differ in terms of when they are worse and their hereditary nature?	Resting tremors are worse at rest, while essential tremors are worse with movement. Essential tremors are also hereditary.
What is the timing of respiratory compensation in response to metabolic acidosis or alkalosis?	Respiratory compensation in response to metabolic acidosis or alkalosis is immediate.
At what point during fetal development is respiration possible during the canalicular period?	Respiration may be possible at week 25 during the canalicular period.
What is the indicator of resorption of the organic matrix of bone and how is it reflected in the urine?	Resorption of the organic matrix of bone is reflected in increased hydroxyproline excretion in the urine.
What are Reslizumab and Mepolizumab, and what is their function in the maintenance therapy for asthma?	Reslizumab and Mepolizumab are monoclonal antibodies against IL-5 used for maintenance therapy for asthma.
What conditions are indicated by the presence of resistant hypertension, hypokalemia, and abdominal bruit?	The presence of resistant hypertension, hypokalemia, and abdominal bruit is suggestive of renal artery stenosis.
How is resistance to Vancomycin encoded and what modification does it cause to the bacteria's D-Ala-D-Ala subunit?	Resistance to Vancomycin is encoded via modifying the bacteria's D-Ala-D-Ala subunit to D-ala-D-lac.
What are the two primary ways in which resistance to Tetracyclines occurs, and what happens in each of these ways?	Resistance to Tetracyclines occurs in two primary ways: 1) decreasing uptake, and 2) increasing efflux.
How does resistance to Tetracyclines occur, and what is the mechanism behind bacterial ribosomal modification/protection?	Resistance to Tetracyclines occurs through bacterial ribosomal modification/protection via soluble GTPase analogues.
What is one way that bacteria can develop resistance to Tetracyclines, and what is the mechanism behind it?	One way that bacteria can develop resistance to Tetracyclines is through the production of efflux pumps.
How is resistance to Sulfonamides primarily developed, and what is the specific mutation that occurs?	Resistance to Sulfonamides is primarily developed through a mutation of bacterial dihydropteroate synthase.
How does resistance to Rifamycins develop, and what is the specific mechanism behind it?	Resistance to Rifamycins develops when mutations reduce binding to RNA polymerase.
How does resistance to macrolides, specifically -thromycin, occur and what is the specific mechanism behind it?	Resistance to macrolides, specifically -thromycin, occurs via post-transcriptional methylation of the 23S bacterial rRNA.
How is resistance to Linezolid developed, and what is the specific mutation that occurs?	Resistance to Linezolid is developed via a point mutation of ribosomal RNA.
How can resistance to Isoniazid develop, and what specific mutations can lead to this resistance?	Resistance to Isoniazid can develop due to mutations that lead to underexpression of KatG.
How does resistance to Foscarnet develop, and what specific mutation is responsible for this resistance?	Resistance to Foscarnet develops via a mutation of DNA Polymerase.
What is the primary mechanism behind resistance to Fluoroquinolones, and where are the mutations that encode this resistance located?	Resistance to Fluoroquinolones is primarily encoded by chromosome-encoded mutations in DNA Gyrase.
What is the mechanism behind resistance to Colistin (Polymixin E), and what specific gene is responsible for encoding this resistance?	Resistance to Colistin (Polymixin E) is encoded via the Mcr-1 gene which alters the structure of Lipid A.
What is the cause of resistance to Chloroquine, and what specific mechanism is responsible for the development of this resistance?	Resistance to Chloroquine is developed due to membrane pumps.
What is the cause of resistance to Chloramphenicol, and what specific type of enzyme is responsible for encoding this resistance?	Resistance to Chloramphenicol is encoded via a plasmid-encoded acetyltransferase enzyme.
What is the relationship between resistance and the radius of a blood vessel, and how is this relationship expressed mathematically?	Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the blood vessel.
What is the relationship between resistance and the length of a blood vessel, and how is this relationship expressed mathematically?	Resistance is directly proportional to the length of the blood vessel.
What are the residual chronic findings of multiple sclerosis, and what specific cellular changes are associated with these findings?	Residual chronic findings of multiple sclerosis include hypertrophy and hyperplasia of astrocytes.
In which specific types of cells does replication of the Rabies virus occur?	Replication of Rabies virus occurs within striated muscle and motor neuronal cells.
What symptoms are suggestive of esophageal perforation?	Repeated vomiting, severe chest/back/epigastric pain, fever and left-sided pleural effusion are suggestive of esophageal perforation.
What is the generic name for drugs such as repaglinide or nateglinide?	The generic name for drugs such as repaglinide or nateglinide is meglitinide.
What are the two types of viruses that belong to the reovirus family?	The two types of viruses that belong to the reovirus family are rotavirus and coltivirus.
What is another virus that belongs to the reovirus family, in addition to rotavirus?	In addition to rotavirus, another virus that belongs to the reovirus family is coltivirus.
How many segments do reoviruses typically have?	Reoviruses typically have 10-12 segments.
What is the typical location of renovascular disease caused by fibromuscular dysplasia?	Renovascular disease caused by fibromuscular dysplasia typically occurs in the distal 2/3 of the renal artery and/or segmental branches.
What is the typical location of renovascular disease caused by atherosclerosis?	Renovascular disease caused by atherosclerosis typically occurs in the proximal 1/3 of the renal artery.
What is the substance that renin converts to angiotensin I?	Renin is responsible for the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.
What is the name of the benign epithelial cell tumor that arises from the collecting ducts?	Renal oncocytoma is a benign epithelial cell tumor arising from the collecting ducts.
What are the two possible defects in the kidney that can cause renal tubular acidosis?	Renal tubular acidosis is caused by a defect in either hydrogen excretion or bicarbonate resorption in the kidney.
What is the typical presentation of renal tubular acidosis in infants?	Renal tubular acidosis in infants commonly presents with failure to thrive in the setting of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
What type of acidosis does Renal Tubular Acidosis cause?	Renal Tubular Acidosis causes non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
What causes renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy?	Renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy occurs due to compression by the uterus and ovarian vein.
Which side is more commonly affected by renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy?	Renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy occurs more commonly on the right side.
What causes renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy?	Renal pelvis and ureter dilation during pregnancy occurs due to compression by the uterus and ovarian vein.
What are the common clinical manifestations of renal papillary necrosis?	Renal papillary necrosis presents with gross hematuria and colicky flank pain.
What are some of the conditions that may cause renal papillary necrosis?	Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by sickle cell disease or trait.
What is a potential cause of renal papillary necrosis?	Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by severe acute pyelonephritis.
What is a possible cause of renal papillary necrosis?	Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by chronic analgesic abuse.
What patient population is commonly affected by renal osteodystrophy, and what condition is often associated with it?	Renal osteodystrophy is often seen in patients with renal failure and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
What are some of the symptoms associated with renal oncocytoma?	Renal oncocytoma presents with painless hematuria, flank pain, and an abdominal mass.
What physiological processes are impaired in renal failure?	Renal failure is associated with an inability to make urine and excrete nitrogenous wastes.
What is the mechanism by which the kidneys correct respiratory acidosis?	Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased reabsorption of "new" HCO3-.
What are the specific ways in which the kidneys correct respiratory acidosis?	Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased excretion of excess fixed H+ as titratable acid and NH4+.
What is a way to prevent renal complications associated with the use of acyclovir?	Renal complications of acyclovir can be avoided with adequate hydration.
What is the mechanism by which the kidneys compensate for respiratory alkalosis?	Renal compensation of respiratory alkalosis includes decreased reabsorption of "new" HCO3-.
What is the specific way in which the kidneys compensate for respiratory alkalosis?	Renal compensation of respiratory alkalosis includes decreased excretion of fixed H+ as titratable acid and NH4+.
What types of medications or agents can reduce renal clearance of lithium in patients?	Renal clearance of lithium is reduced in patients taking thiazide diuretics or other nephrotoxic agents (e.g. NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors).
What are some examples of antiarrhythmic drugs that can decrease renal clearance of digoxin?	Renal clearance of digoxin is decreased with antiarrhythmic drugs such as verapamil, amiodarone, and quinidine.
What are the two possible etiologies that may lead to the development of renal cell carcinoma tumors?	Renal cell carcinoma tumors may be caused by hereditary or sporadic etiologies.
In males, what is a rare presentation of renal cell carcinoma that involves the left side of the body?	Renal cell carcinoma rarely may present with left-sided varicocele in males.
Which cells of the nephron are commonly the origin of renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma often originates from the PCT cells of the nephron.
What are some systemic symptoms that may be present in a patient with renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma may present with systemic symptoms including fever and weight loss.
What is a paraneoplastic syndrome that may be associated with renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma may present with paraneoplastic syndromes, such as secondary polycythemia.
How does renal cell carcinoma typically spread after invading the renal vein and then the IVC?	Renal cell carcinoma may invade the renal vein, then IVC, before spreading hematogenously.
What is meant by the term "silent cancer" when referring to renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma is referred to as a "silent" cancer because it commonly presents as a metastatic neoplasm.
What is the primary management approach for renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma is managed with resection.
What are some of the paraneoplastic syndromes that may be associated with renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as ectopic EPO, ACTH, PTHrP, and renin.
What specific tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p is commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma is associated with loss of the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p.
What is the classic triad of symptoms that may be associated with renal cell carcinoma?	Renal cell carcinoma is associated with a classic triad of hematuria, palpable mass, and flank pain.
What blood vessel does renal cell carcinoma commonly invade into?	Renal cell carcinoma commonly invades into the renal vein.
What percentage of cardiac output is typically accounted for by renal blood flow?	Renal blood flow is usually 20-25% of cardiac output.
Within what blood pressure range does renal blood flow (RBF) remain relatively constant?	Renal blood flow (RBF) remains relatively constant between blood pressure ranges of 80 to 200 mmHg.
What is the equation used to calculate renal blood flow (RBF)?	Renal blood flow (RBF) is calculated using the equation: RBF = RPF / (1 - Hct).
What disease is diagnosed by a renal biopsy showing linear IgG antibodies along the glomerular basement membrane?	Renal biopsy showing linear IgG antibodies along the glomerular basement membrane is diagnostic for Goodpasture's disease.
Among which nephrotic/nephritic syndrome does renal biopsy typically reveal normal kidney architecture?	Renal biopsy typically reveals normal kidney architecture in cases of minimal change disease.
