What is primarily responsible for controlling renal autoregulation, and what specific arteriole is involved in this process?	Renal autoregulation is primarily controlled by changing vascular resistance of the afferent arteriole.
What causes renal agenesis, and what specific structures are involved in this failure?	Renal agenesis occurs due to failure of the ureteric buds to develop and induce differentiation of metanephric mesenchyme.
How is renal agenesis typically diagnosed before birth?	Renal agenesis is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound.
What is the potential consequence of removing a lingual thyroid, particularly if it is the only thyroid tissue present?	Removal of a lingual thyroid may result in hypothyroidism if it is the only thyroid tissue present.
What is the potential role of REM sleep in cognitive function?	REM sleep may play a role in memory processing.
What are some of the physiological characteristics that distinguish REM sleep from other stages of sleep?	REM sleep is characterized by high blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate.
How does REM sleep affect brain oxygen use and cardiovascular function?	REM sleep is characterized by increased brain O2 use and variable pulse and blood pressure.
What medical conditions are often associated with REM sleep behavior disorder?	REM sleep behavior disorder is highly associated with underlying neurodegenerative disorders.
What is the primary characteristic of REM sleep behavior disorder?	REM sleep behavior disorder is characterized by a lack of muscle atonia during REM sleep.
What specific type of neurodegenerative disorders is REM sleep behavior disorder commonly associated with?	REM sleep behavior disorder is associated with alpha-synuclein neurodegenerative disorders.
What is the primary stimulant for the release of the enzymatic component of pancreatic secretion?	Release of the enzymatic component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK).
What is the primary stimulant for the release of the aqueous component of pancreatic secretion?	Release of the aqueous (HCO3-) component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by secretin.
What is the mediator responsible for the release of P-selectin from Weibel-Palade bodies?	Release of P-selectin from Weibel-Palade bodies is mediated by histamine.
What is the difference in the time frame of action between peptide hormones and steroid hormones?	Peptide hormones act quickly (within minutes) while steroid hormones act slowly (taking hours).
What is the formula for calculating relative risk reduction?	Relative risk reduction is equal to 1 - relative risk.
How is relative polycythemia characterized in terms of red blood cell (RBC) mass?	Relative polycythemia is characterized by normal RBC mass.
How is relative polycythemia characterized in terms of erythropoietin (EPO) levels?	Relative polycythemia is characterized by normal EPO levels.
How is relative polycythemia characterized in terms of plasma volume?	Relative polycythemia is characterized by decreased plasma volume.
How is relative polycythemia, also known as hemoconcentration, characterized in terms of plasma volume?	Relative polycythemia (hemoconcentration) is characterized by decreased plasma volume.
What type of food poisoning can result from reheating rice?	Reheating rice can result in food poisoning from Bacillus cereus.
How is regular insulin characterized in terms of its action and duration?	Regular insulin is characterized by short action and duration.
What vitamin is required for the regeneration of 11-cis retinal from all-trans retinal?	Regeneration of 11-cis retinal (from all-trans retinal) requires vitamin A.
What type of metabolic disorder is Refsum disease, and what process is defective in individuals with this condition?	Refsum disease is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by defective α-oxidation.
What condition is indicated by the presence of refractory peptic ulcers and high gastrin levels?	Refractory peptic ulcers and high gastrin levels are indicative of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
What is the recommended management for refractory osteoarthritis?	Refractory osteoarthritis is managed with surgery, specifically total knee arthroplasty.
What condition is indicated by the presence of refractory hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis?	Refractory hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis are suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism.
What condition is indicated by the presence of refractory duodenal ulcers and diarrhea?	Refractory duodenal ulcers and diarrhea are suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES).
What are reflexes called when both their afferent and efferent pathways are contained within the vagus nerve?	Reflexes in which both afferent and efferent pathways are contained in the vagus nerve are called vagovagal reflexes.
What is reflex sympathetic dystrophy, and what is the common cause of pain associated with it?	Reflex sympathetic dystrophy, also known as complex regional pain syndrome, is a condition characterized by pain after a trauma.
What is reflex sympathetic dystrophy, and what is the typical trigger for the pain associated with it?	Reflex sympathetic dystrophy, also known as complex regional pain syndrome, is a condition characterized by pain after a trauma.
What is refeeding syndrome, and what electrolyte imbalances is it commonly associated with?	Refeeding syndrome is a condition that is commonly associated with decreased serum levels of phosphorus, Mg2+, and K+.
What do Reed-Sternberg cells secrete, and what is the effect of this secretion on other inflammatory cells?	Reed-Sternberg cells secrete cytokines, which attract other inflammatory cells.
What is the origin of Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma?	Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma are of B-cell origin.
What are the immunohistochemical markers that are expressed by Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma?	Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma are C 15+ and C 30+.
What are the "B symptoms" that can be caused by Reed-Sternberg cells?	Reed-Sternberg cells can occasionally result in "B symptoms," which include fever, chills, weight loss, and night sweats.
What are the CD markers that are typically expressed by Reed-Sternberg cells?	Reed-Sternberg cells are classically positive for CD 15 and CD 30.
What is the test used to detect reducing sugars, such as fructose, galactose, and glucose, in urine?	The copper reduction test is used to detect reducing sugars in urine.
What is the function of reduced tetrahydrofolate, also known as methyl-THF, in relation to THF?	Reduced tetrahydrofolate, or methyl-THF, is the storage form of THF.
In heart failure, what dietary modifications can be made to reduce fluid overload?	To reduce fluid overload in heart failure, it is recommended to reduce intake of sodium and water.
What is the cause of red, friable lesions on the vagina in a person with choriocarcinoma?	Red, friable lesions on the vagina in a person with choriocarcinoma is due to metastases.
What are the defining features of red man syndrome?	Red man syndrome is characterized by histamine release, which can lead to symptoms such as flushing, itching, and possible hypotension.
What are the typical symptoms of red man syndrome?	Red man syndrome is characterized by erythema, pruritus, and widespread flushing.
How can red man syndrome be prevented when administering vancomycin?	Red man syndrome can be avoided by slowing the infusion of vancomycin.
What is one way to prevent red man syndrome when administering vancomycin?	Red man syndrome can be avoided by pre-treating with anti-histamines.
What is the recommended management for a red, hot, and swollen joint?	A red, hot, swollen joint is managed with arthrocentesis.
What are some red flags that may indicate physical abuse?	Red flags for physical abuse include a history inconsistent with degree or type of injury.
What are some red flags that may indicate physical abuse?	Red flags for physical abuse include delayed medical care.
What are some red flags that may indicate physical abuse?	Red flags for physical abuse include the caregiver's story changing with each retelling.
What is the recommended management for red blood in stool?	Red blood in stool is managed with an NG tube.
What does it mean when bacteria appear red on a gram stain?	Red bacteria of a gram stain are gram negative.
What is the definition of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)?	Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by recurring anxiety-provoking, intrusive thoughts relieved by repetitive behaviors (rituals) that cause distress.
What is the fetal heart rate category for recurrent late and variable decelerations?	Recurrent late and variable decelerations are fetal heart rate category III patterns.
What is the cause of recurrent fevers in Trypanosoma brucei infection?	Recurrent fevers in Trypanosoma brucei infection are due to antigenic variation of surface glycoproteins.
What condition should be evaluated for in a patient with recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis?	Recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis in a patient warrants evaluation for underlying diabetes mellitus.
What condition is suggested by recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and neutrophilia?	Recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and neutrophilia is suggestive of LAD deficiency.
What condition is suggested by recurrent RUQ/epigastric pain with high AST/ALT/ALP without stones visualized and worsened with opioids?	Recurrent RUQ/epigastric pain with high AST/ALT/ALP without stones visualized and worsened with opioids is suggestive of sphincter of oddi dysfunction.
What type of maternal studies may be conducted to investigate recurrent pregnancy loss?	Recurrent pregnancy loss may be investigated with maternal coagulation studies.
In cases of recurrent miscarriage due to factor V Leiden, which vasculature is thought to be affected by thrombosis?	Recurrent miscarriage due to factor V Leiden is thought to be due to thrombosis of the uteroplacental vasculature.
What is the management strategy for recurrent GI bleeding from esophageal varices?	Recurrent GI bleeding from esophageal varices is managed with TIPS.
What is the recommended treatment for suppressing or minimizing the recurrence of genital HSV?	Recurrence of genital HSV can be suppressed or minimized with a daily administration of valacyclovir.
What is the cause of the bulge between the rectus muscles in rectus abdominis diastasis?	Rectus abdominis diastasis is a bulge between the rectus muscles due to weakening of the linea alba.
What is the recommended next step in the management of rectal injury in pelvic fracture?	The recommended next step is to perform a proctoscope.
Why do rectal and sublingual administrations have such high bioavailability?	Rectal and sublingual administration have such high bioavailability because drugs will bypass portal circulation.
What is a potential complication of ARDS recovery, and what causes it?	Recovery of ARDS may be complicated by interstitial fibrosis/scarring due to loss of type II pneumocytes.
How often should women undergo recommended screening mammography?	Recommended screening mammography for women should be done every 2 years.
What medical condition can be treated with recombinant IFN-β?	Recombinant IFN-β can be used to treat Multiple Sclerosis (Type IV HS disease).
What types of cancer can be treated with recombinant IFN-α?	Recombinant IFN-α can be used to treat malignant melanoma, hairy cell leukemia, and renal cell carcinoma.
What medical condition can be treated with recombinant IFN-y?	Recombinant IFN-y can be used to treat Chronic Granulomatous Disease.
What is an example of a tyrosine kinase that receptor-associated tyrosine kinases can be non-covalently associated with?	Receptor-associated tyrosine kinases are non-covalently associated with a tyrosine kinase, such as JAK.
What is recall bias and how is it introduced in a study?	Recall bias is an error in a study introduced when the awareness of the disorder alters recall by the subjects.
How can recall bias be reduced in a study?	Recall bias can be reduced in a study by decreasing the time from exposure to follow-up.
What is involved in reading the PPD test?	Reading the PPD test involves checking the size of the induration.
What are the three components of the reactive arthritis triad?	The reactive arthritis triad includes conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis.
What are the typical symptoms associated with reactive arthritis?	Reactive arthritis is characterized by a triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis, with patients often also experiencing diarrhea.
What are the three main symptoms that make up the triad in reactive arthritis?	Reactive arthritis is characterized by a triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis.
What are some common triggers for the development of reactive arthritis?	Reactive arthritis classically arises in young adults after a gastrointestinal tract or Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
Which virus is associated with the reactivation that leads to nasopharyngeal carcinoma?	The reactivation of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
What is the result of reactivation of VZV in the body?	Reactivation of VZV results in herpes zoster, commonly known as shingles.
What are the conditions under which reactivation of VZV occurs?	Reactivation of VZV can occur with stress, aging, or an immunocompromised state.
Who is at risk for reactivation of CMV?	Reactivation of CMV occurs in individuals who are immunosuppressed, such as organ transplant and AIDS patients.
Which part of the lung is affected by reactivated tuberculosis?	Reactivated tuberculosis typically affects the upper lobes of the lung.
What is the typical presentation of reactivated infection with HSV?	Reactivated infection with HSV typically presents as herpes labialis.
What is the effect of reabsorption of Na+ in the collecting duct on luminal potential and K+ excretion?	Reabsorption of Na+ in the collecting duct creates a negative luminal potential, which facilitates K+ excretion.
What type of cells are activated through IgE-mediated mechanism upon re-exposure to an allergen in asthmatics?	Re-exposure to an allergen in asthmatics leads to IgE-mediated activation of mast cells.
What is the relationship between RDW and iron deficiency anemia?	RDW is not low but actually high in iron deficiency anemia.
What is the main source of oxidative stress that RBCs are exposed to?	RBCs are normally exposed to oxidative stress, especially by hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
What is the potential consequence of Raynaud phenomenon on the digits?	Raynaud phenomenon may result in digital ulceration due to critical ischemia.
What is the name of the rash that occurs in neonates and is associated with a positive Nikolsky sign?	The rash that occurs in neonates and is associated with a positive Nikolsky sign is called Scalded-Skin Syndrome.
What is the name of the syndrome for which Rasburicase, a non-PEGylated uricase, is used for prophylaxis and treatment?	Rasburicase, a non-PEGylated uricase, is used for prophylaxis and treatment of Tumor Lysis Syndrome.
How does Rasburicase differ from Pegloticase?	Rasburicase differs from Pegloticase in that it is not PEGylated.
How does Ras shut off its nuclear signalling?	Ras shuts off its nuclear signalling via GAP cleavage of GTP to GDP.
In what state is Ras associated with growth factor receptors?	Ras is associated with growth factor receptors in an inactive GDP-bound state.
What is the sensitivity of Rapid Strep test in detecting streptococcal pharyngitis when compared to throat culture?	The sensitivity of Rapid Strep test in detecting streptococcal pharyngitis when compared to throat culture is low.
What is the potential complication of rapidly lowering glucose levels in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)?	The potential complication of rapidly lowering glucose levels in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is cerebral edema.
What is the result of thyroid function tests in a patient with congenital hypothyroidism?	The result of thyroid function tests in a patient with congenital hypothyroidism is high TSH and low free T4.
What is the rapid diagnosis for a patient with omphalocele, rocker-bottom feet/hammer toe, microcephaly, and clenched hand?	The rapid diagnosis for a patient with omphalocele, rocker-bottom feet/hammer toe, microcephaly, and clenched hand is Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18).
What is the rapid diagnosis for a newborn with macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, diffuse intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis?	The rapid diagnosis for a newborn with macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, diffuse intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis is toxoplasmosis.
What is the rapid diagnosis for a newborn with cataracts, failed hearing test, and continuous heart murmur?	The rapid diagnosis for a newborn with cataracts, failed hearing test, and continuous heart murmur is Congenital Rubella.
How can rapid diagnosis of group B strep be done in a woman in labor?	Rapid diagnosis of group B strep in a woman in labor can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).
What is the risk associated with rapid deceleration blunt chest trauma, such as a suicide fall?	The risk associated with rapid deceleration blunt chest trauma, such as a suicide fall, is aortic transection.
What is the potential consequence of rapid correction of hyponatremia?	The potential consequence of rapid correction of hyponatremia is osmotic demyelination syndrome.
What is the potential consequence of rapid correction of hypernatremia?	The potential consequence of rapid correction of hypernatremia is cerebral edema/herniation.
What is a potential side effect of ranolazine on ECG?	A potential side effect of ranolazine on ECG is QT prolongation.
What medical condition is ranolazine used to treat when other therapies have failed?	Ranolazine is used to treat angina when other medical therapies have failed.
What is the role of RANKL in the activation of osteoclasts?	The role of RANKL is to bind to RANK on osteoclast precursors or osteoclast surfaces causing activation of these cells.
What is the order of potency of the different forms of estrogen?	The order of potency of the different forms of estrogen is 17β-estradiol > estrone > estriol.
What is the order of the following variables in zone 3 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv?	The order of the following variables in zone 3 of the lung is Pa > Pv > PA.
What is the order of the following variables in zone 2 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv?	The order of the following variables in zone 2 of the lung is Pa > PA > Pv.
What is the order of the following variables in zone 1 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv?	The order of the following variables in zone 1 of the lung is PA > Pa > Pv.
What is the order of the following receptors for affinity to norepinephrine, from highest to lowest: β1, α1, α2?	The order of the following receptors for affinity to norepinephrine, from highest to lowest is α1 > α2 > β1.
What is the order of the following receptors for affinity to dobutamine, from highest to lowest: β1, β2, α?	The order of the following receptors for affinity to dobutamine, from highest to lowest is β1 > β2 > α.
What is the order of the following from highest to lowest prevalence: ASD, PDA, VSD?	The order of the following from highest to lowest prevalence is VSD > ASD > PDA.
What is the target of Ranibizumab and Bevacizumab, and what is their mechanism of action?	Ranibizumab and Bevacizumab are monoclonal antibodies against Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF), which prevents the growth of blood vessels.
What is the importance of randomization in research studies?	Randomization is critical in preventing confounding bias in research studies.
What receptors does Ramelteon bind to and where in the brain are they located?	Ramelteon binds the MT1 and MT2 receptors in the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus.
What is the primary medical condition that Raloxifene is used to treat?	Raloxifene is primarily used to treat post-menopausal osteoporosis.
What is the potential risk associated with Raloxifene use and how does it affect the risk of developing DVT?	Raloxifene can increase the risk of developing DVT.
What is the potential effect of RAI ablation on Graves ophthalmopathy?	RAI ablation can worsen Graves ophthalmopathy.
In what types of closed spaces does radon tend to accumulate?	Radon tends to accumulate in closed spaces, such as basements.
In what clinical situation might radionuclide scans be performed for thyroid nodules?	Radionuclide scans may be done for thyroid nodules in the setting of a low TSH (hyperthyroid) level.
How does radioactive (I131) iodine function as a treatment for hyperthyroidism/Graves' disease?	Radioactive (I131) iodine is a last resort treatment for hyperthyroidism/Graves' disease that works by ablating the thyroid.
What part of the body is affected by radiculopathy, and how would you describe this condition?	Radiculopathy is a pathologic process that affects the nerve root.
What is secondary empty sella syndrome, and what are some causes of this condition?	Secondary empty sella syndrome refers to the regression of the pituitary gland due to radiation, brain injury, or surgery.
What is radial head subluxation, and in what age group is it most commonly seen as an elbow injury?	Radial head subluxation is an elbow injury that is most commonly seen in children under 5 years of age.
What is the cause of radial head subluxation, and which joint is involved in this condition?	Radial head subluxation is caused by the subluxation of the radial head relative to the radiocapitellar joint.
What nerve is affected by radial head subluxation, and what is the resulting symptom of this condition?	Radial head subluxation impinges the deep radial nerve, which can cause weakness of most of the posterior forearm extensors.

What is the cardiac complication associated with post-traumatic myocardial rupture?	The cardiac complication associated with post-traumatic myocardial rupture is cardiac tamponade.
How would you describe placental abruption?	Placental abruption is a condition characterized by pain and separation of the placenta from the uterus.
What is placenta previa and how is it defined?	Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta attaches to the lower uterine segment, covering the internal cervical os.
What is placenta percreta and what happens in this condition?	Placenta percreta is a condition where the placenta abnormally penetrates through the myometrium and into the uterine serosa.
What is placenta increta and what happens in this condition?	Placenta increta is a condition where the placenta abnormally penetrates into the myometrium.
What is placenta accreta and what happens in this condition?	Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta abnormally attaches to the myometrium, without penetrating it.
What are the typical symptoms of placenta previa and when do they usually occur?	Placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding during the third trimester of pregnancy.
What is the relationship between placenta accreta and c-section delivery?	Placenta accreta is often associated with c-section delivery.
What are the distinguishing features of Pityriasis Versicolor on a patient's skin?	Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by hyper or hypopigmented patches on a patient's skin.
Which body part is always spared in cases of Pityriasis rosea?	The palms and soles are always spared in cases of Pityriasis rosea.
What are the characteristic features of Pityriasis rosea lesions?	Pityriasis rosea lesions are typically multiple pink plaques with a collarette scale.
What disease can Pityriasis rosea be an initial presentation of?	Pityriasis rosea can be an initial presentation of syphilis.
What is Pituitary adenoma?	Pituitary adenoma is a benign tumor of the anterior pituitary cells.
What are the clinical features of Pituitary apoplexy?	Pituitary apoplexy presents with sudden onset severe headache with visual impairment (bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia) and features of hypopituitarism.
What is the potential consequence of acute hypopituitarism caused by Pituitary apoplexy?	Pituitary apoplexy may lead to cardiovascular collapse due to acute hypopituitarism causing decreased ACTH.
What are the two types of Pituitary adenomas?	Pituitary adenomas may be functional (hormone producing) or nonfunctional (silent).
What is one potential presentation of Pituitary adenoma?	Pituitary adenoma may present with hypopituitarism due to compression of normal pituitary tissue.
What is one potential presentation of Pituitary adenoma and what is the cause of this presentation?	Pituitary adenoma may present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm.
How is Pituitary adenoma characterized in terms of hyperplasia of endocrine cells?	Pituitary adenoma is characterized by hyperplasia of only one type of endocrine cell.
What are the symptoms associated with Piriformis syndrome?	Piriformis syndrome manifests with symptoms of sciatica.
What is the cause of Piriformis syndrome and what structures are affected by this condition?	Piriformis syndrome is caused by hypertrophy/muscle injury to the piriformis muscle, which compresses structures traveling through the greater sciatic foramen.
What are Piperacillin and ticarcillin, and how are they used to extend their activity?	Piperacillin and ticarcillin are antipseudomonal penicillins that are used with β-lactamase inhibitors to extend their activity.

What are Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone, and what is their abbreviation?	Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are examples of glitazones, also known as thiazolidinediones (TZDs).
What are pinpoint pupils usually associated with, and what causes this condition?	Pinpoint pupils are usually associated with large bilateral pontine lesions caused by damage to the hypothalamospinal tract.
What is Pinealoma, and what condition can it cause due to compression of the cerebral aqueduct?	Pinealoma is a type of brain tumor, and it may cause obstructive hydrocephalus due to compression of the cerebral aqueduct.
What is the significance of PiMZ heterozygotes (α1-antitrypsin), and what action can increase their risk for emphysema?	PiMZ heterozygotes (α1-antitrypsin) are at significant risk for emphysema, and smoking can increase their risk for this condition.
What is the management approach for Pilonidal disease?	Pilonidal disease is managed with surgical drainage.
Where can Pilocytic astrocytomas be found in the brain?	Pilocytic astrocytomas can be found in the posterior fossa or supratentorial region of the brain.
What is a Pilocytic astrocytoma, and what type of tumor is it?	A Pilocytic astrocytoma is a tumor of astrocytes that is well-circumscribed and benign.
What is the effect of Pilocarpine on the body's secretion, and how would you describe its potency?	Pilocarpine is a potent stimulator of tears, sweat, and salivary secretion.
What is the mechanism of action of Pilocarpine in the treatment of closed-angle glaucoma, and which muscle does it contract?	Pilocarpine contracts the pupillary sphincter muscle, which is its mechanism of action in the treatment of closed-angle glaucoma.
What is the mechanism of action of Pilocarpine in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma, and which muscle does it contract?	Pilocarpine contracts the ciliary muscle, which is its mechanism of action in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma.
What medical condition is caused by a PIG-A mutation?	A PIG-A mutation leads to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
What is the typical treatment setting for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)?	PID is usually treated in an outpatient setting.
What is the process by which picornaviruses produce active subunits from an inactive large product?	Picornaviruses produce a large polyprotein product (inactive) that is cleaved into smaller subunits (active).
What is the role of viral proteases in the life cycle of picornaviruses?	Picornaviruses have viral proteases which cleave the large translated polypeptide into functional viral proteins.
What medical condition is characterized by hyperuricemia and can lead to skin picking or lip biting?	Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a medical condition characterized by hyperuricemia and can lead to skin picking or lip biting.
What medical condition may be indicated by pica, particularly pagophagia (craving and chewing ice)?	Pica, especially for ice (pagophagia), may be indicative of iron deficiency anemia.
What is the chemical classification of physostigmine and does it penetrate the central nervous system (CNS)?	Physostigmine is a tertiary amine and thus does penetrate the CNS.
What is the cause of physiological neonatal jaundice?	Physiological neonatal jaundice occurs due to transiently low UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity at birth.
In what groups of males may physiologic gynecomastia occur?	Physiologic gynecomastia may occur in newborn, pubertal, and elderly males.
What types of nonmonetary gifts should physicians accept according to ethical guidelines?	Physicians should only accept nonmonetary gifts that directly benefit the patient, such as educational material or drug samples.
What are the typical findings on physical examination of a ruptured ovarian cyst?	Physical examination of a ruptured ovarian cyst shows unilateral lower quadrant tenderness +/- hemoperitoneum.
What are the factors that can precipitate hypoglycemia in patients with insulin-treated diabetes?	Physical activity/exercise, inadequate food intake, and excessive insulin dose can precipitate hypoglycemia in patients with insulin-treated diabetes.
What is the name of the bulbous deformation of the nose that can be caused by phymatous rosacea?	Phymatous rosacea can cause rhinophyma, which is a bulbous deformation of the nose.
What type of tumors do phyllodes tumors morphologically resemble?	Phyllodes tumors morphologically resemble fibroadenomas.
In what population of women is Phyllodes tumor most commonly seen?	Phyllodes tumor is most commonly seen in post-menopausal women.
What is the effect of photoaging on the epidermis and the stratum corneum?	Photoaging results in gradual thinning of the epidermis, allowing the stratum corneum to become dessicated.
What is the effect of phosphorylation on glycogen synthase enzyme activity?	Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase causes enzyme inactivation.
What is the effect of phosphorylation on glycogen phosphorylase enzyme activity?	Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase causes enzyme activation.
What enzyme is responsible for converting phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) to 5-phosphoribosylamine in purine synthesis?	The enzyme responsible for converting phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) to 5-phosphoribosylamine in purine synthesis is PRPP amidotransferase.
What is the product of Phosphoribosyl Pyrophosphate (PRPP) in purine biosynthesis?	The product of Phosphoribosyl Pyrophosphate (PRPP) in purine biosynthesis is IMP (Inosine monophosphate).
What are the molecules that positively regulate Phosphofructosekinase-1 via positive feedback?	The molecules that positively regulate Phosphofructosekinase-1 via positive feedback are AMP and fructose-2,6-bisphosphate.
What molecule positively regulates Phosphofructokinase-2 via positive feedback?	Phosphofructokinase-2 is positively regulated via positive feedback by insulin.
What molecule negatively regulates Phosphofructokinase-2 via negative feedback?	Phosphofructokinase-2 is negatively regulated via negative feedback by glucagon.
What are the molecules that negatively regulate Phosphofructokinase-1 via negative feedback?	The molecules that negatively regulate Phosphofructokinase-1 via negative feedback are ATP and citrate.
In which part of the nephron and through which type of cotransport is phosphate primarily reabsorbed?	Phosphate is primarily reabsorbed in the early proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) through Na+-phosphate cotransport.
What is the charge that phosphate groups give to DNA?	Phosphate groups give DNA a negative charge.
What is the cause of Phlegmasia alba dolens (painful white "milk" leg)?	Phlegmasia alba dolens (painful white "milk" leg) is caused by massive common iliac vein occlusion.
With which genetic disorders are pheochromocytomas commonly associated?	Pheochromocytomas are commonly associated with MEN 2A/2B, neurofibromatosis type 1, and von Hippel-Lindau disease.
What symptom may accompany pheochromocytoma and is characterized by unexplained high blood sugar levels during periods of fasting?	Pheochromocytoma may be accompanied by unexplained fasting hyperglycemia.
What are some of the neurologic side effects that may be caused by phenytoin?	Phenytoin may cause neurologic side effects such as peripheral neuropathy and ataxia.
What is the mechanism of action of phenytoin and what implications does this have for potential drug interactions?	Phenytoin is an inducer of cytochrome P450, which means it may have many drug interactions.
What is the spectrum of activity of phenytoin as an anti-epileptic?	Phenytoin is a narrow spectrum anti-epileptic.
What is the effect of phenytoin on CYP-450?	Phenytoin is an inducer of CYP-450.
What is the mechanism of action of phenytoin?	Phenytoin exerts its effects by blocking Na+ channels.
At what age should phenylketonuria screening be done?	Phenylketonuria screening should be done at newborn screening.
What are some of the potential symptoms of phenylketonuria?	Phenylketonuria may present with fair skin, eczema, intellectual disability, growth retardation, and seizures.
What are some examples of phenylketones?	Phenylketones include phenylacetate, phenyllactate, and phenylpyruvate.
What medical condition can be treated with phenylephrine?	Phenylephrine may be used to treat hypotension.
What medical condition can be treated with phenylephrine?	Phenylephrine may be used to treat nasal congestion.
What is the potential use of phenylephrine in ocular procedures?	Phenylephrine may be used as a mydriatic for ocular procedures.
What type of agonist is phenylephrine primarily?	Phenylephrine is primarily an α1 agonist.
What effect does phenylephrine have on systolic pressure?	Phenylephrine causes an increase in systolic pressure.
What effect does phenylephrine have on diastolic pressure?	Phenylephrine causes an increase in diastolic pressure.
What type of reflex does phenylephrine cause?	Phenylephrine causes reflex bradycardia.
What effect does phentolamine have on vasculature?	Phentolamine causes vasodilation.
What are phentermine, diethylpropion, and benzphetamine and what are they used for?	Phentermine, diethylpropion, and benzphetamine are sympathomimetic drugs used for weight loss.
What is the effect of phenobarbital on CYP-450?	Phenobarbital is an inducer of CYP-450.
What type of drug is phencyclidine (PCP) and how does it primarily work?	Phencyclidine (PCP) is a hallucinogen that works primarily as a NMDA receptor antagonist.
What is the characteristic feature of phase 4 of the SA node action potential?	Phase 4 of the SA node action potential is characterized by slow depolarization.
What is the characteristic feature of Phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade?	Phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade is characterized as prolonged depolarization.
What are the main objectives of Phase I in clinical trials?	Phase I of clinical trials aims to assess safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a new drug or treatment.
What is the typical outcome of Phase I drug metabolism and what are the properties of the resulting metabolites?	Phase I drug metabolism typically yields slightly polar, water-soluble metabolites that are often still active.
What is the specific phase of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade that is characterized as repolarized but blocked?	Phase II of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade is characterized as repolarized but blocked.
What is the class of antibiotics to which penicillins belong?	Penicillins belong to the β-lactam class of antibiotics.
What type of structural analogs are penicillins and their derivatives, and what do they bind and inhibit?	Penicillins and their derivatives are D-ala-D-ala structural analogs which bind and inhibit transpeptidases.
What is the characteristic of penicillin V, and how can it be administered?	Penicillin V is acid stable, which means it can be given orally.
What type of endocarditis can be treated with penicillin G, and what are the causative agents?	Penicillin G is effective in treating left-sided endocarditis caused by Strep viridans and Strep bovis.
How is penicillin G administered?	Penicillin G is administered intravenously (IV).
What type of organisms are penicillin V/G mostly used for?	Penicillin V/G are mostly used for Gram Positive organisms.
What is the medical condition caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) that can be treated with Penicillin V or G?	Penicillin V or G are treatments for rheumatic fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS).
How is Penicillin V administered compared to Penicillin G?	Penicillin G is given intravenously (IV) and intramuscularly (IM), whereas Penicillin V is given orally.
What is the mechanism by which Penicillin binds to PBP transpeptidases?	Penicillin binds to PBP transpeptidases by mimicking the D-ala-D-ala sequence of peptidoglycan.
What anatomical landmark in the neck is associated with potential injury to the ansa cervicalis in cases of penetrating trauma?	Penetrating trauma to the neck above the cricoid cartilage can injure the ansa cervicalis.
What is the recommended assessment for a patient with unstable penetrating abdominal trauma?	The recommended assessment for a patient with unstable penetrating abdominal trauma is exploratory laparotomy (ex-lap).
What is the cause of Pemphigus vulgaris and what type of antibodies are involved?	Pemphigus vulgaris is caused by IgG antibodies against desmoglein.
What is the mechanism behind the autoimmune destruction in Pemphigus vulgaris?	The mechanism behind the autoimmune destruction in Pemphigus vulgaris is the IgG-mediated destruction of desmoglein/desmosomes between keratinocytes.
What is the indication for Pembrolizumab and what type of mutation should the tumors have?	Pembrolizumab is indicated for the treatment of all solid tumors that bear a PD-L1 mutation.
What part of the nervous system do the pelvic splanchnic nerves and CNs III, VII, IX, and X belong to?	The pelvic splanchnic nerves and CNs III, VII, IX, and X belong to the parasympathetic nervous system.
What is a potential side effect of pelvic radiotherapy?	A potential side effect of pelvic radiotherapy is overflow incontinence.
Is pelvic organ prolapse common among postmenopausal patients?	Yes, pelvic organ prolapse is common among postmenopausal patients.
Is pelvic organ prolapse associated with primary amenorrhea?	No, pelvic organ prolapse is not associated with primary amenorrhea.
What are the treatment options for pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia?	Pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia can be treated with either azithromycin or doxycycline.
What can be the result of pelvic fractures injuring the anterior bladder wall?	Pelvic fractures injuring the anterior bladder wall can result in extra-peritoneal leakage of urine.
What is the recommended treatment for a hemodynamically stable pelvic fracture with bleeding?	The recommended treatment for a hemodynamically stable pelvic fracture with bleeding is external fixation and no surgery.
What vitamin deficiency is responsible for causing Pellagra?	Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin).
What skin manifestation is commonly associated with Pellagra, which is a result of a deficiency in vitamin B3?	Pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B3, is commonly associated with hyper-pigmentation of sun-exposed limbs.
What is the pharmacological property that is extended by PEGylation of interferons?	PEGylation of interferons allows the half-life of the drug to be extended.
What medical condition is PEGylated Liposomal Doxorubicin useful for treating?	PEGylated Liposomal Doxorubicin is useful for the treatment of Kaposi Sarcoma.
What medical condition is Pegloticase used for, specifically in cases where the condition is severe and refractory?	Pegloticase is used for the treatment of severe, refractory gout.
What is the process by which Pegloticase converts one substance into another, and what are the resulting substances?	Pegloticase converts uric acid into water-soluble allantoin.
What potential hematologic pathology should be monitored for in patients receiving Pegloticase?	Patients receiving Pegloticase should be monitored for hemolytic anemia, particularly in those with G6PD deficiency.
In which patient population can Pegloticase cause hemolysis, and what is the specific deficiency that is associated with this risk?	Pegloticase can cause hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.
What are Pegloticase and Rasburicase, and how do they function to treat certain medical conditions?	Pegloticase and Rasburicase are recombinant uricases that work by converting uric acid into water-soluble allantoin to treat certain medical conditions.
What do Pediculus humanus and Phthirus pubis, commonly known as lice, consume as their source of nutrition?	Pediculus humanus and Phthirus pubis, commonly known as lice, drink human blood as their source of nutrition.
What are Pediculus humanus and Phthirus pubis, and what symptom do they commonly cause in humans?	Pediculus humanus and Phthirus pubis are lice that commonly cause intense pruritis or itching in humans.
What is the common cause of vaginal discharge in pediatric patients?	In pediatric patients, vaginal discharge is usually caused by a foreign body.
What are some potential consequences of pediatric obstructive sleep apnea?	Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea can lead to parasomnias and secondary enuresis.
How does pediatric depression commonly present, and what symptoms may be more prominent than a depressed mood?	Pediatric depression often presents with symptoms of irritability rather than depressed mood.
What medical condition is suggested by a peau d'orange appearance of the breast?	A peau d'orange appearance of the breast may suggest the presence of inflammatory carcinoma.
What type of toxin is associated with peanuts and grain crops such as wheat, and what organism produces it?	Aflatoxins are associated with peanuts and grain crops such as wheat, and they are produced by the fungus Aspergillus flavus.
At what age is peak bone mass typically achieved?	Peak bone mass is typically achieved by 30 years of age.
What is the preferred diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism?	The preferred diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism is CT angiography.
What are the effects of PDGF on vascular remodeling and cell migration?	PDGF induces vascular remodeling and smooth muscle cell migration.
How do PDE-5 inhibitors work to produce prolonged smooth muscle relaxation?	PDE-5 inhibitors work by preventing breakdown of cGMP to produce prolonged smooth muscle relaxation.
In what part of the penis does the increased blood flow occur as a result of PDE-5 inhibitors?	PDE-5 inhibitors result in increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.
What is the potential life-threatening risk associated with PDE-5 inhibitors in patients who are taking nitrates?	PDE-5 inhibitors may cause life-threatening hypotension in patients taking nitrates.
What is the suffix commonly found in the names of PDE-5 inhibitors?	PDE-5 inhibitors have the suffix "afil".
With which medication are PDE-5 inhibitors contraindicated?	PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated with nitrates.
For which type of hypertension are PDE-5 inhibitors such as sildenafil and tadalafil indicated?	PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil, tadalafil) are indicated for pulmonary hypertension.
What medications can interact with PDE-5 inhibitors like sildenafil and cause significant hypotension?	PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil) can cause significant hypotension, especially in patients taking alpha blockers or nitrates.
How do PDE inhibitors such as cilostazol and dipyridamole affect platelet aggregation?	PDE inhibitors (e.g. cilostazol, dipyridamole) increase cAMP, which inhibits platelet aggregation.
How do PCSK9 inhibitors such as alirocumab and evolocumab work to decrease LDL levels?	PCSK9 inhibitors (e.g. alirocumab and evolocumab) work by inactivating LDL-receptor degradation, resulting in a dramatic decrease in LDL.
What is required for DNA synthesis in PCR?	PCR requires the addition of all four deoxynucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs) for DNA synthesis.
What are some ovulatory cycle-related risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia?	PCOS, early menarche, late menopause, nulliparity are ovulatory cycle-related risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia.
What hormone is elevated in individuals with PCOS?	PCOS has elevated testosterone levels.
What are the levels of GnRH and estrogen in individuals with PCOS?	PCOS is characterized by high GnRH and high estrogen levels.
What is the ideal time frame for performing PCI in the setting of acute STEMI?	PCI is ideally performed within 2 hours in the setting of acute STEMI.
What laboratory values may be elevated in individuals with PBC and PSC?	ALP, GGT, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and immune proteins (IgM) may be elevated in individuals with PBC and PSC.
What is the risk for patients with β-thalassemia major in relation to parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors?	Patients with β-thalassemia major are at risk of aplastic crisis with parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors.
What is the recommended treatment for patients with β-blocker overdose who have refractory hypotension despite atropine and IV fluids?	Patients with β-blocker overdose that have refractory hypotension (e.g. to atropine, IV fluids) should be started on IV glucagon.
What is the consequence of C5b-C9 deficiency (complement) in patients?	Patients with C5b-C9 deficiency (complement) are unable to form the MAC (membrane attack complex) leading to increased Neisseria infections.
How would you describe the relationship between a patient with obsessive-compulsive disorder and their symptoms?	Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder are ego dystonic, meaning they experience their symptoms as intrusive and unwanted.
How would you describe the relationship between a patient with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder and their behavior?	Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder are ego syntonic, which means their behavior is consistent with their own beliefs or attitudes.
How would you describe the relationship between a patient with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder and their behavior?	Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder are ego syntonic, which means their behavior is consistent with their own beliefs or attitudes.
What is the potential consequence of respiratory muscle weakness in patients with hypothyroidism?	Patients with hypothyroidism may develop hypoventilation from respiratory muscle weakness.
What is the relationship between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and blood urea nitrogen levels in patients?	Patients with upper GI bleeding often have an elevated blood urea nitrogen.
What is the characteristic feature of mast cell proliferation in patients with systemic mastocytosis?	Patients with systemic mastocytosis have clonal mast cell proliferation in the bone marrow, skin, and other organs.
What patient populations are at a high risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis?	Patients with sickle cell disease and asplenic patients are at a high risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis.
What is the predisposing factor for rhinosinusitis in patients with this condition?	Patients with septal deviation are predisposed to rhinosinusitis.
What patient population has an increased risk for metformin-induced lactic acidosis due to metformin accumulation?	Patients with renal insufficiency have increased risk for metformin-induced lactic acidosis due to metformin accumulation.
What is the characteristic feature of social anxiety disorder in patients with performance-only subtype?	Patients with performance-only social anxiety disorder do not fear nonperformance social situations and are not socially avoidant.
What personality disorder is characterized by a need for excessive admiration and a tendency to react to criticism with rage?	Patients with narcissistic personality disorder often require excessive admiration and react to criticism with rage.
What type of infection can lead to the development of rhinocerebral and frontal lobe abscesses?	Patients with Mucormycosis can present with rhinocerebral and frontal lobe abscesses.
What is the typical behavior of patients with malingering during their medical evaluation?	Patients with malingering are usually uncooperative during their medical evaluation.
What type of deficiency can cause patients to develop anaphylaxis to IgA-containing products such as blood transfusions and gammaglobulins?	Patients with IgA deficiency may develop anaphylaxis to IgA-containing products (e.g. blood transfusions, gammaglobulins).
What endocrine disorder increases the risk of carpal tunnel syndrome in patients?	Patients with hypothyroidism are at increased risk for carpal tunnel syndrome.
What type of patients are typically cooperative during their medical evaluation?	Patients with factitious disorder are usually cooperative during their medical evaluation.
What genetic condition is associated with an increased risk for developing Alzheimer disease?	Patients with Down syndrome have an increased risk for developing Alzheimer disease.
What type of personality disorder is associated with getting stuck in abusive relationships?	Patients with dependent personality disorder often get stuck in abusive relationships.
What type of personality disorder is characterized by submissive and clingy behavior?	Patients with dependent personality disorder are typically submissive and clingy.
What medical condition is characterized by decreased reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine?	Patients with cystinuria have decreased reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine.
What eating disorder is characterized by patients having body weights within normal ranges?	Patients with bulimia nervosa often have body weights within normal ranges.
What inherited disorder should patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome be screened for?	Patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome should be screened for MEN1.
What symptoms do patients with Zellweger Syndrome typically present with?	Patients with Zellweger Syndrome typically present with a profound hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly.
What type of abnormalities do patients with Zellweger Syndrome often have?	Patients with Zellweger Syndrome often have craniofacial abnormalities.
At what age do patients with Zellweger Syndrome often die?	Patients with Zellweger Syndrome often die at an early age.
What are the common symptoms that patients with Xeroderma Pigmentosum present with?	Patients with Xeroderma Pigmentosum often present with freckled and dry skin, extreme sunlight sensitivity, and corneal ulcers.
What type of DNA damage can patients with Xeroderma Pigmentosum not repair as a result of UV-B exposure?	Patients with Xeroderma Pigmentosum cannot repair Thymidine Dimers formed as a result of UV-B exposure.
Which type/s of skin cancer are patients with xeroderma pigmentosum at risk for?	Patients with xeroderma pigmentosum are at risk for all types of skin cancer.
What is the increased risk for patients with VUR in terms of developing ureter stenosis?	Patients with VUR are at increased risk of developing ureter stenosis.
What is the cause of the protuberant abdomen seen in patients with von Gierke disease?	Patients with von Gierke disease typically have a protuberant abdomen, which is secondary to hepatomegaly.
What physical characteristics are often seen in patients with von Gierke disease?	Patients with von Gierke disease often have thin extremities, short stature, and a "doll-like" face.
What type of motion causes significant pain in patients with Volkmann ischemic contracture?	Patients with Volkmann ischemic contracture have significant pain with passive extension of fingers/wrist.
What are the common symptoms seen in patients with vertebral osteomyelitis?	Patients with vertebral osteomyelitis will present with focal back tenderness and constitutional symptoms.
What is a characteristic finding in patients with unilateral renal artery stenosis on imaging?	Patients with unilateral renal artery stenosis on imaging will have a characteristic renal size discrepancy.
What are the typical levels of estrogen and FSH/LH seen in patients with Turner syndrome?	Patients with Turner syndrome typically have low levels of estrogen and high levels of FSH/LH.
What are the typical symptoms of patients with trochanteric bursitis?	Patients with trochanteric bursitis present with lateral hip pain that may radiate down the thigh.
What is a potential complication that patients with tinea pedis may develop?	Patients with tinea pedis may develop cellulitis as a complication.
What type of Ehlers danlos can lead to damage to muscles and fragile tissues in patients?	Patients with the vascular type of Ehlers danlos can present with damage to muscles and fragile tissues.
What blood types are incompatible with the AB blood type?	None.
What is a possible cause of low back pain in patients with testicular cancer?	Patients with testicular cancer may present with low back pain due to para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymphadenopathy.
What nerve is involved in temporomandibular disorders and what symptoms can it cause?	Patients with temporomandibular disorder that involve the mandibular nerve can have both jaw pain and otologic symptoms.
What is a possible complication that patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) can present with?	Patients with T2DM in DKA can present with prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI).
What symptoms can patients with systemic mastocytosis present with and what is the underlying cause?	Patients with systemic mastocytosis can present with syncope, flushing, hypotension, pruritis, and urticaria due to massive histamine release.
What type of ulcers are patients with systemic mastocytosis prone to developing?	Patients with systemic mastocytosis are prone to developing gastric ulcers.
What type of therapy will be prescribed to patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis and what is its intended purpose?	Patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis will be prescribed therapy to reduce inflammation.
What are some common clinical manifestations of Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis that patients may present with?	Patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis often present with daily spiking fevers and a salmon-pink macular rash.
What ocular complication are patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis at risk of developing?	Patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis often develop uveitis in their eye.
What is a recommended method for assessing pulmonary function in patients with suspected Guillain-Barré syndrome?	Patients with suspected Guillain-Barré syndrome should have their pulmonary function assessed with serial spirometry.
What type of antibiotic coverage should be included in the treatment of patients with suspected aspiration pneumonia?	Patients with suspected aspiration pneumonia should be treated with antibiotics that include anaerobic coverage.
What are some common symptoms associated with vertebrobasilar insufficiency in patients with subclavian steal syndrome?	Patients with subclavian steal syndrome present with vertebrobasilar insufficiency which can cause symptoms such as dizziness, vertigo, and drop attacks.
What intervention is recommended for patients with spinal shock to prevent acute urinary retention?	Patients with spinal shock should receive a foley catheter to prevent acute urinary retention.
What type of patients may benefit from REM sleep-suppressing drugs, and what are some examples of these drugs?	Patients with significant cataplexy may benefit from REM sleep-suppressing drugs, such as antidepressants and sodium oxybate.
What infection can cause aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia, and how does it affect erythroid precursors?	Patients with sickle cell anemia are at risk of aplastic crisis with parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors.
What type of kidney stones are patients with short bowel syndrome at an increased risk of developing?	Patients with short bowel syndrome often develop an increased frequency of calcium oxalate kidney stones.
What imaging tool should be used to evaluate patients with severe features of PID, and what condition should be excluded?	Patients with severe features of PID should be evaluated with a transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) to exclude tubo-ovarian abscess.
What do patients with severe aortic stenosis depend upon for maintenance of preload?	Patients with severe aortic stenosis depend upon atrial contraction for maintenance of preload.
What are the common symptoms of septic abortion in patients, and what is the characteristic feature of their vaginal discharge?	Patients with septic abortion typically have fever, abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and a foul-smelling vaginal discharge.
What is a potential cause of anaphylaxis in patients with selective IgA deficiency?	Patients with selective IgA deficiency may develop anaphylaxis due to blood transfusions.
What is sclerodermal renal crisis, and what is its characteristic feature in patients with scleroderma?	Sclerodermal renal crisis is an intense renal failure that causes hypertensive emergency and can present in patients with scleroderma.
What is the recommended management for patients with scaphoid fractures, and what complication should be ruled out with serial X-rays?	Patients with scaphoid fractures should have their wrists immobilized, and serial X-rays should be taken to rule out osteonecrosis.
What is the recommended treatment for hypocalcemia in patients with renal insufficiency?	Patients with renal insufficiency can be given Calcitriol to correct their hypocalcemia.
What are the common auscultatory findings in patients with renal artery stenosis?	Patients with renal artery stenosis will present with abdominal and flank bruits.
What are the dermatological and skeletal manifestations of Refsum disease in affected patients?	Patients with Refsum disease have scaly skin and shortening of the 4th toe.
What are the potential ophthalmological complications that can occur in patients with Refsum disease?	Patients with Refsum Disease can have various ophthalmological problems, including cataracts and night blindness.
What is the cause of skeletal and craniofacial dysmorphism in patients with Refsum disease?	Patients with Refsum Disease can have skeletal and craniofacial dysmorphism due to epiphyseal dysplasia.
What is an alternative treatment option for patients with recurrent DVTs who cannot receive anticoagulation therapy?	Patients with recurrent DVTs can be given an IVC filter if they have contraindications to anticoagulation.
What is the typical serology seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency?	Patients with primary ovarian insufficiency typically have decreased estrogen levels, increased LH levels, and increased FSH levels.
What changes in urinary excretion of various substances are typically seen in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism?	Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism typically have increased urinary excretion of phosphate, calcium, and cAMP.
What is the reason for increased Ca2+ excretion in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism?	Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have increased Ca2+ excretion due to the high filtered load of calcium on the kidney.
What type of glasses are often needed by patients with presbyopia?	Patients with presbyopia often need reading glasses (magnifiers).
What medication do patients with polycythemia vera commonly take at a low dose to decrease their risk of thrombosis?	Patients with polycythemia vera commonly take low-dose aspirin to decrease their risk of thrombosis.
What type of carcinoma do patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome have an increased risk of?	Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome have an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma.
What activity should patients with placenta previa be advised to avoid?	Patients with placenta previa should be advised to avoid sexual intercourse.
How do patients with pheochromocytoma experience their symptoms?	Patients with pheochromocytoma experience their symptoms episodically, rather than continuously.
What artificial sweetener should patients with phenylketonuria avoid, and why?	Patients with phenylketonuria should avoid the artificial sweetener aspartame, which contains phenylalanine.
Which brain nuclei experience hypopigmentation in patients with phenylketonuria?	Patients with phenylketonuria develop hypopigmentation in the catecholaminergic brain nuclei.
What type of cancer should patients with pernicious anemia be monitored for?	Patients with pernicious anemia should be monitored for development of gastric cancer.
What is the higher risk that patients with Peripheral Artery Disease have compared to critical limb ischemia?	Patients with Peripheral Artery Disease have a higher risk of having a myocardial infarction (MI) than critical limb ischemia.
What are the common symptoms that patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease present with?	Patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease commonly present with claudication, acute rest pain, and numbness distally to occlusion.
What are the typical characteristics of chest pain in patients with pericarditis, and how is the pain relieved?	Patients with pericarditis typically present with pleuritic chest pain, which is relieved by postural changes.
What do patients with pemphigoid gestationis have autoantibodies against?	Patients with pemphigoid gestationis have autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins.
What is the increased risk for maternal development of disease in patients with pemphigoid gestationis?	Patients with pemphigoid gestationis have an increased risk of maternal development of Graves disease.
What is a possible cause of infertility in patients with PCOS?	Patients with PCOS may have infertility due to anovulation from failed follicular maturation.
What are two possible symptoms that patients with PCOS may experience due to anovulation from failed follicular maturation?	Patients with PCOS may have infertility and irregular menses due to anovulation from failed follicular maturation.
What type of infections can patients with patent ductus arteriosus be predisposed to?	Patients with patent ductus arteriosus can be predisposed to respiratory tract infections.
What type of nystagmus can patients with Parinaud syndrome present with?	Patients with Parinaud syndrome can present with a convergence-retraction nystagmus.
What reflex may be slightly suppressed in patients with optic tract lesions?	Patients with optic tract lesions may have a slightly suppressed pupillary light reflex.
What are some behaviors that patients with oppositional defiant disorder may exhibit?	Patients with oppositional defiant disorder may deliberately annoy others and blame others for their mistakes/misbehavior.
What are some cardiovascular symptoms that patients with opioid intoxication may experience?	Patients with opioid intoxication may experience bradycardia and hypotension.
What is a potential complication that patients with Nutcracker syndrome may develop on the left side?	Patients with Nutcracker syndrome may develop a left-sided varicocele.
What is a potential cause of spinal cord compression in patients with neuroblastomas and metastases?	Patients with neuroblastomas may have metastases that cause spinal cord compression due to epidural invasion.
What are some potential symptoms that patients with neuroblastomas may experience if they have orbital metastases?	Patients with neuroblastomas may have orbital metastases resulting in proptosis and/or periorbital ecchymosis.
What type of infections are patients with nephrotic syndrome particularly susceptible to?	Patients with nephrotic syndrome are especially vulnerable to pneumococcal infections.
What are some potential symptoms that patients with neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage may present with?	Patients with neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage can present with altered level of consciousness, bulging fontanelle, hypotension, seizures, and coma.
What is a characteristic feature of patients with müllerian agenesis in terms of their reproductive anatomy?	Patients with müllerian agenesis lack ovaries.
What is the "second-wind" phenomenon that patients with McArdle disease may experience during exercise, and what is its cause?	Patients with McArdle disease may experience the "second-wind" phenomenon during exercise due to increased muscular blood flow.
What is the typical demographic profile of patients with lung cancers that have a EML4-ALK fusion protein?	Patients with lung cancers that have a EML4-ALK fusion protein are typically seen in young non-smokers.
In patients with long-standing COPD, what physiological parameter do they have decreased sensitivity to?	Patients with long-standing COPD have decreased sensitivity to PaCO2.
What is the potential consequence of administering excessive oxygen to patients with long-standing COPD?	Administering excessive oxygen to patients with long-standing COPD can lead to the development of hypercapnia.
What type of drugs are patients with Lewy body dementia particularly sensitive to?	Patients with Lewy body dementia are especially sensitive to antipsychotic drugs.
Is there an increased risk of pulmonary embolism in patients with left-sided endocarditis?	Yes, patients with left-sided endocarditis are at an increased risk of pulmonary embolism.
What condition can develop in patients with left-sided renal vein thrombosis due to the "nutcracker" effect?	Patients with left-sided renal vein thrombosis can develop a left-sided varicocele due to the "nutcracker" effect.
What type of vision loss do patients with Leber hereditary optic neuropathy develop?	Patients with Leber hereditary optic neuropathy develop a subacute bilateral and progressive loss of central vision.
What are some common symptoms of lead poisoning in patients?	Patients with lead poisoning often manifest with symptoms of gastrointestinal and kidney dysfunction/disease.
In which direction do patients with lateral cerebellar lesions have a propensity to fall?	Patients with lateral cerebellar lesions have a propensity to fall toward the lesioned side.
What are some common symptoms of late diabetic neuropathy in patients?	Patients with late diabetic neuropathy have widespread loss of reflexes with motor weakness.
What are some common symptoms that patients with Lambert-Eaton Syndrome present with?	Patients with Lambert-Eaton Syndrome present with autonomic symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, and impotence.
What is the characteristic appearance of sputum that patients with Klebsiella pneumoniae will cough up?	Patients with Klebsiella pneumoniae will cough up a pink, currant jelly sputum.
What genes are most commonly associated with mutations in patients with Kallmann syndrome?	Patients with Kallmann syndrome most commonly have mutations in the KAL-1 or FGFR-1 genes.
What is the most common dermatological symptom that patients with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy present with?	Patients with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy typically present with pruritus.
What is the cause of nephritic syndrome in patients with infective endocarditis?	Patients with infective endocarditis can develop a nephritic syndrome due to deposition of circulating immune complexes.
What activity are patients with infectious mononucleosis advised to avoid for one month?	Patients with infectious mononucleosis are advised to avoid contact sports for one month.
What is the typical level of urine sodium in patients with hypovolemia?	Patients with hypovolemia often have decreased levels of urine sodium.
What are the typical findings on funduscopy in patients with hypertensive retinopathy?	Patients with hypertensive retinopathy will present on funduscopy with flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, arteriovenous nicking, microaneurysms, macular star, and cotton-wool spots.
What are the common symptoms that patients with hydatiform moles may present with?	Patients with hydatiform moles may present with pelvic discomfort, vaginal bleeding, and hyperemesis.
What is the typical range of cholesterol levels in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia?	Patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (very rare) have cholesterol levels of approximately 700 mg/dL or higher.
What are some common characteristics of patients with histrionic personality disorder?	Patients with histrionic personality disorder are often attention seeking, sexually provocative, and overly concerned with their appearance.
What are some potential pulmonary complications that patients with a history of thoracic radiation may develop?	Patients with a history of thoracic radiation may develop pulmonary fibrosis and pneumonitis as potential complications.
What is the typical presentation of patients with hairy cell leukemia and what is the cause of this presentation?	Patients with hairy cell leukemia typically present with massive splenomegaly due to expansion of the red pulp.
What is the typical presentation of patients with hairy cell leukemia and what is the cause of this presentation?	Patients with hairy cell leukemia typically present with massive splenomegaly due to expansion of the red pulp.
What type of carcinoma can develop in patients with granulosa cell tumors?	Patients with granulosa cell tumors can develop an endometrial carcinoma.
What types of lymphocytes are deficient in patients with Good Syndrome?	Patients with Good Syndrome have deficient levels of B and T lymphocytes.
What are the common reasons for patients with generalized anxiety disorder to visit their primary care physician?	Patients with generalized anxiety disorder frequently come to their PCP with somatic symptoms.
What substance do patients with essential tremor often self-medicate with, and how does it affect their tremors?	Patients with essential tremor often self-medicate with alcohol, which decreases tremor amplitude.
What is the typical survival time for patients with Edwards syndrome and Patau syndrome after birth?	Patients with Edwards syndrome and Patau syndrome often die within 1 year of birth.
What type of reflexes are typically decreased in patients with early diabetic neuropathy?	Patients with early diabetic neuropathy typically have decreased ankle reflexes.
What are the common laboratory findings in patients with DRESS syndrome?	Patients with DRESS syndrome typically have eosinophilia, atypical lymphocytosis, and elevated ALT.
What are the common clinical manifestations of patients with DRESS syndrome?	Patients with DRESS syndrome typically present with fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, facial edema, and diffuse morbilliform skin rash.
What type of dysphagia is commonly seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm?	Patients with diffuse esophageal spasm typically present with intermittent solid/liquid dysphagia.
What sensory deficits are commonly seen in patients with diabetic neuropathy?	Patients with diabetic neuropathy typically present with a slowly progressive decrease in vibratory sensation, proprioception, and temperature sensation.
What is the effect of bicarbonate reuptake in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis?	Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis have increased bicarbonate reuptake.
What is the status of reality testing in patients with depersonalization/derealization disorder?	Patients with depersonalization/derealization disorder have intact reality testing.
What are the common clinical features seen in patients with cyanide poisoning?	Patients with cyanide poisoning typically present with an "almond" breath odor and reddish skin discoloration.
What is the effect of cyanide poisoning on the venous-arterial PO2 gradient in patients?	Patients with cyanide poisoning typically have a narrowing of the venous-arterial PO2 gradient.
In what locations can the testis remain in patients with cryptorchidism?	Patients with cryptorchidism typically have the testis remain in the abdomen or the inguinal canal.
In which organs/tissues do patients with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis typically have deposition of immune complexes?	Patients with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis typically have deposition of immune complexes in the skin, peripheral nervous system, and the kidney.
What is the reason for the increased risk of kidney stones in patients with Crohn disease?	Patients with Crohn disease have an increased risk for kidney stones due to increased absorption of oxalate.
What is the reason for the increased work of breathing in patients with COPD?	Patients with COPD have an increased work of breathing due to a flattened diaphragm.
How does shoulder pain typically present in patients with clavicle fractures?	Shoulder pain typically presents as worsening with movement in patients with clavicle fractures.
What type of infections are patients with Chédiak-Higashi syndrome at an increased risk for, and can you provide some examples?	Patients with Chédiak-Higashi syndrome are at an increased risk for pyogenic infections, such as those caused by staphylococci and streptococci.
In patients with CHF, which renal arterioles are often affected by preferential vasoconstriction?	Patients with CHF often have preferential vasoconstriction of efferent renal arterioles.
What is the recommended imaging evaluation for patients with central precocious puberty prior to starting GnRH agonist therapy?	Patients with central precocious puberty require MRI of the brain prior to starting GnRH agonist therapy.
What is the potential complication that patients with cavernous hemangiomas in the brain are at risk of developing?	Patients with cavernous hemangiomas in the brain are at risk of developing an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
What is the characteristic shape of the heart on chest x-ray in patients with cardiac tamponade?	Patients with cardiac tamponade have an enlarged "water bottle" shaped heart on chest x-ray.
What is the common phenomenon that patients with Buerger disease often experience?	Patients with Buerger disease often experience Raynaud's phenomenon.
What is the recommended device that patients with Brugada syndrome may use to prevent sudden cardiac death?	Patients with Brugada syndrome may prevent sudden cardiac death with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).
What are the potential risks associated with Brugada syndrome that may lead to sudden cardiac death (SCD)?	Patients with Brugada syndrome are at increased risk of ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (SCD).
What is the recommended treatment for patients with blood pressure that is significantly above the goal value?	Patients with BP > 20/10 mmHg above goal should use two antihypertensives.
What is a common history found in patients with borderline personality disorder?	Patients with borderline personality disorder often have a history of childhood trauma, including physical, sexual, and emotional abuse.
What are the typical clinical features of patients with Bloom Syndrome?	Patients with Bloom Syndrome commonly present with cafe-au-lait spots, rash from sun exposure, and short stature.
What is a notable association with premature aging in patients with Bloom syndrome?	Patients with Bloom syndrome are associated with premature aging.
What is a significant risk associated with patients who have bipolar disorder?	Patients with bipolar disorder have a high risk of suicide.

What is a potential complication associated with basilar skull fractures in patients?	Patients with basilar skull fractures can have cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks from the nose or the ears.
What is a possible symptom that patients with basilar skull fracture may present with?	Patients with basilar skull fracture may present with blood in the tympanic cavity of the ear.

What is a potential cause of acute neurological deficits in patients with atlantoaxial instability if their subluxation is worsened?	Patients with atlantoaxial instability can acutely present with neurological deficits due to spinal cord compression if their subluxation is worsened.

What is a common presentation of fertility in patients with Asherman syndrome?	Patients with Asherman syndrome will present with decreased fertility.
