What is a common finding related to axillary and pubic hair in patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS)?	Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) typically have normal axillary and pubic hair development.
What is the recommended treatment approach for patients with an LDL cholesterol level of 190 mg/dL or higher?	Patients with an LDL cholesterol level of 190 mg/dL or higher are recommended to begin high-intensity statin therapy.
What is the recommended treatment approach for patients with an LDL cholesterol level greater than 190 mg/dL?	Patients with an LDL cholesterol level greater than 190 mg/dL are recommended to begin high-intensity statin therapy.
What is the recommended treatment approach for patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk greater than 7.5%?	Patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk greater than 7.5% should be started on a moderate- to high-intensity statin.
What are some common clinical features seen in patients with an anterior urethral injury?	Patients with an anterior urethral injury often present with blood at the urethral meatus and a scrotal hematoma.
What is a potential clinical finding in patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm?	Patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm may present with a decrease in the ankle-brachial index.
What are some common symptoms associated with amoebic liver abscesses?	Patients with amoebic liver abscesses often complain of right upper quadrant pain and may have hepatomegaly.
What are some common symptoms associated with the prodrome of acute viral hepatitis?	Patients with acute viral hepatitis often present with a prodrome of fever, malaise, anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
What is a potential complication that patients with acute pericarditis may be at increased risk for?	Patients with acute pericarditis are at increased risk for developing cardiac tamponade.
What is the pathophysiology behind the development of edema in patients with acute nephritic syndrome?	Patients with acute nephritic syndrome develop edema due to glomerular damage, resulting in decreased GFR and increased Na+/H2O retention.
What are some potential health risks associated with acromegaly?	Patients with acromegaly have an increased risk of developing colorectal polyps and cancer.
What is a potential cardiovascular complication that can occur in patients with acromegaly?	Patients with acromegaly can develop hypertension, which is a potential cardiovascular complication of the condition.
What are some common symptoms that patients with abnormal menstrual bleeding may experience?	Patients with abnormal menstrual bleeding may experience variations of a normal menstrual cycle, as well as symptoms of anemia.
What are some common topics that may be covered during counseling for patients with abnormal blood glucose levels?	Patients with abnormal blood glucose levels may receive counseling on topics such as healthy diet and physical activity.
What is a characteristic feature of enterocytes in patients with Abetalipoproteinemia?	Patients with Abetalipoproteinemia may have enterocytes with clear cytoplasm, which is prominently seen at the tips of the villi.
What physical symptom can patients with a basilar skull fracture present with, and what is it commonly referred to as?	Patients with a basilar skull fracture can present with periorbital ecchymosis, which is commonly referred to as "raccoon eyes".
What are the common genital abnormalities that patients with a 5a-reductase deficiency may present with?	Patients with a 5a-reductase deficiency commonly also have a micropenis and hypospadias.
How much fluid do patients who use probenecid need to drink daily?	Patients who use probenecid need to drink 2L of fluid daily.
What medical condition can patients develop after undergoing radioactive iodine (I131) treatment?	Patients who undergo radioactive iodine (I131) treatment can develop hypothyroidism.
What part of the body is at risk for fibrosis in patients who take Nitrofurantoin?	Patients who take Nitrofurantoin are at risk for fibrosis of the lungs.
What medical condition are patients who survive acute iron toxicity at risk of developing within 2-8 weeks after ingestion?	Patients who survive acute iron toxicity are at risk of developing pyloric stenosis within 2-8 weeks after ingestion.
What is the recommended screening for hepatitis C in patients who received blood transfusions before a certain year?	Patients who received blood transfusions before 1992 should be screened for hepatitis C.
What is the management strategy for patients who present in preterm labor at greater than 34 weeks with breech presentation?	Patients who present in preterm labor at greater than 34 weeks with breech presentation are managed with cesarean delivery.

How is rhabdomyolysis diagnosed in patients?	Rhabdomyolysis is diagnosed in patients by observing a creatine kinase level greater than 1000 u/L.

Which sexually transmitted disease (STD) requires patients to be given prophylactic Benzathine Penicillin G?	Patients who have been exposed to Treponema pallidum, the bacteria that causes syphilis, should be given prophylactic Benzathine Penicillin G.
What type of cephalosporin should be given to patients who have ampicillin resistant Haemophilus Influenzae?	Patients who have ampicillin resistant Haemophilus Influenzae should be given a 3rd generation cephalosporin.
What type of bacterial infections are patients who undergo cystoscopy at an increased risk of developing?	Patients who undergo cystoscopy are especially at risk for infections caused by enterococcus species.
What type of cancer are patients at risk for if they are chronically exposed to Nickel, Chromium, Beryllium, or Silica?	Patients who are chronically exposed to Nickel, Chromium, Beryllium, or Silica are at risk for developing lung cancer.
What ECG finding may be generated in patients who develop right heart strain due to pulmonary emboli?	Patients who develop pulmonary emboli may develop right heart strain that generates a S1Q3T3 ECG finding.
What type of underlying disease do patients who develop ischemic colitis often have extensively?	Patients who develop ischemic colitis often have extensive underlying atherosclerotic disease.
What type of intervention may be required for patients who develop ARDS?	Patients who develop ARDS may require mechanical ventilation.
What syndrome should be considered in patients who experience persistent RUQ pain after cholecystectomy?	Patients who complain of persistent RUQ pain after cholecystectomy should be evaluated for post-cholecystectomy syndrome.
What syndrome are patients rarely at risk of developing when undergoing IVF with ovulation induction (ex. hCG therapy)?	Patients who are undergoing IVF with ovulation induction (ex. hCG therapy) are rarely at risk of developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.
Which serum tumor marker is found in higher levels in patients who smoke?	CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen) is found in higher levels in patients who smoke.
What is the reason for increased side effects from certain drugs in patients who are slow acetylators?	Patients who are slow acetylators have increased side effects from certain drugs due to decreased rate of metabolism.
What medical condition may cause patients to draw their knees to their chest to ease the pain?	Patients who are experiencing intussusception may draw their knees to their chest to ease the pain.
What viruses should patients who are being treated with Rituximab be monitored for reactivation?	Patients who are being treated with Rituximab should be watched for reactivation of the Hepatitis B or JC Virus.
What type of organisms should patients undergoing splenectomy be vaccinated against?	Patients undergoing splenectomy should be vaccinated against encapsulated organisms.
What type of radiation are patients typically exposed to through exposure to sunlight?	Patients are typically exposed to Non-Ionizing radiation through exposure to sunlight.
What type of radiation are patients typically exposed to through nuclear reactor accidents or radiotherapy?	Patients are typically exposed to Ionizing radiation through nuclear reactor accidents or radiotherapy.
In what medical context do patients typically get chronically exposed to Alkylating agents?	Patients typically get chronically exposed to Alkylating agents when they are being given oncologic chemotherapy.
What is the likely symptom that patients will develop if they overdose on Isoniazid?	Patients that overdose on Isoniazid will develop seizures.
What type of metabolic acidosis can patients develop if they overdose on Isoniazid?	Patients that overdose on Isoniazid can develop a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
What should be evaluated in patients who have a sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses?	Patients who have a sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses should be evaluated for underlying internal malignancy (e.g. GI).
What tests should patients taking valproate have prior to therapy and regularly thereafter?	Patients taking valproate should have liver tests prior to therapy and regularly thereafter.
What is a possible symptom that patients taking Tizanidine can develop, in addition to hypotension and weakness?	Patients taking Tizanidine can develop xerostomia (dry mouth) in addition to hypotension and weakness.
What symptoms can patients taking Tetracyclines manifest, related to skin sensitivity and gastrointestinal distress?	Patients taking Tetracyclines can manifest symptoms of skin sensitivity to light and GI distress.
What are the possible side effects that patients taking sevelamer can develop, including hypophosphatemia?	Patients taking sevelamer can develop GI upset in addition to hypophosphatemia.
What type of anemia can patients taking Ribavirin develop?	Patients taking Ribavirin can develop a hemolytic anemia.
What type of anemia can patients taking Penicillin G/V develop?	Patients taking Penicillin G/V can develop a hemolytic anemia.
What type of acidosis can patients taking nucleoside NRTI's develop?	Patients taking nucleoside NRTI's can develop a lactic acidosis.
What type of suppression do patients taking NRTIs suffer from?	Patients taking NRTIs suffer from bone marrow suppression.
What side effects can patients taking Metronidazole report?	Patients taking Metronidazole can report side effects of headache as well as a metallic taste.
What symptoms can patients taking Leuprolide experience?	Patients taking Leuprolide can experience nausea and vomiting.
What condition can patients taking Interferon alpha experience as a result of the drug?	Patients taking Interferon alpha can experience a drug induced lupus.
What type of anemia can patients taking hydroxyurea develop?	Patients taking hydroxyurea can develop a megaloblastic anemia.

What type of toxicity can patients taking Griseofulvin develop?	Patients taking Griseofulvin can develop neurotoxicity.
What type of abnormalities can patients taking Foscarnet experience?	Patients taking Foscarnet can experience various electrolyte abnormalities.
What hormone imbalances can occur in patients taking exogenous testosterone and what are the resulting symptoms?	Patients taking exogenous testosterone can develop hormone imbalances, resulting in small testes, low sperm count, and gynecomastia.
What type of color blindness can patients taking Ethambutol manifest with?	Patients taking Ethambutol can manifest with red-green color blindness.
What type of rash can patients taking Erlotinib get?	Patients taking Erlotinib can get a papulopustular acneiform rash.
What is the risk for patients taking combined oral contraceptive pills in developing functional ovarian cysts?	Patients taking combined oral contraceptive pills are at risk of developing functional ovarian cysts.
What condition can patients taking Colchicine develop?	Patients taking Colchicine can develop agranulocytosis.
What are the two things that patients taking clozapine require regular monitoring of?	Patients taking clozapine require regular monitoring of white blood cell and absolute neutrophil counts.
What skin condition can patients taking Bleomycin experience?	Patients taking Bleomycin can experience hyperpigmentation of the skin.
What are the three side effects that patients taking Basiliximab can experience?	Patients taking Basiliximab can experience side effects of edema, hypertension, and tremor.
What viral infections are patients taking Azathioprine / 6MP predisposed to reactivation or exacerbation of?	Patients taking Azathioprine / 6MP are predisposed to reactivation of Herpes Zoster or exacerbation of chronic viral Hepatitis.
What are the risks associated with taking acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir if not adequately hydrated?	Patients taking acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir are at risk of obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute renal failure if not adequately hydrated.
What syndrome can patients experience when taking 5FU intravenously?	Patients taking 5FU intravenously can experience Hand-Foot syndrome.
What are the potential complications that patients taking 5FU as a topical cream may experience?	Patients taking 5FU as a topical cream can have complications of hyperpigmentation and photosensitivity.
What substance should patients avoid consuming while taking Metronidazole?	Patients should avoid consuming alcohol while taking Metronidazole.
Why should patients not consume Milk, Antacids, or Iron-containing preparations with Tetracyclines?	Patients should not consume Milk, Antacids, or Iron-containing preparations with Tetracyclines as they prevent the drugs absorption.
In which position should patients be placed if they have a bleeding lung?	Patients should be placed with the bleeding lung in the dependent position.
What is the difference in the likelihood of experiencing glycemia between patients receiving parenteral nutrition and those with enteral nutrition?	Patients receiving parenteral nutrition are more likely to experience hyper-glycemia than those with enteral nutrition.
What medication should patients avoid when taking nitrate therapy for 24 hours?	Patients on PDE-5 inhibitors should avoid nitrate therapy for 24 hours.
What is the potential risk for patients on sulfonylureas who have renal failure?	Patients on sulfonylureas are at increased risk of hypoglycemia if they have renal failure.
What potential side effect may occur in patients who are taking stimulants?	Patients on stimulants may develop tics.
Why do patients on nitrates have a nitrate-free interval every day?	Patients on nitrates have a nitrate-free interval everyday to prevent tolerance.
What is the potential risk for patients on erythropoiesis-stimulating agents and why?	Patients on erythropoiesis-stimulating agents are associated with increased risk for thromboembolic events due to increased blood viscosity.
Which patients should not be prescribed fluoroquinolones due to an increased risk of tendon/cartilage damage and why?	Patients on chronic steroid therapy should not be prescribed fluoroquinolones due to a significantly increased risk of tendon/cartilage damage.
How long must patients wait after stopping MAO inhibitors before starting serotonergic drugs and/or stopping dietary restrictions?	Patients must wait 2 weeks after stopping MAO inhibitors before starting serotonergic drugs and/or stopping dietary restrictions.
What type of bias is present when patients are lost to follow up?	Patients lost to follow up is a type of selection bias.
What medication should be given to patients in preterm labor at less than 32 weeks for fetal neuroprotection?	Patients in preterm labor at less than 32 weeks should receive magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection.
What is the carbon length of palmitate, a type of fatty acid?	Palmitate is a 16-carbon fatty acid.
What is another suitable method for assessing rotator cuff tears besides X-ray?	Musculoskeletal ultrasound (MSUS) can also be used to evaluate rotator cuff tears.
What are some signs of a leukemoid reaction?	Some signs of a leukemoid reaction include basophilic peripherally located "döhle bodies" in neutrophils, toxic granulation, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.
What are some common grief symptoms?	Some common grief symptoms include shock, guilt, sadness, anxiety, yearning, and somatic symptoms that usually occur in waves.
What are some alternative names for Parvovirus B19?	Some alternative names for Parvovirus B19 include erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever, and fifth disease.
What is Ostium primum and with what syndrome is it associated?	Ostium primum is a less common type of atrial septal defect that is associated with Down syndrome.
What are the common presentations of osteosarcomas?	Osteosarcomas commonly present as a painful enlarging mass or pathologic fractures.
Which part of the bone do osteosarcomas often invade?	Osteosarcomas often invade the medullary cavity of the bone.
What percentage of primary bone cancers are accounted for by osteosarcomas?	Osteosarcomas account for 20% of primary bone cancers.
What are the common clinical presentations of osteosarcoma?	Osteosarcoma typically presents as a pathologic fracture or bone pain with swelling.
What is osteosarcoma commonly associated with?	Osteosarcoma is commonly associated with radiation exposure.
What type of cells does osteosarcoma involve in its malignant proliferation?	Osteosarcoma involves malignant proliferation of osteoblasts.
What are the common associations of osteosarcoma in the elderly?	Osteosarcoma in the elderly is generally associated with Paget disease and radiation.
Where does osteosarcoma typically arise in long bones and what is the common location around the bone?	Osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, often around the knee.
What is the typical location of osteosarcoma around the knee and which long bones are commonly affected?	Osteosarcoma often arises in the metaphysis of long bones around the knee, such as the femur or tibia.
Where does osteosarcoma typically arise in long bones and what is the common location around the bone?	Osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, often around the knee.
What is the term used to describe osteoporosis with palpable vertebral step-off and pinpoint tenderness?	Osteoporosis with palpable vertebral step-off and pinpoint tenderness is known as a compression fracture.
What are the typical symptoms of osteoporosis and what diagnostic test is used to confirm the diagnosis?	Osteoporosis most commonly presents with vertebral body compression fractures and is diagnosed with a DEXA scan.
What are the potential fractures associated with osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis may present with fracture of the femoral neck or distal radius (Colles fracture).
What medical condition can lead to osteoporosis as a secondary complication?	Osteoporosis may be secondary to hyperthyroidism.
What medical condition can lead to osteoporosis as a secondary complication?	Osteoporosis may be secondary to hyperparathyroidism.
What are the common causes of osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis is most commonly due to decreased estrogen levels or increased age.
What is the T-score threshold used to define osteoporosis in a DEXA scan?	Osteoporosis is defined with a DEXA scan T-score < -2.5.
How is osteoporosis defined in terms of bone mineral density?	Osteoporosis is defined as a bone mineral density at least 2.5 standard deviations below normal.
What is the typical serum PTH level in individuals with osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum PTH.
What is the typical serum PO43- level in individuals with osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum PO43-.
What is the typical serum Ca2+ level in individuals with osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum Ca2+.
What is the typical serum alkaline phosphatase level in individuals with osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum alkaline phosphatase.
In a person with celiac disease, what nutrient malabsorption can lead to osteoporosis?	Osteoporosis in a person who has celiac disease is due to malabsorption of vitamin D.
What type of fractures can osteoporosis lead to, and what are the resulting physical changes in the body?	Osteoporosis can lead to vertebral compression fractures, which result in loss of height and kyphosis.
What treatment option can help reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis?	Nasal calcitonin can help reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.
What condition do osteophytes present similarly to, and how are they different from that condition?	Osteophytes present similarly to herniated disks (sciatica with and SLR), but are not associated with heavy lifting.
What is one potential symptom of osteopetrosis, and what is the underlying cause of this symptom?	Osteopetrosis may present with vision loss due to optic nerve impingement.
What are some potential symptoms of osteopetrosis, and what is the underlying cause of these symptoms?	Osteopetrosis may present with vision and hearing impairment due to cranial nerve impingement.
What is one potential complication of osteopetrosis, and what is the underlying cause of this complication?	Osteopetrosis may present with hydrocephalus due to narrowing of the foramen magnum.
What is one potential symptom of osteopetrosis, and what is the underlying cause of this symptom?	Osteopetrosis may present with facial paralysis due to cranial nerve VII impingement.
What is the underlying cause of osteopetrosis, and how does it affect the bone?	Osteopetrosis is due to poor osteoclast function, impairing the ability to remodel bone.
What is a common characteristic of osteopetrosis on X-ray, and how is the skeletal system affected?	Osteopetrosis is characterized by diffuse, symmetric skeletal sclerosis on X-ray, indicating increased bone density and decreased bone marrow space.
What are some hematologic manifestations that can be associated with osteopetrosis, and what is the underlying cause of these manifestations?	Osteopetrosis is associated with pancytopenia and extramedullary hematopoiesis due to bony replacement of the marrow (myelophthisic process).
What is the recommended empirical treatment for osteomyelitis, and how should it be administered?	Osteomyelitis should be empirically treated with IV vancomycin and IV antipseudomonal agent.
What radiographic findings may be observed in osteomyelitis, and how do they appear on X-ray?	Osteomyelitis may be seen on X-ray as a lytic focus (sequestrum) surrounded by sclerosis (involucrum).
What is the mechanism by which osteomyelitis typically develops in children?	Osteomyelitis in children arises with transient bacteremia that seeds the metaphysis.
What is the typical cause of osteomyelitis in adults, and how does it occur?	Osteomyelitis in adults arises with open-wound bacteremia that seeds the epiphysis.
How does the spread of osteomyelitis differ between adults and children?	Osteomyelitis in adults typically involves contiguous spread, while osteomyelitis in children is often caused by hematogenous spread.
Which bones are most commonly affected by osteomas, and where do they typically arise on these bones?	Osteomas most commonly arise on the surface of facial bones.
What is the characteristic feature of serum PTH levels in individuals with osteomalacia/rickets?	Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by increased serum PTH levels.
What is the characteristic feature of serum alkaline phosphatase levels in individuals with osteomalacia/rickets?	Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by increased serum alkaline phosphatase levels.
What is the characteristic feature of serum PO43- levels in individuals with osteomalacia/rickets?	Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by decreased serum PO43- levels.
What is the characteristic feature of serum Ca2+ levels in individuals with osteomalacia/rickets?	Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by decreased serum Ca2+ levels.
What is osteoma, and at what age is it typically observed?	Osteoma is a benign tumor of bone that is typically observed in middle age.
Where are osteolytic bone metastases most commonly found?	Osteolytic bone metastases are most commonly found in areas of active hematopoiesis, such as the vertebrae and sternum.
Where does osteoid osteoma typically arise, and in which part of long bones?	Osteoid osteoma typically arises in the cortex of the diaphysis of long bones, such as the femur.
What are the typical symptoms of osteoid osteoma, and how do they respond to aspirin/NSAIDs?	Osteoid osteoma typically presents with bone pain, especially at night, that does resolve with aspirin/NSAIDs.
What are the typical characteristics of the bone pain associated with osteoid osteoma, and how does it respond to aspirin?	Osteoid osteoma typically presents with bone pain that is worse at night and does resolve with aspirin.
What is one potential symptom of osteogenesis imperfecta, and what is the underlying cause of this symptom?	Osteogenesis imperfecta may present with hearing loss due to abnormal ossicles.
What is a potential condition that osteogenesis imperfecta may be mistaken for?	Osteogenesis imperfecta may be confused with child abuse.
What are the two genes that are most commonly associated with gene defects that cause osteogenesis imperfecta?	Osteogenesis imperfecta is most commonly caused by gene defects in COL1A1 and COL1A2.
What is the defining characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta, and how does it occur?	Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by multiple recurrent fractures with minimal trauma.
What specific component of the body is affected by the genetic mutation that causes osteogenesis imperfecta?	Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by mutation in the genes coding for type I collagen.
What is the typical symptom associated with osteochondromas?	Osteochondromas are usually painless.
What is an osteochondroma, and where is it most commonly found in the body?	Osteochondroma is a slow growing bone tumor commonly found at the distal femur (near the knee).
What is the anatomical structure from which an osteochondroma arises?	Osteochondroma arises as a lateral projection of the growth plate (metaphysis).
In what part of the body does an osteoblastoma typically arise?	Osteoblastoma typically arises in vertebrae.
Does bone pain associated with osteoblastoma typically resolve with aspirin/NSAIDs?	No, bone pain associated with osteoblastoma does not resolve with aspirin/NSAIDs, especially at night.
Can aspirin alleviate bone pain associated with osteoblastoma, especially at night?	No, bone pain associated with osteoblastoma does not resolve with aspirin, especially at night.
What is the typical size range of an osteoblastoma, a benign tumor of osteoblasts?	Osteoblastoma, a benign tumor of osteoblasts, typically has a size greater than 2 cm.
What are the possible primary cancers that may give rise to osteoblastic metastases, and what are the associated metabolic changes?	Osteoblastic metastases may arise from primary cancers such as prostate cancer and breast cancer, and they cause hypocalcemia.
What are the three markers used to measure osteoblastic activity?	The three markers used to measure osteoblastic activity are ALP, osteocalcin, and propeptides of type I procollagen.
What is a pannus, and how is it related to osteoarthritis?	A pannus is inflamed granulation tissue inside the joint capsule, and it may be present in cases of osteoarthritis.
How does joint stiffness typically present in cases of osteoarthritis?	Joint stiffness in cases of osteoarthritis typically worsens during the day.
What is the typical pattern of improvement for joint stiffness in cases of osteoarthritis?	Joint stiffness in cases of osteoarthritis typically improves with rest.
What are osteoblasts, and from which type of cells do they differentiate in the body?	Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells that differentiate from mesenchymal stem cells in the periosteum.
What is the origin of osteoclasts in the body, and from which type of precursor cells do they differentiate?	Osteoclasts in the body differentiate from a fusion of monocyte/macrophage lineage precursors.
What is the function of osteoblasts in the body, and what substances do they secrete to carry out this function?	Osteoblasts in the body build bone by secreting collagen, and they catalyze mineralization via secretion of ALP.
What is Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica, and with which types of hyperparathyroidism is it most commonly associated?	Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica is a bone disease that is most commonly associated with both primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
What is the specific area of the brain that is affected by massive axonal demyelination in Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome?	Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome is characterized by massive axonal demyelination of the pons in the brain.
How does Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome typically present, and what is the name of the syndrome it is commonly associated with?	Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome classically presents as "locked in" syndrome.
What is the primary source of derivation for osmolality, and which specific serum level contributes the most to it?	Osmolality is primarily derived from serum levels, with serum sodium levels being the most significant contributor.
Which demographic is commonly affected by Osgood-Schlatter Disease?	Osgood-Schlatter Disease is commonly seen in childhood athletes.
At what point in a patient's life is Osgood-Schlatter Disease commonly observed?	Osgood-Schlatter Disease is commonly seen in patients after their pubertal growth spurt.
What is Osgood-Schlatter Disease, and where is the apophysis located that is affected by this overuse injury?	Osgood-Schlatter Disease is an overuse injury caused by inflammation of the apophysis located on the Tibial Tuberosity.
How do Oseltamivir and Zanamivir work to combat viral infections?	Oseltamivir and Zanamivir work by inhibiting Neuraminidase.
How do Oseltamivir and Zanamivir prevent influenza from infecting the respiratory epithelium?	Oseltamivir / zanamivir also prevent influenza by impairing viral penetration of mucous secretions that overlie the respiratory epithelium.
What is one potential health complication that can arise from Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)?	OSA can lead to secondary hypertension.
What is a common management strategy for Orthostatic hypotension?	Orthostatic hypotension is managed with rehydration.
What condition is suggested by the presence of orthopnea, exertional dyspnea, and nocturnal dyspnea?	The presence of orthopnea, exertional dyspnea, and nocturnal dyspnea is suggestive of Left Heart Failure (HF).
How many segments does Orthomyxovirus have?	Orthomyxovirus has 8 segments.
What are the treatment options for orotic aciduria?	Orotic aciduria can be treated with UMP or uridine triacetate to bypass the mutated enzyme.
What is the process for forming UMP in pyrimidine synthesis and what are the molecules involved?	In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is formed by combining orotic acid with phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP).
What is the effect of Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency on serum glutamine levels?	Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency leads to increased serum glutamine levels.
What are the clinical presentations of Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency in terms of NH4+ and ammonemia levels?	Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency presents with increased NH4+ and hyper-ammonemia.
How does Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency affect blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels?	Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency leads to decreased BUN levels.
What is the effect of Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency on the levels of orotic acid in the blood and urine?	Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency leads to increased levels of orotic acid in the blood and urine.
What is the mechanism of action of Orlistat and what is its clinical use?	Orlistat works as an intestinal lipase inhibitor and is used for weight loss.
What is the treatment for organophosphate toxicity and how does it work?	The treatment for organophosphate toxicity is pralidoxime, which regenerates AChE at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors if given early.
What is the treatment for organophosphate toxicity and what type of receptors does it act on?	The treatment for organophosphate toxicity is atropine, which is a competitive inhibitor at muscarinic receptors only.
What happens to organic nitrates when they are metabolized?	When organic nitrates are metabolized, they release nitric oxide.
Which herpesvirus is responsible for an increased risk of pneumonia in organ transplant patients?	CMV (Cytomegalovirus) is responsible for an increased risk of pneumonia in organ transplant patients.
What health risk are organ transplant patients at an increased risk of due to CMV?	Organ transplant patients are at an increased risk of CMV pneumonia.
In what order are growth measurements affected in cases of failure to thrive?	Growth measurements are affected in the order of weight, height, and then head circumference.
What is the risk associated with orchitis due to mumps infection, especially in teenagers?	Orchitis due to mumps infection carries the risk of sterility, especially in teenagers.
What is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis?	Orbital cellulitis is most commonly caused by bacterial spread from ethmoidal or maxillary sinusitis.
How does the severity of orbital cellulitis compare to that of preseptal cellulitis?	Orbital cellulitis is a more severe infection than preseptal cellulitis.
What is oral leukoplakia?	Oral leukoplakia is a white deposit on the tongue that cannot be easily scraped away.
What medication is used to treat severe cystic acne?	Oral isotretinoin (vitamin A) is used to treat severe cystic acne.
What is oral candidiasis?	Oral candidiasis is a white deposit on the tongue that can be easily scraped away.
What are the precursor lesions to squamous cell carcinoma in the oral cavity?	Oral leukoplakia and erythroplakia are precursor lesions to squamous cell carcinoma.
What medications are indicated for recurrent acute otitis media despite amoxicillin therapy?	Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate or fluoroquinolones are indicated for recurrent acute otitis media (within 30 days) despite amoxicillin therapy.
What medications are indicated for acute otitis media and refractory symptoms after 2-3 days despite amoxicillin therapy?	Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate or fluoroquinolones are indicated for acute otitis media and refractory symptoms after 2-3 days despite amoxicillin therapy.
What is the cause of oral thrush of the mouth that appears as a white exudate on mucous membranes?	Oral thrush of the mouth that appears as a white exudate on mucous membranes is due to candida albicans.
What condition is treated with oral terbinafine?	Oral terbinafine is used to treat dermatophyte-related onychomycosis (nail fungus).
Why do oral nitrate preparations require large dosing?	Oral nitrate preparations require large dosing due to first pass metabolism.
What is a potential adverse effect of oral ingestion of Ferrous Sulfate?	Oral ingestion of Ferrous Sulfate can cause esophagitis.
What is the most common cause of oral herpes?	Oral herpes is usually due to HSV-1 infection.
What is oral erythroplakia and what causes it?	Oral erythroplakia is a red plaque that is caused by vascularization of leukoplakia.
What is the age and habit that make oral contraceptives contraindicated in women?	Oral contraceptives are contraindicated in women over the age of 35 who use tobacco.
What medical condition is associated with the use of oral contraceptives?	Oral contraceptives are associated with hypertension.
What types of cancer are associated with a decreased risk when using oral contraceptives?	Oral contraceptives are associated with a decreased risk for ovarian and endometrial cancer.
What type of coagulable state is associated with the use of oral contraceptives?	Oral contraceptives are associated with a hyper-coagulable state.
What can happen to oral candidiasis when it is scraped off?	Oral candidiasis may bleed when scraped off.
In what type of individuals are oral candidiasis and hairy leukoplakia usually seen?	Oral candidiasis and hairy leukoplakia are usually seen in immunocompromised individuals.
What is the most common type of oral cancer and in what type of individuals is it commonly seen?	The most common type of oral cancer is squamous cell carcinoma, which is commonly seen in smokers and drinkers.
What type of side effects may oral bisphosphonates cause?	Oral bisphosphonates may cause upper GI side effects.
What conditions are generally treated with oral antifungals?	Oral antifungals are generally required for treating Tinea capitis and Onychomycosis.
What are the pharmacological options for managing an acutely agitated patient?	The pharmacological options for managing an acutely agitated patient include the administration of a benzodiazepine and/or an antipsychotic agent.
What is the optimal daily calcium supplementation for postmenopausal women?	The optimal daily calcium supplementation for postmenopausal women is 1200 mg.
What is Oprelvekin and what is it used for?	Oprelvekin is a recombinant form of IL-11 used to treat thrombocytopenia.
What are the opportunistic infections associated with Hyper-IgM syndrome and what is the most common cause of this syndrome?	Opportunistic infections with Cryptosporidium are seen with Hyper-IgM syndrome, most commonly caused by a defective CD40L.
What is a potential complication that may arise from the use of opioids and other sedatives?	Opioids and other sedatives may cause respiratory acidosis.
How can opioids and other CNS depressants potentially cause rhabdomyolysis?	Opioids and other CNS depressants can cause rhabdomyolysis by inducing impaired consciousness with prolonged immobilization and ischemic compression.
What is a common pupillary presentation seen in opioid withdrawal?	Opioid withdrawal presents with pupillary dilation.
What is a common symptom associated with opioid withdrawal?	Opioid withdrawal is associated with mydriasis.
What are some common symptoms associated with opioid withdrawal, often referred to as "cold turkey"?	Opioid withdrawal is associated with fever, yawning, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection ("cold turkey").
What is the recommended management for an opioid overdose with a respiratory rate less than 8?	Opioid overdose and RR < 8 is managed with intubation.
What is a common pupillary presentation seen in opioid intoxication?	Opioid intoxication presents with pupillary constriction.
What are the effects of opioid intoxication on respiratory rate and tidal volume?	Opioid intoxication causes decreased respiratory rate and decreased tidal volume.
What is a potential risk associated with the use of opioid analgesics in regards to respiratory function?	Opioid analgesics may cause significant dose-dependent respiratory depression.
In what medical condition may opioid analgesics be used as a treatment option?	Opioid analgesics may be used to treat acute pulmonary edema.
What is a potential adverse effect associated with the use of opioid analgesics on the central nervous system?	Opioid analgesics are associated with CNS depression as an adverse effect.
What effect do opioid agonists, such as loperamide, have on colonic contractions and transit time?	Opioid agonists (e.g. loperamide) increase colonic phasic segmentation contractions, causing increased colonic transit time.
How do opioid agonists, such as diphenoxylate and loperamide, treat diarrhea?	Opioid agonists (e.g. diphenoxylate, loperamide) treat diarrhea by activating μ-opioid receptors in the GI tract.
What is the effect of opiate receptor activation on potassium channels?	Opiate receptor activation causes opening of K+ channels.
What is the effect of opiate receptor activation on voltage-gated calcium channels?	Opiate receptor activation causes closure of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
What is the minimum required FEV1 after resection for operability of lung cancer?	Operability of lung cancer requires FEV1 > 800 mL after resection.

What demographic factors are associated with open-angle glaucoma other than increased age?	Open-angle glaucoma is associated with African-American race and family history.

What type of amino acids are exclusively found in proteins?	Only L-amino acids are found in proteins.
What type of gas contributes to the partial pressure of a gas in solution?	Only free, dissolved gas contributes to the partial pressure of a gas in solution.
What is the relationship between prosthetic valves and the presence of schistocytes?	Only prosthetic valves can lead to schistocytes.

What are the possible side effects of ondansetron?	The possible side effects of ondansetron include constipation at the gut and headache/dizziness at the head.

What are the potential cardiac effects of ondansetron?	Ondansetron can prolong the QT interval and induce torsades.

What is the extracellular matrix component that tumor cells attach themselves to?	Once tumor cells enter the extracellular matrix they will attach themselves to fibronectin.

What is the name given to the structure that was previously the foramen ovale after it has closed?	Once the foramen ovale has closed, it is re-named the fossa ovalis.
What is the process that occurs after the completion of the dsDNA of HBV?	Once the dsDNA of HBV is complete, host RNA polymerase transcribes mRNA from the dsDNA.
What is the process that occurs after T3 is produced inside its target cell?	Once T3 is produced inside its target cell, it enters the nucleus and binds to a nuclear receptor.
Is it acceptable to abandon a patient once they become your responsibility?	No, it is not acceptable to abandon a patient once they become your responsibility.
What is the target of IgE once it is produced in the body?	Once produced, IgE binds to high affinity (FcεRI) receptors on mast cells in the airway mucosa.
What is the typical outcome for women after postpartum thyroiditis is resolved?	Once postpartum thyroiditis is resolved, the majority of women are euthyroid.
What is the mechanism by which invasive carcinomas are able to spread locally after passing the basement membrane?	Once past the basement membrane, invasive carcinomas are able to spread locally via attachment to fibronectin.
What is the process by which nitric oxide activates soluble guanylyl cyclase in muscle cells?	Once nitric oxide diffuses into muscle cells, it activates soluble (cytosolic) guanylyl cyclase, which converts GTP to cGMP.
What is the process by which methotrexate prevents its movement out of the target cell?	Once methotrexate enters the target cell, it undergoes polyglutamation, preventing the movement of MTX out of the cell.
What is the process by which mast cells burst open when exposed to certain antigens?	Once mast cells are sensitized by IgE antibodies on their surface, they burst open when exposed to appropriate antigens.
What is the process by which Cyclins hyperphosphorylate Rb in response to appropriate levels?	Once levels of Cyclins reach an appropriate level, these complex with Cyclin-Dependent Kinases to hyperphosphorylate Rb.
What is the process by which glucose is modified upon entering the pancreatic β-cell?	Once inside the pancreatic β-cell, glucose is phosphorylated by the enzyme glucokinase.
What is the process by which blastomycosis replicates in the body after entering in the yeast form?	Once inside the body, blastomycosis in the yeast form replicates via broad based budding.
What is the process by which fatty acids are converted inside the adipocyte?	Once inside the adipocyte, fatty acids are reconverted into triglycerides.
What is the mechanism by which IDL can bind to a receptor in the liver?	Once in the vicinity of the liver, the IDL may directly bind a LDL receptor via apoprotein B-100.

What is the role of apoprotein C-II on chylomicrons in the vicinity of adipocytes?	Once in the vicinity of adipocytes, apoprotein C-II on the chylomicron activates the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL).
What is the possible conversion of L-DOPA in the CNS and what enzyme is responsible for this conversion?	Once in the CNS, L-DOPA may be converted to dopamine via the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase.
What happens to chylomicron remnants after they have been depleted of their triglycerides and where do they go?	Once depleted of their triglycerides, chylomicron remnants return to the liver.
What happens to the glucocorticoid receptor after it is activated and where does it bind to regulate gene transcription?	Once bound (activated), the glucocorticoid receptor enters the nucleus and binds to glucocorticoid response elements to regulate gene transcription.
What enzyme deamidates gliadin after it has been absorbed?	Once absorbed, gliadin is deamidated by the enzyme tissue transglutaminase (tTG).
What is the next step after a steroid hormone binds its receptor in the cytoplasm or nucleus?	Once a steroid hormone has bound its receptor in the cytoplasm or nucleus, the hormone-receptor complex then dimerizes.
What appearance does Ewing sarcoma display on x-ray and what causes it?	On x-ray, Ewing sarcoma displays a "moth-eaten" appearance due to small areas of lucency in the medullary cavity.

When does the blastocyst typically form following fertilization?	The blastocyst typically forms on the fourth or fifth day following fertilization.
Within what timeframe following fertilization does implantation occur?	Implantation typically occurs within 6-10 days following fertilization.
How many days after fertilization does the zygote typically form?	The zygote typically forms on the first day after fertilization.

How do pancreatic abscesses typically appear on ultrasound?	On ultrasound, pancreatic abscesses typically appear as complex cystic fluid collections.

What type of exchanger is present on the apical membrane of β-intercalated cells?	On the apical membrane of β-intercalated cells, a Cl--HCO3- exchanger is present.

What is a common finding on physical exam in patients with inhalation injury?	On physical exam, many patients with inhalation injury have singed nasal hairs.
What are the typical findings on liver biopsy in patients with hepatitis C infections?	On liver biopsy, hepatitis C infections typically display lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis.
What is a typical finding on imaging in patients with Diffuse Axonal Injury?	On imaging, patients with Diffuse Axonal Injury typically show multiple punctate hemorrhages at grey-white matter junctions.

What happens to the ducts on histology in fibroadenomas due to stromal proliferation?	On histology, the stromal proliferation in fibroadenomas compresses the ducts.
What is observed on histology in patients with postpartum thyroiditis?	On histology, patients with postpartum thyroiditis exhibit a lymphocytic infiltrate with occasional germinal center formation.
What is suggested on histology by the presence of large nuclei with eosinophilic nucleoli and numerous mitotic figures?	On histology, the presence of large nuclei with eosinophilic nucleoli and numerous mitotic figures is suggestive of melanoma.
What is observed on histology in colloid cysts?	On histology, cyst formation and rare mitoses are found in colloid cysts.
What is observed on gross examination of glioblastomas?	On gross examination, glioblastomas are soft and poorly defined with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.
What is observed on funduscopy in papilledema?	On funduscopy, papilledema is characterized by optic disc swelling / elevation with blurred margins (usually bilateral).
What is observed on endoscopy in vascular rings?	On endoscopy, vascular rings appear as deep impressions on the posterior aspect of the esophagus at T4.
What is observed on electron microscopy in carcinoid tumor cells?	On electron microscopy, carcinoid tumor cells display dense cytoplasmic granules (contain secretory products and hormones).
What is observed on digital rectal examination (DRE) in prostate cancer?	On DRE, prostate cancer presents with asymmetric enlargement, nodule formation and areas of induration.
What is observed on CT in constrictive pericarditis?	On CT, constrictive pericarditis presents with calcification and thickening of the pericardium.
What pathology is suggested by the classic "3" sign on chest x-ray created by indentation of the aorta?	The classic "3" sign on chest x-ray created by indentation of the aorta is suggestive of coarctation of the aorta.
What are the typical findings on chest CT in fat embolism?	On chest CT, fat embolism may appear as bilateral scattered ground-glass opacities.
What are the typical findings on biopsy of a heart with viral myocarditis?	On biopsy of a heart with myocarditis, a lymphocytic infiltrate with focal necrosis is highly indicative of viral myocarditis.
What is the average percentage of intracellular fluid in relation to body weight?	On average, intracellular fluid is 40% of body weight.
What is the average percentage of extracellular fluid in relation to body weight?	On average, extracellular fluid is 20% of body weight.
What is the average percentage of total body water (TBW) in relation to body weight?	On average, total body water (TBW) is 60% of body weight.
What is the average frequency of REM sleep occurrence and how does its duration change throughout the night?	On average, REM sleep occurs every 90 minutes, with increasing duration through the night.
What is the average duration of the latent phase of labor for nulliparous women?	On average, the latent phase of labor lasts for 20 hours for nulliparous women.
What condition is associated with a rigid and diffusely tender abdomen on abdominal exam?	Peritonitis is associated with a rigid and diffusely tender abdomen on abdominal exam.
How does acute bleeding appear on a non-contrast head CT?	Acute bleeding appears as hyperattenuated (bright) lesions on a non-contrast head CT.
What happens to K+ secretion on a low K+ diet?	K+ secretion is decreased on a low K+ diet.
What happens to K+ secretion on a high K+ diet?	K+ secretion increases on a high K+ diet.
What is the characteristic finding on a barium swallow x-ray in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm?	Patients with diffuse esophageal spasm are seen to have a "corkscrew esophagus" on a barium swallow x-ray.
What is omphalocele and what does it involve?	Omphalocele is a condition involving a persistent herniation of bowel into the umbilical cord.
What is the target of Omalizumab, a monoclonal antibody?	Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets IgE.
What are the hormonal changes that can lead to oliguria post-operatively?	Oliguria is often seen post-operatively due to increases in aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
What is the indication for a nonstress test (NST) in the case of oligohydramnios?	Oligohydramnios is an indication for a nonstress test (NST).
At what age are oligodendrogliomas most commonly found?	Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly found around the age of 40-50.
What is a common symptom that may be present in cases of oligodendroglioma?	Oligodendroglioma may present with seizures.
What type of tumor is an oligodendroglioma and what is its origin?	Oligodendroglioma is a malignant tumor that originates from oligodendrocytes.
How do oligodendrocytes typically appear histologically?	Oligodendrocytes typically have a "fried egg" appearance histologically.
What is a common cause of olfactory deficits and which specific bone fracture is typically associated with it?	Olfactory deficits are often caused by head injuries, specifically fractures of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.
What are some of the older treatments that can be used for HCV?	Some of the older treatments that can be used for HCV include IFN-alpha and Ribavirin.
Which amino acids are the most potent stimuli for gastrin secretion?	The most potent stimuli for gastrin secretion among the amino acids are phenylalanine and tryptophan.
How many of the 64 possible codons encode amino acids and how many are stop codons?	Of the 64 possible codons, 61 encode amino acids and 3 are stop codons.
What is the inheritance pattern of oculocutaneous albinism?	Oculocutaneous albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion.
What is the key factor that distinguishes allergic rhinitis from vasomotor rhinitis (nonallergic rhinitis)?	The key factor that distinguishes allergic rhinitis from vasomotor rhinitis (nonallergic rhinitis) is the presence of ocular symptoms.
What is the inheritance pattern of ocular albinism?	Ocular albinism is inherited in an X-linked recessive fashion.
What type of side effects can be caused by Octreotide?	Octreotide may cause gastrointestinal (GI) side effects.
What are the risks of taking oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) before menopause in terms of developing different types of carcinoma?	OCPs before menopause have an increased risk of cervical carcinoma but a decreased risk of endometrial and ovarian carcinoma.
How can oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and the estrogen-progestin vaginal ring worsen preexisting hypertension?	OCPs and the estrogen-progestin vaginal ring can worsen preexisting hypertension due to estrogen-induced angiotensinogen synthesis.
What are the two main treatments for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)?	The two main treatments for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) are cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
What is the potential consequence of carotid artery occlusion caused by an expanding dissection in the thoracic aorta?	Occlusion of the carotid arteries by an expanding thoracic aortic dissection may cause ischemic stroke and/or syncope.
In what cases can chronic rheumatic heart disease involve the aortic valve, and what can be the consequence?	Occasionally, chronic rheumatic heart disease involves the aortic valve, leading to fusion of the commissures.
What is a potential consequence of Obstructive Sleep Apnea?	Obstructive Sleep Apnea may cause respiratory acidosis.
What can cause obstructive sleep apnea, and in which population is it commonly seen?	Obstructive sleep apnea may be caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy in children.
What can cause obstructive sleep apnea, and in which population is it commonly seen?	Obstructive sleep apnea may be caused by excess parapharyngeal tissue in adults.
What is the most common association with obstructive sleep apnea, and what are the typical symptoms?	Obstructive sleep apnea is most commonly associated with obesity and presents with snoring and daytime sleepiness.
What causes obstructive sleep apnea during sleep?	Obstructive sleep apnea is due to relaxation of pharyngeal muscle tone during sleep.
What diagnostic test is used to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea, and what is the typical treatment?	Obstructive sleep apnea is diagnosed with polysomnography and treated with CPAP.
What is the main characteristic of obstructive sleep apnea during sleep?	Obstructive sleep apnea is characterized by intermittent obstruction of the air flow during sleep.
What are the common associations and symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea?	Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with obesity, loud snoring with periods of apnea, and daytime sleepiness.
What is the association between obstructive sleep apnea and systemic hypertension, and why is it difficult to manage?	Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with difficult to manage systemic hypertension due to increased sympathetic tone.
What is the main characteristic of obstructive lung diseases?	Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by obstruction of air flow resulting in air trapping in lungs.
What is the effect of obstructive lung diseases on total lung capacity?	Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by an increased total lung capacity.
What is the effect of obstructive lung diseases on residual volume and functional residual capacity?	Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by an increased residual volume and functional residual capacity.
How is obstructive lung disease characterized in terms of the FEV1/FVC ratio?	Obstructive lung disease is characterized by an FEV1/FVC ratio < 70% of predicted.
How are FVC and FEV1 typically affected in obstructive lung disease?	In obstructive lung disease, FVC is typically low and FEV1 is typically very low.
What are the common symptoms associated with obstructive jaundice?	Obstructive jaundice is commonly associated with steatorrhea and malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
What is a common symptom associated with obstructive jaundice?	A common symptom associated with obstructive jaundice is pale stools.
What is a potential consequence of hypercholesterolemia associated with obstructive jaundice?	Hypercholesterolemia associated with obstructive jaundice may cause xanthomas.
How does obstructive jaundice affect the levels of urobilinogen in urine?	Obstructive jaundice is associated with decreased urine urobilinogen levels.
What is a potential consequence of increased serum bile acids associated with obstructive jaundice?	Increased serum bile acids associated with obstructive jaundice may cause pruritus.
What causes dark urine in patients with obstructive jaundice?	Dark urine in patients with obstructive jaundice is caused by increased urine conjugated bilirubin.
What is a potential consequence of obstruction distal to the ureters, such as VUR, posterior urethral valve, or BPH?	Obstruction distal to the ureters, such as VUR, posterior urethral valve, or BPH, may cause bilateral hydronephrosis.
What artery can be obstructed or damaged resulting in a claw-like contracture of the fingers and wrist?	Obstruction or damage to the brachial artery can result in fingers/wrist being flexed into a claw-like contracture.
What syndrome is obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) associated with?	Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is associated with Tourette's syndrome.
How does obesity affect the conversion of T4 to T3?	Obesity increases the conversion of T4 to T3.
How does obesity lead to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale (right-sided heart failure)?	Obesity may cause chronic hypoxia, which leads to pulmonary hypertension and eventual cor pulmonale (right-sided heart failure).
How does obesity affect the risk of fracture?	Obesity is associated with an increased risk of fracture.
What is the relationship between obesity and insulin resistance, and which type of fat is particularly important in this relationship?	Obesity is an important risk factor for insulin resistance, particularly abdominal fat.
What is the next step in managing obesity hypoventilation syndrome?	The next step in managing obesity hypoventilation syndrome is polysomnography.
What are the characteristics of obesity hypoventilation syndrome during sleep?	Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is characterized by decreased Pao2 and increased Paco2 during sleep.
What is the characteristic feature of obesity hypoventilation (Pickwickian) syndrome during waking hours?	Obesity hypoventilation (Pickwickian) syndrome is characterized by increased Paco2 during waking hours.
What is a common post-operative complication in obese patients who undergo bariatric surgery, and what is the resulting condition?	Obese patients who undergo bariatric surgery frequently develop temporary post-operative hypoxemia, resulting in lactic acidosis.
What is the level of leptin in obese individuals?	Obese individuals have increased levels of leptin.
How does the effectiveness of O2-independent killing in phagocytes compare to O2-dependent killing?	O2-independent killing in phagocytes is less effective than O2-dependent killing.
What is the product of the conversion of O2- by the enzyme superoxide dismutase during the oxidative burst?	O2- is converted to H2O2 by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (oxidative burst).
What is the product of the conversion of O2 by the enzyme NADPH oxidase during the oxidative burst?	O2 is converted to superoxide (O2-) by the enzyme NADPH oxidase (oxidative burst).
In what two forms is O2 carried in the blood?	O2 is carried in blood in two forms: dissolved (2%) or bound to hemoglobin (98%).
What type of infections is Nystatin used to treat?	Nystatin is used to treat non-systemic infections caused by Candida albicans.
Against what type of spp. is Nystatin active?	Nystatin is active against Candida spp.
What medical condition is treated with Nusinersen, an antisense drug?	Nusinersen is an antisense drug used to treat Spinal Muscular Atrophy.
How do nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause increase the risk for epithelial ovarian cancer?	Nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause increase the risk for epithelial ovarian cancer due to increased lifetime ovulatory cycles.
What is the association between nulliparity and endometrial cancer risk?	Nulliparity is associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer.
How do nulliparity and extremes of age (<20 or >40) affect the risk for pre-eclampsia?	Nulliparity and extremes of age (<20 or >40) increase the risk for pre-eclampsia.
What is the typical ECG finding in NSTEMI and how does it correspond to the region of infarcted myocardium?	NSTEMI often presents with ST segment depressions in ECG leads that correspond to the region of infarcted myocardium.
What type of medication, and specifically which NSAID, may be used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	NSAIDs, such as indomethacin, may be used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
In which patients should NSAIDs not be used for treatment of gout?	NSAIDs should not be used for treatment of gout in patients taking anticoagulants.
Which medication's excretion may be reduced by NSAIDs, and what is this medication commonly used for?	NSAIDs may reduce excretion of lithium, which is commonly used as an antipsychotic drug.
In which patients may NSAIDs be contraindicated?	NSAIDs may be contraindicated for patients with renal insufficiency.
What effect do NSAIDs have on the afferent arteriole of the kidney, and how does this affect GFR?	NSAIDs cause vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole of the kidney, which decreases GFR.
What effect can NSAIDs have on blood pressure?	NSAIDs can increase blood pressure.
How can NSAIDs worsen anaphylaxis, and what type of cell activation is involved?	NSAIDs can worsen anaphylaxis by resulting in nonimmunologic mast cell activation.
What adverse effect can NSAIDs cause, specifically in relation to renal function?	NSAIDs can cause renal papillary necrosis as an adverse effect.
What adverse effect can NSAIDs cause in relation to the kidneys, and what is the specific type of nephritis involved?	NSAIDs can cause acute interstitial nephritis as an adverse effect.
Where do NSAIDs tend to accumulate in the kidney?	NSAIDs tend to accumulate at the renal papillae of the kidney.
What is the mechanism by which NRTIs disrupt viral DNA synthesis, and what is the consequence of this disruption?	NRTIs are incorporated into viral DNA, causing premature chain termination, which stops further viral DNA synthesis and replication.
What is the typical timing of neurologic deficits in patients with atlantoaxial instability?	Patients with atlantoaxial instability typically develop neurologic deficits late in the disease.
What is the typical amount of hemoglobin in blood?	The typical amount of hemoglobin in blood is 15 g/dL.
How much oxygen can 1g of hemoglobin bind?	1g of hemoglobin can bind 1.34 mL of oxygen.
What is the process that removes a thrombus after a damaged blood vessel has healed?	The process that removes a thrombus after a damaged blood vessel has healed is called normal fibrinolysis.
What is the polarity orientation of normal tissue layers?	Normal tissue layers have basal to apical polarity.
What is the typical value of serum osmolality in the human body?	The typical value of serum osmolality in the human body is approximately 290 mOsm/kg H2O.
What is the typical population that is affected by normal pressure hydrocephalus?	Normal pressure hydrocephalus typically affects the elderly.
What is the characteristic gait that is often associated with normal pressure hydrocephalus?	The characteristic gait that is often associated with normal pressure hydrocephalus is a magnetic gait.
What are the two possible causes of normal pressure hydrocephalus?	The two possible causes of normal pressure hydrocephalus are obstructive hydrocephalus or decreased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) absorption.
What is normal pressure hydrocephalus, and what are its characteristic features?	Normal pressure hydrocephalus is an idiopathic chronic enlargement of the ventricles that is characterized by normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure.
What type of hydrocephalus is normal pressure hydrocephalus classified as?	Normal pressure hydrocephalus is classified as a form of communicating hydrocephalus.
What is the coagulation status of a normal pregnancy, and how is it described?	A normal pregnancy is associated with a hyper-coagulable state.
What is considered a normal postvoid residual volume in women, and what is the maximum volume that is considered normal?	A normal postvoid residual volume in women is < 150 mL.
In which type of trisomy is it normal to observe typical levels of α-fetoprotein (AFP)?	Normal levels of α-fetoprotein (AFP) are seen in Trisomy 13 (Patau).
What condition can norepinephrine be used to treat?	Norepinephrine may be used to treat hypotension.
What is the enzyme responsible for breaking down norepinephrine, and what is the resulting metabolite?	Norepinephrine may be broken down into normetanephrine via the enzyme catechol-O-methyl transferase.
What effect does norepinephrine have on systolic pressure?	Norepinephrine causes an increase in systolic pressure.
What effect does norepinephrine have on pulse pressure?	Norepinephrine causes an increase in pulse pressure.
What effect does norepinephrine have on diastolic pressure?	Norepinephrine causes an increase in diastolic pressure.
What is the reflex that norepinephrine causes?	Norepinephrine causes reflex bradycardia.

When does Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ) occur during the cell cycle?	Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ) occurs before S phase of the cell cycle.
What is the reason for the symptoms presented by nonfunctional pituitary adenomas?	Nonfunctional pituitary adenomas present with symptoms due to mass effect.
What are the hyper-androgen features that are presented in women with nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia?	Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia presents in women with chronic hyper-androgen features such as acne and hirsutism.
What is the cause of nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia?	Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia is caused by a partial deficiency of 21-hydroxylase.
What type of precocious puberty is nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia considered to be?	Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia is considered to be a form of peripheral precocious puberty.
What is the potential risk associated with the use of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics in the elderly population?	Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics can cause central ataxia, which may lead to an increased risk of falls in the elderly.
How do nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics work to improve sleep?	Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics work by decreasing sleep latency.
What is the reason for the short duration of action of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics?	Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics have a short duration of action due to their rapid metabolism by the liver.
How do nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics exert their effects?	Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics exert their effects by binding to an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor.
What is the primary use of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics?	The primary use of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics is for the treatment of insomnia.
What types of drugs should not be combined with nonbenzodiazepene hypnotics?	Nonbenzodiazepene hypnotics should not be combined with other central nervous system (CNS) depressants.
What is the characteristic feature of hepatocytes in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease?	Hepatocytes in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease are characterized by fatty infiltration with cellular ballooning and eventual necrosis.
What is another name for non-volatile acids?	Non-volatile acids are also known as fixed acids.
What condition is suggested by the presence of a non-tender, distended gallbladder (Courvoisier sign)?	A non-tender, distended gallbladder (Courvoisier sign) is suggestive of a pancreatic head tumor.
How is non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) differentiated from unstable angina?	Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) is differentiated from unstable angina by performing cardiac troponin testing.

What are some non-specific symptoms of stimulant intoxication?	Non-specific symptoms of stimulant intoxication include psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, arrhythmias, and anxiety.
What are some non-specific symptoms of depressant withdrawal (stimulant or depressant)?	Non-specific symptoms of depressant withdrawal (stimulant or depressant) include anxiety, tremor, insomnia, and seizures.
What are some non-specific symptoms of depressant intoxication (stimulant or depressant)?	Non-specific symptoms of depressant intoxication (stimulant or depressant) include anxiolysis, disinhibition, respiratory depression, and mood elevation.

What are the typical levels of AFP and β-HCG in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors?	Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors often present with elevated AFP and elevated β-HCG levels.
How do non-polar and lipid-soluble substances cross the blood-brain barrier rapidly?	Non-polar and lipid-soluble substances cross the blood-brain barrier rapidly via diffusion.
What are some non-pharmacological treatments for venous insufficiency?	Non-pharmacological treatments for venous insufficiency include leg elevation and compression leg stockings.
What are some non-pharmacological treatments for Tourette's syndrome?	Non-pharmacological treatment for Tourette's syndrome includes psychoeducation and behavioral therapy.
What is a non-pharmacologic treatment for fibromyalgia?	Non-pharmacologic treatment for fibromyalgia may include regular exercise.

How do non-dihydropyridine CCBs help in the treatment of angina?	Non-dihydropyridine CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

What are the two main causes of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis?	Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis is broadly caused by two things: 1) RTA 2) Diarrhea (HCO3- loss in gut).

What is the association between non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and peripheral resistance?	Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is associated with peripheral insulin resistance.
How is non-pathological grief distinguished from pathological grief?	Non-pathological grief is distinguished from pathological grief in that any thoughts of dying are limited to joining the deceased.
What is the cause of noise-induced hearing loss?	Noise-induced hearing loss is due to damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti.

What is the morphology of Nocardia?	Nocardia is a gram positive branching filamentous rod.

What is the consequence of Nocardia dissemination to the CNS?	Nocardia dissemination commonly occurs to the CNS, causing brain abscess formation.

What are the symptoms and lung manifestations that can be associated with Nocardia infection?	Nocardia can present with pneumonia-like symptoms and cavitary lesions in the lungs.
What is the effect of NO on guanylyl cyclase and the conversion of GTP to cGMP?	NO upregulates guanylyl cyclase, which converts GTP to cGMP.
What is the source of NO and what is its effect on smooth muscle cells?	NO is produced in endothelial cells, then diffuses into smooth muscle cells leading to relaxation.

What are the suffixes that can be used to recognize Nitrosureas, and how are Nitrosureas classified as chemotherapeutics?	Nitrosureas are chemotherapeutics which can be recognized by the suffixes -mustine and -zotocin.

What is the effect of nitric oxide on cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle cells?	Nitric oxide increases levels of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells.
What effect does nitric oxide have on GI smooth muscle and sphincters, including LES?	Nitric oxide causes relaxation of GI smooth muscle and sphincters, including LES.
What is the effect of nitrates on myocardial oxygen requirements?	Nitrates reduce myocardial oxygen requirements.
In what type of myocardial infarction should nitrates be avoided?	Nitrates should be avoided in right-sided myocardial infarction.

What medication are nitrates often combined with, and for what purpose?	Nitrates are often combined with β-blockers to help prevent reflex sympathetic activation.
In what type of patients are nitrates contraindicated?	Nitrates are contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.
What is the potential consequence of nitrate-induced hypotension?	Nitrate-induced hypotension may cause reflex tachycardia.

What type of medication is Nifedipine?	Nifedipine is a type of medication known as a calcium channel blocker (CCB), specifically a dihydropyridine.

What is a potential symptom of Niemann-Pick disease?	Niemann-Pick disease may present with progressive neurodegeneration.

How does niacin affect serum LDL levels and by what mechanism?	Niacin leads to moderately decreased serum LDL by reducing VLDL synthesis.
What adverse effects can niacin cause on liver function, and what is the severity of the toxicity?	Niacin can cause elevated liver function tests with severe hepato-toxicity.
How does niacin (Vitamin B3) affect serum triglyceride levels and what is the mechanism behind it?	Niacin (Vitamin B3) mildly decreases serum triglycerides by decreasing hepatic VLDL secretion.

What protein does the tumor suppressor gene NF1 encode for?	The tumor suppressor gene NF1 encodes for the protein neurofibromin.
How is the cascade of NF-kB activation self-limiting in the NF-kB activation pathway?	In the NF-kB activation pathway, the cascade of NF-kB activation is self-limiting as NF-kB stimulates the transcription of more IkB.
What is the role of Pattern-Recognition Receptors in the NF-kB activation pathway?	In the NF-kB activation pathway, Pattern-Recognition Receptors recognize PAMPs which leads to the activation of IKB kinase.
What is the role of IkB kinase in the NF-kB activation pathway?	In the NF-kB activation pathway, IkB kinase phosphorylates the IkB-NF-kB complex, leading to the ubiquitination of IkB.
What is the recommended next step when SSRIs are found to be effective but cause sexual dysfunction?	The recommended next step is to wait for a short time and then decrease the dose of the SSRI.

What is a common presentation for newborns with Rh incompatibility?	Newborns with Rh incompatibility typically present with severe anemia at birth.
What are some common symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome in newborns, and what is a potential complication they may develop?	Newborns with neonatal abstinence syndrome may present with high-pitched crying and tremors, and they may potentially develop seizures.
What is a potential issue with the suckling reflex in newborns with neonatal abstinence syndrome?	Newborns with neonatal abstinence syndrome may have an uncoordinated suckling reflex.
What is the usual presentation of newborns with ABO incompatibility at birth?	Newborns with ABO incompatibility are typically asymptomatic at birth or have mild anemia.
What is the typical axis deviation seen in newborns?	Newborns usually have right-axis deviation.

How is new onset enuresis managed before treatment is initiated?	New onset enuresis is managed by ruling out organic causes before treatment is started.
How will new bleeding on subdural bleeding "acute on chronic" appear on non-contrast CT scan?	New bleeding on subdural bleeding "acute on chronic" will appear as hyperdense areas on non-contrast CT.
What is the association between Nevirapine and cytochrome p450 enzymes?	Nevirapine is associated with induction of cytochrome p450 enzymes.
What does the presence of neutrophils filled with staph aureus suggest?	The presence of neutrophils filled with staph aureus is suggestive of CGD.

When does neurulation begin during fetal development?	Neurulation begins in the third week of fetal development.
What are some of the neuropsychiatric symptoms associated with cirrhosis?	Neuropsychiatric symptoms of cirrhosis include hepatic encephalopathy and asterixis ("flapping tremor").
