What medication is commonly used to treat neuropathic pain, such as peripheral neuropathy or postherpetic neuralgia?	Gabapentin is a medication commonly used to treat neuropathic pain, such as peripheral neuropathy or postherpetic neuralgia.
Which area of the brain is responsible for integrating information processed in the primary somatosensory cortex?	The somatosensory association cortex is responsible for integrating information processed in the primary somatosensory cortex.
What area of the brain is responsible for planning motor activities?	The premotor cortex is responsible for planning motor activities.
What area of the brain is responsible for organizing and planning the intellectual and emotional aspects of behavior?	The prefrontal cortex is responsible for organizing and planning the intellectual and emotional aspects of behavior.
Where do neurons of the ventral lateral nucleus (thalamus) synapse with upper motor neurons (UMNs)?	Neurons of the ventral lateral nucleus (thalamus) synapse with UMNs in the motor cortex, specifically the precentral gyrus.
What is the mechanism of neuronal death in Huntington disease?	Neuronal death in Huntington disease occurs via NMDA-R binding and glutamate excitotoxicity.
What is the purpose of using neuromuscular blocking drugs in medical procedures?	Neuromuscular blocking drugs are used to induce muscle paralysis for surgery or mechanical ventilation.
Which type of nicotinic receptors are neuromuscular blocking drugs selective for?	Neuromuscular blocking drugs are selective for NM nicotinic receptors.
What is a potential consequence of neurological disorders such as ALS, Guillain-Barré, polio, MG, and botulism?	Neurological disorders such as ALS, Guillain-Barré, polio, MG, and botulism may cause respiratory acidosis.
What are the neurologic manifestations of Rabies virus, and what are the pathognomonic signs?	The neurologic manifestations of Rabies virus include hydro-phobia and aero-phobia, both of which are pathognomonic signs.
What are the potential treatments for neuroleptic malignant syndrome?	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome may be treated with dantrolene or a D2 agonist.
How is neuroleptic malignant syndrome often characterized in terms of muscle rigidity?	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is often characterized by a generalized "lead-pipe" rigidity.
What are the locations of neurogenic tumors and thymomas within the mediastinum?	Neurogenic tumors are located in the posterior mediastinum, while thymomas are located in the anterior mediastinum.
What type of incontinence is commonly associated with neurogenic bladder?	Neurogenic bladder is commonly associated with overflow incontinence.
What is the function of neurofibromin, which is produced by the NF1 gene?	Neurofibromin, which is produced by the NF1 gene, is a Ras GTPase activating protein (GAP).
What are the clinical manifestations associated with neurofibromatosis type I?	Neurofibromatosis type I is associated with optic glioma and Lisch nodules (pigmented iris hamartomas).
What clinical manifestation is associated with neurofibromatosis type II?	Neurofibromatosis type II is associated with juvenile cataracts.
What is another name for neurofibromatosis type I?	Neurofibromatosis type I is also known as von Recklinghausen disease.
What gene mutation is associated with neurofibromatosis type II and on which chromosome is it located?	Neurofibromatosis type II is associated with mutations in the NF2 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22.
What gene mutation is associated with neurofibromatosis type I and on which chromosome is it located?	Neurofibromatosis type I is associated with mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17.
What are some of the bony abnormalities that can be associated with neurofibromatosis 1?	Neurofibromatosis 1 can present with bony abnormalities; including sphenoid dysplasia, scoliosis, and congenital pseudoarthrosis.
What are some of the symptoms that can be associated with neurocysticercosis due to Taenia solium eggs?	Neurocysticercosis due to Taenia solium eggs can present with seizures and hydrocephalus.
What type of cells do neuroblastomas originate from, and what are these cells precursors to?	Neuroblastoma originates from neural crest cells, which are precursors to the sympathetic chain and adrenal medulla.
From what type of cells does neuroblastoma originate, and where can it occur along the body?	Neuroblastoma originates from neural crest cells and can occur anywhere along the sympathetic chain.
What is the name of the syndrome that neuroblastoma may present with, and what is it sometimes referred to as?	Neuroblastoma may present with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, sometimes referred to as "dancing eyes, dancing feet".
What are the serum markers that characterize neuroblastoma?	The serum markers that characterize neuroblastoma are bombesin and neuron specific enolase.
What is the name of the syndrome that neuroblastoma arising in the cervical paravertebral sympathetic chain can present as isolated?	Neuroblastoma arising in the cervical paravertebral sympathetic chain can present as isolated Horner syndrome.
Which types of influenza are neuraminidase inhibitors used to treat and prevent?	Neuraminidase inhibitors are used to treat and prevent Influenza A and B.
How are neural tube defects detected during prenatal care?	Neural tube defects are detected during prenatal care by elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in the amniotic fluid and maternal blood.
What is Nesiritide and how does it cause sodium loss?	Nesiritide is a BNP analog that causes sodium loss through diuresis.
What is Nesiritide and what is it used for in the treatment of heart failure?	Nesiritide is a synthetic form of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) used in the treatment of acute heart failure.
How does Nesiritide affect arterioles and veins, and what is the resulting effect on afterload and preload?	Nesiritide causes arteriolar and venous dilation, which leads to decreased afterload and preload.
What is the target of the nerves in the somatic nervous system?	The nerves of the somatic nervous system innervate skeletal muscle.
Where do the nerves C1 - C8 exit in relation to their corresponding vertebrae?	The nerves C1 - C8 exit above their corresponding vertebrae.
What are the common symptoms of nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome, and which nerve's distribution do they occur in?	Nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome presents as paresthesia, pain, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve.
What type of volume change occurs with nephrotic syndrome, and is it associated with hypo- or hyper-osmolarity?	Nephrotic syndrome will cause a hypo-osmotic volume expansion.
What is the consequence of hypogammaglobulinemia resulting from nephrotic syndrome, and what is the increased risk associated with it?	Nephrotic syndrome results in hypogammaglobulinemia, which increases the risk of infection.
What is the result of hypoalbuminemia caused by nephrotic syndrome, and what are the two ways in which it manifests?	Nephrotic syndrome results in hypoalbuminemia, which manifests as pitting edema and secondary hyperaldosteronism.
What is the consequence of hypoalbuminemia resulting from nephrotic syndrome, and what is the way in which it manifests?	Nephrotic syndrome results in hypoalbuminemia, which manifests as pitting edema.
What is the cause of nephrotic syndrome, and how does it disrupt the glomerular filtration barrier?	Nephrotic syndrome occurs due to podocyte damage disrupting the glomerular filtration charge barrier.
What is the potential consequence of nephrotic syndrome, and what is the term used to describe this state?	Nephrotic syndrome may result in a hyper-coagulable state.
What is a potential cause of nephrotic syndrome, and how does it relate to the term "systemic amyloidosis"?	Nephrotic syndrome may be caused by systemic amyloidosis.
What are the two most common imaging modalities used to diagnose nephrolithiasis?	The two most common imaging modalities used to diagnose nephrolithiasis are non-contrast CT scan and ultrasound.
What type of diet may be recommended for patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus as a treatment option?	A low-salt, low-protein diet may be recommended for patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus as a treatment option.
What are some of the medications that may be used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	Some of the medications that may be used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus include thiazides, NSAIDs, and amiloride.
What are some possible causes of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	Some possible causes of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus include hypercalcemia or hypokalemia.
What type of diuretics are commonly used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	Thiazide diuretics are commonly used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
What are the typical levels of ADH seen in patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?	Patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus typically have normal or elevated levels of ADH.
During what period of gestation does nephrogenesis occur?	Nephrogenesis occurs during the period of 32 to 36 weeks of gestation.
What is the cause of nephritic syndrome?	Nephritic syndrome is caused by disruption of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
What are the common urinary findings associated with nephritic syndrome?	Nephritic syndrome is commonly associated with hematuria and the presence of RBC casts in the urine.
What is the mechanism underlying the development of nephritic syndrome?	Nephritic syndrome typically develops due to immune-complex deposition, which activates complement (e.g. C5a).
What is the typical level of proteinuria seen in patients with nephritic syndrome?	Patients with nephritic syndrome typically have limited proteinuria, with levels < 3.5 g/day.
What are the clinical manifestations associated with nephritic syndrome?	Nephritic syndrome is associated with salt retention, which can lead to periorbital edema and hypertension.
What is the typical laboratory finding seen in patients with nephritic syndrome?	Patients with nephritic syndrome typically have increased levels of BUN and creatinine.
What are the main pathological features of nephritic syndrome?	Nephritic syndrome is a group of glomerular disorders characterized by glomerular inflammation and bleeding.
What is the potential complication of neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy?	Neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy may cause secondary closed-angle glaucoma.
What are the two types of neoplasia?	Neoplasia can either be benign or malignant (malignancy).
What treatment is given to neonates at risk for HBV infection at birth?	Neonates at risk for HBV infection at birth are given anti-HBV immunoglobulins.
What is the possible diagnosis for a neonate who has an NG tube that is coiling in the esophagus?	The possible diagnosis for a neonate who has an NG tube that is coiling in the esophagus is TE fistula.
What is the possible diagnosis for a neonate who required positive pressure ventilation and is now presenting with tachypnea?	The possible diagnosis for a neonate who required positive pressure ventilation and is now presenting with tachypnea is Pneumothorax.
What are the possible treatments for neonatal sepsis?	The possible treatments for neonatal sepsis are ampicillin/gentamicin or cefotaxime +/- vancomycin.
What is the association of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome?	Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with premature birth.
What is the association of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome with maternal diabetes?	Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with maternal diabetes due to increased levels of fetal insulin.
What is the association of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome with C-section delivery?	Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with C-section delivery due to decreased stress-induced release of fetal glucocorticoids.
What type of lung disease is caused by neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease)?	Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease) is a cause of interstitial restrictive lung disease.
What is the cause of respiratory distress in neonatal polycythemia?	Respiratory distress in neonatal polycythemia is caused by increased blood viscosity.
What is a potential complication of neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage?	A potential complication of neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage is communicating hydrocephalus.
What is a potential consequence of neonatal hyperinsulinism in uncontrolled gestational diabetes?	A potential consequence of neonatal hyperinsulinism in uncontrolled gestational diabetes is macrosomia.
In which lobe of the brain can neonatal herpes simplex virus cause hemorrhage and edema?	Neonatal herpes simplex virus can cause hemorrhage and edema in the temporal lobe.
Do neonatal clavicular fractures typically heal quickly?	Yes, neonatal clavicular fractures usually heal rapidly.
What is a significant benefit of neonatal circumcision in the first year of life?	Neonatal circumcision significantly decreases the risk of urinary tract infections in the first year of life.
What type of penile inflammatory disorders can be reduced by neonatal circumcision?	Neonatal circumcision reduces the risk of penile inflammatory disorders, such as balanitis.
Which sexually transmitted infections can be reduced by neonatal circumcision?	Neonatal circumcision reduces the risk of acquiring some sexually transmitted infections, such as HPV and HIV.
What are the potential benefits of neonatal circumcision in terms of preventing penile conditions?	Neonatal circumcision prevents pathologic phimosis and moderately reduces the risk of penile cancer.
What are some common symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome?	Neonatal abstinence syndrome presents with diarrhea, sweating, irritability, and tachypnea.
What is the cause of neonatal abstinence syndrome?	Neonatal abstinence syndrome occurs due to exposure to opiate drugs while in the mother's womb.
In what medical context is neomycin, an aminoglycoside, used and what is its purpose?	Neomycin is an aminoglycoside used in bowel prep before colorectal surgery.
What are the different ways in which neomycin, an aminoglycoside, can be administered and for what purpose?	Neomycin is an aminoglycoside applied topically or ingested as an ammonium detoxicant.
What are the symptoms associated with Nelson syndrome, which is characterized by both mass effect and elevated ACTH?	Nelson syndrome presents with symptoms of both mass effect and elevated ACTH, including hyperpigmentation, headaches, and bitemporal hemianopsia.
What is the mode of transmission for Neisseria meningitidis, and what types of secretions are involved?	Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted via respiratory and oral secretions.
Which species of Neisseria does not have a polysaccharide capsule?	Neisseria gonorrhoeae does not have a polysaccharide capsule.
What is the component of Neisseria spp. that possesses strong endotoxin activity?	Neisseria spp. contains lipooligosaccharides (LOS) with strong endotoxin activity.
What is the Gram stain classification of Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae?	Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are gram negative diplococci.
Which part of the body does Neisseria meningitidis colonize first?	Neisseria meningitidis colonizes the nasopharynx first.
What are the types of agar that can be used to grow Neisseria?	Neisseria can be grown on chocolate agar and Thayer-Martin media.
In which types of cells can Negri bodies of Rabies virus be found?	Negri bodies of Rabies virus can be found in the cytoplasm of hippocampal pyramidal cells and cerebellar Purkinje cells.
In addition to the hippocampal pyramidal cells, where else can Negri bodies of Rabies virus be found?	Negri bodies of Rabies virus can be found in the cytoplasm of cerebellar Purkinje cells.
Where are Negri bodies of Rabies virus found?	Negri bodies of Rabies virus are found within the cytoplasm.
What do negative sense RNA viruses produce in order to transcribe into positive sense RNA?	Negative sense RNA viruses produce their own RNA polymerase to transcribe into positive sense RNA.
What does a negative LR of less than 0.1 indicate in terms of a diagnostic test?	A negative LR of less than 0.1 indicates that a diagnostic test is very useful.
What is the usual microbial nature of necrotizing surgical site infections?	Necrotizing surgical site infections are usually polymicrobial.
What is the presentation of necrotizing fasciitis due to the production of methane and CO2?	Necrotizing fasciitis presents with crepitus due to production of methane and CO2.
What are the common causes of necrotizing fasciitis and what are the usual treatments?	Necrotizing fasciitis is commonly caused by Strep pyogenes or Clostridium perfringens and treated with surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
What are the clinical manifestations of necrotizing fasciitis?	Necrotizing fasciitis causes bullae formation, purple skin discoloration, and pain out of proportion to exam findings.
What is the management approach for necrotizing enterocolitis with peritoneal signs?	Necrotizing enterocolitis with peritoneal signs is managed with surgery.
What condition is characterized by necrotizing dilation and destruction of bronchi?	Bronchiectasis is characterized by necrotizing dilation and destruction of bronchi.
What is the muscarinic antagonist that may be used for nebulized treatment of acute, severe asthma exacerbation?	Nebulized ipratropium is a muscarinic antagonist that may be used to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation.
What is the immediate treatment of choice for moderate-to-severe croup?	Nebulized glucocorticoids are the immediate treatment of choice for moderate-to-severe croup.
What type of receptors are blocked and stimulated by Nebivolol?	Nebivolol blocks 1 receptors and stimulates 3 receptors.
What condition is suggested by the presence of nausea/vomiting, headache, and focal neuro deficits following otitis media?	The presence of nausea/vomiting, headache, and focal neuro deficits following otitis media is suggestive of brain abscess.
What condition may present with nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea due to submucosal swelling in the GI tract?	Hereditary angioedema may present with nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea due to submucosal swelling in the GI tract.
Which common withdrawal syndrome is characterized by symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and muscle aches?	Opioid withdrawal is characterized by symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and muscle aches.
What type of immunization is natural infection an example of?	Natural infection is an example of active immunization.
What is Natalizumab, and what conditions is it used to treat?	Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets α4-integrin and is used to treat Multiple Sclerosis and Crohn's disease.
What is the high-risk side effect associated with Natalizumab and Rituximab?	Natalizumab and Rituximab have a high risk of causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (JC virus).
What is a common presentation of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?	Nasopharyngeal carcinoma often presents with involvement of cervical lymph nodes.
What population is nasopharyngeal carcinoma classically seen in?	Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classically seen in Chinese adults.
What are the common symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma and where does it commonly spread?	Nasopharyngeal carcinoma causes nasal congestion with epistaxis, headaches, and spread to the cervical lymph nodes.
What is a common presentation of nasopharyngeal angiofibromas?	Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas often present with profuse epistaxis.
What is the association between nasogastric tube feeding and the risk for aspiration pneumonia?	Nasogastric tube feeding is associated with an increased risk for aspiration pneumonia.
What are the organs that secrete nascent HDL?	Nascent HDL is secreted by the liver and intestine.
What is the usual cause of nasal polyps?	Nasal polyps are usually secondary to repeated bouts of rhinitis.
What condition are nasal polyps associated with in children?	Nasal polyps are associated with cystic fibrosis in children.
What condition are nasal polyps associated with in adults?	Nasal polyps are associated with aspirin-induced asthma in adults.
What produces the "steeple sign" on CXR in croup (parainfluenza virus)?	Narrowing of the trachea and subglottic region produces the "steeple sign" on CXR in croup (parainfluenza virus).
What type of sleep do nocturnal and narcoleptic sleep episodes start with in narcolepsy?	Nocturnal and narcoleptic sleep episodes in narcolepsy start with REM sleep (sleep paralysis).
What causes narcolepsy?	Narcolepsy is caused by decreased hypocretin (orexin) production in the lateral hypothalamus.
What symptom is associated with narcolepsy, including hypnagogic and hypnopompic types?	Narcolepsy is associated with hallucinations, including hypnagogic and hypnopompic types.
What are two examples of catalase-positive organisms that are not included in SketchyMicro?	Two examples of catalase-positive organisms that are not included in SketchyMicro are Burkholderia cepacia and Serratia marcescens.
What is the potential benefit of using naltrexone, a μ-opioid antagonist?	Naltrexone, a μ-opioid antagonist, can potentially help with weight loss.
Where do naive B-cells migrate to?	Naive B-cells migrate to secondary lymphoid organs.
What condition is specifically associated with nail clubbing (thyroid acropachy) in the setting of hyperthyroidism?	Nail clubbing (thyroid acropachy) in the setting of hyperthyroidism is specifically associated with Graves disease.
What is the prognosis of Naegleria fowleri infection?	Naegleria fowleri infection has a poor prognosis.
What condition can result from Naegleria fowleri infection?	Naegleria fowleri infection can result in primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.
In what types of processes is NADPH generally used as an electron carrier?	NADPH is generally used as an electron carrier in anabolic processes.
What are the two shuttles that NADH electrons from glycolysis can enter the mitochondria through?	NADH electrons from glycolysis can enter the mitochondria via the malate-aspartate or glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle.
In what types of processes is NAD+ generally used as an electron carrier?	NAD+ is generally used as an electron carrier in catabolic processes.
What is the effect of Na+-glucose and Na+-amino acid cotransport on the potential difference across cells of the early PCT?	Na+-glucose and Na+-amino acid cotransport create a lumen negative potential difference across cells of the early PCT.
What type of channels are responsible for the reabsorption of Na+ on the luminal membrane of the collecting duct?	Na+ is reabsorbed on the luminal membrane of the collecting duct through epithelial Na+ channels.
In which part of the nephron and through which cotransporter in the luminal membrane is Na+ reabsorbed?	Na+ is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (of Henle) via the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter in the luminal membrane.
In which part of the nephron and through which cotransporter in the luminal membrane is Na+ reabsorbed?	Na+ is reabsorbed in the early DCT via the Na+-Cl- cotransporter in the luminal membrane.
In rapidly depolarizing tissue such as tachycardia, do Na+ channels spend more time in open or inactivated states?	Na+ channels in rapidly depolarizing tissue (e.g. tachycardia) spend the most time in open or inactivated states.
How do Na+ and K+ ions cross the blood-brain barrier?	Na+ and K+ ions cross the blood-brain barrier via ion channels.
What type of gas exchange does N2O exhibit?	N2O exhibits perfusion-limited gas exchange.
What is a potential cause of bilateral adrenal hemorrhage?	N. meningitidis, sepsis, and septic shock are potential causes of bilateral adrenal hemorrhage.
In the setting of acetaminophen toxicity, what does N-acetylcysteine help restore?	N-acetylcysteine helps restore reduced glutathione stores in the setting of acetaminophen toxicity.
What type of anomalies are associated with Müllerian agenesis?	Müllerian agenesis is associated with renal anomalies.
What are causes of primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sex characteristics?	Müllerian agenesis and imperforate hymen are causes of primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sex characteristics.
What are the symptoms of Ménétrier disease?	Ménétrier disease presents with epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss, vomiting, and edema (due to protein loss).
What is the characteristic feature of Ménétrier disease?	Ménétrier disease is characterized by parietal cell atrophy with decreased acid production.
What are the histological features of Ménétrier disease?	Ménétrier disease is characterized by hyperplasia of the gastric mucosa and atrophy of the parietal/chief cells.
What is the pathophysiological mechanism of edema in Ménétrier disease?	Ménétrier disease is characterized by excess mucus production with resultant protein loss, leading to edema.
What is the consequence of excess mucus production in Ménétrier disease?	Ménétrier disease is characterized by excess mucus production with resultant protein loss, leading to edema.
What are the three common symptoms that present as a triad in Ménière disease?	Ménière disease typically presents with a triad of tinnitus, episodic vertigo, and sensorineural hearing loss.
What is the proposed underlying cause of Ménière disease?	Ménière disease is thought to be due to defective resorption of endolymph.
What type of sensorineural hearing loss is associated with Ménière disease?	Ménière disease is associated with low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
What are the common clinical manifestations of Myotonic Dystrophy that are attributed to weakness of ankle dorsiflexors?	Myotonic Dystrophy commonly presents with abnormal gait and foot drop that are attributed to weakness of ankle dorsiflexors.
What is the cause of Myotonic dystrophy and what enzyme is involved in its pathogenesis?	Myotonic dystrophy is caused by abnormal expression of the myotonin protein kinase enzyme.
What is the specific protein that is abnormally expressed in Myotonic Dystrophy?	Myotonic Dystrophy involves an abnormal expression of the myotonin protein kinase.
What are the diagnostic tests used to confirm Myotonic Dystrophy?	Myotonic Dystrophy is confirmed using electromyography (EMG) and genetic studies.
What is the inheritance pattern of Myotonic Dystrophy?	Myotonic Dystrophy follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
What type of lenses are used to correct Myopia?	Myopia is corrected with biconcave (diverging) lenses.
What condition is suggested by the presence of myoglobinuria and hemoglobinuria?	The presence of myoglobinuria and hemoglobinuria is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis.
What type of infiltrate is found in the myocardium in cases of Myocarditis that are secondary to coxsackie B infection?	Myocarditis, secondary to coxsackie B infection, is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate in the myocardium.
In which age group is Myocarditis a major cause of sudden cardiac death in adults?	Myocarditis is a major cause of sudden cardiac death in adults under 40 years old.
What can Myocarditis precipitate in the heart?	Myocarditis can precipitate a mural thrombus in the heart.
Which artery is most commonly involved in myocardial infarction?	Myocardial infarction most commonly involves the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, accounting for 45% of cases.
What is a potential symptom of myocardial infarction that may be caused by pulmonary congestion and edema?	Myocardial infarction may present with dyspnea, or difficulty breathing, due to pulmonary congestion and edema.
What are the potential consequences of acute left ventricular failure induced by myocardial infarction?	Acute left ventricular failure induced by myocardial infarction can result in rapid onset pulmonary venous hypertension and acute pulmonary edema.
In which coronary artery occlusion may JVD be a potential symptom of myocardial infarction?	Myocardial infarction due to occlusion of the right coronary artery may present with JVD (jugular venous distension).
What is the relationship between diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction, and what is the underlying cause of this relationship?	Myocardial infarction and thrombus formation is a complication of diabetes mellitus due to chronic hyperglycemia.
What are the potential cardiac symptoms associated with myocardial infarction due to occlusion of a specific coronary artery?	Myocardial infarction with occlusion of the right coronary artery may present with bradycardia and/or heart block.
What medical tests should be used to monitor myocardial contusion and assess for potential arrhythmias and cardiac function?	Myocardial contusion should be monitored with ECG and cardiac enzymes to screen for arrhythmias and cardiac function.
What drug can be used to reverse myelosuppression caused by Methotrexate overdose or induced by Methotrexate therapy?	Myelosuppression induced by Methotrexate overdose or therapy can be reversed using the drug Leucovorin.
What is the treatment for myelosuppression caused by methotrexate?	Myelosuppression due to methotrexate is reversible with leucovorin.
At what age do myeloproliferative disorders most commonly present?	Myeloproliferative disorders most commonly present in late adulthood, typically between the ages of 50 and 60 years old.
What are the potential complications of myeloproliferative disorders?	Myeloproliferative disorders may progress to marrow fibrosis or transform to acute leukemia.
What are some potential complications of myeloproliferative disorders related to high cell turnover?	Myeloproliferative disorders may cause hyperuricemia and gout due to high turnover of cells.
What type of primary immunodeficiency is myeloperoxidase deficiency (MPO)?	Myeloperoxidase deficiency (MPO) is an autosomal recessive primary immunodeficiency.
What is the differentiation pathway of myeloid stem cells into granulocytes?	Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into myeloblasts, which mature into granulocytes.
What is the differentiation pathway of myeloid stem cells into monocytes?	Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into monoblasts, which mature into monocytes.
What is the differentiation pathway of myeloid stem cells into megakaryocytes?	Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into megakaryoblasts, which mature into megakaryocytes.
What is the differentiation pathway of myeloid stem cells into red blood cells (RBCs)?	Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into erythroblasts, which mature into RBCs.
What is often associated with massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis?	Myelofibrosis is often associated with massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
What is the typical percentage of increased blasts seen in Myelodysplastic syndromes?	Myelodysplastic syndromes usually present with increased blasts < 20%.
What is the typical presentation of leukocytes and platelets in Myelodysplastic syndromes?	Myelodysplastic syndromes may present with variable leukocytes and platelets.
What is the typical result of Myelodysplastic syndromes on the bone marrow, and how does it relate to pancytopenia?	Myelodysplastic syndromes result in a normal hypercellular bone marrow, despite pancytopenia.
What is the potential progression of Myelodysplastic syndromes, and how often does it occur?	Myelodysplastic syndromes rarely may progress to acute myeloid leukemia.
What are the potential causes of Myelodysplastic syndromes?	Myelodysplastic syndromes are caused by de novo mutations or environmental exposure (e.g. radiation, benzene, chemotherapy).
Who is primarily affected by Myelodysplastic syndrome, and what is a common factor among those affected?	Myelodysplastic syndrome is primarily seen in older adults and those who have had previous chemo- or radiation therapy.
What are the common blood disorders associated with Myelodysplastic syndrome?	Myelodysplastic syndrome is associated with macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia.
What are Auer rods, and what type of cells may have crystal aggregates of MPO that form them?	Myeloblasts may have crystal aggregates of MPO, which are seen on blood smear as Auer rods.
What is the function of myelin in relation to axons, and how does it affect the space (length) constant?	Myelin wraps and insulates axons, thus increasing the space (length) constant.
How does myelin wrapping and insulating axons affect the time constant?	Myelin wraps and insulates axons, thus decreasing the time constant.
What is the typical presentation of mycosis fungoides in adults?	Mycosis fungoides typically presents in adults with skin patches/plaques.
What type of symptoms are typically seen in adults with mycosis fungoides?	Mycosis fungoides typically presents in adults with dermatological symptoms.
What is the name of the syndrome that may develop when mycosis fungoides spreads to involve the blood?	Mycosis fungoides may spread to involve the blood, producing Sézary syndrome (T-cell leukemia).
What type of cells are involved in the neoplastic proliferation seen in mycosis fungoides?	Mycosis fungoides is a neoplastic proliferation of mature CD4+ T cells.
What is the specific requirement for growth of Mycoplasma pneumonia and in which agar is it present?	Mycoplasma pneumonia requires cholesterol to grow, which is present in Eaton's Agar.
What is the mechanism of action of mycophenolate mofetil?	Mycophenolate mofetil works by inhibiting the proliferation of lymphocytes.
What is the effect of mycophenolate mofetil on cellular levels of IMP?	Mycophenolate mofetil will increase cellular levels of IMP.
What is the association between mycophenolate mofetil use and blood pressure?	Mycophenolate mofetil use is associated with hypertension.
What is the association between mycophenolate mofetil use and blood glucose levels?	Mycophenolate mofetil use is associated with hyperglycemia.
What is the potential risk associated with mycophenolate mofetil use due to its immunosuppressive effects?	Mycophenolate mofetil use can result in increased risk for infection due to immunosuppression.
What is the prophylactic use of mycophenolate mofetil?	Mycophenolate mofetil is used prophylactically to reduce transplant rejection.
What is the association between mycophenolate mofetil use and blood sugar levels?	Mycophenolate mofetil is associated with hyperglycemia.
What type of invasive infections are associated with mycophenolate mofetil use?	Mycophenolate mofetil is associated with invasive CMV infections.
What type of cell proliferation is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil?	Mycophenolate mofetil is a powerful inhibitor of lymphocyte (B and T cell) proliferation.
What type of suppression can result from mycophenolate mofetil use?	Mycophenolate mofetil can result in myelo-suppression (-cytopenias).
What hematological side effect can result from mycophenolate mofetil use?	Mycophenolate mofetil can result in the hematological side effect of myelosuppression.
What medical condition can be treated with mycophenolate mofetil?	Mycophenolate mofetil can be used to treat Rheumatoid Arthritis.
What type of gastrointestinal symptom can be caused by mycophenolate mofetil?	Mycophenolate mofetil can affect the GI tract, leading to diarrhea.
What is Mycobacterium avium complex, and in what late-stage disease does it commonly cause disseminated infection?	Mycobacterium avium complex is a non-TB disease that causes disseminated infection in the late stages of AIDS.
What type of bacteria is Mycobacterium leprae?	Mycobacterium leprae is an obligate intracellular bacteria.
What is the treatment for Mycobacterium avium complex, and what drugs are typically used in combination?	Mycobacterium avium complex is treated with azithromycin/clarithromycin (a macrolide) combined with ethambutol.
What are the two species that are included in Mycobacterium avium complex?	Mycobacterium avium complex includes Mycobacterium avium and Mycobacterium intracellulare.
What is the optimal temperature for the growth of Mycobacterium avium complex?	Mycobacterium avium complex grows best at 41°C.
Which species of mycobacteria causes cervical lymphadenitis in children?	Mycobacteria scrofulaceum causes cervical lymphadenitis in children.
Which species of mycobacteria causes a hand infection in aquarium handlers?	Mycobacteria marinum causes a hand infection in aquarium handlers.
In which type of cells does Mycobacteria tuberculosis primarily reside and proliferate?	Mycobacteria tuberculosis primarily resides and proliferates in macrophages.
How would you describe the growth rate of Mycobacteria tuberculosis and how long does it take to grow in culture?	Mycobacteria tuberculosis grows slowly and requires 2-6 weeks to grow in culture.
On which agar does Mycobacteria tuberculosis grow?	Mycobacteria tuberculosis grows on the Löwenstein Jensen agar.
In which animals does Mycobacteria leprae grow extensively and why?	Mycobacteria leprae grows extensively in armadillos, which have a cooler core body temperature.
What are the two types of leprosy that can be caused by Mycobacteria leprae?	Mycobacteria leprae can cause tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy.
What are the common treatments for managing Myasthenic crisis and what is the usual approach to combining them?	Myasthenic crisis is managed with plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulins, usually in combination with corticosteroids.
What is the typical presentation of muscle weakness in Myasthenia gravis and how does it change with muscle use?	Myasthenia gravis presents with muscle weakness that worsens with muscle use.
What is progressive bulbar palsy and how is it characterized in individuals with Myasthenia gravis?	Myasthenia gravis may present with progressive bulbar palsy, which is characterized by dysarthria, dysphagia, and difficulty chewing.
What is the association between Myasthenia gravis and HLA, and which specific HLA allele is commonly associated with the condition?	Myasthenia gravis is associated with HLA, and the specific HLA allele commonly associated with the condition is HLA B8.
What is the age distribution of Myasthenia Gravis, and at which two ages does the condition have a bimodal distribution?	Myasthenia Gravis has a bimodal age distribution at around 20 years old and around 60 years old.
What are the common ocular symptoms associated with Myasthenia gravis?	Myasthenia gravis classically involves the eyes, leading to ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) and diplopia (double vision).
What is the most common inheritance pattern associated with mutations that cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?	Mutations that cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy most commonly have an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
What specific genetic mutations can lead to the development of hereditary elliptocytosis?	Mutations in spectrin can cause hereditary elliptocytosis.
What specific genetic mutations can cause appendages to be placed in incorrect locations?	Mutations in hox genes can cause appendages to be placed in wrong locations during development.
Which tumor suppressor protein is commonly associated with the development of Neurofibromatosis I when mutations occur?	Neurofibromin is the tumor suppressor protein that is commonly associated with the development of Neurofibromatosis I when mutations occur.
What are the specific tumor suppressor genes that are commonly associated with the development of Wilms Tumors when mutations occur?	Mutations in WT1 and CDKN1C (WT2) tumor suppressor genes are commonly associated with the development of Wilms Tumors.
Which specific tumor suppressor genes are commonly associated with the development of Tuberous Sclerosis when mutations occur?	Mutations in TSC1 and TSC2 tumor suppressor genes are commonly associated with the development of Tuberous Sclerosis.
Which specific tumor suppressor genes are commonly associated with the development of Breast, Ovarian, and Pancreatic cancers when mutations occur?	Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 tumor suppressor genes are commonly associated with the development of Breast, Ovarian, and Pancreatic cancers.
What is the specific proto-oncogene that is commonly associated with the development of Chronic Myeloproliferative Disorders when mutations occur?	Mutations in the JAK2 (Janus Kinase 2) proto-oncogene are commonly associated with the development of Chronic Myeloproliferative Disorders.
What is the specific bacterial enzyme that, when mutated, can result in resistance to Rifampin?	Mutations in the DNA-dependent RNA polymerase bacterial enzyme can result in resistance to Rifampin.
Which gene is responsible for enabling HIV to escape from host neutralizing antibodies when mutations occur?	The env gene is responsible for enabling HIV to escape from host neutralizing antibodies when mutations occur.
What is the specific proto-oncogene that is overactivated when mutations occur in the PTEN gene?	The mTOR (Mechanistic Target of Rapamycin) proto-oncogene is overactivated when mutations occur in the PTEN gene.
How do mutations in the CDK4 gene contribute to the development of Melanoma?	Mutations in the CDK4 gene can cause Melanoma due to a resultant amplification of the protein's activity.
How do mutations in the CCND1 gene contribute to the development of Mantle Cell Lymphoma?	Mutations in the CCND1 gene can cause Mantle Cell Lymphoma via a t(11;14) translocation to the Ig Heavy Chain locus.
How do mutations in the c-Myc gene contribute to the development of Burkitt Lymphoma?	Mutations in the c-Myc gene can cause Burkitt Lymphoma via a t(8;14) translocation to the Ig Heavy Chain locus.
What is the effect of mutation of the frataxin gene in Friedreich ataxia?	Mutation of the frataxin gene in Friedreich ataxia leads to impairment of mitochondrial function.
What is the potential consequence of a mutation in the sonic hedgehog gene?	A mutation in the sonic hedgehog gene can cause holoprosencephaly.
What is the effect of mutant α1-antitrypsin on hepatocytes?	Mutant α1-antitrypsin polymerizes and accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage (e.g. cirrhosis).
What is the mechanism by which mutant huntingtin protein in Huntington's Disease leads to transcriptional repression?	Mutant huntingtin protein in Huntington's Disease leads to transcriptional repression by inhibiting histone acetyltransferase.
What are the symptoms associated with musty/mousy body odor, mental retardation, and fair complexion?	Musty/mousy body odor and mental retardation and fair complexion are symptoms associated with PKU.
Which nerve innervates the muscles of the thenar eminence?	The muscles of the thenar eminence are innervated by the median nerve.
Which nerve innervates the muscles of the hypothenar eminence?	The muscles of the hypothenar eminence are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
What are the three muscles of the thenar eminence?	The three muscles of the thenar eminence are the opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, and flexor pollicis brevis.
What are the three muscles of the hypothenar eminence?	The three muscles of the hypothenar eminence are the opponens digiti minimi, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digiti minimi brevis.
Which muscles are lost in thoracic outlet syndrome?	The muscles lost in thoracic outlet syndrome include the intrinsic hand muscles, specifically the lumbricals, interossei, thenar, and hypothenar muscles.
Which muscles are lost in Klumpke palsy?	The muscles lost in Klumpke palsy include the intrinsic hand muscles, specifically the lumbricals, interossei, hypothenar, and thenar muscles.
Which muscles are lost in Erb palsy?	The muscles lost in Erb palsy include the deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and biceps brachii muscles.
What is the cause of muscle tingling or numbness and tetany (spasms)?	Muscle tingling or numbness and tetany (spasms) are caused by hypocalcemia.
What does a muscle strength evaluation of 4/5 indicate?	A muscle strength evaluation of 4/5 indicates some movement against resistance.
What does a muscle strength evaluation of 3/5 indicate?	A muscle strength evaluation of 3/5 indicates movement against gravity, but not resistance.
What does a muscle strength evaluation of 2/5 indicate?	A muscle strength evaluation of 2/5 indicates movement, but not against gravity.
What does a muscle strength evaluation of 1/5 indicate?	A muscle strength evaluation of 1/5 indicates muscle flicker, but no movement.
What clinical manifestations are associated with growth hormone deficiency in adults?	Muscle loss, truncal obesity, and osteoporosis are clinical manifestations of growth hormone deficiency in adults.
What is a potential symptom that muscle disorders may present with?	Muscle disorders may present with respiratory acidosis.
Why can't muscle participate in gluconeogenesis?	Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis because it lacks the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.
What would be observed in a muscle biopsy of a patient with primary carnitine deficiency?	Muscle biopsy of a patient with primary carnitine deficiency shows elevated triglycerides.
What is a common finding in muscle biopsies of patients with mitochondrial myopathies?	Muscle biopsies of patients with mitochondrial myopathies often show "ragged red" fibers.
What effect do muscarinic antagonists have on the bronchi?	Muscarinic antagonists cause bronchodilation.
How does mupirocin work as a topical antibiotic?	Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic that works by inhibiting isoleucine t-RNA synthetase.
What is the clinical presentation of multiple sclerosis?	Multiple white matter lesions separated by time and space is characteristic of multiple sclerosis.
What clinical findings are suggestive of acute traumatic coagulopathy?	Multiple traumatic injuries, persistent oozing from wounds, and elevated PT, PTT, and bleeding time are suggestive of acute traumatic coagulopathy.
What environmental factor can worsen symptoms in patients with multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis symptoms are often worsened upon exposure to heat.
What type of dysfunction may be present in patients with multiple sclerosis due to involvement of the ANS?	Multiple sclerosis may present with bowel and bladder dysfunction due to involvement of the ANS.
What symptoms may be present in patients with multiple sclerosis due to involvement of the brainstem?	Multiple sclerosis may present with vertigo and scanning speech (mimics alcohol intoxication) due to involvement of the brainstem.
What condition may multiple sclerosis cause that results in sudden loss of vision and Marcus Gunn pupils?	Multiple sclerosis may cause optic neuritis, resulting in sudden loss of vision and Marcus Gunn pupils.
What are the diagnostic tests that can be used to diagnose multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis may be diagnosed with either MRI and/or lumbar puncture.
In what regions is multiple sclerosis more commonly seen in caucasians?	Multiple sclerosis is more commonly seen in caucasians in regions away from the equator.
What is the histological characteristic of multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is characterized histologically by perivenular inflammatory infiltrates.
What is the characteristic level of lymphocytes in the CSF in patients with multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of lymphocytes in the CSF.
What is the characteristic protein that is increased in the CSF in patients with multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of myelin basic protein in the CSF.
What is the characteristic type of immunoglobulin that is increased in the CSF in patients with multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of IgG in the CSF.
Which HLA type is associated with multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is associated with HLA DR2.
What is the pathophysiology of multiple sclerosis?	Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune destruction of CNS myelin and oligodendrocytes.
What is the imaging modality commonly used to diagnose multiple sclerosis?	MRI is commonly used to diagnose multiple sclerosis.
What are the typical clinical features of multiple myeloma?	Multiple myeloma typically presents with lytic (punched-out) bone lesions and hypercalcemia.
What is the potential consequence of multiple myeloma depositing in tissue?	Multiple myeloma may deposit in tissue, causing primary (AL) amyloidosis.
What is the association between multiple myeloma and the appearance of red blood cells on a blood smear?	Multiple myeloma is associated with the formation of Rouleaux of red blood cells on a blood smear.
What is the association between multiple myeloma and the results of serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP)?	Multiple myeloma is associated with the presence of M spike on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP).
What is the association between multiple myeloma and the level of serum protein?	Multiple myeloma is associated with elevated serum protein.
What is the typical presentation of multiple endocrine neoplasia in terms of the number and location of tumors?	Multiple endocrine neoplasia presents with multiple tumors, which can sometimes be bilateral.
How does the duration of the first and second stages of labor differ between multiparous and nulliparous patients?	Multiparous patients should experience faster first and second stages of labor compared to nulliparous patients.
How many different P-wave morphologies are required to diagnose multifocal atrial tachycardia?	At least three different P-wave morphologies are required to diagnose multifocal atrial tachycardia.
What is the management strategy for multifocal atrial tachycardia?	Multifocal atrial tachycardia is managed by treating the underlying cause.
How is multicystic dysplastic kidney often diagnosed before birth?	Multicystic dysplastic kidney is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound.
What type of glands secrete mucus into the GI tract in the duodenum specifically?	Mucus is secreted into the GI tract via Brunner glands in the duodenum.
What is the characteristic symptom of Paracoccidioidomycosis and where does it occur in the body?	Mucosal ulcers in the upper respiratory tract and mouth is characteristic of Paracoccidioidomycosis.
What is the name of the syndrome that is characterized by the presence of mucosal neuromas and marfanoid body habitus?	The syndrome that is characterized by the presence of mucosal neuromas and marfanoid body habitus is called MEN 2B.
What are some of the components of mucosal defenses?	Mucosal defenses include the secretion of mucus, HCO3-, prostaglandins, and maintaining a normal blood supply.
What is the role of normal blood supply in mucosal defenses?	Normal blood supply is important in mucosal defenses as it provides nutrients and helps to pick up leaked acids.
What type of epithelium lines the mucosa of the vagina?	The mucosa of the vagina is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
In what manner does mucormycosis enter the brain?	Mucormycosis enters the brain by penetrating the cribriform plate of the skull.
What is a potential area of involvement for Mucoepidermoid carcinoma in the parotid gland?	Mucoepidermoid carcinoma in the parotid gland can potentially involve CN7.
What fungal infection should be suspected if a patient presents with mucocutaneous lesions and lymphadenopathy?	Paracoccidioidomycosis should be suspected if a patient presents with mucocutaneous lesions and lymphadenopathy.
What type of gene is mTOR?	mTOR is a protooncogene.
What is the typical management approach for MSK (musculoskeletal) back pain?	MSK back pain is typically managed with conservative management.
How can multiple sclerosis (MS) affect the detrusor muscle and lead to incontinence?	MS can lead to urge incontinence due to detrusor muscle hyperactivity and overflow incontinence due to detrusor muscle hypoactivity.
What are the common causative organisms of hospital-acquired pneumonia that require treatment with specific antibiotics?	MRSA and Pseudomonas are common causative organisms of hospital-acquired pneumonia that require treatment with Pip/Tazo (Zosyn) and Vancomycin.
Where can mRNAs be stored for future translation?	mRNAs may be stored in P-bodies for future translation.
Where does mRNA quality control occur and what components are present in the site?	mRNA quality control occurs at cytoplasmic processing bodies (P-bodies), which contain exonucleases, decapping enzymes, and microRNAs.
What type of MPGN is associated with subendothelial immune complex deposits?	MPGN type I is associated with subendothelial immune complex deposits.
What type of MPGN is associated with intramembranous immune complex deposits?	MPGN type II is associated with intramembranous immune complex deposits.
What is C3 nephritic factor and what does it stabilize in MPGN type II?	C3 nephritic factor is an IgG antibody that stabilizes C3 convertase in MPGN type II.
What are the common treatments for motion sickness (vestibular nausea)?	Motion sickness (vestibular nausea) is commonly treated with 1st generation anti-histamines such as diphenhydramine and meclizine, as well as scopolamine.
What are motilin receptor agonists used for and what is an example of one?	Motilin receptor agonists, such as erythromycin, are used to stimulate intestinal peristalsis.
When is motilin secreted from the small intestine?	Motilin is secreted from the small intestine during fasting states.
What does the presence of motile, flagellated trypanosomes on a blood smear indicate?	The presence of motile, flagellated trypanosomes on a blood smear is indicative of Trypanosoma brucei.
What does the presence of motile trophozoites on a wet mount indicate?	The presence of motile trophozoites on a wet mount indicates Trichomonas vaginalis.
What are the common causes of transudative pleural effusions?	The common causes of transudative pleural effusions are CHF (congestive heart failure), cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.
In what cells are most tissue histamine sequestered inside their granules?	Most tissue histamine is sequestered inside the granules of mast cells and basophils.
What is the typical functionality of most thyroid adenomas? Can they cause hyperthyroidism and if so, how?	Most thyroid adenomas are nonfunctional ("cold"), but they may rarely cause hyperthyroidism via autonomous thyroid hormone production ("hot" or "toxic").
Which gender is most commonly affected by most subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma?	Most subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma are more common in men.
What is considered the most significant risk factor for postpartum depression?	The most significant risk factor for postpartum depression is prior depression.
What is considered the most significant parental risk factor for child abuse?	The most significant parental risk factor for child abuse is a history of being abused themselves.
What is the typical gram staining result for most rods and coccobacillus bacteria?	Most rods (and coccobacillus) are gram negative.
Where is the typical site of replication for most RNA viruses?	Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm.
What is the typical structure of RNA in most RNA viruses?	Most RNA viruses are single-stranded.
What is the typical structure of RNA virus genomes?	Most RNA virus genomes are single-stranded and linear.
What is the typical origin of a thromboembolus that causes a pulmonary embolism?	Most pulmonary emboli arise via a thromboembolus from the proximal deep veins of the lower extremity.
What is the typical charge of proteins (with an exception)?	Most proteins are negatively charged, except for histones.
What is the typical size of pituitary adenomas that produce ACTH?	Most pituitary adenomas that produce ACTH are microadenomas, which are less than 10 mm in diameter.
What is the most common accompanying defect in patients with truncus arteriosus?	Most patients with truncus arteriosus have an accompanying ventricular septal defect.
In what phase do most patients with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) typically present, and how do their symptoms usually develop?	Most patients with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) present in the chronic phase with an insidious onset of symptoms.
What is the typical course of acute, uncomplicated low back pain, and how long does it usually last?	Most patients with acute, uncomplicated low back pain experience spontaneous resolution of their symptoms in the first few weeks.
What is a common side effect of most opioid analgesics?	Most opioid analgesics cause miosis (constriction of the pupil).
Who is at the highest risk of developing severe fungal infections?	Most often, severe fungal infections occur in immunocompromised/suppressed patients.
How are most of the secreted bile salts recirculated back to the liver?	Most of the secreted bile salts are recirculated to the liver via enterohepatic circulation.
In what category do most of the Bunyaviruses fall, and what is another term used to describe them?	Most of the Bunyaviruses are also arboviruses.
Which serum tumor marker is commonly elevated in Prostate Cancer?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker PSA is elevated in Prostate Cancer.
Which serum tumor marker is commonly elevated in testicular germ tumors and ovarian dysgerminoma?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker LDH is elevated in testicular germ tumors and ovarian dysgerminoma.
Which serum tumor marker is commonly elevated in patients with neuroendocrine tumors?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker Chromogranin is elevated in patients with neuroendocrine tumors.
In which cancer is the serum tumor marker Calcitonin commonly elevated?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker Calcitonin is seen elevated in Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma.
In which cancer is the serum tumor marker CA-125 commonly elevated?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker CA-125 is seen elevated in ovarian cancers.
In which cancer is the serum tumor marker CA 19-9 commonly elevated?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker CA 19-9 is seen elevated in Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.
In which cancer is the serum tumor marker CA 15-3 / CA 27-29 commonly elevated?	Most notably, the serum tumor marker CA 15-3 / CA 27-29 are seen elevated in Breast Cancer.
What is the term used to describe the chromaticity of most microcytic anemias?	Most microcytic anemias are also hypo-chromic.
What is the gender distribution of individuals with kleptomania and pyromania, respectively?	Most individuals with kleptomania are female, while most individuals with pyromania are male.
What type of pathogens are responsible for most infections within the first month following liver transplantation?	Most infections within the first month following liver transplantation are due to bacterial pathogens.
What type of pathogens are responsible for most infections during months 1-6 following liver transplantation?	Most infections during months 1-6 following liver transplantation are due to opportunistic pathogens.
What is the most important modifiable behavioral risk factor associated with preterm labor and birth?	The most important modifiable behavioral risk factor associated with preterm labor and birth is smoking.
What is the most important finding in predicting the morbidity of a temporal bone fracture?	The presence of pneumolabyrinth is the most important finding in predicting the morbidity of a temporal bone fracture.
What is the typical presentation of fibroids?	Most fibroids are asymptomatic.
Where do most fibers in the optic tract project to within the thalamus?	Most fibers in the optic tract project to the lateral geniculate body of the thalamus.
By what point in gestation do most fetuses spontaneously rotate into a longitudinal lie?	Most fetuses spontaneously rotate into a longitudinal lie by term, which is typically around week 37-42, denoted as "T".
What is the most effective intervention for slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy?	The most effective intervention for slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy is controlling hypertension.
Where do most DNA viruses replicate?	Most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus.
What essential amino acid is required by most disorders of the urea cycle, especially during episodes of hyperammonemia?	Most disorders of the urea cycle require arginine as an essential amino acid, particularly during episodes of hyperammonemia.
According to most current guidelines, how often should routine screening mammography be performed and at what age should it begin?	Most current guidelines suggest routine screening mammography every two years beginning at age over 50.
Is surgical intervention required for most communicating hydroceles?	Most communicating hydroceles do not require surgical intervention.
What is the most common site of osteonecrosis?	The most common site of osteonecrosis is the femur head.
What is the most common type of lung cancer in females and non-smokers?	The most common type of lung cancer in females and non-smokers is adenocarcinoma.
What is the most common type of laryngeal cancer in children who present with stridor?	The most common type of laryngeal cancer in children who present with stridor is laryngeal papilloma with stridor or cough.
What is the most common cause of endocarditis associated with S. aureus?	The most common cause of endocarditis associated with S. aureus is intravenous drug use (IVDU).
What is the most common complication that can arise from peptic ulcer disease?	The most common complication that can arise from peptic ulcer disease is bleeding.
What is the most common underlying condition associated with optic neuritis?	The most common underlying condition associated with optic neuritis is multiple sclerosis.
What is the most common cause of hypercalcemia?	The most common cause of hypercalcemia is primary hyperparathyroidism.
What is the most common underlying condition associated with heavy, regular menstrual bleeding in adolescents?	The most common underlying condition associated with heavy, regular menstrual bleeding in adolescents is von Willebrand disease.
What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?	The most common cause of chronic pancreatitis is alcoholism, accounting for 95% of cases.
What is the most common underlying condition associated with primary hyperparathyroidism?	The most common underlying condition associated with primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma.
What are the three most common bacteria associated with neonatal sepsis?	The three most common bacteria associated with neonatal sepsis are Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Escherichia coli (E. coli), and Listeria.
What is the most common type of primary nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults?	The most common type of primary nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults is membranous nephropathy.
What is the Gram stain result for most cocci, and what are two examples of cocci bacteria?	Most cocci bacteria are Gram positive. Examples of cocci bacteria include Streptococcus and Staphylococcus.
At what age are most children typically able to tie their own shoelaces?	Most children are typically able to tie their own shoelaces at around age 5.
What is the most common histological type of cervical cancer?	The most common histological type of cervical cancer is squamous cell carcinoma.
Is spontaneous remission common in cases of pulmonary sarcoidosis?	Yes, most cases of pulmonary sarcoidosis have a high rate of spontaneous remission.
How do most cases of primary tuberculosis typically resolve, and what is the resulting state of the infection?	Most cases of primary tuberculosis resolve via fibrosis and calcification, resulting in a latent infection.
In which populations are most cases of primary tuberculosis commonly observed?	Most cases of primary tuberculosis are commonly observed in children and the immunocompromised.
What is the underlying cause of most cases of papillary thyroid carcinoma?	Most cases of papillary thyroid carcinoma are caused by activating mutations of the MAPK signaling pathway.
What genetic mutations are responsible for the majority of cases of diffuse gastric cancer?	Most cases of diffuse gastric cancer are caused by E-cadherin mutations.
In what age group do most cases of sporadic ALS typically occur?	Most cases of sporadic ALS typically occur in middle-aged adults.
Which Carbapenem has limited coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, despite most Carbapenems being effective against it?	Ertapenem has limited coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, despite most Carbapenems being effective against it.
What is the mechanism of action for most atypical antipsychotics?	Most atypical antipsychotics exert their effects by blocking the D2 dopamine receptor.
What is the main cause of most adverse drug reactions?	Most adverse drug reactions are caused by the known pharmacologic properties of the drug and are predictable.
What is the composition of most adult hemoglobin and what is it commonly referred to as?	Most adult hemoglobin is composed of 2 α and 2 β subunits, and it is commonly referred to as HbA.
Where do most corticospinal tract fibers decussate and what is the structure called?	Most (80-90%) of the corticospinal tract fibers decussate just below the caudal medulla at the pyramidal decussation.
When are symptoms of asthma more frequent and severe in individuals with more severe forms of asthma?	More severe forms of asthma are associated with more frequent and severe symptoms, especially during nighttime.
How is Moraxella catarrhalis transmitted from one person to another?	Moraxella catarrhalis is transmitted through respiratory droplets.
Where is Moraxella catarrhalis normally found in the body as a part of the normal flora?	Moraxella catarrhalis is normal flora of the respiratory tract.
What are some of the medical conditions that Moraxella catarrhalis is associated with causing?	Moraxella catarrhalis is associated with causing COPD exacerbations, otitis media in children, and sinusitis.
What is the gram stain result and morphology of Moraxella catarrhalis?	Moraxella catarrhalis are gram negative diplococci.
What type of asthma are Montelukast and zafirlukast especially effective at treating?	Montelukast and zafirlukast are especially effective at treating aspirin-induced asthma.
What is the purpose of monofilament testing?	Monofilament testing is useful for determining the presence of peripheral neuropathy.
What conditions are associated with monocytosis, which is an increase in monocytes?	Monocytosis, which is an increase in monocytes, is associated with chronic inflammatory states and malignancy.
Who is most likely to develop monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)?	Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is common in the elderly.
What is an infusion reaction and when can it occur with monoclonal antibodies?	An infusion reaction is a possible adverse event that can occur immediately upon IV administration of monoclonal antibodies.
What medical conditions are monoclonal antibodies against TNF-a primarily used to treat?	Monoclonal antibodies against TNF-a are primarily used to treat Rheumatoid Arthritis and Inflammatory Bowel Disease.
Can monobactams penetrate the CNS?	Yes, monobactams can penetrate the CNS.
What types of infections can be treated with monobactams?	Monobactams can treat meningitis and pneumonia caused by aerobic gram negative rods only.
What class of antibiotics do monobactams such as Aztreonam belong to?	Monobactams such as Aztreonam belong to the β-lactam class of antibiotics.
What do monobactams bind to?	Monobactams bind to penicillin binding protein transpeptidases.
What is the potential consequence of consuming tyramine-containing foods while taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors?	Consuming tyramine-containing foods while taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors can cause a hypertensive crisis.
What is Monckeberg sclerosis and is it clinically significant?	Monckeberg sclerosis is a non-obstructive condition and therefore is not clinically significant.
What is Molluscum contagiosum and how is it typically transmitted in adults?	Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that is typically seen in children but can be sexually transmitted in adults.
What is the histological characteristic of Molluscum contagiosum?	Molluscum contagiosum is characterized histologically by the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions known as molluscum bodies.
What type of virus is Molluscum contagiosum and what type of infection does it cause?	Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus that causes localized skin infections.
What type of disorder is MODY and how is it similar to 2DM?	MODY is an autosomal dominant disorder seen in young patients that is similar to type 2 diabetes mellitus.
In moderate global cerebral ischemia, which areas of the brain are typically affected and which area is the most vulnerable?	Moderate global cerebral ischemia typically affects the hippocampus (most vulnerable), neocortex, cerebellum, and watershed areas of the brain.
What is the range of blood alcohol concentration that may be present in moderate ethanol intoxication?	Moderate ethanol intoxication may present with blood alcohol concentration between 0.15-0.3%.
At what age are the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) and varicella (chickenpox) vaccines first recommended to be administered?	The MMR and varicella vaccines are first recommended to be administered at 1 year of age.
What are the characteristic features or conditions that are associated with mixed connective tissue disease?	Mixed connective tissue disease is associated with features of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, and/or polymyositis.
What are the locations where Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma commonly arises?	Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma commonly arises in the spleen and abdominal lymph nodes.
Where does the mixed blood in the fetal inferior vena cava (IVC) enter?	The mixed blood in the fetal inferior vena cava (IVC) enters the right atrium.
What are the common causes of mitral regurgitation, and in what conditions is it often observed?	Mitral regurgitation is often observed in conditions such as ischemic heart disease (post-MI) and LV dilatation.
What is the cause of mitral valve prolapse, and what happens to the valve as a result?	Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxoid degeneration of the valve, which makes it floppy.
What are some of the complications that can arise from mitral valve prolapse, and how common are they?	Complications from mitral valve prolapse are rare, but they can include infective endocarditis, arrhythmia, and severe mitral regurgitation.
What is the most common cause of mitral stenosis, and how does it develop?	Mitral stenosis is usually due to chronic rheumatic valve disease, which causes scarring and thickening of the valve leaflets.
How does mitral stenosis affect pulmonary vascular resistance, and what are the implications of this?	Mitral stenosis is associated with high pulmonary vascular resistance, which can lead to pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.
What are the effects of misoprostol on the gastric mucosa, specifically in terms of mucous barrier production and acid production?	Misoprostol promotes increased production and secretion of a gastric mucous barrier and decreased acid production in the stomach.
What is a common side effect of misoprostol that limits its usage?	Misoprostol is not used very often due to its ability to cause diarrhea as a side effect.
Who should not use misoprostol due to its abortifacient effects?	Misoprostol is contraindicated in women of childbearing potential due to its abortifacient effects.
What is the chemical compound that Misoprostol is a synthetic analog of?	Misoprostol is a synthetic analog of PGE1.
What is the purpose of using Misoprostol, a PGE1 mimic, in relation to uterine contraction?	Misoprostol is a PGE1 mimic which can be used to promote uterine contraction for the purpose of terminating pregnancy.
What is the medical condition that Misoprostol can be used to prevent in relation to NSAID usage?	Misoprostol can be used to prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcers.
How can Misoprostol be clinically used to treat gastric ulcers and what is the mechanism by which it achieves this?	Misoprostol can be clinically used to treat gastric ulcers by inhibiting the secretion of gastric acid at high doses.
What is a possible adverse effect of Mirtazapine and how does it manifest?	Mirtazapine may cause dry mouth as an adverse effect.
What type of adrenergic antagonist is Mirtazapine and what neurotransmitters does it increase the pre-synaptic release of?	Mirtazapine is an α2-adrenergic antagonist that increases the pre-synaptic release of serotonin and norepinephrine.
What type of histamine receptor antagonist is Mirtazapine?	Mirtazapine is a H1 histamine receptor antagonist.
What type of adrenergic antagonist is Mirtazapine?	Mirtazapine is a selective α2 adrenergic antagonist.
What effects can Mirtazapine have on appetite and weight?	Mirtazapine can cause increased appetite and weight gain.
What type of depressed patients may find the sedative effects of Mirtazapine desirable?	The sedative effects of Mirtazapine may be desirable in depressed patients with insomnia.
What condition is Mirabegron indicated for?	Mirabegron is indicated for urinary urge incontinence.
What type of receptors does Mirabegron stimulate as a sympathomimetic?	Mirabegron is a sympathomimetic that stimulates β3 receptors.
What is Mirabegron and what condition is it used to treat?	Mirabegron is a β3 agonist used to treat overactive bladder.
What are the conditions under which minors may be considered emancipated?	Minors may be considered emancipated if they are self-supporting, in the military, married, or have children or pregnant.
What are the minor criteria for diagnosing rheumatic fever and what are some examples of these criteria?	The minor criteria for rheumatic fever are nonspecific and include fever and elevated ESR.
What is the characteristic finding in minimal change disease when examining glomeruli on light microscopy?	Minimal change disease is characterized by normal glomeruli on light microscopy.
What is the characteristic finding in minimal change disease when examining glomeruli on electron microscopy?	Minimal change disease is characterized by effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy.
What is the mechanism of damage and what are the characteristic findings in minimal change disease?	Minimal change disease is characterized by cytokine-mediated damage of foot processes and loss of glomerular basement anions.
What is the response of minimal change disease to corticosteroid treatment?	Minimal change disease has an excellent response to corticosteroids.
What is a rare cause of secondary minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis)?	Minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis) is rarely secondary to Hodgkin lymphoma.
What is the composition of mini-pill, and how does it act in the body?	Mini-pill is composed of only progestin and acts locally.
Among which group of people do mini-epidemics of Pityriasis Rosea often occur?	Mini-epidemics of Pityriasis Rosea will often occur among young adults.
In which types of adrenal insufficiency is mineralocorticoid production by the adrenal gland preserved?	Mineralocorticoid production by the adrenal gland is preserved in secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
What is a potential consequence of mineralocorticoid excess (hyperaldosteronism)?	Mineralocorticoid excess (hyperaldosteronism) may cause metabolic alkalosis.
What effect does milrinone have on arterioles and afterload?	Milrinone causes arteriolar dilation and thus decreased afterload.
What class of inhibitors are milrinone and inamrinone, and what condition are they used to treat?	Milrinone and inamrinone are PDE-3 inhibitors used in the treatment of acute heart failure.
What condition is associated with milky ascites, and what are some possible causes of this condition?	Milky ascites is seen in a chylous ascites, which can be caused by malignancy or cirrhosis.
What are the three main features that characterize milk alkali syndrome?	Milk alkali syndrome is characterized by a triad of hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and AKI.
What is the cause of miliary tuberculosis and where does the infection typically spread?	Miliary tuberculosis develops when the infection is disseminated into the blood (bacteremia).

What condition can result from mild trauma in elderly individuals and cause a gradual decline in mental function?	Chronic subdural hematoma can result from mild trauma in elderly individuals and cause a gradual decline in mental function.
What is mild osteopetrosis, and at what age does it typically present?	Mild osteopetrosis is an autosomal dominant "marble bone disease" that typically presents in adolescence or adulthood.
What is the typical result of mild global cerebral ischemia, and how does recovery usually occur?	Mild global cerebral ischemia typically results in transient confusion, but recovery is usually prompt.
How is mild euvolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia typically managed?	Mild euvolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia is typically managed with fluid restriction.

In which specific disease is Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) observed?	Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) is seen in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
What are the methods that can be used to remedy migration bias?	Migration bias can be remedied with the 5 and 20 rule or the Best/Worst Case analysis.
What is migration (attrition) bias and when does it occur in a study?	Migration (attrition) bias is a form of selection bias that occurs when patients drop out of the study prematurely.
What are the common symptoms associated with migraines?	Migraines typically present as a pulsating pain with nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia.
What is the typical duration of migraines?	Migraines generally last from 4 to 72 hours.
What is the typical pattern of pain distribution in migraines?	Migraines are uni-lateral.

What are the typical symptoms of injury to the femoral nerve?	Injury to the femoral nerve typically presents as decreased thigh flexion and leg extension.
What are the typical symptoms of injury to the superior gluteal nerve?	Injury to the superior gluteal nerve typically presents with a trendelenburg sign and a gluteus medius lurch.

What is the initial and transient effect of PTH on bone and which cells does it act on?	Initially and transiently, PTH causes an increase in bone formation by a direct action on osteoblasts.

What are the initial treatment options for psoriasis?	The initial treatment options for psoriasis include high-potency glucocorticoids or vitamin D derivatives, such as calcipotriene.
What are the initial therapy options for male pattern baldness?	The initial therapy options for male pattern baldness include topical minoxidil and oral finasteride.
What is the initial test used to diagnose subarachnoid hemorrhage?	The initial test used to diagnose subarachnoid hemorrhage is a non-contrast CT scan.

What are the initial management options for necrotizing enterocolitis?	The initial management options for necrotizing enterocolitis include supportive care and initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.

What are the initial management options for acute spinal cord compression?	The initial management options for acute spinal cord compression include emergency MRI and IV glucocorticoids.

What is a potential consequence of initial infection with H. pylori?	Initial infection with H. pylori may cause acute gastritis.
