What type of damage is suggested by the presence of initial hematuria?	The presence of initial hematuria is suggestive of urethral damage.
What is the impact of inhibiting TNF-a (e.g. through immunosuppression or drugs) on tuberculosis infection?	Inhibiting TNF-a can result in a lack of granuloma formation and the reactivation of tuberculosis infection.
What is the impact of inhibiting SNARE proteins on neurotransmitter release?	Inhibiting SNARE proteins can inhibit the docking of neurotransmitter vesicles and ultimately the release of neurotransmitters.
What is the potential consequence of non-dihydropyridine CCBs inhibiting the SA node?	The potential consequence of non-dihydropyridine CCBs inhibiting the SA node is bradycardia.
What is the impact of inhibiting Gi via the pertussis toxin on cAMP levels?	Inhibiting Gi via the pertussis toxin can result in increased levels of cAMP.
What is the effect of inhibiting Gi via the pertussis toxin on chemokine receptors in lymphocytes?	Inhibiting Gi via the pertussis toxin can result in the inhibition of chemokine receptors on lymphocytes.
What is the effect of inhibiting COX-1 by NSAIDs on bleeding time?	Inhibiting COX-1 by NSAIDs can lead to increased bleeding time.
What is the impact of inhibiting Dihydrofolate Reductase on DHF levels?	Inhibiting Dihydrofolate Reductase can result in increased levels of DHF.
What is the mechanism of action of inhaled corticosteroids in reducing inflammation?	Inhaled corticosteroids can inactivate NF-κB, the transcription factor that induces production of TNF-α and other inflammatory agents, thereby reducing inflammation.
What is the recommended daily maintenance therapy for persistent asthma?	Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g. budesonide, fluticasone) can be added as daily maintenance therapy for persistent asthma.
What is the impact of inhaled corticosteroids on cytokine synthesis?	Inhaled corticosteroids, which are used as a therapy for asthma, can inhibit the synthesis of virtually all cytokines.
What is the relationship between the solubility of inhaled anesthetics in blood and their onset of action?	Inhaled anesthetics with lower solubility in blood have a faster onset of action.
How does the arteriovenous concentration gradient affect the onset of action of inhaled anesthetics?	Inhaled anesthetics with lower arteriovenous concentration gradient have a faster onset of action.
How does the solubility of inhaled anesthetics in blood affect their onset of action?	Inhaled anesthetics with higher solubility in blood have a slower onset of action.
What is the relationship between the arteriovenous gradient and the onset of action of inhaled anesthetics?	Inhaled anesthetics with higher arteriovenous gradient have a slower onset of action.
How does the solubility of inhaled anesthetics in blood affect the recovery time?	Inhaled anesthetics with lower solubility in blood have a faster recovery.
What is the relationship between the solubility of inhaled anesthetics in blood and the recovery time?	Inhaled anesthetics with higher solubility in blood have a slower recovery.
What effect can inhaled anesthetics have on cerebral blood flow?	Inhaled anesthetics can cause increased cerebral blood flow.
What respiratory effect can inhaled anesthetics have?	Inhaled anesthetics can cause respiratory depression.
What effect can inhaled anesthetics have on the heart muscle?	Inhaled anesthetics can cause myocardial depression.

What are the two subtypes of inflammatory bowel disease?	Inflammatory bowel disease is subclassified as ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease.

What does infertility combined with a history of irregular menses typically indicate?	Infertility combined with a history of irregular menses typically indicates anovulation.

What is the primary management approach for infective endocarditis?	The primary management approach for infective endocarditis involves blood cultures.
How does the treatment of infective endocarditis differ between prosthetic valves and native valves?	Infective endocarditis in prosthetic valves is much harder to treat than in native valves.
What type of infection can lead to a rash in patients who are exposed to ampicillin?	Patients with infectious mononucleosis can develop a rash if they are exposed to ampicillin.
What type of medication exposure can cause patients with infectious mononucleosis to develop a rash?	Patients with infectious mononucleosis can develop a rash if they are exposed to aminopenicillins such as ampicillin or amoxicillin.
What are the common symptoms of infectious mononucleosis in teenagers and which lymph nodes are typically affected?	Teenagers with infectious mononucleosis often experience fever, exudative pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the posterior cervical lymph nodes.
What is the most common cause of infectious mononucleosis?	The most common cause of infectious mononucleosis is an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.

What type of infection increases the risk of vulvar cancer?	Infection with HPV increases the risk of vulvar cancer.

What can happen to injured portions of the aorta, such as atherosclerotic plaque or catheterization injury, if they become infected?	Infection of injured portions of the aorta (atherosclerotic plaque, catheterization injury) can lead to aortic aneurysm formation.
What type of cells kill infected CD4+ T cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells in HIV?	Infected CD4+ T cells (and macrophages, dendritic cells) are killed by CD8+ T-cells in HIV.

What is a common sign of rickets in infants?	A common sign of rickets in infants is delayed closure of fontanelles.
What is a potential risk for infants who are taking sulfonamides?	Infants who are taking sulfonamides are at risk for Kernicterus.
What are some potential congenital malformations that infants of diabetic mothers may be at increased risk of?	Infants of diabetic mothers are at increased risk of congenital malformations, such as cardiac and CNS, renal, and limb deformities.
What are some common symptoms in infants born to mothers with chorioamniotitis?	Infants born to moms with chorioamniotitis will appear pale, lethargic, and febrile.

When should the first dose of the HBV vaccine be given to infants born weighing less than 2000 g?	Infants born < 2000 g should receive their first dose of the HBV vaccine at 1 month of age.
What are some potential complications that infants under 2 months old with bronchiolitis are at high risk of developing?	Infants age < 2 months with bronchiolitis are at high risk of developing apnea and/or respiratory failure.
What is infantile malignant osteopetrosis, and what is the typical outcome for infants with this condition?	Infantile malignant osteopetrosis is an autosomal recessive bone disorder that is often fatal in infancy due to severe leukopenia.
What is the likely diagnosis for an infant who experiences recurrent infections with Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae?	An infant with recurrent infections with Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae likely has a B-cell disorder.
What is the likely diagnosis for an infant who is born without a thymus or tonsils?	An infant who is born without a thymus or tonsils likely has SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).
What is the most likely diagnosis for an infant who presents with hypotonia, cardiomegaly, and hepatomegaly?	An infant who presents with hypotonia, cardiomegaly, and hepatomegaly is most likely suffering from Pompe disease (type II).
What condition is suggested in an infant who presents with bloody diarrhea and is failing to thrive?	An infant who presents with bloody diarrhea and is failing to thrive is suggestive of milk-protein allergy.
What condition is suggested in an infant who presents with biphasic stridor, wheezing, and dysphagia that improves with extension?	An infant who presents with biphasic stridor, wheezing, and dysphagia that improves with extension is suggestive of vascular ring.
What pathogen is associated with infant pneumonia that presents with a "staccato cough"?	Infant pneumonia that presents with a "staccato cough" is associated with Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K).
What is the duration of infant deprivation that can lead to irreversible changes?	Infant deprivation for more than 6 months can lead to irreversible changes.
What is the cause of infant botulism, and where are the causative agents commonly found?	Infant botulism is caused by ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores, which are commonly found in environmental dust and honey.
What is the common postoperative complication that is associated with inefficient detrusor muscle activity?	Inefficient detrusor muscle activity is commonly associated with hypotonic bladder as a postoperative complication.
In what medical conditions is the induction of labor indicated?	The induction of labor is indicated in cases of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and oligohydramnios.
Under what circumstances is the induction of labor typically performed in cases of fetal distress?	The induction of labor is typically performed in cases of fetal distress.
At what gestational age is indomethacin considered contraindicated?	Indomethacin is considered contraindicated at gestational ages greater than 32 weeks.
Why are individuals with chronic granulomatous disease susceptible to Candida and Aspergillus colonization?	Individuals with chronic granulomatous disease are susceptible to Candida and Aspergillus colonization due to both organisms being catalase-positive.
What genetic mutation is associated with resistance to HIV infection?	Homozygous CCR5 allele mutations are associated with resistance to HIV infection.
What genetic mutation is associated with a slower rate of progression of HIV infection?	Heterozygous CCR5 allele mutations are associated with a slower rate of progression of HIV infection.
What medication can cause a false-negative urease test in individuals with H. pylori?	Proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) can cause a false-negative urease test in individuals with H. pylori.
What condition should be considered in immunocompromised individuals who present with a herpes zoster (shingles) rash that crosses midline?	HIV should be considered in immunocompromised individuals who present with a herpes zoster (shingles) rash that crosses midline.
What type of ANCA is expressed on the cell surface of sensitized neutrophils in individuals predisposed to vasculitis?	p-ANCA is expressed on the cell surface of sensitized neutrophils in individuals predisposed to vasculitis.
How many doses of the HPV vaccine are required for individuals over the age of 15 to achieve immunity?	Individuals over the age of 15 require 3 doses of the HPV vaccine to achieve immunity.
How many doses of the HPV vaccine are required for individuals under the age of 15 to achieve immunity?	Individuals under the age of 15 require 2 doses of the HPV vaccine to achieve immunity.
How is Francisella tularensis indirectly transmitted?	Francisella tularensis is indirectly transmitted through inhalation of aerosol.
What are the two possible sources of indirect transmission of Francisella tularensis?	Indirect transmission of Francisella tularensis can result from a bite by a dermacentor tick or deerfly.
How is Brucella spp. indirectly transmitted?	Brucella spp. is indirectly transmitted through the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products such as milk or cheese.
What causes indirect inguinal hernias in infants?	Indirect inguinal hernias in infants are caused by the failure of the processus vaginalis to close.
In which gender are indirect inguinal hernias more common?	Indirect inguinal hernias are more common in males.
What is the mechanism of action of indirect cholinomimetics?	Indirect cholinomimetics exert their effects via inhibition of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE).
What causes color changes in indicator (differential) media?	Indicator (differential) media can also yield color changes due to differences in metabolism of certain organisms.
What are the indications for endometrial biopsy?	Indications for endometrial biopsy include abnormal uterine or postmenopausal bleeding in women age ≥ 45.
What are the indications for endometrial biopsy in women under the age of 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding?	Indications for endometrial biopsy in women under the age of 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding include obesity and/or anovulation.
What defines the stages of chronic kidney disease?	The stages of chronic kidney disease are defined by incremental reductions in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
How does increasing tidal volume affect alveolar ventilation and PaCO2?	Increasing the tidal volume increases alveolar ventilation and helps decrease PaCO2.
How does an increase in contractility affect the Starling curve?	An increase in contractility causes the Starling curve to shift upward.
What is the effect of increases in arterial H+ on the carotid body peripheral chemoreceptors?	Increases in arterial H+ stimulate the carotid body peripheral chemoreceptors only, independent of changes in Pco2.
What is the relationship between increased preload and the width of a pressure-volume loop curve?	Increased preload results in an increased width on a pressure-volume loop curve.
How does increased contractility affect the width and height of a pressure-volume loop curve?	Increased contractility results in an increased width and increased height on a pressure-volume loop curve.
What is the diagnostic criterion for cystic fibrosis based on Cl- concentration in sweat?	Increased Cl- concentration (> 60 meQ/L) in sweat is diagnostic of cystic fibrosis.
How does increased afterload affect the width and height of a pressure-volume loop curve?	Increased afterload results in a decreased width and increased height on a pressure-volume loop curve.
What is the consequence of increased LA pressure resulting from mitral stenosis?	Increased LA pressure as a result of mitral stenosis may lead to pulmonary congestion with edema and alveolar hemorrhage.
What factor increases the risk for hernia?	Increased intra-abdominal pressure leads to high risk for hernia.
What dermatologic symptoms may result from increased estrogen in cirrhosis?	Increased estrogen in cirrhosis may lead to spider angiomas and palmar erythema (dermatologic symptoms).
What type of intracranial hypertension is caused by increased vessel permeability and fluid accumulation outside of brain cells?	Increased vessel permeability and fluid accumulation outside of brain cells (interstitium) leads to vasogenic intracranial hypertension.
What happens to Paco2 with increased ventilation, such as at high altitude?	Increased ventilation (e.g. high altitude) causes decreased Paco2.
What happens to RV filling and ejection time with increased venous return during inspiration?	Increased venous return during inspiration leads to increased RV filling and ejection time.
What condition is associated with increased vascular markings and no change in DLCO?	Increased vascular markings and no change in DLCO is associated with chronic bronchitis.
What is the result of increased VA/Q?	Increased VA/Q results in alveolar dead space.
What is the cause of increased urinary frequency in pregnancy?	Increased urinary frequency in pregnancy is due to β-hCG stimulated production of relaxin, which increases GFR by increasing renal circulation.
Which adrenergic receptors in the JGA are stimulated by increased sympathetic tone to increase renin release?	Increased sympathetic tone increases renin release via stimulation of the β1 adrenergic receptors of the JGA.
What condition is associated with increased sensitivity to lactate infusion?	Increased sensitivity to lactate infusion is associated with panic attacks.
Which valve experiences delayed closure during inspiration due to increased RV ejection time (normal splitting)?	Increased RV ejection time during inspiration causes delayed closure of the pulmonic valve (normal splitting).
Which type of miners are at an increased risk of lung cancer due to increased exposure to radon?	Increased risk of lung cancer is seen in uranium miners, due to increased exposure to radon.
What factor is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer?	Increased risk of developing breast cancer is associated with an older age at first live birth.
What factors are associated with an increased risk for breast carcinoma?	Increased risk for breast carcinoma is associated with early menarche and late menopause.
What effect does increased prostaglandin have on the afferent arteriole?	Increased prostaglandin (e.g. loop diuretics) causes vasodilation of the afferent arteriole.
How does an increase in prevalence affect the positive predictive value?	An increase in prevalence results in increased positive predictive value.
How does an increase in prevalence affect the negative predictive value?	An increase in prevalence results in decreased negative predictive value.
How is increased precision associated with statistical power (1 - β)?	Increased precision is associated with increased statistical power (1 - β).
How is increased precision associated with the standard deviation?	Increased precision is associated with decreased standard deviation.
How does increased phosphofructokinase-2 affect glycolysis and gluconeogenesis?	Increased phosphofructokinase-2 stimulates glycolysis and inhibits gluconeogenesis.
What is the result of increased phenylalanine (e.g. in PKU) in terms of urine composition?	Increased phenylalanine (e.g. in PKU) results in excess phenylketones in the urine.
How does increased PCO2 (respiratory acidosis) affect HCO3- reabsorption?	Increased PCO2 (respiratory acidosis) results in increased HCO3- reabsorption.
What is the effect of increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) on the systemic circulation?	Increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation.
What is the effect of increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) on the pulmonary circulation?	Increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) causes vasoconstriction in the pulmonary circulation.
What is the effect of increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) on TCA activity and the utilization of acetyl-CoA?	Increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) causes decreased TCA activity, thus increasing utilization of acetyl-CoA for ketogenesis and lipogenesis.
What is the effect of increased Na+ reabsorption in cystic fibrosis on the transepithelial potential difference (TEPD)?	Increased Na+ reabsorption in cystic fibrosis causes a more negative transepithelial potential difference (TEPD).
What is the result of increased Na+ reabsorption due to decreased Cl- secretion in cystic fibrosis?	Increased Na+ reabsorption due to decreased Cl- secretion in cystic fibrosis results in increased H2O reabsorption.
What is the effect of increased Na+ delivery to principal cells (e.g. thiazide and loop diuretics) on K+ secretion?	Increased Na+ delivery to principal cells (e.g. thiazide and loop diuretics) causes increased K+ secretion.
What is the effect of increased lung volumes on pulmonary vascular resistance?	Increased lung volumes result in increased pulmonary vascular resistance.
What is the effect of increased luminal anions (e.g. HCO3-) on K+ secretion and potassium levels?	Increased luminal anions (e.g. HCO3-) may cause an increase in K+ secretion and thus hypo-kalemia.
What is the effect of increased lumen negativity in principal cells on K+ secretion?	Increased lumen negativity in principal cells causes increased K+ secretion.
What medical condition is associated with increased levels of porphobilinogen and D-ALA?	Increased levels of porphobilinogen and D-ALA are seen in acute intermittent porphyria.
What effect does increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte have on the activity of the enzyme ACAT?	Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to increased activity of the enzyme ACAT.
What effect does increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte have on the activity of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase?	Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to decreased activity of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase.
What effect does increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte have on LDL-receptor gene expression?	Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to decreased LDL-receptor gene expression.
What is the effect of increased levels of cGMP on myosin light chain and its interaction with actin?	Increased levels of cGMP cause myosin light chain dephosphorylation, preventing its interaction with actin.
What is the effect of increased intracellular Ca2+ in the pancreatic β-cell on insulin-containing granules?	Increased intracellular Ca2+ in the pancreatic β-cell causes exocytosis of insulin-containing granules.
What is the effect of increased intracellular [Na+] in cardiac myocytes on the activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger?	Increased intracellular [Na+] in cardiac myocytes causes decreased activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger.
What is the effect of increased interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) on the movement of fluid in the capillary?	Increased interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid out of the capillary.
What is the effect of increased interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) on the movement of fluid in the capillary?	Increased interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluid into the capillary.
What is the association between exposure to a certain substance in utero and the incidence of vaginal adenosis in females?	Increased incidence of vaginal adenosis is classically seen in females who were exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero.
What type of ulcer may be caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and what is the mechanism behind it?	Increased ICP may cause a Cushing ulcer due to massive vagal output, which causes increased gastric acid production.
What is the effect of increased HCO3- on arterial pH?	Increased HCO3- causes an increase in arterial pH.
What is the effect of increased filtration fraction on the protein concentration (and thus πc) of peritubular capillary blood?	Increased filtration fraction causes increased protein concentration (and thus πc) of peritubular capillary blood.
What are the reproductive symptoms that may occur due to increased estrogen in cirrhosis?	Increased estrogen in cirrhosis may lead to gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and amenorrhea.
What laboratory findings classify pre-eclampsia as severe?	Increased creatinine or LFTs classify pre-eclampsia as severe.
What is the effect of increased CO2 on arterial pH?	Increased CO2 causes a decrease in arterial pH.
What is the effect of increased CO2 (respiratory acidosis) on HCO3- by mass action?	Increased CO2 (respiratory acidosis) causes an increase in HCO3- by mass action.
What is the relationship between increased cervical cancer and OCPs?	Increased cervical cancer is a known risk factor of OCPs.
What is the effect of increased capillary oncotic pressure (πc) on fluid movement in the capillary?	Increased capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillary.
What is the effect of increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) on fluid movement in the capillary?	Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillary.
What is the effect of increased cAMP via Pertussis Toxin on the recruitment of neutrophils?	Increased cAMP via Pertussis Toxin results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils.
What is the effect of increased body temperature on sympathetic nervous system activity?	Increased body temperature causes decreased sympathetic nervous system activity.
What is the effect of increased arterial pH (metabolic alkalosis) on ventilation and PCO2?	Increased arterial pH (metabolic alkalosis) causes compensatory hypo-ventilation with consequent increased PCO2.
What are the non-modifiable risk factors for developing primary hypertension?	Increased age, African American ethnicity, and family history are non-modifiable risk factors for developing primary hypertension.
What is the relationship between increased alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels and trisomy 21?	Increased AFP levels are seen in trisomy 21.
What is the effect of Hepatitis B incorporation into hepatocytes on the p53 tumor suppressor protein?	Incorporation of Hepatitis B into hepatocytes causes inactivation of the p53 tumor suppressor protein.
What is the cause of incisional hernias?	Incisional hernias occur due to fascial closure breakdown.
What is the effect of an incarcerated hernia on blood flow?	Incarcerated hernias constrict and inhibit venous/lymphatic drainage leading to swelling that surrounds arterial blood flow.
What is the diagnosis for an inappropriately sized neonate with jitteriness and tremors?	The diagnosis is hypoglycemia (<40-45 mg/dL).
What is the characteristic feature of inappropriate absolute polycythemia?	Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased RBC mass.
What is the level of erythropoietin (EPO) in inappropriate absolute polycythemia?	Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased EPO.
What is the management for inadequate colposcopy, such as when the squamocolumnar junction (SCJ) is not fully visualized?	Inadequate colposcopy (e.g. SCJ not fully visualized) is managed with cone biopsy/endocervical curettage.
What is the consequence of the inability of α-intercalated cells to secrete H+ in distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA)?	Inability to secrete H+ by the α-intercalated cells (distal RTA) results in no new HCO3- generation.
What condition is suggested by the inability to flex the middle finger but pops with forced flexion?	Inability to flex middle finger but pops with forced flexion is suggestive of trigger finger.
What are the consequences of α4 tetramers in β-thalassemia major?	In β-thalassemia major, α4 tetramers result in ineffective erythropoiesis and extravascular hemolysis.
What is the role of α4 tetramers in β-thalassemia major?	In β-thalassemia major, α4 tetramers precipitate and damage RBCs.
What type of ossification results in the direct formation of woven bone, which is then later remodeled to lamellar bone?	In membranous ossification, woven bone is formed directly, without cartilage. It is then later remodeled to lamellar bone.
What happens in G6PD deficiency when oxidative stress causes denaturation of hemoglobin?	In G6PD deficiency, oxidative stress precipitates denatured hemoglobin as Heinz bodies.
What is the effect of Leptospira interrogans on the kidneys and liver in Weil's disease?	In Weil's disease, Leptospira interrogans travels through the blood, causing dysfunction in the kidneys and liver.
What is the direction of tracheal and mediastinal shift in tension pneumothorax?	In tension pneumothorax, the trachea and mediastinum shift away from the side of collapse.
What is the direction of the shift in flow volume loops in restrictive lung disease?	In restrictive lung disease, the flow volume loops shift to the right.
Which gene is imprinted and which gene is mutated or deleted in Prader-Willi syndrome?	In Prader-Willi syndrome, the maternal gene is imprinted and the paternal gene is mutated or deleted.
What is perfusion-limited gas exchange, and how can diffusion be increased in this type of gas exchange?	In perfusion-limited gas exchange, diffusion can be increased only if blood flow increases.
What is the direction of the shift in flow volume loops in obstructive lung disease?	In obstructive lung disease, the flow volume loops shift to the left.
What is the glomerular filtration barrier, and what is lost in this barrier in nephrotic syndrome?	In nephrotic syndrome, the charge barrier of the glomerular filtration barrier is lost.
What is Lemierre syndrome, and what can be seen on a chest X-ray in patients with this syndrome?	In Lemierre syndrome, septic thromboemboli from the neck can seed other organs, leading to multiple peripheral lung nodules on CXR.

What is the typical location of primary CNS tumors in children?	In children, primary CNS tumors are usually located infra-tentorial.
What is the genetic basis of Angelman syndrome?	In Angelman syndrome, the paternal gene is imprinted and the maternal gene is mutated/deleted.
What is the typical location of primary CNS tumors in adults?	In adults, primary CNS tumors are usually located supra-tentorial.

What is the characteristic feature of a reaction that follows zero order kinetics?	In zero order kinetics, the rate of reaction is constant.
What is the consequence of a right-to-left shunt on oxygenation?	In right-to-left shunts, hypoxemia always occurs because a significant fraction of the cardiac output is not delivered to the lungs.
What is the expected FEV1/FVC ratio in restrictive lung disease?	In restrictive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is normal or increased.
What is the role of carbonic anhydrase in red blood cells in plasma?	In red blood cells (in plasma), CO2 is combined with H2O via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, forming H2CO3.
What is the characteristic feature of gas exchange in perfusion-limited conditions?	In perfusion-limited gas exchange, the gas equilibrates early along the length of the capillary.
What is the timing of the P2 and A2 sounds in paradoxical splitting?	In paradoxical splitting, the P2 sound occurs before a delayed A2 sound.
What is the expected FEV1/FVC ratio in obstructive lung disease?	In obstructive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is decreased.
What is the appearance of the nasal mucosa in nonallergic rhinitis?	In nonallergic rhinitis, nasal mucosa appears erythematous in color.
What is the function of the HMP shunt in neutrophils?	In neutrophils, the HMP shunt provides a source of NADPH for NADPH oxidase activity, which is used for respiratory burst.
What is the effect of Myeloperoxidase deficiency (MPO) on the respiratory burst?	In Myeloperoxidase deficiency (MPO), the respiratory burst is intact, and thus will produce superoxide (O-) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).

What process causes DNA to condense and form chromosomes?	In mitosis, DNA condenses to form chromosomes.
What condition is associated with right-sided diaphragmatic defects that allow peritoneal fluid to pass into the pleural space?	In hepatic hydrothorax, right-sided diaphragmatic defects permit peritoneal fluid to pass into the pleural space.
What is the relationship between the rate of reaction and substrate (drug) concentration in first order kinetics?	In first order kinetics, the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the substrate (drug) concentration.
What type of ossification involves the first formation of a hyaline cartilage model by chondrocytes?	In endochondral ossification, a hyaline cartilage model is first made by chondrocytes.

What is ATN and what are the pathological changes that can be observed in the nephron?	In ATN, sections of the nephron will show ruptured basement membrane and vacuolization of epithelial cells.

What is the relationship between high alveolar pressure and blood flow in a specific lung zone?	High alveolar pressure may compress the capillaries and reduce blood flow in zone 1 of the lung.
What drives blood flow in zone 3 of the lung, and what are the specific pressures involved?	Blood flow in zone 3 of the lung is driven by the difference between arteriolar and venous pressure.
What drives blood flow in zone 2 of the lung, and what are the specific pressures involved?	Blood flow in zone 2 of the lung is driven by the difference between arteriolar and alveolar pressure.
What is the relationship between vaginal pH levels and the occurrence of candida infections in women?	Candida infections in women do not occur when the vaginal pH is greater than 4.

Does microbial resistance persist through generations in innate immunity or adaptive immunity?	Microbial resistance persists through generations in innate immunity.

In which thyroid disorder(s) is a goiter a possible symptom?	A goiter can be a symptom of both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism.
What is the direction of migration of tetanus toxin to the central nervous system (CNS)?	Tetanus toxin migrates to the CNS via retrograde axonal transport.
Which region of the United States is known for having a high incidence of Lyme Disease?	Lyme Disease is commonly found in the northeastern region of the United States.

Which specific population is indicated for the Adenovirus vaccine?	The Adenovirus vaccine is indicated for military recruits.
Where does the translation of mRNA occur within the cell?	The translation of mRNA occurs in the cytosol of the cell.

What are the characteristics of lesions in vulvar lichen sclerosus?	Lesions in vulvar lichen sclerosus are typically multiple white papules that converge into plaques.

What are the potential consequences of indomethacin exposure in utero?	Exposure to indomethacin in utero can cause premature closure of the PDA, decreased renal perfusion, and fetal oliguria.
What are the characteristic features of Down syndrome in utero?	Down syndrome in utero is associated with short femur length, short fifth digits, clinodactyly, and a small nasal bone.
What is the mechanism of "breathing" in utero and how does it affect pulmonary vascular resistance through gestation?	In utero, "breathing" occurs via aspiration and expulsion of amniotic fluid, which causes increased pulmonary vascular resistance through gestation.
What is the incidence and common cause of hepatic abscesses in underdeveloped countries?	In underdeveloped countries, hepatic abscesses have a relatively high incidence and are usually caused by parasitic infections.
What is the mechanism of action in type III hypersensitivity reactions, and what cells are attracted as a result?	In type III hypersensitivity reactions, antigen-antibody complexes activate complement, which attracts neutrophils.
What is the condition known as twin-twin transfusion syndrome, and what are the characteristics of the recipient twin?	In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the recipient is polycythemic, overloaded, and at risk for heart failure.
What is the condition known as twin-twin transfusion syndrome, and what are the characteristics of the donor twin?	In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the donor is anemic, pale, and has restricted growth.

How many NADH molecules are produced per acetyl-CoA in the TCA cycle?	In total, the TCA cycle produces 3 NADH per acetyl-CoA.
How many GTP molecules are produced per acetyl-CoA in the TCA cycle?	In total, the TCA cycle produces 1 GTP per acetyl-CoA.
How many FADH2 molecules are produced per acetyl-CoA in the TCA cycle?	In total, the TCA cycle produces 1 FADH2 per acetyl-CoA.
How quickly does the loss of cardiomyocyte contractility occur after the onset of total myocardial ischemia?	In total myocardial ischemia, the loss of cardiomyocyte contractility occurs within 60 seconds after onset.
How does bone age compare to chronological age in cases of thyroid hormone deficiency?	In thyroid hormone deficiency, bone age is less than chronological age.
Where in the cell does post-translational O-glycosylation occur, and which amino acids are modified by the addition of sugars?	In the Golgi apparatus, post-translational O-glycosylation adds sugars onto the amino acids serine and threonine.
Where in the cell does co-translational N-glycosylation occur, and which amino acid is modified by the addition of sugars?	In the ER, co-translational N-glycosylation adds sugars onto the amino acid asparagine.
What is the effect of ADH on free-water clearance (CH2O)?	In the presence of ADH, free-water clearance (CH2O) is negative.
What is the role of thyroid hormone during the perinatal period?	During the perinatal period, thyroid hormone is essential for CNS maturation.
What is the effect of oxygenation of hemoglobin in the lungs?	In the lungs, oxygenation of hemoglobin promotes H+ release from its buffering sites.
What is the effect of hypoxia on the vasculature in the lungs?	In the lungs, hypoxia causes vasoconstriction.
What is the effect of the absence of ADH on free-water clearance (CH2O)?	In the absence of ADH, free-water clearance (CH2O) is positive.
What cells in the collecting duct are responsible for secreting NH3 and H+ into the lumen?	The α-intercalated cells in the collecting duct are responsible for secreting NH3 and H+ into the lumen.
Where does the differentiation of a T cell into a CD4+ or CD8+ T cell occur?	The differentiation of a T cell into a CD4+ or CD8+ T cell occurs in the thymic medulla.
Where in the nephron does simple diffusion cause the secretion of urea?	Simple diffusion causes the secretion of urea in the thin descending limb (Henle's loop) of the nephron.
What happens to the osmolarity of the tubular fluid in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)?	The osmolarity of the tubular fluid decreases in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle).
What happens to 50% of the filtered urea in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron?	50% of the filtered urea is reabsorbed by simple diffusion in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron.
Where in the cell can ethanol be converted to acetaldehyde, and what enzyme is responsible for this conversion?	Ethanol may be converted to acetaldehyde in the peroxisome via the enzyme catalase.
Where does HCO3- enter red blood cells and what ion does it exchange with?	HCO3- enters the red blood cells in the lungs and exchanges with Cl-.
Where do nucleic acids get broken down into nucleotide monomers?	Nucleic acids are broken down into nucleotide monomers in the liver.
What is the leading cause of overdose deaths in the United States?	In the United States, the leading cause of overdose deaths is opioids.
What is the ranking of cancer as a cause of death in the United States?	In the United States, cancer is the second leading cause of death.
What type of disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei is Suramin used for in its treatment?	In the treatment of Trypanosoma brucei, Suramin is used for blood-borne disease.
What type of disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei is Melarsoprol used for in its treatment?	In the treatment of Trypanosoma brucei, Melarsoprol is used for CNS disease.
How does Natalizumab work in the treatment of Multiple Sclerosis?	In the treatment of Multiple Sclerosis, Natalizumab works by preventing extravasation of autoreactive CD8+ T Cells.
How does Denosumab work in the treatment of Giant Cell Tumor Of Bone?	In the treatment of Giant Cell Tumor Of Bone, Denosumab works by binding RANKL expressed on multinucleated Giant Cells.
