How does Lumacaftor work in the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis?	In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Lumacaftor works by facilitating proper folding of the CFTR protein.
How does Ivacaftor work in the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis?	In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Ivacaftor works by stimulating activity of the CFTR protein.
What is Creon (pancrelipase) used for in the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis?	In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Creon (pancrelipase) is a mix of pancreatic enzymes used to restore pancreatic function.
What is the role of Azithromycin in the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis?	In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Azithromycin is used as an anti-inflammatory agent.
What is the purpose of using aerosolized hypertonic saline in the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis?	In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, aerosolized hypertonic saline is used to facilitate mucus clearance.
How does Natalizumab work in the treatment of Crohn's Disease?	In the treatment of Crohn's Disease, Natalizumab works by preventing adhesion of autoreactive gut homing Th17 cells.
How does all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) work in the treatment of Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia?	In the treatment of Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia, all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) prevents differentiation from being halted at the promyelocyte stage.
What happens in the third step of ventricular partitioning?	In the third step of ventricular partitioning, growth of endocardial cushions separates atria from ventricles.
What happens to the osmotic concentration of tubular fluid in the thin descending limb (loop of Henle)?	In the thin descending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively hyper-osmotic as it descends.
How can NH4+ be reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb?	In the thick ascending limb, NH4+ may be reabsorbed by substituting for K+ on the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter.
Where is NH4+ reabsorbed and to what gradient is it added in the kidney?	In the thick ascending limb, NH4+ is reabsorbed and added to the corticopapillary osmotic gradient in the kidney.
What happens to the osmotic concentration of tubular fluid in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)?	In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively hypo-osmotic as it ascends.
What protein binds to dietary vitamin B12 in the stomach, and where is this protein secreted from?	In the stomach, dietary vitamin B12 is bound to the protein R-binder, which is secreted from the salivary glands.
What is the typical value of the respiratory quotient (R) in the steady state?	In the steady state, the respiratory quotient (R) is normally equal to 0.8.
What is the relationship between intracellular osmolarity and extracellular osmolarity in the steady state?	In the steady state, intracellular osmolarity is equal to extracellular osmolarity.
What is the effect of stimulating β3 receptors in skeletal muscle?	Stimulation of β3 receptors in skeletal muscle results in increased thermogenesis.
What can an increased CK suggest in the setting of pleurodynia?	An increased CK in the setting of pleurodynia can suggest intercostal muscle necrosis.
What is the potential use of Bleomycin in the setting of lung cancer/mesothelioma?	In the setting of lung cancer/mesothelioma, Bleomycin can be used to prevent recurrent pleural effusions.
What is the potential consequence of fetal hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinism in the setting of poorly controlled gestational diabetes?	In the setting of gestational diabetes with poor control, fetal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperinsulinism and β cell hyperplasia.
What is the recommended form of aspirin administration in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (MI)?	In the setting of acute MI, aspirin should be administered in a chewable form.
What substance can be used to absorb aspirin in the setting of acute aspirin toxicity?	In the setting of acute aspirin toxicity, activated charcoal can be used to absorb aspirin.
What substance can be used to absorb acetaminophen in the setting of acute acetaminophen toxicity?	In the setting of acute acetaminophen toxicity, activated charcoal can be used to absorb acetaminophen.
What happens in the second step of PCR with regards to the DNA strands to be amplified?	In the second step of PCR, DNA primers anneal to specific sequences on each DNA strand to be amplified.
What structure forms in place of the ostium primum in the second step of atrial partitioning?	In the second step of atrial partitioning, the ostium secundum forms in place of the ostium primum.
What is the relative position of the pulmonary artery to the bronchus in the right lung?	In the right lung, the pulmonary artery is anterior to the bronchus.
What is the fate of glutamate in the proximal tubule and what molecule is ultimately reabsorbed?	In the proximal tubule, glutamate is ultimately metabolized to bicarbonate (HCO3-), which is reabsorbed.
What is the value of [TF/P]osm in the proximal tubule?	In the proximal tubule, [TF/P]osm = 1.
What are the two molecules that NH4+ is in equilibrium with in proximal tubule cells?	In proximal tubule cells, NH4+ is in equilibrium with NH3 and H+.
What effect does the presence of MAO inhibitors have on tyramine when it enters the circulation?	The presence of MAO inhibitors causes tyramine to enter the circulation and act as a sympathomimetic agent.
What is a common manifestation of obsessive-compulsive disorder during the postpartum period?	A common manifestation of obsessive-compulsive disorder during the postpartum period is fears of contaminating and harming the baby.
What hormone stimulates cholesterol desmolase activity in the ovaries?	In the ovaries, cholesterol desmolase activity is stimulated by the hormone LH.
What hormone stimulates aromatase activity in the ovaries?	In the ovaries, aromatase activity is stimulated by the hormone FSH.
What type of shunt does a patent ductus arteriosus become in the neonatal period as pulmonary vascular resistance decreases?	In the neonatal period, a patent ductus arteriosus becomes a left-to-right shunt as pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.
What type of nerve fibers are involved in increasing afferent impulses during the muscle stretch reflex?	During the muscle stretch reflex, stretch increases afferent impulses via Ia nerve fibers.
Which muscles are stimulated by some Ia afferent fibers during the muscle stretch reflex, causing muscle contraction?	During the muscle stretch reflex, some Ia afferent fibers stimulate agonist muscles, causing muscle contraction.
Which muscles are inhibited by some Ia afferent fibers through interneurons during the muscle stretch reflex, causing muscle relaxation?	During the muscle stretch reflex, some Ia afferent fibers inhibit antagonist muscles through interneurons causing muscle relaxation.
What effect does estradiol have on the secretion of FSH and LH during the middle of the menstrual cycle?	During the middle of the menstrual cycle, estradiol stimulates the secretion of FSH and LH.
What event occurs in the middle of the menstrual cycle and how many days prior to menses does it occur?	In the middle of the menstrual cycle, ovulation occurs, which happens 14 days prior to menses.
What is the role of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome in male development and what does it produce?	In the male, the SRY gene on the Y chromosome is responsible for testes development, and it produces testis-determining factor.
What is the specific apoprotein that chylomicrons express exclusively in the lymph?	In the lymph, chylomicrons express only apoprotein B-48.
What substances combine in the lumen of the proximal tubule to form NH4+?	In the lumen of the proximal tubule, NH3 and H+ combine to form NH4+.
Which molecule in the liver can transfer a molecule of NH3 to the urea cycle and reform α-ketoglutarate?	In the liver, glutamate can transfer a molecule of NH3 to the urea cycle and reform α-ketoglutarate.
What enzyme in the liver converts unconjugated bilirubin to conjugated bilirubin?	The enzyme UDP-glucuronyl transferase converts unconjugated bilirubin to conjugated bilirubin in the liver.
What molecule can glutamate transfer its NH3 to in the liver, and what are the resulting products of this reaction?	In the liver, glutamate can transfer its NH3 to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate and α-ketoglutarate.
What amino acids are bile acids conjugated to in the liver, and what is the resulting product of this conjugation?	In the liver, bile acids are conjugated to the amino acids glycine or taurine to form bile salts.
In the left lung, where is the pulmonary artery located in relation to the bronchus?	In the left lung, the pulmonary artery is located superior to the bronchus.
In the late phase of liquefactive necrosis, what organ or tissue may show the presence of cystic spaces and cavitation?	In the late phase of liquefactive necrosis of the brain, cystic spaces and cavitation may be seen.
What is the mechanism by which Na+ reabsorption may occur in the late proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?	In the late PCT, Na+ reabsorption may occur through the Na+-H+ exchange mechanism.
What is the value of [TF/P]osm in the late distal tubule when there is high ADH?	In the late distal tubule, [TF/P]osm equals 1 when there is high ADH.
What is the value of [TF/P]osm in the late distal tubule when there is low ADH?	In the late distal tubule, [TF/P]osm is less than 1 when there is low ADH.
What are the products of the breakdown of glutamine in the kidney, and what enzyme is responsible for this process?	In the kidney, glutamine is broken down into NH3 and glutamate via the enzyme glutaminase.
Which amino acid breakdown can lead to the production of NH3 in the intestine?	In the intestine, the breakdown of the amino acid glutamine can lead to the production of NH3.
What is responsible for the production of NH3 in the intestine?	In the intestine, NH3 may be produced by intestinal bacteria.
What type of insulin regimen can sliding scale insulin be added to in the inpatient setting?	In the inpatient setting, sliding scale insulin can be added to an existing basal-bolus regimen.
Where does coarctation of the aorta lie in relation to the aortic arch and the PDA in the infantile form?	In the infantile form, coarctation of the aorta lies after the aortic arch, but before the PDA.
What type of precautions are required for patients in the hospital with multi-drug resistant organisms, enteric organisms, and scabies?	Patients in the hospital with multi-drug resistant organisms, enteric organisms, and scabies require contact precautions.
What molecule is added to proteins in the Golgi apparatus for trafficking to lysosomes?	In the Golgi apparatus, mannose-6-phosphate is added to proteins for trafficking to lysosomes.
What is the expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in the following group of diseases?	The expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in this group of diseases is greater than 50.
What is the expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in the following group of diseases?	The expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in this group of diseases is less than 20.
What is the expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in the following group of diseases?	The expected ratio of conjugated bilirubin to total bilirubin in this group of diseases is between 20 and 50.
Which hormone is responsible for stimulating the development of multiple follicles in the follicular phase?	The hormone responsible for stimulating the development of multiple follicles in the follicular phase is FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone).
What happens in the first step of ventricular partitioning?	In the first step of ventricular partitioning, the muscular interventricular septum develops and forms the interventricular foramen.
What happens in the first step of thyroid hormone synthesis?	In the first step of thyroid hormone synthesis, thyroglobulin is synthesized from tyrosine in the thyroid follicular cells.
What is the enzyme involved in the first step of testosterone synthesis and what is its function?	In the first step of testosterone synthesis, cholesterol is converted to pregnenolone via the enzyme cholesterol desmolase.
What binds to the A site in the first step of strand elongation?	In the first step of strand elongation, an aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site.
What is the first step of PCR, and how is it achieved?	The first step of PCR involves denaturing DNA by using heat to separate the strands.
What is the first step of fibrinolysis, and what are the molecules involved in this step?	The first step of fibrinolysis involves the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, which then binds to fibrin.
What is the first step of fibrinolysis, and what molecule and enzyme are involved in this step?	The first step of fibrinolysis involves the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin via tissue plasminogen activator (tPA).
What is the first step of collagen synthesis, and what molecule is formed through the translation of collagen alpha chains?	The first step of collagen synthesis involves the formation of preprocollagen through the translation of collagen alpha chains.
What is the gold standard for diagnosis of myocardial infarction within the first 6 hours?	Within the first 6 hours, the gold standard for diagnosis of myocardial infarction is the electrocardiogram (ECG).
What are the three joints that make up the elbow, and what are their specific names?	The elbow consists of three joints: the Radiocapitellar Joint, the Ulnohumeral Joint, and the Proximal Radioulnar Joint.
What happens to the mesonephric (wolffian) and paramesonephric (müllerian) ducts during the development of a female?	During the development of a female, the mesonephric (wolffian) duct degenerates and the paramesonephric (müllerian) duct develops.
At what point during fetal development does surfactant synthesis begin?	In the developing fetus, surfactant synthesis begins as early as gestational week 20.
At what point during fetal development are mature levels of surfactant typically achieved?	In the developing fetus, mature levels of surfactant are not achieved until around week 35.
What is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of malate to pyruvate in the cytosol during fatty acid synthesis?	In the cytosol, malate may be converted to pyruvate via the enzyme malic enzyme (fatty acid synthesis).
What is the main protein that thyroid hormones T3 and T4 bind to in the circulation?	In the circulation, most of the T3 and T4 is bound to thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG).
What is the name of the receptor through which histamine may regulate sleep and arousal in the brain?	In the brain, histamine may regulate sleep and arousal via its H1 receptor.
What are the names of the apoproteins that VLDLs pick up from circulating HDL in the blood?	In the blood, VLDLs pick up apoprotein C-II and E from circulating HDL.
What are the names of the apoproteins that chylomicrons pick up from circulating HDL in the blood?	In the blood, chylomicrons pick up apoprotein C-II and E from circulating HDL.
What is the lowest vertebrae to which the subarachnoid space extends in the adult spinal cord?	In the adult spinal cord, the subarachnoid space extends to the lower border of S2 vertebrae.
Where does coarctation of the aorta lie in the adult form?	In the adult form, coarctation of the aorta lies after the aortic arch.
In the adult form of coarctation of the aorta, where does collateral circulation develop most notably?	In the adult form of coarctation of the aorta, collateral circulation develops most notably across the intercostal arteries.
During which phase of the action potential of axons is K+ ion permeance the highest?	In the action potential of axons, K+ ion permeance is highest during the repolarization phase of the action potential.
Does infusion of normal saline cause hyponatremia in the absence of SIADH?	No, infusion of normal saline does not cause hyponatremia in the absence of SIADH.
How can an open globe laceration be inferred in the absence of an obvious wound?	In the absence of an obvious wound, an open globe laceration may be inferred by a peaked or teardrop pupil.
What happens to the corticopapillary osmotic gradient in the absence of ADH?	In the absence of ADH, the corticopapillary osmotic gradient is smaller.
According to the "seed and soil" theory of metastasis, what is the seed?	According to the "seed and soil" theory of metastasis, the seed is the tumor embolus.
How can ovulatory function be gauged in testing for infertility?	Ovulatory function can be gauged in testing for infertility by testing mid luteal phase serum progesterone level.
Which is more common in terms of bone tumors, bone metastases or primary bone tumors?	Bone metastases are significantly more common than primary bone tumors.
What is the most common anatomic deformity in teenagers that increases the risk of testicular torsion?	The most common anatomic deformity in teenagers that increases the risk of testicular torsion is the Bell Clapper deformity.
At what Tanner stage is a person pre-pubertal with no pubic hair and a flat chest?	A person is pre-pubertal with no pubic hair and a flat chest at Tanner stage I.
At what Tanner stage does the penis width and glans increase and the breast enlarge with raised areola?	The penis width and glans increase and the breast enlarges with raised areola at Tanner stage IV.
At what Tanner stage does pubic hair appear, breast buds form, and testicular enlargement occur?	Pubic hair appears (pubarche), breast buds form (thelarche), and testicular enlargement occurs at Tanner stage II.
At what Tanner stage does the pubic hair coarsen, the penis size increase, and the breast enlarge?	The pubic hair coarsens, the penis size increases, and the breast enlarges at Tanner stage III.
What causes ventricular apical ballooning in Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy?	Ventricular apical ballooning in Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is caused by increased sympathetic stimulation.
What is the cause of excess ADH secretion in Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH)?	Excess ADH secretion in Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) is caused by secretion from an autonomous site.
What is the cause of increased mineralocorticoid receptor activity in Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?	Increased mineralocorticoid receptor activity in Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess is caused by excess cortisol.
What is the effect of leptomeningeal angiomas in Sturge-Weber syndrome?	Leptomeningeal angiomas in Sturge-Weber syndrome increase vascularity of the pia and arachnoid mater, eventually growing into the subarachnoid space.
What is the typical location of leptomengeal angiomas in relation to the nevus flammeus in Sturge-Weber syndrome?	Leptomengeal angiomas in Sturge-Weber syndrome are typically ipsilateral to the nevus flammeus.
What is the hemoglobin level at which packed RBC transfusion is indicated in stable patients?	In stable patients, packed RBC transfusion is indicated once the hemoglobin drops below 7 g/dL.
What is the product of heme metabolism in splenic macrophages and which enzyme is responsible for this process?	In splenic macrophages, heme is metabolized to biliverdin by the enzyme heme oxygenase.
What is the end product of the reduction of biliverdin in splenic macrophages?	In splenic macrophages, biliverdin is reduced to (unconjugated) bilirubin.
What is the effect of leaning forward on pain in spinal stenosis?	In spinal stenosis, leaning forward improves pain.
What is the first step in evaluating someone suspected of having meningitis?	In someone with suspected meningitis, the first step is to get blood cultures.
Which androgen is the active hormone in certain tissues such as the prostate, rather than testosterone?	In some tissues, such as the prostate, dihydrotestosterone is the active androgen, not testosterone.
Is it common to observe pathology on the initial x-ray in Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis?	Yes, it is common to observe pathology on the initial x-ray in Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis.
What is the end product of glycogenolysis in skeletal muscle, and how is it metabolized during exercise?	In skeletal muscle, glycogenolysis ultimately produces glucose-6-phosphate, which is rapidly metabolized during exercise.
In silicosis, what happens to the nodules and what is the resulting structure of the lung tissue?	In silicosis, nodules coalesce to form large scars with areas of "honeycombing" in between (cystically dilated).
What causes the overlap of mutated hemoglobin molecules in sickle cells?	In sickle cells, the mutated hemoglobin molecules overlap due to increased hydrophobic/nonpolar interactions between hemoglobin molecules.
Where is a single stone more commonly found in sialolithiasis, and in which duct specifically?	In sialolithiasis, a single stone is more common in the submandibular gland, specifically in the Wharton duct.
What happens to urinary sodium levels in SIADH?	In SIADH, urinary sodium levels are increased (> 40 mEq/L).
What is the role of ANP and BNP in urinary excretion in SIADH?	In SIADH, the atria and ventricles release ANP and BNP, which further contribute to urinary excretion of sodium.
Why must serum Na+ levels be corrected slowly in SIADH, and what condition is this intended to prevent?	In SIADH, serum Na+ levels must be corrected slowly to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome.
What is the role of RAAS in urinary excretion in SIADH, and why is it deactivated?	In SIADH, RAAS is deactivated due to detection of volume expansion, which further contributes to urinary excretion of sodium.
What is the reason for the absence of menses in the postpartum period in Sheehan syndrome?	In Sheehan syndrome, menses may not resume in the postpartum period due to decreased FSH and LH.
What is the cause of headache and vision changes in severe preeclampsia?	In severe preeclampsia, headache and vision changes are due to vasoconstriction of carotid artery branches.
How do hormone levels and FSH levels compare to LH levels in senescence?	In senescence, hormone levels are highest and FSH levels are greater than LH levels.
What are the results of the metyrapone stimulation test in secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency?	In secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency, the metyrapone stimulation test results are decreased ACTH with decreased 11-deoxycortisol.
What is the cause of elevated PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism?	In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated secondary to hypocalcemia (or hyperphosphatemia).
What is the cause of elevated PTH levels in chronic renal disease in the context of secondary hyperparathyroidism?	In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated secondary to hypocalcemia (or hyperphosphatemia) in chronic renal disease.
What is the treatment for scoliosis when the Cobb angle is greater than 40-50 degrees?	In scoliosis, a Cobb angle of >40-50 degrees is treated with surgical fixation.
What is the treatment for scoliosis when the Cobb angle is greater than 30 degrees?	In scoliosis, a Cobb angle of >30 degrees is treated with thoracolumbosacral spinal brace.
What is the recommended course of action for scoliosis when the Cobb angle ranges from 10-30 degrees?	In scoliosis, a Cobb angle of 10-30 degrees is treated with clinical monitoring every 6 months.
What can occur in the lungs of a person with sarcoidosis as a result of pulmonary granulomas?	In sarcoidosis, pulmonary granulomas may be replaced by diffuse interstitial fibrosis.
What biological mechanism is responsible for fibroblast activation and fibrosis in Riedel's thyroiditis?	In Riedel's thyroiditis, release of cytokines (e.g. TGF-β, IL-13) leads to fibroblast activation and fibrosis.
What condition may Riedel thyroiditis mimic due to the extension of fibrosis to local structures such as the airway?	In Riedel thyroiditis, fibrosis may extend to local structures (e.g. airway), thus mimicking anaplastic carcinoma.
What is the mechanism by which aspirin can contribute to the development of Reye syndrome?	In Reye syndrome, aspirin can act as an uncoupling agent in oxidative phosphorylation.
What is the response of breathing rate to a decrease in pH sensed by chemoreceptors?	In response to decreased pH sensed by chemoreceptors, the breathing rate increases (hyperventilation).
What is the effect of increased sympathetic tone on renin release?	In response to increased sympathetic tone, there is increased renin release.
What is the effect of decreased blood pressure on renin release as mediated by the JG cells of the kidney?	In response to decreased blood pressure, the JG cells of the kidney cause increased renin release.
What is the effect of strenuous exercise on pH, and what is the underlying cause of this effect?	In response to strenuous exercise, there is decreased pH, secondary to lactic acidosis.
What is the effect of sleep deprivation on leptin secretion?	In response to sleep deprivation, leptin secretion is decreased.
What is the effect of sleep deprivation on ghrelin secretion?	In response to sleep deprivation, ghrelin secretion is increased.
What is the physiological response to increased Pco2 in the brain?	In response to increased Pco2 in the brain, there is intense peripheral vasoconstriction.
What is the effect of increased Na+ intake and extracellular fluid (ECF) volume on ANP activity?	In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is increased ANP activity.
What is the effect of increased Na+ intake and extracellular fluid (ECF) volume on sympathetic activity?	In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased sympathetic activity.
What is the effect of increased Na+ intake and extracellular fluid (ECF) volume on renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity?	In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity.
What is the effect of increased Na+ intake and extracellular fluid (ECF) volume on peritubular capillary oncotic pressure?	In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased peritubular capillary oncotic pressure.
What is the effect of increased Na+ delivery on the efferent arterioles and renin release, mediated by the macula densa?	In response to increased Na+ delivery, the macula densa causes decreased renin release, which ultimately relaxes the efferent arterioles.
What are the physiological changes that occur in response to high altitude, specifically regarding chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction?	In response to high altitude, chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction occurs, which results in pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy.
What is the effect of high altitude on the levels of 2,3-BPG?	In response to high altitude, there is an increase in the levels of 2,3-BPG.
What is the effect of high altitude on ventilation, specifically in terms of chronic changes?	In response to high altitude, there is a chronic increase in ventilation.
What are some of the cellular changes that occur in response to high altitude?	In response to high altitude, there are cellular changes, such as an increase in the number of mitochondria.
What are the cellular responses to fatty streaks in the intima?	In response to fatty streaks in the intima, there is smooth muscle cell migration/proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.
What is the effect of exercise on ventilation rate and oxygen demand?	In response to exercise, there is an increased ventilation rate to meet the increased oxygen demand.
What happens to venous CO2 content in response to exercise?	In response to exercise, there is an increased venous CO2 content.
What is the relationship between exercise, pulmonary blood flow, and cardiac output?	In response to exercise, there is an increased pulmonary blood flow, which is due to the increased cardiac output.
What is the effect of exercise on oxygen consumption?	In response to exercise, there is an increased oxygen consumption.
What is the effect of exercise on CO2 production?	In response to exercise, there is an increased CO2 production.
What happens to venous O2 content in response to exercise?	In response to exercise, there is a decreased venous O2 content.
How does the V/Q ratio change from apex to base in response to exercise?	In response to exercise, the V/Q ratio from apex to base becomes more even.
What happens to ventilation in response to decreased Pao2, such as in high altitude?	In response to decreased Pao2, such as in high altitude, there is increased ventilation.
What does the macula densa release in response to decreased Na+ delivery and what is the effect on the arterioles?	In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa releases PGE2, which relaxes the afferent arterioles.
What is the effect of decreased atmospheric oxygen, such as at high altitude, on Pao2?	In response to decreased atmospheric oxygen, such as at high altitude, there is a decreased Pao2.
What is the effect of decreased afferent baroreceptor firing on efferent sympathetic firing in the baroreceptor reflex?	In response to decreased afferent baroreceptor firing, there is increased efferent sympathetic firing in the baroreceptor reflex.
What is the effect of decreased afferent baroreceptor firing on efferent parasympathetic firing in the baroreceptor reflex?	In response to decreased afferent baroreceptor firing, there is decreased efferent parasympathetic firing in the baroreceptor reflex.
What changes occur in collagen synthesis and crosslinking in relation to wrinkles of aging?	In regards to wrinkles of aging, there is decreased synthesis of collagen fibrils and increased crosslinking of collagen.
What factors may protect against ventricular free wall rupture in patients with myocardial infarction?	In regards to myocardial infarction complications, LV hypertrophy and previous MI may protect against ventricular free wall rupture.
Where is adenocarcinoma in situ typically located in the lungs?	In regards to lung neoplasias, adenocarcinoma in situ is typically peripherally located in the lungs.
What hormone may be elevated in rare cases of seminomas?	In rare cases of seminomas, the hormone hCG may be elevated.
What is the ultimate product of purine metabolism and what is its relationship to xanthine oxidase?	In Purine metabolism, purines are ultimately converted to hypoxanthine, which is a substrate for xanthine oxidase.
What effect does increased ENaC activity, due to aldosterone, have on lumen in principal cells?	In principal cells, increased ENaC activity due to aldosterone causes an increase in lumen negativity.
How should vaccines be administered in preterm infants?	In preterm infants, all vaccines should be administered according to chronologic age.
What is the effect on reabsorption of Na+ and H2O in prerenal azotemia?	In prerenal azotemia, there is increased reabsorption of Na+ and H2O.
What happens to the ratio of BUN/creatinine in prerenal azotemia?	In prerenal azotemia, there is an increase in the ratio of BUN/creatinine to more than 20.
What is the typical BUN:creatinine ratio in prerenal azotemia?	In prerenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is > 15.
What is the effect of decreased GFR in prerenal azotemia on the levels of BUN and serum creatinine?	In prerenal azotemia, decreased GFR causes increased levels of BUN and serum creatinine.
What medications should pregnant women and children who have been infected with Borrelia Burgdorferi receive?	Pregnant women and children who have been infected with Borrelia Burgdorferi should receive amoxicillin and cefuroxime.
Which vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy?	Vaccines that are contraindicated during pregnancy include HPV, MMR(V), live influenza, and varicella.
Which genes are affected in Prader-Willi syndrome?	Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by the imprinting of the maternal gene and the mutation/deletion of the paternal gene.
What is the consequence of oligohydramnios in Potter sequence?	Oligohydramnios in Potter sequence leads to pulmonary hypoplasia.
What is the effect of oligohydramnios in Potter sequence on the developing fetus?	Oligohydramnios in Potter sequence causes compression of the developing fetus.
What is the consequence of compression of the developing fetus in Potter sequence?	Compression of the developing fetus in Potter sequence results in limb deformities.
What are the facial features associated with compression of the developing fetus in Potter sequence?	Compression of the developing fetus in Potter sequence results in a flat face with low-set ears.
What is the mechanism behind the development of varices in portal hypertension?	In portal hypertension, the left gastric vein backs up into the esophageal vein, resulting in varices.
What is the hormonal imbalance that leads to hirsutism in polycystic ovarian syndrome?	In polycystic ovarian syndrome, increased LH production causes excess androgen production (from theca cells), resulting in hirsutism.
How are the cysts typically distributed in polycystic kidney disease?	In polycystic kidney disease, cysts are usually bi-lateral.
What is the factor that determines the resistance in Poiseuille's equation?	In Poiseuille's equation, Resistance is directly proportional to the viscosity (η) of the blood.
What is the mechanism behind the development of restrictive lung disease in pneumoconiosis?	In pneumoconiosis, release of growth factors leads to production of collagen, which causes restrictive lung disease.
What is the fate of small particles (1-5 microns in diameter) in the lungs in pneumoconioses?	In pneumoconioses, small particles (1-5 microns in diameter) are trapped at the bifurcation of respiratory bronchioles.
What is the fate of medium particles (5-10 microns in diameter) in the lungs in pneumoconioses?	In pneumoconioses, medium particles (5-10 microns in diameter) are cleared by mucociliary transport in the trachea and bronchi.
What is the fate of large particles (10-15 microns in diameter) in the lungs in pneumoconioses?	In pneumoconioses, large particles (10-15 microns in diameter) are trapped in the upper airway.
What is the mechanism behind unconjugated bilirubin deposition in the brain in physiological neonatal jaundice?	Unconjugated bilirubin deposits in the brain, especially in the basal ganglia, in physiological neonatal jaundice.
What is the process of purine excretion in physiological homeostasis?	In physiological homeostasis, purines are excreted by way of metabolism to uric acid.
What is peripheral cyanosis and how does it affect the extremities of patients?	Peripheral cyanosis is a condition characterized by low blood flow, and it causes patients to have cold extremities.
What is the potential consequence of thrombus embolization in peripheral artery disease?	In peripheral artery disease, embolization of thrombus can travel to smaller downstream arteries and cause acute limb ischemia.
What is the underlying cause of calf claudications in peripheral artery disease?	In peripheral artery disease, calf claudications are caused by lesions in the superficial femoral artery.
What artery is affected in peripheral artery disease that leads to buttock pain and erectile dysfunction?	In peripheral artery disease, buttock pain and erectile dysfunction are due to lesions in the internal iliac artery.
What effect can excess androgens in the ovaries have on granulosa cells in PCOS?	In PCOS, excess androgens in the ovaries may cause granulosa cell dysfunction.
What is the purpose of urinary catheter placement in patients with traumatic spinal cord injury?	In patients with traumatic spinal cord injury, urinary catheter placement can assess for urinary retention and prevent acute bladder distention/damage.
What is a common finding on physical exam in patients with tracheomalacia?	In patients with tracheomalacia, expiratory stridor is heard on physical exam.
What class of antibiotics should be given to patients with streptococcal infections who are allergic to penicillin?	Macrolides should be given to patients with streptococcal infections who are allergic to penicillin.
What is the recommended follow-up for patients with stable angina and intermediate pretest probability of CAD?	In patients with stable angina and intermediate pretest probability of CAD, follow-up with cardiac stress testing should occur.
How does thrombocytopenia manifest in patients with SLE?	In patients with SLE, thrombocytopenia may manifest through immune-mediated peripheral destruction.
How does leukopenia manifest in patients with SLE?	In patients with SLE, leukopenia may manifest through immune-mediated peripheral destruction.
At what age does chronic damage and autoinfarction typically cause functional asplenia in patients with sickle cell disease?	Chronic damage and autoinfarction typically cause functional asplenia by age 5 in patients with sickle cell disease.
What is the prophylactic use of Hydroxyurea in patients with Sickle Cell Anemia?	Hydroxyurea is used prophylactically in patients with Sickle Cell Anemia to reduce veno-occlusive crises.
What is the most common causative agent of osteomyelitis in patients with Sickle Cell Disease?	In patients with Sickle Cell Disease, osteomyelitis is most commonly caused by Salmonella species.
What is the highest risk factor for fragility fracture in patients with osteoporosis?	In patients with osteoporosis, the highest risk factor for fragility fracture is having a history of prior fragility fracture.
What is the movement that causes pain in patients with Osgood-Schlatter Disease?	In patients with Osgood-Schlatter Disease, pain is typically reported on resisted knee extension.
What is the risk associated with supplemental oxygen therapy in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome?	In patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, supplemental oxygen therapy increases the risk for free radical injury.
What is the main contributor to respiratory drive in patients with long standing COPD?	In patients with long standing COPD, the main contributor to respiratory drive is arterial PaO2 levels.
What are the necessary steps to prevent permanent and disabling injury in patients with limb compartment syndrome?	In patients with limb compartment syndrome, early diagnosis and fasciotomy are necessary steps to prevent permanent and disabling injury.
What diagnostic and potentially therapeutic procedure is used in patients with intussusception?	In patients with intussusception, a barium enema is the diagnostic and potentially therapeutic procedure that is used.
What type of antibodies are useful for diagnosis in patients with IgA deficiency and celiac disease?	In patients with IgA deficiency and celiac disease, IgG antibodies against endomysium, tTG, or gliadin are useful for diagnosis.
What does intestinal biopsy reveal in patients with hereditary lactose intolerance?	In patients with hereditary lactose intolerance, intestinal biopsy reveals normal mucosa.
What is an alternative method for diagnosing meniscal tear in patients who have contraindications to MRI?	In patients with contraindications to MRI, meniscal tear can be diagnosed by knee arthroscopy.
What is the reason for Bevacizumab being contraindicated in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease?	In patients with cardiovascular disease history, Bevacizumab is contraindicated due to the increased risk of thrombotic events.
What is the duration of succinylcholine induced paralysis in patients with a BCHE mutation?	In patients with a BCHE mutation, succinylcholine induced paralysis lasts for hours.
What is an important side effect of ruxolitinib that patients should be aware of?	In patients taking ruxolitinib, an important side effect is hepatotoxicity.
How is the split sound in paradoxical splitting eliminated?	In paradoxical splitting, the split sound is "paradoxically" eliminated with inspiration.
What are the effects of overexpression of VEGF in ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome?	In ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, overexpression of VEGF leads to increased vascular permeability and capillary leakage.
What do activated chondrocytes release in osteoarthritis and what are its effects?	In osteoarthritis, activated chondrocytes release Matrix Metalloproteinases (MMP), which induces destruction of ECM cartilage and chondrocytes.
What type of tumors are present in Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica?	In Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica, there are brown tumors.
How can healed microavulsions be detected on physical exam in Osgood Schlatter?	In Osgood Schlatter, healed microavulsions can be noted on physical exam by the presence of a pronounced/enlarged tibial tubercle.
What is the order of administration for the medications used to treat organophosphate poisoning?	In organophosphate poisoning, atropine is given first and pralidoxime is given second.
What is the minimum Bishop score required for induction of labor?	In order to do induction of labor, the Bishop score must be greater than 6.
What is the mechanism by which platelets adhere to damaged endothelium?	In order to adhere to the damaged endothelium, platelets bind von Willebrand factor (vWF) using the GPIb receptor.
What condition may REM sleep behavior disorder indicate in older patients?	In older patients, REM sleep behavior disorder may be a sign of neurodegeneration, such as Parkinson’s disease.
How is cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure affected in normal pressure hydrocephalus?	In normal pressure hydrocephalus, CSF pressure is episodically elevated.
What type of gas exchange does oxygen exhibit in normal health?	In normal health, oxygen exhibits perfusion-limited gas exchange.
Does normal conjugation involve transfer of bacterial chromosomal DNA?	No, in normal conjugation, transfer of plasmids only occurs, not bacterial chromosomal DNA.
How long may the latent period be in noncommunicable chronic diseases?	In noncommunicable chronic diseases, the latent period may be long.
What do cutaneous neurofibromas stain positive for in NF1?	In NF1, cutaneous neurofibromas stain positive for S100.
What can homozygous protein C or S deficiency cause in newborns?	In newborns, homozygous protein C or S deficiency can cause neonatal purpura fulminans.
What type of paracentesis should be performed in new-onset ascites to rule out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?	In new-onset ascites, paracentesis with cell count and differential should be performed to rule out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
What type of transient ipsilateral paralysis does an interscalene nerve block cause in nearly all patients?	In nearly all patients, an interscalene nerve block also causes transient ipsilateral diaphragmatic paralysis.
What is the configuration of double bonds in naturally occurring fatty acids?	In naturally occurring fatty acids, double bonds are in the cis configuration.
Where is light focused in myopia (nearsightedness)?	In myopia (nearsightedness), light is focused in front of the retina.
In myelofibrosis, what do megakaryocytes produce in excess that causes activation of fibroblasts and marrow fibrosis?	In myelofibrosis, megakaryocytes produce excess platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-b causing activation of fibroblasts and marrow fibrosis.
What substances do megakaryocytes produce in excess in myelofibrosis, leading to marrow fibrosis?	In myelofibrosis, megakaryocytes produce excess platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-b, causing marrow fibrosis.
How do nodes of Ranvier in myelinated cells increase conduction velocity?	In myelinated cells, nodes of Ranvier increase conduction velocity via saltatory conduction.
What happens during muscle contraction when myosin binds to actin after releasing Pi?	During muscle contraction, the power stroke occurs when myosin binds to actin after releasing Pi.
What is the effect of hyperthyroidism on the expression of cardiac sarcolemmal ATPase and phospholamban in muscle cells?	In muscle cells, hyperthyroidism increases expression of cardiac sarcolemmal ATPase and decreases expression of phospholamban.
What is the cause of renal insufficiency in multiple myeloma, and how does it manifest in tissue?	In multiple myeloma, renal insufficiency is partially due to amyloidosis, which deposits as extracellular fibrils in tissue.
What is the cause of renal insufficiency in multiple myeloma, specifically related to excess serum concentrations of an ion?	In multiple myeloma, renal insufficiency is partially due to excess serum concentrations of calcium, which can cause metastatic calcification.
What specific substance do neoplastic plasma cells produce in multiple myeloma that stimulates osteoclast activating factor?	In multiple myeloma, neoplastic plasma cells produce IL-6 which stimulates osteoclast activating factor.
What is the typical physiological response to hypoxia in most organs?	In most organs, hypoxia leads to compensatory vasodilation.
What is a potential finding in light microscopy of the nephron cells in minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis)?	In minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis), lipids may be seen in proximal tubule cells of the nephron (light microscopy).
During which stage(s) of pregnancy is the placenta the source of steroid hormones?	In mid-to-late pregnancy (second and third trimester), the source of steroid hormones is the placenta.
What is the typical reticulocyte count in microcytic anemia?	In microcytic anemia, the reticulocyte count is low (less than 3%).
What is the substance that accumulates in the lysosomes of oligodendrocytes in metachromatic leukodystrophy?	In metachromatic leukodystrophy, sulfatides accumulate in the lysosomes of oligodendrocytes.
What is the effect of increased levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) in men?	In men, increased levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) causes decreased free testosterone, which can lead to gynecomastia.
What are the symptoms of hypogonadism in men due to testosterone deficiency?	In men, hypogonadism presents with impotence and infertility due to testosterone deficiency.
What happens in megaloblastic anemia when immature megaloblasts in the bone marrow rupture?	In megaloblastic anemia, immature megaloblasts in the bone marrow can rupture, releasing LDH and unconjugated bilirubin.
What is the equation for calculating plateau pressure in mechanically ventilated patients?	In mechanically ventilated patients, plateau pressure is equal to the sum of elastic pressure and PEEP.
What is the equation for calculating peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) in mechanically ventilated patients?	In mechanically ventilated patients, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) is equal to the sum of resistive pressure and plateau pressure.
What does an increased peak pressure and unchanged plateau pressure suggest in mechanically ventilated patients?	In mechanically ventilated patients, an increased peak pressure with an unchanged plateau pressure suggests increased airway resistance.
What does an increased peak pressure and increased plateau pressure suggest in mechanically ventilated patients?	In mechanically ventilated patients, an increased peak pressure with an increased plateau pressure suggests decreased compliance.
In males, what is the position of the ureters in relation to the vas deferens?	In males, the ureters pass under the vas deferens.
What are the common symptoms of prolactinoma in males?	In males, prolactinoma presents as headache, decreased libido, and infertility.
What are the effects of exogenous testosterone on males?	In males, exogenous testosterone causes decreased intratesticular testosterone, leading to decreased testicular size and azoospermia.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting androgens in males?	In males, androgens are converted to estrogen by cytochrome P-450 aromatase.
Where does the conversion of androgens to estrogen primarily occur in males?	In males, androgens are converted to estrogen primarily in adipose tissue and the testis.
What are the effects of RBC rupture in malaria?	In malaria, RBCs rupture as part of the Plasmodium life cycle, resulting in intravascular hemolysis and cyclical fever.
What type of symptoms are common in major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern?	In major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern, atypical symptoms are common (ex. hypersomnia, hyperphagia, leaden paralysis).
What types of cells make up the neoplastic cells in the bone marrow in LymphoPlasmacytic Lymphoma?	In LymphoPlasmacytic Lymphoma, neoplastic cells in the bone marrow are a combination of plasma cells and lymphoid cells.
What type of immunoglobulin do monoclonal plasma cells secrete in LymphoPlasmacytic Lymphoma?	In LymphoPlasmacytic Lymphoma, monoclonal plasma cells secrete IgM.
What happens to the kappa to lambda light chain ratio in monoclonal Lymphoma?	In Lymphoma, which is monoclonal, the kappa to lambda light chain ratio increases to > 6:1 or is inverted.
What are the characteristics of secondary follicles in lymph nodes?	In lymph nodes, secondary follicles have pale, central germinal centers and are active.
What are the characteristics of primary follicles in lymph nodes?	In lymph nodes, primary follicles are dense and dormant.
What is the BUN:creatinine ratio in long-standing postrenal azotemia?	In long-standing postrenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is < 15.
What enzyme in liver microsomes converts ethanol to acetaldehyde?	In liver microsomes, ethanol may be converted to acetaldehyde via the enzyme CYP2E1.
Is pathology often observed on the initial x-ray in Legg-Calvé-Perthes?	No.
What is the mechanism of obstruction of blood to the femoral head in Legg-Calvé-Perthes?	In Legg-Calvé-Perthes, there is an idiopathic mechanism of obstruction of blood to the femoral head.
What happens to the trachea in large pleural effusions?	In large pleural effusions, the trachea may deviate away from the side of the lesion.
What is the effect of the accumulation of galactocerebroside and psychosine in Krabbe disease?	In Krabbe disease, galactocerebroside and psychosine accumulate in macrophages and destroy the myelin sheath.
What is the recommended follow-up test if a rapid strep test is negative in children?	In kids, a negative rapid strep test should always be confirmed with throat culture before treating with penicillin/amoxicillin.
What are some of the severe complications that may result from fetal alcohol syndrome?	In its most severe form, fetal alcohol syndrome may cause heart-lung fistulas and holoprosencephaly.
What is the "halo sign" in the context of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?	In invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, the "halo sign" refers to nodular lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities.
What is the mechanism by which cell-cell contacts are lost in invasive carcinoma?	In invasive carcinoma, cell-cell contacts are lost by inactivation of E-cadherin.
How long is the incubation period generally in infectious diseases?	In infectious diseases, the incubation period is generally short.
How does the required amount of local anesthetics change in infected (acidic) tissue?	In infected (acidic) tissue, more local anesthetics are required to achieve the desired effect.
What is the recommended treatment for infants under one month old?	In infants < 1 month old, only azithromycin is used.
What is the status of HBe in inactive chronic HBV?	In inactive chronic HBV, HBe is negative.
What is the status of Anti-HBe in inactive chronic HBV?	In inactive chronic HBV, Anti-HBe is positive.
How does toxoplasmosis typically present in immunocompetent individuals?	In immunocompetent individuals, toxoplasmosis is asymptomatic or will present as a mononucleosis-like illness.
What is the typical clinical presentation of Cryptosporidium infection in immunocompetent individuals?	In immunocompetent individuals, Cryptosporidium infection causes a self-limiting watery diarrhea.
What is the cause of pain in Iliotibial Band Syndrome?	In Iliotibial Band Syndrome, pain develops secondary to friction of the iliotibial band against the lateral femoral epicondyle.
What is the mechanism of spherocyte formation in IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia?	In IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia, the membrane of the antibody-coated RBCs is consumed by splenic macrophages, resulting in spherocyte formation.
Which structures are commonly affected by myxedema in hypothyroidism patients, and what are the resulting symptoms?	In hypothyroidism patients, myxedema commonly affects the larynx, causing a deep voice, and the tongue, causing enlargement.
What is the relationship between hypocortisolism and gluconeogenesis, and what is the resulting effect on blood glucose levels?	In hypocortisolism, there is decreased gluconeogenesis, resulting in hypoglycemia, and vice versa.
In hyperopia (farsightedness), where is light focused in relation to the retina?	In hyperopia (farsightedness), light is focused behind the retina.
What is the underlying cause of hyperkalemia in hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis (RTA)?	In hyperkalemic RTA, hypoaldosteronism is the underlying cause of hyperkalemia.
Where does the dilation occur in relation to the site of pathology in hydronephrosis?	In hydronephrosis, the dilation occurs proximal to the site of pathology.
What are some non-specific symptoms that may be present in HIV-associated dementia due to subcortical dysfunction?	In HIV-associated dementia, subcortical dysfunction may lead to non-specific symptoms such as slow or jerky movements.
What is the effect of high doses of aspirin on oxidative phosphorylation?	In high doses, aspirin may act as an uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation.
What can be detected in the urine of individuals with hereditary fructose intolerance?	In hereditary fructose intolerance, reducing sugars can be detected in the urine.
What happens to the available phosphate in individuals with hereditary fructose intolerance due to the accumulation of fructose-1-P?	In hereditary fructose intolerance, fructose-1-P accumulates, causing a decrease in available phosphate.
What is the effect of decreased available phosphate in individuals with hereditary fructose intolerance on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis?	In hereditary fructose intolerance, decreased available phosphate leads to inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
What is the result of a mixing study in individuals with hemophilia A?	In hemophilia A, mixing normal plasma with the patient's plasma (mixing study) does correct the PTT.
What is the status of the hypothalamic set point in individuals with heat stroke?	In heat stroke, the hypothalamic set point is normal.
What is the mechanism by which M3 receptor activation causes vasodilation in healthy individuals?	In healthy patients, M3 receptor activation indirectly causes vasodilation via release of nitric oxide.
What is the relationship between physiologic dead space and anatomic dead space in healthy lungs?	In healthy lungs, the physiologic dead space is approximately equal to the anatomic dead space.
What is the percentage of self-limited acute hepatitis B infection in healthy adults?	In healthy adults, acute hepatitis B infection is self-limited in > 90-95% of cases.
What is the effect of L-DOPA and Arginine on growth hormone secretion in Growth Hormone deficiency?	In Growth Hormone deficiency, L-DOPA and Arginine do not increase growth hormone secretion.
What are the components that accumulate due to the activation of orbital fibroblasts in Grave's ophthalmopathy?	In Grave's ophthalmopathy, activation of orbital fibroblasts causes accumulation of fibroblasts, adipose, and glycosaminoglycans.
What are the LH levels at baseline and in response to a GnRH agonist in gonadotropin independent (peripheral) precocious puberty?	In gonadotropin independent (peripheral) precocious puberty, LH levels are low at baseline and do not increase with a GnRH agonist.
What are the LH levels at baseline in gonadotropin dependent (central) precocious puberty?	In gonadotropin dependent (central) precocious puberty, LH levels are high at baseline.
What is the result of the ristocetin test in Glanzmann Thrombasthenia?	In Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, the ristocetin test is positive (normal).
What is the defect in platelets in Glanzmann thrombasthenia?	In Glanzmann thrombasthenia, there is a defect in platelet aggregation.
What is the recommended tidal volume for mechanically ventilated patients in terms of ml/kg of ideal body weight?	In general, the recommended tidal volume for mechanically ventilated patients is about 6 ml/kg of ideal body weight.
What effect do prostaglandins typically have on vascular permeability?	In general, prostaglandins cause increased vascular permeability.
What effect do prostaglandins typically have on blood vessels?	In general, prostaglandins cause vasodilation.
What effect do leukotrienes typically have on vascular permeability?	In general, leukotrienes cause increased vascular permeability.
What effect do leukotrienes typically have on blood vessels?	In general, leukotrienes cause vasoconstriction.
What are the common causes of iron deficiency?	In general, iron deficiency is usually caused by dietary lack or blood loss.
What process experiences a failure of apoptosis in faulty B cells during Follicular lymphoma?	In Follicular lymphoma, there is a failure of apoptosis of faulty B cells during somatic hypermutation.
What is the method used to tag cells in flow cytometry, and what are the antibodies used for?	In flow cytometry, cells are tagged with antibodies that are specific to surface or intracellular proteins.
What is the anatomical relationship between the ureters and the uterine artery in females?	In females, the ureters pass under the uterine artery.
What are the effects of adrenal androgens on the development of secondary sexual characteristics and sexual function in females?	In females, the adrenal androgens are responsible for the development of pubic and axillary hair and for libido.
What are the clinical manifestations of prolactinoma in females?	In females, prolactinoma presents as galactorrhea and amenorrhea.
What are the possible clinical manifestations of hyperandrogenism in females with 11- and 21-hydroxylase deficiency?	In females, 11- and 21-hydroxylase deficiency may present with irregular menses and infertility due to hyperandrogenism.
What is the preferred method of diagnosing abnormalities of the uterine cavity in female infertility testing?	In female infertility testing, saline infusion sonohysterography is the preferred method of diagnosing abnormalities of the uterine cavity.
What is the biomarker that can be used to determine ovarian reserve in female infertility testing?	In female infertility testing, levels of anti-müllerian hormone (MIF) can be used to determine ovarian reserve.
What is the primary purpose of a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) in female infertility testing?	In female infertility testing, a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is primarily used to determine fallopian tube patency.
What is the effect of stimulating β3 receptors in fat?	In fat, stimulation of β3 receptors results in increased lipolysis.
What is the process called in which fatty acids bind to Ca2+ in fat necrosis?	In fat necrosis, fatty acids bind to Ca2+ via a process called saponification.
What is the enzyme and product involved in the conversion of β-hydroxybutyrate in extrahepatic tissues?	In extrahepatic tissues, β-hydroxybutyrate may be converted back to acetoacetate via the enzyme β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase.
What is the product and enzyme involved in the activation of acetoacetate in extrahepatic tissues during ketone body metabolism?	In extrahepatic tissues, acetoacetate is activated to acetoacetyl-CoA via the enzyme thiophorase during ketone body metabolism.
What type of gas exchange does O2 exhibit during exercise?	During exercise, O2 exhibits mixed-limited gas exchange.
What is the substance that can inhibit RNA polymerase II in eukaryotes?	In eukaryotes, RNA polymerase II may be inhibited by α-amanitin.
What is the specific part of a gene in eukaryotes where RNA polymerase II may bind?	In eukaryotes, each gene has its own promoter, to which RNA polymerase II may bind.
What are the two substances that are increased in individuals with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and are associated with calciphylaxis?	In ESRD, calciphylaxis is associated with increased levels of phosphate and PTH.
What is the main metabolic process that occurs in erythrocytes and utilizes 90% of the glucose present in these cells?	In erythrocytes, 90% of glucose is used for glycolysis.
What is the alternative metabolic pathway that utilizes 10% of glucose in erythrocytes, aside from glycolysis?	In erythrocytes, 10% of glucose is used for the HMP shunt.
What is the effect of histone acetylation on DNA accessibility for transcription in epigenetics?	In epigenetics, when a histone is acetylated, the histone unwinds the DNA to make it available for transcription.
What is the usual effect of emphysema on the DLCO?	In emphysema, the DLCO is usually decreased.
What laboratory tests should be performed in elderly patients with suspected dementia to rule out other possible causes?	In elderly patients with suspected dementia, TSH and B12 levels should be measured to rule out other possible causes.
What additional screening should be performed in elderly patients with suspected dementia to rule out other possible causes?	In elderly patients with suspected dementia, screening for depression should be performed to rule out other possible causes.
What laboratory test should be administered in elderly patients with suspected dementia if there is high clinical suspicion of neurosyphilis?	In elderly patients with suspected dementia, a RPR test should be administered to exclude neurosyphilis if there's high clinical suspicion.
In eccentric hypertrophy, where are sarcomeres added?	In eccentric hypertrophy, sarcomeres are added in series.
What is the source of steroid hormones during the first trimester of pregnancy?	In early pregnancy (first trimester), the source of steroid hormones is the corpus luteum.
What is the BUN:creatinine ratio in early postrenal azotemia?	In early postrenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is > 15.
How are cysts usually distributed in a dysplastic kidney?	In dysplastic kidney, cysts are usually uni-lateral.
What is the result of consumption of platelets and factors in disseminated intravascular coagulation?	In disseminated intravascular coagulation, consumption of platelets and factors results in bleeding.
How do ACE inhibitors affect intraglomerular pressure and glomerular basement membrane thickening in diabetics?	In diabetics, ACE inhibitors decrease intraglomerular pressure, thus slowing glomerular basement membrane thickening.
What accumulates in the serum during Diabetic Ketoacidosis and is used as fuel in peripheral tissues?	In Diabetic Ketoacidosis, ketone bodies accumulate in the serum and are used as fuel in peripheral tissues.
What are Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) and how do they relate to protein damage/dysfunction in diabetes, especially in collagen?	In diabetes, Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) can crosslink proteins, leading to damage/dysfunction, especially in collagen.
In what form does IgA exist in circulation?	IgA exists as a monomer in circulation.
What are the hepatitis infections that can be treated with IFN-α?	IFN-α can be used to treat Hepatitis B and C infections.
What is a thyroid nodule with decreased uptake of 131I considered?	A thyroid nodule with decreased uptake of 131I is considered a 'cold' nodule.
What diagnostic test is used to exclude hemorrhage before administering tPA if a stroke is suspected?	If a stroke is suspected, noncontrast CT is used to exclude hemorrhage before tPA can be given.
What happens to the intrapleural pressure if a sharp object punctures the intrapleural space (pneumothorax)?	If a sharp object punctures the intrapleural space (pneumothorax), the intrapleural pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure.
What is the likelihood of a salivary gland tumor being malignant if it involves a non-parotid gland?	If a salivary gland tumor involves a non-parotid gland, it is more likely to be malignant.
What is the likely diagnosis of an adnexal mass in a reproductive age female?	If a reproductive age female presents with an adnexal mass, it is likely a cyst.
What is the recommended management for a patient with CKD 24 hours prior to surgery?	If a patient has CKD, the recommended management 24 hours prior to surgery is dialysis.
What type of tumor is likely to be present in a premenstrual female who presents with an adnexal mass?	If a premenstrual female presents with an adnexal mass, it is likely a germ cell tumor.
What type of tumor is likely to be present in a postmenopausal woman who presents with an adnexal mass?	If a postmenopausal woman presents with an adnexal mass, it is likely an epithelial tumor.
What is the first action that should be taken if a physician suspects child abuse?	The first action that should be taken if a physician suspects child abuse is to contact child protective services (CPS).
Should a patient be allowed to try alternative or holistic medicine that is known to be safe?	Yes.
What should be suspected if a patient taking Integrase Inhibitors develops elevated Creatine Kinase levels?	Rhabdomyolysis should be suspected.
What antimicrobial can be used to treat the organism in question if a patient presents with an undulating fever?	Doxycycline can be used.
What is the first line drug for treating Lyme disease in a patient who presents with the condition?	The first line drug for treating Lyme disease in a patient who presents with the condition is Doxycycline.
What vitamin deficiency should be suspected if a patient on Isoniazid develops peripheral neuropathy and fatigue?	If a patient on Isoniazid develops peripheral neuropathy and fatigue, Vitamin B6 deficiency should be suspected.
What condition should be suspected if a patient on Isoniazid develops arthralgias and a rash?	If a patient on Isoniazid develops arthralgias and a rash, Drug Induced Lupus should be suspected.
