If a male patient has insufficient production of testosterone, will they develop breasts?	The answer is "-/+/-".
Will a patient with hyper/hypogonadotropic hypogonadism have a uterus?	The answer is "+/+/-".
What artery, if present in a patient, can cause profuse bleeding during a midline tracheostomy?	If a patient has a Thyroidea ima artery, a midline tracheostomy may cause profuse bleeding.
What are the treatment options for a patient with a varicocele if it is associated with pain or infertility?	If a patient has a varicocele, consider surgical ligation or catheter embolization if associated with pain or infertility.
What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who develops a whistling noise during respiration following rhinoplasty?	The likely diagnosis is nasal septal perforation.
What is the impact on all of a mother's children if she has a mitochondrial disease?	If a mother has a mitochondrial disease, all her children are affected.
In the event of a successful malpractice case, what types of damages can a patient receive?	If a malpractice case is successful, the patient can receive compensatory damages and punitive damages.
What is the genetic status of a male's daughters if he has an X-linked recessive disease?	If a male has an X-linked recessive disease, all of his daughters will be carriers.
What is the impact on a male's daughters if he has an X-linked dominant disease?	If a male has an X-linked dominant disease, all of his daughters will be affected.
Between which vertebrae is the spinal cord located if a lateral horn is present?	If a lateral horn is present, the spinal cord is between T1 - L2.
What are the possible locations of the spinal cord if a lateral horn is absent?	If a lateral horn is absent, the spinal cord is located between C1 - C8 or L3 - S5.
What is the impact on a father's children if he has a mitochondrial disease?	If a father has a mitochondrial disease, all his children are unaffected.
What is the impact of X-linked recessive inheritance pattern on male-to-male transmission of a disease?	If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, there is NO male-to-male transmission.
What is the usual pattern of generational inheritance for a disease with an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern?	If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, it usually does skip generations.
What is the impact of X-linked dominant inheritance pattern on male-to-male transmission of a disease?	If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, there is NO male-to-male transmission.
What is the usual pattern of generational inheritance for a disease with an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern?	If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, it usually doesn't skip generations.
What is the usual pattern of generational inheritance for a disease with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern?	If a disease has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, it usually does skip generations.
What is the usual pattern of generational inheritance for a disease with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern?	If a disease has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, it usually doesn't skip generations.
From which parent is a disease with a mitochondrial inheritance pattern usually inherited?	If a disease has a mitochondrial inheritance pattern, it can be inherited only from the mother.
What are the clinical presentations of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis presents clinically with progressive dyspnea, cough, and digital clubbing.
What are the initial findings of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on CT scan?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is initially seen on CT in subpleural patches.
What is the characteristic feature of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by patchy interstitial fibrosis due to multiple fibroblastic foci.
What type of restrictive lung disease is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is an intrinsic restrictive lung disease.
What is the end-stage appearance of the lungs on CT in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?	Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis eventually results in diffuse fibrosis with end-stage honeycomb' lung on CT.
What type of precocious puberty is idiopathic precocious puberty?	Idiopathic precocious puberty is a form of central precocious puberty.
What are the visual field testing results in idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with an enlarged blind spot and peripheral constriction on visual field testing.
What is the finding on funduscopy that may be present in idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may present with bilateral symmetric papilledema on funduscopy.
What symptom may be caused by idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may cause pulsatile tinnitus.
Which vitamin excess is associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is associated with vitamin A excess.
Which drugs can be associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension?	Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can be associated with use of certain drugs, such as tetracyclines and danazol.
What type of kidney stones does idiopathic acidic urine account for 50% of?	Idiopathic acidic urine accounts for 50% of uric acid kidney stones.
What is the age range for adults that require lipid screening to identify dyslipidemia and calculate 10-year CVD event risk?	Adults ages 40- to 75-years-old require lipid screening to identify dyslipidemia and calculate 10-year CVD event risk.
What is the ideal type of blood flow in the cardiovascular system?	Ideally, blood flow in the cardiovascular system is laminar, or streamlined.
What are the factors that induce ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 expression?	ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 expression are induced by TNF and IL-1.
What type of enzymes are found in high plasma levels in individuals with I-cell disease?	I-cell disease is characterized by high plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes.
What condition is characterized by the presence of Hürthle cell metaplasia and lymphoid aggregates with germinal centers in the thyroid?	Hürthle cell metaplasia and lymphoid aggregates with germinal centers in the thyroid is seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.
What is the role of hysterosalpingogram in the diagnosis of PID?	Hysterosalpingogram is not useful in the diagnosis of PID, as the answer is F (False).
What causes hysteresis during lung inflation (inspiration)?	Hysteresis occurs during lung inflation (inspiration) due to the need to overcome surface tension forces.
What is one potential cause of hypoxia, and how does it affect the oxygen content of the blood?	Hypoxia may be caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, which decreases the oxygen content of the blood.
What is one potential cause of hypoxia, and how does it relate to the levels of hematocrit and Hb?	Hypoxia may be caused by anemia, which is characterized by decreased levels of hematocrit and Hb.
What is one potential cause of hypoxia, and how does it relate to cardiac output?	Hypoxia may be caused by a decreased cardiac output.
How do hypoxia and increased erythropoiesis affect hepcidin levels?	Hypoxia and increased erythropoiesis act to lower hepcidin levels.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to xanthine, and what is the product of this reaction?	The enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to xanthine is xanthine oxidase, and the product of this reaction is xanthine.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to IMP in the purine salvage pathway?	The enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to IMP in the purine salvage pathway is HGPRT.
What is the product of the conversion of hypoxanthine, and what is the enzyme responsible for this conversion?	The product of the conversion of hypoxanthine is xanthine, and the enzyme responsible for this conversion is xanthine oxidase.
What are the two characteristics of skin that are associated with hypovolemic shock?	The two characteristics of skin that are associated with hypovolemic shock are coldness and clamminess.
What is the recommended treatment for hypovolemic hyponatremia?	The recommended treatment for hypovolemic hyponatremia is isotonic normal saline.
How can hypovolemic hyponatremia be classified based on its causes?	Hypovolemic hyponatremia can be classified into renal and non-renal causes.
What is another potent stimulus for ADH secretion besides hypovolemia?	Volume contraction or hypovolemia is another potent stimulus for ADH secretion.
What are the effects of hypoventilation on the alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient and acid-base status?	Hypoventilation leads to no change in the alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient and respiratory acidosis.
What condition is indicated by the presence of hypotonic hyponatremia and very high creatinine levels?	The presence of hypotonic hyponatremia and very high creatinine levels indicates renal failure.
What type of neuropathy may be present in a "stocking glove" distribution in individuals with hypothyroidism?	Individuals with hypothyroidism may present with distal symmetric neuropathy in a "stocking glove" distribution.
How may hypothyroidism contribute to the development of atherosclerosis?	Hypothyroidism may contribute to the development of atherosclerosis due to dyslipidemia and endothelial dysfunction.
What is the treatment for hypothyroidism?	Hypothyroidism is typically treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy, such as levothyroxine or triiodothyronine.
What condition may hypothyroidism be associated with, and what are the possible causes of this association?	Hypothyroidism may be associated with adrenal insufficiency, which may be caused by autoimmune disease or dysfunctional pituitary/hypothalamus.
What is the consequence of hypothyroidism during the perinatal period?	Hypothyroidism during the perinatal period can cause irreversible mental retardation, which is also known as cretinism.
What is the relationship between hypothyroidism and sodium levels?	Hypothyroidism is associated with hyponatremia, which is a low level of sodium in the blood.
What are the two nuclei in the hypothalamus that mediate the secretion of GnRH?	The two nuclei in the hypothalamus that mediate the secretion of GnRH are the preoptic nucleus and the arcuate nucleus.
What is the target of hypothalamic hormones?	Hypothalamic hormones target the anterior pituitary gland, where they can stimulate or inhibit the release of hormones.
What hormone is responsible for regulating hypothalamic control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion?	The hormone responsible for regulating hypothalamic control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion is GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone).
What hormone is responsible for regulating hypothalamic control of oogenesis and secretion of progesterone and estradiol?	The hormone responsible for regulating hypothalamic control of oogenesis and secretion of progesterone and estradiol is GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone).
What is the management strategy for hypotension, peritonitis, and evisceration?	The management strategy for hypotension, peritonitis, and evisceration is ex lap, which is short for exploratory laparotomy.
What are some clinical findings that indicate right ventricular failure immediately after a myocardial infarction?	Some clinical findings that indicate right ventricular failure immediately after a myocardial infarction include hypotension, clear lungs, and Kussmaul's sign.
What condition is indicated by the presence of hypotension, distended neck veins, and clear lungs?	The presence of hypotension, distended neck veins, and clear lungs indicates right ventricular infarction.
What are some possible presentations of hypospadias at birth, and what is the underlying cause of these presentations?	Hypospadias may present with post-renal acute kidney injury (AKI) and hydronephrosis at birth, which are caused by urinary outlet obstruction.
What is the underlying cause of hypospadias?	Hypospadias is caused by the failure of the urethral folds to close during fetal development.
What is Sheehan syndrome, and how does it relate to hypopituitarism?	Sheehan syndrome is a pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland that can cause hypopituitarism.
What happens to the BUN:creatinine ratio in patients with upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed?	The BUN:creatinine ratio increases in patients with upper GI bleed.
How does the pressure in the alveoli change during mid-inspiration in relation to the pressure in the atmosphere?	During mid-inspiration, the pressure in the alveoli becomes more negative relative to the pressure in the atmosphere.
How does the pressure in the alveoli change during mid-expiration in relation to the pressure in the atmosphere?	During mid-expiration, the pressure in the alveoli becomes more positive relative to the pressure in the atmosphere.
What happens to the activity of acetylcholinesterase when the temperature is lowered?	The activity of acetylcholinesterase decreases when the temperature is lowered.
What happens to the A-a gradient in patients with pulmonary embolism?	The A-a gradient increases in patients with pulmonary embolism due to the development of a ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.
What happens to the A-a gradient in patients with decreased DLCO?	The A-a gradient increases in patients with decreased DLCO.
What happens to the concentration of [TF]urea in the cortical and outer medullary collecting ducts when ADH is present?	The concentration of [TF]urea increases in the cortical and outer medullary collecting ducts when ADH is present.
What is the typical presentation of sickle cell trait?	Generally, sickle cell trait is asymptomatic and does not cause anemia.
What happens to serum K+ levels in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis?	Serum K+ levels can be normal or increased in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis.
Does serum iron/ferritin level change with pregnancy or oral contraceptive pill (OCP) use?	No, there is typically no change in serum iron/ferritin level with pregnancy or OCP use.
What is the effect of septic shock on PCWP (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure)?	Septic shock can lead to normal or decreased PCWP (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure).
What is the effect of secondary adrenal insufficiency on the secretion of glucocorticoids?	In secondary adrenal insufficiency, the secretion of glucocorticoids is decreased.
What are the initial symptoms of small bowel obstruction (SBO)?	Small bowel obstruction (SBO) initially presents with colicky abdominal pain, positive gas/stool, and borborygmi.
What is the effect of obstructive lung disease (e.g. COPD, asthma) on residual volume, FRC, and total lung capacity?	Obstructive lung disease causes an increase in residual volume, FRC, and total lung capacity.
What is the response of renal cell carcinoma to chemotherapy and radiation therapy?	Renal cell carcinoma has a poor response to chemotherapy and radiation therapy, as it is often resistant to these treatments.
How does pregnancy affect the permeability of the renal basement membrane?	The permeability of the renal basement membrane increases during pregnancy.
What is the effect of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) on pulmonary arterial pressure?	ARDS causes an increase in pulmonary arterial pressure, which can lead to pulmonary hypertension.
What is the mechanism by which parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases calcium absorption in the intestines?	PTH increases intestinal calcium absorption indirectly by stimulating the production of 1,25-(OH)2D3 in the kidney.
What is the effect of advanced liver disease on prothrombin time (PT)?	Advanced liver disease causes an increase in prothrombin time (PT).
What is the effect of prior C-section and placenta previa on the risk of placenta accreta?	Prior C-section and placenta previa increase the risk of placenta accreta.
What are the common symptoms associated with postconcussive syndrome?	Postconcussive syndrome typically presents with symptoms such as headache, confusion, difficulty concentrating, mood alterations, and sleep disturbances.
What are the changes in plasma volume and red blood cell (RBC) volume during pregnancy?	During pregnancy, plasma volume increases by 50% and RBC volume increases by 30%.
What is the effect of sweating in a desert on plasma protein concentration?	Sweating in a desert causes an increase in plasma protein concentration.
What is the effect of isotonic NaCl infusion on plasma protein concentration?	Isotonic NaCl infusion causes a decrease in plasma protein concentration.

What is the effect of hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency) on plasma protein concentration?	Hyposmotic volume contraction, such as in adrenal insufficiency, causes an increase in plasma protein concentration.
What is the effect of excessive NaCl intake on plasma protein concentration?	Excessive NaCl intake causes a decrease in plasma protein concentration.
What is the effect of diarrhea on plasma protein concentration?	Diarrhea causes an increase in plasma protein concentration.
What is the mechanism by which phototherapy treats neonatal jaundice?	Phototherapy treats neonatal jaundice by isomerizing unconjugated bilirubin (UCB) to a water-soluble form.
What are the typical presentation and population affected by patellofemoral pain syndrome?	Patellofemoral pain syndrome typically presents as anterior knee pain and is more common in physically active women.
What is the effect of exercise on Pao2?	Exercise does not typically cause a significant change in Pao2.
What is the effect of exercise on Paco2?	Exercise does not typically cause a significant change in Paco2.
What is the effect of atelectasis on PaCO2?	Atelectasis typically causes a decrease in PaCO2.
What is the effect of sweating in a desert on osmolarity?	Sweating in a desert typically causes an increase in osmolarity, as sweat is hypo-osmotic.
What is the effect of SIADH on osmolarity?	SIADH typically causes a decrease in osmolarity, leading to hyposmolarity.
What is the effect of isotonic NaCl infusion on osmolarity?	Isotonic NaCl infusion typically does not cause a significant change in osmolarity.
What is the effect of excessive NaCl intake on osmolarity?	Excessive NaCl intake typically causes an increase in osmolarity.
What is the effect of diarrhea on osmolarity?	Diarrhea typically does not cause a significant change in osmolarity.
What is the effect of adrenal insufficiency on osmolarity?	Adrenal insufficiency typically causes a decrease in osmolarity due to the loss of Na+ caused by the lack of aldosterone.
What is the effect of oral estrogen on the required therapeutic dose of levothyroxine in patients with hypothyroidism?	Oral estrogen typically increases the required therapeutic dose of levothyroxine in patients with hypothyroidism.
What is the effect of normal aging on the A-a gradient?	Normal aging typically causes an increase in the A-a gradient.
What is the effect of normal aging on respiratory muscle strength?	Normal aging typically causes a decrease in respiratory muscle strength.

What is the typical presentation of neonatal sepsis?	Neonatal sepsis classically presents with temperature instability.

What is the effect of pregnancy on minute ventilation?	Minute ventilation typically increases during pregnancy.
What is the difference in presentation between microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener)?	Microscopic polyangiitis typically lacks nasopharyngeal involvement and granulomas, which are commonly seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener).

What is the effect of aging on male libido?	There is no significant change in libido in elderly males.

What is the effect of aging on intelligence?	There is generally no significant change in intelligence in the elderly.

What is the effect of pregnancy on insulin resistance?	Insulin resistance typically increases during pregnancy.
What is the mechanism by which insulin promotes the movement of potassium (K+) into cells?	Insulin promotes the movement of K+ into cells by increasing the activity of the Na+-K+ ATPase.
What are the typical clinical features of intussusception in infants?	Infants with intussusception typically present with a knee-chest position, currant jelly diarrhea, and a sausage-shaped mass in the abdomen.

What is the mechanism by which hyperthyroidism causes an increased basal metabolic rate?	Hyperthyroidism typically leads to an increased synthesis of Na+-K+ ATPase pumps, which in turn causes an increased basal metabolic rate.

What is the potential role of hemoglobin in buffering certain ions?	Hemoglobin may act as a buffer for H+ ions.
What are the components that make up hemoglobin?	Hemoglobin is made of heme and globin.
What is the structure of hemoglobin and how many subunits does it consist of?	Hemoglobin is a globular protein consisting of four subunits.
How does the migration rate of Hemoglobin H compare to normal Hemoglobin (A1) on electrophoresis?	Hemoglobin H migrates faster than normal hemoglobin (A1) on electrophoresis.
What are the two forms in which hemoglobin exists, and what is the difference between them?	Hemoglobin exists in two forms: taut (deoxygenated) and relaxed (oxygenated).
What type of point mutation causes Hemoglobin C disease, and what is the specific substitution that occurs?	Hemoglobin C disease occurs due to a point mutation that substitutes glutamic acid with lysine.
What is the primary type of hemolysis that characterizes Hemoglobin C disease?	Hemoglobin C disease is primarily characterized by extravascular hemolysis.
In which chain of hemoglobin does the mutation occur that causes Hemoglobin C disease?	Hemoglobin C disease is caused by a mutation in the β chain of hemoglobin.
What type of anemia is caused by Hemoglobin C disease?	Hemoglobin C disease is a cause of normocytic anemia.
What diagnostic test should be performed prior to surgical evaluation in hemodynamically unstable patients with evidence of renal trauma?	Hemodynamically unstable patients with evidence of renal trauma should undergo IV pyelography prior to surgical evaluation.
What type of amyloidosis is Hemodialysis-related amyloidosis and what is the cause of its accumulation?	Hemodialysis-related amyloidosis is a systemic amyloidosis caused by accumulation of amyloid β2 microglobulin.
At what age does Hemochromatosis typically present and what is the level of total body iron that is usually observed?	Hemochromatosis typically presents after age 40, when total body iron > 20g.
What are the changes observed in serum iron, transferrin (TIBC), ferritin and transferrin saturation in Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis results in high serum iron, low transferrin (TIBC), high ferritin and very high transferrin saturation.
What is the potential cause of gonadal dysfunction in males as a result of Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis may cause gonadal dysfunction in males due to testicular atrophy.
In which joints does Hemochromatosis commonly cause arthropathy?	Hemochromatosis may cause arthropathy, especially in metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints.
What is a potential cause of secondary Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis may be secondary, due to chronic transfusions.
What is a potential cause of primary Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis may be primary; due to autosomal recessive mutations in iron absorption.
What is a characteristic of serum iron in individuals with Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased serum iron.
What is a characteristic of ferritin levels in individuals with Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased ferritin levels.
What is a characteristic of % saturation in individuals with Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased % saturation.
What is a characteristic of TIBC in individuals with Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis is characterized by decreased TIBC.
In which group of individuals does Hemochromatosis have a slowed progression?	Hemochromatosis has a slowed progression in women.
What are the types of cardiomyopathy that can be caused by Hemochromatosis?	Hemochromatosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy.
Which area of the brain is affected by a lesion that causes Hemispatial neglect syndrome?	Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by lesion to the non-dominant parietal cortex.
Who is most commonly affected by Hemiplegic migraines and what are the symptoms?	Hemiplegic migraines are most common in adolescents and present with headache, visual aura, and a self-resolving hemiplegia.
What is the typical cause of Hemineglect and which part of the brain is usually affected by the stroke?	Hemineglect is usually caused by a stroke of the right (non-dominant) middle cerebral artery (MCA).
What is the cause of Hemiballismus and which part of the brain is affected by the lesion?	Hemiballismus is caused by a lesion to the contra-lateral subthalamic nucleus (e.g. lacunar stroke).
What medical condition is commonly associated with Hemiballismus and how does it increase the risk for a lacunar stroke?	Hemiballismus is usually seen in patients with hypertension, which increases the risk for a lacunar stroke.
What are the components of Heme?	Heme is composed of iron and protoporphyrin.
What is the usual method of managing Hematuria?	Hematuria is managed with urinalysis.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of hematuria and varying proteinuria?	Hematuria and varying proteinuria is suggestive of nephritic syndrome.
What is the usual characteristic of Hematuria in patients with GU cancer?	Hematuria in patients with GU cancer is usually painless.
What is the process of hematopoiesis and what type of hematopoietic stem cells are involved in the stepwise maturation?	Hematopoiesis occurs via a stepwise maturation of CD 34+ hematopoietic stem cells.
What is the common receptor expressed by Hematopoetic Stem Cells, Interstitial Cells of Cajal, Mast Cells, and Melanocytes?	The common receptor expressed by Hematopoetic Stem Cells, Interstitial Cells of Cajal, Mast Cells, and Melanocytes is the c-Kit receptor.
What are the hematological complications associated with the use of Trimethoprim (TMP)?	The hematological complications associated with the use of Trimethoprim (TMP) include pancytopenia (granulocytopenia, leukopenia) and megaloblastic anemia.
What are the hematological complications associated with hookworm infections caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus?	The hematological complications associated with hookworm infections caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus include iron deficiency anemia and eosinophilia.
Which organs or tissues are most commonly affected by hemangiomas?	Hemangiomas most commonly involve the skin and liver.
What is the typical time of onset and progression of hemangiomas?	Hemangiomas commonly present at birth and often regress during childhood.
What are the characteristics of hemangioblastomas in terms of staining and susceptibility to hemorrhage?	Hemangioblastomas stain positive for PAS and are prone to hemorrhage due to thin vascular walls.
What is the capillary architecture like in hemangioblastomas?	Hemangioblastomas have normal capillary architecture.
What is the role of hemagglutinin as a virulence factor in viral entry into cells?	Hemagglutinin is a virulence factor that binds sialic acid, promoting viral entry into cells.
How are Hemagglutinin (HA) antigens designated?	Hemagglutinin (HA) antigens are designated H1, H2, H3, etc.
What is HELLP syndrome and what are its symptoms?	HELLP syndrome is a severe version of preeclampsia that includes symptoms such as hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets.
What is HELLP syndrome and what are its characteristics?	HELLP syndrome is a severe version of pre-eclampsia that includes characteristics such as hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets.
What is the potential complication of HELLP syndrome and how can it lead to severe hypotension?	HELLP syndrome can lead to hepatic subcapsular hematomas, which may rupture and cause severe hypotension.
What is the treatment for achalasia and what is the treatment for GERD?	Heller myotomy is the treatment for achalasia, while Nissen fundoplication is the treatment for GERD.

Which specific strain of Streptococcus is identified by the Gram Positive Algorithm when observing gamma-hemolysis with bile growth only?	The Gram Positive Algorithm identifies Streptococcus bovis when observing gamma-hemolysis with bile growth only.
Which specific strain of Streptococcus is identified by the Gram Positive Algorithm when observing alpha-hemolysis and Optochin sensitivity?	The Gram Positive Algorithm identifies Streptococcus pneumonia when observing alpha-hemolysis and Optochin sensitivity.
What is the specific strain of Staphylococcus that is identified by the Gram Positive Algorithm when observing coagulase positivity?	The Gram Positive Algorithm identifies Staph Aureus when observing coagulase positivity in Staphylococcus.
What is the further classification of Staphylococcus identified by the Gram Positive Algorithm when observing coagulase negativity?	The Gram Positive Algorithm further classifies Staphylococcus Coagulase Negative based on Novobiocin sensitivity, which can be either resistant or sensitive.
What are the two types of Anaerobic Bacilli that are included in the Gram Positive Algorithm?	The Gram Positive Algorithm includes Clostridium and Propionibacterium as the two types of Anaerobic Bacilli.
What are the three types of Aerobic Bacilli that are included in the Gram Positive Algorithm?	The Gram Positive Algorithm includes Listeria, Bacillus, and Corynebacterium as the three types of Aerobic Bacilli.
What is the mechanism by which Gram negative bacteria are able to resist antibiotic treatment?	Gram negative bacteria have enzymes within their periplasm that allow them to resist antibiotic treatment.
What are the two molecules that Lipopolysaccharide (endotoxin) binds to in order to activate macrophages in Gram Negative Bacteria?	Lipopolysaccharide (endotoxin) binds to CD14 and TLR4 in order to activate macrophages in Gram Negative Bacteria.
How are Diplococci further differentiated in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Diplococci are further split via whether or not there is maltose utilization in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which two bacteria are classified as Diplococci without maltose metabolism in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Moraxella are classified as Diplococci without maltose metabolism in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which bacteria is classified as Diplococci with maltose metabolism in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Neisseria meningitidis is classified as Diplococci with maltose metabolism in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
What type of organisms are Diplococci in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Diplococci are aerobic organisms in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which bacteria is a comma-shaped rod that produces urease in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Helicobacter pylori is a comma-shaped rod that produces urease in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which comma-shaped rod grows on alkaline media in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped rod that grows on alkaline media in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which comma-shaped rod grows at 42°C in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Campylobacter jejuni is a comma-shaped rod that grows at 42°C in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
How are lactose fermenting Bacilli further categorized in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Lactose fermenting Bacilli are further split into whether they ferment fast or slow in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
How are Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters further categorized in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters are further split into whether they contain cytochrome oxidase in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which Bacilli are categorized as slow lactose fermenters in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Citrobacter and Serratia are categorized as slow lactose fermenters in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which Bacilli are categorized as not lactose fermenters and oxidase positive in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Pseudomonas is categorized as not lactose fermenters and oxidase positive in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
Which Bacilli are categorized as fast lactose fermenters in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	Klebsiella, E. coli, and Enterobacter are categorized as fast lactose fermenters in the Gram Negative Algorithm.
What is the cytochrome oxidase status of all comma-shaped rods in the Gram Negative Algorithm?	All comma-shaped rods in the Gram Negative Algorithm are cytochrome oxidase positive.
For which condition is graft-versus-host disease potentially beneficial in bone marrow transplants?	Graft-versus-host disease is potentially beneficial in bone marrow transplants for patients with leukemia.
What is the role of recipient T-cells in the development of graft-versus-host disease?	Recipient T-cells in the graft mediate the development of graft-versus-host disease.
What type of cells are responsible for attacking the host in graft-versus-Host disease?	Graft T-cells are responsible for attacking the host in graft-versus-Host disease.
Does graded exercise therapy decrease mortality in patients with PAD?	No, graded exercise therapy does not decrease mortality in patients with PAD.
How is Grade V splenic injury defined?	Grade V splenic injury is defined as shattered spleen or devascularization of the spleen.
What is Grade 3 follicular lymphoma characterized by?	Grade 3 follicular lymphoma is characterized by large noncleaved cells.
What is Grade 2 follicular lymphoma characterized by?	Grade 2 follicular lymphoma is characterized by a mixture of small cleaved cells and large noncleaved cells.
What is Grade 1 follicular lymphoma characterized by?	Grade 1 follicular lymphoma is characterized by small cleaved cells.
What is the role of Gq proteins in the signaling cascade?	Gq proteins activate the IP3-DAG signaling cascade.
What other condition can be treated with the same medications used for gout treatment (NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, colchicine)?	Pseudogout can also be treated with the same medications used for gout treatment (NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, colchicine).
What is the management approach for gout that is not responsive to celecoxib?	Gout that is not responsive to celecoxib is managed with another NSAID (indomethacin).
What is a possible cause of gout and how does it relate to uric acid excretion?	Gout may occur secondary to renal insufficiency, due to decreased ability to excrete uric acid.
How can leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders lead to the development of gout?	Leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders can lead to the development of gout due to increased cell turnover.
How can dehydration lead to the development of gout?	Dehydration can lead to the development of gout by causing hypovolemia and resultant increased uric acid concentration.
What is the treatment for gonococcal urethritis in men?	Gonococcal urethritis in men is typically managed with a combination of ceftriaxone and either azithromycin or doxycycline.
What is the target of golimumab, and what type of drug is it?	Golimumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets TNF-α.
What is goiter, and what are the two possible thyroid conditions it can be associated with?	Goiter is a condition characterized by an enlarged thyroid gland, and it can be associated with both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.
What is the end product of the breakdown of guanosine monophosphate (GMP) in purine salvage?	The end product of the breakdown of GMP in purine salvage is guanosine.
What is the name of the enzyme responsible for the conversion of GM2 ganglioside to GM3?	The enzyme responsible for the conversion of GM2 ganglioside to GM3 is called hexosaminidase A.
What type of receptor antagonist is glycopyrrolate, and what is its mechanism of action in reducing glandular activity?	Glycopyrrolate is an M3 receptor antagonist that reduces glandular activity by blocking the action of acetylcholine on M3 receptors.
What type of antagonist is glycopyrrolate?	Glycopyrrolate is an M3 antagonist.
What medical condition can be treated with glycopyrrolate when it is taken orally?	Glycopyrrolate can be used to treat peptic ulcer disease when taken orally.
What is the mechanism that synchronizes glycogenolysis and skeletal muscle contraction following neuromuscular stimulation?	Glycogenolysis and skeletal muscle contraction are synchronized via intracellular accumulation of Ca2+ following neuromuscular stimulation.
What are the factors that regulate glycogen synthase via positive feedback?	Glycogen synthase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin, cortisol, and glucose-6-phosphate.
What are the factors that regulate glycogen synthase via negative feedback?	Glycogen synthase is regulated via negative feedback by epinephrine and glucagon.
How long does it typically take for glycogen stores to be depleted?	Glycogen stores typically are depleted after 12 - 18 hours.
What factor regulates glycogen phosphorylase via positive feedback in the liver?	Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via positive feedback by glucagon in the liver.
What factor regulates glycogen phosphorylase via positive feedback in muscle?	Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via positive feedback by AMP in muscle.
What factors regulate glycogen phosphorylase via negative feedback?	Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP, insulin, and glucose-6-phosphate.
What factor and receptor regulate glycogen phosphorylase via positive feedback in both liver and muscle?	Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated by positive feedback by epinephrine via the β receptor in both liver and muscle.
What factor and receptor regulate glycogen phosphorylase via positive feedback in the liver only?	Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated by positive feedback by epinephrine via the α receptor in the liver only.
What process does the liver use to convert glycerol, obtained from triglyceride breakdown, into glucose?	The liver converts glycerol, obtained from triglyceride breakdown, into glucose via the process of gluconeogenesis.
What molecule is formed when glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is converted by the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3P-dehydrogenase during glycolysis?	Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is converted into 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG) by the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3P-dehydrogenase during glycolysis.
What molecules regulate Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, the enzyme involved in purine synthesis, via negative feedback?	Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, the enzyme involved in purine synthesis, is regulated by negative feedback via AMP, IMP, and GMP.
What is the effect of glucose-insulinotropic peptide on gastric H+ secretion, specifically in terms of its exocrine effect?	Glucose-insulinotropic peptide decreases gastric H+ secretion through its exocrine effect.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting glucose-6-phosphate to glucose?	Glucose-6-phosphate is converted to glucose via the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.
What is the molecule responsible for positively regulating Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)?	Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is regulated via positive feedback by NADP+.
What is the molecule responsible for negatively regulating Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)?	Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is regulated via negative feedback by NADPH.
What aspect of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is reduced in individuals with G6PD deficiency?	Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is a disorder resulting in reduced half-life of G6PD.
Where in the nephron does glucose reabsorption occur and what type of cotransporters are responsible for this process?	Glucose is reabsorbed in the early proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) by Na+/glucose (SGLT) cotransporters.
What is the product of the conversion of glucose, and which enzyme is responsible for catalyzing this reaction?	Glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase.
What happens to glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) at a normal plasma level (60 - 120 mg/dL)?	Glucose at a normal plasma level (60 - 120 mg/dL) is completely reabsorbed in the PCT.
How are glucose and galactose transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells?	Glucose and galactose are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by Na+-dependent cotransport (SGLT1).
Where does gluconeogenesis primarily occur and where else can the necessary enzymes be found?	Gluconeogenesis occurs primarily in the liver, but necessary enzymes are also found in the kidney and intestinal epithelium.
What regulates glucokinase via positive feedback?	Glucokinase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin.
What regulates glucokinase via negative feedback?	Glucokinase is regulated via negative feedback by fructose-6-phosphate.
How is glucokinase characterized in terms of Vmax relative to hexokinase?	Glucokinase is characterized by a high Vmax relative to hexokinase.
How is glucokinase characterized in terms of Km relative to hexokinase?	Glucokinase is characterized by a high Km relative to hexokinase.
What is the effect of glucocorticoids on glucose utilization by tissues and insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue?	Glucocorticoids decrease glucose utilization by tissues and decrease insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue.
What is the effect of glucocorticoids on the liver and how does it relate to hyperglycemia?	Glucocorticoids stimulate gluconeogenesis by the liver, which may cause hyperglycemia.
What is the mechanism by which glucocorticoids prevent the production of arachidonic acid?	Glucocorticoids prevent the production of arachidonic acid by inhibiting phospholipase A2.
What is the effect of glucocorticoids on neutrophil adhesion molecules and how does it relate to demargination and neutrophilia?	Glucocorticoids prevent the production of neutrophil adhesion molecules, causing demargination and subsequent neutrophilia.
What is the mechanism by which glucocorticoids prevent the activation of T cells and B cells?	Glucocorticoids prevent the activation of T cells and B cells by inhibiting production of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-2).
What is the mechanism by which glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory effects?	Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects via the inhibition of the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets.
What is the mechanism by which glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects and how does it relate to T lymphocyte proliferation?	Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and thus inhibiting the proliferation of T lymphocytes.
What is a potential adverse gastrointestinal effect of glucocorticoids?	Glucocorticoids may cause peptic ulcers as an adverse GI effect.
What cells' proliferation is inhibited by glucocorticoids and what process is impaired as a result?	Glucocorticoids inhibit the proliferation of fibroblasts, thus impairing the process of wound healing.
What is the target of glucocorticoids that leads to the inhibition of production of inflammatory prostaglandins?	Glucocorticoids inhibit the production of inflammatory prostaglandins by targeting cyclooxygenase.
What is the target of glucocorticoids that leads to the inhibition of production of inflammatory leukotrienes?	Glucocorticoids inhibit the production of inflammatory leukotrienes by targeting lipoxygenase.
What effect do glucocorticoids have on peripheral metabolism and how does this provide more glycerol for gluconeogenesis in the liver?	Glucocorticoids increase peripheral lipolysis, which provides more glycerol to the liver for gluconeogenesis.
What effect do glucocorticoids have on hepatic glycogen storage?	Glucocorticoids increase hepatic glycogen storage.
What intrinsic activity do glucocorticoids have and how does it manifest in terms of sodium reabsorption and volume retention?	Glucocorticoids have some intrinsic mineralocorticoid activity, manifesting as increased sodium reabsorption and volume retention.
What effect do glucocorticoids have on peripheral skeletal muscle?	Glucocorticoids have a catabolic effect on peripheral skeletal muscle.
What effect do glucocorticoids have on peripheral fat tissue?	Glucocorticoids have a catabolic effect on peripheral fat tissue.
How do glucocorticoids decrease bone formation and what is the mechanism behind it?	Glucocorticoids decrease bone formation by decreasing osteoblast activity.
Which layer of the skin can glucocorticoids cause atrophy of?	Glucocorticoids can cause atrophy of the dermal layer of the skin.
What type of disorders can glucocorticoids be useful for treating, and what are some examples of these disorders?	Glucocorticoids are useful for treating inflammatory disorders, such as gout, rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, and IBD.
What is the role of glucocorticoids, specifically cortisol, in maintaining the body's response to catecholamines?	Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, play an essential role in maintaining vascular responsiveness to catecholamines.
What is the process by which glucocerebroside is converted to ceramide, and which enzyme is responsible for this conversion?	Glucocerebroside is converted to ceramide through the action of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase).
What type of symptoms may be caused by glucagonomas, and what is the mechanism behind their development?	Glucagonomas may cause gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms due to the secretion of glucagon and other molecules, such as secretin.
What are the effects of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) on insulin and glucagon secretion?	Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) stimulates insulin secretion and inhibits glucagon secretion.
What is the effect of glucagon, cortisol, and epinephrine on insulin resistance, and what is the mechanism behind this effect?	Glucagon, cortisol, and epinephrine induce insulin resistance, leading to the phosphorylation of serine/threonine residues of the insulin receptor and IRS-1.
Which tissues does glucagon primarily act on, and what is the secondary tissue it acts on?	Glucagon acts on the liver primarily and adipose tissue secondarily.
What are the effects of GLP-1 analogs on insulin release and satiety?	GLP-1 analogs cause increased insulin release and satiety.
What are the effects of GLP-1 analogs on glucagon release and gastric emptying?	GLP-1 analogs cause decreased glucagon release and gastric emptying.
How do GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors cause increased satiety, and what is the mechanism behind this effect?	GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors cause increased satiety via decreased gastric emptying.
What is the effect of GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors on glucagon secretion?	GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors cause decreased glucagon secretion.
What type of cells do glomus tumors arise from, and where in the body are these cells located?	Glomus tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the thermoregulatory glomus body.
What is the concept of glomerulotubular balance, and what is the relationship between filtration and reabsorption in this process?	The concept of glomerulotubular balance describes a balance between filtration in the glomerulus and reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
How can glomerular filtration rate be estimated, and what is the equation used to calculate it?	Glomerular filtration rate may be estimated using the equation: GFR = Cinulin = [U]inulin * V / [P]inulin.
What is the association between global growth lag and the different forms of fetal growth restriction (FGR)?	Global growth lag is associated with symmetric forms of FGR.
What is global aphasia, and how is the speech of individuals with this condition typically characterized?	Global aphasia is a type of aphasia that affects multiple language modalities, and it is typically characterized by nonfluent speech.
What is global aphasia, and how does it affect an individual's ability to repeat words or phrases?	Global aphasia is a type of aphasia that affects multiple language modalities, and it is typically characterized by impaired repetition.
What is global aphasia, and how does it affect an individual's ability to comprehend language?	Global aphasia is a type of aphasia that affects multiple language modalities, and it is typically characterized by impaired comprehension.
Where in the brain are glioblastomas most commonly found?	Glioblastomas are most commonly found in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.
What type of cell proliferation characterizes glioblastoma multiforme?	Glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by endothelial cell proliferation.
What is glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), and what type of cells does it affect?	Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant, high-grade tumor of astrocytes.
What type of cells does glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) affect, and what is its nature?	Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant, high-grade tumor of astrocytes.
What type of visual field loss is associated with glaucoma, and what happens if it is left untreated?	Glaucoma is associated with progressive peripheral visual field loss if untreated.
What is glaucoma associated with, and specifically what type of pressure is elevated?	Glaucoma is associated with elevated intraocular pressure.
What is the platelet count like in individuals with Glanzmann thrombasthenia?	Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with normal platelet count.
What is the bleeding time like in individuals with Glanzmann thrombasthenia?	Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with increased bleeding time.
What is a characteristic finding on blood smear in individuals with Glanzmann thrombasthenia?	Glanzmann thrombasthenia is characterized by no platelet clumping on blood smear.
What type of platelet disorder is Glanzmann Thrombasthenia and how is it inherited?	Glanzmann Thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive qualitative platelet disorder.
True or False: Rh-Ab (+) mothers are given Rhogam.	True.
What is the cause of Gilbert syndrome and what is the resulting increase in bilirubin?	Gilbert syndrome is due to mildly low UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity leading to isolated increase in unconjugated bilirubin.
How is Gilbert syndrome diagnosed and what are the typical laboratory findings?	Gilbert syndrome is diagnosed by elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin with normal LFTs and CBC.
What is the appropriate action to take when mentally unstable patients give gifts?	Gifts given by mentally unstable patients should not be accepted.
What triggers the transformation of Giardia lamblia cysts into trophozoites and where does this transformation occur in the body?	Giardia lamblia cysts become trophozoites in the duodenum when stimulated by gastric acid after ingestion.
What is the life cycle of Giardia and what forms does it take during its life cycle?	Giardia is ingested in the cyst form. After ingestion, it differentiates into the trophozoite form.
How is Giardia commonly transmitted and what is the source of transmission?	Giardia is a parasite commonly transmitted through consumption of poorly purified water.
How does Giardia affect the microvilli on enterocytes and what are the consequences of this disruption?	Giardia disrupts microvilli on enterocytes, leading to significant malabsorption, such as lactose intolerance and fatty acid malabsorption.
What are the common symptoms associated with Giardia infection?	Giardia (parasite) commonly presents with bloating, flatulence, and foul-smelling diarrhea.
Where does giant cell tumor typically develop?	Giant cell tumor usually arises at the distal femur or proximal tibia.
What is another name for giant cell tumor of bone?	Giant cell tumor of bone is also known as an osteoclastoma.
What appearance is typically associated with giant cell tumor on an X-ray?	Giant cell tumor is associated with a "soap bubble" appearance on X-ray.
What type of tumor is giant cell tumor?	Giant cell tumor is a locally aggressive benign tumor.
Where does giant cell tumor typically arise, and in which region of the body is it most commonly found?	Giant cell tumor typically arises in the epiphysis of long bones, often in the knee region.
What is the treatment for giant cell arteritis when it presents with impaired vision?	When giant cell arteritis presents with impaired vision, the treatment is high dose IV steroids.
What symptom may be present in cases of giant cell (temporal) arteritis, and what is the cause of this symptom?	Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with unilateral headache, which is caused by involvement of the temporal artery.
What is one symptom that may be present in cases of giant cell (temporal) arteritis?	Jaw claudication is a symptom that may be present in cases of giant cell (temporal) arteritis.
What type of vasculitis is giant cell (temporal) arteritis classified as?	Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is classified as a form of large-vessel vasculitis.
From which cells do GI stromal tumors (GISTs) derive?	GI stromal tumors (GISTs) are well-circumscribed mesenchymal tumors that derive from interstitial cells of Cajal, which are pacemaker cells.
What is the effect of Gi proteins on the cAMP signaling cascade?	Gi proteins inhibit the cAMP signaling cascade.
What is the effect of GI irritation caused by infection, chemotherapy, or distension on mucosal release?	GI irritation caused by infection, chemotherapy, or distension causes mucosal serotonin release.
What is the recommended approach for localizing and embolizing in cases of GI bleeding and hemodynamic instability?	In cases of GI bleeding and hemodynamic instability, angiography is recommended for localizing and embolizing.
What happens to ghrelin levels after gastric bypass surgery?	Ghrelin levels decrease after gastric bypass surgery.
When is ghrelin secreted from the stomach?	Ghrelin is secreted from the stomach during fasting states.
What is the function of ghrelin, which is secreted by gastric cells?	Ghrelin, which is secreted by gastric cells, acts to increase appetite.
What are the potential symptoms of GHomas (mammosomatotroph cells) in children?	GHomas (mammosomatotroph cells) may present with pituitary gigantism and lack of secondary sex characteristics in children.
What are the symptoms of gestational thrombocytopenia?	Gestational thrombocytopenia typically presents with no symptoms.
At what point in a pregnancy can gestational hypertension or eclampsia be diagnosed?	Gestational hypertension or eclampsia diagnosis typically starts after 20 weeks of pregnancy.
What is the treatment for gestational diabetes if nutrition therapy and exercise do not effectively manage the condition?	If nutrition therapy and exercise alone fail to manage gestational diabetes, it is typically treated with insulin replacement.
What is gestational diabetes?	Gestational diabetes is the onset of maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy.
What is the typical management approach for gestational diabetes?	Gestational diabetes is typically managed with insulin.
What is the cause of increased insulin resistance leading to gestational diabetes during pregnancy?	Gestational diabetes is a result of increased insulin resistance due to elevated levels of human placental lactogen during pregnancy.
What are the potential complications of gestational diabetes for the fetus?	Gestational diabetes can lead to a placental vasculopathy, causing fetal asphyxia, growth restriction, and polycythemia.
What is the potential impact of gestational diabetes on the calcium levels of the infant?	Gestational diabetes can lead to hypocalcemia in the infant.
How is gestational diabetes defined in terms of the timing of onset during pregnancy?	Gestational diabetes is defined as diabetes that begins after 20 weeks of gestation.
How is gestational age calculated based on the last menstrual period (LMP)?	Gestational age can be calculated as the number of days after the first day of LMP.
What are the potential symptoms of GERD that can occur as it progresses?	GERD initially presents with dysphagia, but can progress to odynophagia due to erosive esophagitis or esophageal ulcers.
What is the management strategy for GERD in the presence of dysphagia?	GERD and dysphagia are managed with endoscopy to assess the severity of the condition and determine the appropriate treatment plan.
At what age range is genu valgus (knock knees) considered normal?	Genu valgus (knock knees) is considered normal between the ages of 4 and 8.
What are the symptoms associated with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis)?	Genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis) is associated with high rates of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and dysuria.
On which molecules are the abnormal proteins resulting from genetic mutations often expressed?	The abnormal proteins resulting from genetic mutations are often expressed on MHC class I molecules.
What types of pregnancy loss are associated with genetic issues and anatomical issues, respectively?	Genetic issues are often associated with early pregnancy loss, while anatomical issues are more commonly associated with late pregnancy loss.
How is the generation of antibody specificity achieved?	The generation of antibody specificity is achieved via somatic hypermutation with affinity maturation.
What type of group is generally found at the 5' end of DNA or RNA?	Generally, a phosphate group is found at the 5' end of DNA or RNA.
What type of group is generally found at the 3' end of DNA or RNA?	Generally, a hydroxyl group is found at the 3' end of DNA or RNA.
What is the usual diagnostic method for confirming pathology in the right upper quadrant (RUQ)?	Generally, ultrasound is the usual diagnostic method for confirming pathology in the RUQ.
What is the potential consequence of obstructive lung diseases on the pulmonary vasculature?	Generally, obstructive lung diseases increase the risk for chronic, hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction with subsequent development of cor pulmonale.
How does the gram coverage change as we move from 1st generation to 5th generation cephalosporins?	Generally speaking, as we move from 1st generation to 5th generation cephalosporins, there will be more gram negative bacteria coverage.
How can generalized seizures be distinguished from syncopal episodes?	Generalized seizures may be differentiated from syncopal episodes by the presence of a post-ictal state.
What are some potential complications of generalized seizures?	Generalized seizures can lead to tongue laceration and loss of consciousness (LOC) with a post-ictal state.
How are generalized seizures characterized?	Generalized seizures are characterized by loss of consciousness (LOC) with tonic-clonic movements.
In what types of tumors is gemcitabine effective?	Gemcitabine is effective against hematologic malignancies as well as solid tumors.
What type of cytotoxic analog is gemcitabine?	Gemcitabine is a cytotoxic pyrimidine analog.
What is a potential side effect of gemcitabine?	Gemcitabine can result in myelo-suppression, which can lead to -cytopenias.
What is a potential effect of gemcitabine on the immune system?	Gemcitabine can result in immunosuppression, which increases the risk for infection.
What chemotherapeutic agents are used for palliative therapy in nonresectable pancreatic carcinoma?	Gemcitabine and 5-fluorouracil are two chemotherapeutic agents used for palliative therapy in nonresectable pancreatic carcinoma.
What is the basis on which fragments are separated in gel electrophoresis?	Gel electrophoresis separates fragments on the basis of size.
What is the recommended treatment for patients with GBS (+) and non-anaphylactic PCN allergy?	The recommended treatment for patients with GBS (+) and non-anaphylactic PCN allergy is cefazolin.
What do "Gaucher cells" look like and what are they characterized by in Gaucher disease?	"Gaucher cells" are lipid-laden macrophages that are characterized by resembling crumpled tissue paper in Gaucher disease.
What bone abnormality is associated with Gaucher disease?	Gaucher disease is associated with avascular necrosis of the femur.
In what direction do the bright red intestines protrude in Gastroschisis and where do they protrude from?	The bright red intestines in Gastroschisis protrude to the right side of a normal umbilicus.
What is the cause of Gastroparesis and what is the effect on peristalsis of food through the stomach?	Gastroparesis is caused by dysfunction of the vagus nerve, which leads to impaired peristalsis of food through the stomach.
What type of medication can be used to reverse opioid-induced constipation and provide an example of a gastrointestinal-specific opioid antagonist?	Gastrointestinal-specific opioid antagonists such as methylnaltrexone can be used in patients to reverse opioid-induced constipation.
What symptom commonly presents in Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that can be mistaken for cardiac chest pain?	Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) often presents with heartburn, which can mimic cardiac chest pain.
What part of the teeth may be damaged as a result of Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?	Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may damage the enamel of teeth.
What medical condition may result from elevated gastrin levels caused by gastrinomas?	Gastrinomas may cause peptic ulcer disease due to elevated gastrin levels.
What is the effect of high pH of gastric contents on gastrin secretion?	Gastrin secretion is stimulated by high pH of gastric contents.
How does low pH of gastric contents affect gastrin secretion?	Gastrin secretion is inhibited by low pH of gastric contents.
What is the effect of somatostatin on gastrin secretion?	Gastrin secretion is inhibited by somatostatin.
What neuropeptide is involved in the stimulation of gastrin secretion by vagal stimulation?	Gastrin secretion is stimulated by vagal stimulation via the neuropeptide gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP, bombesin).
What factor most stimulates gastrin secretion in the stomach?	Gastrin secretion is most stimulated by stomach distention.
Which receptors on parietal cells does gastrin bind to in order to increase H+ secretion?	Gastrin increases H+ secretion directly via binding to CCKB receptors on parietal cells.
Which cells are primarily affected by gastrin in order to increase acid secretion?	Gastrin increases acid secretion primarily through its effects on ECL cells.
What is the skin condition that can sometimes be associated with gastric adenocarcinoma, and what are its characteristics?	Gastric adenocarcinoma rarely may present with acanthosis nigricans, which is hyperpigmented velvety plaques in the axilla and neck.
What is the layer of the stomach that gastric ulcers can extend into and beyond?	Gastric ulcers may extend into and beyond the submucosa.
Which layer of the stomach is involved in gastric erosions?	Gastric erosions involves loss of the mucosal layer only.
Which artery may experience bleeding as a result of rupture of gastric ulcers on the lesser curvature of the stomach?	Gastric ulcers on the lesser curvature of the stomach may rupture, leading to bleeding from the left gastric artery.
What is the most common cause of gastric ulcers, accounting for approximately 70% of cases?	Gastric ulcers are usually due to H. pylori (~ 70%).
What treatment may lead to regression of gastric MALTomas?	Gastric MALTomas may regress with treatment of H. pylori.
What is responsible for mediating gastric HCl secretion during the cephalic phase?	Gastric HCl secretion during the cephalic phase is mediated by vagal stimulation only.
What are the two factors responsible for mediating gastric HCl secretion during the gastric phase?	Gastric HCl secretion during the gastric phase is mediated by both vagal stimulation and direct gastrin release.
When does gastric carcinoma typically present and what are its common symptoms?	Gastric carcinoma typically presents late with weight loss, early satiety, abdominal pain, and anemia.
How is gastric carcinoma subclassified and what are the two types?	Gastric carcinoma is subclassified into two types: intestinal and diffuse.
What is the difference in lymphadenopathy presentation between GAS Pharyngitis and EBV?	GAS Pharyngitis will present with anterior chain lymphadenopathy, while EBV will have posterior chain lymphadenopathy.
How are GAS erythrogenic toxin genes encoded and what is the process called?	GAS erythrogenic toxin genes are encoded in a lysogenic phage through specialized transduction.
What causes gas emboli in divers and how does it occur?	Gas emboli occur due to bubbling of nitrogen gas out of blood, due to rapid ascent by a diver.
What are iatrogenic gas emboli and how can they occur during laparoscopic procedures?	Gas emboli may be iatrogenic, secondary to laparoscopic procedures as air is pumped into the abdomen.
What is the treatment for Gardnerella vaginalis?	Gardnerella vaginalis is treated with metronidazole.
What is the characteristic odor associated with Gardnerella vaginalis?	Gardnerella vaginalis is said to have a fishy odor.

What type of vaccine is the Gardasil HPV vaccine?	The Gardasil HPV vaccine is a subunit vaccine.
What are the channel proteins called that are found in gap junctions and allow for communication between cells?	The channel proteins found in gap junctions are called connexons.
What type of necrosis is gangrenous necrosis?	Gangrenous necrosis is a form of coagulative necrosis.
What is the cause of ganglion cysts?	Ganglion cysts arise from herniation of dense connective tissue.
What structures are ganglion cysts often found in association and communication with on the dorsum of the hand?	Ganglion cysts are often found in association and in communication with synovial sheaths on the dorsum of the hand.
At what location are ganglion cysts most commonly found?	Ganglion cysts are most commonly found at the distal attachment of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) muscle.
How does ganciclovir triphosphate inhibit viral replication?	Ganciclovir triphosphate incorporates into viral DNA, inhibiting viral DNA-dependent DNA polymerase.
What process must ganciclovir undergo to reach its activated nucleotide form?	Ganciclovir must be phosphorylated three times by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form.
What is the eventual product of the conversion of ganciclovir monophosphate by cellular kinases?	Ganciclovir monophosphate is eventually converted to ganciclovir triphosphate by cellular kinases.
Through which gene do virus-encoded kinases convert ganciclovir to ganciclovir monophosphate?	Virus-encoded kinases convert ganciclovir to ganciclovir monophosphate via the UL-97 gene.
Which organs or tissues are affected by toxicity caused by ganciclovir?	Ganciclovir causes toxicity at the bone marrow and the kidneys.
What type of analogs are Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir?	Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are guanosine analogs.
In which type of patients are Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir used to treat CMV?	Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are used to treat CMV, especially in immunocompromised patients.
In which type of patients are Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir used as prophylaxis of CMV retinitis?	Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are used as prophylaxis of CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients.
What is the common medical condition that Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are used to treat?	Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are commonly used to treat CMV.
What type of suppression is associated with Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir?	Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are associated with bone marrow suppression.

What is the elective treatment for symptomatic gallstones?	The elective treatment for symptomatic gallstones is cholecystectomy.

What type of spectrum anti-epileptic is gabapentin?	Gabapentin is a narrow spectrum anti-epileptic.
What type of stress are red blood cells susceptible to in the presence of G6PD deficiency?	G6PD deficiency renders red blood cells susceptible to oxidative stress.
What are the symptoms that present in G6PD deficiency after exposure to oxidative stress?	G6PD deficiency presents with hemoglobin-uria and back pain hours after exposure to oxidative stress.
What type of hemolysis is primarily associated with G6PD deficiency?	G6PD deficiency is primarily characterized by intravascular hemolysis.
What type of anemia can be caused by G6PD deficiency?	G6PD deficiency can cause normocytic anemia.

What factor activates Factor V of the coagulation cascade?	What factor activates Factor V of the coagulation cascade? Factor IIa.

What medications may cause esophagitis?	Esophagitis may occur with medications such as bisphosphonates, tetracyclines, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), iron supplements, and potassium chloride.
What is Enthesitis and what does it involve?	Enthesitis involves inflammation of the attachments to bone.
What are the potential infections caused by Enterococcus spp.?	Enterococcus spp. can result in urinary tract infections (UTIs), subacute endocarditis, and biliary tree infections.
What is the mechanism by which Enterococcus spp. can become resistant to ampicillin?	Enterococcus spp. can become resistant to ampicillin due to β-lactamase production.
What is the characteristic of Enterococcus spp. with respect to bile solubility?	Enterococcus spp. are bile insoluble (also known as resistant).
What is the result of the pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) test for Enterococcus?	Enterococcus is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) positive.
How does the prevalence of Enterococcus faecium compare to Enterococcus faecalis, and how does their likelihood of vancomycin resistance compare?	Enterococcus faecium is less common and more likely to be resistant to vancomycin than Enterococcus faecalis.
How does the prevalence of Enterococcus faecalis compare to Enterococcus faecium, and how does their likelihood of vancomycin resistance compare?	Enterococcus faecalis is more common and less likely to be resistant to vancomycin than Enterococcus faecium.
In which parts of the human body do Enterococci spp. typically reside?	Enterococci spp. normally inhabit the lower gastrointestinal (GI) and genitourinary (GU) tracts.
What are the two species that are included in Enterococci spp.?	Enterococci spp. include Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium.
What type of anaerobes are Enterococci spp.?	Enterococci spp. are facultative anaerobes.
What is the gram staining characteristic of Enterococci spp.?	Enterococci spp. are gram positive.
What are the two types of culture media on which Enteroccoci species can grow?	Enteroccoci species grows on 6.5% NaCl and 40% bile culture media.
What are the two medications used to treat Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm)?	Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) is treated with pyrantel pamoate or albendazole.
What is the diagnostic method used to detect Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection?	Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection is diagnosed using the "tape test".
What are the two vitamins that are produced by Enteric bacteria (Gut flora)?	Enteric bacteria (Gut flora) produce vitamins, particularly Vitamins K and B9.
What are the three medications that can be used to treat HBV?	Entecavir, tenofovir, and PEG-IFN-alpha can be used to treat HBV.
What is another medication, besides Entecavir and Tenofovir, that can be used to treat HBV?	PEG-IFN-alpha can be used to treat HBV, in addition to Entecavir and Tenofovir.
In which countries is Entamoeba histolytica most commonly found?	Entamoeba histolytica is most common in developing countries.
What are the two stages of Entamoeba histolytica?	Entamoeba histolytica has two stages: an infective 4-nuclei cyst stage and an invasive trophozoite stage.
What is Entacapone and how is it used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa?	Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa by preventing its peripheral methylation.
What is the most likely cause of an enlarging neck fluid collection after thyroidectomy?	Enlarging neck fluid collection after thyroidectomy is most likely an expanding neck hematoma.
