What symptom can enlargement of the heart cause due to compression of the esophagus?	Enlargement of the heart can cause dysphagia due to compression of the esophagus.
What is the function of enhancers in gene transcription?	Enhancers serve as binding sites for specific transcription factors.
How do enhancers increase transcription of genes?	Enhancers increase transcription via enhanced activity of the enzyme RNA polymerase II.
What is the location of the skin reaction caused by enfuvirtide?	Enfuvirtide causes a skin reaction at injection sites.
What is the mechanism of action of enfuvirtide against HIV?	Enfuvirtide binds gp41 of HIV inhibiting viral cell fusion with host cells.
What is the specific patient population that is treated with Enfuvirtide and Maraviroc for HIV?	Enfuvirtide and Maraviroc are used for treatment-resistant patients with HIV.
What is the effect of endotoxin/lipopolysaccharide of Gram-negative bacteria on tissue factor and coagulation?	Endotoxin/Lipopolysaccharide of Gram-negative bacteria can activate tissue factor, resulting in coagulation and possible DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).
What is the effect of endotoxin/lipopolysaccharide binding to CD14 of macrophages and what proinflammatory cytokines are released as a result?	Endotoxin/Lipopolysaccharide binding to CD14 of macrophages releases IL-1, IL-6, TNF-a, and NO (proinflammatory cytokines).
What cytokines are triggered by endotoxin?	TNF and IL-1.
What symptoms can endotoxin present on gram-negative bacteria cause?	Endotoxin present on gram-negative bacteria can cause fever and shock.
What is the heat stability of endotoxin?	Endotoxin is heat stable.
What type of antibody response does endotoxin generate?	Endotoxin generates a weak antibody response.
What are the factors that may lead to a prothrombotic state due to endothelial injury?	Endothelial injury may lead to a prothrombotic state due to activation of endothelin and tissue factor.
What is the effect of endothelial injury on leukocyte adhesion and activation at the site of injury?	Endothelial injury leads to upregulation of leukocyte adhesion molecules, which promote leukocyte adhesion and activation at the site of injury.
What are the effects of endothelial dysfunction on the pulmonary vasculature?	Endothelial dysfunction of the pulmonary vasculature results in increased vasoconstrictors and decreased vasodilators.
What are the effects of endothelial dysfunction, such as left-sided heart failure, on vasoconstrictive and vasodilative mediators?	Endothelial dysfunction, such as left-sided heart failure, leads to an increase in vasoconstrictive mediators and a decrease in vasodilative mediators.
What substance do endothelial cells secrete to prevent thrombosis, and what is the function of this substance?	Endothelial cells secrete tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which converts plasminogen to plasmin and helps prevent thrombosis.
How do endothelial cells prevent thrombosis and what is the role of heparin-like molecules in this process?	Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by secreting heparin-like molecules, which augment antithrombin III (ATIII) and help prevent blood clot formation.
How do endothelial cells prevent thrombosis and what is the role of thrombomodulin in this process?	Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by producing thrombomodulin, which redirects thrombin to activate protein C and inhibit blood clotting.
What substances do endothelial cells produce to prevent thrombosis?	Endothelial cells produce prostacyclin (PGI2) and nitric oxide (NO) to prevent thrombosis.
What is the relationship between endothelial and fibroblast cell death and calcification on the aortic valve?	Endothelial and fibroblast cell death cause calcification on the aortic valve, which can lead to valve dysfunction and cardiovascular disease.
What are the potential symptoms associated with endometriosis spreading to the bowel serosa?	Endometriosis spread to the bowel serosa presents with abdominal pain and adhesions, which can cause bowel obstruction and other complications.
What is a potential symptom associated with endometriosis spreading to the bladder wall?	Endometriosis spread to the bladder wall presents with dysuria, which is pain or discomfort during urination.
How does emphysema typically affect heart and lung sounds?	Emphysema may present with distant or diminished heart and lung sounds.
What is a common symptom of emphysema that relates to weight?	Emphysema may present with weight loss.
What are some of the causes of emphysema?	Emphysema may be caused by excessive inflammation or proteases, or by a lack of α1-antitrypsin.
What is the underlying cause of emphysema?	Emphysema is due to an imbalance of proteases (e.g. elastase) and antiproteases (e.g. α1-antitrypsin).
What is a defining feature of emphysema?	Emphysema is characterized by enlargement of air spaces.
What is the effect of emphysema on the ability to exhale air from the alveoli?	Emphysema is characterized by loss of elastic recoil, which inhibits the ability to exhale air from the alveoli (air trapping).
What is a potential consequence of the loss of elastic recoil in emphysema?	Emphysema is characterized by loss of elastic recoil, which may lead to airway collapse during exhalation.
What are the radiographic features associated with emphysema?	Emphysema is characterized by increased AP diameter with a flattened diaphragm on CXR.
What is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and what type of tissue does it involve?	Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, also known as sarcoma botryoides, is a rare malignant mesenchymal proliferation of immature skeletal muscle.
What are the tumor marker levels associated with embryonal carcinoma?	Embryonal carcinoma may have increased levels of hCG and normal or elevated levels of AFP.
What is the typical morphology of embryonal carcinoma, a type of testicular germ cell tumor?	Embryonal carcinoma is a testicular germ cell tumor that often has a glandular/papillary morphology.
What is the prognosis for embryonal carcinoma, a non-seminoma germ cell tumor?	Embryonal carcinoma is a non-seminoma germ cell tumor and therefore has a relatively worse prognosis.
What is the most common cause of embolic stroke?	Embolic stroke is most commonly due to atrial fibrillation.
Which artery is commonly affected by embolic ischemic strokes?	Embolic ischemic strokes commonly affect the middle cerebral artery.
What type of receptor agonist is Eltrombopag, and what is it used for?	Eltrombopag is a thrombopoetin receptor agonist used to treat thrombocytopenia.
What are some examples of good sleep hygiene that can be used to treat insomnia?	Examples of good sleep hygiene used to treat insomnia include eliminating caffeine after lunch and avoiding naps.
In what situation is elevated β-hCG commonly seen during pregnancy?	Elevated β-hCG is commonly seen in pregnancy, especially when there are multiple gestations.
What type of defects can elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP) be associated with?	Elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP) can be associated with abdominal wall defects (ex. Omphalocele).
What are some risk factors for hernias?	Elevated intra-abdominal pressure and strenuous exercise are risk factors for hernias.
What is a confirmatory test for neural tube defects and what substance is measured in this test?	A confirmatory test for neural tube defects is measuring elevated acetylcholinesterase (AChE) levels in amniotic fluid.
What is suggested by elevated titers of antinuclear antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies?	Elevated titers of antinuclear antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies suggest a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis.
What condition may be caused by elevated PTH levels?	Elevated PTH levels may cause type II RTA (non-anion gap metabolic acidosis).
In a non-pregnant patient, what is indicated by elevated levels of progesterone?	Elevated levels of progesterone in a non-pregnant patient indicate that ovulation has occurred.
What does the presence of elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine indicate?	The presence of elevated levels of 5-HIAA, a metabolite of serotonin, in the urine is indicative of a carcinoid tumor.
What is required for definitive diagnosis of neoplasia when serum tumor markers are elevated?	When serum tumor markers are elevated, tissue biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis of neoplasia.
What are some examples of paraneoplastic syndromes that can cause elevated hCG levels?	Elevated hCG can be a paraneoplastic syndrome, such as in pinealomas or large cell carcinoma.
In what type of woman is an elevated CA-125 level concerning for cancer?	An elevated CA-125 level in a post-menopausal woman is concerning for cancer.
What is indicated by an elevated BNP level?	An elevated BNP level is indicative of S3.
What type of pathology is indicated by elevated levels of both alkaline phosphatase and GGT?	Elevated levels of both alkaline phosphatase and GGT are specific for biliary pathology.
What condition is indicated by the presence of both elevated AFP and oligohydramnios?	The presence of both elevated AFP and oligohydramnios is indicative of Gastroschisis.
What is the most likely diagnosis when a patient presents with both elevated ACE and hypercalcemia?	The most likely diagnosis when a patient presents with both elevated ACE and hypercalcemia is sarcoidosis.
In the electron transport chain, where are electrons from cytochrome C transferred to?	Electrons from cytochrome C in the electron transport chain are transferred to complex IV (Cyto a/a3).
In the electron transport chain, where are electrons from complex III transferred to?	Electrons from complex III in the electron transport chain are transferred to cytochrome C.
In the electron transport chain, where are electrons from coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) transferred to?	Electrons from coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) in the electron transport chain are transferred to complex III (Cyto b/c1).
What effect do electron transport inhibitors have on the proton gradient and ATP synthesis?	Electron transport inhibitors cause a decreased proton gradient and block of ATP synthesis.
Where do Electron Transport and Oxidative Phosphorylation occur in bacteria?	Electron Transport and Oxidative Phosphorylation occur on the cell membrane of bacteria.
What are some electrolyte abnormalities that can result from the use of amphotericin B?	Electrolyte abnormalities, such as hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, can result from amphotericin B use.
What is the potential life-threatening consequence of electrolyte abnormalities due to succinylcholine?	Electrolyte abnormalities due to succinylcholine can lead to a life-threatening cardiac arrhythmia.
What type of seizure does electroconvulsive therapy produce in a patient who is under anesthesia?	Electroconvulsive therapy produces a grand mal seizure in a patient under anesthesia.
In cases of electrical burns, what serum level should be checked due to the potential development of myoglobinuria?	In cases of electrical burns, one should check a serum CK level due to the potential development of myoglobinuria.
What is the type of scaffolding associated with tropoelastin in elastin?	The type of scaffolding associated with tropoelastin in elastin is fibrillin.
Which non-hydroxylated amino acids are abundant in elastin?	Elastin is rich in non-hydroxylated proline, glycine, and lysine residues (amino acids).
What is the enzyme that breaks down elastin, and what is the normal inhibitor of this enzyme?	Elastin is broken down by the enzyme elastase, which is normally inhibited by α1-antitrypsin.
How is elastic recoil related to compliance and elastance?	Elastic recoil is inversely proportional to compliance and directly proportional to elastance.
What is the normal range for ejection fraction?	Ejection fraction is normally > 55%.
What is the process that must occur before ejaculated sperm can fertilize an ovum?	Ejaculated sperm cannot immediately fertilize an ovum, but rather must reside in the female reproductive tract for capacitation to occur.
In which chamber of the heart does Eisenmenger Syndrome lead to a decreased oxygen saturation?	Eisenmenger Syndrome leads to a decreased oxygen saturation in the LV (left ventricle).
What are the three main characteristics that define Eisenmenger syndrome?	Eisenmenger syndrome is characterized by a triad of late cyanosis, clubbing, and polycythemia.
What is the main structure in the adult testis that produces sperm?	Eighty percent of the adult testis is composed of seminiferous tubules, which produce the sperm.
What are some common symptoms associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?	Ehlers-Danlos syndrome may present with easy bruising and a tendency to bleed.
What is the main cause of joint hypermobility in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?	Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by faulty collagen synthesis causing hypermobile joints.
What is the main effect of faulty collagen synthesis on the skin in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?	Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by faulty collagen synthesis causing hyperextensible skin.
What is the relationship between egg protein allergy and administration of the influenza vaccine?	Egg protein allergy is a contraindication when administering the influenza vaccine.
What is the relationship between Effective RPF (eRPF) and true renal plasma flow?	Effective RPF (eRPF) under-estimates true renal plasma flow slightly (~10%).
What is EDTA used for, and in what context is it commonly used?	EDTA is a chelator that is commonly used for heavy metal poisoning.
What is the relationship between hematocrit levels and two types of pancreatitis, edematous pancreatitis and hemorrhagic pancreatitis?	Edematous pancreatitis is typically associated with high hematocrit levels, while hemorrhagic pancreatitis is typically associated with low hematocrit levels.
What are the two factors that may cause edema in the body?	Edema in the body may be caused by sodium and water retention.
What is one possible cause of edema in the body?	Edema in the body may be caused by lymphatic obstruction.
What is one factor that may contribute to the development of edema in the body?	An increase in interstitial proteins (πi) is one factor that may cause edema.
What is one potential cause of edema in the body?	Edema in the body may be caused by an increase in capillary pressure (Pc).
What is one possible reason for the development of edema in the body?	Edema in the body may be caused by an increase in capillary permeability (Kf).
What is one potential factor that may lead to the development of edema in the body?	Edema in the body may be caused by a decrease in plasma proteins (πc).
What medical condition may be associated with both edema and cyanosis?	Chronic bronchitis may be associated with both edema and cyanosis.
What is the medical condition that Eculizumab is indicated for the treatment of?	Eculizumab is indicated for the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria.
What is the specific complement protein that Eculizumab targets as a monoclonal antibody?	Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody for the C5 complement protein.
What is the hormonal presentation that may indicate an ectopic pregnancy?	An ectopic pregnancy may present with a lower than expected rise in the hormone hCG based on dates.
What medical condition is ectopic pregnancy often mistaken for clinically?	Ectopic pregnancy is often clinically mistaken for appendicitis.
In which part of the fallopian tube do ectopic pregnancies have the highest risk of tubal rupture?	Ectopic pregnancies within the isthmus have the highest risk of tubal rupture.
What diagnostic tool is used to confirm ectopic pregnancies and what is the standard treatment for them?	Ectopic pregnancies are confirmed with ultrasound and treated with immediate surgery.
What is the chemical classification of MDMA, commonly known as Ecstasy?	Ecstasy (MDMA) is classified as an amphetamine.
What is the recommended course of action for cases of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome?	Eclampsia and HELLP syndrome both warrant immediate delivery of the baby.
What is the mechanism of action of echothiophate and what condition is it used to treat?	Echothiophate is an indirect cholinomimetic used to treat glaucoma.
How is Echinococcus granulosus transmitted and through which animal's feces?	Echinococcus granulosus is transmitted via dog feces.
What is the purpose of injecting ethanol into Echinococcus granulosus cysts during surgery and what does it prevent?	Echinococcus granulosus cysts are injected with ethanol during surgery to kill larvae and prevent spread/anaphylaxis.
What are the treatment options for Echinococcus granulosus and which method is more commonly used?	Echinococcus granulosus can be treated with albendazole, but the more common method is surgery.
What is the relationship between Echinococcus granulosis (hydatid cysts) and albendazole?	Echinococcus granulosis (hydatid cysts) can be treated with albendazole.
How do echinocandins inhibit cell wall synthesis and what specific component of the cell wall synthesis do they target?	Echinocandins inhibit cell wall synthesis by inhibiting synthesis of B-glucan.
What are the side effects of echinocandins and how do they cause these side effects?	Echinocandins can cause flushing and GI upset by stimulating histamine release.
What is the primary organ responsible for metabolizing echinocandins?	Echinocandins are primarily metabolized via the liver.
What types of infections are echinocandins primarily indicated for and what are the causative agents of these infections?	Echinocandins are primarily indicated for invasive infections of Aspergillosis and Candida.
What is the target site of echinocandins and how do they act as antifungal agents?	Echinocandins act at the cell wall and are antifungal agents.
What is the route of administration for echinocandins when used to treat systemic candidiasis?	Echinocandins are administered intravenously (IV) for systemic candidiasis.
What is the recommended next step in management when an ECG shows ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)?	When an ECG shows ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), the recommended next step in management is cardiac catheterization.
What are the specific ECG changes that may be associated with acute pericarditis?	ECG changes that may be associated with acute pericarditis include widespread, diffuse ST segment elevation and/or PR depression.
What effect does expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume have on capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc)?	Expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume produces an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc).
How does expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume affect capillary oncotic pressure (πC)?	Expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume produces a decrease in capillary oncotic pressure (πC).
How does contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume affect capillary oncotic pressure (πC)?	Contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume produces an increase in capillary oncotic pressure (πC).
How does contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume affect capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc)?	Contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume produces a decrease in capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc).
How does expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume affect HCO3- reabsorption?	Expansion of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume results in decreased HCO3- reabsorption.
How does contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume affect HCO3- reabsorption?	Contraction of extracellular fluid (ECF) volume results in increased HCO3- reabsorption.
What is the significance of EC50 of a drug?	EC50 of a drug is indicative of potency.
What health condition is EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) associated with, particularly in AIDS patients?	EBV is associated with CNS (central nervous system) lymphoma, especially in AIDS patients.
What type of cancer is EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) associated with, specifically the endemic/African form?	EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, the endemic/African form.
What health condition is EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) associated with in the context of post-transplant patients?	EBV is associated with Post-transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease.
Which molecule does the EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) envelope glycoprotein bind to in order to infect B-cells?	The EBV envelope glycoprotein binds CD21 to infect B-cells.
What type of mononucleosis is caused by EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) and what is the heterophile status associated with this condition?	EBV causes heterophile positive mononucleosis.
What type of carcinoma can be caused by EBV (Epstein-Barr virus), and in which population is this condition more prevalent?	EBV can result in nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in Asian and African males.
What cardiac condition is Ebstein's Anomaly associated with, and what is the potential consequence of this association?	Ebstein's Anomaly is associated with Wolff-Parkinson-White, which can lead to arrhythmias.
In an infant, what are the clinical manifestations of Ebstein's Anomaly, and which chamber of the heart is typically affected?	Ebstein's Anomaly manifests as early cyanosis and dilation of the right atrium in an infant.
What is the equivalent medical term for Ebstein's Anomaly?	Ebstein's Anomaly is equivalent to tricuspid regurgitation.
What is the diagnostic method for Ebola virus, and which bodily fluids can be used for testing?	Ebola virus is diagnosed via RT-PCR of blood or other bodily fluids.
What type of dementia is suggested by the presence of Parkinsonian features in individuals with early-onset dementia?	Early-onset dementia with Parkinsonian features is suggestive of Lewy body dementia.
What type of anemia is caused by early stages of iron deficiency?	Early stages of iron deficiency cause a normocytic anemia.
What type of anemia is caused by early stages of anemia of chronic disease?	Early stages of anemia of chronic disease cause a normocytic anemia.
Which lymph nodes are commonly affected by early spread of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?	Early spread of nasopharyngeal carcinoma commonly affects the cervical lymph nodes.
What parts of the kidney are affected in the early and later stages of renal amyloidosis?	In early renal amyloidosis, the mesangium is affected, whereas in later progression of renal amyloidosis, the glomerular capillaries are affected.
Does early postcoital voiding reduce the risk of UTI?	Yes, early postcoital voiding reduces the risk of UTI.
How is early Lyme disease diagnosed?	Early Lyme disease is diagnosed through clinical signs.

Is a new onset murmur a common symptom of pulmonary embolism?	No, a new onset murmur is not a common symptom of pulmonary embolism.
Is underlying carcinoma often present in patients with Paget's disease of the nipple?	Yes, underlying carcinoma is often present in patients with Paget's disease of the nipple.
Are systemic symptoms such as fever and fatigue typically present in patients with osteoarthritis?	No, systemic symptoms such as fever and fatigue are not typically present in patients with osteoarthritis.
Is joint involvement in osteoarthritis typically asymmetric or symmetric?	Joint involvement in osteoarthritis is typically asymmetric.
Is hyperammonemia a common symptom of orotic aciduria?	No, hyperammonemia is not a common symptom of orotic aciduria.
Is decreased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) a common symptom of orotic aciduria?	No, decreased BUN is not a common symptom of orotic aciduria.
Is orotic aciduria a common symptom of ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency?	Yes, orotic aciduria is a common symptom of ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.
Is megaloblastic anemia a common symptom of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency?	No, megaloblastic anemia is not a common symptom of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency.
Is surgical intervention typically necessary for omphalocele?	Yes, surgical intervention is typically necessary for omphalocele as it is considered a surgical emergency.
Is increased subarachnoid space volume a common finding in normal pressure hydrocephalus?	No, increased subarachnoid space volume is not a common finding in normal pressure hydrocephalus.
Is the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils a common finding in non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia?	No, the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils is not a common finding in non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia.
Are Reed-Sternberg cells typically present in Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma?	No, Reed-Sternberg cells are not typically present in Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma.
Does nitroprusside cause dilation of arterioles, veins, or both?	Nitroprusside causes dilation of both arterioles and veins.
Is hepatosplenomegaly a common clinical manifestation of Niemann-Pick disease?	Yes, hepatosplenomegaly is a common clinical manifestation of Niemann-Pick disease.
Is there a strong genetic component associated with narcolepsy?	Yes, there is a strong genetic component associated with narcolepsy.
Is there an increased risk for gastric cancer in patients with Ménétrier disease?	Yes, Ménétrier disease is considered a pre-cancerous lesion and is associated with an increased risk for gastric cancer.
Does myocardial infarction result in irreversible myocyte necrosis?	Yes, myocardial infarction causes irreversible myocyte necrosis.
Does Mittelschmerz pain occur during menstruation?	No, Mittelschmerz pain occurs during ovulation mid-cycle, specifically during the rupture of the follicular cyst.
What type of murmur is typically associated with mitral/tricuspid regurgitation?	A holo-systolic murmur is typically associated with mitral/tricuspid regurgitation.
What type of murmur is typically associated with mitral valve prolapse?	A late systolic murmur, often accompanied by a midsystolic click, is typically associated with mitral valve prolapse.
What type of murmur is typically associated with mitral stenosis?	A diastolic murmur is typically associated with mitral stenosis.
Does metoclopramide, a D2 receptor antagonist, affect colon transit time?	No, metoclopramide does not influence colon transport time.
When cancer metastasizes to the lung, is it more likely to present as a single or multiple lesion(s)?	Cancer metastasis to the lung typically presents as multiple lesions.
When cancer metastasizes to the liver, is it more likely to present as a single or multiple nodules?	Cancer metastasis to the liver typically presents as multiple nodules.
Does medullary thyroid cancer in MEN2A and MEN2B arise spontaneously or is it associated with a specific precursor lesion?	Medullary thyroid cancer in MEN2A and MEN2B is not sporadic; it occurs after parafollicular C cell hyperplasia.
If someone loses the lacrimation reflex, does it prevent the formation of emotional tears?	No, the loss of the lacrimation reflex does not prevent the formation of emotional tears.

Is lichen sclerosus associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma?	Yes, lichen sclerosus is associated with a slightly increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma.
Does lactose intolerance have an impact on the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa?	No, lactose intolerance does not affect the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa.
Does Klebsiella bacteria possess a capsule?	Yes, Klebsiella bacteria have a capsule.
Is Klebsiella capable of lactose fermentation?	Yes, Klebsiella is able to ferment lactose.
Does the innate immune system exhibit a memory response?	No, the innate immune system does not have a memory response.
Does the direct killing of bacteria occur through the inhibition of transpeptidases?	No, the inhibition of transpeptidases does not directly kill bacteria.
Is complement fixation a property of IgM?	Yes, IgM is known to fix complement.
Is IgM capable of crossing the placenta?	No, IgM is too large to cross the placenta, so it does not pass from the mother to the fetus.
Is complement fixation a property of IgG?	Yes, IgG is capable of fixing complement.
Is IgG able to cross the placenta?	Yes, IgG is the only immunoglobulin that is able to cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
Is complement fixation a property of IgA?	No, IgA does not fix complement.

How are different exons combined to produce a larger number of unique proteins?	Different exons are frequently combined by alternative splicing to produce a larger number of unique proteins.
How does the presentation of placenta previa differ from vasa previa?	Placenta previa is characterized by heavy, persistent bleeding, while vasa previa is typically associated with sudden, painless vaginal bleeding.
How does diethylcarbamazine work as an anti-helminthic agent?	Diethylcarbamazine works by interfering with arachidonic acid metabolism, which is an essential process for helminths to survive and reproduce.
What factors are taken into consideration for diagnosing a clavicle fracture?	Diagnosing a clavicle fracture involves taking into consideration the clinical presentation as well as imaging.
Which type of neurons are strictly affected by diabetic neuropathy?	Diabetic neuropathy strictly affects lower motor neurons.
What are some of the cranial nerve palsies that may be caused by diabetic neuropathy?	Diabetic neuropathy may cause cranial nerve palsies, especially affecting extraocular muscles (CN III, IV, and VI).
What type of incontinence is associated with diabetic neuropathy?	Diabetic neuropathy is associated with overflow incontinence.
What are some common triggers for the development of diabetic ketoacidosis?	Diabetic ketoacidosis often arises with stress, such as infection.
What is the common cause of the systemic release of catecholamines and cortisol that can precipitate diabetic ketoacidosis?	Diabetic ketoacidosis is often precipitated by acute infection due to systemic release of catecholamines and cortisol.
What is Kussmaul respirations and why is it associated with diabetic ketoacidosis?	Kussmaul respirations is rapid/deep breathing that is associated with diabetic ketoacidosis, as it compensates for metabolic acidosis.
What type of breath odor is commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis and why does it occur?	Diabetic ketoacidosis is commonly associated with a fruity breath odor due to exhaled acetone.
What are some of the changes in serum levels that may be observed in a person with diabetic ketoacidosis?	Diabetic ketoacidosis can present with increased serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and free fatty acids.
What histological finding is commonly seen on light microscopy in diabetic glomerulonephropathy?	Diabetic glomerulonephropathy is commonly associated with mesangial proliferation on light microscopy.
What are some of the ways in which diabetic gastroparesis can be managed?	Diabetic gastroparesis may be managed with small, frequent meals and prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide, erythromycin, and cisapride.
What complication is more likely to occur in a person with diabetic foot ulcers that have reached the bone?	Diabetic foot ulcers that reach the bone increase the likelihood of osteomyelitis.
What are some of the symptoms that may be seen in a person with diabetic autonomic neuropathy?	Diabetic autonomic neuropathy may present with syncope due to orthostatic hypotension and erectile dysfunction in men.
What condition is suggested by the presence of diabetes, gallstones, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria?	Diabetes, gallstones, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria is suggestive of somatostatinoma.
Who should undergo diabetes screening according to current recommendations?	Diabetes screening is recommended in adults aged 40-70 who are overweight or obese.
What type of incontinence may be seen in a person with diabetes mellitus?	Diabetes mellitus may result in overflow incontinence.
What type of complications can result from the qualitative platelet dysfunction caused by diabetes mellitus?	Diabetes mellitus causes qualitative platelet dysfunction that leads to thrombotic complications.
What is the risk factor associated with diabetes, and what are the mechanisms that contribute to this risk?	Diabetes is a risk factor for atherosclerosis due to chronic inflammation, lipid oxidation, and advanced glycation end products.
What type of osmotic change and volume status can be seen in a person with diabetes insipidus?	Diabetes insipidus will cause a hyper-osmotic change with euvolemia.
What is the recommended treatment for a person with both diabetes and microalbuminuria?	Diabetes and microalbuminuria = add ACE-I.

What is the potential cause of a falsely positive urine drug screen when dextromethorphan is present?	Dextromethorphan may cause a falsely positive PCP urine drug screen.
What are the potential effects and abuse potential of dextromethorphan, an antitussive medication?	Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that has mild opioid effects when used in excess and thus has mild abuse potential.
What type of chelator is dexrazoxane?	Dexrazoxane is an iron chelator.
What class of medications do dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, and prednisone belong to?	Dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, and prednisone are all examples of glucocorticoids.

What is the function of a Pavlik Harness in the treatment of Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip?	A Pavlik Harness is used to treat Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip by keeping the hips flexed and abducted.
What is one management option for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)?	One management option for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) is a harness.
What is the impact of developing an effective vaccine for a disease on its incidence and prevalence?	Developing an effective vaccine for a disease causes a decrease in both incidence and prevalence.
What is the impact of developing an effective treatment for a disease on its incidence and prevalence?	Developing an effective treatment for a disease causes no change in incidence and a decrease in prevalence.

What type of incontinence can be caused by detrusor muscle instability?	Detrusor muscle instability can cause urge incontinence.

What structures do desmosomes connect, and what molecules are involved in this connection?	Desmosomes connect intermediate filaments of adjacent cells via cadherins.
What condition can be treated with desmopressin, and what is this condition commonly known as?	Desmopressin may be used to treat night enuresis, which is commonly known as bed wetting.
What is the effect of desmopressin on the release of vWF, and from which cellular structures is this release increased?	Desmopressin increases the release of vWF from Weibel-Palade bodies.

Which gender is more commonly affected by dermatomyositis and polymyositis?	Dermatomyositis and polymyositis are more common in women.

What is the result of depurination?	Depurination results in the loss of purine bases.

What is the characteristic feature of serotonin levels in depression?	Depression is characterized by decreased serotonin levels.

Which part of the body does Dengue fever infect?	Dengue fever infects the bone marrow.
How many different serotypes of Dengue fever are there?	Dengue fever has 4 different serotypes.
What is a potential complication of Dengue fever?	Dengue fever can result in renal failure.

How would you define serous otitis media?	Serous otitis media can be defined as the presence of middle ear effusion without acute inflammation.
What condition is caused by a deficiency of the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) protein?	A deficiency of the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) protein causes autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome-1.
What condition is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase?	A deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase causes albinism.

What condition is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase?	A deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase causes alkaptonuria.
What condition is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase?	A deficiency of the enzyme branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase causes maple syrup urine disease.
What deficiency is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?	Deficiency of early complement proteins is associated with SLE.
What deficiencies are associated with torsades de pointes?	Deficiencies of potassium (K+) and magnesium (Mg2+) cations are associated with torsades de pointes.

What are deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone used for?	Deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone are iron chelators.
What can happen to defects with left-to-right shunting over time?	Defects with left-to-right shunting may be relatively asymptomatic at birth, but the shunt can eventually reverse.
What role do defects in the ubiquitin-proteasome system play in certain diseases?	Defects in the ubiquitin-proteasome system have been implicated in some cases of Parkinson disease.
Which specific defects in CD are associated with multiple sclerosis and type I diabetes mellitus?	Defects in CD 25 on regulatory T cells are associated with multiple sclerosis and type I diabetes mellitus.
What specific defective interactions can cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome?	Defective Fas-FasL interactions can cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome.
What conditions can result from defective bilirubin conjugation?	Defective bilirubin conjugation can result in Gilbert syndrome and Crigler-Najjar syndrome.
How does a hyperactive reflex (clonus) manifest in the Deep Tendon Reflexes?	A hyperactive reflex (clonus) manifests in the Deep Tendon Reflexes as a 4/4 reflex.
What does a brisk reflex indicate in the Deep Tendon Reflexes?	A brisk reflex in the Deep Tendon Reflexes is indicated by a 3/4 reflex.
What is the normal reflex response in the Deep Tendon Reflexes?	The normal reflex response in the Deep Tendon Reflexes is indicated by a 2/4 reflex.
What does a trace reflex indicate in the Deep Tendon Reflexes?	A trace reflex in the Deep Tendon Reflexes is indicated by a 1/4 reflex.
Which layers of the skin are involved in deep partial thickness burns?	The layers of the skin involved in deep partial thickness burns are the epidermis, superficial dermis, and deep dermis.
What are the characteristics of deep partial thickness burns and what type of pain do they cause?	Deep partial thickness burns are not blanchable and are painful to pressure only.
What is the possible cause of decreasing VA/Q and what type of shunt may be involved?	Decreasing VA/Q may be due to a right to left shunt.
What is the effect of decreases in temperature on the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve?	Decreases in temperature cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left.
What is the effect of decreases in contractility (e.g. heart failure) on the Starling curve?	Decreases in contractility cause the Starling curve to shift downward.
What is a normal finding in elderly patients regarding their upward gaze?	Decreased upward gaze is a normal finding in elderly patients.
What does decreased translation to the right at C4 suggest about the sidebending restriction of C4?	Decreased translation to the right at C4 suggests that C4 is restricted in sidebending to the left.
What condition is suggested by the presence of decreased sensation to pinprick, nystagmus, and hypertonia?	PCP is suggested by the presence of decreased sensation to pinprick, nystagmus, and hypertonia.
What is the effect of decreased Po2 (hypoxia) on the systemic circulation?	Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation.
What is the effect of decreased Po2 (hypoxia) on the pulmonary circulation?	Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vasoconstriction in the pulmonary circulation.
What is a possible consequence of decreased peripheral conversion of levodopa?	A possible consequence of decreased peripheral conversion of levodopa is hallucinations.
What is the effect of decreased PCO2 (respiratory alkalosis) on HCO3- reabsorption?	Decreased PCO2 (respiratory alkalosis) results in decreased HCO3- reabsorption.
What is the consequence of decreased medullary hypertonicity (e.g. due to loop diuretics) on urine concentration ability?	Decreased medullary hypertonicity (e.g. due to loop diuretics) results in an inability to concentrate urine.
What is the potential consequence of decreased magnesium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)?	Decreased magnesium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) may cause hypomagnesemia.
What are the associations between decreased hemoglobin (e.g. anemia) and SaO2, O2 content, and PaO2?	Decreased hemoglobin (e.g. anemia) is associated with normal SaO2, decreased O2 content, and normal PaO2.
What is the effect of decreased HCO3- (metabolic acidosis) on arterial pH?	Decreased HCO3- (metabolic acidosis) causes a decrease in arterial pH.
In what patient population taking what medication can decreased GFR and efferent constriction cause AKI?	Decreased GFR and efferent constriction causes AKI in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis taking ACE inhibitors.
What dietary component, when decreased, may cause calcium oxalate kidney stone formation?	Calcium.
What is the potential life-threatening consequence of decreased cortisol production in congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and what is the underlying mechanism?	Decreased cortisol production in congenital adrenal hyperplasia may cause life-threatening hypotension due to decreased alpha1-adrenergic receptors.
What is the effect on arterial pH of decreased CO2 levels, which are secondary to hyperventilation?	Decreased CO2, secondary to hyperventilation, causes an increase in arterial pH.
What is the effect on HCO3- levels by mass action of decreased CO2 (respiratory alkalosis)?	Decreased CO2 (respiratory alkalosis) causes a decrease in HCO3- by mass action.
What is the potential consequence of decreased cartilage mineralization of open epiphyseal growth plates in children with rickets?	Decreased cartilage mineralization of open epiphyseal growth plates may cause short stature in children with rickets.
What compensatory mechanism occurs in response to decreased arterial pH (metabolic acidosis), and what is the consequent effect on PCO2?	Decreased arterial pH (metabolic acidosis) causes compensatory hyper-ventilation, which leads to a consequent decrease in PCO2.
In the case of decreased ADAMTS13 (e.g. TTP), what is the typical cause of this decrease?	Decreased ADAMTS13 (e.g. TTP) is usually due to an acquired autoantibody.
Which dopaminergic pathway experiences decreased activity resulting in prolactin excess?	The tuberoinfundibular pathway experiences decreased activity resulting in prolactin excess.
Which dopaminergic pathway experiences decreased activity resulting in extrapyramidal symptoms?	The nigrostriatal pathway experiences decreased activity resulting in extrapyramidal symptoms.
What effect does decreased activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger (e.g. due to cardiac glycosides) have on intracellular Ca2+ concentration?	Decreased activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger (e.g. due to cardiac glycosides) causes an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration.
In relation to the red nucleus, what is the difference between decerebrate rigidity and decorticate rigidity?	Decerebrate rigidity occurs below the red nucleus, whereas decorticate rigidity occurs above the red nucleus.
What is the result of guanine deamination?	The result of guanine deamination is the formation of xanthine.
What is the ultimate product of adenine deamination?	The ultimate product of adenine deamination is hypoxanthine.
What is the product of deamination of 5-methyl cytosine?	The product of deamination of 5-methyl cytosine is thymine.
Where is the site of pain in De Quervain Tenosynovitis?	The site of pain in De Quervain Tenosynovitis is over the radial side of the wrist.
What are the management options for DCIS?	DCIS is managed with lumpectomy and radiation and hormonal therapy.
What is the role of DCC in the development of adenocarcinoma of the colon?	DCC is a tumor suppressor gene in the step of adenoma -> adenocarcinoma of the colon.
What is the association between inactivating mutations of the DCC gene and cancer?	The DCC gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and inactivating mutations are associated with colon cancer.
What is the potential finding in the urine days after an episode of intravascular hemolysis?	Days after an episode of intravascular hemolysis, hemosiderin may be seen in the urine.
What is the definition of dawn phenomena in diabetes?	Dawn phenomena in diabetes refers to hyperglycemia in the morning.
What is the significance of darkfield microscopy in the diagnosis of syphilis?	Darkfield microscopy is useful in the diagnosis of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum, especially during early primary syphilis.
What is the mechanism of action of Daptomycin?	Daptomycin is bactericidal, meaning it kills bacteria by disrupting their cell membrane.
What are the potential adverse effects associated with Daptomycin use?	Daptomycin use is associated with myopathy and rhabdomyolysis as potential adverse effects.
What is the mechanism of action of Daptomycin as an antibacterial?	Daptomycin works by creating transmembrane channels, which disrupt the bacterial cell membrane and ultimately lead to bacterial death.
What type of infections is Daptomycin used to treat?	Daptomycin is a lipopeptide antibiotic that is used to treat infections caused by Multi Drug Resistant Gram Positive Cocci.
What is the effect of Daptomycin on the bacterial cell wall?	Daptomycin inserts its lipid tail into the bacterial cell wall, causing membrane depolarization, which ultimately leads to bacterial death.
What is a specific type of infection that Daptomycin can be used to treat?	Daptomycin can be used to treat endocarditis caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
What type of antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains can Daptomycin be used to treat?	Daptomycin can be used to treat vancomycin-resistant bacterial strains.
What is the specific bacterial species that Dapsone is used to treat?	Dapsone is used to treat infections caused by Mycobacterium leprae, the bacteria that causes leprosy.
What is a dermatological condition that can be treated with Dapsone?	Dapsone can be used to treat Dermatitis Herpetiformis, a blistering skin disorder.

What are two medical conditions that are associated with Dandy-Walker malformation?	Dandy-Walker malformation is associated with non-communicating hydrocephalus and spina bifida.
What are two medical conditions that Danazol is used to treat?	Danazol is used to treat endometriosis and hereditary angioedema.
What is Danazol and how does it act on androgen receptors?	Danazol is a synthetic androgen that acts as a partial agonist at androgen receptors.
Which organ's damage can lead to issues with Vancomycin clearance?	The kidneys.
What medical condition can lead to damage in watershed zones?	Damage to watershed zones occurs with severe hypotension.

What type of weakness can result from damage to the internal border zone?	Damage to the internal border zone results in bilateral proximal extremity weakness.
What happens to the platelet count when microthrombi form due to damage to the glomerulus in Shigella-induced HUS?	Damage to the glomerulus in Shigella-induced HUS results in platelet aggregation, decreasing the platelet count when microthrombi form.
What happens to alveolar-capillary permeability when there is damage to the alveolar-capillary interface?	Damage to the alveolar-capillary interface leads to increased alveolar-capillary permeability.
What part of the dorsal column is affected by damage to a posterior spinal artery?	Damage to a posterior spinal artery affects the ipsilateral dorsal column.
What age group is commonly affected by malignancies that are treated with dactinomycin?	Dactinomycin is used to treat numerous malignancies that affect the pediatric age group.
In which group of patients is daclizumab contraindicated?	Daclizumab is contraindicated in patients with liver impairment.
What is the target of daclizumab, and what condition is it used to treat?	Daclizumab is a monoclonal antibody against CD25 (part of IL-2 receptor) that is used to treat relapsing multiple sclerosis.
Where are D2 dopamine receptors primarily found?	D2 dopamine receptors are primarily found in the central nervous system (CNS).
What condition is D-transposition of the great vessels associated with?	D-transposition of the great vessels is associated with maternal diabetes.
What condition is D-transposition of the great vessels and VSD associated with?	D-transposition of the great vessels and VSD are associated with maternal diabetes.
What are the effects of D-transposition of great vessels on the right and left ventricles?	D-transposition of great vessels results in hypertrophy of the right ventricle and atrophy of the left ventricle.
What is necessary to make D-transposition of great vessels compatible with life?	D-transposition of great vessels is not compatible with life unless a shunt is created.
What is the cause of D-transposition of great vessels?	D-transposition of great vessels is due to failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral.
What type of shunt is D-transposition of great vessels an example of?	D-transposition of great vessels is an example of a right-to-left shunt.
What is the source of D-dimers?	D-dimers are derived from splitting of cross-linked fibrin.
What is cytotoxic edema, and what is the cause of impaired function that leads to it?	Cytotoxic edema is an intracellular edema caused by impaired function of Na/K-ATPase pumps on neuronal cell membranes.
What is the structure of cytomegalovirus (CMV)?	The structure of cytomegalovirus (CMV) is icosahedral.
What is the characteristic feature of the outer surface of cytomegalovirus (CMV)?	The characteristic feature of the outer surface of cytomegalovirus (CMV) is that it is enveloped.
What is the shape of the genome of cytomegalovirus (CMV)?	The shape of the genome of cytomegalovirus (CMV) is linear.
Which family does cytomegalovirus (CMV) belong to?	Cytomegalovirus (CMV) belongs to the herpesviridae family.
What is the type of nucleic acid present in cytomegalovirus (CMV)?	Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a dsDNA virus.
What type of cytotoxic analog is cytarabine?	Cytarabine is a cytotoxic pyrimidine analog.
What is the potential adverse effect of cytarabine?	Cytarabine can result in myelo-suppression (-cytopenias).
What is the potential adverse effect of cytarabine with regards to the immune system?	Cytarabine can result in immunosuppression with increased risk for infection.
In what condition may cysts be present in both the pancreas and liver?	Cysts of the pancreas and liver may be present in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
What type of cells line the cysts in autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease?	Cysts of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease are lined by cuboidal epithelial cells.
For what suspected medical conditions is cystoscopy typically performed?	Cystoscopy is typically performed for suspected bladder cancer or UTI.
What are the common symptoms associated with cystitis?	Cystitis typically presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain.
How is cystitis characterized in terms of urine appearance and white blood cell count in urinalysis?	Cystitis is characterized by cloudy urine with > 10 WBCs/hpf (urinalysis).
What are the typical characteristics of urine in cystitis, and what test should be done to confirm the diagnosis?	Cystitis is characterized by cloudy urine and should be confirmed with urinalysis.
In cystitis, what does a positive nitrite test indicate in terms of the type of organisms causing the infection?	Cystitis is characterized by positive nitrites, which indicates gram negative organisms.
What is the significance of a positive leukocyte esterase test in cystitis and what does it indicate?	Cystitis is characterized by positive leukocyte esterase due to pyuria.
What are the typical characteristics of urine in cystitis caused by Proteus mirabilis, in terms of pH and scent?	Cystitis caused by Proteus mirabilis is characterized by alkaline urine (pH) with an ammonia scent.

What is the effect of urine pH on the precipitation of cystine kidney stones?	Cystine kidney stones precipitate with low urine pH.
What type of calculi may be formed by cystine kidney stones?	Cystine kidney stones may form staghorn calculi.
What are the components of cystine and how are they connected?	Cystine is made of two cysteine amino acids connected by a disulfide bond.
What is the most common cause of cystic fibrosis and what specific deletion is involved?	Cystic fibrosis most commonly occurs due to an in-frame deletion of Phe508.
What are some common clinical features that may be present in a patient with cystic fibrosis?	Cystic fibrosis may present with nasal polyps and nail clubbing.
What electrolyte imbalance may be present in a patient with cystic fibrosis?	Cystic fibrosis may present with hyponatremia.
What is a potential acid-base disturbance that may be present in a patient with cystic fibrosis?	Cystic fibrosis may present with contraction alkalosis.
What is a potential gastrointestinal complication that may be present in newborns with cystic fibrosis due to abnormally thick stool?	Cystic fibrosis may present as meconium ileus (10-20% of patients) in newborns due to abnormally thick ("inspissated") stool.
What is a potential cause of malabsorption in patients with cystic fibrosis?	Cystic fibrosis may cause pancreatic insufficiency, resulting in malabsorption.
What are potential liver complications that may be present in patients with cystic fibrosis?	Cystic fibrosis may cause biliary cirrhosis and/or liver disease.
How can cystic fibrosis be distinguished from Kartagener syndrome?	Cystic fibrosis can be differentiated from Kartagener syndrome by the presence of pancreatic insufficiency.
What is a disease that shares similar respiratory tract features with cystic fibrosis?	Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia, which also results in decreased mucociliary clearance.
What are the typical bacterial infections associated with cystic fibrosis in young children and adults?	Staphylococcus aureus is associated with cystic fibrosis in young children, while Pseudomonas is commonly seen in adults with the condition.
What is the potential consequence of cyst formation within end-stage kidneys during dialysis?	Cyst formation within end-stage kidneys during dialysis increases the risk for renal cell carcinoma.
How can cyclosporine cause arthropathy, and what is the mechanism behind this effect?	Cyclosporine can cause arthropathy by causing hyperuricemia, which is an increased level of uric acid in the blood.
What type of Renal Tubular Acidosis can be caused by cyclosporine?	Cyclosporine can cause Type 4 Renal Tubular Acidosis.
What medical conditions can be treated with cyclosporine?	Cyclosporine can be used to treat psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis.

What do Cyclospora, Isospora belli, and C. Parvum have in common?	Cyclospora, Isospora belli, and C. Parvum are all parasites.
What organ is responsible for bioactivating Cyclophosphamide in order for it to function?	Cyclophosphamide must be bioactivated by the liver in order to function.
What is the role of CYP450 in the liver in relation to Cyclophosphamide?	CYP450 in the liver activates Cyclophosphamide.
What type of cells is Cyclophosphamide selective for, in terms of Aldehyde Dehydrogenase expression?	Cyclophosphamide is selective for cells that express low/no levels of Aldehyde Dehydrogenase.
What is a potential side effect of Cyclophosphamide use in women?	Cyclophosphamide is known to cause premature menopause in women.
What is a potential side effect of Cyclophosphamide use in men?	Cyclophosphamide is known to cause infertility in men.
What is the mechanism of action of Cyclophosphamide that makes it useful for treating autoimmune conditions?	Cyclophosphamide has a potent immunosuppressive effect, which makes it useful for treating a variety of autoimmune conditions.
What are the potential effects of Cyclophosphamide on germ cells?	Cyclophosphamide can target germ cells, resulting in infertility and premature menopause.
What is the potential effect of Cyclophosphamide on ADH secretion?	Cyclophosphamide can stimulate ADH secretion, resulting in a euvolemic hyponatremia.
What is the potential effect of Cyclophosphamide on the development of SIADH and serum sodium levels?	Cyclophosphamide can result in SIADH, with resultant hypo-natremia.
What is the potential effect of Cyclophosphamide on the suppression of bone marrow activity and blood cell counts?	Cyclophosphamide can result in myelo-suppression with resultant cytopenias.

What is the normal state of Cyclin-Dependent Kinases and are they constitutive?	Cyclin-Dependent Kinases are normally inactive and are constitutive.
On which chromosome can Cyclin D1 be found?	Cyclin D1 can be found on chromosome 11.
What is ductal-dependent congenital heart defect and what are its symptoms?	Ductal-dependent congenital heart defect is a condition where cyanosis develops soon after birth and does not correct with oxygen.

What type of cutaneous healing results in scar formation?	Cutaneous healing by secondary intention results in scar formation.
What is cutaneous healing by secondary intention?	Cutaneous healing by secondary intention is when the wound edges are not approximated.
What type of cutaneous healing results in minimal scar formation?	Cutaneous healing by primary intention leads to minimal scar formation.
What is cutaneous healing by primary intention?	Cutaneous healing by primary intention is when the wound edges are brought together (e.g. suturing a surgical incision).
What are some cutaneous complications associated with the use of 5-fluorouracil?	Cutaneous complications of 5-fluorouracil use include photosensitivity and hyperpigmentation.

What is Cushing disease and what causes it?	Cushing disease is the result of chronic excess glucocorticoids caused by hypersecretion of ACTH from a pituitary adenoma.
What is Cushing syndrome and what does it refer to?	Cushing syndrome refers to a group of signs and symptoms that occur due to an increase in serum cortisol.
What electrolyte abnormality is more likely to be present in a patient with Cushing syndrome?	Patients with Cushing syndrome are more likely to present with hypokalemia.

What is the definition of Cushing disease and what type of pituitary adenoma is associated with it?	Cushing disease refers specifically to a condition caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

What is the nature of craniopharyngioma in terms of its cellular origin and composition?	Craniopharyngioma is a benign tumor of Rathke's pouch that is filled with cholesterol crystals and calcifications.

What are the DHEAS levels associated with a cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma?	A cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma is associated with low DHEAS levels.
What is the binding protein that cortisol attaches to when traveling in the blood?	Cortisol travels in the blood bound to corticosteroid-binding globulin (CBG).
What effects does cortisol have on REM sleep and awake time?	Cortisol results in decreased REM sleep and increased awake time.
What effect does cortisol have on glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?	Cortisol results in an increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
At what time of day are cortisol levels highest and lowest?	Cortisol levels are highest just before awakening and lowest in the evening.
What receptors on arterioles does cortisol up-regulate, and what effect does this have on their sensitivity to certain substances?	Cortisol (glucocorticoids) up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to catecholamines (i.e. norepinephrine and epinephrine).
From which nuclei of the hypothalamus are cells that secrete corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) found?	Cells that secrete corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) are found in the paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus.
What is the effect of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) on corticotrophs in the anterior pituitary?	Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) binds to corticotrophs on the anterior pituitary, directing them to synthesize POMC and secrete ACTH.
What is the enzyme responsible for converting corticosterone to aldosterone?	Corticosterone may be converted to aldosterone via the enzyme aldosterone synthase.
What role do corticosteroids play in fetal development and lung development?	Corticosteroids are important for fetal surfactant production and overall lung development.
From which part of the cortex do corticobulbar fibers arise?	Corticobulbar fibers arise in the primary motor cortex.
What is the recommended maximum rate for correcting serum sodium levels in cases of both hypo- and hyper-natremia?	Correction of serum sodium (both hypo- and hyper-natremia) should not exceed a rate of 0.5 mEq/L/hr.
What are the modes of transmission for Coronavirus?	Coronavirus is transmitted by airborne or droplet transmission.
What type of RNA virus is Coronavirus and is it enveloped or non-enveloped?	Coronavirus is a positive-sense RNA virus that is enveloped.
What are the possible presentations of Coronavirus infection?	Coronavirus has a wide range of presentations, from asymptomatic to cough and fever to pneumonia to ARDS.
What is the cause of coronary steal syndrome and what happens to the vessels distal to the coronary stenosis?	Coronary steal syndrome occurs because distal to coronary stenosis, vessels are maximally dilated at baseline.
How does coronary atherosclerosis affect the autoregulation mechanism and the ability of coronary vessels to dilate?	Coronary atherosclerosis interferes with the autoregulation mechanism and the ability of coronary vessels to maximally vasodilate.
Which coronary artery is most commonly affected by occlusion?	The left anterior descending artery is the coronary artery that is most commonly affected by occlusion.
What are the main metabolic abnormalities associated with Cori disease?	Cori disease is characterized by functional gluconeogenesis and impaired glycogenolysis.
What type of cellular accumulation is associated with Cori disease?	Cori disease is associated with the accumulation of limit dextrin-like structures in the cytosol.
What is the relationship between cord prolapse and fetal presentation?	Cord prolapse often occurs with abnormal fetal presentation.

What is cor pulmonale, and what are the pulmonary causes that can lead to it?	Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure due to pulmonary cause, such as pulmonary hypertension and COPD.

At what age is a child typically able to copy a line?	A child is typically able to copy a line at around 2 years old.
What is the type of polycythemia caused by COPD, cyanotic congenital heart disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and high altitude?	COPD, cyanotic congenital heart disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and high altitude cause physiologic secondary polycythemia.

What is a potential consequence of COPD?	COPD may cause respiratory acidosis.
What are the two conditions that coexist to form COPD?	COPD is the coexistence of chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
Is the obstruction caused by COPD reversible or irreversible?	The obstruction caused by COPD is irreversible.
How do you convert probability (P) to odds (O)?	To convert probability (P) to odds (O), you use the formula O = P / (1 - P).
What molecules are released when α-ketoglutarate is converted into succinyl CoA?	Conversion of α-ketoglutarate into succinyl CoA releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH.
What molecule is produced when succinyl CoA is converted into succinate?	Conversion of succinyl CoA into succinate produces a molecule of GTP.
What molecule is produced when succinate is converted into fumarate?	Conversion of succinate into fumarate produces a molecule of FADH2.
What molecules are released when pyruvate is converted into acetyl CoA?	Conversion of pyruvate into acetyl CoA releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH.
In the Cori cycle, what molecule is recycled when pyruvate is converted to lactate?	Conversion of pyruvate to lactate in the Cori cycle recycles one molecule of NAD+.
What molecule is produced when phosphoenolpyruvate is converted into pyruvate during glycolysis?	Conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate into pyruvate during glycolysis produces a molecule of ATP.
What molecule is required for the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate?	The conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate requires a molecule of GTP.
What molecule is produced when malate is converted to pyruvate via malic enzyme during fatty acid synthesis?	Conversion of malate to pyruvate via malic enzyme produces a molecule of NADPH during fatty acid synthesis.
What molecule is produced when malate is converted into oxaloacetate?	Conversion of malate into oxaloacetate produces a molecule of NADH.
What molecules are released when isocitrate is converted into α-ketoglutarate?	Conversion of isocitrate into α-ketoglutarate releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH.
What molecule is produced when glyceraldehyde-3P is converted into 1,3-BPG during glycolysis?	Conversion of glyceraldehyde-3P into 1,3-BPG (glycolysis) produces a molecule of NADH.
What molecule is produced when glucose-6-phosphate is converted into 6-phosphogluconate via G6PD?	Conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconate, via G6PD, produces a molecule of NADPH.
What molecules are produced when glucose-6-P is converted into ribulose-5-P via the HMP shunt?	Conversion of glucose-6-P into ribulose-5-P (HMP shunt) produces one molecule of CO2 and two molecules of NADPH.
What molecule is required for the conversion of galactose into galactose-1-phosphate?	Conversion of galactose into galactose-1-phosphate requires a molecule of ATP.
What molecule is required for the conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate?	Conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate requires a molecule of ATP.
What molecule does methylene THF need to be converted to in order for thymidylate synthase to convert dUMP to dTMP?	Conversion of dUMP to dTMP via thymidylate synthase requires conversion of methylene THF to DHF.
What cofactor is converted to DHF during the conversion of dUMP to dTMP via Thymidylate synthase?	Conversion of dUMP to dTMP via Thymidylate synthase converts the cofactor methylene THF to DHF.
What cofactor is required for the conversion of arginine to nitric oxide?	Conversion of arginine to nitric oxide requires BH4 (tetrahydrobiopterin) as a cofactor.
What molecule is produced during the conversion of 1,3-BPG into 3-phosphoglycerate in glycolysis?	Conversion of 1,3-BPG into 3-phosphoglycerate (glycolysis) produces a molecule of ATP.

What is contractility, and how is it defined?	Contractility, also known as inotropism, is the intrinsic ability of myocardial cells to develop force at a given muscle length.

What is the cause of hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis in Conn syndrome?	Hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis in Conn syndrome are caused by increased aldosterone levels.

In cases of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, what laboratory findings are suggestive of intrinsic liver disease?	Predominantly elevated AST/ALT levels are suggestive of intrinsic liver disease in cases of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
In cases of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, what laboratory findings are suggestive of intra- or extra-hepatic cholestasis?	Predominantly elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are suggestive of intra- or extra-hepatic cholestasis in cases of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

What is the cause of congenital umbilical hernia?	Congenital umbilical hernia is due to an incomplete closure of the umbilical ring.
What is congenital umbilical hernia and what causes it?	Congenital umbilical hernia is a condition where the umbilical ring fails to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

What is the underlying cause of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and what is the mechanism behind it?	Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is caused by decreased levels of cortisol, which leads to increased ACTH secretion via negative feedback.

How does the time constant affect conduction velocity?	Conduction velocity is increased when the time constant is decreased.
How does the space (length) constant affect conduction velocity?	Conduction velocity is increased when the space (length) constant is increased.

Is combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) the treatment for Mittelschmerz?	No, combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are not the treatment for Mittelschmerz.
What type of cancer does combined estrogen/progestin therapy for vasomotor postmenopausal symptoms increase the risk for?	Combined estrogen/progestin therapy for vasomotor postmenopausal symptoms increases the risk for breast cancer.
What are the different types of combined estrogen-progesterone contraceptive options available?	The different types of combined estrogen-progesterone contraceptive options available are daily pills, weekly patches, and monthly rings.
In which group of patients are combined contraceptives contraindicated?	Combined contraceptives are contraindicated in patients with an increased risk for cardiovascular disease.
What medical conditions would make a patient ineligible for using combined contraceptives?	Patients who have migraines, breast cancer, or endometrial cancer would be ineligible for using combined contraceptives.
What is the age limit for patients who smoke and are contraindicated to use combined contraceptives?	Patients who smoke and are over 35 years old are contraindicated to use combined contraceptives.
Is combined antiretroviral therapy recommended for HIV-positive mothers throughout their pregnancy?	Yes, combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is recommended throughout pregnancy for HIV-positive mothers.
What is the association between severe hypothermia and coma or cardiovascular collapse?	Severe hypothermia is associated with coma and cardiovascular collapse.
What is Coltivirus, and what is it also known as?	Coltivirus is a type of virus that is also known as Colorado tick virus.
How can colorectal carcinoma be visualized on a barium enema X-ray, and what does it look like?	Colorectal carcinoma can be visualized on a barium enema X-ray as an "apple core" lesion.
What is the ranking of colorectal carcinoma in terms of its frequency as a cause of cancer-related death?	Colorectal carcinoma is the third most common cause of cancer-related death.
Where is Brucella spp. found within the body and what type of bacteria is it?	Brucella spp. is a facultative intracellular zoonotic bacteria that is commonly found within macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system.
What type of motoneuron signs are typically seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome and where in the body do they present?	Brown-Sequard syndrome typically presents with ipsi-lateral lower motoneuron signs at the level of the lesion.
What is a potential cardiovascular complication associated with bronchopulmonary dysplasia?	Bronchopulmonary dysplasia can lead to hypertension.
What are some common characteristics of bronchopneumonia in terms of its distribution and presentation?	Bronchopneumonia is often multifocal and bilateral in distribution.
What are some common medications used in the treatment of bronchiolitis?	Bronchodilators, epinephrine, and corticosteroids are commonly used in the treatment of bronchiolitis.
What is the typical finding on bronchoalveolar lavage in a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii infection?	Bronchoalveolar lavage of Pneumocystis jirovecii infection will reveal disc-shaped yeast" or cysts containing dark oval bodies.
What is a common symptom associated with both bronchitis and bronchiolitis?	Bronchitis/Bronchiolitis is often associated with wheezing.
Where is bronchioloalveolar carcinoma of the lung typically located?	Bronchioloalveolar carcinoma of the lung is typically peripherally located.
What is a common respiratory sound associated with bronchiolitis, as opposed to stridor?	Bronchiolitis often presents with wheezing or crackles, rather than stridor.
Which lobes of the lung are primarily affected in bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis primarily affects the lower lobes of the lung.
What are some symptoms that may be present in a person with bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis may present with dyspnea and cough, along with hemoptysis.
What is a potential physical manifestation of bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis may cause digital clubbing.
What are the underlying causes of bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis is caused by chronic necrotizing inflammation or obstruction, which leads to the permanent dilation of airways.
What is the relationship between bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?	Bronchiectasis is associated with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus.
What are some common symptoms of bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis is associated with recurrent infections and foul-smelling, purulent sputum.
What factors are associated with poor ciliary motility in bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis is associated with poor ciliary motility, which can be caused by factors such as smoking or Kartagener syndrome.
What are some potential causes of bronchial obstruction in bronchiectasis?	Bronchiectasis is associated with bronchial obstruction, which can be caused by factors such as a tumor or foreign body.
What are the histological characteristics of bronchial carcinoid tumor?	Bronchial carcinoid tumor is characterized histologically by nests of well differentiated neuroendocrine cells.
What is the nature of bronchial hamartomas?	Bronchial hamartomas are benign.
Where can bronchial carcinoid tumor be located?	Bronchial carcinoid tumor can be peripherally or centrally located.
What is the characteristic staining pattern for bronchial carcinoid tumor?	Bronchial carcinoid tumor is characterized by positive staining for chromogranin A.
Where does bronchial carcinoid tumor typically form a polyp-like mass?	Bronchial carcinoid tumor typically forms a polyp-like mass in the bronchus.
What is the characteristic histological appearance of bronchial carcinoid tumor?	Bronchial carcinoid tumor can appear histologically as sheets of uniform cells with a "salt and pepper" pattern.
How is comprehension affected in individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia?	Comprehension is intact in individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia.
How is repetition affected in individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia?	Repetition is impaired in individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia.
How would you describe the speech of individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia?	The speech of individuals with Broca's (expressive) aphasia is nonfluent.
What type of adrenergic agonist is Brimonidine and what condition is it commonly used to treat?	Brimonidine is an α2 adrenergic agonist used to treat chronic open angle glaucoma.
What is the usual cause or trigger of brief psychotic disorder?	Brief psychotic disorder is usually stress-related.
What are Brenner tumors and how do their nuclei appear on H&E stain?	Brenner tumors are solid, encapsulated tumors with a yellow-tan appearance; their nuclei appear as "coffee bean" on H&E stain.
What is the typical mode of delivery for a baby in breech position?	A baby in breech position is typically delivered via C-section.
What are breathing-related disorders and which specific sleep disorders fall under this category?	Breathing-related disorders are the most common of the hypersomnias and include obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea.

What is the embryological origin of breast tissue and what is it a modified form of?	Breast tissue is a modified form of a sweat gland that is embryologically derived from skin.

How can breast milk jaundice be distinguished from breastfeeding failure jaundice?	Breast milk jaundice can be distinguished from breastfeeding failure jaundice by the absence of signs of dehydration.

What is the recommended procedure for BRCA-positive individuals to decrease their risk of ovarian cancer?	The recommended procedure for BRCA-positive individuals to decrease their risk of ovarian cancer is a prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

How does ventilation and perfusion differ between the base and apex of the lung?	Both ventilation and perfusion are greater at the base of the lung than at the apex of the lung.

Which group of patients are at the highest risk for the dangers associated with Babesia?	As per the information provided, Babesia is most dangerous for asplenic patients.
How are B-cells with self-reactivity in the bone marrow typically dealt with?	B-cells with self-reactivity in the bone marrow are typically destroyed by clonal deletion.

What is the source of Aβ amyloid, and where is the protein that gives rise to it encoded?	As per the information provided, Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein, which is encoded on chromosome 21.
What is the specific type of bacteria that Aztreonam is used to treat?	As per the information provided, Aztreonam is used only for Gram negative Rods.
