What are the two substances in the blood that are typically elevated in a condition known as Azotemia?	As per the information provided, Azotemia typically refers to an increase in serum BUN and creatinine.
What effect do Azoles have on cytochrome p450?	As per the information provided, Azoles inhibit cytochrome p450.
What is the mechanism of action of Azoles in the Fungi?	As per the information provided, Azoles work by inhibiting cytochrome P450 enzymes in the Fungi.
What specific conversion process do Azoles inhibit in the Fungi?	As per the information provided, Azoles inhibit the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol.
What is the potential impact of Azoles on the synthesis of steroids in humans?	As per the information provided, Azoles can inhibit cytochrome p450 enzymes involved in synthesis of steroids in humans.
What is a potential side effect of Azoles?	As per the information provided, Azoles can cause GI distress.
What are some potential side effects of Azoles?	As per the information provided, Azoles can cause side effects of dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and hepatotoxicity.
What is a potential anti-androgenic side effect of Azoles?	As per the information provided, Azoles can cause anti-androgenic side effects, most commonly resulting in gynecomastia.
What is a potential side effect of Azoles, which are a class of antifungals?	As per the information provided, Azoles are a class of antifungals that can cause hepato-toxicity.
What is a possible use of Azithromycin as an antiprotozoal medication?	As per the information provided, Azithromycin can be used as an antiprotozoal in the treatment of Babesiosis.
What are the potential adverse effects associated with the use of Azathioprine/6-MP?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine/6-MP is associated with pancreatitis and hepato-toxicity.
What is a potential adverse effect associated with the use of Azathioprine/6-MP?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine/6-MP can result in myelo-suppression (-cytopenias).
What is a medical condition that can be treated with Azathioprine/6-MP?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine/6-MP can be used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.
What is the mechanism of action of Azathioprine as an immunosuppressant, and what enzyme does it inhibit?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant antimetabolite precursor of 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits the enzyme PRPP amidotransferase.
What is a potential side effect of Azathioprine, and what symptoms may indicate this side effect?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine can cause pancreatitis resulting in elevated amylase and lipase levels.
What is the effect of Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine on cellular levels of PRPP?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine increase cellular levels of PRPP.
What enzyme is responsible for the metabolism of Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine are metabolized by xanthine oxidase.
What is a potential side effect of Azathioprine and 6MP, and why is it important to monitor liver function tests?	As per the information provided, Azathioprine and 6MP can cause Hepatitis, thus it is important to monitor liver function tests.
Which type of cells myelinate axons that have the potential to regenerate following injury?	As per the information provided, axons that are myelinated by Schwann cells have the potential to regenerate following injury.
What is the name of the type of cells whose axons leave the eye via the optic nerve?	As per the information provided, the axons of the retinal ganglion cells leave the eye via the optic nerve.
In which condition should nodal blockers such as adenosine be avoided?	As per the information provided, nodal blockers such as adenosine should be avoided in WPW (Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome).
What are the effects of AV shunts on preload and afterload?	As per the information provided, AV shunts increase preload and decrease afterload.
What are the effects of AV fistula on preload, afterload, and cardiac output?	As per the information provided, AV fistula increases preload, decreases afterload, and increases cardiac output.
What are the characteristics of autosomal dominant diseases in terms of pleiotropy and expressivity?	As per the information provided, autosomal dominant diseases are often pleiotropic and variably expressive.
What is the characteristic feature of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease in terms of renal anatomy?	As per the information provided, autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is characterized by cystic dilation of the renal collecting ducts.
What are the clinical features of autosomal recessive PKD in infants?	As per the information provided, autosomal recessive PKD presents in infants as worsening renal failure and hypertension.
What is the common cause of autosomal recessive diseases?	As per the information provided, autosomal recessive diseases are often due to enzyme deficiencies.
What is the renal characteristic associated with Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease?	As per the information provided, Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease is associated with an inability to concentrate urine.
What are the renal regions where cysts are commonly observed in Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is characterized by cysts in the renal cortex and medulla.
What is a possible clinical presentation of Autosomal dominant PKD in young adults, and what is the underlying cause?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults with hypertension due to increased renin.
What are some of the possible symptoms that may be present in young adults with Autosomal dominant PKD?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults with flank pain and urinary infection.
What are some of the possible clinical presentations of Autosomal dominant PKD in young adults?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults as worsening renal failure and hematuria.
What is a potential complication associated with Autosomal dominant PKD that can be a significant cause of mortality?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant PKD is associated with berry aneurysm, which is an important cause of death.
What type of genes are commonly affected in Autosomal dominant diseases?	As per the information provided, Autosomal dominant diseases are often due to defects in structural genes.
What medical condition is suggested by the autoimmune destruction of presynaptic Ca2+ channels?	As per the information provided, the autoimmune destruction of presynaptic Ca2+ channels is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
What is the method used by autoclaves to sterilize equipment?	As per the information provided, autoclaves work to sterilize equipment by using pressurized steam.
At what stage of life must Autism Spectrum Disorder be present according to the information provided?	As per the information provided, Autism Spectrum Disorder must present in early childhood.
What is the condition that is more commonly accompanied by intellectual disability as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Autism Spectrum Disorder is more commonly accompanied by intellectual disability.
Which gender is more commonly affected by Autism Spectrum Disorder as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Autism Spectrum Disorder is more common in boys.
What is the association between Autism Spectrum Disorder and head/brain size as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Autism Spectrum Disorder is associated with increased head/brain size.
Which groups of people are more likely to experience atypical symptoms associated with MI as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atypical symptoms associated with MI are more common in women, the elderly, and diabetics.
What eating disorder is associated with atypical depression as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atypical depression is associated with hyperphagia, an eating disorder characterized by excessive hunger and overeating.
Which atypical antipsychotic is known for its sedative and orthostatic effects?	Quetiapine is known for its sedative and orthostatic effects among atypical antipsychotics.
What is the association between Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and intelligence, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is associated with normal intelligence that coexists with difficulties in school.
At what age does Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) typically have its onset, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) has an onset before age 12.
What percentage of cases does Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) continue into adulthood, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) continues into adulthood in 50% of cases.
What symptom of cystitis may Atropine be used to decrease, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Atropine may be used to decrease urinary urgency in cystitis.
What is the potential risk associated with Atropine use in relation to acute-angle closure glaucoma, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Atropine can cause acute-angle closure glaucoma.
What is the potential mechanism behind atrophy via decrease in cell size, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via ubiquitin-proteasome degradation of cytoskeleton.
What is one potential mechanism behind atrophy via decrease in cell size, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via autophagy of cellular components.
What is the potential mechanism behind atrophy via decrease in cell number, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrophy via decrease in cell number occurs via apoptosis.
What are the clinical manifestations of iron deficiency anemia, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, the clinical manifestations of iron deficiency anemia include atrophic glossitis and angular cheilitis.
What is the typical appearance of atrial flutter on an ECG, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial flutter typically has a 4:1 "sawtooth" pattern appearance on ECG.
What type of shunt is associated with atrial septal defect (ASD), as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial septal defect (ASD) results in a left-to-right shunt.
What effect does atrial natriuretic peptide have on arterioles, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial natriuretic peptide generally causes dilation of arterioles.
What medical condition is atrial flutter typically treated similarly to, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial flutter is typically treated similarly to atrial fibrillation.
What is the most common cause of atrial flutter, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial flutter is most commonly caused by a re-entrant circuit around the tricuspid annulus.
What is the recommended treatment for atrial fibrillation, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial fibrillation should be treated with anticoagulation first, followed by cardioversion.
How is the rhythm of atrial fibrillation characterized, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, the rhythm of atrial fibrillation is characterized by an irregularly, irregular patterned rhythm.
What type of thromboembolic event can atrial fibrillation lead to, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atrial fibrillation can lead to thromboembolic events, particularly stroke (brain complication).
What type of neuromuscular blocking agents are atracurium and mivacurium, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atracurium and mivacurium are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.
What effect do ATP synthase inhibitors have on the proton gradient and ATP synthesis, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, ATP synthase inhibitors cause an increased proton gradient and a block of ATP synthesis.
What exacerbates ATP depletion in cases of vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, glucose infusion exacerbates ATP depletion in cases of vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency.
On which part of the body does atopic (eczematous) dermatitis typically appear in infancy, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atopic (eczematous) dermatitis typically appears on the face in infancy.
With what is increased serum I associated in atopic (eczematous) dermatitis, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, increased serum IgE is associated with atopic (eczematous) dermatitis.
What are the causes of ATN, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, the causes of ATN include prolonged ischemia, toxins (drugs, myoglobin, Ig), and contrast-induced injury.
In which conditions may atlantoaxial instability be seen, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atlantoaxial instability may be seen in patients with Down syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis.
What should athletes with polycythemia be tested for, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, athletes with polycythemia should be tested for exogenous erythropoietin injection.
What do atherosclerotic plaques contain due to upregulation of growth factors, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atherosclerotic plaques contain proliferations of thin-walled blood vessels due to upregulation of growth factors.
What type of strokes may be caused by atherosclerosis, inflammation, vasospasm, and sickle cell disease, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atherosclerosis, inflammation, vasospasm, and sickle cell disease may cause large vessel ischemic strokes.
What can be the result of atherosclerosis causing weakening of the blood vessel wall, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, the result of atherosclerosis causing weakening of the blood vessel wall can be an aneurysm.
What causes atherosclerosis and obstructs blood flow, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atherosclerosis is caused by a buildup of intimal plaques that obstruct blood flow.
What are atezolizumab, durvalumab, and avelumab, and what do they bind to on tumor cells, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atezolizumab, durvalumab, and avelumab are checkpoint inhibitors that bind to PD-L1 on tumor cells.
What are atenolol, timolol, and carvedilol, and what class of antiarrhythmics do they belong to, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atenolol, timolol, and carvedilol are examples of class II antiarrhythmics.
What is the usual method of managing/preventing atelectasis, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atelectasis is usually managed/prevented with incentive spirometry.
What are the common causes of atelectasis post-operatively, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atelectasis commonly occurs post-operatively due to shallow breathing and weak cough secondary to pain.
What is the typical percussion finding in atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction), as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction) presents with dullness to percussion.
What is the usual finding of fremitus in atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction), as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction) presents with decreased fremitus.
What is the typical finding of breath sounds in atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction), as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, atelectasis (bronchial/bronchiole obstruction) presents with decreased breath sounds.
What are the three components of the triad that Ataxia-TelangiectasiA presents with, as per the information provided?	As per the information provided, Ataxia-TelangiectasiA presents with a triad of cerebellar defects (Ataxia), spider angiomas (Telangiectasia), and IgA deficiency.
According to the information provided, what are the two conditions that Ataxia-telangiectasia is associated with an increased risk of?	As per the information provided, Ataxia-telangiectasia is associated with an increased risk of lymphoma and leukemia.
According to the information provided, what effect does vitamin D have on bone mineralization at low levels?	As per the information provided, at low levels, vitamin D increases bone mineralization.
According to the information provided, what is the relationship between flow rates and Cl- concentration in pancreatic secretions?	As per the information provided, at low flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high Cl- concentration.
According to the information provided, what is the relationship between epinephrine and β adrenergic receptors at low doses?	As per the information provided, at low doses, epinephrine primarily activates β adrenergic receptors.
According to the information provided, what effect does vitamin D have on bone resorption at high levels?	As per the information provided, at high levels, vitamin D increases bone resorption.
According to the information provided, what is the relationship between flow rates and HCO3- concentration in pancreatic secretions?	As per the information provided, at high flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high HCO3- concentration.
According to the information provided, what effect does epinephrine have on α adrenergic receptors at high doses?	As per the information provided, at high doses, epinephrine primarily activates α adrenergic receptors.
According to the information provided, what effect does dopamine have on β1 receptors at medium doses?	As per the information provided, at medium doses, dopamine stimulates β1 receptors.
According to the information provided, what effect does dopamine have on renal arterioles and interlobular arteries at low levels?	As per the information provided, at low levels, dopamine causes vasodilation of renal arterioles and interlobular arteries.
According to the information provided, what effect does PTH have on osteoblasts and osteoclasts at low, intermittent levels?	As per the information provided, at low, intermittent levels, PTH exerts anabolic effects on osteoblasts and osteoclasts.
According to the information provided, what effect does dopamine have on α1 receptors at high doses?	As per the information provided, at high doses, dopamine stimulates α1 receptors.
According to the information provided, what is the effect of alkaline urine pH on the excretion of weak bases?	As per the information provided, at alkaline urine pH, the B form of a weak base exists, thus decreasing excretion.
According to the information provided, what is the effect of alkaline urine pH on the excretion of weak acids?	As per the information provided, at alkaline urine pH, the A- form of a weak acid exists, thus increasing excretion.
According to the information provided, what is the effect of acidic urine pH on the excretion of weak acids?	As per the information provided, at acidic urine pH, the HA form of a weak acid exists, thus decreasing excretion.
According to the information provided, what is the effect of acidic urine pH on the excretion of weak bases?	As per the information provided, at acidic urine pH, the BH+ form of a weak base exists, thus increasing excretion.
Where in the nephron do SGLT2 inhibitors block the reabsorption of glucose?	SGLT2 inhibitors block the reabsorption of glucose in the proximal tubule of the nephron.
What is the typical age at which a baby is expected to be able to walk on its own?	The typical age at which a baby is expected to be able to walk on its own is 12 months.
What is the age range for which annual influenza vaccination is recommended?	Annual influenza vaccination is recommended for individuals older than 6 months of age.
What is the minimum β-hCG level required for a transvaginal ultrasound to detect a fetus?	A transvaginal ultrasound can detect a fetus at a β-hCG level greater than 1500 IU/L.

At how many weeks of gestation should pregnant women be screened or cultured for Group B Streptococcus (GBS)?	Pregnant women should be screened or cultured for GBS at 35 weeks of gestation.

During translation initiation, which site of the ribosome does the tRNA molecule bind to?	The tRNA molecule binds to the P site of the ribosome during translation initiation.
During translation elongation, which site of the ribosome does the tRNA molecule bind to?	The tRNA molecule binds to the A site of the ribosome during translation elongation.

When should a child be able to sit momentarily?	A child should be able to sit momentarily at around 6 months old.

At what age can patients begin to be screened for HIV?	Patients can begin to be screened for HIV at around 15 years old.
What type of ion channels are present in high concentration at the nodes of Ranvier?	At the nodes of Ranvier, there is a high concentration of Na+ channels.
What is the name of the smooth muscle band located at the junction of arterioles and capillaries?	At the junction of the arterioles and capillaries is a smooth muscle band called the pre-capillary sphincter.

What is the result of stimulating β3 receptors at the bladder?	Stimulation of β3 receptors at the bladder results in bladder relaxation.
What is the structure that glomerular filtrate passes at the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule?	At the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate passes the macula densa.
What is the most likely cause of new-onset oligohydramnios at term?	The most likely cause of new-onset oligohydramnios at term is spontaneous rupture of membranes.
What happens to the GnRH receptor in the anterior pituitary during puberty?	During puberty, GnRH up-regulates its own receptor in the anterior pituitary, thus increasing sensitivity.
What changes occur in cervical mucus during ovulation?	During ovulation, cervical mucus increases in quantity and becomes more watery and penetrable by sperm.
What is the primary organ responsible for excreting uric acid at normal levels?	The kidneys are the primary organ responsible for excreting uric acid at normal levels.
What is the purpose of TMP-SMX prophylaxis in AIDS patients with a CD4 count of less than 100?	In AIDS patients with a CD4 count of less than 100, TMP-SMX prophylaxis is indicated to prevent Toxoplasmosis.
How does dopamine act on renal arterioles at higher doses and what effect does it have?	At higher doses, dopamine acts as a vasoconstrictor of renal arterioles, causing a decrease in renal blood flow.
What happens to cortisol at high concentrations and which receptors can it bind to?	At high concentrations, cortisol can bind to mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) receptors.
When do the testes begin to develop in genetic males during gestation and at what gestational weeks does this occur?	The testes begin to develop in genetic males during gestation at gestational weeks 6 to 7.
What is the pressure of the intrapleural space relative to the atmosphere at FRC and how is this pressure described?	At FRC, the intrapleural space normally has a negative pressure relative to the atmosphere.
What are the airway and alveolar pressures at FRC and to what pressure are they equal to at this point?	At FRC, the airway and alveolar pressures are equal to atmospheric pressure, which is 0.
What are the typical findings on bronchoscopy 18 hours after inhalation injury and how severe are these findings?	Typically, 18 hours after inhalation injury, bronchoscopy will show severe edema, congestion of bronchi, and deposition of soot.
What is the management approach for an asymptomatic sliding hiatal hernia?	An asymptomatic sliding hiatal hernia is typically managed with observation.
What is the difference in management between asymptomatic and symptomatic SIADH?	Asymptomatic SIADH is typically managed with fluid restriction, while symptomatic SIADH may require treatment with 3% saline.
What is the difference in management between asymptomatic and symptomatic PVCs?	Asymptomatic PVCs typically do not require treatment, while symptomatic PVCs may be managed with β-blockers or calcium channel blockers.
At what point in a pregnancy should asymptomatic pregnant women be tested for gestational diabetes mellitus?	Asymptomatic pregnant women should be tested for gestational diabetes mellitus at 24 weeks of gestation.
What condition is suggested by the presence of asymptomatic monoclonal plasma cell expansion of 10% or less?	Asymptomatic monoclonal plasma cell expansion of 10% or less is suggestive of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS).
What condition is suggested by an asymmetric red reflex?	An asymmetric red reflex is suggestive of strabismus.
What type of lenses are used to correct astigmatism?	Astigmatism is corrected with cylindrical lenses.
What is the management for an asthmatic patient with postpartum hemorrhage, failed uterine massage, and high-dose oxytocin?	The management for an asthmatic patient with postpartum hemorrhage, failed uterine massage, and high-dose oxytocin is tranexamic acid.
What are the processes that mediate asthmatic bronchoconstriction and what type of tone is involved?	Asthmatic bronchoconstriction is mediated by inflammatory processes and parasympathetic tone.
What condition is suggested by the presence of asthma, eosinophils, and p-ANCA?	The presence of asthma, eosinophils, and p-ANCA is suggestive of Churg-Strauss Syndrome.
What does it indicate when wheezing disappears in a patient with asthma?	When wheezing disappears in a patient with asthma, it is considered a bad sign.
What condition is suggested by asthma symptoms that do not respond to typical asthma therapy?	Asthma symptoms that fail to respond to typical asthma therapy are suggestive of vocal cord dysfunction.
In asthma pathogenesis, what is the role of TH2 cells and what do they secrete that attracts certain cells?	TH2 cells play a role in asthma pathogenesis by secreting IL 5, which attracts eosinophils.
What is the role of IL 10 in asthma pathogenesis and what cells does it stimulate and inhibit?	In asthma pathogenesis, IL 10 secreted by TH2 cells stimulates TH2 cells and inhibits TH1 cells.
At what age does asthma most commonly present?	Asthma most commonly presents in childhood.
What is a possible symptom of asthma presentation?	Tachypnea is a possible symptom of asthma presentation.
What radiological finding may be present in a patient with asthma?	Peribronchial cuffing may be present on CXR in a patient with asthma.
What change in the inspiratory/expiratory ratio may be present in a patient with asthma?	A decreased inspiratory/expiratory ratio may be present in a patient with asthma.
What acid-base disturbance may be caused by asthma?	Asthma may cause respiratory alkalosis.
What can excessive production of mucus caused by asthma result in?	Excessive production of mucus caused by asthma may result in mucus plugging.
What conditions or factors are often associated with asthma?	Asthma is often associated with allergic rhinitis, eczema, and a family history of atopy.
What is asthma associated with in terms of bronchial smooth muscle?	Asthma is associated with bronchial smooth muscle hypertrophy.
What are the classic symptoms of asthma and what lung sound is commonly associated with it?	The classic symptoms of asthma are episodic cough, dyspnea, and wheezing (lung sound).
What conditions or diseases are associated with asterixis?	Asterixis is associated with hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson disease, and other metabolic derangements.
What does it suggest when AST is greater than ALT in nonalcoholic liver disease?	When AST is greater than ALT in nonalcoholic liver disease, it suggests progression to advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis.
What are the common bacterial infections that asplenic sickle cell disease patients are vulnerable to?	Asplenic sickle cell disease patients are commonly infected with Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae.
What is the reason for the increased risk of sepsis in asplenic patients?	Asplenia can result in an increased risk of sepsis from encapsulated bacteria due to loss of splenic phagocytes.
What medications should be stopped before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding?	Aspirin, NSAIDs, and Vitamin E should be stopped 2 weeks before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding.
Which substance can be seen on an x-ray, and which one cannot?	Iron can be seen on an x-ray, while aspirin cannot be seen on an x-ray.
What is the treatment for aspirin toxicity?	Aspirin toxicity may be treated with alkalinization of serum/urine.
How does aspirin therapy affect the frequency of unstable angina episodes?	Aspirin therapy reduces the frequency of unstable angina episodes.
How long before surgery should aspirin be stopped?	Aspirin should be stopped 1 week before surgery.
How can aspirin cause a "pseudo-allergy"?	Aspirin may cause a "pseudo-allergy" due to excess leukotriene synthesis.
How does aspirin affect platelet function?	Aspirin irreversibly inactivates the enzyme cyclooxygenase, thus decreasing synthesis of TXA2 and impairing platelet aggregation.
How does aspirin inhibit cyclooxygenase?	Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase via irreversible covalent acetylation.
What effect does aspirin have on uric acid secretion in the renal tubules at low doses?	Aspirin at low doses inhibits uric acid secretion in the renal tubules.
What effect does aspirin have on uric acid reabsorption in the renal tubules at high doses?	Aspirin at high doses decreases uric acid reabsorption in the renal tubules.
Which hormones can aspirin and ibuprofen displace from binding proteins and in which patients should these drugs be avoided?	Aspirin and ibuprofen can displace thyroid hormones from binding proteins and should be avoided in patients with hyperthyroidism.
What are examples of anti-platelet agents and anti-coagulants?	Aspirin and clopidogrel are examples of anti-platelet agents, while Heparin, Warfarin, and Direct Thrombin/Xa inhibitors are examples of anti-coagulants.
In which patient populations is aspiration pneumonia commonly seen?	Aspiration pneumonia is commonly seen in alcoholics and anesthetized patients.
What is the morphology of Aspergillus fumigatus and in what form does it occur?	Aspergillus fumigatus is not dimorphic and occurs only as molds.
With which lung pathologies are Aspergillomas associated and why?	Aspergillomas are associated with Tuberculosis or Klebsiella, as both pathologies have pre-existing cavities within the lungs.
What is the significance of ASO (anti-streptolysin O) antibodies and what condition are they associated with?	ASO (anti-streptolysin O) antibodies are associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
Can you ask the patient about their use of tobacco, alcohol, and history of depression?	Yes.
What are the most common types of cancers, excluding skin cancer?	Aside from skin cancer, the highest incidence cancers are breast/prostate cancer, lung cancer, and colorectal cancer.
What are the possible clinical presentations of mammary duct ectasia, besides discharge?	Aside from discharge, mammary duct ectasia may present with breast pain due to inflammation.
Besides cruises, what other settings are Norovirus infections commonly associated with?	Aside from cruises, Norovirus infection is associated with daycare centers and schools.
What is one of the common causes of Asherman syndrome?	Asherman syndrome is often the result of overaggressive dilation and curettage (D&C).
What are the hormonal characteristics of a person with Asherman syndrome?	Asherman syndrome is characterized by normal FSH and normal estrogen levels.
What is the effect of progesterone challenge in individuals with Asherman syndrome?	Asherman syndrome causes no response to progesterone challenge.
What are some of the causes of Asherman syndrome (intrauterine synechiae)?	Asherman syndrome (intrauterine synechiae) is often the result of intrauterine surgery (e.g. myomectomy or overaggressive dilation and curettage (D&C)).
What is the result of a cardiac echo bubble study in individuals with ASD?	ASD has a positive (+) bubble study on cardiac echo.
In patients with ASCUS and positive HPV, what is the recommended next step?	The recommended next step is colposcopy.
How is portal hypertension diagnosed in patients with ascites?	Portal hypertension is diagnosed in patients with ascites by a serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) greater than 1.1.
What are the classic manifestations of Sporothrix schenckii infection/sporotrichosis?	The classic manifestations of Sporothrix schenckii infection/sporotrichosis are ascending lymphangitis and cigar-shaped yeast.
What is the most common cause of ascending cholangitis?	Ascending cholangitis is usually caused by ascending infection with enteric gram negative bacteria.
What are the most common causes of ascending aortic aneurysms?	The most common causes of ascending aortic aneurysms are cystic medial necrosis (due to aging) and connective tissue disorders.
What is the treatment for Ascaris lumbricoides infection?	Ascaris lumbricoides infection is treated with albendazole.
What is the cause of asbestosis?	Asbestosis is caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers.
Which part of the lung is most commonly affected by asbestosis?	Asbestosis most commonly affects the lower lobes of the lung.
What are Asbestos bodies and what is their appearance?	Asbestos bodies are golden-brown fusiform rods resembling dumbbells that may be present in asbestosis lesions.
Which occupations are commonly associated with asbestosis?	Asbestosis is commonly seen in construction workers, shipyard workers, and plumbers.
What types of cancers are associated with asbestosis?	Asbestosis is associated with increased risk for lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.
Which part of the lung is commonly affected in asbestosis?	Asbestosis commonly affects the lower lobes of the lung.
What is the method used to obtain an alveolar septum sputum sample to detect asbestos bodies?	An alveolar septum sputum sample to detect asbestos bodies is often obtained by bronchoalveolar lavage.
What substance do asbestos bodies contain, and what type of stain is used to visualize them?	Asbestos bodies contain iron, and they may be visualized using a Prussian blue stain.
How does asbestos act as a carcinogen?	Asbestos acts as a carcinogen by physically destroying cellular chromosomes.
What happens to VLDLs as triglycerides are removed from them?	As triglycerides are removed from VLDLs, they shrink and form IDL.
What happens to a chylomicron as triglycerides are removed from it?	As triglycerides are removed from a chylomicron, it shrinks and forms a chylomicron remnant.
How does the standard error change as the sample size increases?	The standard error decreases as the sample size increases.
What is the phenomenon known as when the orad stomach also relaxes as the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes?	When the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes, the orad stomach also relaxes, and this phenomenon is known as receptive relaxation.
What direction does air flow as the alveolar pressure becomes positive relative to the atmosphere during mid-expiration?	As the alveolar pressure becomes positive relative to the atmosphere during mid-expiration, air flows outwards.
What direction does air flow as the alveolar pressure becomes negative relative to the atmosphere during mid-inspiration?	As the alveolar pressure becomes negative relative to the atmosphere during mid-inspiration, air flows inwards.
What happens to lecithin and sphingomyelin levels as surfactant production is increased during fetal lung maturation?	As surfactant production is increased during fetal lung maturation, lecithin levels increase while sphingomyelin levels remain constant.
What happens to the excretion of H+ as NH4+ as the pH of the tubular fluid decreases?	As the pH of the tubular fluid decreases, the excretion of H+ as NH4+ increases.
What can be given as part of the reversal of digoxin toxicity to chelate Digoxin?	As part of the reversal of digoxin toxicity, anti-digoxin Fab fragments can be given to chelate Digoxin.
What happens to the therapeutic window for levodopa and the predictability of response as Parkinson's disease progresses?	As Parkinson's disease progresses, the therapeutic window for levodopa narrows and response becomes more unpredictable.
How does the development of Guillain-Barré syndrome differ from that of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis?	As opposed to acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, Guillain-Barré syndrome develops over the course of days to weeks once symptoms begin.
What is the effect of methotrexate on a patient's scalp, and why does it occur?	As methotrexate affects all rapidly dividing cells, it can affect a patient's scalp and cause alopecia.
What is the effect of lactation on ovulation, and why does it occur?	As long as lactation continues, ovulation is suppressed, due to inhibitory effects of prolactin on GnRH, FSH, and LH.
What deficits can patients develop as limb compartment syndrome progresses?	As limb compartment syndrome progresses, patients can develop motor deficits.
What types of cancers of lymphocytes is Methotrexate primarily indicated for as an antineoplastic?	As an antineoplastic, Methotrexate is primarily indicated for cancers of lymphocytes, particularly leukemias and lymphomas.
What conditions can Denosumab be used for as an antineoplastic, in addition to metastases to bone?	As an antineoplastic, Denosumab can be used for Giant Cell Tumor of Bone as well as metastases to bone.
What is the increased risk that patients with dissociative amnesia face as their amnesia resolves and overwhelming memories return?	As amnesia resolves and the overwhelming memories return, patients with dissociative amnesia are at an increased risk for suicide.
What type of carcinoma can be treated with 5FU as a topical cream?	As a topical cream, 5FU can be used to treat basal cell carcinoma.
How does pregabalin affect neurotransmission and which membrane of neurons is involved in this process?	As a result of inhibition of VDCCs located on the presynaptic membrane of neurons, pregabalin results in decreased neurotransmission.
What is the effect of Thymidylate Synthase inhibition on the levels of dUMP?	As a result of inhibition of Thymidylate Synthase, there are increased levels of dUMP.
What type of kidney stones are patients with primary hyperparathyroidism at an increased risk for as a result of hypercalcemia?	As a result of hypercalcemia, patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are at increased risk for calcium oxalate kidney stones.
What is the potential effect of bisphosphonates on calcium levels and osteoclast activity?	As a result of decreased osteoclast activity, bisphosphonates may cause hypocalcemia.
What is the association between Cyclophosphamide metabolites and transitional cell carcinoma, and where do these metabolites accumulate?	As a result of Cyclophosphamide metabolites accumulating in the bladder, it is associated with transitional cell carcinoma.
What is the potential effect of 5FU on the gut mucosa and why does it occur?	As a result of 5FU targeting rapidly dividing cells, it can affect the gut mucosa resulting in diarrhea.
What is the regulatory mechanism for arteriolar resistance and which nervous system is responsible for it?	Arteriolar resistance is regulated by the sympathetic nervous system.
What is the pressure status of arteries?	Arteries are under high pressure.
What is the medical condition associated with arterial or venous thrombosis?	Arterial or venous thrombosis is associated with HIT.

What type of liver condition is associated with arsenic exposure?	Arsenic is associated with angiosarcoma of the liver.

Name two atypical antipsychotics that are least likely to cause hyperprolactinemia.	Aripiprazole and quetiapine are atypical antipsychotics that are least likely to cause hyperprolactinemia.

What are the products of the breakdown of arginine by the enzyme arginase?	The breakdown of arginine by the enzyme arginase produces ornithine and urea.
How many circular segments do Arenaviruses have?	Arenaviruses have 2 circular segments.
What is the classification of Arenaviruses?	Arenaviruses are classified as negative sense RNA viruses.
What type of capsid does Arenavirus have?	Arenavirus has a helical capsid.

Do diabetic patients have a contraindication for β-blockers?	No, diabetic patients do not have a contraindication for β-blockers.

What are the typical auscultatory findings in a patient with ARDS?	Patients with ARDS typically present with bilateral diffuse crackles on auscultation.
How does ARDS affect the alveolar-capillary interface and what is the consequence of this damage?	ARDS causes damage to the alveolar-capillary interface, which results in increased capillary permeability.
What is the relationship between ARDS and PCWP?	ARDS is characterized by a normal or low pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), indicated by the symbol ↔.
What is the next branch of arteries after the arcuate arteries in the kidney?	The arcuate arteries of the kidney further branch into interlobular arteries.
In what situation are ARBs contraindicated, and why?	ARBs are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the possible teratogenic effects they may have.
