Which arboviruses are classified as togaviruses, and can you name them?	Arboviruses that are also togaviruses include eastern, western, and Venezuelan equine encephalitis.
What are some common symptoms associated with arbovirus infections?	Arboviruses typically present with symptoms such as fever, altered mental status, seizures, and cranial nerve palsies.
What are some common symptoms that arboviruses can cause?	Arboviruses typically cause encephalitis and fever.
What is the name of the enzyme responsible for converting arachidonic acids into prostaglandins?	Arachidonic acids are converted to prostaglandins via the enzyme cyclooxygenase.
What is the name of the enzyme responsible for converting arachidonic acids into leukotrienes?	Arachidonic acids are converted to leukotrienes via the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase.
What type of drugs can be used to decrease aqueous humor production?	Aqueous humor production can be decreased with β antagonists.
What type of drugs can be used to decrease aqueous humor production?	Aqueous humor production can be decreased with α2 agonists.
What type of drugs can be used to decrease aqueous humor production?	Aqueous humor production can be decreased by carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
What is the source of aqueous humor production in the eye?	Aqueous humor is produced by nonpigmented epithelium on the ciliary body.
What is the pathway of aqueous humor flow in the eye?	Aqueous humor from the posterior chamber enters the anterior chamber.
Where is a significant portion of the platelet pool stored in the body?	Approximately one-third of the platelet pool is stored in the spleen.
What is the expected number of wet diapers a 5-day-old newborn should have per day?	A 5-day-old newborn should have more than 5 wet diapers per day.
In patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, where are left atrial thrombi most commonly found?	Approximately 90% of left atrial thrombi are found within the left atrial appendage in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.
In which part of the nephron does approximately 20% of potassium (K+) reabsorption occur?	Approximately 20% of K+ reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle).
In giant cell arteritis (GCA), which part of the body is affected in approximately 10-20% of patients?	Approximately 10-20% of patients with giant cell arteritis (GCA) will have involvement of the thoracic aorta.
What is the characteristic feature of appropriate absolute polycythemia?	Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased RBC mass.
What is the characteristic feature of appropriate absolute polycythemia in terms of erythropoietin (EPO) levels?	Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased EPO levels.
What are the typical presenting symptoms of appendicitis in terms of pain location?	Appendicitis presents with diffuse periumbilical pain that eventually localizes to McBurney's point.
What are the potential physical exam findings in a patient with appendicitis that has resulted in peritonitis due to rupture?	Appendicitis may lead to rupture, resulting in peritonitis with guarding and rebound tenderness on physical exam.
What is the cause of appendicitis in children?	Appendicitis in children is related to obstruction of the appendix by lymphoid hyperplasia.
What is the most common cause of appendicitis in adults?	Appendicitis in adults is typically related to obstruction of the appendix by a fecalith.
What is the fate of apoptotic bodies that are formed as a result of apoptosis?	Apoptosis results in the formation of apoptotic bodies, which are subsequently phagocytosed by macrophages.
What is the main mediator of apoptosis and what is its function?	Apoptosis is mediated by caspases, which activate proteases and endonucleases.
What are the morphological characteristics of apoptosis?	Apoptosis is characterized morphologically by cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and membrane blebbing.
What is the role of apoprotein C-II and which enzyme does it activate?	Apoprotein C-II is a cofactor and activator of the enzyme LPL (lipoprotein lipase).
What is the role of apoprotein E in the liver and what does it mediate?	Apoprotein E mediates chylomicron remnant uptake in the liver.
What is the function of apoprotein B-48 in the intestines and what does it mediate?	Apoprotein B-48 mediates chylomicron secretion by the intestines.
Which apoprotein binds to the LDL receptor on the liver?	Apoprotein B-100 binds the LDL receptor on the liver.
On which lipoprotein is apoprotein E not found and on which lipoproteins can it be found?	Apoprotein E may not be found on LDL, but it may be found on every other lipoprotein.
What is the major lipoprotein that apoprotein A-1 is a component of?	Apoprotein A-1 is a major component of high density lipoprotein.
Which apolipoprotein is found on LDL, IDL, and VLDL lipoproteins?	Apolipoprotein B-100 is found on the lipoproteins LDL, IDL, and VLDL.
What is the platelet count like in patients with sickle cell disease who are experiencing aplastic crisis?	Aplastic crisis is often seen in patients with sickle cell disease and is characterized by a normal platelet count.
What are some of the characteristic features of aplastic anemia, in terms of reticulocyte count and erythropoietin levels?	Aplastic anemia is characterized by a decreased reticulocyte count and an increased erythropoietin level.
What is one of the characteristic findings on biopsy in patients with aplastic anemia?	Aplastic anemia is characterized by an empty, fatty marrow on biopsy, also known as a "dry marrow tap".
What is one of the potential triggers for aphthous ulcers, and what is their typical course?	Aphthous ulcers can arise in relation to stress and usually resolve spontaneously, but they frequently recur.
What is the appearance of aphthous ulcers, in terms of the color and surrounding tissue?	Aphthous ulcers are characterized by a grayish base surrounded by erythema.
What is the predictive value of APGAR scores for future outcomes, and how should they be used in guiding therapy?	APGAR scores are not predictive of future outcome, and should not be used to guide therapy.
What is the uncommon complication associated with aortocavitary fistulas?	Aortocavitary fistulas are an uncommon complication of bacterial endocarditis.
What is the potential consequence of aortic stenosis, and how does it progress?	Aortic stenosis may lead to concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, which can further progress to heart failure.
What is the potential consequence of aortic stenosis, and how does it occur?	Aortic stenosis may cause microangiopathic hemolytic anemia as red blood cells are damaged while crossing the calcified valve, producing schistocytes.
What is the potential consequence of aortic regurgitation, and how does it progress?	Aortic regurgitation may lead to left ventricle dilation with eccentric hypertrophy, which can progress to left heart failure.
What condition may develop as a result of chronic rheumatic valve disease affecting the aortic valve?	Aortic stenosis may arise as a consequence of chronic rheumatic valve disease.
What is the meaning of "Pulsus parvus et tardus", and with which condition is it associated?	"Pulsus parvus et tardus", meaning weak pulses with a delayed peak, is associated with aortic stenosis.
What is a potential clinical manifestation of aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection may present with markedly unequal blood pressure in the arms.
What are some potential symptoms of aortic stenosis that may occur during exertion?	Aortic stenosis may present with syncope, angina, and dyspnea on exertion.
What symptom may be caused by aortic stenosis when the aortic valve area is reduced to 1cm2?	Aortic stenosis may cause symptoms of angina when the aortic valve area is reduced to 1cm2.
What are some common causes of aortic stenosis?	Aortic stenosis is typically caused by calcification (old, normal wear and tear), congenital bicuspid valve (middle age), and rheumatic fever.
How is the second heart sound (s2) typically affected in a patient with aortic stenosis?	In a patient with aortic stenosis, the second heart sound (s2) is typically soft.
How does aortic stenosis affect the oxygen demand of the left ventricle?	Aortic stenosis typically leads to a high oxygen demand of the left ventricle.
Where is the best location to auscultate aortic regurgitation murmurs that are due to valvular disease?	Aortic regurgitation murmurs that are due to valvular disease are best heard at the left sternal border (3rd intercostal space).
In what region of the aorta does aortic dissection typically occur?	Aortic dissection typically occurs in the proximal 10 cm of the aorta, which is a high stress region.
What is a potential consequence of aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection may result in rupture into the mediastinum, which can cause fatal hemorrhage.
What is a potential complication of aortic dissection due to backflow into the pericardium?	Aortic dissection may result in cardiac tamponade as a potential complication due to backflow into the pericardium.
What are some common symptoms of aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection may present with sudden sharp, tearing chest pain that radiates to the back as a common symptom.
What can happen as a result of aortic dissection obstructing branching arteries?	Aortic dissection can lead to obstruction of branching arteries, potentially causing end-organ ischemia.
What type of inherited disorders are associated with aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection is associated with inherited connective tissue disorders as a type of inherited disorders.
What type of aortic valve is associated with aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection is associated with a bicuspid aortic valve.
What is a potential consequence of aortic dissection?	Aortic dissection can lead to pleural effusion as a potential consequence.
What symptom do aortic dissection and esophageal perforation have in common?	Aortic dissection and esophageal perforation both present with a widened mediastinum as a common symptom.
What are some symptoms of aortic aneurysm that may indicate leaking, dissection, or imminent rupture?	Aortic aneurysm may cause abdominal and/or back pain, which are symptoms that may indicate leaking, dissection, or imminent rupture.
What effect does mydriasis have on acute angle closure glaucoma?	Anything that causes mydriasis will worsen acute angle closure glaucoma.
What assumption should be made regarding a person who is under 18 years old?	Anyone who is under 18 years old should be assumed to be incompetent.
What is a virus called if it is transmitted by mosquitoes, fleas, or ticks?	A virus that is transmitted by mosquitoes, fleas, or ticks is called an arbovirus.
At what intercostal space is a penetrating wound considered to involve the abdomen?	A penetrating wound below the 4th intercostal space is considered to involve the abdomen.
What should be asked to any patient who reports feeling hopeless, even if the initial symptoms are somatic?	Any patient who reports feeling hopeless, even if the initial symptoms are somatic, should be asked about suicidal ideation.
What kind of anomaly can increase the risk of preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy, and cervical incompetence?	Any kind of uterine anomaly (septate, bicornuate, didelphys) can increase the risk of preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy, and cervical incompetence.
What factor causes coronary sinus dilation?	Any factor that causes increased right atrial pressure will cause coronary sinus dilation.
What condition is suggested by the presence of anxiety, sleep disturbances, high LFTs and macrocytosis?	The presence of anxiety, sleep disturbances, high LFTs and macrocytosis is suggestive of alcohol use disorder.
What is the characteristic of serotonin levels in anxiety?	Anxiety is characterized by decreased serotonin levels.
What does anuria after removing a catheter indicate?	Anuria after removing a catheter indicates urinary tract obstruction.
What is the function of Antithrombin III in relation to thrombin and coagulation factors?	Antithrombin III inactivates thrombin and coagulation factors.
Which gender is more commonly affected by antisocial personality disorder?	Antisocial personality disorder is more common in males.
What is the caution that must be exercised when prescribing antipsychotics to patients with seizure disorders?	Antipsychotics may lower the seizure threshold and must be used with caution in patients who have seizure disorders.
What are some of the symptoms of prolactin excess that may be caused by antipsychotics?	Antipsychotics may cause symptoms of prolactin excess such as galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and gynecomastia.
What autoimmune disease is associated with the presence of antinuclear antibodies such as anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA?	The presence of antinuclear antibodies such as anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease.
What suffix do antineoplastic topoisomerase II inhibitors have, and at what phases of the cell cycle do they prevent progression?	Antineoplastic topoisomerase II inhibitors have the suffix -posides, and they prevent cell cycle progression at the S and G2 phases.
What medical condition is associated with the presence of antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs)?	The presence of antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs) is associated with primary biliary cirrhosis.
What phase of the cell cycle do antimetabolites such as Methotrexate, 5FU, and Hydroxyurea block the progression of?	Antimetabolites such as Methotrexate, 5FU, and Hydroxyurea block the progression of the S phase of the cell cycle.
What type of antigens are not recognizable by T cells and instead stimulate B cells directly?	Antigens that lack a peptide component are not recognizable by T cells and thus stimulate B cells directly.
What type of lymphatics bring antigens into a lymph node?	Antigens are brought into a lymph node via afferent lymphatics.
What is the explanation for why we need a flu shot every year?	Antigenic drift is the reason why we need a flu shot every year.
What are the changes that occur in influenza viruses that lead to antigenic variation?	Antigenic variation of influenza viruses occurs with changes to the viral hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA).
What are the two types of antigenic variation that can occur in influenza viruses?	Antigenic variation in influenza viruses can occur due to antigenic drift or antigenic shift.
What type of pandemic is associated with antigenic shift?	Antigenic shift is associated with pandemics.
What type of epidemic is associated with antigenic drift?	Antigenic drift is associated with epidemics.
How is antigen independent antibody diversity generated?	Antigen independent antibody diversity is generated via random combination of heavy and light chains.
What is the enzyme responsible for generating antigen-independent antibody diversity by inserting random nucleotides during V(D)J recombination?	The enzyme responsible for generating antigen-independent antibody diversity by inserting random nucleotides during V(D)J recombination is terminal deoxyribonucleotidyl transferase (Tdt).
In what type of chains is antigen-independent antibody diversity generated by VJ gene recombination?	Antigen-independent antibody diversity is generated by VJ gene recombination in light chains.
In what type of chains is antigen-independent antibody diversity generated by V(D)J gene recombination?	Antigen-independent antibody diversity is generated by V(D)J gene recombination in heavy chains.
What is the process by which antigen loading onto MHC II occurs, and what happens prior to this process?	Antigen loading onto MHC II occurs following release of the invariant chain in an acidified endosome.
What are some antidotes that can be used to treat cyanide poisoning, and what are some alternative methods of treatment?	Antidotes for cyanide poisoning include hydroxycobalamin (preferred) or sodium thiosulfate; alternatively nitrites may be used to induce methemoglobinemia.
Are antidiarrheals recommended for use in cases of infectious diarrhea?	No, antidiarrheals are contraindicated in cases of infectious diarrhea.
What medical condition is associated with the presence of anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, and anti-β2 glycoprotein?	Anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, and anti-β2 glycoprotein are seen in antiphospholipid syndrome.
What medical condition is highly associated with antibodies to U1 RNP?	Antibodies to U1 RNP are highly associated with mixed connective tissue disease.
What medical condition are antibodies to spliceosomal snRNPs, also known as anti-Smith antibodies, highly specific for?	Antibodies to spliceosomal snRNPs, also known as anti-Smith antibodies, are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
What is the microbe that can flourish in the vagina when antibiotics kill off the normal microflora?	Antibiotics kill vaginal microflora, allowing microbes such as Candida albicans to flourish.
What vitamin deficiency is associated with antibiotics due to their activity against colonic bacteria?	Antibiotics are associated with vitamin K deficiency due to their activity against colonic bacteria.
What is the recommended antibiotic therapy for hospitalized patients with pelvic inflammatory disease?	Antibiotic therapy for hospitalized patients with pelvic inflammatory disease includes IV cefoxitin or cefotetan plus oral doxycycline.
What antibiotic prophylaxis should be given to HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 50/mm3?	Antibiotic prophylaxis in HIV patients with CD4+ count < 50/mm3 should include TMP-SMX.
What is the recommended antibiotic for tetanus?	The recommended antibiotic for tetanus is metronidazole.
What antibiotics are recommended for coverage of gallbladder disease?	Antibiotic coverage for gallbladder disease includes Cipro or Amp-Gent and Metronidazole.
What are some examples of anti-pseudomonal penicillins?	Examples of anti-pseudomonal penicillins include piperacillin, ticarcillin, and carbenicillin.
What type of drugs may induce oxidative stress and are contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency?	Anti-tuberculosis drugs, such as dapsone, may induce oxidative stress and are contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency.
What type of drugs may induce oxidative stress and are contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency?	Anti-malarial drugs, such as primaquine, may induce oxidative stress and are thus contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency.
What condition is associated with anti-Yo, anti-Tr, and anti-Hu antibodies?	Subacute cerebellar degeneration is associated with anti-Yo, anti-Tr, and anti-Hu antibodies.
What condition is suggested by the presence of anti-U1 RNP antibodies?	The presence of anti-U1 RNP antibodies is suggestive of mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD).
What condition is associated with the presence of anti-topoisomerase antibodies?	The presence of anti-topoisomerase antibodies is associated with diffuse systemic scleroderma.
What condition is suggested by the presence of anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies?	The presence of anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies is suggestive of celiac disease (GSE).
Which drugs are classified as anti-staph penicillins?	The drugs classified as anti-staph penicillins include oxacillin, nafcillin, and dicloxacillin.
Against which organism do anti-staph penicillins have activity?	Anti-staph penicillins have activity against Staphylococcus aureus (except MRSA).
Why are anti-staph penicillins ineffective against MRSA?	Anti-staph penicillins are ineffective against MRSA due to the organism's altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP) target site.
With which conditions are anti-SRP antibodies associated?	Anti-SRP antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
What condition is suggested by the presence of anti-smooth muscle antibodies?	The presence of anti-smooth muscle antibodies is suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
How is the coagulability state characterized in anti-phospholipid syndrome?	The coagulability state in anti-phospholipid syndrome is characterized by a hyper-coagulable state.
What is a possible association of Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, which can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome?	Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis can be associated with ovarian teratoma, when it presents as a paraneoplastic syndrome.
What is another name for Anti-müllerian hormone, which is secreted by the Sertoli cells?	Anti-müllerian hormone, secreted by the Sertoli cells, is also known as müllerian inhibitory factor.
What are some therapeutic uses of anti-muscarinics?	Anti-muscarinics can be used therapeutically to dilate bronchial airways and reduce secretions.
How do anti-muscarinics cause hyperthermia, and what is the mechanism behind it?	Anti-muscarinics cause hyperthermia by inhibiting sweat gland function via antagonism of M3 receptors.
What is the mechanism of action of anti-muscarinics?	Anti-muscarinics work by blocking the action of acetylcholine at M receptors.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies?	The presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies is suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis.
What is the role of anti-M protein antibodies in the development of a medical condition?	Anti-M protein antibodies are the cause of Rheumatic Fever.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-Jo, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2 antibodies?	The presence of anti-Jo, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2 antibodies is suggestive of myositis.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-Jo (anti-synthetase) antibodies?	The presence of anti-Jo (anti-synthetase) antibodies is suggestive of myositis.
What medical condition is associated with the presence of anti-islet cell cytoplasmic autoantibodies?	The presence of anti-islet cell cytoplasmic autoantibodies is associated with type I diabetes mellitus.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-histone antibodies?	The presence of anti-histone antibodies is suggestive of drug-induced SLE.
What does the presence of Anti-HBs and Anti-HBe or Anti-HBc Ab indicate?	The presence of Anti-HBs and Anti-HBe or Anti-HBc Ab indicates recovery from Hepatitis B.
What is the significance of Anti-HBc IgM in the context of Hepatitis B?	Anti-HBc IgM is the sole marker during the window period of Hepatitis B infection.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies?	The presence of anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies is suggestive of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.
In which patients are anti-diarrheal agents contraindicated?	Anti-diarrheal agents are contraindicated in patients with bloody diarrhea or fever.
What is the effect of anti-cholinergic medication (e.g. TCAs) on compound muscle action potential following motor nerve stimulation?	The effect of anti-cholinergic medication (e.g. TCAs) is no change in compound muscle action potential following motor nerve stimulation.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-centromere antibodies?	The presence of anti-centromere antibodies is suggestive of limited scleroderma (CREST).
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anti-CCP antibodies being greater than anti-RF antibodies?	The presence of anti-CCP antibodies being greater than anti-RF antibodies is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
What is the effect of anthracyclines on hair follicles?	Anthracyclines can target hair follicles, resulting in alopecia.
In what form can anthracyclines be prepared to minimize the risk of Dilated Cardiomyopathy?	Anthracyclines can be prepared in liposomal form to minimize the risk of Dilated Cardiomyopathy.
What type of blood cell neoplasias are treated with anthracyclines?	Anthracyclines are used to treat white blood cell neoplasias.
What mechanisms do anthracyclines use to act as antineoplastics?	Anthracyclines act as antineoplastics by producing free radicals and causing DNA intercalation.
How do anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin) block DNA and RNA synthesis?	Anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin) intercalate into DNA, blocking DNA and RNA synthesis.
What types of malignancies can be treated with anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin)?	Anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin) treat both hematologic malignancies and solid tumors.
What is the mechanism by which anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin) cause breaks in DNA?	Anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin) form free radicals which cause breaks in DNA.
What is the target of anthracyclines (-rubicin) that leads to cleavage of DNA?	Anthracyclines (-rubicin) bind topoisomerase II to cause cleavage of DNA.
What is the name of the iron chelating agent that can be used to prevent Anthracycline associated Dilated Cardiomyopathy?	Anthracycline associated Dilated Cardiomyopathy can be prevented with dexrazoxane, an iron chelating agent.
What is the name of the bacterial species from which Anthracycline antitumor antibiotics were first isolated?	Anthracycline antitumor antibiotics were first isolated from a species of Actinomyces bacteria.
What is another name for Anterior uveitis?	Anterior uveitis is also known as iritis.
What is the typical cause of Anterior urethral injuries?	Anterior urethral injuries are typically caused by a perineal straddle injury.
What are the signs that result from Anterior spinal artery occlusion?	Anterior spinal artery occlusion results in signs of bilateral upper motoneuron lesion below the infarct.
What are the signs that result from Anterior spinal artery occlusion at the level of the infarct?	Anterior spinal artery occlusion results in signs of bilateral lower motoneuron lesion at the level of the infarct.
Which hormones regulate the anterior pituitary control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion?	The anterior pituitary control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion are regulated via the hormones FSH and LH.
What is the management for anterior and posterior epistaxis?	Anterior epistaxis is managed with cauterization while posterior epistaxis is managed with packing.
What is the initial presentation of anterior cord syndrome?	The initial presentation of anterior cord syndrome is bilateral flaccid paralysis.
What conditions are associated with anterior anal fissures?	Anterior anal fissures are associated with Crohn's disease, malignancy, and infection.
What is the delivery method for antenatally diagnosed placenta accreta?	Antenatally diagnosed placenta accreta is delivered by planned cesarean hysterectomy.
How can antacids affect the bioavailability of other drugs?	Antacids can affect the bioavailability of other drugs by altering gastric and urinary pH.
Which enzyme is responsible for the endogenous metabolism of ANP and BNP?	The enzyme neprilysin is responsible for the endogenous metabolism of ANP and BNP.
What is the result of the breakdown and shedding of proliferative glands in anovulatory cycles?	The breakdown and shedding of proliferative glands in anovulatory cycles result in abnormal uterine bleeding.
What is the result of anovulatory cycles in terms of the progesterone-driven secretory phase and estrogen-driven proliferative phase?	Anovulatory cycles result in an estrogen-driven proliferative phase, but no progesterone-driven secretory phase.
What is an anovulatory cycle?	An anovulatory cycle is a menstrual cycle that lacks ovulation.
What are the possible causes of another type of secondary pulmonary hypertension, besides the known cause?	Another type of secondary pulmonary hypertension may arise due to multifactorial causes, such as hematologic, systemic, and metabolic disorders.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anosmia and low GnRH levels?	Anosmia and low GnRH levels are suggestive of Kallmann syndrome.
What type of fracture is suggested by the presence of anosmia, raccoon eyes, and CSF rhinorrhea?	Anosmia, raccoon eyes, and CSF rhinorrhea are suggestive of a fracture of the cribriform plate in the anterior cranial fossa.
What is the reason behind the association of anorexia nervosa or strenuous exercise with amenorrhea?	Anorexia nervosa or strenuous exercise is associated with amenorrhea due to the loss of pulsatile GnRH secretion.
What bone condition is associated with anorexia nervosa, and what is the potential consequence of this condition?	Anorexia nervosa is associated with osteopenia, which can increase the risk of bone fractures.
What is one medical condition that is associated with anorexia nervosa?	Anorexia nervosa is associated with hypercarotenemia.
What are some of the bone-related conditions that are associated with anorexia nervosa?	Anorexia nervosa is associated with decreased bone density and an increased risk of metatarsal stress fractures.
What is a common mental health condition that is often present alongside anorexia nervosa?	Anorexia nervosa commonly coexists with depression.
What is one potential secondary condition that can result from anorexia?	Anorexia can lead to secondary osteoporosis.
How can anorexia affect hormone levels in the body?	Anorexia can lead to low levels of LH, FSH, and estrogen.
What is a potential effect of anorexia on cholesterol levels in the body?	Anorexia can result in hypercholesterolemia.
What are some potential symptoms or complications that may result from annular pancreas?	Annular pancreas may cause duodenal obstruction and bilious vomiting.
Which parts of the body are affected by ankylosing spondylitis?	Ankylosing spondylitis primarily involves the spine and sacroiliac joints.
What is the potential respiratory complication associated with ankylosing spondylitis and what causes it?	Ankylosing spondylitis can cause restrictive lung disease due to limited chest wall expansion.
What is the risk of vertebral fracture associated with ankylosing spondylitis?	Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with a high risk of vertebral fracture.
What is the management approach for ankle fractures that involve displacement of fragments?	Ankle fractures with displacement of fragments are managed with ORIF (Open Reduction Internal Fixation).
What is anisocytosis and what does it refer to in relation to red blood cells?	Anisocytosis refers to variation in red blood cell size.
What are some examples of anions that competitively inhibit the sodium-iodide transporter?	Some examples of anions that competitively inhibit the sodium-iodide transporter include perchlorate, pertechnetate, and thiocyanate.
Which types of cancer are associated with exposure to aniline (azo) dyes?	Exposure to aniline (azo) dyes is a risk factor for hepatocellular and transitional cell carcinoma.
What effect does angiotensin II have on Na+-H+ exchange in the proximal tubule?	Angiotensin II stimulates Na+-H+ exchange in the proximal tubule.
What hormone is synthesized and secreted by the adrenal cortex in response to stimulation by angiotensin II?	Aldosterone is synthesized and secreted by the adrenal cortex in response to stimulation by angiotensin II.
Which arteriole in the kidney does angiotensin II normally constrict?	Angiotensin II normally constricts the efferent arteriole of the kidney.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on blood vessels?	Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on thirst and how does it achieve this effect?	Angiotensin II increases thirst via its action on the hypothalamus.
What type of ion exchange does angiotensin II increase in the proximal convoluted tubule?	Angiotensin II increases Na+-H+ exchange in the proximal convoluted tubule.
What hormone release does angiotensin II increase from the adrenal cortex?	Angiotensin II increases aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on arterioles?	Angiotensin II causes constriction of arterioles.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle?	Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction of vascular smooth muscle.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on the posterior pituitary and what hormone is released as a result?	Angiotensin II acts on the posterior pituitary to increase release of ADH.
What is the effect of angiotensin II on the hypothalamus and what response does it increase?	Angiotensin II acts on the hypothalamus to increase thirst.
What is the direct effect of angiotensin II on the PCT and what does it do to NaHCO3 reabsorption?	Angiotensin II acts directly at the PCT to increase NaHCO3 reabsorption.
What enzyme primarily converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II and where does this conversion occur?	Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by ACE in the lungs (primarily).
What are the common symptoms associated with angioinvasive aspergillosis?	Angioinvasive aspergillosis will present with fever, cough and hemoptysis.
What is the most common treatment for angioinvasive aspergillosis?	Angioinvasive aspergillosis is treated with Amphotericin B.
In which part of the colon does angiodysplasia typically occur and why?	Angiodysplasia usually arises in the cecum and right colon due to high wall tension.
What are the medical conditions that are associated with a higher incidence of angiodysplasia?	Angiodysplasia is more common in patients with chronic kidney disease and von Willebrand disease.
What are the medical conditions associated with a higher incidence of angiodysplasia in patients?	Angiodysplasia is more common in patients with advanced renal disease, aortic stenosis, and von Willebrand disease.
What is the diagnostic method used to confirm the presence of angiodysplasia?	Angiodysplasia is confirmed by angiography.
What is the typical clinical presentation of angiodysplasia in an older adult?	Angiodysplasia classically presents as hematochezia in an older adult.
What is angiodysplasia and what does it result in?	Angiodysplasia is an acquired malformation resulting in tortuous dilation of vessels of the GI tract.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of angina, syncope, and CHF?	Angina, syncope, and CHF is suggestive of aortic stenosis.
In what parts of the body do aneurysmal bone cysts most typically localize?	Aneurysmal bone cysts most typically localize to the spine, femur, and tibia.
What is a potential consequence of anencephaly during pregnancy?	Anencephaly may result in polyhydramnios.
What is a characteristic feature of anencephaly in terms of AFP levels during pregnancy?	Anencephaly is characterized by elevated levels of AFP in utero.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of anemia with a positive osmotic fragility test?	Anemia with a positive osmotic fragility test is suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.
What is the treatment for anemia of chronic kidney disease?	Anemia of chronic kidney disease is managed with erythropoietin (EPO).
What are the typical changes in serum iron, transferrin (TIBC), and ferritin levels associated with anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease results in low serum iron, low transferrin (TIBC), and high ferritin levels.
What is a characteristic feature of ferritin levels in anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by increased ferritin levels.
What is a characteristic feature of transferrin (TIBC) levels in anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased transferrin (TIBC) levels.
What is a characteristic feature of serum iron levels in anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased serum iron levels.
What is a characteristic feature of % saturation levels in anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased % saturation levels.
What is a characteristic feature of free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP) levels in anemia of chronic disease?	Anemia of chronic disease is associated with an increased free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP) level.
What are the common physical signs of anemia?	Anemia may present with pale conjunctiva and skin.
What is a potential cardiovascular symptom that may be associated with anemia, particularly in individuals with pre-existing coronary artery disease?	Anemia may present with angina, especially with pre-existing coronary artery disease.
What are the typical signs and symptoms associated with anemia?	Anemia may present with signs and symptoms of hypoxia.
What is the definition of anemia in males in terms of hemoglobin levels?	Anemia is defined as Hb < 13.5 g/dL in males.
What is the definition of anemia in females in terms of hemoglobin levels?	Anemia is defined as Hb < 12.5 g/dL in females.
What is the classification of anemia when the MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is between 80 to 100 μm3?	Anemia is classified as normocytic when the MCV is between 80 to 100 μm3.
What is the classification of anemia when the MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is less than 80 μm3?	Anemia is classified as microcytic if the MCV < 80 μm3.
What is the classification of anemia when the MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is greater than 100 μm3?	Anemia is classified as macrocytic when the MCV > 100 μm3.
What are the associations of anemia with SaO2, O2 content, and PaO2?	Anemia is associated with normal SaO2, decreased O2 content, and normal PaO2.
What is the possible cause of anemia due to underproduction?	Anemia due to underproduction may occur with chronic kidney disease, due to decreased production of EPO.
What is the conversion process of androstenedione and which enzyme is involved?	Androstenedione may be converted to testosterone via the enzyme 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.
What type of hypercortisolism is associated with androgenic symptoms in Cushing syndrome, such as acne and irregular menses?	Androgenic symptoms associated with Cushing syndrome (e.g. acne, irregular menses) are seen with ACTH dependent hypercortisolism.
What is the source and form of androgen production during puberty?	Androgen production during puberty comes from the adrenal glands in the form of DHEA.
What is the cause of androgen insensitivity syndrome in target tissues of males?	Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a deficiency of androgen receptors in target tissues of males.
What is the difference in hair growth between individuals with androgen insensitivity syndrome and those with Müllerian agenesis?	Individuals with androgen insensitivity syndrome have absent hair growth, while those with Müllerian agenesis have present hair growth.
What is the effect of androgen abuse on body hair?	Androgen abuse does not have a significant effect on body hair, as it typically results in normal body hair.
What is the association between Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma and cell division checkpoint regulation?	Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is associated with the loss of p53 cell division checkpoint regulation.
What is the management approach for anaphylaxis that is refractory to one dose of IM epi without respiratory failure signs?	Anaphylaxis that is refractory to one dose of IM epi without respiratory failure signs is managed with repeat IM epi.
What is the management approach for anaphylactic shock and hypotension?	The management approach for anaphylactic shock and hypotension involves administering IM epi and an IVF bolus.
What is Analgesic nephropathy and what is its association with NSAID use?	Analgesic nephropathy is a renal complication that occurs due to prolonged use of NSAIDs.
What are anal fissures and where are they located in the anal canal?	Anal fissures are tears in the anal mucosa that are located below the pectinate line in the anal canal.
What are the common clinical presentations of anal squamous cell carcinoma?	Anal squamous cell carcinoma often presents with rectal bleeding and a visible ulcerative mass.
What are the common symptoms associated with anal fissures?	Anal fissures typically present with pain while pooping and blood on toilet paper.
What is the typical location of anal fissures and why are they located in that area?	Anal fissures are typically located posteromedially, because this area is poorly perfused.
What are the risk factors associated with anal fissures?	Anal fissures are associated with constipation and low-fiber diets.
What are the common clinical presentations of anal carcinoma?	Anal carcinoma presents with proctitis with tenesmus and bloody discharge.
What medical condition is Anakinra used to treat?	Anakinra is used to treat Rheumatoid Arthritis.
What medication is used to treat anaerobic infections below the diaphragm?	Anaerobic infections below the diaphragm are treated with metronidazole.
What medication is used to treat anaerobic infections above the diaphragm?	Anaerobic infections above the diaphragm are treated with clindamycin.
What is the net amount of NADH produced by anaerobic glycolysis per glucose molecule?	Anaerobic glycolysis produces a net of 2 NADH per glucose molecule.
How many ATP molecules are produced by anaerobic glycolysis per glucose molecule?	Anaerobic glycolysis produces a net of 2 ATP per glucose molecule.
Does the use of anabolic steroids lead to hypogonadism?	Yes, the use of anabolic steroids leads to hypogonadism.
What condition is suggested by the presence of ANA, anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2, and anti-SRP antibodies?	The presence of ANA, anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2, and anti-SRP antibodies is suggestive of myositis.
What type of test is used to diagnose diabetes mellitus and impaired glucose tolerance in patients with insulin resistance?	An oral glucose tolerance test is used to diagnose diabetes mellitus and impaired glucose tolerance in patients with insulin resistance.
What is an isochromosome and how is it characterized?	An isochromosome is a chromosome that has two copies of one arm and no copies of the other.
What type of deficiency may present after administration of the BCG vaccine?	An IL-12 Receptor Deficiency may present after administration of the BCG vaccine.
In the context of mitral stenosis, what does an earlier snap signify?	An earlier snap in mitral stenosis signifies more severe disease.
What condition is suggested by an x-ray of the spine that shows focal, sclerotic, hyperdense lesions?	An x-ray of the spine that shows focal, sclerotic, hyperdense lesions is suggestive of prostate cancer.
What does an ultrasound of a patient with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis show in regards to the pylorus?	An ultrasound of a patient with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis shows a thickened and lengthened pylorus.
What medication can be used to reverse an overdose of Dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor?	An overdose of Dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor, can be reversed by Idarucizumab.
What are the two types of cells that surround an oocyte in an ovarian follicle?	An ovarian follicle consists of an oocyte surrounded by granulosa and theca cells.
What are the symptoms of an obstructed kidney stone?	An obstructed kidney stone may present with unilateral flank tenderness that radiates to the groin.
What are the typical symptoms associated with an intervertebral disc herniation at the L4-L5 level?	An intervertebral disc herniation at the L4-L5 level typically results in weakness of dorsiflexion and difficulty in heel-walking.
What is the initial measure to treat fetal hypoperfusion causing late decels?	The initial measure to treat fetal hypoperfusion causing late decels is to move the mother into the left lateral position.
What is the effect of an increased TPR on cardiac output and venous return?	An increased TPR causes the cardiac output to decrease and venous return to decrease.
What is the effect of increased blood volume or venous tone on cardiac output and right atrial pressure?	An increased blood volume (or venous tone) causes the cardiac output to increase and right atrial pressure to increase.
What is the effect of an increase in mean systemic pressure on the vascular function curve?	An increase in mean systemic pressure is reflected in a shift of the vascular function curve to the right.
What is the term used to describe an increase in lymph node size due to infection?	An increase in lymph node size due to infection is known as reactive hyperplasia.
What are the two components of an incidence rate?	An incidence rate is a special type of proportion that includes a given time range and a population at risk.
What is the characteristic gross appearance of intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma?	The characteristic gross appearance of intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma is an exophytic mass with bleeding and ulcerations.
In which type of cancer is the tumor staging factor of tumor size/invasiveness typically the most important?	The tumor staging factor of tumor size/invasiveness is typically the most important in melanoma (Breslow thickness).
What percentage of the body surface area is affected by an entire torso burn?	An entire torso burn affects 18% of the body surface area.
What percentage of the body surface area is affected by an entire leg burn?	An entire leg burn affects 18% of the body surface area.
What percentage of the body surface area is affected by an entire head burn?	An entire head burn affects 9% of the body surface area.
What percentage of the body surface area is affected by an entire arm burn?	An entire arm burn affects 9% of the body surface area.
What percentage of the body surface area is affected by an entire abdomen burn?	An entire abdomen burn affects 18% of the body surface area.
What is the cause of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and edema in individuals with enteropeptidase deficiency?	Individuals with enteropeptidase deficiency experience diarrhea, failure to thrive, and edema due to hypoproteinemia.
In CML, what organ's enlargement suggests a progression to accelerated disease ("blast crisis")?	In CML, the enlargement of the spleen suggests a progression to accelerated disease ("blast crisis").
If an endotracheal tube is advanced too far, which mainstem bronchus will it preferentially enter into?	If an endotracheal tube is advanced too far, it will preferentially enter into the right mainstem bronchus.
In which population is an EGFR "driver mutation" especially common in individuals with adenocarcinomas of the lung?	An EGFR "driver mutation" is especially common in Asian female non-smokers who have adenocarcinomas of the lung.
What is an effective treatment for Moraxella catarrhalis?	An effective treatment for Moraxella catarrhalis is amoxicillin and clavulanic acid.
What is an early sign of ALS?	An early sign of ALS is atrophy and weakness of the hands.
What is an apophysis and what is its function?	An apophysis is a secondary ossification center which serves as an attachment for a tendon.
How should an adrenal crisis be treated?	An adrenal crisis should be treated with immediate glucocorticoid supplementation and aggressive fluid resuscitation.
What is considered an adequate duration for an antidepressant trial at a therapeutic dosage?	An adequate antidepressant trial is generally considered to be at least 4 - 6 weeks at a therapeutic dosage.
What does an absence of DTRs indicate in an elderly person?	An absence of DTRs in an elderly person is normal.
What is the recommended course of action if there is an abnormally elevated msAFP during pregnancy?	An abnormally elevated msAFP suggests a neural tube defect or multiple gestation, and warrants fetal ultrasound.
What does an abnormal Valgus test indicate?	An abnormal Valgus test shows increased medial space widening of the tibia.
What are the next steps after an abnormal pap smear?	An abnormal pap smear is followed by confirmatory colposcopy (visualization of cervix with a magnifying glass) and biopsy.
What does an abnormal head thrust test detect?	An abnormal head thrust test can detect vestibular dysfunction.
What does an abnormal biophysical profile score indicate?	An abnormal biophysical profile score (0 - 4) is consistent with fetal hypoxia due to placental dysfunction.
What ABI value is considered diagnostic of occlusive peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in symptomatic patients?	An ABI of ≤ 0.90 is considered diagnostic of occlusive peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in symptomatic patients.
What is an aberrant right subclavian artery and what does it result in?	An aberrant right subclavian artery is an aortic arch defect which results in a misplaced 4th aortic arch derivative.
What effect does an aberrant right subclavian artery have on the right recurrent laryngeal nerve?	An aberrant right subclavian artery causes the right recurrent laryngeal nerve to become non-recurrent.
What is an aberrant internal carotid artery and what symptom does it present with?	An aberrant internal carotid artery is a defect of the 3rd aortic arch that presents with pulsatile tinnitus.
What language milestone should an 18-month-old child be able to achieve?	An 18-month-old child should be able to say several single words.
What findings will be seen on EMG and nerve conduction studies in a patient with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?	Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis will show fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves on EMG and nerve conduction studies.
At what level of the spinal cord does amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically begin?	Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically begins at cervical levels of the spinal cord.
What is the common name for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)?	Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is commonly known as Lou Gehrig disease.
What are the characteristic findings of amyloidosis under polarized light after staining with Congo red?	Amyloidosis is characterized by apple-green birefringence under polarized light after staining with Congo red.
What staining method can be used to visualize amyloid?	Amyloid may be visualized using Congo red staining.
How does amyloid appear when visualized under polarized light?	Amyloid may be visualized as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
What is the increased risk associated with amyloid angiopathy?	Amyloid angiopathy increases the risk for intracranial hemorrhage.
What is the effect of amylin analogues, such as pramlintide, on glucagon secretion?	Amylin analogues (e.g. pramlintide) decrease glucagon secretion.
What effect do amylin analogues, such as pramlintide, have on gastric emptying?	Amylin analogues (e.g. pramlintide) cause decreased gastric emptying.
What organism is responsible for meningitis that can be treated with ampicillin?	Meningitis produced by Listeria monocytogenes can be treated with ampicillin.
What type of toxicity is associated with the use of Amphotericin B?	The use of Amphotericin B is associated with renal toxicity.
What does Amphotericin B suppress in terms of renal synthesis?	Amphotericin B suppresses renal erythropoietin (EPO) synthesis.
What is the consequence of Amphotericin B related renal toxicity, and what is the underlying mechanism?	The consequence of Amphotericin B related renal toxicity is anemia, which is due to decreased erythropoietin production.
What are the drug options for treating systemic candidal infections?	Amphotericin B or echinocandins (drug class) can be used for treating systemic candidal infections.
What type of fungal infections is Amphotericin B typically used to treat?	Amphotericin B is typically used to treat serious systemic fungal infections.
What are the effects of Amphotericin B on renal tubule permeability, and what are the resulting electrolyte imbalances?	Amphotericin B increases renal tubule permeability, which can result in potassium (K+) and magnesium (Mg2+) wasting.
What type of renal tubular acidosis is caused by Amphotericin B, and is it dose-dependent or slow-accumulated?	Amphotericin B causes Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis, which can be dose-dependent or slow-accumulated.
What type of toxicity can be caused by Amphotericin B, and is it dose-dependent or slow-accumulated?	Amphotericin B can cause reversible nephrotoxicity, which can be dose-dependent or slow-accumulated.
For which protozoal infections is Amphotericin B used, and can you provide some examples?	Amphotericin B can be used for certain protozoal infections, such as Leishmaniasis and Naegleria Fowleri.
How do amphetamines exert their effects on the body, and what is the mechanism behind it?	Amphetamines exert their effects by displacing catecholamines (NE, dopamine) into the synapse, which is the mechanism behind their action.
What are the potential risks associated with amphetamine abuse during pregnancy, particularly for the developing fetus?	Amphetamine abuse during pregnancy is associated with fetal growth restriction, which is a potential risk for the developing fetus.
What is the end product of the breakdown of AMP (adenosine monophosphate) during purine salvage?	The end product of the breakdown of AMP is adenosine during purine salvage.
What is the difference in time frame between the occurrence of amniotic fluid embolism and pulmonary embolism?	Amniotic fluid embolism occurs during delivery or right afterwards, while pulmonary embolism can occur up to days afterwards.
What are the features of DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) that are present in cases of amniotic fluid embolism?	Amniotic fluid embolism has features of DIC, including thrombocytopenia, elevated D-dimer levels, and abnormal coagulation studies.
What are the common symptoms associated with amniotic fluid emboli?	Amniotic fluid emboli may present with neurologic symptoms and respiratory distress.
What part of the body do amniotic bands commonly constrict?	Amniotic bands commonly constrict limbs.
Is amnioinfusion contraindicated in patients with a history of uterine surgery?	No, amnioinfusion is not contraindicated in patients with a history of uterine surgery.
Is amnioinfusion indicated for late fetal decelerations or tachysystole?	No, amnioinfusion is not indicated for late fetal decelerations or tachysystole.
Between what weeks of pregnancy may amniocentesis be performed?	Amniocentesis may be performed between 15 to 22 weeks of pregnancy.
What is the earliest possible time frame for performing amniocentesis?	Amniocentesis may be done as early as 15 to 17 weeks of pregnancy.
What is the urine pH level associated with precipitation of ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones?	Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones precipitate with high urine pH.
What type of organisms are associated with the formation of ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones?	Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones are caused by urease positive organisms.
What is the classic location and shape of ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) kidney stones?	Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) kidney stones classically form staghorn calculi in renal calyces.
What type of pre-existing syndromes can AML arise from?	AML may arise from pre-existing myelodysplastic syndromes.
What type of cells accumulate in the bone marrow in AML?	AML is a neoplastic accumulation of myeloblasts (>20%) in the bone marrow.
What type of cells accumulate in the bone marrow in AML and ALL?	AML and ALL are neoplastic accumulations of myeloblasts or lymphoblasts (>20%) in the bone marrow.
Is Amitriptyline indicated for abortive migraine therapy?	No, Amitriptyline is not indicated for abortive migraine therapy.
What is the potential adverse effect of Amiodarone, especially with rapid IV administration?	Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can induce heart failure, especially with rapid IV administration.
What is a potential hypersensitivity reaction that can be caused by Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic?	Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can cause hypersensitivity hepatitis.
How can Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, act and what is the result of this action?	Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can act as a hapten, resulting in gray corneal microdeposits.
What type of pneumonia may be caused by Amiodarone?	Amiodarone may cause cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.
How can Amiodarone act as a hapten and what type of skin discoloration can result from this action?	Amiodarone can act as a hapten resulting in gray-blue skin discoloration with photodermatitis.
What potential cardiac condition can be caused by Amiodarone as a result of its class II antiarrhythmic activity?	Amiodarone can cause heart block as a result of its class II antiarrhythmic activity.
What type of pulmonary condition can be caused by Amiodarone and what can it progress to?	Amiodarone can cause pulmonary fibrosis with progression to restrictive lung disease.
What are the names of the two antibiotics that belong to the group of aminopenicillins?	The two antibiotics that belong to the group of aminopenicillins are amoxicillin and ampicillin.
In what viral illness setting can a rash be caused by the administration of aminopenicillins?	Aminopenicillins can cause rash if given in the setting of EBV infectious mononucleosis.
What type of rash can be caused by the administration of aminopenicillins in the setting of EBV infectious mononucleosis?	Aminopenicillins can cause a polymorphous, maculopapular rash if given in the setting of EBV infectious mononucleosis.
What type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with aminopenicillins (amoxicillin) causing a maculopapular rash in the setting of EBV infection?	Aminopenicillins (amoxicillin) causing a maculopapular rash in EBV infection is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
What is clavulanic acid/clavulanate when used with aminopenicillins (amoxicillin)?	Clavulanic acid/clavulanate is a β-lactamase inhibitor when used with aminopenicillins (amoxicillin).
What mnemonic can be used to remember the coverage and toxicities of aminoglycosides?	The mnemonic that can be used to remember the coverage and toxicities of aminoglycosides is "Mean GNATS caNNOT kill anaerobes".
What specific type of nephrotoxicity is caused by aminoglycosides?	Aminoglycosides cause acute tubular necrosis, a specific type of nephrotoxicity.
What is the mechanism of action of aminoglycosides in inhibiting protein synthesis?	Aminoglycosides cause the misreading of mRNA, inhibiting translation and thus protein synthesis.
Which part of the kidney is damaged by aminoglycosides, causing nephrotoxicity?	Aminoglycosides cause nephrotoxicity by damaging the proximal convoluted tubule in the kidney.
What electrolyte disturbance can be caused by aminoglycosides and what can it eventually precipitate in prolonged use?	Aminoglycosides can lead to severe decreases in Mg2+ serum concentration, which in prolonged use can eventually precipitate tetany.
How do aminoglycosides affect the neuromuscular junction and what type of receptors do they block?	Aminoglycosides can impact the neuromuscular junction by blocking post-synaptic Nm receptors.
Which ribosomal subunit do aminoglycosides bind to and what is the consequence of this binding?	Aminoglycosides bind the 30S ribosomal subunit, irreversibly inhibiting formation of the initiation complex.
What is the potential teratogenic effect of aminoglycosides and what condition can it cause in newborns?	Aminoglycosides are teratogenic and can cause deafness in newborns.
For what type of infections are aminoglycosides primarily indicated, and what is the specific Gram classification of these infections?	Aminoglycosides are primarily indicated for severe Gram Negative Rod infections.
What are the potential toxic effects associated with aminoglycosides and what are the specific types of toxicity?	Aminoglycosides are known to be both oto-toxic and nephro-toxic.
What are the common drugs that are paired with aminoglycosides to enhance their penetration of cells?	Aminoglycosides are commonly paired with β-lactams or vancomycin to enhance their penetration of cells.
What is the mode of action of aminoglycosides on bacteria?	Aminoglycosides are bactericidal.
What is the mechanism by which aminoglycosides are actively transported into the cell?	Aminoglycosides are actively transported into the cell via an oxygen-dependent process.
What is the potential teratogenic effect of aminoglycosides?	Aminoglycosides act as a teratogen by causing congenital deafness.
What are the requirements and products of the aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase reaction?	Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase requires ATP and releases inorganic PPi.
What is responsible for the accuracy of amino acid selection during protein synthesis?	Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and binding of charged tRNA to the codon are responsible for accuracy of amino acid selection.
What amino acid are amine hormones derived from?	Amine hormones are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine.
What type of diabetes insipidus can be treated with amiloride?	Amiloride is useful for the treatment of lithium-induced diabetes insipidus.
What type of molecules does amifostine scavenge, and what is the source of these molecules in the kidney?	Amifostine scavenges free radicals produced by cisplatin in the kidney.
At what age is amenorrhea a concern if a patient has not yet begun menstruating?	Amenorrhea is a concern if a patient does not menstruate by age 15.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and infertility?	Amenorrhea and galactorrhea and infertility are suggestive of prolactinoma.
How is amblyopia treated if it is diagnosed at an early age, specifically before the age of 8?	Amblyopia caught at an early age (< 8) is treated by patching the good eye.
What is the mechanism of action of amantadine in relation to dopamine?	Amantadine inhibits dopamine reuptake.
What are the effects of amantadine on dopamine, specifically in terms of synthesis and release?	Amantadine increases dopamine synthesis and release.
What is the target of amantadine and rimantadine, and what virus does it relate to?	Amantadine and Rimantadine are drugs that inhibit the M2 protein channels of influenza A.
What are some of the adverse effects associated with the use of amantadine?	Amantadine adverse effects include livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, and orthostatic dysregulation.
In Alzheimer's Disease, what is the cause of low acetylcholine levels?	Alzheimer's Disease presents with low acetylcholine levels due to decreased activity of choline acetyltransferase.
What is the main characteristic of acetylcholine levels in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer's disease is characterized by decreased acetylcholine.
How does memory loss typically present in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease presents with slow-onset memory loss, beginning with short-term and progressing to long-term loss.
What is executive cognitive dysfunction and how does it relate to Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease may present with executive cognitive dysfunction, characterized by difficulty organizing or planning.
What is the main histological characteristic of Alzheimer's disease and where is it found?	Alzheimer disease is characterized histologically by neuritic (senile) plaques in gray matter.
What changes are observed in the sulci of the brain in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by widening of sulci.
What are neurofibrillary tangles and what type of protein do they consist of in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by neurofibrillary tangles, which are intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
What changes are observed in the gyri of the brain in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by narrowing of gyri.
What is the main cortical change that is observed in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by widespread cortical atrophy.
What neurotransmitter is found to be low in the basal nucleus of Meynert in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by low levels of acetylcholine (ACh) in the basal nucleus of Meynert.
Besides generalized cortical atrophy, what other type of atrophy is commonly observed in Alzheimer's disease?	Alzheimer disease is characterized by generalized cortical atrophy but also temporal lobe atrophy.
What is the tendency of alveoli during expiration?	Alveoli have an increased tendency to collapse during expiration.
What are the respiratory consequences of alveolar hypoventilation and atelectasis?	Alveolar hypoventilation leads to respiratory acidosis, while atelectasis leads to respiratory alkalosis.
What is the classic presentation of the "unhappy triad" injury and which meniscus is more commonly injured?	Although the classic presentation for the "unhappy triad" involves medial meniscus injury, the lateral meniscus is more commonly injured.
What is a potential complication of chronic urinary retention in benign prostatic hyperplasia?	Chronic urinary retention in benign prostatic hyperplasia can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
What are some factors that may contribute to the development of slipped-capital femoral epiphysis, in addition to obesity?	Although obesity is a risk factor, slipped-capital femoral epiphysis may also be seen in tall, thin adolescents.
What is an alternative treatment option to β-blockers for stable angina?	A non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (non-DHP CCB) can be an alternative treatment option for stable angina.
What are some symptoms of CNS tumors in both pediatric and adult patients?	Altered mental status, headache, intracranial hypertension, and seizures are common symptoms of CNS tumors in both pediatric and adult patients.
What can happen if there are alterations in the natural bacterial flora in the vagina?	If there are alterations in the natural vaginal bacterial flora, it can lead to overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis.
What is the mechanism behind methicillin resistance in MRSA?	Methicillin resistance in MRSA occurs due to the alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBP).
What are the typical clinical features of ALS?	ALS typically presents with asymmetric spastic paralysis in the lower limbs.
What type of paralysis is commonly seen in the upper limbs of patients with ALS?	ALS commonly presents with asymmetric flaccid paralysis in the upper limbs.
In what context is Alprostadil used to maintain a specific cardiovascular structure in certain types of congenital heart disease?	Alprostadil is used to maintain a Patent Ductus Arteriosus in the setting of certain types of congenital heart disease.
What is the chemical structure that Alprostadil and Misoprostol share as analogues?	Alprostadil and Misoprostol are analogues of PGE1.
What is the characteristic feature of the half-life of benzodiazepines such as Alprazolam, Lorazepam, Temazepam, and Oxazepam?	Benzodiazepines such as Alprazolam, Lorazepam, Temazepam, and Oxazepam have intermediate half-lives.
What type of collagen is affected by an inherited defect that leads to Alport syndrome?	Alport syndrome occurs secondary to an inherited defect in type IV collagen.
What is the characteristic appearance seen on electron microscopy in individuals with Alport syndrome?	Alport syndrome is associated with a "basket-weave" appearance on electron microscopy.
What is the effect of alpha-blockers on prostate growth or PSA level?	Alpha-blockers have a mild effect on prostate growth or PSA level.
What type of muscle fibers are innervated by alpha motoneurons?	Alpha motoneurons innervate extra-fusal muscle fibers.
What substances are contained in the alpha granules of platelets?	The alpha granules of platelets contain von Willebrand factor (vWF) and fibrinogen.
What effect does the exotoxin Alpha Toxin have on muscle blood flow, in addition to causing muscle breakdown?	Along with muscle breakdown, the exotoxin Alpha Toxin also results in decreased muscle blood flow.

Besides bats, which other animals commonly carry the Rabies virus in the eastern United States?	Along with bats, Rabies virus is also commonly carried by raccoons and foxes in the eastern U.S.
What is the characteristic feature of mesotheliomas in terms of calretinin positivity, and how does it differ from most carcinomas?	Almost all mesotheliomas are calretinin positive, which is negative in most carcinomas.
How does allopurinol serve as a treatment for chronic gout, and what is the mechanism of action of this medication?	Allopurinol is a treatment for chronic gout, as it inhibits xanthine oxidase.
What is a potential side effect of allopurinol, and what medical condition is associated with this side effect?	Allopurinol can result in eosinophilia.
What type of inflammatory infiltrate is commonly associated with allergic rhinitis?	Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils.
What are some atopic disorders that are commonly associated with allergic rhinitis?	Allergic rhinitis is associated with other atopic disorders, such as asthma and eczema.
Which histamine receptor is responsible for mediating allergic inflammation by histamine?	Allergic inflammation is mediated by histamine, which acts on the H1 histamine receptor.
What are some medical conditions that are commonly associated with the development of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?	Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis typically occurs in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis.
What are some medical conditions that are commonly associated with the development of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?	Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is usually seen in individuals with asthma or cystic fibrosis.
What type of medication is commonly used to treat allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and what is its mechanism of action?	Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis can be treated with corticosteroids to reduce IgE response.
What is the mechanism of action of all-trans-retinoic acid in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)?	All-trans-retinoic acid binds the altered retinoic acid receptor in APL and causes blasts to mature.
What viral infection can be treated with all-trans retinoic acid?	All-trans retinoic acid can be used to treat the measles virus.
What is the mechanism of action of β-lactam antibiotics, and why are they effective against bacteria?	All β-lactam antibiotics are bactericidal, as cell walls of bacteria are essential for growth and development.

What is the charge of all RNA/DNA molecules?	All RNA/DNA is negatively charged.
In which part of the cell do most RNA viruses replicate? Are there any exceptions?	All RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm except for influenza and retroviruses.

Which neurotransmitter do all post-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons utilize?	All post-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons utilize acetylcholine as their neurotransmitter.
Which patients with virologic evidence of chronic HCV infection should not be considered for treatment?	Patients with limited life expectancy should not be considered for treatment, despite having virologic evidence of chronic HCV infection.
What test should all patients with syncope receive to find arrhythmias?	All patients with syncope should receive an ECG to find arrhythmias.
What should be done for all patients with severe, ongoing hematemesis and altered mental status?	All patients with severe, ongoing hematemesis and altered mental status should be intubated for airway protection.
What should be done for all patients with polymyositis/dermatomyositis?	All patients with polymyositis/dermatomyositis should be screened for occult malignancy.
What should be done for all patients with cognitive impairment?	All patients with cognitive impairment must be evaluated for hypothyroidism, as this is a treatable and reversible condition.
How often should patients with cirrhosis have a screening ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein test?	Patients with cirrhosis should have a screening ultrasound every 6 months +/- alpha-fetoprotein.
What major complications should be regularly screened for in patients with cirrhosis?	Patients with cirrhosis should be regularly screened for major complications, in particular, esophageal varices and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
Who should be considered for treatment among patients with chronic HCV?	All patients with chronic HCV except those with limited life expectancy should be considered for treatment.
What medical therapy should be given to patients with carotid artery stenosis?	Patients with carotid artery stenosis should receive medical therapy with anti-platelets (aspirin) and statin.
What medications should be given to patients with acute COPD exacerbation?	Patients with acute COPD exacerbation should receive inhaled bronchodilators and PO/IV corticosteroids.
What medications should be given to patients with acute COPD exacerbation?	Patients with acute COPD exacerbation should receive inhaled bronchodilators (albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer) and systemic corticosteroids.
What should all sexually active patients under the age of 24 be screened for?	All sexually active patients under the age of 24 should be screened for chlamydia and gonorrhea.
What is the result of complement activation in all pathways and what is the function of C5 convertase?	All pathways of complement activation result in the production of C5 convertase, which converts C5 to C5a and C5b.
What is the result of complement activation in all pathways and what is the function of C3 convertase?	All pathways of complement activation result in the production of C3 convertase, which converts C3 to C3a and C3b.
What is the target of all inputs to the cerebellum and what type of cells are influenced by these inputs?	All of the inputs to the cerebellum are directed towards influencing the firing of Purkinje cells.
What type of capsids do all naked viruses have?	All naked viruses have icosahedral capsids.
What is ALL, and what type of cells make up the neoplastic accumulation in the bone marrow?	ALL is a neoplastic accumulation of lymphoblasts (>20%) in the bone marrow.
What are the common metabolic side effects caused by all HIV Protease Inhibitors?	All HIV Protease Inhibitors cause insulin resistance and dyslipidemia.
At what rate are all glucose transporters fully saturated (Tm)?	All glucose transporters are fully saturated (Tm) at a rate of ~ 375 mg/min.
What type of transmission do all GI protozoa have?	All GI protozoa have a fecal-oral transmission.
What type of bacteria can all generations of Cephalosporins be used for?	All generations of Cephalosporins can be used for Gram positive cocci.

What supplement should be given to exclusively breastfed infants within the first month of life?	All exclusively breastfed infants should be started on daily vitamin D supplements within the first month of life.
What are the recommended treatments for breast cancers that are ER+ and/or PR+?	All ER+ and/or PR+ breast cancers should receive tamoxifen/raloxifene (SERMs) or aromatase inhibitors*.
Are diastolic murmurs considered normal or abnormal?	All diastolic murmurs are considered abnormal.
What is a common characteristic of all Clostridium spp.?	All Clostridium spp. are spore-forming.
What is the aerobic/anaerobic nature and gram stain characteristic of all Clostridium spp.?	All Clostridium spp. are anaerobic, gram positive rods.
What are the common characteristics of all clostridium species?	All clostridium species are spore-forming, anaerobic, and produce toxins.
What are the characteristics of all Clostridia in terms of gram staining, spore formation, and oxygen requirements?	All Clostridia are gram positive bacilli, spore-forming, obligate anaerobes.
