What is a potential side effect of antineoplastic nucleoside analogs, such as cladribine, cytarabine, and gemcitabine?	All antineoplastic nucleoside analogs can cause myelosuppression.
Which adult patients should receive the pneumococcal vaccine?	All adult patients who are smokers should receive the pneumococcal vaccine.
How do alkylating agents work to induce cell apoptosis?	Alkylating agents donate an alkyl group that cross-links DNA, resulting in cell apoptosis.
What types of cancer are associated with the carcinogen alkylating agents?	Alkylating agents are associated with leukemia and lymphoma.
What is Alkaptonuria and what are its associated symptoms?	Alkaptonuria is a usually benign condition that may present with debilitating arthralgias.
What is the term used to describe the bluish-black discoloration of connective tissue and sclerae associated with Alkaptonuria?	The term used to describe the bluish-black discoloration of connective tissue and sclerae associated with Alkaptonuria is ochronosis.
How does alkalosis affect potassium levels in the body, and what condition may result from this shift?	Alkalosis may cause potassium to shift into cells, resulting in hypokalemia.
What is the definition of alkalemia, and what arterial pH value characterizes this condition?	Alkalemia is a condition characterized by arterial pH greater than 7.45.
What is Alexia without Agraphia, and what type of artery infarct is it associated with?	Alexia without Agraphia is a speech deficit, and it is associated with posterior cerebral artery infarct.
What are the primary medical conditions that Alemtuzumab is used to treat?	Alemtuzumab is primarily used to treat Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia and Multiple Sclerosis.
What is Alemtuzumab, and what specific component of lymphocytes does it target as an antitumor monoclonal antibody?	Alemtuzumab is an antitumor monoclonal antibody, and it targets CD52 of lymphocytes.
What specific type of leukemia can Alemtuzumab be used to treat?	Alemtuzumab can be used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
What is the term used to describe the eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions often displayed by aldosterone-secreting adenomas?	The term used to describe the eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions often displayed by aldosterone-secreting adenomas is "spironolactone bodies".
Which pump does aldosterone upregulate on the basolateral membrane of the principal cells?	Aldosterone upregulates the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral membrane of the principal cells.
What effect does aldosterone have on the activity of the epithelial Na+ channel (ENaC)?	Aldosterone leads to increased activity of the epithelial Na+ channel (ENaC).
What effect does aldosterone have on apical K+ conductance?	Aldosterone leads to increased apical K+ conductance.
What are the effects of aldosterone on Na+ and H2O reabsorption at the distal tubules and collecting duct?	Aldosterone increases Na+ and H2O reabsorption at the distal tubules and collecting duct.
What are the effects of aldosterone on K+ and H+ secretion at the distal tubules and collecting duct?	Aldosterone increases K+ and H+ secretion at the distal tubules and collecting duct.
What is Aldesleukin and what medical conditions is it used to treat?	Aldesleukin is a recombinant form of IL-2 and it is used to treat renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma.
What mechanisms do alcohols and Chlorhexidine use to achieve their antimicrobial effects?	Alcohols and Chlorhexidine achieve their antimicrobial effects by denaturing proteins and disrupting cell membranes.
What is a common metabolic abnormality seen in alcoholics during fasting?	A common metabolic abnormality seen in alcoholics during fasting is hypoglycemia.
What is alcoholic hepatitis and what are its characteristic features?	Alcoholic hepatitis is a liver disease characterized by swelling of hepatocytes with necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration.
What is alcoholic neuropathy and what type of pain does it typically cause?	Alcoholic neuropathy is a toxic neuropathy that typically results in a symmetric distal polyneuropathy with burning type pain.
What symptom related to hepatomegaly may be present in a patient with alcoholic hepatitis?	Alcoholic hepatitis may present with painful hepatomegaly.
What histological finding may be associated with alcoholic cirrhosis in early disease?	Alcoholic cirrhosis may be associated with sclerosis around central veins in early disease.
What type of cells in the anterior cerebellar vermis are damaged in alcoholic cerebellar degeneration?	Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration is caused by damage to the Purkinje cells in the anterior cerebellar vermis.
What condition may be caused by alcohol consumption, fat-rich diets, caffeine, obesity, pregnancy, smoking, and hiatal hernias?	GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) may be caused by alcohol consumption, fat-rich diets, caffeine, obesity, pregnancy, smoking, and hiatal hernias.
Which type of cancer is associated with alcohol consumption in the oropharynx and upper esophagus?	Alcohol is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and upper esophagus.
What part of viruses does alcohol disrupt?	Alcohol disrupts the envelope of viruses.
What type of kinetics does alcohol dehydrogenase operate via?	Alcohol dehydrogenase operates via zero-order kinetics.
Can alcoholic cardiomyopathy be reversed by stopping alcohol consumption?	Yes, alcohol cessation can reverse alcoholic cardiomyopathy.
What types of carcinoma can alcohol consumption lead to the development of?	Alcohol consumption can lead to the development of squamous cell carcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma.
What is the risk of osteoporosis associated with alcohol consumption and smoking?	Alcohol consumption and smoking are associated with a high risk of osteoporosis.
What is the purpose of using an albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer?	An albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer is used for acute asthma attacks.
What type of drugs are albuterol, pirbuterol, and metaproterenol?	Albuterol, pirbuterol, and metaproterenol are short-acting β2 agonists.
What are the causes of albinism?	Albinism is usually caused by decreased tyrosinase activity or defective tyrosine transport.
What health condition is albinism associated with an increased risk of?	Albinism is associated with an increased risk of skin cancer.
What is the relationship between melanocyte count and melanin production in individuals with albinism?	Albinism is associated with a normal melanocyte count with decreased melanin production.
What is the conversion process of alanine during gluconeogenesis?	Alanine is converted to pyruvate by alanine aminotransferase during the process of gluconeogenesis.
What are the possible manifestations of AL amyloidosis?	AL amyloidosis may manifest as periorbital purpura, waxy skin, and macroglossia due to protein deposits and weakening of vessel walls.
Which part of the body may be affected by AL amyloidosis and why?	AL amyloidosis may affect the joints because amyloid deposits in synovial tissues.
What is suggested by airway swelling after starting ACE-Inhibitor?	Airway swelling after starting ACE-Inhibitor is suggestive of angioedema.
Where do airway smooth muscle cells extend to in the conducting zone, and how sparse are they beyond this point?	Airway smooth muscle cells extend to the terminal bronchioles of the conducting zone, and they are sparse beyond this point.
What is the relationship between airway resistance and the radius of the airway?	Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the airway.
What is the relationship between airflow and airway resistance?	Airflow is inversely proportional to airway resistance.
What is the relationship between airflow and the pressure gradient?	Airflow is directly proportional to the pressure gradient.
What are some x-ray findings that may be seen in small bowel obstruction?	Air-fluid levels, "transition point", and epigastric distension are x-ray findings that may be seen in small bowel obstruction.
At what CD4 count are AIDS patients at risk for CMV infections?	AIDS patients are at risk for CMV infections when their CD4 count is less than 50.
What are the diagnostic criteria for AIDS?	AIDS can be diagnosed through a CD4 count of less than 200 or the presence of an AIDS-defining infection.
With which disorder is agoraphobia commonly associated?	Agoraphobia is commonly associated with panic disorder.
What is the result of aging of the organophosphate-cholinesterase complex?	Aging of the organophosphate-cholinesterase complex leads to irreversible binding.
What is the effect of aging on the shape of the ventricular septum in the heart?	Aging of the heart eventually results in the ventricular septum acquiring a sigmoid shape.
What are the recommended ages for car seats, specifically rear-facing ones?	For car seats, the recommended age for rear-facing ones is 0-4 years.
What are agents that damage DNA called?	Agents that damage DNA are called carcinogens.
What are the effects of age-related macular degeneration on vision?	Age-related macular degeneration causes distortion (metamorphopsia) and eventual loss of central vision.
What are some risk factors for molar pregnancy?	Some risk factors for molar pregnancy include age extremes <15 or >35, previous miscarriage, history of molar pregnancy, and infertility.
What is the management strategy for individuals over the age of 25 with CIN3 on colposcopy?	Individuals over the age of 25 with CIN3 on colposcopy are managed with ablation procedures such as conization or LEEP.
What is the approximation used to determine afterload?	Afterload is approximated by mean arterial pressure.
What is the system responsible for the removal of red blood cells after approximately 120 days?	The reticuloendothelial system is responsible for the removal of red blood cells after approximately 120 days.
What is the process that allows the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus to be translated into polyproteins?	After viral uncoating, the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus can be translated into 2 long polyproteins.
At which stage of spermatogenesis does the diploid sperm become haploid?	The diploid sperm becomes haploid during Meiosis I, specifically during the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte.
What is the treatment for PCOS after weight loss to regulate menstrual cycles and reduce androgenic symptoms?	After weight loss, PCOS is treated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) to regulate cycles and reduce androgenic symptoms.
What is the recommended management for a patient who has experienced a fall from height after treatment of limb injuries?	The recommended management is to perform an X-ray of the spine.
Where are the S, M, and E proteins of coronavirus transported to after translation?	After translation, the S, M, and E proteins of coronavirus are transported to the Golgi apparatus.
What becomes the main source of energy for the brain from which stores after three days of starvation?	After three days of starvation, the main source of energy for the brain becomes ketone bodies from adipose stores.
What is the relationship between the [TF/P]Na and [TF/P]osmolarity levels after the thick ascending limb?	After the thick ascending limb, both the [TF/P]Na and [TF/P]osmolarity levels are less than 1.0.
What intermediate is generated after the spliceosome has been formed in alternative splicing?	After the spliceosome has been formed in alternative splicing, a lariat-shaped (looped) intermediate is generated.
What process does the secondary spermatocyte undergo to become a spermatid?	After the secondary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes meiosis II to become a spermatid.
What can the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus be transcribed into after the replication-transcription complex is assembled?	After the replication-transcription complex is assembled, the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus can be transcribed into negative-sense RNA.
What are the two most common sites of metastasis after the regional lymph nodes?	The two most common sites of metastasis after the regional lymph nodes are the liver and lung.
What happens to the pronephros after it develops?	After the pronephros develops, it then degenerates.
What process does the primary spermatocyte undergo to become a secondary spermatocyte?	After the primary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes meiosis I to become a secondary spermatocyte.
What additional test should be done to assess for a cause after the initial presentation of an ischemic stroke?	An ECG should be done to assess for a cause after the initial presentation of an ischemic stroke.
What is the likelihood of tumor recurrence after surgical removal in multiple endocrine neoplasias?	After surgical removal, tumors in multiple endocrine neoplasias usually do recur.
What process do spermatids undergo to form spermatozoa after they have been formed from secondary spermatocytes?	Spermatids undergo spermiogenesis to form spermatozoa after they have been formed from secondary spermatocytes.
Where do T4 and T3 enter after release from iodinated thyroglobulin?	T4 and T3 enter the systemic circulation after release from iodinated thyroglobulin.
What happens after PTH binds to osteoblasts and what is the role of RANK-L and RANK in this process?	After PTH binds to osteoblasts, RANK-L is secreted which binds to RANK on osteoclasts, increasing bone resorption.
What can happen after primary infection with HSV-1 and how can stress reactivate it?	After primary infection, stress can reactivate HSV-1, which can result in herpes labialis (cold sores).
What happens to preprohormone after it has been formed and how is it transferred to the golgi apparatus?	After preprohormone has been formed, signal peptides are cleaved, producing a prohormone, which is transferred to the golgi apparatus.
What happens to the insulin receptor after it phosphorylates intracellular proteins and how is it processed?	After phosphorylating intracellular proteins, the insulin receptor is internalized (via endocytosis) and either degraded, stored, or recycled.
What happens to tissues after mucormycosis penetrates the cribriform plate and continues to proliferate in the blood vessels?	After penetrating the cribriform plate, mucormycosis continues to proliferate in the blood vessels, causing necrosis of tissues.
What is the process by which HBV produces progeny dsDNA from mRNA after it has been produced?	After mRNA is produced, HBV uses reverse transcriptase to produce progeny dsDNA from mRNA.
What happens to breast tissue after menopause?	After menopause, breast tissue undergoes atrophy.
What is the process by which Dracunculus medinensis, a helminth, induces a painful ulcer?	After maturation in the abdomen, Dracunculus medinensis migrates to the skin, where it induces a painful ulcer.
What are the potential side effects of progestin-releasing IUD insertion for patients?	After insertion of a progestin-releasing IUD, patients may experience 3-6 months of irregular bleeding due to gradual endometrial thinning.
What is the recommended next step for burn patients who require aggressive fluid resuscitation after initial stabilization?	After initial stabilization, burn patients who require aggressive fluid resuscitation should undergo urethral catheterization ASAP.
What are the common sites of metastasis for melanomas after initial spread to regional lymph nodes?	After initial spread to regional lymph nodes, melanomas commonly metastasize to the brain and lungs.
At what point in the course of ulcerative colitis is surveillance colonoscopy required, and how frequently should it be performed?	Surveillance colonoscopy is required at year 8 from diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, and should be performed every year (q1 yr).
What is the process by which fibrin, formed from fibrinogen, is cross-linked to yield a stable platelet-fibrin thrombus?	After fibrin is formed from fibrinogen, it is cross-linked by factor XIII yielding a stable platelet-fibrin thrombus.
What process occurs in the secondary oocyte after fertilization, and what is the resulting structure?	After fertilization, the secondary oocyte completes meiosis II to form an ovum.
What is the destination of LDL, macrophages, smooth muscle cells, and T-cells after they migrate following endothelial injury?	After endothelial injury, LDL, macrophages, smooth muscle cells, and T-cells migrate to the tunica intima.
What condition can cause heart failure and shock after closure of a PDA?	After closure of a PDA, severe coarctation of the aorta may cause heart failure and shock.
What complex do the proteins assemble into after cleavage of the coronavirus long polyprotein by viral protease?	After cleavage of the coronavirus long polyprotein by viral protease, the proteins assemble into the replication-transcription complex.
What kind of sensation may patients feel on the sides of an incision after a cesarean section?	After cesarean section, patients may feel a pulling sensation on the sides of an incision.
How long should children be given 400IU vitamin D after birth?	After birth, children should be given 400IU vitamin D until 1 year of age.
What should be suctioned and where should a newborn be placed after being dried and stimulated?	After being dried and stimulated, a newborn should receive suction of the oropharynx and be placed on the mother's chest.
What is the process by which free cholesterol is packaged after being absorbed from the GI tract?	After being absorbed from the GI tract, free cholesterol is packaged into a chylomicron as cholesterol ester.
What happens after aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site of the ribosome during translation, and which ribozyme catalyzes this process?	After aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site of the ribosome during translation, peptidyl transferase, a ribozyme, catalyzes peptide bond formation.
What percentage of bone mass is lost each year after the age of 30?	After age 30, slightly less than 1% of bone mass is lost each year.
What disorder is often reclassified as antisocial personality disorder after the age of 18?	After age 18, conduct disorder is often reclassified as antisocial personality disorder.
What is the immediate risk for patients after a high cervical spine injury?	After a high cervical spine injury, the immediate risk for patients is diaphragmatic paralysis.
Is ischemic injury reversible after 30 minutes of total myocardial ischemia?	No, ischemic injury is not reversible after 30 minutes of total myocardial ischemia.
What does an increased flow caught by intracranial doppler after 20 weeks of pregnancy indicate?	An increased flow caught by intracranial doppler after 20 weeks of pregnancy is indicative of fetal anemia.
What do the muscle and liver shift fuel use from glucose to after 1-3 days of starvation?	After 1-3 days of starvation, the muscle and liver shift fuel use from glucose to free fatty acids.
What is the relationship between aflatoxins and cancer?	Aflatoxins are carcinogenic and can lead to the development of hepatocellular carcinoma.
Which type of cancer is associated with aflatoxins as a carcinogen?	Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
What is a possible diagnosis for an afebrile postpartum patient with a non-erythematous, fluctuant breast mass?	A possible diagnosis for this patient could be a galactocele.
What is the net ATP produced and which shuttle is used for the aerobic metabolism of glucose in muscle?	The aerobic metabolism of glucose in muscle produces 30 net ATP via the glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle.
What are some adverse effects of tricyclic antidepressants?	Some adverse effects of tricyclic antidepressants include respiratory depression and hyperpyrexia.
What are some adverse effects of vortioxetine?	Some adverse effects of vortioxetine include anti cholinergic effects, sleep disturbances (abnormal dreams), and sexual dysfunction.
What are some adverse effects of vilazodone?	Some adverse effects of vilazodone include anti cholinergic effects and weight gain.
What are some adverse effects of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)?	Some adverse effects of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) include respiratory depression and hyperpyrexia.
What are some adverse effects of the antifungal voriconazole?	Some adverse effects of the antifungal voriconazole include blurry vision, changes in color vision, and flashes of light.
What are some adverse effects of suvorexant?	Some adverse effects of suvorexant include CNS depression, headache, dizziness, abnormal dreams, and upper respiratory tract infection.
What are some adverse effects of sirolimus (rapamycin)?	Some adverse effects of sirolimus (rapamycin) include pancytopenia and insulin resistance.
What are some adverse effects of simeprevir?	Some adverse effects of simeprevir include photosensitivity and rash.
What are some adverse effects of selective α2 antagonists, such as mirtazapine?	Some adverse effects of selective α2 antagonists, such as mirtazapine, include sedation, increased appetite, and increased serum cholesterol.
What are some adverse effects of ranolazine?	Some adverse effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and nausea.
What are some adverse effects of non-selective β-blockers?	Some adverse effects of non-selective β-blockers include exacerbation of asthma and COPD.
What are some adverse effects of long-acting β2 agonists, such as salmeterol and formoterol?	Some adverse effects of long-acting β2 agonists, such as salmeterol and formoterol, include tremor and arrhythmia.
What are some adverse effects of gabapentin?	Some adverse effects of gabapentin include sedation and ataxia.
What are some adverse effects of epoprostenol and iloprost?	Some adverse effects of epoprostenol and iloprost include flushing and jaw pain.
What are some adverse effects of electroconvulsive therapy?	Some adverse effects of electroconvulsive therapy include temporary headache, disorientation, and partial amnesia; usually resolves within 6 months.
What are some adverse effects of clonidine?	Some adverse effects of clonidine include CNS and respiratory depression.
What are some adverse effects of chronic aspirin use?	Some adverse effects of chronic aspirin use include acute renal injury, acute interstitial nephritis, and GI bleeding.
What are some adverse effects of antimuscarinics?	Some adverse effects of antimuscarinics include agitation, hallucination, and coma, especially in elderly patients.
What are some adverse effects of anti-muscarinics on the eye and its muscles (not including glands)?	Adverse effects of anti-muscarinics on the eye and its muscles (not including glands) include mydriasis and cycloplegia.
What are some adverse effects of anti-muscarinics?	Some adverse effects of anti-muscarinics include dry eyes and mouth.
In which patient population may adverse effects of 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists be more common and more severe?	Adverse effects of 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may be more common and more severe in elderly patients.
What are some adverse effects associated with sofosbuvir?	Adverse effects associated with sofosbuvir include fatigue and nausea.
What are some adverse effects associated with pseudoephedrine?	Adverse effects associated with pseudoephedrine include CNS stimulation and anxiety (mood altering).
What are some adverse effects associated with phenytoin?	Adverse effects associated with phenytoin include diplopia and nystagmus (eye complications).
What are some adverse effects associated with nitrates?	Adverse effects associated with nitrates include orthostatic hypotension and syncope due to pooling of blood in veins.
What are some adverse effects associated with levetiracetam use?	Adverse effects associated with levetiracetam use include somnolence and neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g. behavioral change).
What are some adverse effects associated with amantadine?	Adverse effects associated with amantadine include ataxia and livedo reticularis.
What are some adverse effects associated with adenosine?	Adverse effects associated with adenosine include chest pain and a sense of impending doom.
What is an adverse effect associated with Ethambutol?	An adverse effect associated with Ethambutol is optic neuritis (including red-green color blindness).
What are some potential effects of advanced rheumatoid arthritis?	Potential effects of advanced rheumatoid arthritis include fibrous ankylosis (near-fused joints) and pannus (fibrovascular synovial hyperplasia).
What is a potential risk factor for fetal growth restriction?	Advanced maternal age is a potential risk factor for fetal growth restriction.
What are some potential physical changes associated with advanced invasive ductal carcinoma tumors?	Potential physical changes associated with advanced invasive ductal carcinoma tumors include dimpling of skin or retraction of the nipple.
What is the target of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) in the body?	Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) can bind to and activate receptors of AGE (RAGE) throughout the body.
What is a potential consequence of advanced cervical carcinoma tumors invading through the anterior uterine wall?	Advanced cervical carcinoma tumors often invade through the anterior uterine wall into the bladder, blocking the ureters.
What is a potential complication for adults who have chickenpox?	Adults with chickenpox are at a greater risk of developing pneumonia.
Besides pneumonia, what is another potential complication for adults who have chickenpox?	Adults with chickenpox are at a greater risk of developing encephalitis.
What type of fungal infection are adults receiving parenteral nutrition at high risk for?	Adults receiving parenteral nutrition are at high risk for fungal infection with Candida (candidemia).
At what age should adults receive a one-time dose of the pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)?	Adults over 65 should receive a one-time dose pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23).
What symptom may be present in cases of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma due to skin infiltration?	Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma may present with cutaneous lesions (rash) due to skin infiltration.
What type of cells are affected in cases of Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL)?	Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a neoplastic proliferation of mature CD4+ T cells.
Who is most likely to present with adult T-cell leukemia and what is the TdT status of this disease?	Adult T-cell leukemia typically presents in older adults and is TdT -.
What type of cardiomyopathy is associated with the use of Adriamycin (doxorubicin)?	Adriamycin (doxorubicin) is associated with irreversible dilated cardiomyopathy.
What are the organs and tissues affected by Adrenoleukodystrophy, and how does the disease progress?	Adrenoleukodystrophy is a progressive disease that damages the adrenal glands and white matter of the brain.
What are some common symptoms associated with adrenal insufficiency, and what is the underlying cause of these symptoms?	Adrenal insufficiency may present with sugar and/or salt cravings due to decreased levels of glucocorticoids +/- mineralocorticoids.
What is the recommended imaging modality for diagnosing autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)?	Ultrasound is the recommended imaging modality for diagnosing ADPKD.
What is the role of ADP in platelet aggregation, and which receptors does it bind to on platelets?	ADP is released upon platelet degranulation and binds to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, resulting in platelet aggregation.
What is the recommended therapy for adolescents with irregular menstrual bleeding caused by anovulatory cycles?	Adolescents with irregular menstrual bleeding due to anovulatory cycles may benefit from progesterone therapy.
What medical treatment may lead to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, and what is the treatment and condition being treated?	Administration of Penicillin for Syphilis may lead to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.
What type of immunization is exemplified by the administration of vaccines?	Administration of vaccines is an example of active immunization.
What type of immunization is exemplified by the administration of toxoid?	Administration of toxoid is an example of active immunization.
What is the result of administering methotrexate to cells, and what substance builds up as a result?	Administration of methotrexate results in a build-up of DHF in cells.
What is the typical result of administering L-DOPA and Arginine, and how does it affect Growth Hormone secretion?	Administration of L-DOPA and Arginine normally leads to increased Growth Hormone secretion.
What are the potential substances that may build up in cells as a result of administering hydroxyurea?	Administration of hydroxyurea can lead to a build-up of UDP or CTP in the cell.
What type of immunization is demonstrated by the administration of antitoxin or monoclonal antibody?	Administration of antitoxin or monoclonal antibody is an example of passive immunization.
What substance accumulates in cells as a result of administering 5-fluorouracil?	Administration of 5-fluorouracil results in a build-up of dUMP in cells.
What substances are released by adipocytes, β cells, and FFAs that contribute to insulin resistance in obesity?	Adipocytes, β cells, and FFAs cause release of cytokines ("adipokines"), which contributes to insulin resistance in obesity.
Who is Adie pupil more commonly seen in, and what reflex is often lost in association with it?	Adie pupil is more commonly seen in women and is often associated with loss of the knee jerk reflex.
What is the most common cause of mechanical bowel obstruction?	Adhesions are the most common cause of mechanical bowel obstruction.
What are the common treatments for ADHD, and what additional therapy might be used in conjunction with stimulants?	ADHD is commonly treated with stimulants, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) may be used in conjunction with stimulants.
In how many settings is ADHD typically diagnosed?	ADHD is typically diagnosed in 2 or more settings.
What are the alternatives to stimulants for treating ADHD?	The alternatives to stimulants for treating ADHD are atomoxetine or clonidine.
What is the mechanism by which ADH-activated V2 receptors cause increased reabsorption of free water in the kidneys?	ADH-activated V2 receptors cause translocation of aquaporin 2 channels to the renal apical membrane, causing increased reabsorption of free water.
What is the effect of ADH on the activity of the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter?	ADH increases the activity of the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter.
What is the effect of ADH on the activity of the urea cycle?	ADH enhances the activity of the urea cycle.
What is the effect of ADH activation of the V2 receptor on vascular endothelium?	ADH activation of the V2 receptor on vascular endothelium causes release of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and factor VIII.
What is the effect of ADH activation of the V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle?	ADH activation of the V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle causes vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.
How does adequate hydration help prevent a potential side effect of Indinavir use (protease inhibitor)?	Adequate hydration helps prevent nephrolithiasis with Indinavir use (protease inhibitor).
How are adequate contractions defined in terms of Montevideo units (MVUs) generated in a 10-minute period?	Adequate contractions are defined as generation of > 200 Montevideo units (MVUs) in 10 minutes.
Which type of cells does Adenovirus enter and lyse?	Adenovirus will enter and lyse mucosal cells.
What is the structure of the DNA genome of Adenovirus?	Adenovirus has a linear DNA genome.
What are the common symptoms associated with a common cold caused by Adenovirus?	Adenovirus commonly causes the common cold, which will present with pharyngitis, coryza, and cough.
How does Adenovirus bind to cells?	Adenovirus can bind cells via hemagglutinin.
What effect does Adenosine have on conduction velocity through the AV node?	Adenosine decreases conduction velocity through the AV node.
What potential cardiac side effect is associated with Adenosine due to its direct AV node inhibition?	Adenosine may cause transient high grade heart block due to direct AV node inhibition.
What is the potential use of Adenosine as an antiarrhythmic?	Adenosine may be used as a very short acting antiarrhythmic.
What is the product of the conversion of Adenosine via the enzyme adenosine deaminase in purine salvage?	Adenosine is converted to inosine via the enzyme adenosine deaminase (purine salvage).
What is one of the major causes of autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?	Adenosine deaminase deficiency is one of the major causes of autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
How does Adenosine cause coronary dilation?	Adenosine causes coronary dilation via its action on A2 receptors.
What effect does Adenosine have on the bronchi?	Adenosine causes broncho constriction.
Which inhibitory receptors does Adenosine activate on the myocardium of the SA and AV nodes?	Adenosine activates inhibitory A1 receptors on the myocardium of the SA and AV nodes.
What are the typical symptoms of Adenomyosis in multiparous women over the age of 40?	Adenomyosis typically causes dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding in multiparous women > 40 years of age.
What is the typical management approach for Adenomyosis?	Adenomyosis is managed with hysterectomy.
How does Adenomyosis grossly present in the uterus?	Adenomyosis grossly presents with a uniformly enlarged, soft, globular uterus.
How are Adenomatous polyps classified in terms of neoplasia?	Adenomatous polyps are considered neoplastic.
How does the malignant potential of Adenomatous polyps with tubular histology compare to those with villous histology (tubular or villous)?	Adenomatous polyps with a tubular histology have less malignant potential than villous histology (tubular or villous).
What is the pathway by which adenomatous colonic polyps may progress to adenocarcinoma?	Adenomatous colonic polyps may progress to adenocarcinoma via the adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
How would you describe the malignant potential of adenomatous colonic polyps?	Adenomatous colonic polyps are benign with some malignant potential.
Where is adenocarcinoma of the lung typically located?	Adenocarcinoma of the lung is peripherally located.
What are the histological characteristics of adenocarcinoma of the lung?	Adenocarcinoma of the lung is characterized by cuboidal to low columnar cells with hyperchromatic prominent nuclei.
What is the most common precursor lesion for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus?	Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus most commonly arises from pre-existing Barrett esophagus.
What type of metaplasia in response to chronic inflammation may lead to the development of adenocarcinoma of the bladder?	Adenocarcinoma of the bladder may arise from cystitis glandularis, which is a columnar metaplasia in response to chronic inflammation.
Where in the bladder does adenocarcinoma typically develop when it arises from a urachal remnant?	Adenocarcinoma arising from a urachal remnant develops at the dome of the bladder.
What substance can be added to a culture medium to degrade any naked DNA present and inhibit bacterial transformation?	Addition of DNAase will degrade any naked DNA present in a culture medium, inhibiting any bacterial transformation.
What symptom related to androgen production can be present in women with Addison's disease?	Addison's disease presents with irregular menses in women due to decreased androgen production.
What symptoms related to androgen levels can be present in females with Addison's disease?	Addison's disease may present with decreased pubic/axillary hair and libido in females due to decreased levels of androgens.
What is the target of adalimumab, a monoclonal antibody?	Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF-α.
What is the level of activity of Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir against EBV?	Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir have weak activity against EBV.
In what type of patients are Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir used for prophylaxis against HSV/VZV?	Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir are used for HSV/VZV prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients.
What types of infections are Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir used to treat?	Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir are used to treat active VZV and HSV infections.
What type of analogs are Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir?	Acyclovir, Famciclovir, and Valacyclovir are all guanosine analogs.
How does Acyclovir triphosphate inhibit viral replication?	Acyclovir triphosphate incorporates into replicating viral DNA, inhibiting DNA-dependent DNA polymerase.
What process must Acyclovir undergo to reach its activated nucleotide form?	Acyclovir must be phosphorylated three times by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form.
What is Acyclovir monophosphate eventually converted to by cellular kinases?	Acyclovir monophosphate is eventually converted to acyclovir triphosphate by cellular kinases.
In what type of cells and by what enzyme is Acyclovir converted to acyclovir monophosphate?	Acyclovir is converted to acyclovir monophosphate by thymidine kinase in virus-infected cells.
What are the renal side effects that can be caused by Acyclovir?	Acyclovir can cause interstitial nephritis and crystalline nephropathy as renal side effects.
What condition is suggested by the presence of acute-onset focal neurological findings, fever, and behavioral changes in a young patient?	The presence of acute-onset focal neurological findings, fever, and behavioral changes in a young patient is suggestive of HSV encephalitis.
What are the common presenting symptoms of acute pericarditis?	Acute pericarditis commonly presents with sharp pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward.
What imaging finding may suggest the presence of acute pyelonephritis?	Acute pyelonephritis may be characterized by striated parenchymal enhancement of the kidney on CT.
What are the common presenting symptoms of acute epiglottitis?	Acute epiglottitis often presents with acute-onset fever, drooling, and dysphagia with respiratory distress.
What are the common presenting symptoms of acute closed-angle glaucoma?	Acute closed-angle glaucoma results in a painful, red eye that is fixed and mid-dilated.
What are the common presenting symptoms of acute cholecystitis?	Acute cholecystitis presents with RUQ pain that often radiates to the right shoulder/scapula.
What are the typical characteristics of pain in acute cholecystitis?	Acute cholecystitis presents with RUQ pain that often radiates to the right scapula.
What is the pathophysiology behind acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?	Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is caused by diffuse alveolar damage with impairment of the alveolar-capillary interface.
What is the definition of acute pericarditis?	Acute pericarditis is defined as inflammation of the pericardium.
What are the typical symptoms of acute myeloid leukemia?	Acute myeloid leukemia presents with fever, bone pain, weakness and fatigue.
What are the possible clinical manifestations of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?	Acute lymphoblastic leukemia may present with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy due to infiltration by leukemic cells.
What are the common symptoms of acute epiglottitis?	Acute epiglottitis presents with high fever, sore throat, and drooling with dysphagia.
What type of glaucoma is considered a true ophthalmic emergency?	Acute closed-angle glaucoma is considered a true ophthalmic emergency.
What are the typical symptoms of acute vitamin A toxicity?	Acute vitamin A toxicity presents with nausea, vomiting, vertigo, and blurred vision.
What is a potential consequence of acute tubular necrosis?	Acute tubular necrosis may cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
What is a potential cause of acute tubular necrosis?	Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by radio-contrast dyes.
What is a potential cause of acute tubular necrosis that can occur with crush injuries?	Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by myoglobinuria, which can occur with crush injuries.
What is a potential cause of acute tubular necrosis that is associated with oxalate crystals in the urine?	Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by ingestion of ethylene glycol, which is associated with oxalate crystals in the urine.
What is a potential cause of acute tubular necrosis that can occur with tumor lysis syndrome?	Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by high levels of uric acid (e.g. tumor lysis syndrome).
What is a potential heavy metal that can cause acute tubular necrosis?	Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by heavy metals such as lead.
What is a common supportive measure that is often required for patients with acute tubular necrosis due to electrolyte imbalances?	Acute tubular necrosis is reversible but often requires supportive dialysis due to electrolyte imbalances (e.g. hypokalemia).
What are the two histological characteristics that are used to describe acute tubular necrosis?	Acute tubular necrosis is characterized histologically by loss of nuclei and detachment of tubular cells from the basement membrane.
What are the two types of injury that can cause acute tubular necrosis?	Acute tubular necrosis is caused by ischemic or nephrotoxic injury.
Which part of the kidney is most commonly affected by acute tubular necrosis due to nephrotoxic injury?	Acute tubular necrosis due to nephrotoxic injury most commonly affects the proximal tubule.
What is a common precursor to acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury?	Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury is often preceded by prerenal azotemia.
What is the cause of acute tubular necrosis when it is due to nephrotoxicity?	Acute tubular necrosis caused by nephrotoxicity is due to toxic substances.
What is the cause of acute tubular necrosis when it is due to ischemia?	Acute tubular necrosis caused by ischemia is due to decreased renal blood flow.
What is a common acute toxicity that can occur as a result of amphotericin B administration?	Acute toxicities of amphotericin B administration include fever, chills, headache, and hypo-tension.
What are the acute symptoms associated with Chagas disease?	Acute symptoms of Chagas disease include chagoma and Romaña's sign.
What is the cause of acute subdural hematomas and how do they appear on CT scans?	Acute subdural hematomas arise with trauma and appear hyper-dense on CT.
What is acute scleroderma renal crisis, and what is the recommended treatment for this condition?	Acute scleroderma renal crisis leads to malignant HTN and is treated with ACE inhibitor.
What is the underlying cause of acute rheumatic fever, and how is it related to bacterial infections?	Acute rheumatic fever is immune-mediated, not a direct effect of bacteria.
What is the specific type of bacterial infection that leads to the development of acute rheumatic fever?	Acute rheumatic fever is a consequence of pharyngeal infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci.
What is the potential long-term complication of acute rheumatic fever, and how does it relate to the heart?	Acute rheumatic fever attack usually resolves, but may progress to chronic rheumatic heart disease.
What is the typical radiographic appearance on a chest X-ray of a patient with acute respiratory distress syndrome?	Acute respiratory distress syndrome presents with a "white-out" appearance on CXR.
What type of lung disease can result from acute respiratory distress syndrome?	Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a cause of interstitial restrictive lung disease.
What is a common symptom that is often present in patients with acute renal infarction?	Acute renal infarction is accompanied by hypertension.
What are some common findings in the urine of patients with acute pyelonephritis?	Acute pyelonephritis may present with white blood cells in the urine +/- white blood cell casts.
What is the hallmark feature of acute pyelonephritis in terms of renal pathology?	Acute pyelonephritis is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration of the renal interstitium.
Which part of the kidney is primarily affected in acute pyelonephritis and which structures are relatively spared?	Acute pyelonephritis affects the cortex of the kidney with relative sparing of glomeruli/vessels.
What are some common symptoms of acute prostatitis?	Acute prostatitis often presents with dysuria and fever/chills.
What are the two main treatments used for acute promyelocytic leukemia?	Acute promyelocytic leukemia is treated with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA), a vitamin A derivative, as well as arsenic.
What is the name of the vitamin A derivative used to treat acute promyelocytic leukemia?	The vitamin A derivative used to treat acute promyelocytic leukemia is called all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).
What is the hallmark sign of acute pericarditis?	The hallmark sign of acute pericarditis is a pericardial fluid accumulation.
What is a common complication of acute pericarditis?	A common complication of acute pericarditis is pericardial effusion.
What type of necrosis does acute pancreatitis result in?	Acute pancreatitis results in liquefactive necrosis of the pancreas.
What type of necrosis does acute pancreatitis result in the peripancreatic fat?	Acute pancreatitis results in fat necrosis of the peripancreatic fat.
What is a potential complication of acute pancreatitis due to pancreatic hemorrhage and fluid sequestration?	Acute pancreatitis may progress to shock, due to pancreatic hemorrhage and fluid sequestration.
What electrolyte abnormalities may be present in a patient with acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis may present with hypo-calcemia/magnesemia.
What may cause absent bowel sounds in a patient with acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis may present with absent bowel sounds due to ileus.
What is a potential complication of acute pancreatitis that is formed by fibrous tissue surrounding liquefactive necrosis and pancreatic enzymes?	Acute pancreatitis may be complicated by pancreatic pseudocysts, which are formed by fibrous tissue surrounding liquefactive necrosis and pancreatic enzymes.
What are the two most common causes of acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis is most commonly due to alcohol or gallstones.
What is the effect of leaning forward on the characteristic epigastric pain that is caused by acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis causes epigastric pain radiating to the back that is relieved by leaning forward.
How can acute pancreatitis lead to third spacing?	Acute pancreatitis can cause third spacing through increased capillary permeability.
What condition can be indicated by high levels of AST, ALT, and ALP in conjunction with acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis and high AST/ALT/ALP = gallstones.
What imaging modality is typically used to diagnose acute pancreatitis?	Acute pancreatitis is typically diagnosed using a CT scan with contrast.
What type of infection commonly precedes the development of acute otitis media?	Acute otitis media often follows an upper respiratory infection.
In what age group does acute myeloid leukemia (AML) most commonly occur?	Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) most commonly arises in older adults, with a median onset age of 65 years.
What are the treatment options for acute and chronic multiple sclerosis (MS)?	Acute MS is managed with corticosteroids, while chronic MS is managed with interferon β, glatiramer, or natalizumab.
What is a potential stool presentation in a patient with acute mesenteric ischemia?	Acute mesenteric ischemia may present with a stool that appears like "currant jelly".
What are some potential complications of acute mesenteric ischemia?	Acute mesenteric ischemia is associated with transmural infarction and perforation, which may cause septic shock.
What is the most common cause of bacterial infection in acute mastitis?	Acute mastitis is due to bacterial infection of the breast, most commonly with Staphylococcus aureus.
What are some options for acute management of migraine headaches?	Acute management of migraine headaches includes NSAIDs, triptans, or dihydroergotamine.
What are some options for acute management of cluster headaches?	Acute management of cluster headaches includes sumatriptan and 100% O2.
What are some common symptoms of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia?	Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia usually presents with easy bruising/bleeding, fatigue and fever.
How is Acute lymphoblastic leukemia subclassified based on surface markers?	Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is subclassified into B-ALL and T-ALL based on surface markers.
What type of symptoms are commonly associated with acute lithium toxicity?	Acute lithium toxicity presents with GI symptoms.
What are the side effects associated with acute and chronic lithium toxicity?	Acute lithium toxicity is associated with GI side effects, while chronic lithium toxicity is associated with neurologic side effects.
What is the typical association between acute leukemias and circulating white blood cells (WBCs)?	Acute leukemias are typically associated with increased circulating WBCs.
What are the acute symptoms that may be associated with acute leukemia?	Acute leukemia may present acutely with symptoms of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and/or neutropenia.
What are the nonspecific symptoms that may be associated with acute leukemia, in addition to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and/or neutropenia?	Acute leukemia may present acutely with nonspecific symptoms such as bone pain, as well as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and/or neutropenia.
How is acute leukemia subdivided based on the phenotype of the blasts?	Acute leukemia is subdivided into ALL or AML based on the phenotype of the blasts.
How is acute leukemia defined in terms of the percentage of blasts in the bone marrow?	Acute leukemia is defined as a neoplastic proliferation of blasts greater than 20% in the bone marrow.
What is the percentage of blasts on bone marrow biopsy that defines acute leukemia as a neoplastic proliferation?	Acute leukemia is defined as a neoplastic proliferation of blasts greater than 25% on bone marrow biopsy.
What are the metabolic consequences of acute kidney injury?	Acute kidney injury causes a metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia.
What type of acidosis can be caused by acute kidney injury?	Acute kidney injury can cause a non-anion gap or anion-gap acidosis.
What are the metabolic and potassium consequences of acute kidney injury and loop diuretic use?	Acute kidney injury results in metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia, while loop diuretic use results in metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.
What are the clinical manifestations of acute kidney injury, depending on the underlying cause (pre-renal, intrarenal, or postrenal)?	Acute kidney injury (pre-renal, intrarenal, or postrenal) leads to increased serum creatinine and/or decreased urine output.
What is the potential complication of acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis may progress to renal papillary necrosis.
What type of urinary casts may be present in a patient with acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis may present with WBC casts in the urine.
What are the potential laboratory and clinical findings in a patient with acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis may present with increased serum BUN and Cr with decreased urine output.
What are the potential symptoms of acute interstitial nephritis that may occur days to weeks after starting a drug?	Acute interstitial nephritis may present with fever and rash, days to weeks after starting a drug.
What type of hypersensitivity reaction may mediate acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis may be mediated by a type I or IV hypersensitivity reaction.
What types of diseases are less commonly associated with acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to autoimmune diseases (e.g. Sjögren's syndrome, SLE, sarcoidosis).
What types of conditions are less commonly associated with acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to systemic infections (e.g. mycoplasma).
What is the histological characteristic of acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis is characterized histologically by inflammatory infiltrate in the connective tissue between renal tubules.
What are the classic laboratory findings associated with acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis is associated with hematuria and pyuria (classically eosinophils).
What type of AKI is acute interstitial nephritis a less common cause of?	Acute interstitial nephritis is a less common cause of intrinsic AKI.
What are the two parts of the kidney that are affected by acute interstitial nephritis?	Acute interstitial nephritis affects the interstitium and the renal tubules.
What is the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome?	The most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy.
What are the mediators that typically result in resolution and healing during acute inflammation?	IL-10 and TGF-β are the mediators that typically result in resolution and healing during acute inflammation.
What is the term used to describe acute inflammation that is surrounded by fibrosis?	Acute inflammation that is surrounded by fibrosis is called abscess formation.
What are the two main characteristics of tissue during acute inflammation?	The two main characteristics of tissue during acute inflammation are the presence of edema and neutrophils.
What condition is characterized by acute inflammation causing follicular rupture, leading to transient hyperthyroidism?	Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis is the condition characterized by acute inflammation causing follicular rupture, leading to transient hyperthyroidism.
What are the four main triggers that can cause acute inflammation?	The four main triggers that can cause acute inflammation are infection, tissue necrosis, trauma, and foreign bodies.
How is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction differentiated from febrile non-hemolytic reaction?	Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is differentiated from febrile non-hemolytic reaction by the presence of a positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test.
Where does acute gout commonly manifest?	Acute gout commonly manifests in the 1st metatarsal.
What types of food consumption may lead to acute gout?	Acute gout may occur with red meat or seafood consumption, which are foods rich in purines.
What are some foods or drinks that may cause acute gout due to their purine content?	Acute gout may occur with red meat, alcohol, or seafood consumption, which are rich in purines.
Which joint is commonly affected in acute gout and what is the medical term for it?	Acute gout classically presents as a painful MTP joint of the big toe, which is also known as podagra.
What is a common cause of acute gastritis and what are the typical ulcer presentations associated with it?	Acute gastritis may arise with shock, which presents as multiple stress ulcers secondary to ischemia.
How does the use of NSAIDs relate to the occurrence of acute gastritis and what is the mechanism behind it?	Acute gastritis may arise with NSAID use due to decreased PGE2.
What is a potential cause of acute gastritis and how does it lead to mucosal damage?	Acute gastritis may arise with severe burns due to hypovolemia, which causes mucosal ischemia.
What is a potential cause of acute gastritis and how does it lead to an increase in H+ production?	Acute gastritis may arise with increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which increases vagal stimulation, leading to an increase in H+ production.
What is the recommended management for acute fatty liver of pregnancy?	Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is managed with immediate delivery.
What are the possible clinical manifestations of acute epiglottitis?	Acute epiglottitis may present with muffled voice and inspiratory stridor.
What are the possible clinical manifestations of acute epiglottitis?	Acute epiglottitis may present with a muffled ("hot potato") voice and inspiratory stridor.
What is the potential complication associated with acute epiglottitis?	Acute epiglottitis is associated with the risk of acute airway obstruction.
What are the common clinical manifestations of acute endometritis?	Acute endometritis presents as fever, abnormal uterine bleeding, and pelvic pain.
What are the possible causes of acute endometritis?	Acute endometritis is associated with retained products of conception or foreign bodies.
What is the potential complication of acute dystonia?	Acute dystonia can lead to laryngospasm, requiring intubation.
What is the usual management approach for acute diverticulitis?	Acute diverticulitis is managed with antibiotics.
What are the possible triggers of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis?	Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis can be triggered by infection with chickenpox or measles, or by the rabies or smallpox vaccines.
What are the typical clinical manifestations of acute disseminated (postinfectious) encephalomyelitis?	Acute disseminated (postinfectious) encephalomyelitis typically presents with rapidly progressive multifocal neurologic symptoms and altered mental status.
What is the recommended treatment for acute decompensated heart failure and hypoxemia/respiratory distress?	Noninvasive ventilation is the recommended treatment for acute decompensated heart failure and hypoxemia/respiratory distress.
What is the cause of plaque rupture leading to acute coronary syndrome (unstable angina/MI)?	Acute coronary syndrome (unstable angina/MI) usually occurs due to plaque rupture, which is caused by an imbalance of metalloproteinase activity.
What is the recommended treatment for acute complications of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia?	Acute complications of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia are typically treated with plasmapheresis, which helps to remove IgM from the serum.
Who is most commonly affected by acute colonic ischemia?	Acute colonic ischemia most commonly occurs in elderly individuals.
What effect can acute colonic ischemia have on bowel sounds?	Acute colonic ischemia may cause diminished or absent bowel sounds.
What is a common trigger for acute chest syndrome in patients with sickle cell anemia?	Acute chest syndrome in patients with sickle cell anemia is often precipitated by pneumonia.
What is the typical causative agent of acute bacterial endocarditis?	Acute bacterial endocarditis is typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
What is a potential complication of acute aortic dissection, and what are its associated signs and symptoms?	Acute aortic dissection may lead to new-onset heart failure with signs and symptoms of cardiogenic shock.
What are the typical symptoms of acute angle-closure glaucoma?	Acute angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss with "halos" around lights.
What is the prognosis for individuals with acute and late onset schizophrenia?	Individuals with acute and late onset schizophrenia have a good prognosis.
What effect does acute alcohol use have on CYP-450?	Acute alcohol use leads to inhibition of CYP-450.
What are the acute adverse effects associated with aspirin use?	The acute adverse effects of aspirin use are gastric ulceration and tinnitus (CN VIII) (ears ringing).
How is acute (primary) HIV infection diagnosed?	Acute (primary) HIV infection is diagnosed with HIV RNA (viral load).
What are the characteristic symptoms of acute (lactational) mastitis?	Acute (lactational) mastitis presents as a warm, erythematous breast with purulent nipple discharge.
What is the association between acute (lactational) mastitis and breastfeeding?	Acute (lactational) mastitis is associated with breastfeeding.
What is the treatment for acute (< 1 month), uncomplicated back pain such as lumbar strain?	Acute (< 1 month), uncomplicated back pain (e.g. lumbar strain) is treated with NSAIDs/acetaminophen.
What does an acute "popping" sensation followed by "clicking" during McMurray's test suggest?	An acute "popping" sensation followed by "clicking" during McMurray's test is suggestive of meniscal tear.
How much cervical dilation is expected during the active phase of labor every 2 hours?	The active phase of labor normally progresses > 1 cm every 2 hours.
What method is used to detect active coronavirus infection?	Active coronavirus infection is detected using nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).
How can active coronavirus infection be diagnosed, and what can be detected to confirm the diagnosis?	Active coronavirus infection can be diagnosed by detecting antigens, such as nucleocapsid proteins.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on systemic vascular resistance (SVR)?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors causes decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
What is the effect of activating β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors on lipolysis and the release of fatty acids?	Activating β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors stimulates lipolysis and the release of fatty acids.
What is the effect of activating β1 adrenergic receptors on cardiac output?	Activating β1 adrenergic receptors results in increased cardiac output.
What is the effect of activating β adrenergic receptors on intracellular cAMP levels?	Activating β adrenergic receptors causes increased levels of intracellular cAMP.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on gluconeogenesis in the liver?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on insulin release in pancreatic islet cells?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors on pancreatic islet cells causes increased insulin release.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies on aqueous humor production?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies causes increased aqueous humor production.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on diastolic blood pressure?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors causes decreased diastolic blood pressure.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on coronary and skeletal muscle vasculature?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors causes coronary and skeletal muscle vasodilation.
What is the effect of activating β2 adrenergic receptors on bronchi?	Activating β2 adrenergic receptors causes bronchodilation.
What is the effect of activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the SA node on heart rate?	Activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the SA node causes increased heart rate.
What is the effect of activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the juxtaglomerular cells on renin release?	Activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the juxtaglomerular cells causes increased renin release.
What is the effect of activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the cardiac myocytes on cardiac contractility?	Activating β1 adrenergic receptors on the cardiac myocytes causes increased cardiac contractility.
What is the effect of activating α2 adrenergic receptors on lipolysis and release of fatty acids?	Activating α2 adrenergic receptors inhibits lipolysis and release of fatty acids.
What is the effect of activating α2 adrenergic receptors on pancreatic islet cells on insulin release?	Activating α2 adrenergic receptors on pancreatic islet cells causes decreased insulin release.
What is the effect of activating α2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies on aqueous humor production?	Activating α2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies causes decreased aqueous humor production.
What is the effect of activating α2 adrenergic receptors on platelet aggregation?	Activating α2 adrenergic receptors causes increased platelet aggregation.
Which sympathetic receptor activation leads to increased lipolysis, increased thermogenesis in skeletal muscle, and increased bladder relaxation?	The activation of β3 sympathetic receptor leads to increased lipolysis, increased thermogenesis in skeletal muscle, and increased bladder relaxation.
Which adrenergic receptor activation increases the production of insulin?	The activation of β2 adrenergic receptor increases the production of insulin.
What is the potential urinary effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor may cause urinary retention.
What is the effect of activating the α2 adrenergic receptor on the levels of intracellular cAMP?	Activation of the α2 adrenergic receptor causes decreased levels of intracellular cAMP.
What is the effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor on mean arterial pressure (MAP)?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor increases mean arterial pressure (MAP).
What is the effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor on the intestinal and bladder sphincter muscles?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes contraction of the intestinal and bladder sphincter muscles.
What is the effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor on venous vessels?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes veno constriction.
What is the effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor on blood vessels?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes vaso constriction.
What is the effect of activating the α1 adrenergic receptor on the pupillary dilator muscle?	Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes contraction of the pupillary dilator muscle, causing mydriasis.
What is the effect of activating the H1 histamine receptor?	Activation of the H1 histamine receptor may cause pain, pruritus, and vasodilation.
What is the effect of activating the presynaptic α2 adrenergic receptors?	Activation of the presynaptic α2 adrenergic receptors can inhibit neurotransmitter release.
What is the effect of activating the inflammasome?	Activation of the inflammasome leads to increased production of IL-1B and IL-18.
What is required for activation of the coagulation cascade?	Activation of the coagulation cascade requires Ca2+ ions derived from platelet dense granules.
What surface of platelets is required for activation of the coagulation cascade?	Activation of the coagulation cascade requires the phospholipid surface of platelets.
What effect does activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine have on K+ current?	Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine increases outward K+ current.
What effect does activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine have on Ca2+ current?	Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine decreases inward Ca2+ current.
What substance degrades fibrin clots when activated?	Activated plasmin degrades fibrin clots.
Which enzyme does activated vitamin K act as a co-factor for?	Activated vitamin K acts as a co-factor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase.
What are the names of the anti-inflammatory cytokines produced by activated regulatory T cells?	The anti-inflammatory cytokines produced by activated regulatory T cells are IL-10 and TGF-β.
How is activated Ras regulated?	Activated Ras is regulated by its own intrinsic GTPase activity.
What is the name of the complex that sends signals to the nucleus when Ras is activated?	The complex that sends signals to the nucleus when Ras is activated is called Ras GTP complex.
What condition is suggested by activated protein C resistance?	Activated protein C resistance is suggestive of factor V Leiden.
What is the pathway of action potential spread in the heart from the SA node?	The action potentials spread from the SA node to the AV node and right/left atria, simultaneously.
Where are action potentials in the heart usually initiated and what is its function?	Action potentials in the heart are usually initiated in the SA node, which serves as the pacemaker.
What is the mechanism of action of Actinomycin D and how does it block DNA and RNA synthesis?	Actinomycin D intercalates into DNA, blocking DNA and RNA synthesis.
Which pediatric tumors can be treated with Actinomycin D?	Actinomycin D can be used to treat pediatric tumors such as Wilms tumor, Ewing sarcoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.
What is Actinomycin D (aka Dactinomycin) and how does it work as an antineoplastic antibiotic?	Actinomycin D (aka Dactinomycin) is an antineoplastic antibiotic that works by preventing transcription through the process of DNA intercalation.
What do Actinomyces-like organisms look like on a pap smear and how are they arranged?	Actinomyces-like organisms appear as clusters of basophilic thin filaments that resemble "cotton candy" on a pap smear.
Where is Actinomyces considered normal flora?	Actinomyces is considered normal flora of the oral cavity, GI and GU tracts.
In what setting is Actinomyces commonly transmitted?	Actinomyces is commonly transmitted in the setting of dental procedures.
What is Actinomyces infection of the GU tract in women commonly associated with?	Actinomyces infection of the GU tract in women is commonly associated with intrauterine devices (IUDs).
What specific tumor suppressor gene mutation is strongly associated with Actinic keratosis?	Actinic keratosis is strongly associated with a mutation in the p53 tumor suppressor gene.
What type of hormone is ACTH?	ACTH is a polypeptide hormone.
What is the mechanism by which ACTH increases steroid hormone synthesis?	ACTH increases steroid hormone synthesis via stimulation of the enzyme cholesterol desmolase, thus increasing the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone.
What type of heart failure may be caused by ACS, dilated cardiomyopathy, valvular insufficiency, and L-R shunts?	ACS, dilated cardiomyopathy, valvular insufficiency, and L-R shunts may cause systolic heart failure.
What is a potential symptom of acromegaly related to tongue enlargement and upper airway obstruction?	Acromegaly may present with obstructive sleep apnea due to tongue enlargement and upper airway obstruction.
What is a potential consequence of acromegaly related to the growth of visceral organs?	Acromegaly may cause growth of visceral organs, leading to dysfunction.
What physical characteristics are associated with acromegaly, including a large tongue with deep furrows and a deep voice?	Acromegaly is characterized by a large tongue with deep furrows and a deep voice.
What is a potential metabolic consequence of acromegaly, including increased insulin resistance?	Acromegaly is associated with increased insulin resistance.
What parts of the body are commonly affected by bone enlargement in individuals with acromegaly?	Acromegaly causes enlarged bones in the hands, feet, and jaw.
What is the diagnostic test used to confirm a diagnosis of acromegaly, which involves measuring serum IGF-1 levels?	Acromegaly is diagnosed with serum IGF-1.
What are some potential causes of acquired GnRH deficiency (secondary amenorrhea), and what factors can contribute to this condition?	Acquired GnRH deficiency (secondary amenorrhea) may be due to severe stress, excessive exercise, and anorexia.
What is the prevalence of acoustic neuromas among elderly individuals?	Acoustic neuromas are common among the elderly.
What is the defining feature of acidemia, and how is it measured?	Acidemia is characterized by arterial pH levels below 7.35, which is how it is measured.
What are the primary physical characteristics associated with achondroplasia, and how do they differ from those of typical human development?	Achondroplasia is characterized by short (rhizomelic) extremities and a relatively large head, which differ from the typical human development.
What physical features are commonly associated with achondroplasia, and how do they differ from typical human development?	Achondroplasia is characterized by short extremities and a relatively large head, which differ from typical human development.
What is the primary issue with bone growth that characterizes achondroplasia?	Achondroplasia is characterized by failure of longitudinal bone growth.
How is abnormal uterine bleeding characterized and what are the two types of abnormal uterine bleeding?	Abnormal uterine bleeding is characterized as either heavy menstrual bleeding (AUB HMB) or intermenstrual bleeding (AUB IMB).
On what type of MHC are abnormal proteins produced endogenously by cells typically expressed?	Abnormal proteins produced endogenously by cells are typically expressed on MHC I.
What causes abnormal prenatal development of the acetabulum and what is the medical term for it?	Abnormal prenatal development of the acetabulum is caused by excessive uterine packing, also known as uterine constraint.
What condition is suggested by the presence of abnormal melanocyte migration and a white forelock on the scalp?	The presence of abnormal melanocyte migration and a white forelock on the scalp is suggestive of piebaldism.
How does abnormal expression of miRNAs contribute to certain medical conditions, and what is an example of such a condition?	Abnormal expression of miRNAs contributes to certain malignancies, such as by silencing an mRNA from a tumor suppressor gene.
What should be suspected in a patient with a history of recent ciprofloxacin treatment and watery diarrhea?	Pseudomembranous colitis should be suspected in a patient with a history of recent ciprofloxacin treatment and watery diarrhea.
What medication may result in a patient having a CH2O = 0?	Loop diuretics may result in a patient having a CH2O = 0.
What condition may be present in a patient who is receiving bevacizumab and develops abdominal pain?	A GI perforation may be present in a patient who is receiving bevacizumab and develops abdominal pain.
What is the suspected diagnosis and treatment for a patient who presents with uterine bleeding and a precancerous endometrial biopsy?	The suspected diagnosis is endometrial hyperplasia and the treatment is high-dose progesterone.
Which anti-diarrheal μ-opioid agonist is more likely to cause addiction in a patient?	Diphenoxylate is more likely to cause addiction in a patient as it is known to cross the blood-brain barrier.
What is the recommended course of action when a patient experiences bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury?	In case of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, an urgent tracheostomy is recommended.
What are the typical symptoms of a patent urachus?	A patent urachus typically presents as a straw-colored urine discharge from the umbilicus with erythema around the area.
What are the two conditions that a patent processus vaginalis can predispose an individual to?	A patent processus vaginalis can predispose an individual to Hydrocele and Indirect inguinal hernia.
What is the typical presentation of a partially involuted thyroglossal duct?	A partially involuted thyroglossal duct may present as a pyramidal lobe on the thyroid.
What is the result of p57 immunostaining in a partial hydatidiform mole?	A partial hydatidiform mole is p57 positive on immunostaining.
Where are cells scraped from during a pap smear?	During a pap smear, cells are scraped from the transformation zone of the cervix.
What is the term used to describe a painless, palpable gallbladder in pancreatic adenocarcinoma?	A painless, palpable gallbladder in pancreatic adenocarcinoma is also known as the Courvoisier sign.
What condition is suggested by the presence of a painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy?	The presence of a painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum.
What aspect of genetics can be studied using a Northern blot?	A Northern blot is useful for studying gene expression.
What is the typical range for a normal white blood cell (WBC) count?	A normal WBC count is approximately 5 - 10 K/μL.
What is the typical range for a normal reticulocyte count?	A normal reticulocyte count is between 1 to 2%.
What is considered a normal result for a 1-hour glucose challenge test?	A normal 1-hour glucose challenge test is <140 mg/dL.
What aspects of fetal heart activity does a nonstress test measure to assess fetal well-being?	A nonstress test assesses the fetal well-being by measuring the heart for both accelerations and variability.
What is a common, nonspecific symptom of a deficiency in vitamin B9 (folate)?	A nonspecific symptom of vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is glossitis.
What is a common, non-specific symptom of pituitary adenoma that occurs due to mass effect?	A non-specific symptom of pituitary adenoma is headache (due to mass effect).
What are the requirements for prescribing isotretinoin (vitamin A)?	A negative pregnancy test and two forms of contraception are required before isotretinoin (vitamin A) is prescribed.
What does a negative likelihood ratio of less than 0.1 indicate about a medical test?	A negative likelihood ratio < 0.1 indicates a highly sensitive test.
What is the effect of a negative inotropic effect on heart contractility?	A negative inotropic effect decreases heart contractility.
What are the effects of a negative inotropic agent on cardiac output and right atrial pressure?	A negative inotropic agent causes the cardiac output to decrease and right atrial pressure to increase.
What is the effect of a negative dromotropic effect on conduction velocity through the AV node?	A negative dromotropic effect decreases conduction velocity through the AV node.
What is the effect of a negative chronotropic effect on heart rate?	A negative chronotropic effect decreases heart rate.
Where should a needle be positioned for a tension pneumothorax and what is the reference point for this placement?	A needle should be positioned for a tension pneumothorax at the 5th intercostal space along the anterior-axillary line.
What is the name of the necrotizing skin condition of diabetes mellitus that is more commonly seen in women?	The necrotizing skin condition of diabetes mellitus that occurs more commonly in women is called necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.
What is the effect of a mutation in the promoter on the level of gene transcription?	A mutation in the promoter commonly results in a dramatic decrease in the level of gene transcription.
What is the consequence of a mutation in Rb on the regulation of cell cycle progression?	A mutation in Rb results in constitutively free E2F, leading to uncontrolled cell cycle progression.
What is the most likely pathology indicated by a murmur with an opening snap?	A murmur with an opening snap is most likely indicative of mitral stenosis.
What is the pathology indicated by a murmur with a midsystolic click?	A murmur with a midsystolic click is indicative of mitral valve prolapse.
What is the possible location where a murmur due to mitral regurgitation may radiate?	A murmur due to mitral regurgitation may radiate to the axilla.
What is the possible location where a murmur due to aortic stenosis may radiate?	A murmur due to aortic stenosis may radiate to the carotid arteries.
What is the possible location where a murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation may radiate?	A murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation may radiate to the right sternal border.
At which heart sound is a murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus loudest?	A murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus is loudest at S2.
Just before which heart sound is a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse loudest?	A murmur due to mitral valve prolapse is loudest just before S2.
What modified Wells score suggests that pulmonary embolism is likely?	A modified Wells score greater than 4 suggests that pulmonary embolism is likely.

What type of tumor is a mesenchymal tumor?	A mesenchymal tumor is a sarcoma.
What type of cells are affected by mantle cell lymphoma?	Mantle cell lymphoma is a lymphoma of B-cells.
