What is a major complication associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm and when is it more likely to occur?	A major complication associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm is rupture, especially when the aneurysm is 5 cm in diameter.

What is a mainstay of treatment for left heart failure and how does it help?	A mainstay of treatment for left heart failure is ACE inhibitors, which help counteract fluid retention and prevent heart remodeling.
What is the relationship between lung compliance and the ease of filling the lung?	A lung with low compliance is harder to fill.
What is the relationship between lung compliance and the ease of filling the lung?	A lung with high compliance is easier to fill.

What cardiac condition is associated with a prolonged QT interval?	A long QT interval predisposes to torsades de pointes.

What does a hyper-osmotic disturbance refer to?	A hyper-osmotic disturbance refers to an increase in extracellular fluid (ECF) osmolarity.

What are the clinical manifestations associated with 11β-hydroxylase deficiency?	11β-hydroxylase deficiency presents with hypokalemia and hypertension.

What is the medical condition characterized by the presence of widespread urticaria, hypotension, and wheezing?	The medical condition characterized by the presence of widespread urticaria, hypotension, and wheezing is anaphylaxis.
What is the relationship between PCP (phencyclidine), cocaine, and cannabis in milk and breast feeding?	PCP (phencyclidine), cocaine, and cannabis in milk are all contraindications to breast feeding.
What are the reversal agents for warfarin and heparin overdose, respectively?	The reversal agents for warfarin overdose are FFP and Vitamin K, while the reversal agent for heparin overdose is protamine.
What is a potential diagnosis for a child who experiences snoring with partial obstruction?	Childhood snoring with partial obstruction may be a symptom of choanal atresia.
What laboratory test, when negative or absent, can rule out the possibility of lupus?	A negative or absent result for ANA (sensitive) can rule out the possibility of lupus.
What are the characteristic symptoms of a third-degree burn?	The characteristic symptoms of a third-degree burn include lack of pain, white or charred edges, and full-thickness burn.
What is the recommended management for children under 5 years old with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) grades 1-3?	The recommended management for children under 5 years old with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) grades 1-3 is prophylactic antibiotics.
What is the recommended management for a patient with unstable angina and a positive stress test?	The recommended management for a patient with unstable angina and a positive stress test is cardiac catheterization.
What is the frontal axis indicated by a positive QRS in lead I and a positive QRS in lead II?	A positive QRS in lead I and a positive QRS in lead II indicates a normal frontal axis.
What is the recommended management for a patient with a positive PPD and negative X-ray?	The recommended management for a patient with a positive PPD and negative X-ray is INH for 9 months.
What degree of burn is indicated by the presence of pain, blistering, and partial thickness skin damage?	The presence of pain, blistering, and partial thickness skin damage indicates a 2nd degree burn.
What is the psychogenic cause of erectile dysfunction that is indicated by the presence of nocturnal erections?	The presence of nocturnal erections is indicative of a psychogenic cause of erectile dysfunction.
What type of infections are detected by a positive lactoferrin test?	A positive lactoferrin test is indicative of bacterial infections.
What medical procedure is typically recommended as a follow-up to a positive FOBT result?	A positive FOBT result typically leads to a colonoscopy.
What medical condition is suggested by a positive Coombs test?	A positive Coombs test is suggestive of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
What medical condition is suggested by a positive Carnett sign, which is characterized by pain with abdominal contraction?	A positive Carnett sign is suggestive of abdominal wall pain.
What is the prognosis for 'Triple-Negative' breast cancer, which is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu?	'Triple-Negative' breast cancer, which is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu, has a poor prognosis.
What is the leading cause of ARDS?	The leading cause of ARDS is sepsis.
How many word phrases or sentences are typically used by children between the ages of 1 and 5 years?	Children between the ages of 1 and 5 years typically use 1-5 word phrases or sentences.
What types of corneal ulcers are typically seen in a fluorescein slit lamp exam of keratoconjunctivitis caused by HSV-1?	Serpiginous and dendritic corneal ulcers are typically seen in a fluorescein slit lamp exam of keratoconjunctivitis caused by HSV-1.
What is the significance of "triphasic bursts" or "sharp wave complexes" seen on an EEG?	The presence of "triphasic bursts" or "sharp wave complexes" on an EEG is indicative of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
What is the significance of "triphasic bursts" seen on an EEG?	The presence of "triphasic bursts" on an EEG is indicative of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
What is the significance of the "thumb-sign" seen on a lateral X-ray?	The presence of "thumb-sign" on a lateral X-ray is indicative of H. influenzae epiglottitis.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of periarticular osteopenia on X-ray?	The presence of periarticular osteopenia on X-ray is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis.
What medical condition is suggested by the presence of oil cysts and foam cells on mammography?	The presence of oil cysts and foam cells on mammography is suggestive of fat necrosis.
What are the common clinical features of "Locked-in" syndrome?	"Locked-in" syndrome is characterized by quadriplegia and loss of voluntary facial, mouth, and tongue movements.
What is the typical cause of "Locked-in" syndrome?	"Locked-in" syndrome is typically caused by a stroke of the basilar artery.
What medical condition is characterized by "Leonine facies"?	"Leonine facies" are characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy, which is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae.
What is the medical term for "Broken Heart Syndrome"?	"Broken Heart Syndrome" is also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
Where in the cell are "Barr bodies" formed by lyonization typically visible?	"Barr bodies" formed by lyonization are typically visible at the periphery of the nucleus in the cell.
How would you describe the timing of abdominal pain associated with perforation?	The timing of perforation abdominal pain is typically sudden onset.
Is A part of B in a proportion of A/B?	Yes, A is part of B in a proportion of A/B.
